The Blessed One, it seems, having heard that, “Kandaraka, you say that this Order of monks is well-composed, but the reason for this Order of monks being well-composed is not clear to you. For you did not fulfil the thirty perfections, ripen the roots of welfare, and penetrate omniscient knowledge on the throne of enlightenment,

translated: the reason for these being well-composed is clear to me.” in order to show this, he began this teaching.

original: Santi hi kandarakāti ayampi pāṭiekko anusandhi. Bhagavato kira etadahosi – “ayaṃ🔽paribbājako imaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ upasantoti vadati, ayañca bhikkhusaṅgho kappetvā🔽pakappetvā kuhakabhāvena iriyāpathaṃ saṇṭhapento cittena anupasanto na upasantākāraṃ🔽dasseti. Ettha pana bhikkhusaṅghe paṭipadaṃ pūrayamānāpi paṭipadaṃ pūretvā matthakaṃ
analyzed: santi hi ayam pi ayam  paribbājakaḥ imam bhikkhu saṅgham upasantaḥ ti vadati ayam ca bhikkhu saṅghaḥ kappetvā  pakappetvā kuhaka bhāvena iriyāpatham saṇṭhapento cittena an upasantaḥ na upasanta ākāram  dasseti ettha pana bhikkhu saṅghe paṭipadam pūrayamānā api paṭipadam pūretvā matthakam
translated: “There are the Kandarakas” is another way of connecting this story.🔽The Blessed One thought, “This wanderer🔽says that this bhikkhu-sangha is quiet, but this bhikkhu-sangha, having eaten,🔽having thrown away the bowls, having washed its feet, having arranged its sitting mat, sitting down, having folded its hands, is listening to the Dhamma with a quiet mind.🔽But this wanderer, having eaten, having thrown away the bowls, having washed its feet, having arranged his sitting mat, sitting down, having folded his hands, is not quiet, he is not showing a quiet appearance.

original: patvā ṭhitabhikkhūpi atthi, tattha paṭipadaṃ pūretvā matthakaṃ pattā attanā paṭividdhaguṇeheva🔽upasantā, paṭipadaṃ pūrayamānā uparimaggassa vipassanāya upasantā, ito muttā pana🔽avasesā catūhi satipaṭṭhānehi upasantā. Taṃ nesaṃ upasantakāraṇaṃ dassessāmī”ti “iminā🔽ca iminā ca kāraṇena ayaṃ bhikkhusaṅgho upasanto”ti dassetuṃ “santi hi kandarakā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: patvā ṭhita bhikkhū api atthi tattha paṭipadam pūretvā matthakam pattā attanā paṭividdha guṇehā iva 🔽upasantā paṭipadam pūrayamānā upari maggassa vipassanāya upasantā itas muttā pana 🔽avasesā catūhi satipaṭṭhānehi upasantā tam na īsam upasanta kāraṇam dassessāmi iti iminā 🔽ca iminā ca kāraṇena ayam bhikkhu saṅghaḥ upasantaḥ ti dassetum santi hi kandaraka iti ādim āha
translated: For there are the Kandarakas, etc. The Blessed One thought: “This wanderer says that this bhikkhu Saṅgha is not tranquil. But this bhikkhu Saṅgha, having eaten and having put away its bowl and robe, is sitting with crossed legs, holding its body erect, having established mindfulness in front of it, not tranquil in appearance but showing the appearance of tranquility. But in this bhikkhu Saṅgha there are bhikkhus who have fulfilled the practice and, having fulfilled the practice, are standing at the head, tranquil by the virtue of the special qualities they have themselves discovered. There are others who are tranquil by the insight of the higher paths. But the rest are tranquil by the four foundations of mindfulness. I shall show the reason for their tranquility.” In order to show that “for this reason and for that reason this bhikkhu Saṅgha is tranquil,” he said: “For there are the Kandarakas, etc.”

original: Tattha arahanto khīṇāsavātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ mūlapariyāyasuttavaṇṇanāyameva

translated: Herein, as to the words “Arahats, whose cankers are destroyed,” etc., what is to be said has already been said in the description of the “root-conditions” .🔽The disciple’s way is also given in detail there.

original: vuttaṃ. Sekhapaṭipadampi tattheva vitthāritaṃ. Santatasīlāti satatasīlā nirantarasīlā.
analyzed: vuttam sekha paṭipadam pi tattha iva vitthāritam santata sīlā ati satata sīlā nirantara sīlā
translated: “Constant in virtue” : constant in virtue, uninterrupted in virtue.

original: Santatavuttinoti tasseva vevacanaṃ, santatajīvikā vātipi attho. Tasmiṃ santatasīle

translated: “Constant in practice” : this is a synonym for the same expression. The meaning is: “constant in livelihood.”

original: ṭhatvāva jīvikaṃ kappenti, na dussīlyaṃ maraṇaṃ pāpuṇantīti attho.

translated: Having stood in that constant virtue, they make their livelihood, they do not die in a state of moral depravity.

original: Nipakāti nepakkena samannāgatā paññavanto. Nipakavuttinoti paññāya vuttino, paññāya🔽ṭhatvā jīvikaṃ kappenti. Yathā ekacco sāsane pabbajitvāpi jīvitakāraṇā chasu agocaresu🔽carati, vesiyāgocaro hoti, vidhavathullakumārikapaṇḍakapānāgārabhikkhunigocaro hoti.
analyzed: nipakā ati nepakkena samannāgatā paññavantaḥ nipaka vuttinaḥ ti paññāya vuttinaḥ paññāya  ṭhatvā jīvikam kappenti yathā ekaccaḥ sāsane pabbajitvā api jīvita kāraṇā chasu agocaresu  carati vesiyā gocaraḥ hoti vidhava thulla kumārika paṇḍaka pānāgāra bhikkhuni gocaraḥ hoti
translated: “Skilled” : endowed with skill, wise. “Constant in practice” : constant in practice through wisdom, having stood in wisdom they make their livelihood.

original: Saṃsaṭṭho viharati rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi ananulomikena
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭhaḥ viharati rājūhi rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi ananulomikena
translated: For just as one who has gone forth in the Dispensation makes his living by the six kinds of improper search , so too some who have gone forth in the Dispensation live in association with kings, with kings’ ministers, with sectarians, with the disciples of sectarians, in a way that is not proper.

original: gihisaṃsaggena, vejjakammaṃ karoti, dūtakammaṃ karoti, pahiṇakammaṃ karoti, gaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: gihi saṃsaggena vejja kammam karoti dūta kammam karoti pahiṇa kammam karoti gaṇḍaṃ
translated: he associates with householders; he acts as a doctor; he acts as a messenger; he acts as an intermediary, arranging meetings of lovers,🔽

original: phāleti, arumakkhanaṃ deti, uddhaṃvirecanaṃ deti, adhovirecanaṃ deti, natthutelaṃ🔽pacati, pivanatelaṃ pacati, veḷudānaṃ, pattadānaṃ, pupphadānaṃ, phaladānaṃ, sinānadānaṃ,🔽dantakaṭṭhadānaṃ, mukhodakadānaṃ, cuṇṇamattikadānaṃ deti, cāṭukamyaṃ karoti, muggasūpiyaṃ,
analyzed: arumakkhanam deti uddhaṃvirecanam deti adhovirecanam deti natthu telam  pacati pivana telam pacati veḷu dānam patta dānam puppha dānam phala dānam sināna dānam  danta kaṭṭha dānam mukha udaka dānam cuṇṇa mattika dānam deti cāṭu kamyam karoti muggasūpiyam
translated: He lives by one of the twenty-one kinds of wrong livelihood, namely, by scheming, by hinting, by belittling, by undervaluing, by overvaluing, by giving, by allowing, by pretending, by a pretended question, by a pretended consultation, by a pretended expression of approval, by seeking a favour in return for a previous favour, by flattery, by hinting, by ornamentation, by divination, by the roundabout way, by a pretended display of wonders, by the main road, by the roundabout way.

original: pāribhaṭuṃ, jaṅghapesaniyaṃ karotīti ekavīsatividhāya anesanāya jīvikaṃ kappento
analyzed: pāribhaṭum jaṅghapesaniyam karoti iti ekavīsati vidhāya an esanāya jīvikam kappentaḥ
translated: He lives by one of the twenty-one kinds of wrong livelihood, namely, by scheming, by hinting, by belittling, by undervaluing, by overvaluing, by giving, by allowing, by pretending, by a pretended question, by a pretended consultation, by a pretended expression of approval, by seeking a favour in return for a previous favour, by flattery, by hinting, by ornamentation, by divination, by the roundabout way, by a pretended display of wonders, by the main road, by the roundabout way.

original: anipakavutti nāma hoti, na paññāya ṭhatvā jīvikaṃ kappeti, tato kālakiriyaṃ katvā
analyzed: anipaka vutti nāma hoti na paññāya ṭhatvā jīvikam kappeti tatas kālakiriyam katvā
translated: He does not live by depending on his wisdom. After his death

original: samaṇayakkho nāma hutvā “tassa saṅghāṭipi ādittā hoti sampajjalitā”ti vuttanayena
analyzed: samaṇayakkhaḥ nāma hutvā tassa saṅghāṭipi ādittā hoti sampajjalitā ati vutta nayena
translated: he becomes a yakkha of the ascetics, and he experiences great suffering in the way described thus: “His outer robe is ablaze, blazing and afire … ”

original: mahādukkhaṃ anubhoti. Evaṃvidhā ahutvā jīvitahetupi sikkhāpadaṃ anatikkamanto catupārisuddhisīle
analyzed: mahā dukkham anubhoti evaṃvidhāḥ a hutvā sikkhāpadam an atikkamanto catu pārisuddhi sīle
translated: Without being such, and not transgressing the training precepts even for the sake of his life, he keeps the virtue consisting in the fourfold purity of the schoo1

original: patiṭṭhāya yathābalaṃ buddhavacanaṃ uggaṇhitvā rathavinītapaṭipadaṃ, mahāgosiṅgapaṭipadaṃ,
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya yathābalam buddha vacanam uggaṇhitvā rathavinīta paṭipadam mahāgosiṅga paṭipadam
translated: Having established themselves thus, they learned the Buddha’s word according to their ability, and they fulfilled the Noble Paths, namely, the path of the chariot-maker, the path of the great man of Gosiṅga,

original: mahāsuññatapaṭipadaṃ, anaṅgaṇapaṭipadaṃ, dhammadāyādapaṭipadaṃ, nālakapaṭipadaṃ,🔽tuvaṭṭakapaṭipadaṃ, candopamapaṭipadanti imāni ariyapaṭipadāni pūrento catupaccaya-santosa-bhāvanārāma-ariyavaṃsapaṭipattiyaṃ
analyzed: mahāsuññata paṭipadam anaṅgaṇa paṭipadam dhamma dāyāda paṭipadam nālaka paṭipadam  tuvaṭṭaka paṭipadam candopama paṭipadanti imāni ariya paṭipadāni pūrento catu paccaya santosa bhāvanā ārāma ariya vaṃsa paṭipattiyam
translated: the path of the great void, the path of the man without attachments, the path of the heir to the Dhamma, the path of the reed,🔽the path of the circle, and the path that is like the moon.🔽They were content with the four requisites, they delighted in meditation, and they followed the Noble Lineage.

original: kāyasakkhino hutvā anīkā nikkhantahatthī viya yūthā vissaṭṭhasīho viya nipacchābandhamahānāvā
analyzed: kāya sakkhinaḥ hutvā anīkā nikkhanta hatthī viya yūthā vissaṭṭha sīhaḥ viya nipacchābandha mahā nāvā
translated: They were physically strong, like elephants that have left the herd, like a lion that has left the pack, like a great ship that has broken its moorings,

original: viya ca gamanādīsu ekavihārino vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā ajjaajjeva arahattanti pavattaussāhā viharantīti attho.
analyzed: ca gamana ādīsu ekavihārinaḥ vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā ajja ajja iva arahattam ti pavatta ossāhāḥ viharanti iti attho
translated: and like those who live alone in a solitary place. They were intent on insight, and they lived with the determination “Today we will reach Arahantship.”

original: Suppatiṭṭhitacittāti catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suṭṭhapitacittā hutvā. Sesā satipaṭṭhānakathā
analyzed: suppatiṭṭhita cittā ti catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu su ṭhapita cittā hutvā sesā sati paṭṭhāna kathā
translated: They had well-established minds, that is, they had established their minds well in the four foundations of mindfulness. The rest of the sutta is self-explanatory.

original: heṭṭhā vitthāritāva. Idha pana lokiyalokuttaramissakā satipaṭṭhānā kathitā, ettakena
analyzed: heṭṭhā idha pana lokiya lokuttara missakā sati paṭṭhānā kathitā ettakena
translated: Here the foundations of mindfulness are taught as a mixture of mundane and supramundane.

original: bhikkhusaṅghassa upasantakāraṇaṃ kathitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghassa upasanta kāraṇam kathitam hoti
translated: The reason for the peacefulness of the Community of Bhikkhus is stated.

original: 3. Yāva supaññattāti yāva suṭṭhapitā sudesitā. Mayampi hi, bhanteti iminā esa attano🔽kārakabhāvaṃ dasseti, bhikkhusaṅghañca ukkhipati. Ayañhettha adhippāyo, mayampi hi,
analyzed: yāva su paññattā ati yāva su ṭṭhapitā su desitā mayam pi hi bhante ti iminā esa attanaḥ  kāraka bhāvam dasseti bhikkhu saṅghañca ukkhipati ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ mayam pi hi
translated: As long as it is well proclaimed: as long as it is well laid down, well taught. For we too, venerable sir: by this he shows his own helpfulness,🔽and he extols the Community of Bhikkhus. This is the purport here: for we too, venerable sir, are householders … and we live with a mind that is confident,

original: bhante, gihi…pe… suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharāma, bhikkhusaṅghassa pana ayameva kasi
analyzed: bhante gihipe su patiṭṭhita cittāḥ viharāma bhikkhu saṅghassa pana ayam eva kasi
translated: but for the Community of Bhikkhus this is the means of support,

original: ca bījañca yuganaṅgalañca phālapācanañca, tasmā bhikkhusaṅgho sabbakālaṃ satipaṭṭhānaparāyaṇo,
analyzed: ca bījam ca yuga naṅgalañca phāla pācanañca tasmā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ sabbakālam sati paṭṭhāna parāyaṇaḥ
translated: and the seed, and the plough and yoke, and the threshing-floor and oven. Consequently the Community of Bhikkhus is devoted to the Arousings of Mindfulness all the time,

original: mayaṃ pana kālena kālaṃ okāsaṃ labhitvā etaṃ manasikāraṃ karoma, mayampi kārakā,
analyzed: mayam pana kālena kālam okāsam labhitvā etam manasikāram karoma kārakā
translated: but we only get the opportunity to do this attention from time to time, and so we are helpful too,

original: na sabbaso vissaṭṭhakammaṭṭhānāyevāti. Manussagahaneti manussānaṃ ajjhāsayagahanena
analyzed: na sabbasas vissaṭṭha kammaṭṭhānāya iva ati manussa gahane ti manussānam ajjhāsaya gahanena
translated: and we are not entirely without a meditation subject. In the human world: the state of being crowded is owing to the crowdedness of human beings’ intentions,

original: gahanatā, ajjhāsayassāpi nesaṃ kilesagahanena gahanatā veditabbā. Kasaṭasāṭheyyesupi
analyzed: gahana tā ajjhāsayassa api na isam kilesa gahanena gahana tā veditabbā kasaṭa sāṭheyyesu pi
translated: and the crowdedness of their intentions should be understood as owing to the crowdedness of their defilements. In the case of the rubbish-heap ascetic,

original: eseva nayo. Tattha aparisuddhaṭṭhena kasaṭatā, kerāṭiyaṭṭhena sāṭheyyatā veditabbā.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tattha aparisuddha ṭṭhena kasaṭa tā kerāṭiya ṭṭhena sāṭheyya tā veditabbā
translated: and so on. Here, the state of being dusty should be understood as the state of impurity, and the state of being a cheat as the state of being a swindler.

original: Sattānaṃ hitāhitaṃ jānātīti evaṃ gahanakasaṭakerāṭiyānaṃ manussānaṃ hitāhitapaṭipadaṃ🔽yāva suṭṭhu bhagavā jānāti. Yadidaṃ pasavoti ettha sabbāpi catuppadajāti pasavoti
analyzed: sattānam hita ahitam jānāti iti evam gahanaka saṭakerāṭiyānam manussānam hita ahita paṭipadam  yāva suṭṭhu bhagavā jānāti yat idam pasavo ti ettha sabbā api catuppada jāti pasavo ti
translated: and so on. Here, the state of being a cheat should be understood as the state of being impure, and the state of being a swindler as the state of being a cheat.🔽The Blessed One knows very well the way of practice that is beneficial and not beneficial to people who are cheats, swindlers, and frauds.

original: adhippetā. Pahomīti sakkomi. Yāvatakena antarenāti yattakena khaṇena. Campaṃ gatāgataṃ
analyzed: adhippetā pahomi iti sakkomi yāvatakena antarena ati yattakena khaṇena campam gatāgatam
translated: As to what is meant by “he breeds” here, all four-footed animals are intended.🔽“I can” : I am able.

original: karissatīti assamaṇḍalato yāva campānagaradvārā gamanañca āgamanañca karissati. Sāṭheyyānīti
analyzed: karissati iti assa maṇḍalataḥ yāva campā nagara dvārā gamanañca āgamanañca karissati sāṭheyyāni iti
translated: “In the time it takes to go from here to Campā and back again” : in the time it takes to go from the deer park to the city gate of Campā and return.🔽“His swindles” : his deceptions.🔽“His frauds” : his frauds.

original: saṭhattāni. Kūṭeyyānīti kūṭattāni. Vaṅkeyyānīti vaṅkattāni. Jimheyyānīti jimhattāni.
analyzed: saṭhattāni kūṭeyyāni iti kūṭattāni vaṅkeyyāni iti vaṅkattāni jimheyyāni iti jimhattāni
translated: “His crookedness” : his crookedness.🔽“His deviousness” : his deviousness.

original: Pātukarissatīti pakāsessati dassessati. Na hi sakkā tena tāni ettakena antarena dassetuṃ.
analyzed: pātukarissati iti pakāsessati dassessati na hi sakkā tena tāni ettakena antarena dassetuṃ
translated: “He will show” : he will reveal, he will demonstrate. For it is not possible to demonstrate them in that short a time.

original: Tattha yassa kismiñcideva ṭhāne ṭhātukāmassa sato yaṃ ṭhānaṃ manussānaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ,
analyzed: tattha yassa kismiṃcid eva ṭhāne ṭhātu kāmassa sataḥ yam ṭhānam manussānam sa paṭibhayam
translated: Here, when someone wants to go somewhere, if the place is dangerous for people,

original: purato gantvā vañcetvā ṭhassāmīti na hoti, tasmiṃ ṭhātukāmaṭṭhāneyeva nikhātatthambho🔽viya cattāro pāde niccale katvā tiṭṭhati, ayaṃ saṭho nāma. Yassa pana kismiñcideva🔽ṭhāne avacchinditvā khandhagataṃ pātetukāmassa sato yaṃ ṭhānaṃ manussānaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ,🔽purato gantvā vañcetvā pātessāmīti na hoti, tattheva avacchinditvā pāteti, ayaṃ kūṭo🔽nāma. Yassa kismiñcideva ṭhāne maggā ukkamma nivattitvā paṭimaggaṃ ārohitukāmassa🔽sato yaṃ ṭhānaṃ manussānaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ, purato gantvā vañcetvā evaṃ karissāmīti🔽na hoti, tattheva maggā ukkamma nivattitvā paṭimaggaṃ ārohati, ayaṃ vaṅko nāma. Yassa
analyzed: puratas gantvā vañcetvā ṭhassāmi iti na hoti tasmin ṭhātu kāma ṭṭhāneya iva nikhāta tthambho  cattāro pāde niccale katvā tiṭṭhati ayam saṭhaḥ nāma yassa pana kismiñcid eva  ṭhāne avacchinditvā khandha gatam pātetu kāmassa sataḥ yam ṭhānam manussānam sa paṭibhayam  puratas gantvā vañcetvā pātessāmi iti na hoti tattha iva avacchinditvā pāta iti ayam kūṭaḥ  nāma yassa kismiṃcid eva ṭhāne maggāḥ ukkamma nivattitvā paṭimaggam ārohitu kāmassa  sataḥ yam ṭhānam manussānam sa paṭibhayam puratas gantvā vañcetvā evam karissāmi iti  na hoti tattha iva maggā ukkamma nivattitvā paṭimaggam ārohati ayam vaṅkaḥ nāma yassa
translated: He does not think, “I will go in front and deceive them and then stand in the place where I want to stand.” He stands still as if he were a pillar that has been dug into the ground. This is called deceit.🔽But when someone has decided on some place and thinks, “I will throw down my burden there,” he does not think, “I will go in front and deceive them and then throw it down.” He throws it down right there. This is called fraud.🔽But when someone has decided on some place and thinks, “I will turn back from this place and go back by the same way I came,” he does not think, “I will go in front and deceive them and then do this.” He turns back from that place and goes back by the same way he came. This is called crookedness.🔽

original: pana kālena vāmato kālena dakkhiṇato kālena ujumaggeneva gantukāmassa sato yaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana kālena vāmatas kālena dakkhiṇatas kālena uju maggena iva gantu kāmassa sataḥ yam ṭhānam
translated: He does not think, “I shall go in front and deceive them and then stand in the place where I want to stand.” He stands still as if he were a pillar driven in. This is called deceit. But when one who wants to jump down from somewhere after making a spring does not think, “I shall go in front and deceive them and then jump down in the place where I want to jump down,” but jumps down there and then, this is called fraud. When one who wants to turn off the path and go back and get on to the right path again does not think, “I shall go in front and deceive them and do this,” but turns off the path and goes back and gets on to the right path again there and then, this is called crookedness. But when one who wants to go sometimes by the left, sometimes by the right, sometimes straight on does not think, “I shall go in front and deceive them and do this,” but goes sometimes by the left, sometimes by the right, sometimes straight on, this is called wriggling.

original: manussānaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ, purato gantvā vañcetvā evaṃ karissāmīti na hoti, tattheva
analyzed: manussānam sa paṭibhayam puratas gantvā vañcetvā evam karissāmi iti na hoti tattha eva
translated: He does not think, “I will deceive them by going in front and then turning off in some other direction,”

original: kālena vāmato kālena dakkhiṇato kālena ujumaggaṃ gacchati, tathā laṇḍaṃ vā passāvaṃ🔽vā vissajjetukāmassa sato idaṃ ṭhānaṃ susammaṭṭhaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ, imasmiṃ
analyzed: kālena vāmatas kālena dakkhiṇatas kālena uju maggam gacchati tathā laṇḍam vā passāvam  vā vissajjetu kāmassa sataḥ idam ṭhānam su sammaṭṭham ākiṇṇa manussam ramaṇīyam imasmin
translated: but he goes to the left or to the right or along the straight path at the proper time. Likewise, when he wants to defecate or urinate,

original: ṭhāne evarūpaṃ kātuṃ na yuttaṃ, purato gantvā paṭicchannaṭhāne karissāmīti na hoti,
analyzed: ṭhāne evarūpam kātum na yuttam puratas gantvā paṭicchanna ṭhāne karissāmi iti na hoti
translated: he does not think, “This place is well swept and crowded with people. It is not proper to do this here. I will go in front and do it in a concealed place,”

original: tattheva karoti, ayaṃ jimho nāma. Iti imaṃ catubbidhampi kiriyaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha iva karoti ayam jimhaḥ nāma iti imam catubbidham pi kiriyam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: but he does it right there. This is called crookedness. The text is stated with reference to these four kinds of action.

original: Sabbāni tāni sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni vaṅkeyyāni jimheyyāni pātukarissatīti evaṃ karontāpi
analyzed: sabbāni tāni sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni vaṅkeyyāni jimheyyāni pātukarissati iti evam karontā api
translated: All these crookednesses, hypocrisies, inflections, and crookednesses will manifest themselves. Even though they act thus,

original: te saṭhādayo tāni sāṭheyyādīni pātukaronti nāma.
analyzed: te tāni sāṭheyī ādīni pātukaronti nāma
translated: they manifest these crookednesses, etc.

original: Evaṃ pasūnaṃ uttānabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni manussānaṃ gahanabhāvaṃ dassento amhākaṃ
analyzed: evam pasūnam uttāna bhāvam dassetvā idāni manussānam gahana bhāvam dassentaḥ amhākam
translated: Having thus shown the exposedness of animals, he now shows the hiddenness of human beings:

original: pana, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha dāsāti antojātakā vā dhanakkītā vā karamarānītā vā
analyzed: pana bhante ti ādim āha tattha dāsā ti antojātakāḥ vā dhanakkītāḥ vā karamara ānītāḥ vā
translated: or they may have become slaves through debt or through fear or through sickness.🔽They are called “slaves” because they are owned by another, because they are not free, because they are subject to the will of another, because they are not independent, because they are not their own masters, because they are not free to go where they want, because they are not free to stay where they want.🔽They are called “servants” because they serve, because they are at the disposal of another, because they are not at their own disposal.🔽They are called “workmen” because they work for wages.🔽They are called “hired people” because they are employed for a stipulated wage.🔽They are called “day-labourers” because they work for a stipulated wage for a day.

original: sayaṃ vā dāsabyaṃ upagatā. Pessāti pesanakārakā. Kammakarāti bhattavetanabhatā. Aññathāva
analyzed: sayam vā dāsabyam upagatā pessā ati pesana kārakā kamma karā ati bhatta vetana bhatā aññathā va
translated: They are called “dependents” because they are dependent on another.🔽They are called “followers” because they follow another.🔽They are called “attendants” because they attend on another.🔽They are called “retainers” because they are kept by another.🔽They are called “companions” because they are companions of another.🔽They are called “associates” because they are associated with another.🔽They are called “subordinates” because they are under another.🔽They are called “subservients” because they are subservient to another.

original: kāyenāti aññenevākārena kāyena samudācaranti, aññenevākārena vācāya, aññena ca nesaṃ🔽ākārena cittaṃ ṭhitaṃ hotīti dasseti. Tattha ye sammukhā sāmike disvā paccuggamanaṃ
analyzed: kāyena ati aññena iva ākārena kāyena samudācaranti aññena iva ākārena vācāya aññena ca nesam  ākārena cittam ṭhitam hoti iti dasseti tattha ye sammukhā sāmike disvā paccuggamanaṃ
translated: They are called “submissives” because they submit to another.🔽They are called “dependents” because they are dependent on another.🔽They are called “followers” because they follow another.🔽They are called “attendants” because they attend on another.🔽They are called “retainers” because they are kept by another.

original: karonti, hatthato bhaṇḍakaṃ gaṇhanti, imaṃ vissajjetvā imaṃ gaṇhantā sesānipi āsana-paññāpana-tālavaṇṭabījana-pādadhovanādīni🔽sabbāni kiccāni karonti, parammukhakāle pana telampi uttarantaṃ na olokenti, satagghanakepi
analyzed: karonti hatthataḥ bhaṇḍakam gaṇhanti imam vissajjetvā imam gaṇhantā sesāni pi āsana paññāpana tāla vaṇṭa bījana pāda dhovana ādīni  sabbāni kiccāni karonti parammukha kāle pana telam pi uttarantam na olokenti
translated: They are called “companions” because they are companions of another.🔽They are called “associates” because they are associated with another.🔽They are called “subordinates” because they are under another.🔽They are called “subservients” because they are subservient to another.

original: sahassagghanakepi kamme parihāyante nivattitvā oloketumpi na icchanti, ime aññathā
analyzed: kamme parihāyante nivattitvā oloketum pi na icchanti ime aññathā
translated: They are called “submissives” because they submit to another.

original: kāyena samudācaranti nāma. Ye pana sammukhā “amhākaṃ sāmi amhākaṃ ayyo”tiādīni vatvā
analyzed: kāyena samudācaranti nāma ye pana sammukhāḥ amhākam sāmi amhākam vatvā

analyzed: bhagavatā tesam tesam sattānam āsaya anusayam jānatā hattha tale ṭhapita āmalakam viya
translated: By that Blessed One, who knows the underlying tendencies and latent tendencies of all beings, who sees all knowable dhammas as clearly as a fruit held in the palm of the hand,

original: sabbaṃ ñeyyadhammaṃ passatā. Apica pubbenivāsādīhi jānatā, dibbena cakkhunā passatā,
analyzed: sabbam ñeyya dhammam passatā apica pubbenivāsa ādīhi jānatā dibbena cakkhunā passatā
translated: who knows by means of the knowledge of recollection of past lives, etc., and sees by means of the divine eye,

original: tīhi vijjāhi chahi vā pana abhiññāhi jānatā, sabbattha appaṭihatena samantacakkhunā🔽passatā, sabbadhammajānanasamatthāya paññāya jānatā, sabbasattānaṃ cakkhuvisayātītāni
analyzed: tīhi vijjāhi chahi vā pana abhiññāhi jānatā sabbattha a paṭihatena samanta cakkhunā  passatā sabba dhamma jānana samatthāya paññāya jānatā sabba sattānam cakkhu visaya atītāni
translated: who knows by means of the three knowledges or the six kinds of direct knowledge, and sees by means of the unobstructed eye that extends everywhere,

original: tirokuṭṭādigatānipi rūpāni ativisuddhena maṃsacakkhunā passatā, attahitasādhikāya
analyzed: tiro kuṭṭa ādi gatāni api rūpāni ati visuddhena maṃsa cakkhunā passatā atta hita sādhikāya
translated: who knows by means of the wisdom that is capable of knowing all dhammas, and sees by means of the purified fleshly eye all visible forms, even those behind walls and so forth, which are beyond the range of vision of ordinary men,🔽who knows by means of the wisdom that accomplishes his own welfare,

original: samādhipadaṭṭhānāya paṭivedhapaññāya jānatā, parahitasādhikāya karuṇāpadaṭṭhānāya🔽desanāpaññāya passatā, arīnaṃ hatattā paccayādīnañca arahattā arahatā, sammā sāmañca🔽saccānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddhena. Antarāyikadhamme vā jānatā, niyyānikadhamme
analyzed: samādhi pada ṭṭhānāya paṭivedha paññāya jānatā para hita sādhikāya karuṇā pada ṭṭhānāya  desanā paññāya passatā arīnam hatattā paccaya ādīnam ca arahattā arahatā sammā sāmañca  saccānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhena antarāyika dhamme vā jānatā niyyānika dhamme
translated: He sees with the understanding of teaching, which has compassion as its footing, since this is the footing for the benefit of others.🔽He is an Arahant because he has slain the foes, that is, the taints, and because he has reached the worthiness of the Alms-food offered to him by others by the destruction of the conditions for being a bad vessel, and so on. He is a Fully Enlightened One because he has found out all things by himself.

original: passatā, kilesārīnaṃ hatattā arahatā, sāmaṃ sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddhenāti
analyzed: passatā kilesa arīnam hata ttā arahatā sāmam sabba dhammānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhena ati
translated: Or alternatively, he is an Arahant because he knows the states that obstruct the path and because he sees the states that lead to it, and because he has slain the foes, that is, the defilements, and he is a Fully Enlightened One because he has found out all things by himself.🔽Thus he is praised for four reasons, namely, for the four kinds of perfect confidence.

original: evaṃ catuvesārajjavasena catūhi kāraṇehi thomitena. Atthi nu kho eko dhammo akkhātoti.
analyzed: evam catu vesārajja vasena catūhi kāraṇehi thomitena atthi nu kho ekaḥ dhammo akkhāto ti
translated: “Is there any one thing taught by the Blessed One, venerable sir, under which all good states are included? ”

original: 19. Abhisaṅkhatanti kataṃ uppāditaṃ. Abhisañcetayitanti cetayitaṃ pakappitaṃ. So
analyzed: katam uppāditam abhisañcetayitanti cetayitam pakappitam
translated: “‘Conditioned’: made, produced. ‘Conditioned by that’: willed, planned.

original: tattha ṭhitoti so tasmiṃ samathavipassanādhamme ṭhito. Dhammarāgena dhammanandiyāti
analyzed: tattha ṭhitaḥ ti saḥ tasmin samatha vipassanā dhamme ṭhitaḥ dhamma rāgena dhamma nandiyā ati
translated: ‘Standing on that’: standing on that state of serenity and insight. ‘With lust for things of mental nature, with delight in things of mental nature’:🔽these two terms, ‘lust for things of mental nature’ and ‘delight in things of mental nature,’ refer to desire and lust for serenity and insight.

original: padadvayehi samathavipassanāsu chandarāgo vutto. Samathavipassanāsu hi sabbena sabbaṃ
analyzed: pada dvayehi samatha vipassanāsu chanda rāgaḥ vuttaḥ samatha vipassanāsu hi sabbena sabbam
translated: For in serenity and insight all desire and lust for the five cords of sense desire are abandoned in every way.

original: chandarāgaṃ pariyādiyituṃ sakkonto arahā hoti, asakkonto anāgāmī hoti. So samathavipassanāsu
analyzed: chanda rāgam pariyādiyitum sakkontaḥ arahā hoti a sakkontaḥ anāgāmī hoti so samatha vipassanāsu
translated: and if he is able to abandon desire and lust for it he becomes an Arahant, and if he is unable he becomes a Non-returner. He is reborn in the Pure Abodes by the volition of the fourth jhāna,

original: chandarāgassa appahīnattā catutthajjhānacetanāya suddhāvāse nibbattati, ayaṃ ācariyānaṃ samānakathā.
analyzed: chanda rāgassa appahīna ttā catuttha jhāna cetanāya suddhāvāse nibbattati ayam ācariyānam samāna kathā
translated: because he has not abandoned desire and lust for the jhāna. This is the teachers’ agreed statement.

original: Vitaṇḍavādī panāha “teneva dhammarāgenāti vacanato akusalena suddhāvāse nibbattatī”ti🔽so “suttaṃ āharā”ti vattabbo, addhā aññaṃ apassanto idameva āharissati, tato vattabbo
analyzed: vitaṇḍa vādī pana āha tena iva dhamma rāgena ati vacanataḥ akusalena suddhāvāse nibbattati iti  so suttam āharāti vattabbaḥ addhā aññam a passantaḥ idam eva āharissati tatas vattabbaḥ
translated: But the one who argues from the words ‘by that same lust for the Dhamma’ says that he is reborn in the Pure Abodes by the unprofitable resultant rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: “kiṃ panidaṃ suttaṃ neyyatthaṃ nītattha”nti, addhā nītatthanti vakkhati. Tato vattabbo
analyzed: kim panidam suttam neyyattham nīta atthanti addhā nīta atthanti vakkhati tatas vattabbo
translated: He should be asked, ‘What is the sutta that you are relying on?’—for he will certainly quote this one. Then he should be asked, ‘But is the meaning of this sutta plain or recondite?’—for he will certainly say, ‘Recondite.’ Then he should be told:

original: – evaṃ sante anāgāmiphalatthikena samathavipassanāsu chandarāgo kattabbo bhavissati,
analyzed: evam sante anāgāmi phala tthikena samatha vipassanāsu chanda rāgaḥ kattabbaḥ bhavissati
translated: ‘If that is so, then anyone who wants the fruit of non-return must arouse desire and lust for the serenity and insight,

original: chandarāge uppādite anāgāmiphalaṃ paṭividdhaṃ bhavissati “mā suttaṃ me laddha”nti
analyzed: chanda rāge uppādite anāgāmi phalam paṭividdham bhavissati mā suttam me laddhanti
translated: and when desire and lust are aroused the fruit of non-return will be penetrated. But you must not quote this sutta to me as a reason.’

original: yaṃ vā taṃ vā dīpehi. Pañhaṃ kathentena hi ācariyassa santike uggahetvā attharasaṃ
analyzed: yam vā tam vā dīpehi pañham kathentena hi ācariyassa santike uggahetvā attha rasam
translated: Or he should point out whatever he has seen. For when he is answering a question, he is allowed to answer it after learning it from his teacher.

original: paṭivijjhitvā kathetuṃ vaṭṭati, akusalena hi sagge, kusalena vā apāye paṭisandhi
analyzed: paṭivijjhitvā kathetum vaṭṭati akusalena hi sagge kusalena vā apāye paṭisandhi
translated: For there is no rebirth-linking by unwholesome consciousness in the heavenly world, nor by wholesome consciousness in an unhappy destination.

original: nāma natthi. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: nāma na atthi vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Na, bhikkhave, lobhajena kammena dosajena kammena mohajena kammena devā paññāyanti,
analyzed: na bhikkhave lobha jena kammena dosa jena kammena moha jena kammena devā paññāyanti
translated: “Bhikkhus, it is not by reason of the performance of an act of greed, hatred, or delusion that gods are declared,

original: manussā paññāyanti, yā vā panaññāpi kāci sugatiyo, atha kho, bhikkhave, lobhajena
analyzed: manussā paññāyanti yā vā pana aññā api kāci sugatiyaḥ atha kho bhikkhave lobha jena
translated: humans are declared, or any other happy destination is declared.

original: kammena dosajena kammena mohajena kammena nirayo paññāyati, tiracchānayoni paññāyati,
analyzed: kammena dosa jena kammena moha jena kammena nirayaḥ paññāyati tiracchāna yoni paññāyati
translated: But it is by reason of the performance of an act of non-greed, non-hatred, non-delusion that hell is declared, the animal realm is declared,

original: pettivisayo paññāyati, yā vā panaññāpi kāci duggatiyo”ti –
analyzed: petti visayo paññāyati yā vā panaññā api kāci duggatiyā ti
translated: the realm of ghosts is declared, or any other unhappy destination is declared” .

original: Evaṃ paññāpetabbo. Sace sañjānāti sañjānātu, no ce sañjānāti, “gaccha pātova vihāraṃ pavisitvā yāguṃ pivāhī”ti uyyojetabbo.
analyzed: evam paññāpetabbo sace sañjānāti sañjānātu no ce sañjānāti gaccha pātova vihāram pavisitvā yāgum pivāhi iti uyyojetabbo
translated: This is how he should point out. If the other understands, let him understand. If not, he should be dismissed with the words, “Go in the morning to the monastery and drink rice porridge.”

original: Yathā ca pana imasmiṃ sutte, evaṃ mahāmālukyovādepi mahāsatipaṭṭhānepi kāyagatāsatisuttepi
analyzed: yathā ca pana imasmim sutte evam mahāmālukya uvāde pi mahāsatipaṭṭhāne pi kāyagata asati sutte pi
translated: And just as in this sutta, so also in the Mahāmāluṅkyavibhanga, the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna, and the Kāyagatāsati Suttas,

original: samathavipassanā kathitā. Tattha imasmiṃ sutte samathavasena gacchatopi vipassanāvasena
analyzed: samatha vipassanā kathitā tattha imasmin sutte samatha vasena gacchataḥ api vipassanā vasena
translated: concentration and insight are taught. Therein, in this sutta, whether one goes by way of concentration or by way of insight,

original: gacchatopi samathadhurameva dhuraṃ, mahāmālukyovāde vipassanāva dhuraṃ, mahāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: gacchataḥ api samatha dhuram eva dhuram mahā mālukya uvāde dhuram mahā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: the burden of concentration is the burden. In the Mahāmāluṅkyavibhanga, insight is the burden. In the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna,

original: pana vipassanuttaraṃ nāma kathitaṃ, kāyagatāsatisuttaṃ samathuttaranti.
analyzed: pana vipassanuttaram nāma kathitam kāyagata asati suttam samathuttaranti
translated: it is said that insight is the burden. In the Kāyagatāsati Sutta, concentration is the burden.

original: Ayaṃ kho gahapati…pe… ekadhammo akkhātoti ekadhammaṃ pucchitena ayampi ekadhammoti
analyzed: ayam kho gahapatipe eka dhammo akkhāto ti eka dhammam pucchitena ayam pi eka dhammo ti
translated: “This one thing, householder, is well expounded by the Exalted One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened … “🔽When he was asked about one thing, he answered with another, saying, “This one thing is well expounded by the Exalted One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened.”

original: evaṃ pucchāvasena kathitattā ekādasapi dhammā ekadhammo nāma jāto. Mahāsakuludāyisuttasmiñhi
analyzed: evam pucchā vasena kathita ttā ekādasa api dhammā ekadhammaḥ nāma jātaḥ mahā sakuludāyi suttasmin hi
translated: Thus, although eleven things were mentioned, they are called “one thing.” In the Mahāsakuludāyisutta,

original: ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadāvasena ekadhammo nāma jātāni, idha ekādasapucchāvasena
analyzed: ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadā vasena eka dhammaḥ nāma jātāni idha ekādasa pucchā vasena
translated: nineteen things are called “one thing” in the sense of the way of practice. Here, they are called “one thing” in the sense of the question.

original: ekadhammoti āgatāni. Amatuppattiyatthena vā sabbānipi ekadhammoti vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: eka dhammo ti āgatāni amata uppattiya tthena vā sabbāni pi eka dhammo ti vattum vaṭṭati
translated: Or, all of them can be called “one thing” in the sense of the attainment of the deathless.

original: 21. Nidhimukhaṃ gavesantoti nidhiṃ pariyesanto. Sakidevāti ekapayogena. Kathaṃ pana🔽ekapayogeneva ekādasannaṃ nidhīnaṃ adhigamo hotīti. Idhekacco araññe nidhiṃ gavesamāno🔽carati, tamenaṃ aññataro atthacarako disvā “kiṃ bho carasī”ti pucchati. So “jīvitavuttiṃ🔽pariyesāmī”ti āha. Itaro “tena hi samma āgaccha, etaṃ pāsāṇaṃ pavattehī”ti āha. So
analyzed: nidhi mukham gavesantaḥ iti nidhim pariyesantaḥ sakid eva iti eka payogena katham pana  eka payogena iva ekādasannam nidhīnam adhigamaḥ hoti iti idha ekaccaḥ araññe nidhim gavesamāno  carati tam enam aññataraḥ attha carakaḥ disvā kim bho carasi iti pucchati saḥ jīvita vuttim  pariyesāmi iti āha itaraḥ tena hi samme āgaccha etam pāsāṇam pavattehi iti āha saḥ
translated: Seeking for a treasure store means seeking for a treasure. At one time means by one means. But how is it that the discovery of the eleven treasures is by one means? Here someone is wandering about seeking for a treasure in the forest. Another man who is a treasure-seeker sees him and asks him, “What are you doing?” He replies, “I am seeking a means of livelihood.” The other says, “Well then, come along, turn over this stone.”

original: taṃ pavattetvā uparūpari ṭhapitā vā kucchiyā kucchiṃ āhacca ṭhitā vā ekādasa kumbhiyo🔽passeyya, evaṃ ekapayogena ekādasannaṃ nidhīnaṃ adhigamo hoti.🔽Ācariyadhanaṃ pariyesissantīti aññatitthiyā hi yassa santike sippaṃ uggaṇhanti, tassa
analyzed: tam pavattetvā upari upari ṭhapitāḥ vā kucchiyā kucchim āhacca ṭhitāḥ vā ekādasa kumbhiyaḥ  passeyya evam eka payogena ekādasannam nidhīnam adhigamaḥ hoti  ācariya dhanam pariyesissanti iti añña titthiyāḥ hi yassa santike sippam uggaṇhanti tassa
translated: Seeking a treasure store means seeking a treasure. At one time means by one means. But how does the acquisition of the eleven treasures come about by one means? Here someone is wandering in the forest seeking a treasure. Another man, a treasure-seeker, sees him and asks, “What are you doing, sir?” He replies, “I am seeking a means of livelihood.” The other says, “In that case, come along, sir, and turn over this rock.” He turns it over and sees eleven jars placed one above the other, either with their mouths touching or with their bellies touching. Thus the acquisition of the eleven treasures comes about by one means.

original: sippuggahaṇato pure vā pacchā vā antarantare vā gehato nīharitvā dhanaṃ denti. Yesaṃ
analyzed: sippu gahaṇataḥ pure vā pacchā vā antar antare vā gehataḥ nīharitvā dhanam denti yesam
translated: Seeking the teacher’s fee means that the adherents of other sects give a fee to the teacher from whom they learn a craft, either before or after or during the learning.

original: gehe natthi, te ñātisabhāgato pariyesanti, tathā alabhamānā bhikkhampi caritvā dentiyeva.
analyzed: gehe natthi te ñāti sabhāgataḥ pariyesanti tathā a labhamānāḥ bhikkham pi caritvā dentiyā iva
translated: If there is none in the house, they search for one among his relatives and kinsmen. If they cannot find one, they give him alms after he has gone on his alms round.

original: Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: This is what is meant.

original: Kimaṅgaṃ panāhanti bāhirakā tāva aniyyānikepi sāsane sippamattadāyakassa dhanaṃ pariyesanti;
analyzed: kim aṅgam pana ahanti bāhirakā tāva aniyyānike pi sāsane sippa matta dāyakassa dhanam pariyesanti
translated: What then of me? The outsiders, even though they are not in the Dispensation, seek wealth for one who gives them mere craft-knowledge.

original: ahaṃ pana evaṃvidhe niyyānikasāsane ekādasavidhaṃ amatuppattipaṭipadaṃ desentassa
analyzed: aham pana evaṃvidhe niyyānika sāsane ekādasavidham amata uppatti paṭipadam desentassa
translated: But I, in this Dispensation which is the means of attaining the eleven kinds of supramundane states,

original: ācariyassa pūjaṃ kiṃ na karissāmi, karissāmiyevāti vadati. Paccekadussayugena acchādesīti
analyzed: ācariyassa pūjam kim na karissāmi karissāmi iya eva ati vadati pacceka dussa yugena acchādesi iti
translated: shall I not honour my teacher who teaches the eleven kinds of supramundane states? I shall honour him.”🔽“With a pair of cloths for each recluse” means he gave a pair of cloths to each recluse.

original: ekamekassa bhikkhuno ekekaṃ dussayugamadāsīti attho. Samudācāravacanaṃ panettha evarūpaṃ
analyzed: ekam ekassa bhikkhuno ekekam dussayugam adāsi iti attho samudācāra vacanam pana ittha evarūpam
translated: But here the expression is of this kind,🔽therefore it is said “with a pair of cloths.”

original: hoti, tasmā acchādesīti vuttaṃ. Pañcasatavihāranti pañcasatagghanikaṃ paṇṇasālaṃ
analyzed: hoti tasmai acchādesi iti vuttam pañca sata vihāram pañca sata ghanikam paṇṇa sālam
translated: “A five-hundred-cell monastery” means a leaf-hut monastery worth five hundred.

original: kāresīti attho. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: kāresi iti attho sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear throughout.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya called “Papañcasūdanī”🔽is finished.

original: Aṭṭhakanāgarasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽3. Sekhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhaka nāgara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽sekha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Aṭṭhakanāgarasutta is finished.🔽The explanation of the Sekhasutta is finished.

original: 22. Evaṃ me sutanti sekhasuttaṃ. Tattha navaṃ santhāgāranti adhunā kāritaṃ santhāgāraṃ,
analyzed: evam me sutanti sekha suttam tattha navam santhāgāranti adhunā kāritam santhāgāram
translated: The Sutta on the Learner is called “Evam me sutam” . Herein, a new assembly hall is a newly built hall.

original: ekā mahāsālāti attho. Uyyogakālādīsu hi rājāno tattha ṭhatvā “ettakā purato gacchantu,
analyzed: ekā mahā sālā ati atthaḥ uyyoga kāla ādīsu hi rājānaḥ tattha ṭhatvā ettakā puratas gacchantu
translated: The meaning is a great hall. For when it is time to start work, kings stand there and give directions thus: “So many men go in front,

original: ettakā pacchā, ettakā ubhohi passehi, ettakā hatthīsu abhiruhantu, ettakā assesu,
analyzed: ettakā pacchā ettakā ubhohi passehi ettakā hatthīsu abhiruhantu ettakā assesu
translated: so many behind, so many on both sides, so many mount the elephants, so many the horses,

original: ettakā rathesu tiṭṭhantū”ti evaṃ santhaṃ karonti, mariyādaṃ bandhanti, tasmā taṃ🔽ṭhānaṃ santhāgāranti vuccati. Uyyogaṭṭhānato ca āgantvā yāva gehesu allagomayaparibhaṇḍādīni
analyzed: ettakāḥ rathesu tiṭṭhantu iti evam santham karonti mariyādam bandhanti tasmai tam  ṭhānam santhāgāranti vuccati uyyoga ṭṭhānato ca āgantvā yāva gehesu alla gomaya paribhaṇḍa ādīni
translated: so many stand in the chariots.” They make a plan and set a limit, and so that place is called “an assembly hall” .

original: karonti, tāva dve tīṇi divasāni te rājāno tattha santhambhantītipi santhāgāraṃ. Tesaṃ
analyzed: karonti dve tīṇi divasāni te rājāno tattha santhāgāram tesam
translated: And after coming from the place of work, for two or three days the kings make a plan there while they are having fresh cow dung spread on the floors of their houses, etc., and so it is also an assembly hall in this sense.

original: rājūnaṃ saha atthānusāsanaṃ agārantipi santhāgāraṃ gaṇarājāno hi te, tasmā uppannakiccaṃ
analyzed: rājūnam saha santhāgāram gaṇa rājānaḥ hi te tasmai uppanna kiccam
translated: And it is also an assembly hall because the kings make a plan there together with their advisers.

original: ekassa vasena na chijjati, sabbesaṃ chando laddhuṃ vaṭṭati, tasmā sabbe tattha sannipatitvā
analyzed: ekassa vasena na chijjati sabbesam chandaḥ laddhum vaṭṭati tasmā sabbe tattha sannipatitvā
translated: For they are kings of a multitude, and so the business that has arisen is not settled on the authority of one; the consent of all is required. So they all assemble there and make a plan.

original: anusāsanti. Tena vuttaṃ “saha atthānusāsanaṃ agārantipi santhāgāra”nti. Yasmā panete🔽tattha sannipatitvā “imasmiṃ kāle kasituṃ vaṭṭati, imasmiṃ kāle vapitu”nti evamādinā
analyzed: anusāsanti tena vuttam saha attha anusāsanam yasmā pana ete  tattha sannipatitvā imasmin kāle kasitum vaṭṭati imasmin kāle vapitum ti evamādinā
translated: They advise him. Hence it is said: “The meeting hall is where advice is given.”🔽But since they assemble there and discuss the affairs of the household life, saying, “At this time it is proper to plow,” “At this time to sow,”

original: nayena gharāvāsakiccāni sammantayanti, tasmā chiddāvachiddaṃ gharāvāsaṃ tattha santharantītipi
analyzed: nayena ghara āvāsa kiccāni sammantayanti tasmā chidda avachiddam ghara āvāsam tattha santharanti iti pi
translated: etc., the open-air pavilion is so called because they spread out there the household life with its openings and gaps.
