original: 47. Yānaṃ vā poriseyyanti purisānucchavikaṃ yānaṃ. Pavaramaṇikuṇḍalanti nānappakāraṃ uttamamaṇiñca kuṇḍalañca. Sāni harantīti attano bhaṇḍakāni gaṇhanti.
analyzed: yānam vā poriseyyanti purisa anucchavikam yānam pavara maṇi kuṇḍalanti nānappakāram uttama maṇim ca kuṇḍalam ca sāni haranti iti attanaḥ bhaṇḍakāni gaṇhanti
translated: A vehicle fit for a hero: a vehicle suitable for a man. A necklace of choice gems: a necklace of various kinds of choice gems. They would carry off: they would take his own possessions.

original: 48. Sampannaphalanti madhuraphalaṃ. Upapannaphalanti phalūpapannaṃ bahuphalaṃ.
analyzed: sampanna phalanti madhura phalam upapanna phalanti phala upapannam bahu phalam
translated: Rich in fruit: sweet-fruited. Bearing fruit: having much fruit.

original: 49. Anuttaranti uttamaṃ pabhassaraṃ nirupakkilesaṃ.
analyzed: an uttaranti uttamam pabhassaram nirupakkilesam
translated: “Unsurpassed” : supreme, bright, and free from defilement.

original: 50. Ārakā ahaṃ, bhanteti pathavito nabhaṃ viya samuddassa orimatīrato paratīraṃ viya
analyzed: ārakā aham bhante ti pathavitaḥ nabham viya samuddassa orima tīrataḥ para tīram viya
translated: “Far from it, venerable sir” : as far away as the sky from the earth, as far away as the further shore from this shore.

original: ca suvidūravidūre ahaṃ. Anājānīyeti gihivohārasamucchedanassa kāraṇaṃ ajānanake.
analyzed: ca su vidūra vidūre aham gihi vohāra samucchedanassa kāraṇam a jānanake
translated: “I did not know” : I did not know the reason for the cessation of the householder’s duties.🔽“Food that is to be eaten without knowing” : food that is to be eaten by those who do not know the reason.

original: Ājānīyabhojananti kāraṇaṃ jānantehi bhuñjitabbaṃ bhojanaṃ. Anājānīyabhojananti kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ājānīya bhojananti kāraṇam jānantehi bhuñjitabbam bhojanam an ājānīya bhojananti kāraṇam
translated: “Food that is to be eaten knowing” : food that is to be eaten by those who know the reason.

original: ajānantehi bhuñjitabbaṃ bhojanaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: a jānantehi bhuñjitabbam bhojanam sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear throughout.🔽The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya,

analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya

analyzed: potaliya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

original: 5. Jīvakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jīvaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Jīvaka Sutta

original: 51. Evaṃ me sutanti jīvakasuttaṃ. Tattha jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavaneti ettha
analyzed: evam me sutanti jīvaka suttam tattha jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane iti ettha
translated: Thus I heard. The Jīvaka Sutta. Therein, in Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove.

original: jīvatīti jīvako. Kumārena bhatoti komārabhacco. Yathāha “kiṃ etaṃ bhaṇe kākehi samparikiṇṇanti?
analyzed: jīvati iti jīvakaḥ kumārena bhatoti komārabhaccaḥ yathā āha kim etam bhaṇe kākehi
translated: Jīvaka means he lives. Komārabhacca means he is a young man’s food. As it is said: “What is this, my dear? It is surrounded by crows.”

original: Dārako devāti. Jīvati bhaṇeti? Jīvati devāti. Tena hi bhaṇe taṃ dārakaṃ amhākaṃ antepuraṃ🔽netvā dhātīnaṃ detha posetunti. Tassa jīvatīti jīvakoti nāmaṃ akaṃsu, kumārena posāpitoti🔽komārabhaccoti nāmaṃ akaṃsū”ti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārena pana jīvakavatthu
analyzed: dārakaḥ devāti jīvati bhaṇa iti jīvati devāti tena hi bhaṇe tam dārakam amhākam antepuram  netvā dhātīnam detha posetunti tassa jīvatīti jīvakaḥ iti nāmam akaṃsu kumārena posāpitoti  nāmam akaṃsu iti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārena pana jīvaka vatthu
translated: “Is the boy alive?” “He is alive, sire.” “Then, good Bhaṇṇā, take the boy to our harem and give him to the nurses to bring up.” And because he was alive they gave him the name Jīvaka, and because he was brought up by the prince they gave him the name Komārabhacca. This is the brief account. But the story in detail is as follows.

original: khandhake āgatameva. Vinicchayakathāpissa samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāya vuttā.🔽Ayaṃ pana jīvako ekasmiṃ samaye bhagavato dosābhisannaṃ kāyaṃ virecetvā sīveyyakaṃ🔽dussayugaṃ datvā vatthānumodanapariyosāne sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya cintesi – “mayā🔽divasassa dvattikkhattuṃ buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ gantabbaṃ, idañca veḷuvanaṃ atidūre, mayhaṃ
analyzed: khandhake āgatam eva vinicchaya kathā apissa samanta pāsādikāya vinaya aṭṭhakathāya vuttā  ayam pana jīvakaḥ ekasmin samaye bhagavataḥ dosa abhisannam kāyam virecetvā sīveyyakam  dussayugam da tvā vattha anumodana pariyosāne sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya cintesi mayā  divasassa dvatti khattum buddha upaṭṭhānam gantabbam idam ca veḷuvanam atidūre mayham
translated: The boy is alive, sire? ’ ‘He is alive, your majesty. ’ ‘Well then, my dear, bring that boy to our harem and give him to the nurses to rear. ’ Because he was alive, they gave him the name Jīvaka, and because he was reared by the prince, they gave him the name Komārabhacca. ’ This is the brief account. The detailed account is given in the Jīvaka Sutta in the Khandhaka. The commentary on the legal question is given in the commentary on the Vinaya, the Samantapāsādikā.

original: uyyānaṃ ambavanaṃ āsannataraṃ, yaṃnūnāhamettha bhagavato vihāraṃ kāreyya”nti. So
analyzed: uyyānam ambavanam āsannataram yat nūna aham ettha bhagavataḥ vihāram kāreyyanti saḥ
translated: Now, on one occasion, after Jīvaka had purged the Blessed One’s body, which was afflicted with dysentery, and had dressed it, he gave him a pair of cloths woven with golden thread. At the end of the expression of appreciation for the cloths, Jīvaka was established in the fruit of stream-entry. He then thought, “I have to go to wait on the Blessed One thirty-two times a day, and this Bamboo Grove is too far away. My pleasure garden, the Mango Grove, is nearer. Suppose I were to build a dwelling for the Blessed One there.”

original: tasmiṃ ambavane rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānaleṇakuṭimaṇḍapādīni sampādetvā bhagavato anucchavikaṃ
analyzed: tasmin amba vane ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāna leṇa kuṭi maṇḍapa ādīni sampādetvā bhagavataḥ anucchavikam
translated: Having had built in that Mango Grove night quarters, day quarters, caves, huts, and pavilions, etc., suitable for the Blessed One,

original: gandhakuṭiṃ kāretvā ambavanaṃ aṭṭhārasahatthubbedhena tambapaṭṭavaṇṇena pākārena🔽parikkhipāpetvā buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ cīvarabhattena santappetvā dakkhiṇodakaṃ
analyzed: gandhakuṭim kāretvā ambavanam aṭṭhārasa hatthubbedhena tamba paṭṭa vaṇṇena pākārena  parikkhipāpetvā buddha ppamukham bhikkhu saṅgham cīvara bhattena santappetvā dakkhiṇa udakam
translated: and having had the Mango Grove surrounded by a wall eighteen cubits high, the colour of copper,

analyzed: pātetvā vihāram niyyātesi tam sandhāya vuttam jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane ti
translated: and having satisfied the Community of monks with robes and meals headed by the Buddha, and having poured the water of offering, he dedicated the monastery. In reference to that it was said: “In the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca.”

original: Ārabhantīti ghātenti. Uddissakatanti uddisitvā kataṃ. Paṭiccakammanti attānaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: ārabhanti iti ghātenti uddissa katam iti uddisitvā katam paṭiccakammanti attānam paṭicca
translated: They begin: they kill. Commissioned: done on commission. On account of a request: done on account of oneself.

original: kataṃ. Atha vā paṭiccakammanti nimittakammassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, taṃ paṭicca kammamettha
analyzed: katam atha vā paṭiccakammanti nimitta kammassa etam adhivacanam tam paṭicca kammam ettha
translated: Or else, on account of a request: this is a designation for a deed done for a reason, and because there is a deed done on account of that,

analyzed: atthi iti maṃsam paṭiccakammanti vuttam hoti yaḥ evarūpam maṃsam paribhuñjati saḥ api
translated: the flesh is called “on account of a request.” It is said that he who partakes of such flesh is

original: tassa kammassa dāyādo hoti, vadhakassa viya tassāpi pāṇaghātakammaṃ hotīti tesaṃ
analyzed: tassa kammassa dāyādaḥ hoti vadhakassa viya tassa api pāṇa ghāta kammam hoti iti tesam
translated: an heir to that deed, and for him too there is the deed of killing breathing things, just as for the killer.

original: laddhi. Dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākarontīti bhagavatā vuttakāraṇassa anukāraṇaṃ kathenti.
analyzed: laddhi dhammassa ca anudhammam byākaronti iti bhagavatā vutta kāraṇassa anukāraṇam kathenti
translated: “The reason” : the reason stated by the Blessed One. “In accordance with the Dhamma” : they explain in accordance with the reason stated by the Blessed One.

original: Ettha ca kāraṇaṃ nāma tikoṭiparisuddhamacchamaṃsaparibhogo, anukāraṇaṃ nāma mahājanassa🔽tathā byākaraṇaṃ. Yasmā pana bhagavā uddissakataṃ na paribhuñjati, tasmā neva taṃ
analyzed: ettha ca kāraṇam nāma ti koṭi parisuddha maccha maṃsa paribhogaḥ anukāraṇam nāma mahājanassa  tathā byākaraṇam yasmai pana bhagavā uddissakatam na paribhuñjati tasmai na iva tam
translated: And here the reason is the consumption of unblemished meat that is completely pure in three respects. The explanation of the reason by the sectarians is the explanation in accordance with the reason.

original: kāraṇaṃ hoti, na titthiyānaṃ tathā byākaraṇaṃ anukāraṇaṃ. Sahadhammiko vādānuvādoti
analyzed: kāraṇam hoti na titthiyānam tathā byākaraṇam anukāraṇam sahadhammikaḥ vādānuvādaḥ ti
translated: But since the Blessed One does not consume meat that he has ordered to be killed, therefore that is not the reason, and the explanation of the reason by the sectarians is not the explanation in accordance with the reason.

original: parehi vuttakāraṇena sakāraṇo hutvā tumhākaṃ vādo vā anuvādo vā viññūhi garahitabbakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: parehi vutta kāraṇena sa kāraṇaḥ hutvā tumhākam vādaḥ vā anuvādaḥ vā viññūhi garahitabba kāraṇam
translated: “A reasoned reply” : a reply that is reasoned by means of the reason stated by others.🔽“What reason, however slight, is not found in your doctrine or discipline that might be criticized by wise men?”

original: koci appamattakopi kiṃ na āgacchati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “kiṃ sabbākārenapi tumhākaṃ🔽vāde gārayhaṃ kāraṇaṃ natthī”ti. Abbhācikkhantīti abhibhavitvā ācikkhanti.
analyzed: koci appamattakaḥ api kim na āgacchati idam vuttam hoti kim sabba ākārena api tumhākam  vāde gārayham kāraṇam na atthi iti abbhā ācikkhanti iti abhibhavitvā ācikkhanti
translated: This is what is meant: “Is there not found in your doctrine or discipline any reason, however slight, that might be criticized?”🔽“They misrepresent” : they misrepresent by overpowering .

original: 52. Ṭhānehīti kāraṇehi. Diṭṭhādīsu diṭṭhaṃ nāma bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya migamacche vadhitvā
analyzed: ṭhānehi iti kāraṇehi diṭṭha ādīsu diṭṭham nāma bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya miga macche vadhitvā
translated: “On the ground” : on the reason. “Seen” : for the sake of the bhikkhus, deer-trappers have killed deer and given the meat to the bhikkhus.

analyzed: gayhamānam diṭṭham sutam nāma bhikkhūnam atthāya miga macche vadhitvā gahitanti sutam
translated: What is seen is that it is taken. What is heard is that it is taken by hunters for the sake of the monks.

translated: What is suspected is threefold: suspected on the seen, suspected on the heard, and suspected on the seen and heard.

original: Tatrāyaṃ sabbasaṅgāhakavinicchayo – idha bhikkhū passanti manusse jālavāgurādihatthe
analyzed: tatra ayam sabba saṅgāhaka vinicchayaḥ idha bhikkhū passanti manusse jāla vāgurā ādi hatthe

analyzed: paviṭṭhānam samaccha maṃsam piṇḍapātam abhiharanti te tena diṭṭhena parisaṅkanti  bhikkhūnam nu kho atthāya katanti idam diṭṭha parisaṅkitam nāma etam gahetum na  vaṭṭati yam evam a parisaṅkitam tam vaṭṭati sace pana te manussā kasmai bhante
translated: the people give them meat as alms. They suspect because of what they have seen

analyzed: na gaṇhatha ati pucchitvā tam attham sutvā na yidam bhante bhikkhūnam atthāya katam

But if the people ask, “Why don’t you take it, venerable sirs?” and, on being told the reason, say, “Venerable sirs, this has not been killed for the sake of the monks,

translated: “Monks, if they don’t see, but they hear that people with nets, snares, and so on are leaving the village or wandering in the wilderness,

original: samacchamaṃsaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ abhiharanti. Te tena sutena parisaṅkanti “bhikkhūnaṃ nu
analyzed: sa maccha maṃsam piṇḍapātam abhiharanti te tena sutena bhikkhūnam nu
translated: and on the following day they enter that village for alms and are given meat that is not left over,

analyzed: kho atthāya katanti idam sutaparisaṅkitam nāma etam gahetum na vaṭṭati yam evam

analyzed: a parisaṅkitam tam vaṭṭati sace pana te manussā kasmai bhante na gaṇhatha ati pucchitvā  tam attham sutvā na yidam bhante bhikkhūnam atthāya katam amhehi attanaḥ atthāya

translated: and, on being told the reason, say, ‘Venerables, this was not done for the sake of the monks, but for our own sake or for the sake of the king’s men and so on,’ it is acceptable.

analyzed: na ha iva kho pana passanti na suṇanti apica tesam gāmam piṇḍāya paviṭṭhānam pattam  gahetvā sa maccha maṃsam piṇḍapātam abhisaṅkharitvā abhiharanti te parisaṅkanti bhikkhūnam  nu kho atthāya katanti idam tad ubhaya vimutta parisaṅkitam nāma etam pi gahetum na  vaṭṭati yam evam a parisaṅkitam tam vaṭṭati sace pana te manussā kasmai bhante
translated: Nor do they see or hear that it was given for the benefit of the Sangha or for the benefit of a particular individual. What is not suspect in this way may be accepted. If people give to them, saying,

original: na gaṇhathā”ti pucchitvā tamatthaṃ sutvā “nayidaṃ, bhante, bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya kataṃ,🔽amhehi attano atthāya vā rājayuttādīnaṃ atthāya vā kataṃ, pavattamaṃsaṃ vā kataṃ,🔽kappiyameva labhitvā bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya sampādita”nti vadanti, kappati.
analyzed: na gaṇhatha ati pucchitvā tam attham sutvā na yidam bhante bhikkhūnam atthāya katam  amhehi attanaḥ atthāya vā rāja yutta ādīnam atthāya vā katam pavatta maṃsam vā katam  kappiyam eva labhitvā bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya sampāditanti vadanti kappati
translated: They do not see or hear, but they suspect that the meat has been prepared for the bhikkhus. This is called “suspected because of both.” It is not allowable to eat this. That which is not suspected in any of these three ways is allowable. But if the people ask, “Why don’t you take it, venerable sirs?” and, on being told the reason, say, “Venerable sirs, this was not prepared for the bhikkhus. It was prepared for our own use or for the use of the king’s men, or it is meat that was already available and was prepared for the bhikkhus after being bought with the price of allowable meat,” then it is allowable.

original: Matānaṃ petakiccatthāya maṅgalādīnaṃ vā atthāya katepi eseva nayo. Yaṃ yañhi bhikkhūnaṃyeva
analyzed: matānam peta kicca atthāya maṅgala ādīnam vā atthāya kate pi esa iva nayaḥ yam yam hi bhikkhūnam yeva
translated: The same method applies to meat prepared for the funeral of a relative or for a festival, etc. For whatever is not prepared for the bhikkhus

original: atthāya akataṃ, yattha ca nibbematikā honti, taṃ sabbaṃ kappati. Sace pana ekasmiṃ
analyzed: atthāya a katam yattha ca nibbematikāḥ honti tat sabbam kappati sace pana ekasmin
translated: What has not been made for a purpose and what has no value is allowable in all cases. But if it is made for a purpose and has value,

original: vihāre bhikkhū uddissa kataṃ hoti, te ca attano atthāya katabhāvaṃ na jānanti, aññe
analyzed: vihāre bhikkhū uddissa katam hoti te ca attanaḥ atthāya kata bhāvam na jānanti aññe
translated: What is not made for the benefit of anyone is allowable in all cases. But if it is made in a dwelling for the benefit of the resident monks, and they do not know that it was made for their benefit,🔽but others do know,🔽then it is not allowable for those who know, but it is allowable for the others.

original: jānanti. Ye jānanti, tesaṃ na vaṭṭati, itaresaṃ vaṭṭati. Aññe na jānanti, teyeva
analyzed: jānanti ye jānanti tesam na vaṭṭati itaresam vaṭṭati aññe na jānanti te yeva
translated: If the others do not know, but those who know,🔽then it is not allowable for them, but it is allowable for the others.

original: jānanti, tesaṃyeva na vaṭṭati, aññesaṃ vaṭṭati. Tepi “amhākaṃ atthāya kataṃ”ti jānanti
analyzed: jānanti tesam yeva na vaṭṭati aññesam vaṭṭati te pi amhākam atthāya katam ti jānanti
translated: If they know that it was made for their benefit,🔽and others know that it was made for them,🔽then it is not allowable for any of them.

original: aññepi “etesaṃ atthāya kata”nti jānanti, sabbesampi taṃ na vaṭṭati. Sabbe na jānanti,
analyzed: aññe api etesam atthāya katanti jānanti sabbesam pi tam na vaṭṭati sabbe na jānanti
translated: If none of them know,🔽then it is allowable for all of them.

original: sabbesaṃ vaṭṭati. Pañcasu hi sahadhammikesu yassa kassaci vā atthāya uddissa kataṃ
analyzed: sabbesam vaṭṭati pañcasu hi sahadhammikesu yassa kassaci vā atthāya uddissa katam
translated: For if it is made for the benefit of any one of the five kinds of “fellow-religionists,”

original: sabbesaṃ na kappati.🔽Sace pana koci ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ uddissa pāṇaṃ vadhitvā tassa pattaṃ pūretvā deti, so
analyzed: sabbesam na kappati  sace pana koci ekam bhikkhum uddissa pāṇam vadhitvā tassa pattam pūretvā deti so
translated: then it is not allowable for any of them.🔽But if someone kills an animal and fills the bowl of a monk, and that monk, knowing that it was made for his benefit,

original: ce attano atthāya katabhāvaṃ jānaṃyeva gahetvā aññassa bhikkhuno deti, so tassa saddhāya
analyzed: ce attanaḥ atthāya kata bhāvam jānaṃya iva gahetvā aññassa bhikkhunaḥ deti so tassa saddhāya
translated: takes it and gives it to another monk, then it is allowable for the second monk if he does not know.

original: paribhuñjati. Kassāpattīti? Dvinnampi anāpatti. Yañhi uddissa kataṃ, tassa abhuttatāya🔽anāpatti, itarassa ajānanatāya. Kappiyamaṃsassa hi paṭiggahaṇe āpatti natthi. Uddissakatañca
analyzed: paribhuñjati kassa āpatti iti dvinnam pi anāpatti yat hi uddissa katam tassa a bhutta tāya  anāpatti itarassa a jānana tāya kappiya maṃsassa hi paṭiggahaṇe āpatti natthi uddissaka tañca
translated: What is the offence? There is no offence for either. Because it was not eaten by the one for whom it was killed,🔽and because the other did not know. For there is no offence in receiving meat that is allowable. But when it is killed on purpose for a monk,

original: ajānitvā bhuttassa pacchā ñatvā āpattidesanākiccaṃ nāma natthi. Akappiyamaṃsaṃ pana🔽ajānitvā bhuttena pacchā ñatvāpi āpatti desetabbā. Uddissakatañhi ñatvā bhuñjatova
analyzed: a jānitvā bhuttassa pacchā ñatvā āpatti desanā kiccam nāma natthi akappiya maṃsam pana  a jānitvā bhuttena pacchā ñatvā api āpatti desetabbā uddissa katam hi ñatvā bhuñjataḥ eva
translated: and he eats it without knowing, there is no need to make a formal announcement of the offence after he finds out. But if it is meat that is not allowable,

original: āpatti, akappiyamaṃsaṃ ajānitvā bhuttassāpi āpattiyeva. Tasmā āpattibhīrukena rūpaṃ
analyzed: āpatti akappiya maṃsam a jānitvā bhuttassa api āpattiyā iva tasmai āpatti bhīrukena rūpam
translated: even though he finds out after he has eaten it without knowing, he must still make a formal announcement of the offence. For there is an offence only for one who eats it after finding out that it was killed on purpose. But there is an offence even for one who eats it without knowing that it is not allowable. Therefore, even if he is afraid of an offence,

original: sallakkhentenāpi pucchitvāva maṃsaṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ, paribhogakāle pucchitvā paribhuñjissāmīti
analyzed: sallakkhentena api pucchitvā ava maṃsam paṭiggahetabbam paribhoga kāle pucchitvā paribhuñjissāmi iti
translated: he should receive the meat after asking, while examining the colour, etc., and at the time of eating he should receive it, saying, “I will ask and then eat it.”

original: vā gahetvā pucchitvāva paribhuñjitabbaṃ. Kasmā? Duviññeyyattā. Acchamaṃsañhi sūkaramaṃsasadisaṃ
analyzed: vā gahetvā pucchitvā ava paribhuñjitabbam kasmā duviññeyya ttā acchamaṃsan hi sūkara maṃsa sadisam
translated: Or he should receive it after asking. Why? Because it is difficult to know. For pork is similar to the meat of a human being.

original: hoti, dīpimaṃsādīni ca migamaṃsasadisāni, tasmā pucchitvā gahaṇameva vaṭṭatīti vadanti.
analyzed: hoti dīpi maṃsa ādīni ca miga maṃsa sadisāni tasmai pucchitvā gahaṇam eva vaṭṭati iti vadanti
translated: and deer’s flesh such as that of the dīpi deer is similar to that of the spotted deer. Therefore they say that it is proper to take it only after asking .🔽Not seen : not seen being killed for the sake of bhikkhus.

original: Adiṭṭhanti bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya vadhitvā gayhamānaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ. Asutanti bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya
analyzed: a diṭṭham ti bhikkhūnam atthāya vadhitvā gayhamānam a diṭṭham a sutam ti bhikkhūnam atthāya
translated: Not heard : not heard being killed for the sake of bhikkhus.

original: vadhitvā gahitanti asutaṃ. Aparisaṅkitanti diṭṭhaparisaṅkitādivasena aparisaṅkitaṃ.
analyzed: vadhitvā a sutam a parisaṅkitam ti diṭṭha parisaṅkita ādi vasena a parisaṅkitam
translated: Not suspected : not suspected by the three kinds of suspicion, that is, by what is seen, etc.

original: Paribhoganti vadāmīti imehi tīhi kāraṇehi parisuddhaṃ tikoṭiparisuddhaṃ nāma hoti,
analyzed: vadāmi iti imehi tīhi kāraṇehi parisuddham tikoṭiparisuddham nāma hoti
translated: I allow the use of : when it is purified by these three reasons, it is called purified by the triple purification.

original: tassa paribhogo araññe jātasūpeyyasākaparibhogasadiso hoti, tathārūpaṃ paribhuñjantassa
analyzed: tassa paribhogaḥ araññe jāta sūpeyya sāka paribhoga sadisaḥ hoti tathārūpam paribhuñjantassa
translated: The use of it is like the use of rice and flour grown in the wilderness.

original: mettāvihārissa bhikkhuno doso vā vajjaṃ vā natthi, tasmā taṃ paribhuñjitabbanti vadāmīti attho.
analyzed: mettāvihārissa bhikkhuno dosaḥ vā vajjam vā na atthi tasmā tam paribhuñjitabbanti vadāmi iti attho
translated: When one who dwells in loving-kindness uses it in this way, there is no fault or transgression in him. Therefore I say that it should be used.

original: 53. Idāni tādisassa paribhoge mettāvihārinopi anavajjataṃ dassetuṃ idha, jīvaka,
analyzed: idāni tādisassa paribhoge mettā vihārinaḥ api anavajja tam dassetum idha jīvaka
translated: Now, in order to show that even one who dwells in loving-kindness is free from transgression in using such things, the Exalted One said, “Here, Jīvaka,

original: bhikkhūtiādimāha. Tattha kiñcāpi aniyametvā bhikkhūti vuttaṃ, atha kho attānameva
analyzed: bhikkhū iti ādim āha tattha kiñcā api aniyametvā bhikkhū iti vuttam atha kho attānam eva
translated: a bhikkhu … .” Although the bhikkhus are mentioned without any distinction, nevertheless the Exalted One himself

original: sandhāya etaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Bhagavatā hi mahāvacchagottasutte, caṅkīsutte,
analyzed: sandhāya etam vuttam iti veditabbam bhagavatā hi mahāvacchagotta sutte caṅkīsutte
translated: and it should be understood that it was said with reference to himself. For the Exalted One gave this teaching with reference to himself in three places, namely, in the Mahāvacchagotta Sutta, in the Caṅkī Sutta,

original: imasmiṃ sutteti tīsu ṭhānesu attānaṃyeva sandhāya desanā katā. Paṇītena piṇḍapātenāti🔽heṭṭhā anaṅgaṇasutte yo koci mahaggho piṇḍapāto paṇītapiṇḍapātoti adhippeto, idha
analyzed: imasmin sutta iti tīsu ṭhānesu attānam yeva sandhāya desanā katā paṇītena piṇḍapātena ati  heṭṭhā anaṅgaṇa sutte yaḥ koci mahagghaḥ piṇḍapāto paṇīta piṇḍapāto ti adhippeto idha
translated: and in this sutta. “With choice almsfood”:🔽the choice almsfood referred to here is any almsfood of high quality, as in the Anaṅgaṇasutta below.

original: pana maṃsūpasecanova adhippeto. Agathitoti taṇhāya agathito. Amucchitoti taṇhāmucchanāya
analyzed: pana adhippeto a gathitaḥ uti taṇhāya a gathitaḥ a mucchitaḥ uti taṇhā a mucchanāya
translated: But here it refers to food mixed with meat. “Not clinging”: not clinging through craving. “Not grasping”: not grasping through craving.

original: amucchito. Anajjhopannoti na adhiopanno, sabbaṃ ālumpitvā ekappahāreneva gilitukāmo
analyzed: a mucchitaḥ an ajjhopannaḥ ti na adhiopannaḥ sabbam ālumpitvā eka pahārena iva gilitu kāmo
translated: “Not overindulging”: not overindulging, not wanting to eat everything at once, all at one go,

analyzed: kākaḥ viya na hoti iti attho ādīnava dassāvī iti eka ratti vāsena udara paṭalam pavisitvā
translated: like a crow. “Seeing danger”: seeing danger in the way beginning, “Having stayed for one night, it will enter the stomach-cavity

original: navahi vaṇamukhehi nikkhamissatītiādinā nayena ādīnavaṃ passanto. Nissaraṇapañño
analyzed: navahi vaṇa mukhehi nikkhamissati itiādinā nayena ādīnavam passantaḥ nissaraṇa pañño
translated: and come out through the nine orifices.” “Possessed of insight”:

original: paribhuñjatīti idamatthamāhāraparibhogoti paññāya paricchinditvā paribhuñjati. Attabyābādhāya
analyzed: paribhuñjati iti paññāya paricchinditvā paribhuñjati atta byābādhāya
translated: “he partakes of it” means that he discerns the meaning of “partaking of requisites” by means of insight and then partakes of them. “Not for the harm of himself” means

analyzed: vā cetā iti iti atta dukkhāya vā citā iti sutam etat ti sutam mayā etam pubbe etam mayham
translated: What I have heard is this: I have heard this before, this is my hearing

original: savanamattamevāti dasseti. Sace kho te, jīvaka, idaṃ sandhāya bhāsitanti, jīvaka,
analyzed: savanam attam eva ati dassa iti sace kho te jīvaka idam sandhāya bhāsitan ti jīvaka
translated: only, he shows. If, Jīvaka, you are speaking with reference to this, Jīvaka,

original: mahābrahmunā vikkhambhanappahānena byāpādādayo pahīnā, tena so mettāvihārī mayhaṃ🔽samucchedappahānena, sace te idaṃ sandhāya bhāsitaṃ, evaṃ sante tava idaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: mahābrahmunā vikkhambhana ppahānena byāpāda ādayaḥ pahīnā tena saḥ mettā vihārī mayham  samuccheda ppahānena sace te idam sandhāya bhāsitam evam sante tava idam vacanam
translated: by the Great Brahmā’s abandonment by suppression, ill-will, etc., are abandoned, therefore he, who abides in loving-kindness,

original: anujānāmīti attho. So sampaṭicchi.
analyzed: anujānāmi iti attho so sampaṭicchi
translated: by the abandonment by cutting off, if you are speaking with reference to this, in that case I allow your statement, is the meaning. He agreed.

original: 54. Athassa bhagavā sesabrahmavihāravasenāpi uttari desanaṃ vaḍḍhento “idha, jīvaka, bhikkhū”tiādimāha. Taṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā sesa brahmavihāra vasena api uttari desanam vaḍḍhentaḥ idha jīvaka bhikkhu iti ādim āha tam uttāna attham eva
translated: Then the Blessed One, increasing the teaching further by means of the remaining divine abidings, said “Here, Jīvaka, bhikkhus” , etc., the meaning of which is plain.

original: 55. Yo kho jīvakāti ayaṃ pāṭiekko anusandhi. Imasmiñhi ṭhāne bhagavā dvāraṃ thaketi,
analyzed: yaḥ kho jīvakāti ayam pāṭiekkaḥ imasmin hi ṭhāne bhagavā dvāram
translated: “Who, Jīvaka, is a certain person” is a separate continuity. For in this place the Blessed One sets up a door,

analyzed: satta anuddayam dasseti sace hi kassaci evam assa ekam rasa piṇḍapātam da tvā kappa sata sahassam
translated: he shows the arising of beings. For if anyone should think thus “Having given a single lump of alms food, for a hundred thousand aeons

analyzed: sagga sampattim paṭilabhanti yaṃ kiñci katvā param māretvā api rasa piṇḍapātaḥ uva dātabbaḥ ti
translated: They attain heavenly bliss. Even if one has to kill another, one should give him a morsel of food.”

analyzed: tam paṭisedhentaḥ yaḥ kho jīvaka tathāgatam vātiādim āha
translated: In order to refute this, the Buddha said: “Jīvaka, whoever, whether a monk or a nun, should intentionally deprive a human being of life, even cause an abortion,

original: Tattha iminā paṭhamena ṭhānenāti iminā āṇattimatteneva tāva paṭhamena kāraṇena. Galappavedhakenāti
analyzed: tattha iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena ati iminā āṇatti mattena iva tāva paṭhamena kāraṇena gala ppavedhakena ati
translated: Herein, by this first ground: by this first reason, by this mere order of sequence. By a rope round the neck: by one who is dragged along by being bound with a rope round the neck.🔽Is being killed: is being murdered.

original: yottena gale bandhitvā kaḍḍhito galena pavedhentena. Ārabhiyamānoti māriyamāno. Akappiyena
analyzed: yottena gale bandhitvā kaḍḍhitaḥ galena ārabhiyamānaḥ iti māriyamānaḥ akappiyena
translated: By an improper means: by a means that is not proper.

original: āsādetīti acchamaṃsaṃ sūkaramaṃsanti, dīpimaṃsaṃ vā migamaṃsanti khādāpetvā – “tvaṃ
analyzed: āsāda iti iti accha maṃsam sūkara maṃsanti dīpi maṃsam vā miga maṃsanti khāda apetvā tvam
translated: Persuades: having had him eat improper meat, such as beef, pork, or venison, saying “This is not beef, this is not pork, this is not venison,”

original: kiṃ samaṇo nāma, akappiyamaṃsaṃ te khādita”nti ghaṭṭeti. Ye pana dubbhikkhādīsu vā
analyzed: kim samaṇaḥ nāma akappiya maṃsam te khāditanti ghaṭṭeti ye pana dubbhikkha ādīsu vā
translated: he accuses him, saying “What sort of recluse are you, eating improper meat?” But those who, in times of famine,

original: byādhiniggahaṇatthaṃ vā “acchamaṃsaṃ nāma sūkaramaṃsasadisaṃ, dīpimaṃsaṃ migamaṃsasadisa”nti
analyzed: byādhi niggahaṇa attham vā accha maṃsam nāma sūkara maṃsa sadisam dīpi maṃsam miga maṃsa sadisanti
translated: or in order to cure an illness, know that “beef is like pork, venison is like beef,”

original: jānantā “sūkaramaṃsaṃ idaṃ, migamaṃsaṃ ida”nti vatvā hitajjhāsayena khādāpenti, na
analyzed: jānantā sūkara maṃsam idam miga maṃsam idam ti vatvā na
translated: and having said “This is pork, this is venison,” cause him to eat it with the intention of doing him good,

original: te sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tesañhi bahupuññameva hoti. Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ
analyzed: te sandhāya itam vuttam tesam hi bahu puññam eva hoti esā aham bhante bhagavantam saraṇam
translated: This was said with reference to them. For they have much merit.🔽I go to the Blessed One for refuge, to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañcāti ayaṃ āgataphalo viññātasāsano diṭṭhasacco ariyasāvako.
analyzed: gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca ati ayam āgata phalaḥ viññāta sāsanaḥ diṭṭha saccaḥ ariya sāvako
translated: This is the one who has attained the fruits of the path and has come to know the Master’s Dispensation, who is a true man of noble character.

original: Imaṃ pana dhammadesanaṃ ogāhanto pasādaṃ uppādetvā dhammakathāya thutiṃ karonto evamāha.
analyzed: imam pana dhamma desanam ogāhantaḥ pasādam uppādetvā dhamma kathāya thutim karontaḥ evam āha
translated: But when he was listening to this Dhamma teaching he aroused confidence and then, in praise of the Dhamma talk, he said this:

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is all clear.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya called “The Sūdani of the Great Book”

original: Jīvakasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jīvaka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 6. Upālisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upāli sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Upāli Sutta

original: 56. Evaṃ me sutanti upālisuttaṃ. Tattha nāḷandāyanti nālandāti evaṃnāmake nagare
analyzed: evam me sutanti upāli suttam tattha nāḷandāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare
translated: Thus I heard. This is the Upāli Sutta. Herein, in Nāḷandā means in the town called Nāḷandā.

original: taṃ nagaraṃ gocaragāmaṃ katvā. Pāvārikambavaneti dussapāvārikaseṭṭhino ambavane.
analyzed: tam nagaram gocara gāmam katvā pāvārika ambavane iti dussa pāvārika seṭṭhinaḥ ambavane
translated: Having made that town his resort, in the mango grove of Cunda the Smith means in the mango grove of the merchant Cunda the Smith.

original: Taṃ kira tassa uyyānaṃ ahosi, so bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ sutvā bhagavati pasanno
analyzed: tam kira tassa uyyānam ahosi so bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam sutvā bhagavati pasannaḥ
translated: That was his pleasure garden, it seems. He heard the Blessed One teaching the Dhamma and he became confident in the Blessed One.

original: tasmiṃ uyyāne kuṭileṇamaṇḍapādipaṭimaṇḍitaṃ bhagavato vihāraṃ katvā niyyādesi, so
analyzed: tasmin uyyāne kuṭileṇa maṇḍapa ādi paṭimaṇḍitam bhagavataḥ vihāram katvā niyyādesi saḥ
translated: He had a dwelling built for the Blessed One in the park, complete with a reception hall, a pavilion, etc., and presented it to him.🔽That dwelling became as well known as the Jīvaka Mango Grove and the Pāvādika Mango Grove.

original: vihāro jīvakambavanaṃ viya pāvārikambavananteva saṅkhaṃ gato. Tasmiṃ pāvārikambavane
analyzed: vihāraḥ jīva kamba vanam viya saṅkham gataḥ tasmin pāvāri kamba vane
translated: The meaning is that he dwelt in the Pāvārika Mango Grove.🔽Long-nailed: he got his name because of the length of his nails.

original: viharatīti attho. Dīghatapassīti dīghattā evaṃladdhanāmo. Piṇḍapātapaṭikkantoti piṇḍapātato
analyzed: viharati iti atthaḥ dīgha tapassī iti dīgha ttā evaṃladdha nāmo piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ ti piṇḍapātataḥ
translated: After returning from his almsround: after returning from his almsround.

original: paṭikkanto. Sāsane viya kiṃ pana bāhirāyatane piṇḍapātoti vohāro atthīti, natthi.
analyzed: paṭikkanto sāsane viya kim pana bāhira āyatane piṇḍapāto ti vohāro atthi iti natthi
translated: But is there such a usage as “almsround” in regard to an external object? No, there is not.🔽He lays down: he shows, he establishes.

original: Paññapetīti dasseti ṭhapeti. Daṇḍāni paññapetīti idaṃ nigaṇṭhasamayena pucchanto
analyzed: paññapeti iti dasseti ṭhapeti daṇḍāni paññapeti iti idam nigaṇṭha samayena pucchantaḥ
translated: He lays down rods: this is said by one who asks according to the doctrine of the Niganthas.

original: āha. Kāyadaṇḍaṃ vacīdaṇḍaṃ manodaṇḍanti ettha purimadaṇḍadvayaṃ te acittakaṃ payyapenti.
analyzed: āha kāya daṇḍam vacī daṇḍam manaḥ daṇḍa nti ettha purima daṇḍa dvayam te acittakam payyapenti
translated: The bodily rod, the verbal rod, and the mental rod. Herein, the first two rods are unintentional, they say.

original: Yathā kira vāte vāyante sākhā calati, udakaṃ calati, na ca tattha cittaṃ atthi, evaṃ
analyzed: yathā kira vāte vāyante sākhā calati udakam calati na ca tattha cittam atthi evam
translated: Just as when the wind blows, a branch moves, and water ripples, and there is no consciousness there,

original: kāyadaṇḍopi acittakova hoti. Yathā ca vāte vāyante tālapaṇṇādīni saddaṃ karonti,
analyzed: kāya daṇḍaḥ api acittakaḥ eva hoti yathā ca vāte vāyante tāla paṇṇa ādīni saddam karonti
translated: so too the bodily rod is unintentional. And just as when the wind blows, palm leaves, etc., make a sound,

original: udakāni saddaṃ karonti, na ca tattha cittaṃ atthi, evaṃ vacīdaṇḍopi acittakova hotīti
analyzed: udakāni saddam karonti na ca tattha cittam atthi evam vacī daṇḍaḥ api acittakaḥ va hoti iti
translated: and the water makes a sound, but there is no consciousness there, so too the verbal rod is without consciousness.

original: imaṃ daṇḍadvayaṃ acittakaṃ paññapenti. Cittaṃ pana manodaṇḍanti paññapenti. Athassa
analyzed: imam daṇḍa dvayam acittakam paññapenti cittam pana manodaṇḍanti paññapenti athassa
translated: Thus they declare these two rods to be without consciousness. But they declare the mental rod to be consciousness.

original: bhagavā vacanaṃ patiṭṭhapetukāmo “kiṃ pana tapassī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhagavā vacanam patiṭṭhapetu kāmo kim pana tapassi itiādim āha
translated: Then the Blessed One, wishing to establish his statement, said: “But, ascetic, what is the mental rod?”

original: Tattha kathāvatthusminti ettha kathāyeva kathāvatthu. Kathāyaṃ patiṭṭhapesīti attho.
analyzed: tattha kathāvatthusmin ti ettha kathāya iva kathāvatthu kathāyam patiṭṭhapesi iti attho
translated: Herein, in the discussion-basis means that the discussion itself is the discussion-basis. The meaning is that he established the discussion in the discussion-basis.

original: Kasmā pana bhagavā evamakāsi? Passati hi bhagavā “ayaṃ imaṃ kathaṃ ādāya gantvā attano
analyzed: kasmā pana bhagavā evam akāsi passati hi bhagavā ayam imam katham ādāya gantvā attanaḥ
translated: But why did the Blessed One do so? The Blessed One sees that “taking this discussion, he will go and report it

original: satthu mahānigaṇṭhassa ārocessati, tāsañca parisati, upāli gahapati nisinno, so imaṃ🔽kathaṃ sutvā mama vādaṃ āropetuṃ āgamissati, tassāhaṃ dhammaṃ desessāmi, so tikkhattuṃ
analyzed: satthu mahānigaṇṭhassa ārocessati tāsam ca parisati upāli gahapati nisinnaḥ saḥ imaṃ  katham sutvā mama vādam āropetum āgamissati tassa aham dhammam desessāmi saḥ tikkhattum
translated: to his teacher, the great recluse, and to his assembly. And the householder Upali is sitting in that assembly. He will come to me🔽to dispute my doctrine after he has heard this discussion. I shall teach him the Dhamma. He will go for refuge three times

original: saraṇaṃ gamissati, athassa cattāri saccāni pakāsessāmi, so saccapakāsanāvasāne sotāpattiphale
analyzed: saraṇam gamissati atha assa cattāri saccāni pakāsessāmi saḥ sacca pakāsana avasāne sotāpatti phale
translated: and will enter upon the way to the realization of the fruit of stream-entry.

original: patiṭṭhahissati, paresaṃ saṅgahatthameva hi mayā pāramiyo pūritā”ti. Imamatthaṃ passanto evamakāsi.
analyzed: patiṭṭhahissati paresam saṅgaha attham eva hi mayā pāramiyaḥ pūritā iti imam attham passantaḥ evam akāsi
translated: for it is only in order to gather others to myself that I have fulfilled the pāramīs.”🔽. He asked this question in order to show the three kinds of kamma.

original: 57. Kammāni paññapesīti idaṃ nigaṇṭho buddhasamayena pucchanto āha. Kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ🔽manokammanti ettha kāyadvāre ādānagahaṇamuñcanacopanapattā aṭṭhakāmāvacarakusalacetanā🔽dvādasākusalacetanāti vīsaticetanā kāyakammaṃ nāma. Kāyadvāre ādānādīni apatvā vacīdvāre
analyzed: kammāni paññapesi iti idam nigaṇṭhaḥ buddha samayena pucchantaḥ āha kāya kammam vacī kammam  ettha kāya dvāre ādāna gahaṇa muñcana copana pattā aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā  dvādasa akusala cetanā ati vīsati cetanā kāya kammam nāma kāya dvāre ādāna ādīni a patvā vacī dvāre
translated: The three kinds of kamma are bodily kamma, verbal kamma, and mental kamma.🔽Herein, the twenty volitions of the sense sphere, namely, the eight wholesome volitions that occur in the door of the body, the twelve unwholesome volitions, are called bodily kamma.

original: vacanabhedaṃ pāpayamānā uppannā tāyeva vīsaticetanā vacīkammaṃ nāma. Ubhayadvāre
analyzed: vacana bhedam pāpayamānā uppannā tāyā iva vīsati cetanā vacī kammam nāma ubhaya dvāre
translated: Apart from the volitions that occur in the door of the body, the same twenty volitions that occur in the door of speech, while producing the various kinds of speech, are called verbal kamma.

original: copanaṃ appatvā manodvāre uppannā ekūnatiṃsakusalākusalacetanā manokammaṃ nāma. Apica
analyzed: copanam appatvā manaḥ dvāre uppannā ekūnatiṃsa kusala akusala cetanā manokammam nāma apica
translated: Apart from the volitions that occur in both doors, the twenty-nine wholesome and unwholesome volitions that occur in the door of the mind are called mental kamma.

original: saṅkhepato tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ kāyakammaṃ nāma, catubbidhaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ vacīkammaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ tividham kāya duccaritam kāya kammam nāma catubbidham vacī duccaritam vacī kammam
translated: Moreover, the three kinds of bodily misconduct are called bodily kamma; the four kinds of verbal misconduct, verbal kamma;

original: nāma, tividhaṃ manoduccaritaṃ manokammaṃ nāma. Imasmiñca sutte kammaṃ dhuraṃ, anantarasutte
analyzed: nāma tividham manoduccaritam manokammam nāma imasmin ca sutte kammam anantara sutte
translated: and in the immediately following sutta:

original: “cattārimāni puṇṇa kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti evamāgatepi
analyzed: cattāri imāni puṇṇa kammāni mayā sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni iti evam āgate pi
translated: “These four kinds of action have been declared by me after I realized them with direct-knowledge,”

original: cetanā dhuraṃ. Yattha katthaci pavattā cetanā “kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipāka”ntiādibhedaṃ labhati.
analyzed: cetanā dhuram yattha katthaci pavattā cetanā kaṇham labhati
translated: volition is the burden. Volition, wherever it occurs, is classed as “black, with black result,” and so on.

original: Niddesavāre cassa “sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharotī”tiādinā nayena sā vuttāva.
analyzed: niddesa vāre ca ssa sa byābajjham kāya saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti iti ādinā nayena sā vuttā ava
translated: And it is mentioned in the Description of Action in the way beginning, “He generates an action-aggregate that is blameworthy” .

original: Kāyadvāre pavattā pana idha kāyakammanti adhippetaṃ, vacīdvāre pavattā vacīkammaṃ,🔽manodvāre pavattā manokammaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “imasmiṃ sutte kammaṃ dhuraṃ, anantarasutte
analyzed: kāya dvāre pavattā pana idha kāya kamman ti adhippetam vacī dvāre pavattā vacī kammaṃ  manaḥ dvāre pavattā manaḥ kammam tena vuttam imasmin sutte kammam dhuram anantara sutte
translated: But what occurs in the door of the body is intended here as bodily action, and what occurs in the door of speech as verbal action,

original: cetanā”ti. Kammampi hi bhagavā kammanti paññapeti yathā imasmiṃyeva sutte. Cetanampi,
analyzed: cetanā ati kammam pi hi bhagavā kammanti paññapeti yathā imasmiṃ yeva sutte cetanam pi
translated: and what occurs in the door of the mind as mental action. That is why it was said above: “In this sutta action is the burden, and in the immediately following sutta volition.” For the Blessed One describes action as action, as in this sutta,🔽and he describes volition as action,

original: yathāha – “cetanāhaṃ, bhikkhave, kammaṃ vadāmi, cetayitvā kammaṃ karotī”ti. Kasmā
analyzed: yathā āha cetanā aham bhikkhave kammam vadāmi cetayitvā kammam karoti iti kasmā
translated: as in the passage: “Bhikkhus, I say that volition is kamma. Having willed, one acts by body or by speech or by mind” . Why?

original: pana cetanā kammanti vuttā? Cetanāmūlakattā kammassa.🔽Ettha ca akusalaṃ patvā kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ mahantanti vadanto na kilamati, kusalaṃ🔽patvā manokammaṃ. Tathā hi mātughātādīni cattāri kammāni kāyeneva upakkamitvā kāyeneva🔽karoti, niraye kappaṭṭhikasaṅghabhedakammaṃ vacīdvārena karoti. Evaṃ akusalaṃ patvā
analyzed: pana cetanā kammanti vuttā cetanā mūlaka ttā kammassa  ettha ca akusalam patvā kāya kammam vacī kammam vadantaḥ na kilamati kusalam  patvā manaḥ kammam tathā hi mātughāta ādīni cattāri kammāni kāyena iva upakkamitvā kāyena iva  karoti niraye kappaṭṭhika saṅgha bheda kammam vacī dvārena karoti evam akusalam patvā
translated: But why is it said that volition is action? Because action has volition as its root.🔽And here, when it is said that bodily action and verbal action are great in the case of unwholesome action, one is not being contentious. But when it is said that mental action is great in the case of wholesome action, one is being contentious.

original: kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ mahantanti vadanto na kilamati nāma. Ekā pana jhānacetanā caturāsītikappasahassāni
analyzed: kāya kammam vacī kammam mahantanti vadantaḥ na kilamati nāma ekā pana jhāna cetanā caturāsīti kappa sahassāni
translated: For the four kinds of action beginning with the killing of one’s mother are undertaken and performed by the body alone. The action of schism in the Saṅgha, which lasts for an eon, is done by the speech door. Thus when it is said that bodily action and verbal action are great in the case of unwholesome action, one is not being contentious.

original: saggasampattiṃ āvahati, ekā maggacetanā sabbākusalaṃ samugghātetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhāpeti.
analyzed: sagga sampattim āvahati ekā magga cetanā sabba akusalam samugghātetvā arahattam gaṇhāpeti
translated: But a single volition of jhāna brings about the attainment of heavenly bliss for eighty-four thousand eons, and a single volition of the path eradicates all unwholesome states and brings about the attainment of arahatship.

original: Evaṃ kusalaṃ patvā manokammaṃ mahantanti vadanto na kilamati nāma. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne
analyzed: evam kusalam patvā mano kammam mahantanti vadantaḥ na kilamati nāma imasmim pana ṭhāne
translated: Thus when it is said that mental action is great in the case of wholesome action, one is being contentious. But in this context,

original: bhagavā akusalaṃ patvā manokammaṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ vadamāno niyatamicchādiṭṭhiṃ sandhāya
analyzed: bhagavā akusalam patvā manaḥ kammam mahā sāvajjam vadamānaḥ niyatam icchādiṭṭhim sandhāya
translated: when the Blessed One says that mental action is of great result in the case of unwholesome action, he is referring to a fixed wrong view.

original: vadati. Tenevāha – “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: vadati tena iva āha na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evam
translated: He says this: “Bhikkhus, I do not see even one other thing through the appearance of which … the true Dhamma disappears so quickly as through negligence.

original: mahāsāvajjaṃ, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, micchādiṭṭhi. Micchādiṭṭhiparamāni, bhikkhave, mahāsāvajjānī”ti.
analyzed: mahā sāvajjam yathayidam bhikkhave micchādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhi paramāni bhikkhave mahā sāvajjāni iti
translated: He says this. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, I see no other single thing so productive of great harm as wrong view. Wrong view, bhikkhus, is productive of great harm” .

original: Idāni nigaṇṭhopi tathāgatena gatamaggaṃ paṭipajjanto kiñci atthanipphattiṃ apassantopi “kiṃ panāvuso, gotamā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni nigaṇṭhaḥ api tathāgatena gata maggam paṭipajjanto kiñci attha nipphattim a passantaḥ api kim pana āvuso gotama ti ādim āha
translated: Now, although the Nigantha did not see any benefit in following the way of the Tathagata, he said: “But, friend Gotama,” etc.

original: 58. Bālakiniyāti upālissa kira bālakaloṇakāragāmo nāma atthi, tato āyaṃ gahetvā manussā🔽āgatā, so “etha bhaṇe, amhākaṃ satthāraṃ mahānigaṇṭhaṃ passissāmā”ti tāya parisāya
analyzed: bālakiniyā ti upālissa kira bālakaloṇakāragāmaḥ nāma atthi tatas āyam gahetvā manussā  āgatā sā u etha bhaṇe amhākam satthāram mahānigaṇṭham passissāma ati tāya parisāya
translated: The “group of young men” : there was, it seems, a village called the Young Men’s Salt-making Village . People came from there, taking their wages,

original: parivuto tattha agamāsi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “bālakiniyā parisāyā”ti, bālakagāmavāsiniyāti
analyzed: parivutaḥ tattha agamāsi tam sandhāya vuttam bālakiniyā parisāyā ati bālaka gāma vāsiniyā ati
translated: and he went there surrounded by that assembly, saying: “Come, let us see our teacher, the great Nigantha.” Referring to that, it is said: “in the group of young men.” The meaning is: in the group of the inhabitants of the Young Men’s Village.

original: attho. Upālipamukhāyāti upālijeṭṭhakāya. Apica bālakiniyāti bālavatiyā bālussannāyātipi
analyzed: upāli pamukhāya ati upāli jeṭṭhakāya apica bālakiniyā ati bālavatiyā bālussannāya atipi
translated: “With Upali at their head”: with Upali as their chief. Moreover, “group of young men” means “endowed with young men,” “endowed with fools.”

original: attho. Upālipamukhāyāti upāligahapatiyeva tattha thokaṃ sappañño, so tassā pamukho
analyzed: upāli pamukhāya ti upāli gahapatiyā iva tattha thokam sappañño so tassā pamukho
translated: The meaning. Upālipamukhāyā: Upāli the householder was a little clever there, he was the chief

original: jeṭṭhako. Tenāpi vuttaṃ “upālipamukhāyā”ti. Handāti vacasāyatthe nipāto. Chavoti
analyzed: jeṭṭhako tena api vuttam upāli pamukhāya ati handa iti nipāto chavaḥ ti
translated: of them. Therefore it was said: “Upālipamukhāyā.” Hand: a particle in the sense of speech. Chavo:

original: lāmako. Oḷārikassāti mahantassa. Upanidhāyāti upanikkhipitvā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, kāyadaṇḍassa
analyzed: lāmakaḥ oḷārikassa ati mahantassa upanidhāya ati upanikkhipitvā idam vuttam hoti kāya daṇḍassa
translated: a fool. Oḷārikassāti mahantassa: of the great. Upanidhāyāti upanikkhipitvā: having placed near. This is what is said:

original: santike nikkhipitvā “ayaṃ nu kho mahanto, ayaṃ mahanto”ti evaṃ olokiyamāno chavo
analyzed: santike nikkhipitvā ayam nu kho mahantaḥ ayam mahantaḥ iti evam olokiyamānaḥ chavaḥ
translated: having placed near the bodily rod, “This is great, this is great,” thus looking at it, the fool

original: manodaṇḍo kiṃ sobhati, kuto sobhissati, na sobhati, upanikkhepamattampi nappahotīti
analyzed: manodaṇḍaḥ kim sobhati kutas sobhissati na sobhati upanikkhepa mattam pi na ppahoti iti
translated: the mental rod, how does it shine? From where will it shine? It does not shine, it is not even able to be placed near.

original: dīpeti. Sādhu sādhu, bhante, tapassīti dīghatapassissa sādhukāraṃ dento, bhanteti nāṭaputtamālapati.
analyzed: dīpeti sādhu sādhu bhante tapassī iti dīghatapassissa sādhukāram dentaḥ bhante iti nāṭa puttam ālapati
translated: Thus he shows. Sādhu sādhu, bhante, tapassī: giving his approval to Dīghatapassī, bhante he addresses the son of the Nāṭas.

original: 60. Na kho metaṃ, bhante, ruccatīti, bhante, etaṃ mayhaṃ na ruccati. Māyāvīti māyākāro.
analyzed: na kho mā etam bhante ruccati iti bhante etam mayham na ruccati māyāvī iti māyā kāro
translated: Na kho metaṃ, bhante, ruccati: bhante, this does not please me. Māyāvī: a magician.

original: Āvaṭṭanimāyanti āvaṭṭetvā gahaṇamāyaṃ. Āvaṭṭetīti āvaṭṭetvā parikkhipitvā gaṇhāti.
analyzed: āvaṭṭanimāyanti āvaṭṭetvā gahaṇa māyam āvaṭṭeti iti āvaṭṭetvā parikkhipitvā gaṇhāti
translated: Āvaṭṭanimāyāti āvaṭṭetvā gahaṇamāyaṃ: the magic of seizing after turning around. Āvaṭṭetīti āvaṭṭetvā parikkhipitvā gaṇhāti: he seizes after turning around and surrounding.

original: Gaccha tvaṃ gahapatīti kasmā mahānigaṇṭho gahapatiṃ yāvatatiyaṃ pahiṇatiyeva? Dīghatapassī
analyzed: gaccha tvam gahapati iti kasmai mahānigaṇṭhaḥ gahapatim yāvatatiyam dīgha tapassī
translated: Why did the great Nigantha, after sending the householder three times, say, “Go, householder”?🔽

original: pana paṭibāhateva? Mahānigaṇṭhena hi bhagavatā saddhiṃ ekaṃ nagaraṃ upanissāya viharantenapi
analyzed: pana paṭibāhatā iva mahānigaṇṭhena hi bhagavatā saddhim ekam nagaram upanissāya viharantena api
translated: Why did Mahānigaṇṭha send the householder so often? But Dīghatapassī kept on refusing. For Mahānigaṇṭha had lived in a certain town with the Blessed One,

original: na bhagavā diṭṭhapubbo. Yo hi satthuvādapaṭiñño hoti, so taṃ paṭiññaṃ appahāya buddhadassane
analyzed: na bhagavā diṭṭha pubbaḥ yaḥ hi satthuvāda paṭiññaḥ hoti saḥ tam paṭiññam a pahāya buddha dassane
translated: but he had never seen the Blessed One. And one who has accepted the doctrine of a teacher cannot see the Buddha

original: abhabbo. Tasmā esa buddhadassanassa aladdhapubbattā dasabalassa dassanasampattiñca🔽niyyānikakathābhāvañca ajānanto yāvatatiyaṃ pahiṇateva. Dīghatapassī pana kālena
analyzed: abhabbo tasmai esa buddha dassanassa a laddha pubba ttā dasa balassa dassana sampattiñca  niyyānika kathā bhāvañca a jānantaḥ yāvatatiyam pahiṇatā iva dīgha tapassī pana kālena
translated: without giving up that acceptance. Therefore, because he had never seen the Buddha, and because he did not know the excellence of the vision of the One of Ten Powers

original: kālaṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi pañhampi pucchati, so tathāgatassa🔽dassanasampattimpi niyyānikakathābhāvampi jānāti. Athassa etadahosi – “ayaṃ gahapati
analyzed: kālam bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā tiṭṭhati pi nisīdati pi pañham pi pucchati saḥ tathāgatassa  dassana sampattim pi niyyānika kathā bhāvam pi jānāti atha assa etat ahosi ayam gahapati
translated: and the excellence of the doctrine that leads out , he sent the householder so often. But Dīghatapassī had gone to the Blessed One from time to time, and he had stood with him, sat with him, and asked him questions. He knew the excellence of the vision of the Tathāgata

original: paṇḍito, samaṇassa gotamassa santike gantvā dassanepi pasīdeyya, niyyānikakathaṃ
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ samaṇassa gotamassa santike gantvā dassane pi pasīdeyya niyyānika katham
translated: and the excellence of the doctrine that leads out . Then he thought, “This householder is wise. He might go to the recluse Gotama and be confirmed in the excellence of the vision of the Tathāgata and the excellence of the doctrine that leads out .

original: sutvāpi pasīdeyya. Tato na puna amhākaṃ santikaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti. Tasmā yāvatatiyaṃ paṭibāhateva.
analyzed: sutvā api pasīdeyya tatas na punar amhākam santikam āgaccheyya ati tasmai yāvatatiyam
translated: and having heard it, he would be confirmed in his faith and would not come back to us again.” That is why he refused him up to the third time.

original: Abhivādetvāti vanditvā. Tathāgatañhi disvā pasannāpi appasannāpi yebhuyyena vandantiyeva,
analyzed: abhivādetvā ati vanditvā tathāgatam hi disvā pasannā api appasannā api yebhuyyena vandantiyā iva
translated: Having paid homage: having worshipped. For when people see the Tathāgata, whether they have faith or not, they generally pay homage.

original: appakā na vandanti. Kasmā? Atiucce hi kule jāto agāraṃ ajjhāvasantopi vanditabboyevāti.
analyzed: appakāḥ na vandanti kasmai atiucce hi kule jātaḥ agāram ajjhāvasantaḥ api vanditabbaḥ yā iva ati
translated: Few do not pay homage. Why is that? Because he is one who should be worshipped, even though he was born in a high family and lived in a house.🔽But this householder paid homage because of his faith. It seems that he was confirmed in his faith by the mere sight of the Tathāgata.

original: Ayaṃ pana gahapati pasannattāva vandi, dassaneyeva kira pasanno. Āgamā nu khvidhāti āgamā nu kho idha.
analyzed: ayam pana gahapati vandi dassaneyā iva kira pasannaḥ āgamā nu khvidha ati āgamā nu kho idha
translated: Āgamā nu khvidha: āgamā nu kho idha?

original: 61. Sādhu sādhu, bhante, tapassīti dīghatapassissa sādhukāraṃ dento, bhanteti, bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: sādhu sādhu bhante tapassi iti dīghatapassissa sādhukāram dentaḥ bhante iti bhagavantam
translated: Sādhu sādhu, bhante, tapassī: giving his approval to Dīghatapassī, he addressed the Blessed One as “Bhante.”

original: ālapati. Sacce patiṭṭhāyāti thusarāsimhi ākoṭitakhāṇuko viya acalanto vacīsacce patiṭṭhahitvā.
analyzed: ālapati sacce patiṭṭhāyāti thusarāsimhi ākoṭita khāṇukaḥ viya a calantaḥ vacīsacce patiṭṭhahitvā
translated: Sacce patiṭṭhāya: having established himself in verbal truth without wavering like a post in a heap of chaff.

original: Siyā noti bhaveyya amhākaṃ.
analyzed: siyā no ti bhaveyya amhākam
translated: Siyā no: it might be ours.

original: 62. Idhāti imasmiṃ loke. Assāti bhaveyya. Sītodakapaṭikkhittoti nigaṇṭhā sattasaññāya
analyzed: idha ati imasmin loke assa ati bhaveyya sīta udaka paṭikkhitto ti nigaṇṭhā satta saññāya
translated: Idha: in this world. Assa: it might be. Sītodakapaṭikkhitto: the Nigaṇṭhas are averse to cold water.

original: sītodakaṃ paṭikkhipanti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Manosattā nāma devāti manamhi sattā🔽laggā lagitā. Manopaṭibaddhoti yasmā manamhi paṭibaddho hutvā kālaṅkaroti, tasmā
analyzed: sīta udakam paṭikkhipanti tam sandhāya itam vuttam manosattāḥ nāma devā ti manamhi sattā  laggā lagitā manaḥ paṭibaddhā iti yasmai manamhi paṭibaddhaḥ hutvā kālaṅkaroti tasmai
translated: and they do not allow cold water. That is why it is said. “Mind-made beings” : beings who are attached to, who are stuck on, the mind.

original: manosattesu devesu upapajjatīti dasseti. Tassa hi pittajararogo bhavissati. Tenassa🔽uṇhodakaṃ pivituṃ vā hatthapādādidhovanatthāya vā gattaparisiñcanatthāya vā upanetuṃ
analyzed: manosattesu devesu upapajjati iti dasseti tassa hi pitta jarā rogaḥ bhavissati tena ssa  uṇha udakam pivitum vā hattha pāda ādi dhovana tthāya vā gatta parisiñcana tthāya vā upanetum
translated: “Bound to the mind” : because he dies bound to the mind, it shows that he is reborn among the Mind-made Gods. For he will have a disease of bile. Therefore

original: na vaṭṭati, rogo balavataro hoti. Sītodakaṃ vaṭṭati, rogaṃ vūpasameti. Ayaṃ pana🔽uṇhodakameva paṭisevati, taṃ alabhamāno odanakañjikaṃ paṭisevati. Cittena pana sītodakaṃ🔽pātukāmo ca paribhuñjitukāmo ca hoti. Tenassa manodaṇḍo tattheva bhijjati. So kāyadaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: na vaṭṭati rogaḥ balavataraḥ hoti sītā udakam vaṭṭati rogam vūpasameti ayam pana  uṇha udakam eva paṭisevati tam a labhamānaḥ odana kañjikam paṭisevati cittena pana sīta udakam  pātu kāmo ca paribhuñjitu kāmo ca hoti tena assa manaḥ daṇḍaḥ tattha iva bhijjati saḥ kāya daṇḍam
translated: it is not allowed him to drink hot water or to have it brought for bathing the body or for washing the hands and feet, for the disease is too strong. Cold water is allowed, for it allays the disease. But he

original: vacīdaṇḍaṃ rakkhāmīti sītodakaṃ pātukāmo vā paribhuñjitukāmo vā sītodakameva dethāti
analyzed: vacī daṇḍam rakkhāmi iti sīta udakam pātu kāmaḥ vā paribhuñjitu kāmaḥ vā sīta udakam eva detha ati
translated: only uses hot water, and when he cannot get it he uses rice-gruel. But he wants cold water and he wants to use it, and so his mental rod breaks there. He thinks, “I am keeping the rod of body and the rod of speech,” and he wants cold water or wants to use it, and so he says, “Give me only cold water.”

original: vattuṃ na visahati. Tassa evaṃ rakkhitāpi kāyadaṇḍavacīdaṇḍā cutiṃ vā paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: vattum na visahati tassa evam rakkhitā api kāya daṇḍa vacī daṇḍā cutim vā paṭisandhim
translated: He cannot speak. So though guarded thus, the body-puni.shment and the speech-punishment cannot lead him to death or rebirth-linking.

original: vā ākaḍḍhituṃ na sakkonti. Manodaṇḍo pana bhinnopi cutimpi paṭisandhimpi ākaḍḍhatiyeva.
analyzed: vā ākaḍḍhitum na sakkonti manodaṇḍaḥ pana bhinnaḥ api cutim pi paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhatiyā iva
translated: But the mind-punishment, though broken, can lead him to death and rebirth-linking.

original: Iti naṃ bhagavā dubbalakāyadaṇḍavacīdaṇḍā chavā lāmakā, manodaṇḍova balavā mahantoti vadāpesi.🔽Tassapi upāsakassa etadahosi. “Mucchāvasena asaññibhūtānañhi sattāhampi assāsapassāsā
analyzed: iti nam bhagavā dubbala kāya daṇḍa vacī daṇḍā chavā lāmakā manaḥ daṇḍā uva balavā mahantaḥ iti vadāpesi  tassa api upāsakassa etat ahosi mucchā vasena asaññi bhūtānam hi sattāham pi assāsa passāsā
translated: So the Blessed One had him say that the body-punishment and the speech-punishment are weak and feeble, and that the mind-punishment is strong and powerful.

original: nappavattanti, cittasantatipavattimatteneva pana te matāti na vuccanti. Yadā nesaṃ
analyzed: na ppavattanti citta santati pavattimattena iva pana te matā ati na vuccanti yadā
translated: The lay follower thought, “When beings are unconscious and senseless, their in-breaths and out-breaths do not occur for a whole week. But they are not called dead so long as the continuity of consciousness persists.

original: cittaṃ nappavattati, tadā ‘matā ete nīharitvā te jhāpethā’ti vattabbataṃ āpajjanti.
analyzed: cittam na ppavattati tadā matāḥ ete nīharitvā te jhāpetha iti vattabbatam āpajjanti
translated: When their consciousness ceases, they come to be called dead and to be treated as ‘dead so-and-so.’

original: Kāyadaṇḍo nirīho abyāpāro, tathā vacīdaṇḍo. Citteneva pana tesaṃ cutipi paṭisandhipi
analyzed: kāya daṇḍaḥ nirīhaḥ abyāpāro tathā vacī daṇḍaḥ cittena iva pana tesam cuti pi paṭisandhi pi
translated: The body-punishment is inactive and harmless, and so is the speech-punishment. But it is only by the mind that they die and are reborn.

original: hoti. Itipi manodaṇḍova mahanto. Bhijjitvāpi cutipaṭisandhiākaḍḍhanato eseva mahanto.
analyzed: hoti iti pi manodaṇḍaḥ uva mahantaḥ bhijjitvā api cuti paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhanato esā iva mahantaḥ
translated: So the mind-punishment is the greater. It is the greater because it can lead to death and rebirth-linking even when broken.”

original: Amhākaṃ pana mahānigaṇṭhassa kathā aniyyānikā”ti sallakkhesi. Bhagavato pana vicittāni
analyzed: amhākam pana mahā nigaṇṭhassa kathā aniyyānikā ti sallakkhesi bhagavataḥ pana vicittāni
translated: but the doctrine of our great teacher Nigantha Nathaputta is not a doctrine of total Nibbāna.”🔽

original: pañhapaṭibhānāni sotukāmo na tāva anujānāti.🔽Na kho te sandhiyatīti na kho te ghaṭiyati. Purimena vā pacchimanti “kāyadaṇḍo mahanto”ti
analyzed: pañha paṭibhānāni sotu kāmaḥ na tāva anujānāti  na kho te sandhiyati iti na kho te ghaṭiyati purimena vā pacchimanti kāya daṇḍaḥ mahanto ti
translated: but the Great Ascetic’s talk is not emancipating. ” But he, being desirous of hearing the Blessed One’s various answers to questions, did not give his consent.🔽“It does not fit in with the former”: it does not fit in with the latter, or the former does not fit in with the latter.

original: iminā purimena vacanena idāni “manodaṇḍo mahanto”ti idaṃ vacanaṃ. Pacchimena vā purimanti
analyzed: iminā purimena vacanena idāni manodaṇḍaḥ mahantaḥ iti idam vacanam pacchimena vā purimanti
translated: “The bodily rod is great”: with this former statement, the present statement “the mental rod is great” does not fit in.

original: tena vā pacchimena aduṃ purimavacanaṃ na ghaṭiyati.
analyzed: tena vā pacchimena purima vacanam na
translated: Or with the latter, the former does not fit in.

original: 63. Idānissa bhagavā aññānipi kāraṇāni āharanto “taṃ kiṃ maññasī”tiādimāha. Tattha🔽cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvutoti na pāṇamatipāteti, na pāṇamatipātayati, na pāṇamatipātayato
analyzed: idāni ssa bhagavā aññāni api kāraṇāni āharantaḥ tam kim maññasi iti ādim āha tattha  cātuyāma saṃvara saṃvutaḥ uti na pāṇam atipāteti na pāṇam atipātayati na pāṇam atipātayataḥ
translated: Now the Blessed One, bringing up other reasons, said: “What do you think, Nigrodha? ”🔽“Restrained by the four-factored restraint”: he does not kill living beings, he does not cause others to kill living beings, he does not approve of killing living beings;

original: samanuñño hoti. Na adinnaṃ ādiyati, na adinnaṃ ādiyāpeti, na adinnaṃ ādiyato samanuñño
analyzed: samanuññaḥ hoti na adinnam ādiyati na adinnam ādiyāpeti na adinnam ādiyataḥ samanuññaḥ
translated: he does not take what is not given, he does not cause others to take what is not given, he does not approve of taking what is not given;

original: hoti. Na musā bhaṇati, na musā bhaṇāpeti, na musā bhaṇato samanuñño hoti. Na bhāvitamāsīsati,
analyzed: hoti na musā bhaṇati na musā bhaṇāpeti na musā bhaṇato samanuññaḥ hoti na bhāvitam āsīsati
translated: He does not tell lies, he does not instigate others to tell lies, he does not approve of telling lies. He does not long for what has not been prepared,

original: na bhāvitamāsīsāpeti, na bhāvitamāsīsato samanuñño hotīti iminā catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena
analyzed: na bhāvita māsīsa apeti na bhāvita māsīsataḥ samanuññaḥ hoti iti iminā catu koṭṭhāsena saṃvarena
translated: he does not instigate others to long for what has not been prepared, he does not approve of longing for what has not been prepared. He is restrained by this fourfold restraint.

original: saṃvuto. Ettha ca bhāvitanti pañcakāmaguṇā.
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇā
translated: And here, what has been prepared is the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: Sabbavārivāritoti vāritasabbaudako, paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti attho. So hi sītodake
analyzed: sabba vāri vārito ti vārita sabba odako paṭikkhitta sabba sīta udakaḥ ti attho saḥ hi sīta udake
translated: All water is barred: he has barred all water that is cool, the meaning is. For he has the perception of water,

original: sattasaññī hoti, tasmā na taṃ valañjeti. Atha vā sabbavārivāritoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena🔽vāritapāpo. Sabbavāriyuttoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena yutto. Sabbavāridhutoti sabbena
analyzed: satta saññī hoti tasmā na tam valañjeti atha vā sabba vāri vāritaḥ ti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena  vārita pāpaḥ sabba vāri yuttaḥ ti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena yuttaḥ sabba vāri dhutaḥ iti sabbena
translated: therefore he does not touch it. Or alternatively, all water is barred: he is barred from all evil by the barrier of all water,

original: pāpavāraṇena dhutapāpo. Sabbavāriphuṭoti sabbena pāpavāraṇena phuṭo. Khuddake pāṇe🔽saṅghātaṃ āpādetīti khuddake pāṇe vadhaṃ āpādeti. So kira ekindriyaṃ pāṇaṃ duvindriyaṃ
analyzed: pāpa vāraṇena dhuta pāpaḥ sabba vāri phuṭaḥ ti sabbena pāpa vāraṇena phuṭaḥ khuddake pāṇe 🔽saṅghātam āpādeti iti khuddake pāṇe vadham āpādeti saḥ kiraḥ eka indriyam pāṇam duvindriyam
translated: he is joined to all water, he is purified by all water, he is covered by all water. He inflicts death on small creatures: he inflicts death on small creatures. It seems that he inflicts death on a creature with one sense-organ, or on a creature with two sense-organs,

original: pāṇanti paññapeti. Sukkhadaṇḍaka-purāṇapaṇṇasakkhara-kathalānipi pāṇoteva paññapeti.
analyzed: pāṇanti paññapeti sukkha daṇḍaka purāṇa paṇṇa sakkhara kathalāni pi pāṇa uta iva paññapeti
translated: He defines ‘living beings’ as the small water animal called the ‘sukkha-daṇḍaka’, the ‘purāṇa-paṇṇa’, the ‘sakkharaka’, and the ‘kathala’.

original: Tattha khuddakaṃ udakabindu khuddako pāṇo, mahantaṃ mahantoti saññī hoti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ
analyzed: tattha khuddakam udaka bindu khuddakaḥ pāṇaḥ mahantam mahanto ti saññī hoti tam sandhāya itam
translated: Herein, he is aware of the small water animal as ‘small’, and of the large one as ‘large’.🔽This is said with reference to that.

original: vuttaṃ. Kismiṃ paññapetīti kattha katarasmiṃ koṭṭhāse paññapeti. Manodaṇḍasminti
analyzed: vuttam kismin paññapeti iti kattha katarasmin koṭṭhāse paññapeti manodaṇḍasmin ti
translated: ‘In what way does he define?’ means ‘in which place, in which part does he define?’🔽‘In the mind-rod’ means in the part of the mind-rod.

original: manodaṇḍakoṭṭhāse, bhanteti. Ayaṃ pana upāsako bhaṇantova sayampi sallakkhesi – “amhākaṃ
analyzed: manodaṇḍa koṭṭhāse bhante ti ayam pana upāsakaḥ bhaṇantaḥ iva sayam pi sallakkhesi amhākam
translated: ‘Venerable Sir’ means ‘this lay follower, while speaking, himself considers thus:

original: mahānigaṇṭho ‘asañcetanikaṃ kammaṃ appasāvajjaṃ, sañcetanikaṃ mahāsāvajja’nti paññapetvā
analyzed: mahā nigaṇṭhaḥ a sañcetanikam kammam appa sāvajjam sañcetanikam mahā sāvajjanti paññapetvā
translated: “Our great Nigaṇṭha, after defining ‘unintentional action is less blameworthy, intentional action is more blameworthy’,

original: cetanaṃ manodaṇḍoti paññapeti, aniyyānikā etassa kathā, bhagavatova niyyānikā”ti.
analyzed: cetanam manodaṇḍo ti paññapeti aniyyānikā etassa kathā bhagavataḥ va niyyānikā ati
translated: defines ‘intention’ as the mind-rod. His talk is not emancipating, but the Blessed One’s talk is emancipating.”’

original: 64. Iddhāti samiddhā. Phītāti atisamiddhā sabbapāliphullā viya. Ākiṇṇamanussāti janasamākulā.
analyzed: iddhā ati samiddhā phītā ati ati samiddhā sabba pāli phullā viya ākiṇṇa manussā ati jana samākulā
translated: ‘Prosperous’ means ‘prospering’. ‘Flourishing’ means ‘very prosperous’, like a fully blossomed flower. ‘Crowded with people’ means ‘full of people’.

original: Pāṇāti hatthiassādayo tiracchānagatā ceva itthipurisadārakādayo manussajātikā ca.
analyzed: hatthi assa ādayaḥ tiracchāna gatā ca iva itthi purisa dāraka ādayaḥ manussa jātikā ca
translated: ‘Living beings’ means elephants, horses, etc., animals, and human beings such as women, men, boys, and girls.

original: Ekaṃ maṃsakhalanti ekaṃ maṃsarāsiṃ. Puñjanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Iddhimāti ānubhāvasampanno.
analyzed: ekam maṃsa khalanti ekam maṃsa rāsim puñjanti tassa iva vevacanam iddhimā ati ānubhāva sampannaḥ
translated: A single heap of flesh: a single mass of flesh. A single pile: a synonym for the same thing. He had psychic power: he was endowed with the ability to work miracles.

original: Cetovasippattoti citte vasībhāvappatto. Bhasmaṃ karissāmīti chārikaṃ karissāmi. Kiñhi🔽sobhati ekā chavā nāḷandāti idampi bhaṇanto so gahapati – “kāyapayogena paññāsampi🔽manussā ekaṃ nāḷandaṃ ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ kātuṃ na sakkonti, iddhimā pana eko ekeneva
analyzed: cetaḥ vasi patto ti citte vasībhāva ppattaḥ bhasmam karissāmi iti chārikam karissāmi kim hi  sobhati ekā chavā na āḷandāti idampi bhaṇanto so gahapati kāya payogena  manussāḥ ekam nāḷandam ekam maṃsa khalam kātum na sakkonti iddhimā pana ekaḥ ekena iva
translated: He had attained mental mastery: he had attained mastery over his mind. I will reduce it to ashes: I will reduce it to cinders. What is the use of🔽a single corpse, a single Nāḷandā?

original: manopadosena bhasmaṃ kātuṃ samattho. Amhākaṃ mahānigaṇṭhassa kathā aniyyānikā, bhagavatova🔽kathā niyyānikā”ti sallakkhesi.🔽65. Araññaṃ araññabhūtanti agāmakaṃ araññameva hutvā araññaṃ jātaṃ. Isīnaṃ manopadosenāti
analyzed: manaḥ upadosena bhasmam kātum samatthaḥ amhākam mahā nigaṇṭhassa kathā a niyyānikā bhagavataḥ iva  kathā niyyānikā ati sallakkhesi  araññam arañña bhūtanti agāmakam araññam eva hutvā araññam jātam isīnam manaḥ upadosena ati
translated: As he said this, the householder reflected: “Even with the help of the body, fifty men cannot make a single Nāḷandā into a single heap of flesh, but a man of psychic power can reduce it to ashes with a single angry thought. The doctrine of our great Nigaṇṭha is not emancipating, but the doctrine of the Exalted One is emancipating.”

original: isīnaṃ atthāya katena manopadosena taṃ manopadosaṃ asahamānāhi devatāhi tāni raṭṭhāni
analyzed: isīnam atthāya katena manopadosena tam manopadosam asahamānāhi devatāhi tāni
translated: . The forest became a forest as it was before: it became a forest as it was before it was turned into a non-forest. By the angry thought of the seers: the deities, unable to endure that angry thought which had arisen for the sake of the seers,🔽destroyed those kingdoms.

original: vināsitāni. Lokikā pana isayo manaṃ padosetvā vināsayiṃsūti maññanti. Tasmā imasmiṃ
analyzed: vināsitāni lokikā pana isayaḥ manam padosetvā vināsayiṃsū iti maññanti tasmai imasmin
translated: but the worldlings think that the seers destroyed them by their anger.🔽

original: lokavāde ṭhatvāva idaṃ vādāropanaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: lokavāde idam vāda āropanam kata nti veditabbam
translated: and the world-renouncing sages destroyed them by arousing anger in their minds. Therefore it should be understood that this argument is put forward by one who stands on the doctrine of the world-creator.

original: Tattha daṇḍakīraññādīnaṃ evaṃ araññabhūtabhāvo jānitabbo – sarabhaṅgabodhisattassa
analyzed: tattha daṇḍakīrañña ādīnam evam arañña bhūta bhāvaḥ jānitabbaḥ sarabhaṅga bodhisattassa
translated: Herein, the state of being a forest should be understood in the case of King Daṇḍaki and the rest in this way.

original: tāva parisāya ativepullataṃ gatāya kisavaccho nāma tāpaso mahāsattassa antevāsī vivekavāsaṃ
analyzed: tāva parisāya ativepullatam gatāya kisavacchaḥ nāma tāpasaḥ mahāsattassa antevāsī viveka vāsam
translated: When the assembly of the Bodhisatta Sarabhṅga had become very large, a certain ascetic named Kisavaccha, who was a pupil of the Great Being,

original: patthayamāno gaṇaṃ pahāya godhāvarītīrato kaliṅgaraṭṭhe daṇḍakīrañño kumbhapuraṃ
analyzed: patthayamānaḥ gaṇam pahāya godhāvarī tīrataḥ kaliṅga raṭṭhe daṇḍakī raññaḥ kumbhapuram
translated: desiring a secluded abode, left the assembly, crossed the Godhāvarī River, and in the Kaliṅga country, near the city of Kumbhapurī of King Daṇḍaki,

original: nāma nagaraṃ upanissāya rājuyyāne vivekamanubrūhayamāno viharati. Tassa senāpati upaṭṭhāko hoti.
analyzed: nāma nagaram upanissāya rāja uyyāne vivekam anubrūhayamānaḥ viharati tassa senāpati upaṭṭhākaḥ hoti
translated: he lived in the royal park, pursuing the life of seclusion. The general of the army was his supporter.

original: Tadā ca ekā gaṇikā rathaṃ abhiruhitvā pañcamātugāmasataparivārā nagaraṃ upasobhayamānā
analyzed: tadā ca ekā gaṇikā ratham abhiruhitvā pañca mātu gāma sata parivārā nagaram upasobhayamānā
translated: At that time a certain courtesan, mounted on a chariot, surrounded by five hundred women,

original: vicarati. Mahājano tameva olokayamāno parivāretvā vicarati, nagaravīthiyo nappahonti.
analyzed: vicarati mahājanaḥ tam eva olokayamānaḥ parivāretvā vicarati nagara vīthiyaḥ
translated: was going about adorning the city. The multitude, looking at her, surrounded her and went about in such a way that the city streets could not accommodate them.

original: Rājā vātapānaṃ vivaritvā ṭhito taṃ disvā kā esāti pucchi. Tumhākaṃ nagarasobhinī
analyzed: rājā vātapānam tam disvā kā esā ati pucchi tumhākam nagara sobhinī
translated: The king, who was standing by the window, saw her and asked, “Who is that?” “Your city ornament, your majesty.”

original: devāti. So ussūyamāno “kiṃ etāya sobhati, nagaraṃ sayaṃ sobhissatī”ti taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ acchindāpesi.
analyzed: devāti saḥ ussūyamānaḥ kim etāya sobhati nagaram sayam sobhissati iti tam
translated: The king was angry and said, “What is she good for? The city itself is the ornament.” And he deprived her of her office.

original: Sā tato paṭṭhāya kenaci saddhiṃ santhavaṃ katvā ṭhānantaraṃ pariyesamānā ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: sā tatas paṭṭhāya kenacid saddhim santhavam katvā ṭhāna antaram pariyesamānā eka divasam
translated: From that time on, whenever she had anything to do with anyone, she sought a reward. One day

original: rājuyyānaṃ pavisitvā caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ālambanaphalakaṃ nissāya pāsāṇaphalake nisinnaṃ
analyzed: rāja uyyānam pavisitvā caṅkamana koṭiyam ālambana phalakam nissāya pāsāṇa phalake nisinnam
translated: she went into the royal park and sat down on a stone slab leaning against a post at the end of a walk.

original: tāpasaṃ disvā cintesi – “kiliṭṭho vatāyaṃ tāpaso anañjitamaṇḍito, dāṭhikāhi paruḷhāhi
analyzed: tāpasam disvā cintesi kiliṭṭhaḥ vata ayam tāpasaḥ an añjita maṇḍitaḥ dāṭhikāhi paruḷhāhi
translated: There she saw a certain ascetic sitting cross-legged on the ground. She thought to herself, “How dirty that ascetic is! He is not even anointed with oil.

original: mukhaṃ pihitaṃ, massunā uraṃ pihitaṃ, ubho kacchā paruḷhā”ti. Athassā domanassaṃ

original: pana aṅgaṇe nipajji.

translated: But the Bodhisatta lay down in the courtyard.🔽They told the merchant, “The outcaste has fallen in your courtyard.”
