original: pāsādaṃ āruyha supupphitakiṃsukasākhaṃ ucchindantā viya tassā sabbābharaṇāni omuñcitvā🔽nakhehi sīmantaṃ katvā kese bandhitvā nīlasāṭakaṃ nivāsāpetvā hatthe nīlapilotikakhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: pāsādam āruyha su pupphita kiṃsuka sākham ucchindantā viya tassā sabba ābharaṇāni omuñcitvā  nakhehi sīmantam katvā kese bandhitvā nīla sāṭakam hatthe nīla pilotika khaṇḍam
translated: went up to the palace and, as if cutting off a branch of the coral-tree in full blossom, they took off all her ornaments,🔽made a parting in her hair with their nails, tied up her hair, dressed her in a blue garment,🔽wrapped a piece of blue cloth round her hands,

original: veṭhetvā kaṇṇesu tipupaṭṭake piḷandhāpetvā tālapaṇṇapacchiṃ datvā pāsādato otārāpetvā
analyzed: veṭhetvā kaṇṇesu tipu paṭṭake piḷandhāpetvā tālapaṇṇa pacchim datvā pāsādataḥ otārāpetvā
translated: put two strips of bark round her ears, gave her a palm-leaf basket, and made her come down from the palace.

original: dvīsu bāhāsu gahetvā – “tava sāmikaṃ gahetvā yāhī”ti mahāpurisassa adaṃsu.
analyzed: dvīsu bāhāsu gahetvā tava sāmikam gahetvā yāhi iti mahāpurisassa adaṃsu
translated: and taking him by the arms, said to the Great Man, “Take your husband and go.”

original: Nīluppalampi atibhāroti anukkhittapubbā sukhumāladārikā “uṭṭhāhi sāmi, gacchāmā”ti
analyzed: nīluppalam pi atibhāro ti an ukkhitta pubbā sukhumāla dārikā uṭṭhāhi sāmi gacchāma ati
translated: But Nīluppalā, who was a very delicate girl, and had never before been so much as touched by a man, said, “Rise up, my husband, let us go.”

original: āha. Bodhisatto nipannakova āha “nāhaṃ uṭṭhahāmī”ti. Atha kinti vadāmīti. “Uṭṭhehi
analyzed: āha bodhisattaḥ nipannakaḥ iva āha na aham uṭṭhahāmi iti atha kinti vadāmi iti uṭṭhehi
translated: But the Bodhisatta, still lying down, said, “I will not rise up.”🔽“Then what shall I say?” “Say, ‘Rise up, Master Mātaṅga.’ ”

original: ayya mātaṅgā”ti evaṃ maṃ vadāhīti. Sā tathā avoca. Na tuyhaṃ manussā uṭṭhānasamatthaṃ
analyzed: ayya mātaṅga ati evam mama vadāhi iti sā tathā avoca na tuyham manussāḥ uṭṭhāna samattham
translated: She did so. “You men have not the strength to make me rise up.🔽Take me up in your arms and carry me.” She did so.

original: maṃ akaṃsu, bāhāya maṃ gahetvā uṭṭhāpehīti. Sā tathā akāsi. Bodhisatto uṭṭhahanto
analyzed: mam akaṃsu bāhāya mam gahetvā uṭṭhāpehi iti sā tathā akāsi bodhisattaḥ uṭṭhahantaḥ
translated: As the Bodhisatta rose up, he turned over, and fell to the ground, and cried out, “Ah!

original: viya parivaṭṭetvā bhūmiyaṃ patitvā – “nāsitaṃ, bho, diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya paṭhamaṃ manussehi
analyzed: viya parivaṭṭetvā bhūmiyam patitvā na āsitam bho diṭṭha maṅgalikāya paṭhamam manussehi
translated: Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā has had me beaten by men, and now she beats me herself.”

original: koṭṭāpetvā, idāni sayaṃ koṭṭetī”ti viravittha. Sā kiṃ karomi ayyāti? Dvīhi hatthehi
analyzed: koṭṭāpetvā idāni sayam koṭṭeti iti viravittha sā kim karomi ayyā ati dvīhi hatthehi
translated: “What shall I do, Master?” “Take me up in your arms and carry me.”

original: gahetvā uṭṭhāpehīti. Sā tathā uṭṭhāpetvā nisīdāpetvā gacchāma sāmīti. Gacchā nāma
analyzed: gahetvā uṭṭhāpehi iti sā tathā uṭṭhāpetvā nisīdāpetvā gacchāma sāmi iti gaccha nāma
translated: She did so, and then made him sit down, and said, “Let us go, my husband.” “Let us go.”

original: araññe honti, mayaṃ manussā, atikoṭṭitomhi tuyhaṃ manussehi, na sakkomi padasā gantuṃ,
analyzed: araññe honti mayam manussāḥ atikoṭṭitaḥ amhi tuyham manussehi na sakkomi padasā gantum
translated: “I am a man, and your men have beaten me too much. I cannot walk.

original: piṭṭhiyā maṃ nehīti. Sā onamitvā piṭṭhiṃ adāsi. Bodhisatto abhiruhi. Kuhiṃ nemi sāmīti?
analyzed: piṭṭhiyāḥ mama nehi iti sā onamitvā piṭṭhim adāsi bodhisattaḥ abhiruhi kuhim nemi sāmi iti
translated: Carry me on your back.” She bent down and gave him her back. The Bodhisatta mounted. “Where shall I take you, my lord?”

original: Bahinagaraṃ nehīti. Sā pācīnadvāraṃ gantvā – “idha te sāmi vasanaṭṭhāna”nti pucchi.
analyzed: bahi nagaram nehi iti sā pācīna dvāram gantvā idha te sāmi vasana ṭṭhānanti pucchi
translated: “To the outskirts of the city.” She went to the eastern gate and asked, “Is this the place, my lord, where you wish to live?”

original: Kataraṭṭhānaṃ etanti? Pācīnadvāraṃ sāmīti. Pācīnadvāre caṇḍālaputtā vasituṃ na labhantīti
analyzed: katara ṭṭhānam etat ti pācīna dvāram sāmi iti pācīna dvāre caṇḍāla puttāḥ vasitum na labhanti iti
translated: “What place is this?” “The eastern gate, my lord.” “The outcasts cannot live at the eastern gate.”

original: attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ anācikkhitvāva sabbadvārāni āhiṇḍāpesi. Kasmā? Bhavaggapattamassā
analyzed: attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam an ācikkhitvā ava sabba dvārāni āhiṇḍāpesi kasmai
translated: So she did not point out her own dwelling-place, but made him go to all the gates. Why?

original: mānaṃ pātessāmīti. Mahājano ukkuṭṭhimakāsi – “ṭhapetvā tumhādisaṃ añño etissā mānaṃ bhedako natthī”ti.
analyzed: mānam pātessāmi iti mahā janaḥ ukkuṭṭhim akāsi ṭhapetvā tumha ādisam aññaḥ etissā mānam bhedakaḥ natthi iti
translated: Because she thought, “I will break his pride.” A great crowd gathered, and they all cried out, “Except one like you, there is no one else who can break her pride.”

original: Sā pacchimadvāraṃ patvā “idha te sāmi vasanaṭṭhāna”nti pucchi. Kataraṭṭhānaṃ etanti?
analyzed: sā pacchima dvāram patvā idha te sāmi vasana ṭṭhānan ti pucchi katara ṭṭhānam etat ti
translated: She went to the western gate and asked, “Is this the place, my lord, where you wish to live?” “What place is this?”

original: Pacchimadvāraṃ sāmīti. Iminā dvārena nikkhamitvā cammagehaṃ olokentī gacchāti. Sā🔽tattha gantvā āha “idaṃ cammagehaṃ tumhākaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ sāmī”ti? Āmāti piṭṭhito
analyzed: pacchima dvāram sāmi iti iminā dvārena nikkhamitvā camma geham olokentī gacchāti sā  tattha gantvā āha idam camma geham tumhākam vasana ṭhānam sāmi iti āma ati piṭṭhitaḥ
translated: “This is the western gate.” “By this gate I shall go out and look at the house of the raiment.”🔽She went there and said, “This is the house of the raiment, my lord.” “Yes.”

original: otaritvā cammagehaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: otaritvā camma geham pāvisi
translated: She descended from the back of the elephant and entered the house of the raiment.

original: Tattha sattaṭṭhadivase vasanto sabbaññutagavesanadhīro ettakesu divasesu na ca jātisambhedamakāsi.

translated: There she stayed seven or eight days. The hero who was seeking omniscience did not distinguish between the days during that period.

analyzed: mahā kulassa dhītā sace mam nissāya mahantam yasam na pāpuṇāti na camhā aham catuvīsatiyā
translated: “If I do not obtain great fame by depending on her, I am not the disciple of the twenty-four Buddhas.

original: buddhānaṃ antevāsiko. Etissā pādadhovanaudakena sakalajambudīpe rājūnaṃ abhisekakiccaṃ🔽karissāmī”ti cintetvā puna cintesi – “agāramajjhevasanto na sakkhissāmi, pabbajitvā
analyzed: buddhānam antevāsikaḥ etissā pāda dhovana odakena sakala jambudīpe rājūnam abhiseka kiccam  karissāmi iti cintetvā puna cintesi agāram ajjhevasantaḥ na sakkhissāmi pabbajitvā
translated: I shall perform the consecration of the kings of the whole of Jambudīpa with the water that has been used for washing her feet.”🔽He thought further, “I shall not be able to do this while I am in the midst of the householders. But if I go forth, I shall be able to do it.”

original: pana sakkhissāmī”ti. Cintetvā taṃ āmantesi – “diṭṭhamaṅgalike mayaṃ pubbe ekacarā
analyzed: pana sakkhissāmi iti cintetvā tam āmantesi diṭṭha maṅgalike mayam pubbe ekacarā

analyzed: kammam katvā api a katvā api sakkāḥ jīvitum idāni pana dāra bharaṇam paṭipannamha kammaṃ
translated: “Whether we do or do not do the work, we can live. But now we have taken a wife, and we must do the work.

analyzed: a katvā na sakkā jīvitum tvam yāva aham āgacchāmi tāva mā ukkaṇṭhittha ati araññam
translated: “I can live without doing it, but now that I have taken a wife, I cannot live without doing it. Do not despair while I am away.”

analyzed: pavisitvā susāna ādīsu nantakāni saṅkaḍḍhitvā nivāsana pārupanam katvā samaṇa pabbajjam

analyzed: paharitvā viravamānā pāda mūle patitvā āha yadi te sāmi edisam cittam atthi kasmai
translated: and falling at his feet, she cried out, “If you have such feelings, why did you

analyzed: mam mahatā yasā parihāpetvā anātham akāsi iti nānappakāram paridevam paridevitvā

original: disvā nigaṇṭhaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchante – “kiṃ ayaṃ upāli diṭṭhadiṭṭhameva saraṇaṃ gacchatī”ti?
analyzed: disvā nigaṇṭham saraṇam gacchante  kim ayam upāli diṭṭha diṭṭham eva saraṇam gacchati iti
translated: and these to one who is not seen?”

original: Garahā uppajjissati, tasmā anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ sādhūti dasseti. Paṭākaṃ parihareyyunti
analyzed: garahā uppajjissati tasmai anuviccakāro tumha ādisānam sādhu iti dasseti paṭākam parihareyyunti
translated: Criticism would arise, and so he shows that it would be good if you were to consider the matter. “Should take down the flag”:

original: te kira evarūpaṃ sāvakaṃ labhitvā – “asuko nāma rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā seṭṭhi vā
analyzed: te kira evarūpam sāvakam labhitvā asukaḥ nāma rājā vā rāja mahāmattaḥ vā seṭṭhi vā
translated: it seems that when they got such a disciple, they would hoist a flag and go about the town proclaiming: “So-and-so, a king or a royal minister or a merchant,

original: amhākaṃ saraṇaṃ gato sāvako jāto”ti paṭākaṃ ukkhipitvā nagare ghosentā āhiṇḍanti.
analyzed: amhākam saraṇam gataḥ sāvakaḥ jātaḥ iti paṭākam ukkhipitvā nagare ghosentāḥ āhiṇḍanti
translated: has gone for refuge to us; he is our disciple.”🔽“

original: Kasmā? Evaṃ no mahantabhāvo āvi bhavissatīti ca, sace tassa “kimahaṃ etesaṃ saraṇaṃ
analyzed: kasmai evam naḥ mahanta bhāvaḥ āvi bhavissati iti ca sace tassa kim aham etesam saraṇam
translated: Why? “So our greatness will be known.” And if he thinks: “What is the use of my going for refuge to them?

original: gato”ti vippaṭisāro uppajjeyya, tampi so “etesaṃ me saraṇagatabhāvaṃ bahū jānanti,
analyzed: gataḥ ti vippaṭisāraḥ uppajjeyya tam pi saḥ etesam me saraṇa gata bhāvam bahū jānanti
translated: Why? So that our greatness may be known. And if he should have any regret, thinking, “Why did I go for refuge to them?” he would dispel it, thinking, “Many people know that I have gone for refuge to them.

original: dukkhaṃ idāni paṭinivattitu”nti vinodetvā na paṭikkamissatīti ca. “Tenāha paṭākaṃ parihareyyu”nti.🔽68. Opānabhūtanti paṭiyattaudapāno viya ṭhitaṃ. Kulanti tava nivesanaṃ. Dātabbaṃ
analyzed: dukkham idāni paṭinivattitunti vinodetvā na paṭikkamissati iti ca tena āha paṭākam parihareyyun ti  opāna bhūtanti viya ṭhitam kulanti tava nivesanam dātabbam
translated: It would be difficult for me to turn back now.” And he would not turn back. Therefore it is said: “He would remove the flag.”

original: maññeyyāsīti pubbe dasapi vīsatipi saṭṭhipi jane āgate disvā natthīti avatvā deti.
analyzed: maññeyyāsi iti pubbe dasapi vīsatipi saṭṭhipi jane āgate disvā na atthi iti avatvā deti
translated: “A place of rest”: a place where water is kept ready for travelers. “Your house”: your home. “You would think”: in the past, when ten, twenty, or thirty people came, you gave them food without saying “There is none.”

original: Idāni maṃ saraṇaṃ gatakāraṇamattenava mā imesaṃ deyyadhammaṃ, upacchindittha, sampattānañhi🔽dātabbamevāti ovadati. Sutametaṃ, bhanteti kuto sutaṃ? Nigaṇṭhānaṃ santikā, te kira
analyzed: idāni mam saraṇam gata kāraṇa mattena iva mā imesam deyya dhammam upacchindittha sampattānam hi  dātabbam eva ati ovadati sutam etam bhante iti kutas sutam nigaṇṭhānam santikā te kira
translated: Now, do not cut off the gifts to those who have come to you merely because they have gone for refuge to me. For what has been given to those who have come should be given.🔽“Venerable sir, I have heard this:” Where did you hear this? From the Niganthas. For they proclaim in the families of the faithful:

original: kulagharesu evaṃ pakāsenti – “mayaṃ ‘yassa kassaci sampattassa dātabba’nti vadāma,
analyzed: kula gharesu evam pakāsenti mayam yassa kassaci sampattassa dātabbanti vadāma
translated: “We say that what has been given to those who have come should be given to them.

original: samaṇo pana gotamo ‘mayhameva dānaṃ dātabbaṃ…pe… na aññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphala’nti🔽vadatī”ti. Taṃ sandhāya ayaṃ gahapati “sutameta”nti āha.🔽69. Anupubbiṃ kathanti dānānantaraṃ sīlaṃ, sīlānantaraṃ saggaṃ, saggānantaraṃ magganti
analyzed: samaṇaḥ pana gotamaḥ mayham eva dānam dātabbam pe na aññesam sāvakānam dinnam mahapphalanti  vadati iti tam sandhāya ayam gahapati sutam etat iti āha  anupubbim kathanti dāna anantaram sīlam sīla anantaram saggam sagga anantaram magganti
translated: ” The householder said, “I have heard this too,”🔽“A talk in due course” is a talk in the regular sequence beginning with generosity, virtue, and heaven, and ending with the determination of the four noble truths.🔽Herein, “a talk on generosity” is a talk on giving, which is the source of happiness, the source of welfare, the source of heaven,🔽the source of the imperturbable, the source of the right path, the source of the right way, the source of the right method, the source of the unconditioned,

original: evaṃ anupaṭipāṭikathaṃ. Tattha dānakathanti idaṃ dānaṃ nāma sukhānaṃ nidānaṃ, sampattīnaṃ
analyzed: evam anupaṭipāṭi katham tattha dāna kathanti idam dānam nāma sukhānam nidānam sampattīnam
translated: the source of Nibbāna. For this generosity is like a mother in being the source of happiness, like a field in being the source of welfare,🔽like a cloud in being the source of heaven, like a mine in being the source of the imperturbable, like a guide in being the source of the right path,

original: mūlaṃ, bhogānaṃ patiṭṭhā, visamagatassa tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gatiparāyaṇaṃ, idhalokaparalokesu
analyzed: mūlam bhogānam patiṭṭhā visama gatassa tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam idhaloka paralokesu
translated: like a caravan leader in being the source of the right way, like a boat in being the source of the right method, like a river in being the source of the unconditioned,

original: dānasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi. Idañhi🔽avassayaṭṭhena ratanamayasīhāsanasadisaṃ, patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena mahāpathavisadisaṃ, ālambanaṭṭhena
analyzed: dāna sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi idam hi  avassaya ṭṭhena ratana maya sīhāsana sadisam patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena mahā pathavi sadisam ālambana ṭṭhena
translated: like a city in being the source of Nibbāna. For this generosity is a refuge, a support, a resting-place, a place of last resort, a guide, a light, a torch-bearer, a lamp, and a means of deliverance for beings in the sense of being a refuge in the sense of being a jewel throne,

original: ālambanarajjusadisaṃ. Idañhi dukkhanittharaṇaṭṭhena nāvā, samassāsanaṭṭhena saṅgāmasūro,
analyzed: ālambana rajju sadisam idam hi dukkha nittharaṇa ṭhena nāvā samassāsana ṭhena
translated: in the sense of being a support in the sense of being a great highway, in the sense of being a resting-place in the sense of being a great earth, in the sense of being a place of last resort in the sense of being a great ocean, in the sense of being a guide in the sense of being a caravan leader, in the sense of being a light in the sense of being the sun, in the sense of being a torch-bearer in the sense of being the moon, in the sense of being a lamp in the sense of being a jewel lamp, in the sense of being a means of deliverance in the sense of being a raft.

original: bhayaparittāṇaṭṭhena susaṅkhatanagaraṃ, maccheramalādīhi anupalittaṭṭhena padumaṃ,🔽tesaṃ nidahanaṭṭhena aggi, durāsadaṭṭhena āsīviso. Asantāsanaṭṭhena sīho, balavantaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhaya parittāṇa ṭṭhena susaṅkhata nagaram macchera mala ādīhi an upalitta ṭṭhena padumam  tesam nidahana ṭṭhena aggi durāsada ṭṭhena āsīvisaḥ asanta asana ṭṭhena sīhaḥ balavanta ṭṭhena
translated: It is a well-built city in the sense of being a protection from fear; a lotus in the sense of being unstained by the stain of selfishness;🔽a fire in the sense of burning up their causes; a poisonous snake in the sense of being hard to approach; a lion in the sense of being unperturbed;

original: hatthī, abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena setavasabho, khemantabhūmisampāpanaṭṭhena valāhako
analyzed: hatthī abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena setavasabhaḥ khemanta bhūmi sampāpana ṭṭhena valāhako
translated: an elephant in the sense of being powerful; a white bull in the sense of being highly esteemed; a rain-cloud in the sense of bringing about a state of peace.

original: assarājā. Dānaṃ nāmebhaṃ mayhaṃ gatamaggo, mayheveso vaṃso, mayā dasa pāramiyo pūrentena
analyzed: assa rājā dānam nāma ibham mayham gata maggaḥ mayhā iva isaḥ vaṃsaḥ mayā dasa pāramiyaḥ pūrentena
translated: The gift is my path gone, this is my lineage, by me fulfilling the ten perfections

original: velāmamahāyañño, mahāgovindamahāyañño mahāsudassanamahāyañño, vessantaramahāyaññoti
analyzed: velāma mahāyaññaḥ mahāgovinda mahāyaññaḥ mahāsudassana mahāyaññaḥ vessantara mahāyaññaḥ iti
translated: the Velama Great Sacrifice, the Great Govinda Great Sacrifice, the Great Sudassana Great Sacrifice, the Vessantara Great Sacrifice

original: anekamahāyaññā pavattitā, sasabhūtena jalite aggikkhandhe attānaṃ niyyādentena sampattayācakānaṃ
analyzed: aneka mahā yaññā pavattitā sasa bhūtena jalite aggi kkhandhe attānam niyyādentena sampatta yācakānam
translated: many great sacrifices were performed, by me offering myself into the burning fire-heap, the minds of the supplicants

original: cittaṃ gahitaṃ. Dānañhi loke sakkasampattiṃ deti, mārasampattiṃ deti, brahmasampattiṃ
analyzed: cittam gahitam dānam hi loke sakka sampattim deti māra sampattim deti brahma sampattim
translated: were captured. For the gift gives in the world the prosperity of Sakka, the prosperity of Mara, the prosperity of Brahma,

original: deti, cakkavattisampattiṃ deti, sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ, paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ, abhisambodhiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: deti cakkavatti sampattim deti sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paccekabodhi ñāṇam abhisambodhi ñāṇam
translated: he gives the equipment of a Universal Monarch, he gives the knowledge of the perfection of disciples, he gives the knowledge of the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha, he gives the knowledge of the supreme enlightenment,

original: detīti evamādiṃ dānaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: deti iti evamādim dāna guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: he gives’ and so on, is a talk connected with the virtue of giving.

original: Yasmā pana dānaṃ dadanto sīlaṃ samādātuṃ sakkoti, tasmā tadanataraṃ sīlakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: yasmai pana dānam dadantaḥ sīlam samādātum sakkoti tasmai tad anataram sīla katham kathesi
translated: But because, when giving a gift, one is able to undertake virtue, therefore, next to that, he spoke a talk on virtue.

original: Sīlakathanti sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ,
analyzed: sīlakathanti sīlam nāma etam avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam
translated: ‘A talk on virtue’: this virtue is a support, a foundation, a basis, a refuge, a shelter, a final relief, a last resource,

original: sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ mama vaṃso, ahaṃ saṅkhapālanāgarājakāle, bhūridattanāgarājakāle, campeyyanāgarājakāle,
analyzed: sīlam nāma itam mama aham saṅkhapāla nāga rāja kāle bhūridatta nāga rāja kāle campeyya nāga rāja kāle
translated: this virtue is my family, in the time when I was the nāga king Saṅkhapāla, in the time when I was the nāga king Bhūridatta, in the time when I was the nāga king Campeyya,

original: sīlavanāgarājakāle, mātuposakahatthirājakāle, chaddantahatthirājakāleti anantesu🔽attabhāvesu sīlaṃ paripūresiṃ. Idhalokaparalokasampattīnañhi sīlasadiso avassayo,
analyzed: sīlava nāga rāja kāle mātu posaka hatthi rāja kāle chaddanta hatthi rāja kāla iti anantesu  atta bhāvesu sīlam idha loka para loka sampattīnam hi sīla sadisaḥ avassayaḥ
translated: in the time when I was the nāga king Sīlava, in the time when I was the elephant king Mātāposaka, in the time when I was the elephant king Chaddanta, in countless🔽existences I fulfilled virtue. For there is no support like virtue, no foundation, no basis, no refuge, no shelter, no final relief, no last resource like virtue,

original: sīlasadisā patiṭṭhā, ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi, sīlālaṅkārasadiso
analyzed: sīla sadisā patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam natthi sīla alaṅkāra sadisaḥ
translated: there is no ornament like the ornament of virtue,

original: alaṅkāro natthi, sīlapupphasadisaṃ pupphaṃ natthi, sīlagandhasadiso gandho natthi.
analyzed: alaṅkāraḥ natthi sīla puppha sadisam puppham natthi sīla gandha sadisaḥ gandhaḥ natthi
translated: There is no ornament like virtue, no flower like virtue, no scent like the scent of virtue.

original: Sīlālaṅkārena hi alaṅkataṃ sīlakusumapiḷandhanaṃ sīlagandhānulittaṃ sadevakopi loko
analyzed: sīla alaṅkārena hi alaṅkatam sīla kusuma piḷandhanam sīla gandha anulittam
translated: For the world with its gods looks on one adorned with the ornament of virtue, sprinkled with the flower of virtue, anointed with the scent of virtue,🔽and never has its fill of looking.

original: olokento tittiṃ na gacchatīti evamādiṃ sīlaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: olokentaḥ tittim na gacchati iti evamādim sīla guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: And so on. This is the kind of talk he gave on the subject of virtue.

original: Idaṃ pana sīlaṃ nissāya ayaṃ saggo labbhatīti dassetuṃ sīlānantaraṃ saggakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: idam pana sīlam nissāya ayam saggo labbhati iti dassetum sīla anantaram sagga katham kathesi
translated: But in order to show that it is by means of virtue that heaven is obtained, he gave talk on heaven next to the talk on virtue.

original: Saggakathanti ayaṃ saggo nāma iṭṭho kanto manāpo, niccamettha kīḷā, niccaṃ sampattiyo🔽labbhanti, cātumahārājikā devā navutivassasatasahassāni dibbasukhaṃ dibbasampattiṃ
analyzed: sagga kathanti ayam saggaḥ nāma iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ niccam ettha kīḷā niccam sampattiyaḥ  labbhanti cātumahārājikāḥ devāḥ navuti vassa sata sahassāni dibba sukham dibba sampattim
translated: “Talk on heaven” is talk on the subject of heaven, which is desirable, lovely, agreeable, and which people are not fed up with looking at,

original: anubhavanti, tāvatiṃsā tisso ca vassakoṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassasatasahassānīti evamādiṃ
analyzed: anubhavanti tāvatiṃsā tissaḥ ca vassa koṭiyaḥ saṭṭhi ca vassa sata sahassāni iti evamādim
translated: for in heaven gods experience divine happiness and divine well-being for nine hundred thousand years, and the Thirty-Three for three hundred and sixty thousand years, and so on.

original: saggaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ. Saggasampattiṃ kathayantānañhi buddhānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti.
analyzed: sagga guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham sagga sampattim kathayantānam hi buddhānam mukham nappahoti
translated: This is the kind of talk he gave on the subject of heaven. For the Buddhas’ faces do not open out to give talk on the subject of the happiness of heaven.

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ “anekapariyāyena kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, saggakathaṃ katheyya”ntiādi.
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam aneka pariyāyena kho aham bhikkhave sagga katham katheyya tiādi
translated: And this is said: “Monks, I could tell you about heaven in many ways” .

original: Evaṃ saggakathāya palobhetvā puna hatthiṃ alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍaṃ chindanto viya
analyzed: evam sagga kathāya palobhetvā puna hatthim alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍam chindantaḥ viya
translated: Having thus tempted him with talk of heaven, he then, as it were, decorated an elephant and cut off its tusks,

original: – “ayampi saggo anicco addhuvo, na ettha chandarāgo kātabbo”ti dassanatthaṃ – “appassādā🔽kāmā vuttā mayā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”tiādinā nayena kāmānaṃ
analyzed: ayam pi saggaḥ aniccaḥ addhuvaḥ na ettha chanda rāgo kātabbaḥ iti dassana ttham appassādā  kāmāḥ vuttāḥ mayā bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyaḥ iti ādinā nayena kāmānam
translated: in order to show that “this heaven is impermanent, unstable, and one should not delight in it or be attached to it” .🔽He spoke about the danger, the destruction, the defilement of sensual desires, in the way beginning:

original: ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ kathesi. Tattha ādīnavoti doso. Okāroti avakāro lāmakabhāvo.
analyzed: ādīnavam okāram saṃkilesam kathesi tattha ādīnavaḥ ti dosaḥ okāraḥ ti avakāraḥ lāmaka bhāvo
translated: “Sensual desires have been declared by me to be of little satisfaction and much suffering, much affliction and much despair, and the danger in them is even greater” . Herein, danger is their fault. Destruction is their vulnerability, their rottenness.

original: Saṃkilesoti tehi sattānaṃ saṃsāre saṃkilissanaṃ. Yathāha “kilissanti vata, bho, sattā”ti.
analyzed: saṃkilesaḥ ti tehi sattānam saṃsāre saṃkilissanam yathā āha kilissanti vata bho sattā ati
translated: Defilement is the defilement of beings in the round of rebirths by means of them, as it is said: “Defiled, indeed, are beings by sensual desires” .🔽Having thus frightened him with the danger in sensual desires, he then proclaimed the benefit in renunciation,

original: Evaṃ kāmādīnavena tajjitvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi. Kallacittanti arogacittaṃ.
analyzed: evam kāma ādīnavena tajjitvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsam pakāsesi kalla cittam ti aroga cittam
translated: in the way beginning: “The renunciation of the will-to- sensual-desire is bliss, the recluse’s bliss” . Herein, the renunciation of the will-to-sensual-desire is the non-readiness to do any act of defilement consisting in bodily misconduct, etc., that is rooted in the will-to-sensual-desire.

original: Sāmukkaṃsikāti sāmaṃ ukkaṃsikā attanāyeva gahetvā uddharitvā gahitā, sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: sāmukkaṃsikā iti sāmam ukkaṃsikā attanāya iva gahetvā uddharitvā gahitā sayambhū ñāṇena
translated: The recluse’s bliss is the bliss of renunciation. This is a term for the path. For the path is called “the recluse’s bliss” because it is the bliss of renunciation, and also because it is the bliss of those who are recluses, that is, of noble persons .

original: diṭṭhā, asādhāraṇā aññesanti attho. Kā panesāti, ariyasaccadesanā? Tenevāha – “dukkhaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhāḥ asādhāraṇāḥ aññesanti attho kā pana isā ati ariya sacca desanā tena iva āha dukkham
translated: The meaning is: seen, not shared in common with others. But what is it? —The teaching of the noble truths. Hence he said: “Suffering,

original: samudayaṃ nirodhaṃ magga”nti.
analyzed: samudayam nirodham magganti
translated: its origin, its cessation, the way” .

original: Virajaṃ vītamalanti rāgarajādīnaṃ abhāvā virajaṃ, rāgamalādīnaṃ vigatattā vītamalaṃ.
analyzed: virajam abhāvāḥ virajam rāga mala ādīnam vigata ttāḥ vīta malam
translated: “Stainless, without defilement”: it is stainless because of the absence of the stains of lust, etc., and it is without defilement because of the absence of the defilements of lust, etc.

original: Dhammacakkhunti upari brahmāyusutte tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ, cūḷarāhulovāde āsavakkhayassetaṃ🔽nāmaṃ. Idha pana sotāpattimaggo adhippeto. Tassa uppattiākāradassanatthaṃ “yaṃkiñci
analyzed: dhammacakkhunti upari brahmāyusutte tiṇṇam maggānam cūḷarāhulovāde āsava kkhayassa etam  idha pana sotāpatti maggo adhippeto tassa uppatti ākāra dassana ttham yaṃkiñci
translated: “The eye of Dhamma”: in the Brahmāyusutta above it refers to the three paths, and in the Cūḷarāhulovāda to the destruction of the taints.

original: samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma”nti āha. Tañhi nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti āha tat hi nirodham ārammaṇam katvā
translated: But here it refers to the path of stream-entry. In order to show the mode of its arising he said: “Whatever is of the nature to arise, all that is of the nature to cease” .

original: kiccavasena evaṃ sabbasaṅkhataṃ paṭivijjhantaṃ uppajjati.🔽Diṭṭho ariyasaccadhammo etenāti diṭṭhadhammo. Esa nayo sesapadesupi. Tiṇṇā vicikicchā
analyzed: kicca vasena evam sabba saṅkhatam paṭivijjhantam uppajjati  diṭṭhaḥ ariya sacca dhammo etena ati diṭṭha dhammaḥ esa nayo sesa padesu pi tiṇṇā vicikicchā
translated: For it arises by way of function, penetrating all formations in this way, taking cessation as its object.🔽“One who has seen the Dhamma”: he has seen the Dhamma of the noble truths. The same method applies to the other terms.🔽“One who has crossed over doubt”: he has crossed over doubt by means of this .

original: anenāti tiṇṇavicikiccho. Vigatā kathaṃkathā assāti vigatakathaṃkatho. Vesārajjappattoti
analyzed: anena ati tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ vigatā kathaṃkathā assa ati vigata kathaṃkathaḥ vesārajja ppatto ti
translated: “One who has put away uncertainty”: he has put away uncertainty.

original: vesārajjaṃ patto. Kattha? Satthu sāsane. Nāssa paro paccayo, na parassa saddhāya🔽ettha vattatīti aparappaccayo.
analyzed: vesārajjam pattaḥ kattha satthu sāsane na assa paraḥ paccayaḥ na parassa saddhāya  ettha vattati iti apara paccayaḥ
translated: he is not led by others in regard to the Teacher’s Dispensation.

original: 70. Cittena sampaṭicchamāno abhinanditvā, vācāya pasaṃsamāno anumoditvā. Āvarāmīti thakemi pidahāmi. Anāvaṭanti na āvaritaṃ vivaṭaṃ ugghāṭitaṃ.
analyzed: cittena sampaṭicchamānaḥ abhinanditvā vācāya pasaṃsamānaḥ anumoditvā āvarāmi iti pidahāmi na āvaritam vivaṭam ugghāṭitam
translated: he approves of it with his mind and he extols it with his speech. I have closed it off, I have shut it off, I have sealed it off’ means ‘I have closed it off, I have shut it off, I have sealed it off, so that it is not open, not disclosed, not revealed.’

original: 71. Assosi kho dīghatapassīti so kira tassa gatakālato paṭṭhāya – “paṇḍito gahapati,
analyzed: assosi kho dīghatapassī iti so kira tassa gata kālato paṭṭhāya paṇḍitaḥ gahapati
translated: Dīghatapassī heard that the householder had gone forth. It seems that from the time of his going forth he was thinking: ‘The householder is wise,

original: samaṇo ca gotamo dassanasampanno niyyānikakatho, dassanepi tassa pasīdissati, dhammakathāyapi
analyzed: samaṇaḥ ca gotamaḥ dassana sampannaḥ niyyānika kathaḥ dassane pi tassa pasīdissati dhamma kathāya api
translated: and the recluse Gotama is one who has vision, who is a speaker of the truth, who has a doctrine that can be understood, who is a teacher of the deathless, who proclaims the deathless. If he sees him he will be confident,

original: pasīdissati, pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gamissati, gato nu kho saraṇaṃ gahapati na tāva gato”ti
analyzed: pasīdissati pasīditvā saraṇam gamissati gataḥ nu kho saraṇam gahapati na tāva gataḥ iti
translated: and being confident he will go for refuge. Has the householder gone for refuge or not?’

original: ohitasotova hutvā vicarati. Tasmā paṭhamaṃyeva assosi.
analyzed: hutvā vicarati tasmai
translated: and he was wandering about with his ears open. That is why he heard first of all.

original: 72. Tena hi sammāti balavasokena abhibhūto “ettheva tiṭṭhā”ti vacanaṃ sutvāpi atthaṃ asallakkhento dovārikena saddhiṃ sallapatiyeva.
analyzed: tena hi balava sokena abhibhūtaḥ ettha iva tiṭṭhāti vacanam sutvā api attham a sallakkhentaḥ dovārikena saddhim sallapatiyā iva
translated: “Well then, stand right here,” he said, still overwhelmed by his great sorrow. But he did not understand the meaning of the words. He continued his conversation with the doorkeeper.

original: Majjhimāya dvārasālāyānti yassa gharassa satta dvārakoṭṭhakā, tassa sabbaabbhantarato
analyzed: majjhimāya dvāra sālāya anti yassa gharassa satta dvāra koṭṭhakā tassa sabba abbhantarato
translated: In the middle of the courtyard: in the middle of the courtyard of a house with seven doors.

original: vā sabbabāhirato vā paṭṭhāya catutthadvārakoṭṭhako, yassa pañca, tassa tatiyo, yassa🔽tayo, tassa dutiyo dvārakoṭṭhako majjhimadvārasālā nāma. Ekadvārakoṭṭhakassa pana
analyzed: vā sabba bāhirataḥ vā paṭṭhāya catuttha dvāra koṭṭhakaḥ yassa pañca tassa tatiyaḥ yassa  tayo tassa dutiyaḥ dvāra koṭṭhakaḥ majjhimadvārasālā nāma eka dvāra koṭṭhakassa pana
translated: In a house with five doors it is the third door,🔽in a house with three doors it is the second door that is called the middle of the courtyard.

original: gharassa majjhaṭṭhāne maṅgalatthambhaṃ nissāya majjhimadvārasālā. Tassa pana gehassa
analyzed: gharassa majjha ṭṭhāne maṅgala tthambham nissāya majjhima dvāra sālā tassa pana gehassa
translated: But in a house with one door it is the middle of the house, near the auspicious pillar.

original: satta dvārakoṭṭhakā, pañcātipi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: satta dvāra koṭṭhakā vuttam
translated: It is said that the house had seven doors or five doors.

original: 73. Aggantiādīni sabbāni aññamaññavevacanāni. Yaṃ sudanti ettha yanti yaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ.
analyzed: agga anti ādīni sabbāni aññamañña vevacanāni yam ettha yanti yam nāṭa puttam
translated: “He came” and so on are synonyms. “He went to Sudatta” means he went to the householder Anāthapiṇḍika.

original: Sudanti nipātamattaṃ. Pariggahetvāti teneva uttarāsaṅgena udare parikkhipanto gahetvā.
analyzed: sudanti nipāta mattam pariggahetvā iti tena iva uttarāsaṅgena udare parikkhipantaḥ gahetvā
translated: “Sudatta” is a mere particle. “Having seized him” means having encircled his belly with his upper robe.

original: Nisīdāpetīti saṇikaṃ ācariya, saṇikaṃ ācariyāti mahantaṃ telaghaṭaṃ ṭhapento viya
analyzed: nisīda apeti iti saṇikam ācariya saṇikam ācariya ati mahantam tela ghaṭam ṭhapentaḥ viya
translated: “He makes him sit down” means he makes him sit down slowly, as if placing down a vessel of oil.🔽“You are given” means “Are you so stupid?”

original: nisīdāpeti. Dattosīti kiṃ jaḷosi jātoti attho. Paṭimukkoti sīse parikkhipitvā gahito.
analyzed: nisīda apa iti dattaḥ asi iti kim jaḷaḥ asi jātaḥ ti attho paṭimukkaḥ ti sīse parikkhipitvā gahitaḥ
translated: “He is seized by the hair” means he is seized by the hair on his head.🔽“The egg-carrier” and so on are also coarse expressions.

original: Aṇḍahārakotiādiṃ duṭṭhullavacanampi samānaṃ upaṭṭhākassa aññathābhāvena uppannabalavasokatāya🔽idaṃ nāma bhaṇāmīti asallakkhetvāva bhaṇati.🔽74. Bhaddikā, bhante, āvaṭṭanīti nigaṇṭho māyameva sandhāya vadati, upāsako attanā
analyzed: aṇḍa hāraka uti ādim duṭṭhulla vacanam pi samānam upaṭṭhākassa aññathā bhāvena uppanna balava soka tāya  idam nāma bhaṇāmi iti a sat lakkhetvā ava bhaṇati  bhaddikā bhante āvaṭṭanī iti nigaṇṭhaḥ mā ayam eva sandhāya vadati upāsakaḥ attanā
translated: Because the attendant is very sorrowful, he speaks without considering what he is saying.🔽“A good trick, venerable sir” means the Nigaṇṭha is referring to his own magic. The lay follower has realized the stream-entry path.

original: paṭividdhaṃ sotāpattimaggaṃ. Tena hīti nipātamattametaṃ, bhante, upamaṃ te karissāmicceva🔽attho. Kāraṇavacanaṃ vā, yena kāraṇena tumhākaṃ sāsanaṃ aniyyānikaṃ, mama satthu
analyzed: paṭividdham sotāpatti maggam tena hi iti nipāta mattam etam bhante upamam te karissāmi icca eva  attho kāraṇa vacanam vā yena kāraṇena tumhākam sāsanam aniyyānikam mama satthu
translated: “In that case” is merely a particle. The meaning is “I will make a comparison for you.”

original: niyyānikaṃ, tena kāraṇena upamaṃ te karissāmīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: niyyānikam tena kāraṇena upamam te karissāmi iti vuttam hoti
translated: Or it is a reason statement: “For this reason, your teaching is not final, but my teacher’s teaching is final. For this reason, I will make a comparison for you.”

original: 75. Upavijaññāti vijāyanakālaṃ upagatā. Makkaṭacchāpakanti makkaṭapotakaṃ. Kiṇitvā🔽ānehīti mūlaṃ datvāva āhara. Āpaṇesu hi saviññāṇakampi aviññāṇakampi makkaṭādikīḷanabhaṇḍakaṃ🔽vikkiṇanti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ āha. Rajitanti bahalabahalaṃ pītāvalepanaraṅgajātaṃ gahetvā🔽rajitvā dinnaṃ imaṃ icchāmīti attho. Ākoṭitapaccākoṭitanti ākoṭitañceva parivattetvā
analyzed: upavijaññā ti vijāyana kālam upagatā makkaṭa chāpakam ti makkaṭa potakam kiṇitvā  ānehi iti mūlam āhara āpaṇesu hi sa viññāṇakam api a viññāṇakam api makkaṭa ādi kīḷana bhaṇḍakam  tam sandhāya itam āha bahala bahalam pīta avalepana raṅga jātam gahetvā  rajitvā dinnam imam icchāmi iti ākoṭita pacca ākoṭitanti ākoṭitam ca iva parivattetvā
translated: ‘To be born’: that which has reached the time of being born. ‘A monkey-doll’: a young monkey. ‘Buy and bring’: having given the price, bring. For in shops they sell dolls with consciousness and without consciousness, such as monkeys, etc. He said this referring to that. ‘Dyed’: having taken a dye that is a thick yellow paste,🔽and having dyed it, given it. The meaning is: ‘I want this.’ ‘Rubbed and turned’: rubbed and turned over.

original: punappunaṃ ākoṭitañca. Ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhanti maṇipāsāṇena ubhosu passesu suṭṭhu🔽vimaṭṭhaṃ ghaṭṭetvā uppāditacchaviṃ.🔽Raṅgakkhamo hi khoti saviññāṇakampi aviññāṇakampi raṅgaṃ pivati. Tasmā evamāha. No
analyzed: punappunam ākoṭitam ca maṇi pāsāṇena ubhosu passesu suṭṭhu  vimaṭṭham ghaṭṭetvā uppādita chavim  raṅga kkhamaḥ hi kho ti sa viññāṇakam pi a viññāṇakam pi raṅgam pivati tasmai evam āha no
translated: ‘When it is about to give birth’: when the time for giving birth has arrived. ‘A young monkey’: a young monkey. ‘Buy and bring it’: having given the price, bring it. For in shops they sell toys for monkeys, etc., both with and without consciousness. He said this referring to that. ‘Dyed’: having taken a thick, thick, yellow, mixed dye, and having dyed it, given it. The meaning is: ‘I want this.’ ‘Rubbed and re-rubbed’: rubbed and turned over and rubbed again and again. ‘Well rubbed on both sides’: well rubbed on both sides with a gem-stone, having produced a surface by rubbing.

original: ākoṭṭanakkhamoti saviññāṇakassa tāva ākoṭṭanaphalake ṭhapetvā kucchiyaṃ ākoṭitassa
analyzed: ākoṭṭana khamaḥ ti sa viññāṇakassa tāva ākoṭṭana phalake ṭhapetvā kucchiyam ākoṭitassa
translated: ‘It is able to take dye’: it drinks dye, both with and without consciousness. Therefore he said this. ‘But it is not able to be rubbed’: for one with consciousness, having placed it on a rubbing board, if it is rubbed on the belly,

original: kucchi bhijjati, karīsaṃ nikkhamati. Sesī ākoṭitassa sīsaṃ bhijjati, mattaluṅgaṃ
analyzed: kucchi bhijjati karīsam nikkhamati sesī ākoṭitassa sīsam bhijjati matta luṅgam
translated: his belly bursts open and his excrement comes out. The rest of them, when they are beaten, their heads split open and their brains come out.

original: nikkhamati. Aviññāṇako khaṇḍakhaṇḍitaṃ gacchati. Tasmā evamāha. No vimajjanakkhamoti🔽saviññāṇako maṇipāsāṇena vimaddiyamāno nillomataṃ nicchavitañca āpajjati, aviññāṇakopi🔽vacuṇṇakabhāvaṃ āpajjati. Tasmā evamāha. Raṅgakkhamo hi kho bālānanti bālānaṃ mandabuddhīnaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamati aviññāṇakaḥ khaṇḍa khaṇḍitam gacchati tasmai evam āha no vimajjana khamaḥ ti  sa viññāṇakaḥ maṇi pāsāṇena vimaddiyamānaḥ nilloma tam nicchavi tat ca āpajjati a viññāṇakaḥ api  vacuṇṇaka bhāvam āpajjati tasmai evam āha raṅga kkhamaḥ hi kho bālānam ti bālānam manda buddhīnam
translated: the belly bursts open and the excrement comes out. In the other, the head splits open and the brain comes out. The unconscious one goes to pieces. That is why he said as he did. He is not fit for discussion:🔽the conscious one, when being discussed with a gem or a stone, comes to be without hair and without skin. The unconscious one comes to be without flesh. That is why he said as he did. For the fool is fit for colouring:

original: raṅgakkhamo, rāgamattaṃ janeti, piyo hoti. Paṇḍitānaṃ pana nigaṇṭhavādo vā añño vā🔽bhāratarāmasītāharaṇādi niratthakakathāmaggo appiyova hoti. No anuyogakkhamo, no🔽vimajjanakkhamoti anuyogaṃ vā vīmaṃsaṃ vā na khamati, thuse koṭṭetvā taṇḍulapariyesanaṃ
analyzed: raṅga kkhamaḥ rāga mattam janeti piyaḥ hoti paṇḍitānam pana nigaṇṭha vādaḥ vā aññaḥ vā  bhārata rāma sītā haraṇa ādi niratthaka kathā maggaḥ appiyaḥ iva hoti no anuyoga kkhamaḥ no  vimajjana khamaḥ ti anuyogam vā vīmaṃsam vā na khamati thuse koṭṭetvā taṇḍula pariyesanam
translated: the fool, who is of low understanding, is fit for colouring, he generates mere lust, he becomes dear. But the wise man’s way of talk, such as the Niganthas’ doctrine or any other,🔽which is concerned with such a useless story as the carrying off of Sītā by Rāvaṇa, is not dear. He is not fit for discussion, he is not fit for investigation:

original: viya kadaliyaṃ sāragavesanaṃ viya ca rittako tucchakova hoti. Raṅgakkhamo ceva paṇḍitānanti
analyzed: viya kadaliyam sāragavesanam viya ca rittakaḥ tucchakaḥ uva hoti raṅga kkhamaḥ ca iva
translated: he does not stand up to discussion or investigation. He is as hollow and void as a bamboo, as a plantain trunk, as a fake coin, like one who, having dug up the earth here, seeks rice grains there. For the wise man is fit for colouring:

original: catusaccakathā hi paṇḍitānaṃ piyā hoti, vassasatampi suṇanto tittiṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: catu sacca kathā hi paṇḍitānam piyā hoti vassa satam pi suṇantaḥ tittim na gacchati
translated: for the discourse on the Four Truths is dear to the wise, and one who listens to it for a hundred years on end is never satisfied.🔽So he said, “He is capable of taking up the discussion and of examining it.” But the more one plunges into the word of the Buddha, the more profound it becomes,

original: Tasmā evamāha. Buddhavacanaṃ pana yathā yathāpi ogāhissati mahāsamuddo viya gambhīrameva🔽hotīti “anuyogakkhamo ca vimajjanakkhamo cā”ti āha. Suṇohi yassāhaṃ sāvakoti tassa
analyzed: tasmai evam āha buddha vacanam pana yathā yathā api ogāhissati mahā samuddaḥ viya gambhīram eva  hoti iti anuyoga khamaḥ ca vimajjana khamaḥ ca ati āha suṇohi yassa aham sāvakaḥ iti tassa
translated: like the great ocean, so he said, “He is capable of taking up the discussion and of examining it.”

original: guṇe suṇāhīti bhagavato vaṇṇe vattuṃ āraddho.🔽76. Dhīrassāti dhīraṃ vuccati paṇḍiccaṃ, yā paññā pajānanā…pe… sammādiṭṭhi, tena🔽samannāgatassa dhātuāyatanapaṭiccasamuppādaṭṭhānāṭṭhānakusalassa paṇḍitassāhaṃ sāvako,
analyzed: guṇe suṇāhi iti bhagavataḥ vaṇṇe vattum āraddhaḥ  dhīrassa ati dhīram vuccati paṇḍiccam yā paññā pajānanā pe sammādiṭṭhi tena  samannāgatassa dhātu āyatana paṭiccasamuppāda ṭṭhāna aṭṭhāna kusalassa paṇḍitassa aham sāvakaḥ
translated: “Listen to me as I tell you of the one who is my disciple”: he began to praise the Blessed One.

original: so mayhaṃ satthāti evaṃ sabbapadesu sambandho veditabbo. Pabhinnakhīlassāti bhinnapañcacetokhilassa.🔽Sabbaputhujjane vijiniṃsu vijinanti vijinissanti vāti vijayā. Ke te, maccumārakilesamāradevaputtamārāti?
analyzed: saḥ mayham satthā iti evam sabba padesu sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ pabhinna khīlassa ati bhinna pañca cetaḥ khilassa 🔽sabba puthujjane ke te maccumāra kilesamāra deva putta mārā ti
translated: “The wise man”: the wise man is called “wise” because of his wisdom, his understanding, his insight, his penetration, his clear-sightedness, his discernment, his investigation, his search, his erudition, his great erudition, his learning, his great learning, his wide learning, his learning in many modes, his being learned in the scriptures, his being a great man, his being a great man of learning, his being a great man of wisdom, his being a great man of discernment, his being a great man of clear-sightedness, his being a great man of penetration, his being a great man of investigation, his being a great man of search, his being a great man of erudition, his being a great man of great erudition, his being a great man of learning, his being a great man of great learning, his being a great man of wide learning, his being a great man of learning in many modes, his being a great man of learning in the scriptures, his being a great man of wisdom, his being a great man of great wisdom, his being a great man of discernment, his being a great man of great discernment, his being a great man of clear-sightedness, his being a great man of great clear-sightedness, his being a great man of penetration, his being a great man of great penetration, his being a great man of investigation, his being a great man of great investigation, his being a great man of search, his being a great man of great search, his being a great man of erudition, his being a great man of great erudition, his being a great man of learning, his being a great man of great learning, his being a great man of wide learning, his being a great man of learning in many modes, his being a great man of learning in the scriptures, his being a great man of wisdom, his being a great man

original: Te vijitā vijayā etenāti vijitavijayo. Bhagavā, tassa vijitavijayassa. Anīghassāti
analyzed: te vijitāḥ vijayāḥ etena ati vijita vijayaḥ bhagavā tassa vijita vijayassa anīghassa ati
translated: He is called “the Victorious Victor” because he has conquered and is victorious by means of that . The Blessed One is the “Victorious Victor” of that .🔽“Free from fear” : he is free from fear of the suffering of defilements and the suffering of the results of kamma .

original: kilesadukkhenapi vipākadukkhenapi niddukkhassa. Susamacittassāti devadattadhanapālakaaṅgulimālarāhulatherādīsupi
analyzed: kilesa dukkhena pi vipāka dukkhena pi niddukkhassa su sama cittassa ati devadatta dhanapālaka aṅguli māla rāhula thera ādīsu pi
translated: “Of well-composed mind” : he is well-composed in mind towards gods, men, Devadatta, Dhanapāla, Aṅgulimāla, Rāhula, and so forth.

original: devamanussesu suṭṭhu samacittassa. Vuddhasīlassāti vaḍḍhitācārassa. Sādhupaññassāti🔽sundarapaññassa. Vesamantarassāti rāgādivisamaṃ taritvā vitaritvā ṭhitassa. Vimalassāti🔽vigatarāgādimalassa.
analyzed: deva manussesu suṭṭhu sama cittassa vuddha sīlassa ati vaḍḍhita ācārassa sādhu paññassa ati  sundara paññassa vesamantarassa ati rāga ādi visamam taritvā vitaritvā ṭhitassa vimalassa ati  vigata rāga ādi malassa
translated: “Of developed virtue” : he has developed his conduct . “Of good understanding” : he has a beautiful understanding .🔽“Having crossed over the swamp” : having crossed over and gone beyond the swamp of lust, etc. “The stainless one” : he is stainless, free from the stains of lust, etc.

original: Tusitassāti tuṭṭhacittassa. Vantalokāmisassāti vantakāmaguṇassa. Muditassāti muditāvihāravasena
analyzed: tusitassa ati tuṭṭha cittassa vanta loka āmisassa ati vanta kāma guṇassa muditassa ati muditā vihāra vasena
translated: “The contented one” : he is contented in mind. “Having abandoned worldly pleasures” : having abandoned the worldly pleasures of the five strands of sense pleasure . “The joyful one” : he is joyful by way of the dwelling in loving-kindness .

original: muditassa, punaruttameva vā etaṃ. Pasādavasena hi ekampi guṇaṃ punappunaṃ vadatiyeva.
analyzed: muditassa punar uttamā iva vā etam pasāda vasena hi ekam pi guṇam punappunam
translated: Or else, this is merely a repetition . For it is by way of confidence that he repeats a quality again and again.

original: Katasamaṇassāti katasāmaññassa, samaṇadhammassa matthakaṃ pattassāti attho. Manujassāti
analyzed: kata samaṇassa ati kata sāmaññassa samaṇa dhammassa matthakam pattassa ati atthaḥ manujassa ati
translated: “The monk” : the one who has made himself a monk , the meaning is that he has reached the peak of the state of a monk . “The man” :

original: lokavohāravasena ekassa sattassa. Narassāti punaruttaṃ. Aññathā vuccamāne ekekagāthāya
analyzed: loka vohāra vasena ekassa sattassa narassa ati punaruttam aññathā vuccamāne ekeka gāthāya
translated: in the world’s usage, of a single being. ‘Men’ is said again. If it were said otherwise,

original: dasa guṇā nappahonti.🔽Venayikassāti sattānaṃ vināyakassa. Ruciradhammassāti sucidhammassa. Pabhāsakassāti
analyzed: dasa guṇāḥ nappahonti  venayikassa ati sattānam vināyakassa rucira dhammassa ati suci dhammassa pabhāsakassa ati
translated: ten times the merit would not be enough for each verse.

original: obhāsakassa. Vīrassāti vīriyasampannassa. Nisabhassāti usabhavasabhanisabhesu sabbattha
analyzed: obhāsakassa vīrassa ati vīriya sampannassa nisabhassa ati usabha vasabha nisabhesu sabbattha
translated: ‘The one who guides beings’ is the one who trains beings. ‘The one with a clear Dhamma’ is the one with a beautiful Dhamma. ‘The one who illuminates’ is the one who shines. ‘The one with strength’ is the one endowed with strength. ‘The one with power’ is the one who is unequalled in all respects among those who have power, strength, and power.

original: appaṭisamaṭṭhena nisabhassa. Gambhīrassāti gambhīraguṇassa, guṇehi vā gambhīrassa.🔽Monapattassāti ñāṇapattassa. Vedassāti vedo vuccati ñāṇaṃ, tena samannāgatassa. Dhammaṭṭhassāti
analyzed: appaṭisamaṭṭhena nisabhassa gambhīrassa ati gambhīra guṇassa guṇehi vā gambhīrassa  mona pattassa ati ñāṇa pattassa vedassa ati vedaḥ vuccati ñāṇam tena samannāgatassa dhammaṭṭhassa ati
translated: ‘The one with depth’ is the one with profound qualities, or the one who is profound because of his qualities.

original: dhamme ṭhitassa. Saṃvutattassāti pihitattassa.🔽Nāgassāti catūhi kāraṇehi nāgassa. Pantasenassāti pantasenāsanassa. Paṭimantakassāti
analyzed: dhamme ṭhitassa saṃvutattassa ati pihitattassa  nāgassa ati catūhi kāraṇehi nāgassa pantasenassa ati panta senāsanassa paṭimantakassa ati
translated: ‘The one who has attained knowledge’ is the one who has attained knowledge. ‘The one with knowledge’ is said to be the one who has knowledge. ‘The one who is established in the Dhamma’ is the one who is established in the Dhamma. ‘The one who is restrained’ is the one who is closed off.

original: paṭimantanapaññāya samannāgatassa. Monassāti monaṃ vuccati ñāṇaṃ, tena samannāgatassa,
analyzed: paṭimantana paññāya samannāgatassa monassa ati monam vuccati ñāṇam tena samannāgatassa
translated: ‘The one who is a nāga’ is a nāga for four reasons. ‘The one who has a secluded dwelling’ is the one who has a secluded dwelling place. ‘The one who has a reply’ is the one who is endowed with the wisdom of a reply. ‘The one who is silent’ is the one who is endowed with knowledge,🔽where ‘silence’ is said to be knowledge.

original: dhutakilesassa vā. Dantassāti nibbisevanassa.
analyzed: dhuta kilesassa vā dantassa ati nibbisevanassa
translated: or of one who has shaken off defilements. Tamed: without conceit.

original: Isisattamassāti vipassiādayo cha isayo upādāya sattamassa. Brahmapattassāti seṭṭhapattassa.
analyzed: isi sattamassa ati vipassi ādayaḥ cha isayaḥ upādāya sattamassa brahmapattassa ati seṭṭhapattassa
translated: Of the seventh: of the seventh of the seven Buddhas beginning with Vipassi. Of the one who has won the supreme: of the one who has won the best.

original: Nhātakassāti nhātakilesassa. Padakassāti akkharādīni samodhānetvā gāthāpadakaraṇakusalassa.
analyzed: nhātakassa ati nhāta kilesassa padakassa ati akkhara ādīni samodhānetvā gāthā pada karaṇa kusalassa
translated: Of the one who has bathed: of the one who has bathed in the water of knowledge. Of the one who has made the verse: of the one who is skilled in making verses by combining syllables, etc.

original: Viditavedassāti viditañāṇassa. Purindadassāti sabbapaṭhamaṃ dhammadānadāyakassa.
analyzed: vidita vedassa ati vidita ñāṇassa purindadassa ati sabba paṭhamam dhamma dāna dāyakassa
translated: Of the one who has known and seen: of the one who has known and seen. Of the one who gives first: of the one who gives the gift of the Dhamma first.

original: Sakkassāti samatthassa. Pattipattassāti ye pattabbā guṇā, te pattassa. Veyyākaraṇassāti
analyzed: sakkassa ati samatthassa patti pattassa ati ye pattabbāḥ guṇāḥ te pattassa veyyākaraṇassa ati
translated: Of the one who is able: of the one who is capable. Of the one who has won the path: of the one who has won the special qualities that should be won. Of the one who has expounded:

original: vitthāretvā atthadīpakassa. Bhagavatā hi abyākataṃ nāma tanti padaṃ natthi sabbesaṃyeva attho kathito.🔽Vipassissāti vipassanakassa. Anabhinatassāti anatassa. No apanatassāti aduṭṭhassa.
analyzed: vitthāretvā attha dīpakassa bhagavatā hi abyākatam nāma tanti padam natthi sabbesam yeva atthaḥ kathito  vipassissa āti vipassanakassa an abhinatassa ati anatassa no apanatassa ati aduṭṭhassa
translated: of the one who has expounded the meaning in detail. For there is no such thing as an unexpounded thread or line in the Blessed One’s dispensation: the meaning of all of them has been told.🔽Of the one who has insight: of the one who has insight. Of the one who is not bent: of the one who is not crooked. Of the one who is not broken: of the one who is not broken by anger.

original: Ananugatantarassāti kilese ananugatacittassa. Asitassāti abaddhassa.
analyzed: ananugata antarassa ati kilese ananugata cittassa asitassa ati abaddhassa
translated: Of the one who is not followed by the inner foe: of the one whose mind is not followed by defilements. Of the one who is not bound: of the one who is not bound by craving.

original: Bhūripaññassāti bhūri vuccati pathavī, tāya pathavīsamāya paññāya vipulāya mahantāya vitthatāya samannāgatassāti attho. Mahāpaññassāti mahāpaññāya samannāgatassa.
analyzed: bhūri paññassa ati bhūri vuccati pathavī tāya pathavī samāya paññāya vipulāya mahantāya vitthatāya samannāgatassa ati atthaḥ mahā paññassa ati mahā paññāya samannāgatassa
translated: Bhuripanna: the meaning is, endowed with the earth-like understanding, for “earth” is said to be “bhuri” . Mahapanna: endowed with great understanding.

original: Anupalittassāti taṇhādiṭṭhikilesehi alittassa. Āhuneyyassāti āhutiṃ paṭiggahetuṃ
analyzed: an upalittassa ti taṇhā diṭṭhi kilesehi a littassa āhuneyyassa ati āhutim paṭiggahetum
translated: Anupalitta: unsoiled by craving and views. Aahuneyya: fit to receive offerings.

original: yuttassa. Yakkhassāti ānubhāvadassanaṭṭhena ādissamānakaṭṭhena vā bhagavā yakkho🔽nāma. Tenāha “yakkhassā”ti. Mahatoti mahantassa. Tassa sāvakohamasmīti tassa evaṃvividhaguṇassa
analyzed: yuttassa yakkhassa ati ānubhāva dassana ṭhena ādissamānaka ṭṭhena vā bhagavā yakkho  nāma tena āha yakkhassa ati mahataḥ ti mahantassa tassa sāvakaḥ ham asmi iti tassa evam vividha guṇassa
translated: Yakkha: the Blessed One is called a “yakkha” in the sense of one who shows his power, or in the sense of one who is addressed.🔽Tenassa: of him. Sohamasmi: I am his disciple.

original: satthussa ahaṃ sāvakoti. Upāsakassa sobhāpattimaggeneva paṭisambhidā āgatā. Iti paṭisambhidāvisaye
analyzed: satthussa aham sāvakaḥ iti upāsakassa sobhā patti maggena iva paṭisambhidā āgatā iti paṭisambhidā visaye
translated: Upasakassobhapattimaggena: by the path of the attainment of the beauty of a lay follower.🔽Iti: thus. Patisambhidā: the analytical knowledges.🔽Agatā: have come. Iti: thus. Patisambhidāvisaye: in the domain of the analytical knowledges.

original: ṭhatvā padasatena dasabalassa kilesappahānavaṇṇaṃ kathento “kassa taṃ gahapati sāvakaṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā pada satena dasabalassa kilesa ppahāna vaṇṇam kathento kassa tam gahapati sāvakam
translated: Tathā: thus. Tathāgata: the Enlightened One. Dasabalassa: of the One of Ten Powers. Kilesappahānavaṇṇaṃ: the praise of the abandoning of defilements. Kathento: speaking. “Kassa tam gahapati sāvakaṃ dhārema” : “Whose disciple should I be, householder?”

original: dhāremā”ti pañhassa atthaṃ vissajjesi.
analyzed: dhārema iti pañhassa attham vissajjesi
translated: Vissajjesi: he answered.

original: 77. Kadā saññūḷhāti kadā sampiṇḍitā. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “ayaṃ idāneva samaṇassa
analyzed: kadā saññūḍhā ati kadā sampiṇḍitā evam ayam idānā iva samaṇassa
translated: 77. When are they combined? When are they lumped together? He thought thus: “This bhikkhu has just now

original: gotamassa santikaṃ gantvā āgato, kadānena ete vaṇṇā sampiṇḍitā”ti. Tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: gotamassa santikam gantvā āgataḥ kadā anena ete vaṇṇā sampiṇḍitā ati tasmai evam āha
translated: “When were they mixed?” he asked, thinking, “He has just come from the presence of the recluse Gotama. When did he mix these colors?”

original: Vicittaṃ mālaṃ gantheyyāti sayampi dakkhatāya pupphānampi nānāvaṇṇatāya ekatovaṇṭikādibhedaṃ🔽vicitramālaṃ gantheyya. Evameva kho, bhanteti ettha nānāpupphānaṃ mahāpuppharāsi🔽viya nānāvidhānaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ bhagavato sinerumatto vaṇṇarāsi daṭṭhabbo. Chekamālākāro🔽viya upāli gahapati. Mālākārassa vicitramālāganthanaṃ viya gahapatino tathāgatassa
analyzed: vicittam mālam gantheyya ati sayam pi dakkha tāya pupphānam pi nānā vaṇṇa tāya ekatovaṇṭika ādi bhedam  vicitra mālam gantheyya evam eva kho bhante ti ettha nānā pupphānam mahā puppha rāsi  viya nānāvidhānam vaṇṇānam bhagavataḥ sinerumattaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ cheka mālākāro  viya upāli gahapati mālākārassa vicitra mālā ganthanam viya gahapatino tathāgatassa
translated: “A variegated garland” means a garland of various colors, such as a garland of flowers of the same stalk, etc.

original: vicitravaṇṇaganthanaṃ.🔽Uṇhaṃ lohitaṃ mukhato uggañchīti tassa hi bhagavato sakkāraṃ asahamānassa etadahosi
analyzed: vicitra vaṇṇa ganthanam  uṇham lohitam mukhataḥ uggañchi iti tassa hi bhagavataḥ sakkāram a sahamānassa etat ahosi
translated: “So it is, venerable sir,” means that the mass of colors of the Blessed One should be seen as a great mass of flowers of various kinds, like a heap of various flowers, and the householder Upāli as a garland maker, and the mixing of the variegated colors of the Tathāgata by the householder Upāli as the garland maker’s making of a variegated garland.

original: – “anatthiko dāni ayaṃ gahapati amhehi, sve paṭṭhāya paṇṇāsa saṭṭhi jane gahetvā
analyzed: anatthikaḥ dāni ayam gahapati amhehi sve paṭṭhāya paṇṇāsa saṭṭhi jane gahetvā
translated: “Hot blood gushed from his mouth” means that he thought, “This householder is no longer interested in us. From tomorrow onwards he will take fifty or sixty people with him and go to the recluse Gotama.”

original: etassa gharaṃ pavisitvā bhuñjituṃ na labhissāmi, bhinnā me bhattakumbhī”ti. Athassa
analyzed: etassa gharam pavisitvā bhuñjitum na labhissāmi bhinnā me bhatta kumbhī iti
translated: I shall not be able to enter his house and eat. My food-pot is broken.” Then

original: upaṭṭhākavipariṇāmena balavasoko uppajji. Ime hi sattā attano attanova cintayanti.🔽Tassa tasmiṃ soke uppanne abbhantaraṃ uṇhaṃ ahosi, lohitaṃ vilīyittha, taṃ mahāvātena
analyzed: upaṭṭhāka vipariṇāmena balava sokaḥ uppajji ime hi sattāḥ attanaḥ attanā iva cintayanti  tassa tasmin soke uppanne abbhantaram uṇham ahosi lohitam vilīyittha tam mahā vātena
translated: because of the change in his attendant, he was overcome with grief. For these beings think only of themselves.🔽When grief arose in him, his inner heat was generated, his blood melted, and that,

original: samuddharitaṃ kuṭe pakkhittarajanaṃ viya pattamattaṃ mukhato uggañchi. Nidhānagatalohitaṃ🔽vamitvā pana appakā sattā jīvituṃ sakkonti. Nigaṇṭho tattheva jāṇunā patito, atha
analyzed: samuddharitam kuṭe pakkhitta rajanam viya patta mattam mukhataḥ uggañchi nidhāna gata lohitam  vamitvā pana appakā sattāḥ jīvitum sakkonti nigaṇṭhaḥ tattha iva jāṇunā patitaḥ atha
translated: like a red dye put into a bowl and stirred by a great wind, came out of his mouth in a mere drop. But few beings are able to live after vomiting blood🔽that has gone into the repository. The Nigantha fell down right there on his knees. Then

original: naṃ pāṭaṅkiyā bahinagaraṃ nīharitvā mañcakasivikāya gahetvā pāvaṃ agamaṃsu, so na
analyzed: pāṭaṅkiyāḥ bahi nagaram nīharitvā mañcaka sivikāya gahetvā saḥ na
translated: they took him out of the city to the outskirts and, carrying him on a couch, they went to Pāvā. He died there

original: cirasseva pāvāyaṃ kālamakāsi. Imasmiṃ pana sutte ugghāṭitaññūpuggalassa vasena dhammadesanā pariniṭṭhitāti.
analyzed: cirassa iva pāvā ayam kālam akāsi imasmin pana sutte ugghāṭita ññū puggalassa vasena dhamma desanā pariniṭṭhitā ti
translated: in Pāvā after not a long time. But in this sutta, the teaching of the Dhamma is completed in terms of the person who is one who is open to advice.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the commentary to the Majjhima Nikāya called Papañcasūdanī,

original: Upālisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: upāli sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Upāli Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Kukkuravatikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽78. Evaṃ me sutanti kukkuravatikasuttaṃ. Tattha koliyesūti evaṃnāmake janapade. So
analyzed: kukkuravatika sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutam ti kukkuravatika suttam tattha koliyesu iti evaṃnāmake janapade so
translated: 7. The Discussion of the Dog-duty Discourse

original: hi ekopi kolanagare patiṭṭhitānaṃ koliyānaṃ rājakumārānaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānattā evaṃ vuccati.🔽Tasmiṃ koliyesu janapade. Haliddavasananti tassa kira nigamassa māpitakāle pītakavatthanivatthā🔽manussā nakkhattaṃ kīḷiṃsu. Te nakkhattakīḷāvasāne nigamassa nāmaṃ āropentā haliddavasananti🔽nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Taṃ gocaragāmaṃ katvā viharatīti attho. Vihāro panettha kiñcāpi na🔽niyāmito, tathāpi buddhānaṃ anucchavike senāsaneyeva vihāsīti veditabbo. Govatikoti
analyzed: hi ekaḥ api kola nagare patiṭṭhitānam koliyānam rāja kumārānam nivāsa ṭṭhāna ttā evam vuccati  tasmin koliyesu janapade tassa kira nigamassa māpita kāle pītaka vattha nivatthā  manussāḥ nakkhattam kīḷiṃsu te nakkhatta kīḷā avasāne nigamassa nāmam āropentā halidda vasananti  tam gocaragāmam katvā viharati iti atthaḥ vihāraḥ pana ittha kiñcā api na  niyāmitaḥ tathā api buddhānam anucchavike senāsane iya iva vihāsī iti veditabbaḥ govatikaḥ ti
translated: Thus I have heard: this is the Dog-duty Discourse . Herein, in the Koliyan country means in a country named thus. For that country is so called because it was the place of residence of princes of the Koliya clan who were settled in the city of Kola .

original: samādinnagovato, sīse siṅgāni ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭhaṃ bandhitvā gāvīhi saddhiṃ tiṇāni
analyzed: samādinna govataḥ sīse siṅgāni ṭhapetvā naṅguṭṭham bandhitvā gāvīhi saddhim tiṇāni
translated: In that Koliyan country, in the village of Haliddavasana means he was staying in that village which was his alms-resort. The meaning is that he was staying in that village. Although there is no monastery here which is fixed , nevertheless it should be understood that he was staying in a monastery which was suitable for Buddhas. The Dog-duty man means a man who has been given a dog’s duty . Having placed horns on his head and having tied a tail behind, he goes about with the cows, eating the grass which they have trampled down.

original: khādanto viya carati. Aceloti naggo niccelo. Seniyoti tassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: khādantaḥ viya carati acelaḥ ti naggaḥ niccelaḥ seniyaḥ ti tassa nāmaṃ
translated: he goes about as if he were eating. Acelakassapa was naked, without any clothes. Seni was his name.

original: Kukkuravatikoti samādinnakukkuravato, sabbaṃ sunakhakiriyaṃ karoti. Ubhopete sahapaṃsukīḷikā🔽sahāyakā. Kukkurova palikujjitvāti sunakho nāma sāmikassa santike nisīdanto dvīhi🔽pādehi bhūmiyaṃ vilekhitvā kukkurakūjitaṃ kūjanto nisīdati, ayampi “kukkurakiriyaṃ🔽karissāmī”ti bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammoditvā dvīhi hatthehi bhūmiyaṃ vilekhitvā sīsaṃ🔽vidhunanto ‘bhū bhū’ti katvā hatthapāde samiñjitvā sunakho viya nisīdi. Chamānikkhittanti
analyzed: kukkuravatikā uti samādinna kukkuravataḥ sabbam su nakha kiriyam karoti ubha upete saha paṃsukīḷikā  sahāyakā kukkurā uva palikujjitvā ati sunakhaḥ nāma sāmikassa santike nisīdantaḥ dvīhi  pādehi vilekhitvā kukkura kūjitam kūjantaḥ nisīdati ayam pi kukkura kiriyam  karissāmi iti bhagavatā saddhim sammoditvā dvīhi hatthehi bhūmiyam vilekhitvā sīsam  vidhunantaḥ bhū bhūti katvā hattha pāde samiñjitvā su nakhaḥ viya nisīdi
translated: Dog-duty-man: he did the duty of a dog, he did all the actions of a dog. Both were friends, playing together in the dust.

original: bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapitaṃ. Samattaṃ samādinnanti paripuṇṇaṃ katvā gahitaṃ. Kā gatīti kā nipphatti.🔽Ko abhisamparāyoti abhisamparāyamhi kattha nibbatti. Alanti tassa appiyaṃ bhavissatīti
analyzed: ṭhapitam sa mattam samādinnanti paripuṇṇam katvā gahitam kā gatī iti kā nipphatti 🔽kaḥ abhisamparāyaḥ ti abhisamparāyamhi kattha nibbatti alanti tassa appiyam bhavissati iti
translated: Dog-duty-man: a dog, when it sits down in the presence of its master, scratches the ground with its two feet, it sits down barking the dog’s bark. This man, thinking “I will do the duty of a dog,” after exchanging greetings with the Lord, scratched the ground with his two hands, shook his head, barked “bhū bhū,” contracted his hands and feet, and sat down like a dog. On a hide: on a hide that was spread on the ground. Fully taken up: taken up after making it complete. What is your destiny? What is your future state? What will be unpleasant for you?

original: yāvatatiyaṃ paṭibāhati. Kukkuravatanti kukkuravatasamādānaṃ.
analyzed: yāvatatiyam kukkuravatanti kukkuravata samādānam
translated: He persists in this up to the third time. The dog-duty: the undertaking of the dog-duty.

original: 79. Bhāvetīti vaḍḍheti. Paripuṇṇanti anūnaṃ. Abbokiṇṇanti nirantaraṃ. Kukkurasīlanti
analyzed: bhāveti iti vaḍḍheti paripuṇṇanti anūnam nirantaram
translated: He cultivates: he increases. Complete: not deficient. Unbroken: without a break. The dog-manner:

original: kukkurācāraṃ. Kukkuracittanti “ajja paṭṭhāya kukkurehi kātabbaṃ karissāmī”ti evaṃ🔽uppannacittaṃ. Kukkurākappanti kukkurānaṃ gamanākāro atthi, tiṭṭhanākāro atthi, nisīdanākāro🔽atthi, sayanākāro atthi, uccārapassāvakaraṇākāro atthi, aññe kukkure disvā dante
analyzed: kukkura ācāram kukkura cittam ti ajja paṭṭhāya kukkurehi kātabbam karissāmi iti evam  uppanna cittam kukkurā ākappanti kukkurānam gamana ākāraḥ atthi tiṭṭhana ākāraḥ atthi nisīdana ākāraḥ  atthi sayana ākāraḥ atthi uccāra passāva karaṇa ākāraḥ atthi aññe kukkure disvā dante
translated: the dog-behaviour. The dog-state of mind: the state of mind arisen thus: “From today onward I shall do what dogs do.”

original: vivaritvā gamanākāro atthi, ayaṃ kukkurākappo nāma, taṃ bhāvetīti attho. Imināhaṃ
analyzed: vivaritvā gamana ākāraḥ atthi ayam kukkurākappaḥ nāma tam bhāveti iti iminā aham
translated: The dog-mode: there is a mode of going, a mode of standing, a mode of sitting, a mode of lying down, a mode of defecating, a mode of urinating, a mode of scratching when one wants to, a mode of looking back when one wants to, a mode of shaking out the bedding when one wants to, a mode of looking at a companion when one wants to, a mode of yawning when one wants to, a mode of opening the mouth when one wants to, a mode of stretching out the limbs when one wants to, a mode of shaking out the ears when one wants to, a mode of going after seeing other dogs and showing the teeth, this is called the dog-mode. The meaning is: he cultivates it.

original: sīlenātiādīsu ahaṃ iminā ācārena vā vatasamādānena vā dukkaratapacaraṇena vā methunaviratibrahmacariyena
analyzed: aham iminā ācārena vā vata samādānena vā dukkara tapa caraṇena vā methuna virati brahmacariyena
translated: By this virtue: the meaning is: by this virtue or by this undertaking of the vow or by this practice of what is hard to do or by this celibacy consisting in abstinence from sexual intercourse.

original: vāti attho. Devoti sakkasuyāmādīsu aññataro. Devaññataroti tesaṃ dutiyatatiyaṭṭhānādīsu
analyzed: vā ti atthaḥ devo ti sakka suyāma ādīsu aññataraḥ devaññataraḥ ti tesam dutiya tatiya ṭṭhāna ādīsu
translated: A god: one of the Sakka-Suyama gods, etc. Another god: one of the second or third, etc., of those.

original: aññataradevo. Micchādiṭṭhīti adevalokagāmimaggameva devalokagāmimaggoti gahetvā uppannatāya
analyzed: aññatara devaḥ micchādiṭṭhī iti a deva loka gāmi maggam eva deva loka gāmi maggo ti gahetvā uppanna tāya
translated: a certain god. Wrong view: because of the view that the path leading to the world of the gods is the path leading to the world of the gods,

original: sā assa micchādiṭṭhi nāma hoti. Aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmīti tassa hi nirayato vā tiracchānayonito
analyzed: sā assa micchādiṭṭhi nāma hoti aññataram gatim vadāmi iti tassa hi nirayataḥ vā tiracchāna yonitaḥ
translated: his view is called wrong view. I declare that he has a certain destination: for him there is no other destination than hell or the animal realm,

original: vā aññā gati natthi, tasmā evamāha. Sampajjamānanti diṭṭhiyā asammissaṃ hutvā nipajjamānaṃ.🔽Nāhaṃ, bhante, etaṃ rodāmi, yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāhāti yaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā evamāha,
analyzed: vā aññā gati na atthi tasmai evam āha sampajjamānam ti diṭṭhiyā a sammissam hutvā nipajjamānam  na aham bhante etam rodāmi yam mam bhagavān evam āha ati yam mam bhante bhagavān evam āha
translated: therefore he says thus. He lies down: he lies down without mixing with the view.

original: ahametaṃ bhagavato byākaraṇaṃ na rodāmi na paridevāmi, na anutthunāmīti attho. Evaṃ
analyzed: aham etam bhagavataḥ byākaraṇam na rodāmi na paridevāmi na an utthunāmi iti evam
translated: “Venerable sir, I do not weep because the Blessed One has said this to me,” he does not weep, does not lament, does not grieve, is the meaning. Thus

original: sakammakavasenettha attho veditabbo, na assumuñcanamattena.
analyzed: sa kammaka vasena ittha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ na assu muñcana mattena
translated: the meaning should be understood here by way of the active voice, not by way of the passive voice.

original: “Mataṃ vā amma rodanti, yo vā jīvaṃ na dissati;
analyzed: matam vai amma rodanti yaḥ vā jīvam na dissati
translated: “They weep for one who is dead, amma, or for one who is not seen alive;

original: Jīvantaṃ amma passantī, kasmā maṃ amma rodasī”ti. –
analyzed: jīvantam amma passantī kasmā mama amma rodasi iti
translated: Seeing me alive, amma, why do you weep, amma?”

original: Ayañcettha payogo. Apica me idaṃ, bhanteti apica kho me idaṃ, bhante, kukkuravataṃ
analyzed: ayam ca itthā payogaḥ apica me idam bhante iti apica kho me idam bhante kukkuravatam
translated: This is the construction here. Furthermore, venerable sir: moreover, venerable sir.

original: dīgharattaṃ samādinnaṃ, tasmiṃ sampajjantepi vuddhi natthi, vipajjantepi. Iti “ettakaṃ
analyzed: dīgharattam samādinnam tasmin sampajjante ipi natthi vipajjante ipi iti ettakam
translated: and it is not increased by its success nor decreased by its failure.

original: kālaṃ mayā katakammaṃ moghaṃ jāta”nti attano vipattiṃ paccavekkhamāno rodāmi, bhanteti.
analyzed: kālam mayā kata kammam mogham jātan ti attanaḥ vipattim paccavekkhamānaḥ rodāmi bhante iti
translated: and I have been doing it for a long time. If it succeeds, there is no increase in it, and if it fails, there is none either. So I weep, venerable sir, reflecting on my own failure: ‘For so long I have been making an effort in vain.’

original: 80. Govatantiādīni kukkuravatādīsu vuttanayeneva veditabbāni. Gavākappanti goākappaṃ.🔽Sesaṃ kukkurākappe vuttasadisameva. Yathā pana tattha aññe kukkure disvā dante vivaritvā
analyzed: govata nti ādīni kukkuravata ādīsu vutta nayena iva veditabbāni gavākappanti goākappam  sesam kukkurākappe vutta sadisam eva yathā pana tattha aññe kukkure disvā dante vivaritvā
translated: The cow-faced, etc., should be understood in the way already described under the dog-faced, etc. The cow-headed is the cow-faced.

original: gamanākāro, evamidha aññe gāvo disvā kaṇṇe ukkhipitvā gamanākāro veditabbo. Sesaṃ tādisameva.🔽81. Cattārimāni puṇṇa kammānīti kasmā imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi? Ayañhi desanā ekaccakammakiriyavasena
analyzed: gamana ākāraḥ evam idha aññe gāvaḥ disvā kaṇṇe ukkhipitvā gamana ākāraḥ veditabbo sesam tādisam eva  cattāri imāni puṇṇa kammāni iti kasmai imam desanam ārabhi ayam hi desanā ekacca kamma kiriya vasena
translated: The rest is similar to that given under the dog-headed. But while the dog-headed one opens his mouth and goes on seeing other dogs, here the cow-headed one should be understood as raising his ears and going on seeing other cows. The rest is similar.

original: āgatā, imasmiñca kammacatukke kathite imesaṃ kiriyā pākaṭā bhavissatīti imaṃ desanaṃ
analyzed: āgatāḥ imasmin ca kamma catukke kathite imesam kiriyā pākaṭā bhavissati iti imam desanam
translated: Why did he begin this teaching with “There are these four kinds of persons who perform the sacrifice”? Because this teaching comes under the heading of the single sacrifice. And when this tetrad of sacrifices is stated, the performance of these becomes evident. So he began this teaching with “There are these four kinds of persons who perform the sacrifice.”

original: ārabhi. Apica imaṃ kammacatukkameva desiyamānaṃ ime sañjānissanti, tato eko saraṇaṃ
analyzed: ārabhi apica imam kamma catukkam eva desiyamānam ime sañjānissanti tatas ekaḥ saraṇaṃ
translated: and he began to teach. Moreover, he thought: “When this tetrad of deeds is being taught, these will understand it. Then one will go for refuge,

original: gamissati, eko pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇissatīti ayameva etesaṃ sappāyāti ñatvāpi
analyzed: gamissati ekaḥ pabbajitvā arahattam pāpuṇissati iti ayam eva etesam sappāyā ati ñatvā api
translated: and the other, after going forth, will attain Arahantship.” Knowing that this teaching was suitable for them,

original: imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: imam desanam
translated: he began to teach.

original: Tattha kaṇhanti kāḷakaṃ dasaakusalakammapathakammaṃ. Kaṇhavipākanti apāye nibbattanato🔽kāḷakavipākaṃ. Sukkanti paṇḍaraṃ dasakusalakammapathakammaṃ. Sukkavipākanti sagge
analyzed: tattha kaṇhanti kāḷakam dasa akusala kammapatha kammam kaṇha vipākam ti apāye nibbattanato  kāḷaka vipākam sukkan ti paṇḍaram dasa kusala kammapatha kammam sukka vipākan ti sagge
translated: Herein, black is the ten unprofitable courses of action. Its ripening is black because of rebirth in the states of loss.🔽White is the ten profitable courses of action. Its ripening is white because of rebirth in the happy states.

original: nibbattanato paṇḍaravipākaṃ. Kaṇhasukkanti vomissakakammaṃ. Kaṇhasukkavipākanti sukhadukkhavipākaṃ.
analyzed: nibbattanataḥ paṇḍara vipākam kaṇha sukkam ti vomissaka kammam kaṇha sukka vipākam ti sukha dukkha vipākam
translated: Mixed is mixed action. Its ripening is mixed because of the mixedness of pleasure and pain.

original: Missakakammañhi katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyaṃ maṅgalahatthiṭṭhānādīsu uppanno
analyzed: missaka kamman hi katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyam maṅgala hatthi ṭṭhāna ādīsu uppannaḥ
translated: For after performing mixed action, through the unprofitable he is reborn in the animal generation in the state of a lucky elephant, etc.,

original: kusalena pavatte sukhaṃ vediyati. Kusalena rājakulepi nibbatto akusalena pavatte
analyzed: kusalena pavatte sukham vediyati kusalena rāja kule api nibbattaḥ akusalena pavatte
translated: and through the profitable he experiences pleasure in the course of his existence. And after being reborn in a royal family through the profitable,

original: dukkhaṃ vediyati. Akaṇhaṃ asukkanti kammakkhayakaraṃ catumaggacetanākammaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: dukkham vediyati a kaṇham a sukkam ti kamma khaya karam catu magga cetanā kammaṃ adhippetaṃ
translated: and he feels pain. It is action that causes the destruction of kamma that is intended by the words “neither dark nor bright.”

original: Tañhi yadi kaṇhaṃ bhaveyya, kaṇhavipākaṃ dadeyya. Yadi sukkaṃ bhaveyya, sukkavipākaṃ
analyzed: tat hi yadi kaṇham bhaveyya kaṇha vipākam dadeyya yadi sukkam bhaveyya sukka vipākam
translated: For if it were dark, it would give a dark result; if it were bright, it would give a bright result.

original: dadeyya. Ubhayavipākassa pana adānato akaṇhāsukkavipākattā “akaṇhaṃ asukka”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dadeyya ubhaya vipākassa pana adānataḥ akaṇha asukka vipāka attā akaṇham asukkanti vuttam
translated: But because it does not give a result that is either of those two, it is said to have a neither-dark-nor-bright result.

original: Ayaṃ tāva uddese attho.🔽Niddese pana sabyābajjhanti sadukkhaṃ. Kāyasaṅkhārādīsu kāyadvāre gahaṇādivasena
analyzed: ayam tāva uddese attho  niddese pana sa byābajjhanti sa dukkham kāya saṅkhāra ādīsu kāya dvāre gahaṇa ādi vasena
translated: This, firstly, is the meaning of the text.

original: copanappattā dvādasa akusalacetanā sabyābajjhakāyasaṅkhāro nāma. Vacīdvāre hanusañcopanavasena
analyzed: copana pattā dvādasa akusala cetanā sa byābajjha kāyasaṅkhāraḥ nāma vacī dvāre hanu sañcopana vasena
translated: As regards the commentary, the words “with painful impact” mean painful. The twelve kinds of unprofitable volition that reach the state of being a “threshold” by being the cause of the occurrence of bodily and verbal kamma in the three doors are called “bodily impulsion” .

original: vacībhedapavattikā tāyeva dvādasa vacīsaṅkhāro nāma. Ubhayacopanaṃ appattā raho cintayantassa
analyzed: vacībheda pavattikā tāya iva dvādasa vacīsaṅkhāro nāma ubhaya copanam appattā raho cintayantassa
translated: The same twelve kinds that occur in the verbal door by causing the utterance of speech in the form of the expression of joy, etc., are called “verbal impulsion” .

original: manodvāre pavattā manosaṅkhāro nāma. Iti tīsupi dvāresu kāyaduccaritādibhedā akusalacetanāva
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre pavattā manaḥ saṅkhāraḥ nāma iti dvāresu kāya duccarita ādi bhedāḥ
translated: The same twelve kinds that occur in the mind door in one who is thinking in private are called “mental impulsion” . Thus the unprofitable volition classed as bodily misconduct, etc., in the three doors

original: saṅkhārāti veditabbā. Imasmiñhi sutte cetanā dhuraṃ, upālisutte kammaṃ. Abhisaṅkharitvāti
analyzed: saṅkhārā ati veditabbāḥ imasmin hi sutte cetanā dhuram upāli sutte kammam abhisaṅkharitvā iti
translated: should be understood as formations. For in this sutta volition is the main subject, while in the Upāli Sutta it is kamma.

original: saṅkaḍḍhitvā, piṇḍaṃ katvāti attho. Sabyābajjhaṃ lokanti sadukkhaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
analyzed: saṅkaḍḍhitvā piṇḍam katvā iti attho sa byābajjham lokam ti sa dukkham lokam upapajjanti
translated: Having formed, having collected, having lumped together, is the meaning. They are reborn in a world with conflict, in a world with suffering.

original: Sabyābajjhā phassā phusantīti sadukkhā vipākaphassā phusanti. Ekantadukkhanti nirantaradukkhaṃ.
analyzed: sa byābajjhā phassā phusanti iti sa dukkhā vipāka phassā phusanti ekanta dukkhanti nirantara dukkhaṃ
translated: They are touched by painful contact, by painful resultants. They are entirely painful.

original: Bhūtāti hetvatthe nissakkavacanaṃ, bhūtakammato bhūtassa sattassa uppatti hoti. Idaṃ
analyzed: bhūtā ati hetvatthe nissakka vacanam bhūta kammataḥ bhūtassa sattassa uppatti hoti idam
translated: Bhūta is a word in the ablative case in the sense of cause: “The birth of a being is from kamma that has become.”

original: vuttaṃ hoti – yathābhūtaṃ kammaṃ sattā karonti, tathābhūtena kammena kammasabhāgavasena
analyzed: vuttam hoti yathābhūtam kammam sattā karonti tathābhūtena kammena kamma sabhāga vasena
translated: This is what is meant: “Beings do kamma in accordance with the way it is, and they are reborn in accordance with the kamma they have done. It is by way of the similarity of kamma that their rebirth takes place.”

original: tesaṃ upapatti hoti. Tenevāha “yaṃ karoti tena upapajjatī”ti. Ettha ca tenāti kammena
analyzed: tesam hoti tena iva āha yam karoti tena upapajjati iti ettha ca tena ati kammena
translated: Therefore it is said: “By what one does one is led to rebirth.” Here the word tena is used as if it were the kamma.

original: viya vuttā, upapatti ca nāma vipākena hoti. Yasmā pana vipākassa kammaṃ hetu, tasmā
analyzed: viya vuttā upapatti ca nāma vipākena hoti yasmā pana vipākassa kammam hetu tasmā
translated: And rebirth is by way of result. But since kamma is the cause of result,

original: tena mūlahetubhūtena kammena nibbattatīti ayamettha attho. Phassā phusantīti yena
analyzed: tena mūla hetu bhūtena kammena nibbattati iti ayam ettha attho phassā phusanti iti yena
