translated: the meaning here is that it is produced by that kamma, which is the root cause.🔽They are touched by contact.

original: kammavipākena nibbatto, taṃkammavipākaphassā phusanti. Kammadāyādāti kammadāyajjā🔽kammameva nesaṃ dāyajjaṃ santakanti vadāmi.🔽Abyābajjhanti niddukkhaṃ. Imasmiṃ vāre kāyadvāre pavattā aṭṭha kāmāvacarakusalacetanā
analyzed: kamma vipākena nibbattaḥ taṃ kamma vipāka phassā phusanti kamma dāyādāti kamma dāyajjā  kammam eva na isam dāyajjam santakanti vadāmi  a byābajjhanti niddukkham imasmin vāre kāya dvāre pavattāḥ aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā
translated: He is born as a result of kamma and the results of that kamma touch him. ‘Heirs of kamma’: they have kamma as their heir,

original: kāyasaṅkhāro nāma. Tāyeva vacīdvāre pavattā vacīsaṅkhāro nāma. Manodvāre pavattā
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāraḥ nāma tāyā iva vacī dvāre pavattā vacī saṅkhāraḥ nāma manaḥ dvāre pavattā
translated: I say. ‘Free from affliction’: free from pain. In this section the eight kinds of profitable volition of the sense sphere that occur in the body door are called bodily formation. The same that occur in the speech door are called verbal formation.

original: tāyeva aṭṭha, tisso ca heṭṭhimajhānacetanā abyābajjhamanosaṅkhāro nāma. Jhānacetanā
analyzed: tāya iva aṭṭha tisso ca heṭṭhima jhāna cetanāḥ abyābajjha manosaṅkhāraḥ nāma jhāna cetanā
translated: The same eight and the three kinds of volition of the lower jhāna are called the non-afflictive mental formation.

original: tāva hotu, kāmāvacarā kinti abyābajjhamanosaṅkhāro nāma jātāti. Kasiṇasajjanakāle
analyzed: tāva hotu kāmāvacarā kinti a byābajjha manaḥ saṅkhāraḥ nāma jātā ati kasiṇa sajjana kāle
translated: Let that be. But what is the non-afflictive mental formation that is of the sense sphere? It is found in the case of one who is practising the kasiṇa and in the case of one who is developing it.

original: ca kasiṇāsevanakāle ca labbhanti. Kāmāvacaracetanā paṭhamajjhānacetanāya ghaṭitā,
analyzed: ca kasiṇa āsevana kāle ca labbhanti kāmāvacara cetanā paṭhama jhāna cetanāya ghaṭitā
translated: The volition of the sense sphere is combined with the volition of the first jhāna,

original: catutthajjhānacetanā tatiyajjhānacetanāya ghaṭitā. Iti tīsupi dvāresu kāyasucaritādibhedā
analyzed: catuttha jhāna cetanā tatiya jhāna cetanāya ghaṭitā iti dvāresu kāya su carita ādi bhedā
translated: and the volition of the fourth jhāna is combined with the volition of the third jhāna. So in the three doors the kinds of bodily good conduct, etc.,

original: kusalacetanāva saṅkhārāti veditabbo. Tatiyavāro ubhayamissakavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: kusala cetanā ava saṅkhārā ti veditabbaḥ tatiya vāraḥ ubhaya missaka vasena veditabbā
translated: and wholesome volition is the volitions. The third section should be understood as a mixture of both.

original: Seyyathāpi manussātiādīsu manussānaṃ tāva kālena sukhaṃ kālena dukkhaṃ pākaṭameva,🔽devesu pana bhummadevatānaṃ, vinipātikesu vemānikapetānaṃ kālena sukhaṃ kālena dukkhaṃ
analyzed: seyyathā api manussa ati ādīsu manussānam tāva kālena sukham kālena dukkham pākaṭam eva  devesu pana bhummadevatānam vinipātikesu vemānika petānam kālena sukham kālena dukkham
translated: As to “among human beings” and so on, it is obvious that human beings have pleasure and pain by turns.🔽But it should be understood that among deities there is pleasure and pain by turns among the deities of the earth and the deities who have come down to earth, and among the petas who are called “those who get food by their own effort” .

original: hotīti veditabbaṃ. Hatthiādīsu tiracchānesupi labbhatiyeva.
analyzed: hoti iti veditabbam hatthi ādīsu tiracchānesu pi
translated: And it is found among the animals such as elephants and so on.

original: Tatrāti tesu tīsu kammesu. Tassa pahānāya yā cetanāti tassa pahānatthāya maggacetanā.
analyzed: tatra ati tesu tīsu kammesu tassa pahānāya yā cetanā ati tassa pahāna atthāya magga cetanā
translated: “As to that, the volition for abandoning that” is the path volition for the abandoning of that.🔽There is no other state more purified than the path volition for the purpose of reaching the kamma.

original: Kammaṃ patvāva maggacetanāya añño paṇḍarataro dhammo nāma natthi. Idaṃ pana kammacatukkaṃ🔽patvā dvādasa akusalacetanā kaṇhā nāma, tebhūmakakusalacetanā sukkā nāma, maggacetanā
analyzed: kammaṃ patvā ava magga cetanāya añño paṇḍarataro dhammo nāma natthi idam pana kamma catukkam  patvā dvādasa akusala cetanā kaṇhā nāma tebhūmaka kusala cetanā sukkā nāma magga cetanā
translated: But this tetrad of kamma

original: akaṇhā asukkāti āgatā.
analyzed: a kaṇhā a sukkā ati āgatā
translated: is called “black” because it is the twelve unwholesome volitions, and it is called “white” because it is the wholesome volition of the three planes, and it is called “neither black nor white” because it is the path volition.

original: 82. “Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante”ti idaṃ so “ciraṃ vata me aniyyānikapakkhe yojetvā attā
analyzed: labheyya aham bhante ti idam so ciram vata me aniyyānika pakkhe yojetvā attā
translated: “Venerable sir, may I receive the going forth in the Blessed One’s presence? May I receive the full admission?” He thought: “At last I have got him to join the side that is not doomed to defeat.

original: kilamito, ‘sukkhanadītīre nhāyissāmī’ti samparivattentena viya thuse koṭṭentena viya
analyzed: kilamitaḥ sukkha nadī tīre nhāyissāmi iti samparivattentena viya thuse koṭṭentena viya
translated: as if he were tired out by turning round and round, saying, “I will bathe in the river Sukka,” or by threshing with his armpit,

original: ca na koci attho nipphādito, handāhaṃ attānaṃ yoge yojemī”ti cintetvā āha. Atha bhagavā
analyzed: ca na koci atthaḥ nipphāditaḥ handa aham attānam yoge yojemi iti cintetvā āha atha bhagavā
translated: and no purpose has been served. Now I shall apply myself to yoga.” So he said.🔽The probation for a former member of another sect is prescribed in the Khandhaka in the section on the proper course .

original: yonena khandhake titthiyaparivāso paññatto, yaṃ aññatitthiyapubbo sāmaṇerabhūmiyaṃ🔽ṭhito – “ahaṃ, bhante, itthannāmo aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhāmi
analyzed: yonena khandhake titthiya parivāsaḥ paññattaḥ yam añña titthiya pubbo sāmaṇera bhūmiyam  ṭhitaḥ aham bhante itthannāmaḥ añña titthiya pubbaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye ākaṅkhāmi
translated: A former member of another sect who is a novice🔽should take up the probation in the way beginning, “Venerable sirs, I, so-and-so, a former member of another sect, desire acceptance in this Dhamma and Discipline.

original: upasampadaṃ, svāhaṃ, bhante, saṅghaṃ cattāro māse parivāsaṃ yācāmī”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: upasampadam svāham bhante saṅgham cattāraḥ māse parivāsam yācāmi itiādinā nayena
translated: I ask the Order for probation for four months.”

original: samādiyitvā parivasati, taṃ sandhāya “yo kho, seniya, aññatitthiyapubbo”tiādimāha.
analyzed: samādiyitvā parivasati tam sandhāya yaḥ kho seniya añña titthiya pubba uti ādim āha
translated: The passage beginning, “Seniya, a former member of another sect,” refers to him.

original: Tattha pabbajjanti vacanasiliṭṭhatāvaseneva vuttaṃ. Aparivasitvāyeva hi pabbajjaṃ
analyzed: tattha pabbajjanti vacana siliṭṭha tā vasena iva vuttam a parivasitvāya iva hi pabbajjam
translated: Herein, “gone forth” is said according to the grammatical construction of the words. For he obtains the going forth even without probation.

original: labhati. Upasampadatthikena pana nātikālena gāmappavesanādīni aṭṭha vattāni pūrentena
analyzed: labhati upasampad atthikena pana na atikālena gāma ppavesana ādīni aṭṭha vattāni pūrentena
translated: But one who desires acceptance must fulfil the eight duties, such as entering the village only for alms,

original: parivasitabbaṃ. Āraddhacittāti aṭṭhavattapūraṇena tuṭṭhacittā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo.🔽Vitthārato panesa titthiyaparivāso samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāya pabbajjakhandhakavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: parivasitabbam āraddha cittā ati aṭṭhavatta pūraṇena tuṭṭha cittā ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ  vitthārato pana isa titthiya parivāso samantapāsādikāya vinaya aṭṭhakathāya pabbajja khandhaka vaṇṇanāyaṃ
translated: He should live on probation. With his mind inclined: with his mind satisfied by fulfilling the eight means of settling. This is the brief explanation here.🔽But the detailed explanation should be understood in the way given in the commentary on the chapter on going forth in the Sāratthapakāsinī, the commentary on the Vinaya.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Apica metthāti apica me ettha. Puggalavemattatā viditāti

original: pavattā. Tampi tathāgato na bhāsati. Tatiyavācā “idāni akatapuññatāya duggato dubbaṇṇo🔽appesakkho, idha ṭhatvāpi puna puññaṃ na karosi, dutiyacittavāre kathaṃ catūhi apāyehi
analyzed: pavattā tam pi tathāgataḥ na bhāsati tatiya vācā idāni a kata puñña tāya duggataḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ  appesakkho idha ṭhatvā api puna puññam na karosi dutiya citta vāre katham catūhi apāyehi
translated: and so on. The second kind of speech occurs thus, “The robber is a robber,” “The slave is a slave,” “The misbehaving person is a misbehaving person,”

original: na muccissasī”ti evaṃ mahājanassa atthapurekkhārena dhammapurekkhārena anusāsanīpurekkhārena🔽ca vattabbavācā. Tatra kālaññū tathāgatoti tasmiṃ tatiyabyākaraṇe tassā vācāya byākaraṇatthāya
analyzed: na muccissasi iti evam mahājanassa attha purekkhārena dhamma purekkhārena anusāsanī purekkhārena  ca vattabba vācā tatra kālaññū tathāgataḥ ti tasmin tatiya byākaraṇe tassāḥ vācāya byākaraṇa atthāya
translated: and so on. The third kind of speech is that which should be spoken with a view to the benefit of the people, with a view to the Dhamma, and with a view to the discipline, thus: “Now, because you have not made merit, you are unfortunate, ugly, and insignificant. Even while standing here you do not make merit. In the second thought-unit how will you escape from the four states of loss?”

original: tathāgato kālaññū hoti, mahājanassa ādānakālaṃ gahaṇakālaṃ jānitvāva byākarotīti attho.
analyzed: tathāgato kālaññū hoti mahājanassa ādāna kālam gahaṇa kālam jānitvā ava byākaroti iti attho
translated: Herein, the Tathāgata is one who knows the right occasion: in the case of this third kind of answer, the Tathāgata is one who knows the right occasion for answering it. The meaning is that he answers it after knowing the right occasion for the people to take it up and to grasp it.

original: Piyapakkhe paṭhamavācā aṭṭhāniyakathā nāma. Sā evaṃ veditabbā – evaṃ kira gāmavāsimahallakaṃ

original: nagaraṃ āgantvā pānāgāre pivantaṃ vañcetukāmā sambahulā dhuttā pītaṭṭhāne ṭhatvā
analyzed: nagaram āgantvā pānāgāre pivantam vañcetu kāmā sambahulā dhuttā pīta ṭṭhāne ṭhatvā

analyzed: tena saddhim suram pivantā imassa nivāsana pāvuraṇam pi hatthe bhaṇḍakam pi sabbam  gaṇhissāma iti cintetvā katikam akaṃsu ekekam atta paccakkha katham kathema yaḥ

analyzed: kathesi kathitam vā na saddahati tam dāsam katvā gaṇhissāma ati tam pi mahallakam

analyzed: tumhākam pi tāta ruccati iti evam hotu tāta ati  ekaḥ dhuttaḥ āha mayham bho mātu mayi kucchi gate kapiṭṭha phala dohalaḥ ahosi sā
translated: “So be it, father.”🔽One of the prostitutes said, “When I was in my mother’s womb, there was a craving for a fruit from the top of a jack tree.

analyzed: gāmika mahallakaḥ tuṇhī nisīditvā sabbesam kathā pariyosāne pucchitaḥ āha evam bhavissati

analyzed: tathārūpāsu nikkāraṇa kathāsu kathitāsu āha mayham pi tātā suṇātha na tumhākam yā iva

analyzed: tassa aneka karīsa satassa kappāsa khettassa majjhe ekaḥ kappāsa rukkhaḥ mahā asīti hatthubbedho  ahosi tassa pañca sākhā tāsu avasesa sākhā phalam na gaṇhiṃsu pācīna sākhāyaḥ ekam eva

analyzed: te na mayam vattum na asakkhiṃsu atha ne vinicchayam

translated: The second kind of speech is the various kinds of flattering speech of others, such as flattery for the sake of material gain, for the sake of intimacy, and so on, as well as deceitful speech.

analyzed: rāja kathanti ādi naya ppavattā tiracchāna kathā ca tam pi tathāgataḥ na bhāsati tatiya vācā

analyzed: ariya sacca sannissita kathāḥ yam vassa satam pi suṇantāḥ paṇḍitāḥ na iva tittim gacchanti

analyzed: iti tathāgataḥ na iva sabbam pi appiya vācam bhāsati na piya vācam tatiyam tatiyam eva  pana bhāsitabba kālam an atikkamitvā bhāsati tattha tatiyam appiya vācam sandhāya heṭṭhā
translated: So the Tathāgata speaks neither all that is unlovable nor all that is lovable.🔽The third kind of speech he speaks only when the time for it has come.

original: daharakumāraupamā āgatāti veditabbaṃ.🔽87. Udāhu ṭhānasovetanti udāhu ṭhānuppattikañāṇena taṅkhaṇaṃyeva taṃ tathāgatassa

original: upaṭṭhātīti pucchati. Saññātoti ñāto paññāto pākaṭo. Dhammadhātūti dhammasabhāvo.
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti iti pucchati saññātaḥ ati ñātaḥ paññātaḥ pākaṭaḥ dhammadhātū ti dhamma sabhāvaḥ

analyzed: sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa itam adhivacanam tam bhagavatā su paṭividdham hattha gatam bhagavataḥ

analyzed: tasmā saḥ yam yam icchati tam tam sabbam ṭhānasā uva paṭibhāti iti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva

original: Ayaṃ pana dhammadesanā neyyapuggalavasena pariniṭṭhitāti.
analyzed: ayam pana dhamma desanā neyya puggala vasena pariniṭṭhitā ti

analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya

analyzed: evam me sutam ti bahu vedanīya suttam tattha pañcakaṅgo thapati iti pañcakaṅgo ti
translated: Thus have I heard. The Bahuvedaniya Sutta. There, Pañcakaṅga the foreman: Pañcakaṅga is his name.

original: tassa nāmaṃ. Vāsipharasunikhādanadaṇḍamuggarakāḷasuttanāḷisaṅkhātehi vā aṅgehi samannāgatattā
analyzed: tassa nāmam vā asiphara sunikhādana daṇḍa muggara kāḷa sutta nāḷi saṅkhātehi vā aṅgehi samannāgata ttā
translated: Because he is endowed with the five limbs called the razor, the axe, the adze, the hammer, and the black string,

analyzed: so pañcaṅgo ti paññāto thapatī iti vaḍḍhakī jeṭṭhakaḥ udāyī iti paṇḍita audāyi thero
translated: he is known as Pañcakaṅga. Foreman: the chief of the builders. Udāyī: the wise elder Udāyī.

original: 89. Pariyāyanti kāraṇaṃ. Dvepānandāti dvepi, ānanda. Pariyāyenāti kāraṇena. Ettha
analyzed: pariyāyanti kāraṇam dvepa ānanda ati ānanda pariyāyena ati kāraṇena ettha
translated: Cause: reason. Two, Ānanda: both of you, Ānanda. By reason: by cause.

original: ca kāyikacetasikavasena dve veditabbā. Sukhādivasena tisso, indriyavasena sukhindriyādikā
analyzed: ca kāyika cetasika vasena dve veditabbā sukha ādi vasena tisso indriya vasena sukha indriya ādikā
translated: And here, they should be understood as two by way of bodily and mental, three by way of pleasure, etc., and by way of the faculties of pleasure, etc.,

original: pañca, dvāravasena cakkhusamphassajādikā cha, upavicāravasena “cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā🔽somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicaratī”tiādikā aṭṭhārasa, cha gehassitāni somanassāni,🔽cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni, cha gehassitāni domanassāni, cha nekkhammasitāni🔽domanassāni, cha gehassitā upekkhā, cha nekkhammasitāti evaṃ chattiṃsa, tā atīte
analyzed: pañca dvāra vasena cakkhu samphassa ja ādikā cha upavicāra vasena cakkhunā rūpam disvā  somanassa ṭṭhāniyam rūpam upavicarati iti ādikā aṭṭhārasa cha geha sitāni somanassāni  cha nekkhamma sitāni somanassāni cha geha sitāni domanassāni cha nekkhamma sitāni  domanassāni cha gehassitā upekkhā cha nekkhamma sitā ati evam chattiṃsa tāḥ atīte
translated: There are five kinds of joy based on the five strands of sense pleasure. There are six kinds based on the six doors, namely, those born of eye-contact, etc. There are eighteen kinds based on the eighteen kinds of minor trace, namely, “On seeing a form with the eye, one pursues forms that arouse joy” , etc. There are thirty-six kinds, namely, the six kinds of joy based on the household life, the six kinds of joy based on renunciation, the six kinds of grief based on the household life, the six kinds of grief based on renunciation, the six kinds of equanimity based on the household life, and the six kinds of equanimity based on renunciation. These are thirty-six kinds of joy and grief and equanimity based on the past, the future, and the present.

original: chattiṃsa, anāgate chattiṃsa, paccuppanne chattiṃsāti evaṃ aṭṭhavedanāsataṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽90. Pañca kho ime, ānanda, kāmaguṇāti ayaṃ pāṭiekko anusandhi. Na kevalampi dve ādiṃ
analyzed: chattiṃsa anāgate chattiṃsa paccuppanne chattiṃsa ati evam aṭṭha vedanā satam veditabbam  pañca kho ime ānanda ayam pāṭiekkaḥ na kevalam pi dve
translated: There are five kinds of feeling classed according to the door, namely, those born of eye-contact, etc., which make six; there are eighteen kinds classed according to the kinds of reflection, namely, “On seeing a visible object with the eye, he reflects on a visible object that is a cause for joy” , etc., which make eighteen; there are thirty-six kinds classed according to the household and the homeless life, namely, the six kinds of joy classed according to the household life, the six kinds of joy classed according to the homeless life, the six kinds of grief classed according to the household life, the six kinds of grief classed according to the homeless life, the six kinds of equanimity classed according to the household life, and the six kinds of equanimity classed according to the homeless life; there are thirty-six kinds in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present, which make one hundred and eight kinds of feeling.🔽“Ānanda, there are these five cords of sensual pleasure” . This is the particular connexion here.

original: katvā vedanā bhagavatā paññattā, pariyāyena ekāpi vedanā kathitā. Taṃ dassento pañcakaṅgassa🔽thapatino vādaṃ upatthambhetuṃ imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi.

analyzed: purima vāre vutta sadisam eva  natthi hetu natthi paccayo ti ettha paccayaḥ hetu vevacanam ubhayena api vijjamānakam eva

original: kāyaduccaritādisaṃkilesapaccayaṃ kāyasucaritādivisuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipanti. Natthi
analyzed: kāya duccarita ādi saṃkilesa paccayam kāya su carita ādi visuddhi paccayam paṭikkhipanti natthi
translated: ‘There is no cause, there is no condition’ : here ‘condition’ is a synonym for ‘cause.’ By both they reject the existing condition for defilement consisting in bodily misconduct, etc., and the existing condition for cleansing consisting in bodily good conduct, etc. ‘There is no

original: balaṃ, natthi vīriyaṃ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamoti sattānaṃ saṃkilesituṃ
analyzed: balam natthi vīriyam natthi purisa thāmaḥ natthi purisa parakkamo ti sattānam saṃkilesitum
translated: There is no strength, no effort, no manly endurance, no manly strength.🔽There is no strength or effort in beings for the purpose of defilement or purification.

original: vā visujjhituṃ vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā purisena kātabbo nāma purisathāmo vā purisaparakkamo vā natthi.
analyzed: vā visujjhitum vā balam vā vīriyam vā purisena kātabbaḥ nāma purisa thāmaḥ vā purisa parakkamaḥ vā natthi
translated: There is no manly endurance or manly strength that can be done by a man.

original: Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese nidassenti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo
analyzed: sabbe sattā ti oṭṭha goṇa gadrabha ādayaḥ anavasese nidassenti sabbe pāṇā ti eka indriyaḥ
translated: All beings: they show all beings without exception, such as oxen, donkeys, etc.

original: pāṇo dvindriyo pāṇoti ādivasena vadanti. Sabbe bhūtāti aṇḍakosavatthikosesu bhūte
analyzed: pāṇaḥ dvindriyaḥ pāṇaḥ iti ādi vasena vadanti sabbe bhūtā ati aṇḍa kosa vatthi kosesu bhūte
translated: All breathing things: they say “a breathing thing with one sense-organ,” “a breathing thing with two sense-organs,” etc.🔽All living beings: they refer to living beings in the egg and in the womb.

original: sandhāya vadanti. Sabbe jīvāti sāliyavagodhumādayo sandhāya vadanti. Tesu hete viruhanabhāvena
analyzed: sandhāya vadanti sabbe jīvāti sāli yava godhuma ādayo sandhāya vadanti tesu ha ete viruhana bhāvena
translated: All that is born: they refer to rice, barley, etc. In these, because of their growth,🔽there is the notion of a living being.

original: jīvasaññino. Avasā abalā avīriyāti tesaṃ attano vaso vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā natthi.🔽Niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti ettha niyatīti niyatatā. Saṅgatīti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ
analyzed: jīva saññinaḥ a vasāḥ abalāḥ a vīriyā ti tesam attanaḥ vasaḥ vā balam vā vīriyam vā natthi  niyati saṅgati bhāva pariṇatā ati ettha niyatī iti niyata tā saṅgatī iti channam abhijātīnam
translated: Powerless, without control: they have no power or control of their own.

original: tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Bhāvoti sabhāvoyeva. Evaṃ niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena
analyzed: tattha tattha gamanam evam niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena
translated: Subject to the conditions of union and destiny: here “subject to the conditions” means subject to conditions. “Union” means the going of the six classes of birth here and there. “Destiny” means the nature of the being. Thus,

original: ca pariṇatā nānappakārataṃ pattā. Yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ, so tatheva bhavati.🔽Yena no bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavatīti dassenti. Chasvevābhijātīsūti chasu eva abhijātīsu
analyzed: ca pariṇatāḥ nānā pakāra tat pattāḥ yena hi yathā bhavitabbam saḥ tathā iva bhavati  yena naḥ bhavitabbam saḥ na bhavati iti dassenti chasu eva abhijātīsu iti chasu eva abhijātīsu
translated: and they have come to pass in various ways. For it is just as it should be that it is so.🔽And it is not so that it is not so. They show that it is just in the six kinds of reappearance that they experience pleasure and pain,

original: ṭhatvā sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti, aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dassenti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā sukham ca dukkham ca paṭisaṃvedenti aññā sukha dukkha bhūmi natthi iti dassenti
translated: and that there is no other plane of pleasure and pain.

original: Tattha cha abhijātiyo nāma kaṇhābhijāti nīlābhijāti lohitābhijāti haliddābhijāti
analyzed: tattha cha abhijātiyaḥ nāma kaṇha abhijāti nīla abhijāti lohita abhijāti halidda abhijāti
translated: Herein, the six kinds of reappearance are the black kind, the blue kind, the red kind, the yellow kind,

original: sukkābhijāti paramasukkābhijātīti. Tattha sākuṇiko sūkariko luddo macchaghātako coro
analyzed: sukka abhijāti parama sukka abhijāti iti tattha sākuṇiko sūkarikaḥ luddaḥ maccha ghātako coro
translated: the white kind, and the very white kind. Herein, the black kind is such as a bird-catcher, a pig-killer, a butcher, a hunter, a fisherman,

original: coraghātako, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā, ayaṃ kaṇhābhijāti nāma. Bhikkhū
analyzed: cora ghātakaḥ ye vā pana aññe pi keci kurūra kammantāḥ ayam kaṇhābhijāti nāma bhikkhū
translated: a thief, or any other such kind of craft. The blue kind is monks,

original: nīlābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti. “Bhikkhū
analyzed: nīlābhijātī iti vadanti te kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti bhikkhū
translated: they say. They are said to eat after inserting thorns into the four requisites. For this is their text: “Monks are thorn-eaters.”

original: ca kaṇṭakavuttino”ti ayañhi nesaṃ pāḷiyeva. Atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikā evaṃ nāma eke
analyzed: ca kaṇṭakavuttino ti ayam hi atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikāḥ evam nāma eke
translated: Or else those who live by thorns are called “blue”

original: pabbajitāti vadanti. “Samaṇakaṇṭakavuttikā”tipi hi nesaṃ pāḷi. Lohitābhijāti nāma
analyzed: pabbajitā iti vadanti hi nesam pāḷi lohitābhijāti nāma
translated: they are called “gone forth.” For their text reads: “They live as ascetics with thorns.”🔽The “red-complexioned” are the Niganthas.🔽They are called “one-cloth-wearers.” They are whiter than the first two, it seems.

original: nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadanti. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī acelakasāvakā
analyzed: nigaṇṭhāḥ ekasāṭakā ati vadanti ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā gihī acelakasāvakā
translated: The lay disciples of the naked ascetics

original: haliddābhijātīti vadanti. Iti attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karonti.
analyzed: haliddābhijātī iti vadanti iti attano paccaya dāyake nigaṇṭhehi pi jeṭṭhakatare karonti
translated: are called “yellow-complexioned.” So they make the Niganthas, their own supporters, the whitest of all.

original: Nando, vaccho, saṅkicco, ayaṃ sukkābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā.
analyzed: nandaḥ vacchaḥ saṅkiccaḥ ayam sukkābhijātī iti vadanti te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā
translated: Nanda, Vaccha, Saṅkicca, are called “white-complexioned.” They are whiter than the first four, it seems.

original: Ājīvake pana paramasukkābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā.
analyzed: ājīvake pana parama sukka abhijātī iti vadanti te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā
translated: But the Ājīvaka disciples are called “the whitest of all.” They are whiter than all the rest, it seems.

original: Tattha sabbe sattā paṭhamaṃ sākuṇikādayova honti, tato visujjhamānā sakyasamaṇā honti,
analyzed: tattha sabbe sattā paṭhamam sākuṇika ādayaḥ uva honti tatas sakya samaṇāḥ honti
translated: Herein, all these beings are first fowlers, and so on. Then, as they become purified, they become Sakyan ascetics,

original: tato visujjhamānā nigaṇṭhā, tato ājīvakasāvakā, tato nandādayo, tato ājīvakāti ayametesaṃ
analyzed: tatas visujjhamānāḥ nigaṇṭhā tatas ājīvaka sāvakā tatas nanda ādayaḥ tatas ājīvaka ati ayam etesam
translated: then Niganthas, then Ājīvaka disciples, then Nanda, and so on, then Ājīvakas. This is their theory.

original: laddhi. Sukkapakkho vuttapaccanīkena veditabbo. Sesamidhāpi purimavāre vuttasadisameva.
analyzed: laddhi sukkapakkhaḥ vutta paccanīkena veditabbaḥ sesam idha api purima vāre vutta sadisam eva
translated: The white faction should be understood in the opposite sense to the one just stated. The rest here is of the same kind as that already stated in the case of the first faction.

original: Imāsu pana tīsu diṭṭhīsu natthikadiṭṭhi vipākaṃ paṭibāhati, akiriyadiṭṭhi kammaṃ
analyzed: imāsu pana tīsu diṭṭhīsu natthika diṭṭhi vipākam paṭibāhati akiriya diṭṭhi kammaṃ
translated: But of these three views, the view that there is no efficacy is a denial of the result, the view that there is no doing is a denial of the action,

original: paṭibāhati, ahetukadiṭṭhi ubhayampi paṭibāhati. Tattha kammaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi vipāko
analyzed: paṭibāhati ahetuka diṭṭhi ubhayam pi paṭibāhati tattha kammam paṭibāhantena api vipāko
translated: and the view that there is no cause is a denial of both. Herein, by one who denies the result the action is also denied,

original: paṭibāhito hoti, vipākaṃ paṭibāhantenāpi kammaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ. Iti sabbepete atthato
analyzed: paṭibāhitaḥ hoti vipākam paṭibāhantena api kammam paṭibāhitam iti sabbe pi ete atthataḥ
translated: and by one who denies the action the result is also denied. So all of them in fact

original: ubhayapaṭibāhakā natthikavādā ceva ahetukavādā akiriyavādā ca honti. Ye pana tesaṃ
analyzed: ubhaya paṭibāhakāḥ natthika vādā ca iva ahetuka vādāḥ akiriya vādā ca honti ye pana tesam
translated: are deniers of both, and they are also deniers of efficacy and deniers of cause and deniers of doing.

original: laddhiṃ gahetvā rattiṭṭhāne divāṭṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti, tesaṃ – “natthi
analyzed: laddhim gahetvā ratti ṭṭhāne divāṭṭhāne nisinnā sajjhāyanti vīmaṃsanti tesam na atthi
translated: But those who, having adopted their view, sit down to recite and to discuss it in the daytime in their daytime quarters and at night in their night quarters,

original: dinnaṃ natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, karoto na kariyati pāpaṃ, natthi hetu natthi paccayo”ti tasmiṃ
analyzed: dinnam natthi karotaḥ na kariyati pāpam natthi hetu natthi paccayo ti tasmim
translated: in them wrong mindfulness is established on the object, “There is no giving, no offering … down to … no good and virtuous people arise in the world,”

original: ārammaṇe micchāsati santiṭṭhati, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, javanāni javanti, paṭhamajavane
analyzed: ārammaṇe micchā satī santiṭṭhati cittam ekaggam hoti javanāni javanti paṭhama javane
translated: and the mind becomes concentrated, and impulsion impels. In the first impulsion they are still curable,

original: satekicchā honti, tathā dutiyādīsu. Sattame buddhānampi atekicchā anivattino ariṭṭhakaṇṭakasadisā.
analyzed: sa tekicchāḥ honti tathā dutiya ādīsu sattame buddhānam pi atekicchāḥ anivattinaḥ ariṭṭha kaṇṭaka sadisāḥ
translated: and likewise in the second and the third. But in the seventh they are incurable, irreversible, like Ariṭṭha and Kaḷārakhattiya.

original: Tattha koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamati, koci dve, koci tīṇipi, ekasmiṃ okkantepi dvīsu
analyzed: tattha koci ekam dassanam okkamati koci dve koci tīṇi pi ekasmin okkante pi dvīsu
translated: Herein, some enter upon one view, some upon two, some upon three.

original: tīsu okkantesupi niyatamicchādiṭṭhikova hoti, patto saggamaggāvaraṇañceva mokkhamaggāvaraṇañca,🔽abhabbo tassa attabhāvassa anantaraṃ saggampi gantuṃ, pageva mokkhaṃ. Vaṭṭakhāṇu
analyzed: tīsu okkantesu pi niyatam icchādiṭṭhikaḥ uva hoti patto sagga magga āvaraṇam ca iva mokkha magga āvaraṇam ca  abhabbaḥ tassa atta bhāvassa anantaram saggam pi gantum pagā iva mokkham
translated: Even when one has entered upon one, two, or three, he is still definitely one of false view, and he has reached the plane of the round of rebirths that is obstructed as to the path to heaven and as to the path to deliverance.

original: nāmesa satto pathavīgopako. Kiṃ panesa ekasmiṃyeva attabhāve niyato hoti, udāhu aññasmimpīti?
analyzed: nāma isa satto pathavī gopako kim pana esa ekasmiṃ yeva attabhāve niyataḥ hoti udāhu aññasmim pi iti
translated: He is incapable of arousing even the path to heaven, let alone the path to deliverance, in that existence. The being in the crevice of the world-system is a subterranean animal. But is he definitely so only in that existence, or in other existences too?

original: Ekasmiññeva niyato, āsevanavasena pana bhavantarepi taṃ taṃ diṭṭhiṃ rocetiyeva. Evarūpassa
analyzed: ekasmin ñeva niyataḥ āsevana vasena pana bhavantare pi tam tam diṭṭhim rocetiya iva evarūpassa
translated: He is definitely so only in that existence. But by repetition in other existences he comes to prefer that view.

original: hi yebhuyyena bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: hi yebhuyyena bhavataḥ vuṭṭhānam nāma natthi
translated: For such a one there is generally no rebirth except in that place.🔽Therefore, like a snake, avoid

original: Tasmā akalyāṇajanaṃ, āsīvisamivoragaṃ;
analyzed: tasmai akalyāṇa janam
translated: A wicked man from far away,

original: Ārakā parivajjeyya, bhūtikāmo vicakkhaṇoti.
analyzed: ārakā parivajjeyya bhūti kāmaḥ vicakkhaṇo ti
translated: If you are wise and want to live.

original: 103. Natthi sabbaso āruppāti arūpabrahmaloko nāma sabbākārena natthi. Manomayāti
analyzed: na atthi sabbaso āruppā ati arūpa brahma lokaḥ nāma sabba ākārena na atthi manaḥ mayā ati
translated: There is no immaterial state at all: the immaterial plane of existence called the realm of infinite space does not exist in any way at all. Made only of mind:

original: jhānacittamayā. Saññāmayāti arūpajjhānasaññāya saññāmayā. Rūpānaṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya
analyzed: jhāna citta mayā saññā mayā ati arūpa jhāna saññāya saññā mayā rūpā naṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya
translated: They are made of jhāna consciousness. They are made of perception: they are made of the perception of the immaterial jhānas.

original: nirodhāya paṭipanno hotīti ayaṃ lābhī vā hoti takkī vā. Lābhī nāma rūpāvacarajjhānalābhī.
analyzed: nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti iti ayam lābhī vā hoti takkī vā lābhī nāma rūpāvacara jhāna lābhī
translated: He is practicing for the purpose of disenchantment, for the purpose of dispassion, for the purpose of cessation, regarding form: he is either a gainer of the attainment or one who has the view of it. The gainer of the attainment is one who has attained jhāna in the fine-material sphere.

original: Tassa rūpāvacare kaṅkhā natthi, arūpāvacaraloke atthi. So – “ahaṃ āruppā atthīti🔽vadantānampi natthīti vadantānampi suṇāmi, atthi natthīti pana na jānāmi. Catutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: tassa rūpāvacare kaṅkhā natthi arūpāvacara loke atthi so aham āruppā atthi iti  vadantānam pi natthi iti vadantānam pi suṇāmi atthi natthi iti pana na jānāmi catutthajjhānaṃ
translated: He has no doubt about the fine-material sphere, but he has doubt about the immaterial sphere. He thinks: “I hear that there are immaterial states,

original: padaṭṭhānaṃ katvā arūpāvacarajjhānaṃ nibbattessāmi. Sace āruppā atthi, tattha nibbattissāmi,
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam katvā arūpāvacara jhānam nibbattessāmi sace āruppāḥ atthi tattha nibbattissāmi
translated: but I do not know whether there are or not. I shall develop the immaterial jhānas, making the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere their proximate cause. If there are immaterial states, I shall be reborn in them;

original: sace natthi, rūpāvacarabrahmaloke nibbattissāmi. Evaṃ me apaṇṇako dhammo apaṇṇakova
analyzed: sace natthi rūpāvacara brahmaloke nibbattissāmi evam me apaṇṇakaḥ dhammaḥ apaṇṇakaḥ vā
translated: if not, I shall be reborn in the Brahmā-world of the fine-material sphere. In this way my state will be secure,

original: aviraddhova bhavissatī”ti tathā paṭipajjati. Takkī pana appaṭiladdhajjhāno, tassāpi
analyzed: aviraddhaḥ uva bhavissati iti tathā paṭipajjati takkī pana appaṭiladdha jjhāno tassa api
translated: and I shall not be deceived.” He practices accordingly. But one who has the view of it is one who has not attained jhāna. He too🔽has no doubt about the fine-material jhānas, but he has doubt about the immaterial sphere. He thinks: “I hear that there are immaterial states,

original: rūpajjhāne kaṅkhā natthi, arūpaloke pana atthi. So – “ahaṃ āruppā atthīti vadantānampi
analyzed: rūpa jhāne kaṅkhā natthi arūpa loke pana atthi so aham āruppā atthi iti vadantānam pi
translated: but I do not know whether there are or not.

original: natthīti vadantānampi suṇāmi, atthi natthīti pana na jānāmi. Kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā
analyzed: natthi iti vadantānam pi suṇāmi atthi natthi iti pana na jānāmi kasiṇa parikammam katvā
translated: I hear that there is no self, and I hear that there is a self. But I do not know whether there is or is not. I will do the preliminary work on the kasiṇas,

original: catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā taṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ katvā arūpāvacarajjhānaṃ nibbattessāmi.
analyzed: catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā tam padaṭṭhānam katvā arūpāvacara jhānam nibbattessāmi
translated: and having aroused the fourth jhāna, I will make that the basis and arouse the jhānas of the immaterial sphere.

original: Sace āruppā atthi, tattha nibbattissāmi. Sace natthi, rūpāvacarabrahmaloke nibbattissāmi.
analyzed: sace āruppāḥ atthi tattha nibbattissāmi sace na atthi rūpāvacara brahmaloke nibbattissāmi
translated: If the immaterial sphere exists, I will be reborn there. If it does not exist, I will be reborn in the Brahmā-world of the fine-material sphere.

original: Evaṃ me apaṇṇako dhammo apaṇṇakova aviraddhova bhavissatī”ti tathā paṭipajjati.
analyzed: evam me apaṇṇakaḥ dhammaḥ apaṇṇakaḥ iva aviraddhaḥ va bhavissati iti tathā paṭipajjati
translated: In this way my Dhamma will be free from doubt, free from error.” He practices accordingly.

original: 104. Bhavanirodhoti nibbānaṃ. Sārāgāya santiketi rāgavasena vaṭṭe rajjanassa santike.
analyzed: bhava nirodhaḥ ti nibbānam sa ārāgāya santike iti rāga vasena vaṭṭe rajjanassa santike
translated: Cessation of being is Nibbāna. Near to lust is the near side of lust.

original: Saṃyogāyāti taṇhāvasena saṃyojanatthāya. Abhinandanāyāti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena abhinandanāya.
analyzed: saṃyogāya ati taṇhā vasena saṃyojana tthāya abhinandanāya ati taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena abhinandanāya
translated: For the purpose of bondage is for the purpose of fettering by craving. For the purpose of delighting is for the purpose of delighting through craving and views.

original: Paṭipanno hotīti ayampi lābhī vā hoti takkī vā. Lābhī nāma aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī. Tassa
analyzed: paṭipannaḥ hoti iti ayam pi lābhī vā hoti takkī vā lābhī nāma aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī tassa
translated: Has entered upon the way is either one who has attained or one who has confidence. One who has attained is one who has attained the eight attainments.

original: āruppe kaṅkhā natthi, nibbāne atthi. So – “ahaṃ nirodho atthītipi natthītipi suṇāmi,
analyzed: āruppe kaṅkhā natthi nibbāne atthi saḥ aham nirodhaḥ atthi itipi natthi itipi suṇāmi
translated: He has no doubt about the immaterial sphere but has doubt about Nibbāna. He thinks: “I hear that there is Nibbāna and that there is no Nibbāna.

original: sayaṃ na jānāmi. Samāpattiṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhessāmi. Sace nirodho bhavissati,
analyzed: sayam na jānāmi samāpattim pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhessāmi sace nirodhaḥ bhavissati
translated: I do not know for myself. I shall develop insight by making the attainment my footing. If there is cessation,

original: arahattaṃ patvā parinibbāyissāmi. No ce bhavissati, āruppe nibbattissāmī”ti evaṃ
analyzed: arahattam patvā parinibbāyissāmi no ce bhavissati āruppe nibbattissāmi iti evam
translated: I shall attain Arahantship and attain extinction. If there is not, I shall be reborn in the immaterial sphere. ’

original: paṭipajjati. Takkī pana ekasamāpattiyāpi na lābhī, āruppe panassa kaṅkhā natthi,
analyzed: paṭipajjati takkī pana eka samāpattiyā api na lābhī āruppe panassa kaṅkhā natthi
translated: The sceptic, however, is not even a possessor of one attainment, but he has no doubt about the immaterial sphere,

original: bhavanirodhe atthi. So – “ahaṃ nirodho atthītipi natthītipi suṇāmi, sayaṃ na jānāmi,
analyzed: bhava nirodhe atthi saḥ aham nirodhaḥ atthi iti pi na atthi iti pi suṇāmi sayam na jānāmi
translated: which he has heard about, and he has doubt about the cessation of being. He thinks thus: ‘I hear that there is and that there is not cessation. I do not know for myself.

original: kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā aṭṭhasamāpattiyo nibbattetvā samāpattipadaṭṭhānaṃ vipassanaṃ
analyzed: kasiṇa parikammam katvā aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā samāpatti padaṭṭhānam vipassanam
translated: I shall make the kasiṇa exercise my footing, produce the eight attainments, and develop insight with the attainment as its proximate cause.

original: vaḍḍhessāmi. Sace nirodho bhavissati, arahattaṃ patvā parinibbāyissāmi. No ce bhavissati,
analyzed: vaḍḍhessāmi sace nirodhaḥ bhavissati arahattam patvā parinibbāyissāmi no ce bhavissati
translated: If there is cessation, I shall attain Arahantship and attain extinction. If there is not, I shall be reborn in the immaterial sphere. ’

original: āruppe nibbattissāmī”ti evaṃ paṭipajjati. Etthāha – “atthi dinnantiādīni tāva apaṇṇakāni
analyzed: āruppe nibbattissāmi iti evam paṭipajjati ettha āha atthi dinna nti ādīni tāva apaṇṇakāni
translated: Here it may be said: ‘Let be the four beginning with “There is what is given” ;

original: bhavantu, natthi dinnantiādīni pana kathaṃ apaṇṇakānī”ti. Gahaṇavasena. Tāni hi apaṇṇakaṃ
analyzed: bhavantu natthi dinna nti ādīni pana katham apaṇṇakāni iti gahaṇa vasena tāni hi apaṇṇakam
translated: but how can the four beginning with “There is no what is given” be undeclared? ’—By way of taking them. For these are undeclared

original: apaṇṇakanti evaṃ gahitattā apaṇṇakāni nāma jātāni.
analyzed: apaṇṇakam ti evam gahita ttā apaṇṇakāni nāma jātāni
translated: “Safe” : they are called “safe” because they are taken as such.

original: 105. Cattārometi ayaṃ pāṭiekko anusandhi. Natthikavādo, ahetukavādo akiriyavādo,
analyzed: cattāro me ti ayam pāṭiekkaḥ anusandhi natthika vādaḥ ahetuka vādaḥ akiriya vādaḥ
translated: “These five kinds of persons”: this is a separate continuity. The five are the five persons who are the proponents of non-existence, of causelessness, of inaction,

original: āruppā natthi nirodho natthīti evaṃvādino ca dveti ime pañca puggalā heṭṭhā tayo
analyzed: āruppāḥ natthi nirodho natthi iti evaṃvādino ca dve ti ime pañca puggalāḥ heṭṭhā tayo
translated: and of the two views that there is no immaterial realm and that there is no cessation through specific insight.

original: puggalāva honti. Atthikavādādayo pañca eko catutthapuggalova hoti. Etamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: puggalāḥ ava honti atthika vāda ādayo pañca ekaḥ catuttha puggalaḥ uva hoti etam attham dassetuṃ
translated: The proponents of existence, etc., are the four persons.🔽The Blessed One began this teaching in order to show this meaning.

original: bhagavā imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha sabbaṃ atthato uttānamevāti.🔽Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: bhagavā imam desanam ārabhi tattha sabbam atthato uttānam eva ati  papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: Herein, the whole meaning is self-evident.

original: Apaṇṇakasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: apaṇṇaka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Apaṇṇaka Sutta in the Majjhima Nikāya is finished.

original: Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first vagga is finished.

original: 2. Bhikkhuvaggo
analyzed: bhikkhu vaggo
translated: The Bhikkhu Vagga

original: 1. Ambalaṭṭhikarāhulovādasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Ambalatthika-Raṭṭhapala Sutta

original: 107. Evaṃ me sutanti ambalaṭṭhikarāhulovādasuttaṃ. Tattha ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ viharatīti
analyzed: evam me sutam ti amba laṭṭhika rāhulovāda suttam tattha amba laṭṭhi kāyam viharati iti
translated: “Thus I heard.” The Ambalatthika-Raṭṭhapala Sutta. Therein, he lives at Ambalatthika :

original: veḷuvanavihārassa paccante padhānagharasaṅkhepe vivekakāmānaṃ vasanatthāya kate ambalaṭṭhikāti
analyzed: veḷuvana vihārassa paccante padhāna ghara saṅkhepe viveka kāmānam vasana tthāya kate ambalaṭṭhikā ti

original: evaṃnāmake pāsāde pavivekaṃ brūhayanto viharati. Kaṇṭako nāma jātakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: evaṃnāmake pāsāde viharati kaṇṭakaḥ nāma jāta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: He was living in the Kantaka Palace, which was built by King Bimbisāra, and which was situated in the midst of a forest, a league from Rājagaha.

original: tikhiṇova hoti, evamevaṃ ayampi āyasmā sattavassikasāmaṇerakāleyeva pavivekaṃ brūhayamāno
analyzed: evam evam ayam pi āyasmā satta vassika sāmaṇera kāleya iva brūhayamānaḥ
translated: Kantaka was sharp from the time of his birth. In the same way, this venerable one, while still a novice of seven years’ standing, was living there, increasing his seclusion.

original: tattha vihāsi. Paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhāya. Āsananti pakatipaññattamevettha
analyzed: tattha vihāsi paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya āsanam ti pakati paññattam eva ittha
translated: Having risen from his seclusion: having risen from the attainment of fruition. His seat: here his seat was the one he had prepared for himself.

original: āsanaṃ atthi, taṃ papphoṭetvā ṭhapesi. Udakādhāneti udakabhājane. “Udakaṭṭhāne”tipi pāṭho.🔽Āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ āmantesīti ovādadānatthaṃ āmantesi. Bhagavatā hi rāhulattherassa
analyzed: āsanam atthi tam papphoṭetvā ṭhapesi udaka ādhāne iti udaka bhājane udaka ṭṭhāna iti pi pāṭhaḥ  ā yasmantam rāhulam āmantesi iti ovāda dāna attham āmantesi bhagavatā hi rāhula therassa
translated: He shook it and put it away. His water-pot: his water-jar. “His water-place” is another reading.🔽He addressed the venerable Rāhula: he addressed him in order to give him advice. For the venerable Rāhula

original: sambahulā dhammadesanā katā. Sāmaṇerapañhaṃ therasseva vuttaṃ. Tathā rāhulasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: sambahulā dhamma desanā katā sāmaṇera pañham therassa iva vuttam tathā rāhula saṃyuttam
translated: had received many discourses from the Blessed One. The novice’s question was put to the elder himself. So too the Rāhula Samyutta,

original: mahārāhulovādasuttaṃ cūḷarāhulovādasuttamidaṃ ambalaṭṭhikarāhulovādasuttanti.
analyzed: mahā rāhulovāda suttam cūḷa rāhulovāda suttam idam ambalaṭṭhika rāhulovāda suttam idam
translated: the Great Advice to Rāhula Discourse, the Shorter Advice to Rāhula Discourse, and this Ambattha Advice to Rāhula Discourse.

original: Ayañhi āyasmā sattavassikakāle bhagavantaṃ cīvarakaṇṇe gahetvā “dāyajjaṃ me samaṇa
analyzed: ayan hi āyasmā sattavassika kāle bhagavantam cīvara kaṇṇe gahetvā dāyajjam me samaṇa
translated: For this venerable one, when he was seven years old, took hold of the Blessed One’s robe-edge and said, “Ascetic, give me my inheritance.

original: dehī”ti dāyajjaṃ yācamāno bhagavatā dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherassa niyyādetvā pabbājito.
analyzed: dehi iti dāyajjam yācamānaḥ bhagavatā dhammasenāpati sāriputta therassa niyyādetvā pabbājitaḥ
translated: and the Exalted One, having given him to the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, as his attendant, had him admitted to the Order.

original: Atha bhagavā daharakumārā nāma yuttāyuttaṃ kathaṃ kathenti, ovādamassa demīti rāhulakumāraṃ
analyzed: atha bhagavā dahara kumārāḥ nāma yutta ayuttam katham kathenti ovādam assa demi iti rāhula kumāram
translated: Then the Exalted One thought: “Young men talk about what is proper and improper. I will give him advice.”

original: āmantetvā “sāmaṇerena nāma, rāhula, tiracchānakathaṃ kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati, tvaṃ kathayamāno
analyzed: āmantetvā sāmaṇerena nāma rāhula tiracchāna katham kathetum na vaṭṭati tvam kathayamānaḥ
translated: So he addressed the young Rāhula thus: “Rāhula, a novice should not talk about what is improper. If you talk,

analyzed: evarūpam katham katheyyāsi iti sabba buddhehi a vijahitam dasa puccham pañca paṇṇāsa vissajjanam
translated: you should talk like this.” And he taught him the Ten Questions, which are never separated from the Buddhas, and the Fifty Replies.

original: – “eko pañho eko uddeso ekaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ dve pañhā…pe… dasa pañhā dasa uddesā dasa
analyzed: ekaḥ pañhaḥ ekaḥ uddeso ekam veyyākaraṇam dve pañhāpe dasa pañhāḥ dasa uddesāḥ dasa
translated: “One question, one explanation, one reply; two questions… ten questions, ten explanations, ten replies.”

original: veyyākaraṇāti. Ekaṃ nāma kiṃ? Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā…pe… dasa nāma kiṃ? Dasahaṅgehi
analyzed: veyyākaraṇā ti ekam nāma kim sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā pe dasa nāma kim dasa haṅgehi
translated: What is one? “All beings subsist on nutriment.”… What is ten? “One who possesses ten factors is called an arahant.”

original: samannāgato arahāti vuccatī”ti imaṃ sāmaṇerapañhaṃ kathesi. Puna cintesi “daharakumārā
analyzed: samannāgataḥ arahā ati vuccati iti imam sāmaṇera pañham kathesi puna cintesi dahara kumārā
translated: This is the Novice’s Questions. Then he thought: “Young men talk about what is proper and improper.

original: nāma piyamusāvādā honti, adiṭṭhameva diṭṭhaṃ amhehi, diṭṭhameva na diṭṭhaṃ amhehīti🔽vadanti ovādamassa demī”ti akkhīhi oloketvāpi sukhasañjānanatthaṃ paṭhamameva catasso
analyzed: nāma piya musā vādāḥ honti a diṭṭham eva diṭṭham amhehi diṭṭham eva na diṭṭham amhehi iti  vadanti ovādam assa demi iti akkhīhi oloketvā api sukha sañjānana attham paṭhamam eva catasso
translated: They say: ‘We have seen what we have not seen, we have not seen what we have seen.’🔽I give him this advice.”

original: udakādhānūpamāyo, tato dve hatthiupamāyo ekaṃ ādāsūpamañca dassetvā imaṃ suttaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: udaka ādhāna upamāyo tatas dve hatthi upamāyo ekam ādāsu upamañca dassetvā imam suttam kathesi
translated: Having shown the four similes of the water-pot, the two similes of the elephant, the simile of the looking-glass, and the simile of the scales, he preached this sutta.

original: Catūsu pana paccayesu taṇhāvivaṭṭanaṃ pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chandarāgappahānaṃ kalyāṇamittupanissayassa
analyzed: catūsu pana paccayesu taṇhā vivaṭṭanam pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chanda rāga ppahānam kalyāṇa mitta upanissayassa
translated: In the four conditions, the turning away of craving, the abandoning of desire and lust for the five strands of sense pleasure, the greatness of the support of a good friend,

analyzed: mahanta bhāvañca dassetvā rāhula suttam kathesi āgata āgata ṭṭhāne bhavesu chanda rāgaḥ
translated: having shown all this, he preached the Rāhula Sutta. In the place of coming and going, desire and lust for existence

analyzed: na kattabbā iti dassetum rāhula saṃyuttam kathesi aham sobhāmi mama vaṇṇa āyatanam
translated: should not be made. To show this, he preached the Rāhula Samyutta. “I am beautiful, my sense-field of beauty
