original: Upadhi dukkhassa mūlanti ettha pañca khandhā upadhi nāma. Taṃ dukkhassa mūlanti iti
analyzed: upadhi dukkhassa mūlanti ettha pañca khandhā upadhi nāma tam dukkhassa mūlanti iti
translated: “The footing for suffering” : here the five categories are called “the footing” . That is the footing for suffering. Having known that thus,

original: viditvā kilesupadhinā nirupadhi hoti, niggahaṇo nitaṇhoti attho. Upadhisaṅkhaye vimuttoti
analyzed: viditvā kilesa upadhinā nirupadhi hoti niggahaṇaḥ nitaṇho ti attho upadhi saṅkhaye vimutto ti
translated: he is without footing through the footing of defilement, the meaning is that he is without obstruction, without desire. “ Freed in the destruction of footing” :

original: taṇhakkhaye nibbāne ārammaṇato vimutto.🔽155. Evaṃ cattāro puggale vitthāretvā idāni ye pajahanti, te “ime nāma ettake kilese
analyzed: taṇha khaye nibbāne ārammaṇataḥ vimuttaḥ  evam cattāraḥ puggale vitthāretvā idāni ye pajahanti te ime nāma ettake kilese
translated: freed by object in extinction, which is the destruction of craving.

original: pajahanti”. Ye nappajahanti, tepi “ime nāma ettake kilese nappajahantī”ti dassetuṃ
analyzed: pajahanti ye na ppajahanti te pi ime nāma ettake kilese na ppajahanti iti dassetuṃ
translated: Having thus expounded the four types of persons in detail, he now said “ And those who abandon” in order to show that “ those who abandon are those who abandon so many defilements, and those who do not abandon are those who do not abandon so many defilements”.

original: pañca kho ime udāyi kāmaguṇātiādimāha. Tattha miḷhasukhanti asucisukhaṃ. Anariyasukhanti
analyzed: pañca kho ime udāyi kāmaguṇā ati ādim āha tattha asuci sukham an ariya sukham
translated: “ There are these five cords of sensual pleasure, Udayi” , he said. Herein, “filth-happiness” is impure happiness. “ Unedifying happiness” is🔽happiness that is not edifying. “

original: anariyehi sevitasukhaṃ. Bhāyitabbanti etassa sukhassa paṭilābhatopi vipākatopi bhāyitabbaṃ.🔽Nekkhammasukhanti kāmato nikkhantasukhaṃ. Pavivekasukhanti gaṇatopi kilesatopi pavivittasukhaṃ.🔽Upasamasukhanti rāgādivūpasamatthāya sukhaṃ. Sambodhasukhanti maggasaṅkhātassa sambodhassa
analyzed: anariyehi sevita sukham bhāyitabbanti etassa sukhassa paṭilābhataḥ api vipākataḥ api bhāyitabbam  nekkhamma sukhanti kāmataḥ nikkhanta sukham paviveka sukham ti gaṇataḥ pi kilesataḥ pi pavivitta sukham  upasama sukham sukham sambodha sukham ti magga saṅkhātassa sambodhassa
translated: The pleasure that is relished by the ignoble. “One should fear it”: one should fear it as the result of the pleasure that is relished by the ignoble.🔽The pleasure of renunciation: the pleasure of renunciation from sense desires. The pleasure of seclusion: the pleasure of seclusion from the multitude and from defilements.🔽The pleasure of peace: the pleasure that is for the sake of the peace of lust, etc. The pleasure of enlightenment: the pleasure that is for the sake of the enlightenment called the path.

original: nibbattanatthāya sukhaṃ. Na bhāyitabbanti etassa sukhassa paṭilābhatopi vipākatopi
analyzed: nibbattana thāya sukham na bhāyitabbanti etassa sukhassa paṭilābhataḥ pi vipākataḥ pi
translated: “One should not fear it”: one should not fear it as the result of the pleasure that is relished by the ignoble.

original: na bhāyitabbaṃ, bhāvetabbamevetaṃ.
analyzed: na bhāyitabbam bhāvetabbam eva etam
translated: One should not fear it, but should develop it.

original: 156. Iñjitasmiṃ vadāmīti iñjanaṃ calanaṃ phandananti vadāmi. Kiñca tattha iñjitasminti
analyzed: iñjitasmin vadāmi iti iñjanam calanam phandananti vadāmi kiñca tattha iñjitasmin ti
translated: “I say that there is agitation in what is agitated”: I say that there is trembling, shaking, and vibrating in what is agitated. And what is agitated?🔽“What is agitated there?” What is agitated there?

original: kiñca tattha iñjitaṃ. Idaṃ tattha iñjitasminti ye ete aniruddhā vitakkavicārā, idaṃ
analyzed: kiñca tattha iñjitam idam tattha iñjitasmin ti ye ete aniruddhāḥ vitakka vicārāḥ idam
translated: These are the thoughts and the thought-concomitants that are not yet ceased.

original: tattha iñjitaṃ. Dutiyatatiyajjhānesupi eseva nayo. Aniñjitasmiṃ vadāmīti idaṃ catutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: tattha iñjitam dutiya tatiya jhānesu pi esa iva nayaḥ aniñjitasmin vadāmi iti idam catuttha jhānam
translated: This is what is agitated there. The same method applies to the second and third jhānas. “I say that there is no agitation in what is not agitated”: the fourth jhāna.

original: aniñjanaṃ acalanaṃ nipphandananti vadāmi.🔽Analanti vadāmīti akattabbaālayanti vadāmi, taṇhālayo ettha na uppādetabboti dasseti.
analyzed: aniñjanam acalanam nipphandanam ti vadāmi  vadāmi iti vadāmi taṇhā ālayaḥ ettha na uppādetabbaḥ ti dasseti
translated: I say it is unagitated, unmoved, and uninflected.🔽I say it is not to be sought: I say it is not to be sought as a resting-place, as a shelter, as a refuge, as a resort.

original: Atha vā analaṃ apariyattaṃ, na ettāvatā alametanti sanniṭṭhānaṃ kātabbanti vadāmi.
analyzed: atha vā analam a pariyattam na ettāvatā alam etat ti sanniṭṭhānam kātabbanti vadāmi
translated: Or alternatively, I say it is not to be sought as enough, as ‘It is only this much, no more than this’—that is how I say it.

original: Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanassāpīti evarūpāyapi santāya samāpattiyā pahānameva vadāmi.
analyzed: nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanassa api iti evarūpāya api santāya samāpattiyāḥ pahānam eva vadāmi
translated: I say it is to be abandoned even in the case of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: Aṇuṃ vā thūlaṃ vāti khuddakaṃ vā mahantaṃ vā appasāvajjaṃ vā mahāsāvajjaṃ vā. Sesaṃ
analyzed: aṇum vā thūlam vā ati khuddakam vā mahantam vā appasāvajjam vā mahā sāvajjam vā sesam
translated: Small or great: either slight or gross, either less blamable or more blamable. The rest is as above.

original: sabbattha uttānameva. Desanā pana neyyapuggalassa vasena arahattanikūṭeneva niṭṭhāpitāti.
analyzed: sabbattha uttānam eva desanā pana neyya puggalassa vasena arahatta nikūṭena iva niṭṭhāpitā ati
translated: But the teaching is concluded with the peak of the arahant’s path in order to suit the type of person to be trained.🔽The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya,

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: the Great Book of the Middle Length Sayings,

original: Laṭukikopamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: laṭukikopama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 7. Cātumasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Four-Quintal Weight Discourse

original: 157. Evaṃ me sutanti cātumasuttaṃ. Tattha cātumāyanti evaṃnāmake gāme. Pañcamattāni
analyzed: evam me sutam ti cātumasuttam tattha evaṃnāmake gāme pañcamattāni
translated: Thus I heard. The Four-Quintal Weight Discourse. There, in the village named Cātumā. Five or six.

original: bhikkhusatānīti adhunā pabbajitānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pañca satāni. Therā kira cintesuṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu satāni iti adhunā pabbajitānam bhikkhūnam pañca satāni therāḥ kira cintesuṃ
translated: Bhikkhus: five hundred bhikkhus who had recently gone forth. The elders thought:

original: – “ime kulaputtā dasabalaṃ adisvāva pabbajitā, etesaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassessāma, bhagavato
analyzed: ime kula puttāḥ dasabalam a disvā ava pabbajitāḥ etesam bhagavantam dassessāma bhagavataḥ
translated: “These young men have gone forth without seeing the Enlightened One. We shall show them the Blessed One.

original: santike dhammaṃ sutvā attano attano yathāupanissayena patiṭṭhahissantī”ti. Tasmā
analyzed: santike dhammam sutvā attanaḥ attanaḥ yathāupanissayena patiṭṭhahissanti iti tasmā
translated: After they have heard the Dhamma from the Blessed One, they will establish themselves in accordance with their individual capacities.” Therefore

original: te bhikkhū gahetvā āgatā. Paṭisammodamānāti “kaccāvuso, khamanīya”ntiādiṃ paṭisanthārakathaṃ🔽kurumānā. Senāsanāni paññāpayamānāti attano attano ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānāni🔽pucchitvā dvāravātapānāni vivaritvā mañcapīṭhakaṭasārakādīni nīharitvā papphoṭetvā🔽yathāṭṭhāne saṇṭhāpayamānā. Pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānāti, bhante, idaṃ me pattaṃ
analyzed: te bhikkhū gahetvā āgatā paṭisammodamānā ati kaccāvuso khamanīya nti ādim paṭisanthāra katham  kurumānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā ati attanaḥ attanaḥ ācariya upajjhāyānam vasanaṭṭhānāni  pucchitvā dvāra vāta pānāni mañca pīṭha kaṭasāraka ādīni nīharitvā papphoṭetvā  yathāṭṭhāne saṇṭhāpayamānā patta cīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā ati bhante idam me pattam
translated: they brought them along. They were exchanging friendly greetings: they were conversing with the words “I hope you are all right,” etc.🔽They were preparing their resting places: they were asking their teachers and preceptors where they should stay, opening the doors and windows, taking out the beds and chairs and wooden benches, dusting them, and putting them back in their places.

original: ṭhapetha, idaṃ cīvaraṃ, idaṃ thālakaṃ, idaṃ udakatumbaṃ, imaṃ kattarayaṭṭhinti evaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetha idam cīvaram idam thālakam idam udaka tumbam imam evam
translated: They were putting away their bowls and robes: they were saying, “Venerable sir, please put away this bowl, this robe, this water- strainer, this towel, this key,” etc.

original: samaṇaparikkhāre saṅgopayamānā.
analyzed: samaṇa parikkhāre saṅgopayamānā
translated: and they were using the requisites of a monk.

original: Uccāsaddā mahāsaddāti uddhaṃ uggatattā uccaṃ, patthaṭattā mahantaṃ avinibbhogasaddaṃ🔽karontā. Kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilopeti kevaṭṭānaṃ macchapacchiṭhapitaṭṭhāne mahājano🔽sannipatitvā – “idha aññaṃ ekaṃ macchaṃ dehi, ekaṃ macchaphālaṃ dehi, etassa te mahā
analyzed: uccāsaddā mahāsaddā ti uddham uggata ttā uccam patthaṭa ttā mahantam a vinibbhoga saddam  karontā kevaṭṭā maññe maccha vilopeti kevaṭṭānam mahājanaḥ  sannipatitvā idha aññam ekam maccham dehi ekam maccha phālam dehi etassa te mahā
translated: Making a great noise: making a great noise, a loud noise, a noise that is not broken, because it goes up and out.

original: dinno, mayhaṃ khuddako”ti evaṃ uccāsaddaṃ mahāsaddaṃ karonti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Macchagahaṇatthaṃ jāle pakkhittepi tasmiṃ ṭhāne kevaṭṭā ceva aññe ca “paviṭṭho na
analyzed: dinnaḥ mayham khuddakaḥ iti evam uccā saddam mahā saddam karonti tam sandhāya itam vuttam  maccha gahaṇa attham jāle pakkhitte pi tasmin ṭhāne kevaṭṭā ca iva aññe ca paviṭṭhaḥ na
translated: Like fishermen with their fish-catch: just as a great crowd of people, having assembled at a place where fishermen are gutting fish, make a great noise, a loud noise, saying, “Give me another fish, give me a fish-slice, you gave me a big one, this one is small for me,” so they made a great noise, a loud noise. This is the meaning here.

original: paviṭṭho, gahito na gahito”ti mahāsaddaṃ karonti. Tampi sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Paṇāmemīti
analyzed: paviṭṭhaḥ gahitaḥ na gahitaḥ iti mahā saddam karonti tam pi sandhāya itam vuttam paṇāmemi iti
translated: When the net was cast for catching fish, the fishermen and others made a great noise there, saying, “He has entered, he has not entered, he has been caught, he has not been caught.” This is also the meaning here.🔽I banish you: I remove you.

original: nīharāmi. Na vo mama santike vatthabbanti tumhe mādisassa buddhassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nīharāmi na vaḥ mama santike vatthabbanti tumhe mādisassa buddhassa vasana ṭṭhānam
translated: You are not to live in my presence: you are not to live in the dwelling place of a Buddha like me.

original: āgantvā evaṃ mahāsaddaṃ karotha, attano dhammatāya vasantā kiṃ nāma sāruppaṃ karissatha,
analyzed: āgantvā evam mahā saddam karotha attanaḥ dhamma tāya vasantā kim nāma sāruppam karissatha
translated: and you make such a great noise when you come, what is so suitable about that? You are living according to your own ideas, what will you do?

original: tumhādisānaṃ mama santike vasanakiccaṃ natthīti dīpeti. Tesu ekabhikkhupi “bhagavā
analyzed: tumha ādisānam mama santike vasana kiccam natthi iti dīpeti tesu bhagavā
translated: There is no need for you to live near me.” Not a single bhikkhu was able to say to the Blessed One,

original: tumhe mahāsaddamattakena amhe paṇāmethā”ti vā aññaṃ vā kiñci vattuṃ nāsakkhi, sabbe
analyzed: tumhe mahā sadda mattakena amhe paṇāmetha ati vā aññam vā kiñci vattum na asakkhi sabbe
translated: “Lord, you are sending us away because of the noise we make,” or anything else. All of them

original: bhagavato vacanaṃ sampaṭicchantā “evaṃ, bhante,”ti vatvā nikkhamiṃsu. Evaṃ pana tesaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ vacanam sampaṭicchantāḥ evam bhante iti vatvā nikkhamiṃsu evam pana tesam
translated: agreed with the Blessed One’s words, saying, “Yes, Lord.” And they left. But they thought,

original: ahosi “mayaṃ satthāraṃ passissāma, dhammakathaṃ sossāma, satthu santike vasissāmāti🔽āgatā. Evarūpassa pana garuno satthu santikaṃ āgantvā mahāsaddaṃ karimhā, amhākameva
analyzed: ahosi mayam satthāram passissāma dhamma katham sossāma satthu santike vasissāma ati  āgatāḥ evarūpassa pana garunaḥ satthu santikam āgantvā mahā saddam karimhā amhākam eva
translated: “We came here to see the Teacher, to hear the Dhamma, and to live near the Teacher.

original: dosoyaṃ, paṇāmitamhā, na no laddhaṃ bhagavato santike vatthuṃ, na suvaṇṇavaṇṇasarīraṃ
analyzed: dosaḥ yam na no laddham bhagavato santike vatthum na suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa sarīram
translated: But we have made a great noise when we came near such a venerable and great Teacher. This is our fault. We are sent away. We have not been able to live near the Blessed One, to look at his golden-coloured body,

original: oloketuṃ, na madhurassarena dhammaṃ sotu”nti. Te balavadomanassajātā hutvā pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: oloketum na madhurassarena dhammam sotunti te balava domanassa jātāḥ hutvā pakkamiṃsu
translated: or to hear the Dhamma from his sweet-sounding voice.” And they left, deeply distressed.

original: 158. Tenupasaṅkamiṃsūti te kira sakyā āgamanasamayepi te bhikkhū tattheva nisinnā
analyzed: tena upasaṅkamiṃsu iti te kira sakyāḥ āgamana samaye pi te bhikkhū tattha eva nisinnā
translated: 158. They approached: it seems that the Sakyans, when they were coming, saw those bhikkhus sitting there,

original: passiṃsu. Atha nesaṃ etadahosi – “kiṃ nu kho ete bhikkhū pavisitvāva paṭinivattā,
analyzed: passiṃsu atha nesam etat ahosi kim nu kho ete bhikkhū pavisitvā ava paṭinivattā
translated: 158. They approached: it seems that the Sakyans saw those bhikkhus sitting there even at the time of their coming. Then they thought, “Why did these bhikkhus come in and then turn back?

original: jānissāma taṃ kāraṇa”nti cintetvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. Handāti vavassaggatthe
analyzed: jānissāma tam kāraṇan ti cintetvā yena te bhikkhū tena upasaṅkamiṃsu handa ati vavassagga tthe
translated: We shall find out the reason,” and they approached those bhikkhus. The particle handa is in the sense of “let us.”

original: nipāto. Kahaṃ pana tumheti tumhe idāneva āgantvā kahaṃ gacchatha, kiṃ tumhākaṃ koci
analyzed: nipāto kaham pana tumhe iti tumhe idānī iva āgantvā kaham gacchatha kim tumhākam koci
translated: Where are you going? You have just come and where are you going? Is there some danger for you, or is it the Master?

original: upaddavo, udāhu dasabalassāti? Tesaṃ pana bhikkhūnaṃ, – “āvuso, mayaṃ bhagavantaṃ🔽dassanāya āgatā, diṭṭho no bhagavā, idāni attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gacchāmā”ti kiñcāpi
analyzed: upaddavaḥ udāhu dasabalassa ati tesam pana bhikkhūnam āvuso mayam bhagavantam  dassanāya āgatā diṭṭhaḥ naḥ bhagavā idāni attanaḥ vasana ṭhānam gacchāma ati kiñcā api
translated: But although the bhikkhus had this exchange of conversation, still they said, “Friend, we have come to see the Lord,

original: evaṃ vacanaparihāro atthi, evarūpaṃ pana lesakappaṃ akatvā yathābhūtameva ārocetvā
analyzed: evam vacana parihāraḥ atthi evarūpam pana lesa kappam a katvā yathābhūtam eva ārocetvā
translated: we have seen the Lord, and now we are going to our own resting places,” and they did not make any pretext at all, but they told them the truth, saying,

original: bhagavatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhusaṅgho paṇāmitoti āhaṃsu. Te pana rājāno sāsane dhuravahā,
analyzed: bhagavatā kho āvuso bhikkhu saṅghaḥ paṇāmitaḥ iti āhaṃsu te pana rājānaḥ sāsane dhura vahā
translated: “The Lord, friends, has dismissed the Order of bhikkhus.” But these kings were leaders in the Dispensation,

original: tasmā cintesuṃ – “dvīhi aggasāvakehi saddhiṃ pañcasu bhikkhusatesu gacchantesu bhagavato
analyzed: tasmā cintesum dvīhi aggasāvakehi saddhim pañcasu bhikkhu satesu gacchantesu bhagavato
translated: Therefore they thought: “If the Blessed One goes with the two chief disciples and five hundred bhikkhus,

original: pādamūlaṃ vigacchissati, imesaṃ nivattanākāraṃ karissāmā”ti. Evaṃ cintetvā tena hāyasmantotiādimāhaṃsu.
analyzed: pāda mūlam vigacchissati imesam nivattana ākāram karissāma ati evam cintetvā tena ha āyasmantaḥ iti ādim āhaṃsu
translated: Therefore they thought: “If the Blessed One goes with the two chief disciples and five hundred bhikkhus, the Blessed One’s feet will get tired. We shall make some pretext for turning them back.” Having thus thought, they said the verse beginning with the words, “Venerable Sirs.”

original: Tesupi bhikkhūsu “mayaṃ mahāsaddamattakena paṇāmitā, na mayaṃ jīvituṃ asakkontā pabbajitā”ti
analyzed: tesu pi bhikkhūsu mayam mahā sadda mattakena paṇāmitā na mayam jīvitum a sakkontā pabbajitā ati
translated: And among those bhikkhus there was not one who was displeased, thinking: “We have been sent away because of a mere loud noise. We have not gone forth because we are unable to earn a living.”

original: ekabhikkhupi paṭippharito nāma nāhosi, sabbe pana samakaṃyeva, “evamāvuso,”ti sampaṭicchiṃsu.🔽159. Abhinandatūti bhikkhusaṅghassa āgamanaṃ icchanto abhinandatu. Abhivadatūti etu
analyzed: eka bhikkhu pi paṭippharitaḥ nāma na ahosi sabbe pana samakam yeva evam āvuso ti sampaṭicchiṃsu  abhinandatu uti bhikkhu saṅghassa āgamanam icchantaḥ abhinandatu abhivadatu uti etu
translated: But all of them agreed, saying: “So be it, friend.”

original: bhikkhusaṅghoti evaṃ cittaṃ uppādento abhivadatu. Anuggahitoti āmisānuggahena ca
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghaḥ iti evam cittam uppādentaḥ abhivadatu anuggahitaḥ ti āmisa anuggahena ca
translated: “May he welcome”: may he welcome the coming of the bhikkhu-sangha, desiring it. “May he greet”: may he greet the bhikkhu-sangha, arousing the thought: “Let the bhikkhu-sangha come.” “May he be favoured”: may he be favoured with material gifts and

original: dhammānuggahena ca anuggahito. Aññathattanti dasabalassa dassanaṃ na labhāmāti pasādaññathattaṃ
analyzed: dhamma anuggahena ca anuggahitaḥ aññathattanti dasabalassa dassanam na labhāma ati pasāda aññathattaṃ
translated: with the Dhamma. “May he be otherwise”: may he be otherwise, may he have faith, thinking: “We shall not get to see the One of Ten Powers.”

original: bhaveyya. Vipariṇāmoti pasādaññathattena vibbhamantānaṃ vipariṇāmaññathattaṃ bhaveyya.🔽Bījānaṃ taruṇānanti taruṇasassānaṃ. Siyā aññathattanti udakavārakāle udakaṃ alabhantānaṃ🔽milātabhāvena aññathattaṃ bhaveyya, sussitvā milātabhāvaṃ āpajjanena vipariṇāmo bhaveyya.
analyzed: bhaveyya vipariṇāmaḥ ti pasāda ññathattena vibbhamantānam vipariṇāma ññathattam bhaveyya  bījānam taruṇānam ti taruṇa sassānam siyā aññathattam ti udakavāra kāle udakam a labhantānam  milāta bhāvena aññathattam bhaveyya sussitvā milāta bhāvam āpajjanena vipariṇāmaḥ bhaveyya
translated: “Change of state” : the change of state of those who disappear by the alteration of their confidence.🔽“The young plants” : the young crops. “There would be a change of state” : at the time of the drought,🔽there would be a change of state by the drying up of those that had not received water. There would be a change of state by their drying up and perishing.

original: Vacchakassa pana khīrapipāsāya sussanaṃ aññathattaṃ nāma, sussitvā kālakiriyā vipariṇāmo nāma.
analyzed: vacchakassa pana khīra pipāsāya sussanam aññathattam nāma sussitvā kālakiriyā vipariṇāmaḥ nāma
translated: But in the case of the calf, the drying up of the milk is a change of state, and its death is a change of state by alteration.

original: 160. Pasādito bhagavāti thero kira tattha nisinnova dibbacakkhunā brahmānaṃ āgataṃ
analyzed: pasāditaḥ bhagavā ti thero kira tattha nisinnaḥ uva dibba cakkhunā brahmānam āgatam
translated: “The Blessed One has confidence in me” : the elder, it seems, saw by means of the divine eye that Brahmā had come while he was sitting there.

original: addasa, dibbāya sotadhātuyā ca āyācanasaddaṃ suṇi, cetopariyañāṇena bhagavato pasannabhāvaṃ
analyzed: addasa dibbāya sotadhātuyā ca āyācana saddam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena bhagavato pasanna bhāvam
translated: And he heard with the divine ear the sound of his supplication. And he knew by means of the knowledge of the minds of others that the Blessed One had confidence in him.

original: aññāsi. Tasmā – “kañci bhikkhuṃ pesetvā pakkosiyamānānaṃ gamanaṃ nāma na phāsukaṃ,
analyzed: aññāsi tasmai kañci bhikkhum pesetvā pakkosiyamānānam gamanam nāma na phāsukam
translated: Therefore, thinking “It is not convenient to go when one is sent by a bhikkhu,

original: yāva satthā na peseti, tāvadeva gamissāmā”ti maññamāno evamāha. Appossukkoti aññesu
analyzed: yāva satthā na peseti tāvat eva gamissāma ati maññamānaḥ evam āha appa ussukkaḥ ti aññesu
translated: we will go only as long as the Master does not send anyone,” he said as above. “Without exertion” : in other words,

original: kiccesu anussukko hutvā. Diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāranti phalasamāpattivihāraṃ anuyutto
analyzed: kiccesu anussukkaḥ hutvā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāran ti phala samāpatti vihāram anuyuttaḥ
translated: and not being eager to do the work. As to “dwelling in bliss here and now”: the Blessed One is intent on dwelling in the attainment of fruition.

original: maññe bhagavā viharitukāmo, so idāni yathāruciyā viharissatīti evaṃ me ahosīti vadati.
analyzed: maññe bhagavā viharitu kāmo saḥ idāni yathāruciyā viharissati iti evam me ahosi iti vadati
translated: I thought: “Now the Blessed One will dwell as he wishes.”

original: Mayampi dānīti mayaṃ paraṃ ovadamānā vihārato nikkaḍḍhitā, kiṃ amhākaṃ parovādena.
analyzed: mayam pi dāni iti mayam param ovadamānā vihārataḥ nikkaḍḍhitā kim amhākam parovādena
translated: “We too now” : we have been expelled from the dwelling by the exhortation of others. What is the use of exhorting others?

original: Idāni mayampi diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāreneva viharissāmāti dīpeti. Thero imasmiṃ ṭhāne
analyzed: idāni mayam pi diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārena iva viharissāma ati dīpeti theraḥ imasmim ṭhāne
translated: Now we too will dwell in bliss here and now. The Elder

original: viraddho attano bhārabhāvaṃ na aññāsi. Ayañhi bhikkhusaṅgho dvinnampi mahātherānaṃ
analyzed: viraddhaḥ attanaḥ bhāra bhāvam na aññāsi ayam hi bhikkhu saṅgho dvinnam pi mahā therānam
translated: at this point was not aware of his own burden. For this community of bhikkhus is the burden of both great elders,

original: bhāro, tena naṃ paṭisedhento bhagavā āgamehītiādimāha. Mahāmoggallānatthero pana
analyzed: tena nam paṭisedhentaḥ bhagavā āgamehi iti ādim āha mahāmoggallāna ttheraḥ pana
translated: and so the Blessed One said “Wait,” etc., in order to restrain him. But the Elder Maha Moggallana

original: attano bhārabhāvaṃ aññāsi. Tenassa bhagavā sādhukāraṃ adāsi.
analyzed: attanaḥ bhāra bhāvam aññāsi tena assa bhagavā sādhukāram adāsi
translated: was aware of his own burden, and so the Blessed One gave him praise.

original: 161. Cattārimāni, bhikkhaveti kasmā ārabhi? Imasmiṃ sāsane cattāri bhayāni. Yo tāni
analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave iti kasmai ārabhi imasmin sāsane cattāri bhayāni yaḥ tāni
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four” : why did he begin with this? There are four dangers in this Dispensation.

original: abhīto hoti, so imasmiṃ sāsane patiṭṭhātuṃ sakkoti. Itaro pana na sakkotīti dassetuṃ
analyzed: abhītaḥ hoti saḥ imasmiṃ sāsane patiṭṭhātum sakkoti itaro pana na sakkoti iti dassetum
translated: In order to show this,

original: imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha udakorohanteti udakaṃ orohante puggale. Kumbhīlabhayanti
analyzed: imam desanam ārabhi tattha udakorohanta iti udakam orohante puggale
translated: he began this teaching. Herein, as to one who goes into the water: a person who goes into the water. The danger from crocodiles:

original: suṃsumārabhayaṃ. Susukābhayanti caṇḍamacchabhayaṃ.
analyzed: caṇḍam accha bhayam
translated: the danger from Supaṇṇas. The danger from whirlpools: the danger from fierce fish.

original: 162. Kodhupāyāsassetaṃ adhivacananti yathā hi bāhiraṃ udakaṃ otiṇṇo ūmīsu osīditvā
analyzed: kodha upāyāsassa etam adhivacananti yathā hi bāhiram udakam otiṇṇaḥ ūmīsu osīditvā
translated: This is a term for anger and resentment: just as one who has gone into the water outside is drowned and dies after sinking in the mud,

original: marati, evaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane kodhupāyāse osīditvā vibbhamati. Tasmā kodhupāyāso “ūmibhaya”nti vutto.
analyzed: marati evam imasmin sāsane kodha upāyāse osīditvā vibbhamati tasmā kodha upāyāsaḥ ūmibhayanti vutto
translated: so too, one sinks in anger and resentment in this Dispensation and then falls away. That is why anger and resentment are called “the danger from whirlpools.”

original: 163. Odarikattassetaṃ adhivacananti yathā hi bāhiraṃ udakaṃ otiṇṇo kumbhīlena khādito
analyzed: odarikattassa itam yathā hi bāhiram udakam otiṇṇaḥ kumbhīlena khāditaḥ
translated: This is a term for greed: just as one who has gone into the water outside is devoured by crocodiles and dies,

original: marati, evaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane odarikattena khādito vibbhamati. Tasmā odarikattaṃ “kumbhīlabhaya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: marati evam imasmin sāsane odarikattena khāditaḥ vibbhamati tasmai odarikattam kumbhīlabhayanti vuttam
translated: so too, one is devoured by greed in this Dispensation and then falls away. That is why greed is called “the danger from crocodiles.”

original: 164. Arakkhiteneva kāyenāti sīsappacālakādikaraṇena arakkhitakāyo hutvā. Arakkhitāya
analyzed: arakkhitena iva kāyena ati sīsa ppacālaka ādi karaṇena arakkhita kāyaḥ hutvā arakkhitāya
translated: With his body unguarded: having made his body unguarded by such means as letting his head hang out of a window. With his mind unguarded: having made his mind unguarded by such means as giving attention to the sign of foulness in a woman.

original: vācāyāti duṭṭhullabhāsanādivasena arakkhitavāco hutvā. Anupaṭṭhitāya satiyāti kāyagatāsatiṃ🔽anupaṭṭhāpetvā. Asaṃvutehīti apihitehi. Pañcannetaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ adhivacananti yathā🔽hi bāhiraṃ udakaṃ otiṇṇo āvaṭṭe nimujjitvā marati, evaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane pabbajito
analyzed: vācāya iti duṭṭhulla bhāsana ādi vasena arakkhita vācaḥ hutvā anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā iti kāya gata asatim  an upaṭṭhāpetvā a saṃvutehi iti apihitehi yathā  hi bāhiram udakam otiṇṇaḥ āvaṭṭe nimujjitvā marati evam imasmin sāsane pabbajitaḥ
translated: “In speech” means: having become one who is not guarded in speech by speaking what is not factual, and so on. “With mindfulness unestablished” means: not having established mindfulness directed to the body. “With the sense faculties unrestrained” means: with the sense faculties unguarded. “This is a designation for the five strands of sense pleasure” means: just as one who has gone into the water of a river may drown in a whirlpool, so too, one who has gone forth in this Dispensation may be destroyed by the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: pañcakāmaguṇāvaṭṭe nimujjitvā vibbhamati. Tasmā pañca kāmaguṇā “āvaṭṭabhaya”nti vuttā.🔽165. Anuddhaṃsetīti kilameti milāpeti. Rāgānuddhaṃsenāti rāgānuddhaṃsitena. Mātugāmassetaṃ
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa avaṭṭe nimujjitvā vibbhamati tasmai pañca kāmaguṇāḥ āvaṭṭabhayanti vuttā  an uddhaṃseti iti kilama iti milāpa iti rāga an uddhaṃsena ati rāga an uddhaṃsitena mātu gāmaḥ etam
translated: “In speech”: being unrestrained in speech by speaking what is not factual, and so on. “With mindfulness unestablished”: without establishing mindfulness directed to the body. “With sense faculties unrestrained”: with the sense faculties unguarded. “This is a term for the five cords of sense desire”: just as one who has gone into the water of a river may drown in a whirlpool, so too, one who has gone forth in this Dispensation may fall away from the spiritual life in the whirlpool of the five cords of sense desire. Therefore the five cords of sense desire are called “the danger of whirlpools.”

original: adhivacananti yathā hi bāhiraṃ udakaṃ otiṇṇo caṇḍamacchaṃ āgamma laddhappahāro marati,
analyzed: adhivacanam ti yathā hi bāhiram udakam otiṇṇaḥ caṇḍamaccham āgamma laddha ppahāraḥ marati
translated: “He does not pull out”: he does not pull out, he drowns, he sinks. “By being pulled out by lust”: by being pulled out by lust. “This is a term for women”: just as one who has gone into the water of a river may drown when seized by a crocodile,

original: evaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane mātugāmaṃ āgamma uppannakāmarāgo vibbhamati. Tasmā mātugāmo “susukābhaya”nti vutto.
analyzed: evam imasmin sāsane mātugāmam āgamma uppanna kāma rāgaḥ vibbhamati tasmā mātugāmaḥ vutto
translated: so too, one who has gone forth in this Dispensation may fall away from the spiritual life when lust arises in him for women. Therefore women are called “the danger of crocodiles.”

original: Imāni pana cattāri bhayāni bhāyitvā yathā udakaṃ anorohantassa udakaṃ nissāya ānisaṃso
analyzed: imāni pana cattāri bhayāni bhāyitvā yathā udakam anorohantassa udakam nissāya ānisaṃsaḥ
translated: But when one is afraid of these four dangers and does not go down into the water, then, as in the case of the man who does not go down into the water, there is no advantage to be derived from the water.

original: natthi, udakapipāsāya pipāsito ca hoti rajojallena kiliṭṭhasarīro ca, evamevaṃ imāni
analyzed: natthi udaka pipāsāya pipāsito ca hoti rajojallena kiliṭṭha sarīro ca evam evam imāni
translated: He is thirsty with the thirst for water and his body is soiled with mud and clay.

original: cattāri bhayāni bhāyitvā sāsane apabbajantassāpi imaṃ sāsanaṃ nissāya ānisaṃso natthi,
analyzed: cattāri bhayāni bhāyitvā sāsane a pabbajantassa api imam sāsanam nissāya ānisaṃsaḥ natthi
translated: So too, when one is afraid of these four dangers and does not go forth into homelessness in the Dispensation, then there is no advantage to be derived from the Dispensation.

original: taṇhāpipāsāya pipāsito ca hoti kilesarajena saṃkiliṭṭhacitto ca. Yathā pana imāni🔽cattāri bhayāni abhāyitvā udakaṃ orohantassa vuttappakāro ānisaṃso hoti, evaṃ imāni🔽abhāyitvā sāsane pabbajitassāpi vuttappakāro ānisaṃso hoti. Thero panāha – “cattāri
analyzed: taṇhā pipāsāya pipāsito ca hoti kilesa rajena saṃkiliṭṭha citto ca yathā pana imāni  cattāri bhayāni a bhāyitvā udakam orohantassa vutta ppakāraḥ ānisaṃsaḥ hoti evam imāni  a bhāyitvā sāsane pabbajitassa api vutta ppakāraḥ ānisaṃsaḥ hoti theraḥ pana āha cattāri
translated: He is thirsty with the thirst for sensual pleasures and his mind is soiled with the defilements.🔽But when one is not afraid of these four dangers and goes down into the water, then the advantage already mentioned is derived. So too, when one is not afraid of these four dangers and goes forth into homelessness in the Dispensation, then the advantage already mentioned is derived.

original: bhayāni bhāyitvā udakaṃ anotaranto sotaṃ chinditvā paratīraṃ pāpuṇituṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: bhayāni bhāyitvā udakam sotam chinditvā para tīram pāpuṇitum na sakkoti
translated: But the Elder said: “When one is afraid of these four dangers and does not go down into the water, he is unable to cut across the stream and reach the further bank.

original: abhāyitvā otaranto sakkoti, evamevaṃ bhāyitvā sāsane apabbajantopi taṇhāsotaṃ chinditvā
analyzed: a bhāyitvā otaranto sakkoti evam evam bhāyitvā sāsane a pabbajantaḥ api taṇhā sotam chinditvā
translated: But when one goes down into the water without being afraid, he is able to do so. So too, when one is afraid of these four dangers and does not go forth into homelessness in the Dispensation, he is unable to cut across the stream of craving and reach Nibbāna.

original: nibbānapāraṃ daṭṭhuṃ na sakkoti, abhāyitvā pabbajanto pana sakkotī”ti. Sesaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: nibbāna pāram daṭṭhum na sakkoti abhāyitvā pabbajanto pana sakkoti iti sesam sabbattha
translated: he cannot see to the other side of Nibbāna, but one who goes forth after being terrified can.” The rest is clear in all ways.

original: uttānameva. Ayaṃ pana desanā neyyapuggalassa vasena niṭṭhāpitāti.
analyzed: uttānam eva ayam pana desanā neyya puggalassa vasena niṭṭhāpitā ati
translated: But this teaching was concluded with reference to the type of person who is to be led.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhimanikāya of the Papañcasūdani

original: Cātumasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cātuma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Cātumā Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Naḷakapānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: naḷaka pāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Naḷakapāna Sutta

original: 166. Evaṃ me sutanti naḷakapānasuttaṃ. Tattha naḷakapāneti evaṃnāmake gāme. Pubbe
analyzed: evam me sutan ti naḷaka pāna suttam tattha naḷaka pāne ti evaṃnāmake gāme pubbe
translated: Thus I heard. The Naḷakapāna Sutta. There, in the village of the same name. Formerly,

original: kira amhākaṃ bodhisatto vānarayoniyaṃ nibbatto, mahākāyo kapirājā anekavānarasahassaparivuto
analyzed: kira amhākam bodhisattaḥ vānara yoniyam nibbattaḥ mahā kāyaḥ kapi rājā aneka vānara sahassa parivutaḥ
translated: it seems, our Bodhisatta was reborn in the animal kingdom as a monkey. He was a great monkey king, surrounded by many thousands of monkeys,

original: pabbatapāde vicarati. Paññavā kho pana hoti mahāpuñño. So parisaṃ evaṃ ovadati –🔽“imasmiṃ pabbatapāde tātā, visaphalāni nāma honti, amanussapariggahitā pokkharaṇiyo
analyzed: pabbata pāde vicarati paññavā kho pana hoti mahā puñño so parisam evam ovadati  imasmin pabbata pāde tātā visaphalāni nāma honti amanussa pariggahitāḥ pokkharaṇiyaḥ
translated: wandering on the side of a mountain. He was wise and had great merit. He advised his retinue thus:🔽“Dears, there are poisonous fruits on this mountain side, and there are lotus ponds belonging to non-human beings.

original: nāma honti, tumhe pubbe khāditapubbāneva phalāni khādatha, pītapubbāneva pānīyāni
analyzed: nāma honti tumhe pubbe khādita pubbāni eva phalāni khādatha pīta pubbāni eva pānīyāni
translated: You should not eat fruits that you have not eaten before, or drink water that you have not drunk before.

original: ca pivatha, ettha vo maṃ paṭipucchitabbakiccaṃ natthi, akhāditapubbāni pana phalāni
analyzed: ca pivatha ettha vaḥ mama paṭipucchitabba kiccam natthi a khādita pubbāni pana phalāni
translated: “Drink, there is no need to ask me about it. But as for fruits that you have never tasted before,

original: apītapubbāni ca pānīyāni maṃ apucchitvā mā khādittha mā pivitthā”ti.
analyzed: a pīta pubbāni ca pānīyāni mama a pucchitvā mā khādittha mā pivittha ati
translated: and water that you have never drunk before, do not eat or drink them without asking me.”

original: Te ekadivasaṃ caramānā aññaṃ pabbatapādaṃ gantvā gocaraṃ gahetvā pānīyaṃ olokentā🔽ekaṃ amanussapariggahitaṃ pokkharaṇiṃ disvā sahasā apivitvā samantā parivāretvā mahāsattassa
analyzed: te eka divasam caramānāḥ aññam pabbata pādam gantvā gocaram gahetvā pānīyam olokentā  ekam amanussa pariggahitam pokkharaṇim disvā sahasā a pivitvā samantā parivāretvā mahāsattassa
translated: One day, as they were wandering about, they went to another mountain-side, and after they had taken their food, they looked about for water.🔽They saw a lotus-pool which was haunted by a demon, and they refrained from drinking the water, but after they had gone all round it, they sat down and waited for the Great Being to come.

original: āgamanaṃ olokayamānā nisīdiṃsu. Mahāsatto āgantvā “kiṃ tātā pānīyaṃ na pivathā”ti
analyzed: āgamanam olokayamānāḥ nisīdiṃsu mahāsatto āgantvā kim tātā pānīyam na pivatha ati
translated: The Great Being came and said, “Dears, why do you not drink the water?”

original: āha. Tumhākaṃ āgamanaṃ olokemāti. Sādhu tātāti samantā padaṃ pariyesamāno otiṇṇapadaṃyeva
analyzed: āha tumhākam āgamanam olokema ati sādhu tāta ati samantā padam pariyesamānaḥ otiṇṇa padaṃyā iva
translated: “We are waiting for you to come.” “Very well, dears,” and after he had searched all round for a place where he could get down, he saw only a place where someone had come out,

original: addasa, na uttiṇṇapadaṃ, disvā saparissayāti aññāsi. Tāvadeva ca tattha abhinibbattaamanusso
analyzed: addasa naḥ uttiṇṇa padam disvā saparissayā ati aññāsi tāvat eva ca tattha abhinibbatta amanusso
translated: and no place where anyone had gone in. When he saw this, he knew that there was danger there. And immediately the demon, who had taken up his abode there,

original: udakaṃ dvedhā katvā uṭṭhāsi setamukho nīlakucchi rattahatthapādo mahādāṭhiko vaṅkadāṭho
analyzed: udakam dvedhā katvā uṭṭhāsi seta mukhaḥ nīla kucchi ratta hattha pādaḥ mahā dāṭhikaḥ vaṅka dāṭho
translated: divided the water into two parts and stood up, white-faced, black-bellied, with red hands and feet, with big teeth, and crooked teeth.

original: virūpo bībhaccho udakarakkhaso. So evamāha – “kasmā pānīyaṃ na pivatha, madhuraṃ
analyzed: virūpaḥ bībhacchaḥ udaka rakkhasaḥ saḥ evam āha kasmai pānīyam na pivatha madhuram
translated: Virūpakkha, the water-demon. He said: “Why do you not drink? Drink the sweet water.

original: udakaṃ pivatha, kiṃ tumhe etassa vacanaṃ suṇāthā”ti? Mahāsatto āha – “tvaṃ idha adhivattho🔽amanusso”ti? Āmāhanti. Tvaṃ idha otiṇṇe labhasīti? Āma labhāmi, tumhe pana sabbe
analyzed: udakam pivatha kim tumhe etassa vacanam suṇātha ati mahāsattaḥ āha tvam idha adhivatthaḥ  amanussaḥ ti tvam idha otiṇṇe labhasi iti āma labhāmi tumhe pana sabbe
translated: Why do you listen to his words?” The Great Being said: “You are a non-human being who lives here.”

original: khādissāmīti. Na sakkhissasi, yakkhāti. Pānīyaṃ pana pivissathāti? Āma pivissāmāti.
analyzed: khādissāmi iti na sakkhissasi yakkha ati pānīyam pana pivissatha ati āma pivissāma ati
translated: “Yes.” “Do you get what you want here?” “Yes, I get it, but I shall eat all of you.” “You cannot, demon.” “But will you drink water?” “Yes, we will drink.”

original: Evaṃ sante ekopi vo na muccissatīti. Pānīyañca pivissāma, na ca te vasaṃ gamissāmāti🔽ekanaḷaṃ āharāpetvā koṭiyaṃ gahetvā dhami, sabbo ekacchiddo ahosi, tīre nisīditvāva🔽pānīyaṃ pivi, sesavānarānaṃ pāṭiyekke naḷe āharāpetvā dhamitvā adāsi. Sabbe yakkhassa
analyzed: evam sante ekaḥ api vaḥ na muccissati iti pānīyam ca pivissāma na ca te vasam gamissāma ati  eka naḷam āharāpetvā koṭiyam gahetvā dhami sabbaḥ eka chiddaḥ ahosi tīre nisīditvā ava  pānīyam sesa vānarānam pāṭiyekke naḷe āharāpetvā dhamitvā adāsi sabbe yakkhassa
translated: “In that case, not one of you will escape.” “We will drink water and we will not come under your control.”

original: passantasseva pānīyaṃ piviṃsu. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: passantassa iva pānīyam piviṃsu vuttam pi ca itam
translated: He had a reed brought, seized it by the top, and blew it. It became one long tube, and they sat down on the bank and drank water through it. He had reeds brought for the other monkeys, blew them, and gave them to them. They all drank water in the presence of the demon. And this is said:

original: “Disvā padamanuttiṇṇaṃ, disvāno’ taritaṃ padaṃ;
analyzed: disvā padam an uttiṇṇam disvānaḥ taritam padam
translated: “Seeing the foot that has not crossed over, seeing the foot that has crossed over,

original: Naḷena vāriṃ pissāma, neva maṃ tvaṃ vadhissasī”ti. ;
analyzed: naḷena vārim pissāma na iva mama tvam vadhissasi iti
translated: We will drink water through a reed, and you will not kill me.”

original: Tato paṭṭhāya yāva ajjadivasā tasmiṃ ṭhāne naḷā ekacchiddāva honti. Iminā hi saddhiṃ
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya yāva ajja divasā tasmin ṭhāne naḷāḥ ekacchiddāḥ ava honti iminā hi saddhiṃ
translated: Ever since that time, until this very day, the reeds in that place have remained split at one end.

original: imasmiṃ kappe cattāri kappaṭṭhiyapāṭihāriyāni nāma – cande sasabimbaṃ, vaṭṭakajātakamhi
analyzed: imasmin kappe cattāri kappaṭṭhiya pāṭihāriyāni nāma cande sa sa bimbam vaṭṭaka jātakamhi
translated: In this world-cycle there are four miracles that last for a whole world-cycle: the hare’s image in the moon,🔽the stopping of the fire that was kindled at the time of the performance of the miracle of the Twin-miracle,

original: saccakiriyaṭṭhāne aggissa gamanupacchedo, ghaṭikārakumbhakārassa mātāpitūnaṃ vasanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: sacca kiriya ṭṭhāne aggissa gamana upacchedaḥ ghaṭikāra kumbhakārassa mātā pitūnam vasana ṭṭhāne
translated: the non-falling of rain on the parents of Ghaṭīkāra the potter,

original: devassa avassanaṃ, tassā pokkharaṇiyā tīre naḷānaṃ ekacchiddabhāvoti. Iti sā pokkharaṇī🔽naḷena pānīyassa pītattā naḷakapānāti nāmaṃ labhi. Aparabhāge taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ nissāya
analyzed: devassa avassanam tassā pokkharaṇiyā tīre naḷānam ekacchidda bhāvaḥ iti sā pokkharaṇī  naḷena pānīyassa pīta ttā naḷakapānā ati nāmam labhi aparabhāge tam pokkharaṇim nissāya
translated: and the splitting of the reeds at one end on the bank of that lotus-pond.🔽Thus that lotus-pond came to be known as Naḷakapāna,

original: gāmo patiṭṭhāsi, tassāpi naḷakapānanteva nāmaṃ jātaṃ. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “naḷakapāne”ti.
analyzed: gāmaḥ patiṭṭhāsi tassa api naḷaka pāna ntā iva nāmam jātam tam sandhāya vuttam naḷaka pānā iti
translated: “Reed-drink,” because water was drunk through a reed. Later on, a village was established near that lotus-pond, and it too came to be known as Naḷakapāna.

original: Palāsavaneti kiṃsukavane.
analyzed: palāsa vana iti kiṃsuka vane
translated: In the Palāsa forest.

original: 167. Taggha mayaṃ, bhanteti ekaṃseneva mayaṃ, bhante, abhiratā. Aññepi ye tumhākaṃ sāsane abhiramanti, te amhehi sadisāva hutvā abhiramantīti dīpenti.
analyzed: tat ha mayam bhante iti ekaṃsena iva mayam bhante abhiratāḥ aññe pi ye tumhākam sāsane abhiramanti te amhehi sadisā ava hutvā abhiramanti iti dīpenti
translated: “Indeed, venerable sir, we delight in it” means “We delight in it, venerable sir, with one-pointed intentness. And those others who delight in your dispensation delight in it just as we do.”

original: Neva rājābhinītātiādīsu eko rañño aparādhaṃ katvā palāyati. Rājā kuhiṃ, bho, asukoti?
analyzed: na iva rājā abhinītā ati ādīsu ekaḥ raññaḥ aparādham katvā palāyati rājā kuhim bho asuka iti
translated: As to “not by royal command”: One man commits an offence against the king and flees. The king says, “Where is so-and-so?”

original: Palāto devāti. Palātaṭṭhānepi me na muccissati, sace pana pabbajeyya, mucceyyāti
analyzed: palātaḥ deva ati palāta ṭṭhāne pi me na muccissati sace pana pabbajeyya mucceyya ati
translated: “He has fled, your majesty.” “He will not escape me even if he has fled. But if he goes forth, he will escape.”

original: vadati. Tassa kocideva suhado gantvā taṃ pavattiṃ ārocetvā tvaṃ sace jīvitumicchasi,
analyzed: vadati tassa kocid eva suhadaḥ gantvā tam pavattim ārocetvā tvam sace jīvitum icchasi
translated: So he says. Then one of the king’s friends goes and tells him, “If you want to live,

original: pabbajāhīti. So pabbajitvā jīvitaṃ rakkhamāno carati. Ayaṃ rājābhinīto nāma.
analyzed: pabbajāhi iti so pabbajitvā jīvitam rakkhamāno carati ayam rājābhinītaḥ nāma
translated: go forth.” He goes forth and lives the holy life, preserving his life. This is called “one who has gone forth by royal command.”

original: Eko pana corānaṃ mūlaṃ chindanto carati. Corā sutvā “purisānaṃ atthikabhāvaṃ na jānāti,
analyzed: ekaḥ pana corānam mūlam chindanto carati corā sutvā purisānaṃ atthika bhāvam na jānāti
translated: Another man goes about cutting off the roots of the thieves. The thieves say, “He does not know that we are in need of men,

original: jānāpessāma na”nti vadanti. So taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā palāyati. Corā palātoti sutvā “palātaṭṭhānepi
analyzed: jānāpessāma nanti vadanti saḥ tam pavattim sutvā palāyati corā palāto ti sutvā palāta ṭṭhāne pi
translated: let us find out.” He hears about this and flees. The thieves hear that he has fled and say, “He has fled

original: no na muccissati, sace pana pabbajeyya, mucceyyā”ti vadanti. So taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā
analyzed: no na muccissati sace pana pabbajeyya mucceyya ati vadanti saḥ tam pavattim sutvā
translated: “He will not be released, but if he goes forth he will be released.”🔽🔽He heard what was happening,

original: pabbajati. Ayaṃ corābhinīto nāma.
analyzed: pabbajati ayam corābhinītaḥ nāma
translated: and if he went forth he would be released. ’ So he goes forth. This is called the one gone forth on account of a thief.

original: Eko pana bahuṃ iṇaṃ khāditvā tena iṇena aṭṭo pīḷito tamhā gāmā palāyati. Iṇasāmikā
analyzed: ekaḥ pana bahum iṇam khāditvā tena iṇena aṭṭaḥ pīḍitaḥ tamhā gāmā palāyati iṇa sāmikā
translated: But one who has eaten much food on credit and is pressed by his creditors flees from that village.

original: sutvā “palātaṭṭhānepi no na muccissati, sace pana pabbajeyya, mucceyyā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: sutvā palāta ṭṭhāne pi no na muccissati sace pana pabbajeyya mucceyya ati vadanti
translated: The creditors hear of this and say, ‘We will not let him go even if he flees. But if he goes forth we will let him go.’

original: So taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā pabbajati. Ayaṃ iṇaṭṭo nāma.
analyzed: saḥ tam pavattim sutvā pabbajati ayam iṇaṭṭaḥ nāma
translated: So he goes forth. This is called the one gone forth on account of a debt.

original: Rājabhayādīnaṃ pana aññatarena bhayena bhīto aṭṭo āturo hutvā nikkhamma pabbajito
analyzed: rāja bhaya ādīnam pana aññatarena bhayena bhītaḥ aṭṭaḥ āturaḥ hutvā nikkhamma pabbajitaḥ
translated: But one who is frightened, terrified, and alarmed by the fear of a king, etc., goes forth after fleeing from it.

original: bhayaṭṭo nāma. Dubbhikkhādīsu jīvituṃ asakkonto pabbajito ājīvikāpakato nāma, ājīvikāya
analyzed: bhayaṭṭaḥ nāma dubbhikkha ādīsu jīvitum a sakkontaḥ pabbajitaḥ ājīvikāpakataḥ nāma ājīvikāya
translated: This is called the one gone forth on account of fear. The one gone forth on account of livelihood is one who goes forth because he cannot manage to live in a time of famine, etc.;

original: pakato abhibhūtoti attho. Imesu pana ekopi imehi kāraṇehi pabbajito nāma natthi,
analyzed: pakataḥ abhibhūtaḥ ti attho imesu pana ekaḥ api imehi kāraṇehi pabbajitaḥ nāma natthi
translated: the meaning is, he is overcome by the need to earn a living. But there is no one among these who has gone forth for any one of these reasons,

original: tasmā “neva rājābhinīto”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tasmai na iva rājā abhinītā iti ādim āha
translated: so he says, ‘Not gone forth on account of a king,’ and so on.

original: Vivekanti vivicca vivitto hutvā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ kāmehi ca akusaladhammehi🔽ca vivittena paṭhamadutiyajjhānasaṅkhātaṃ pītisukhaṃ adhigantabbaṃ, sace taṃ vivicca🔽kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṃ nādhigacchati, aññaṃ vā upari dvinnaṃ
analyzed: vivekam ti vivicca vivittaḥ hutvā idam vuttam hoti yam kāmehi ca akusala dhammehi  ca vivittena paṭhama dutiya jhāna saṅkhātam pīti sukham adhigantabbam sace tam vivicca  kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi pīti sukham na adhigacchati aññam vā upari dvinnam
translated: “Secluded” means secluded, secluded from the unprofitable. This is the meaning: the happiness and bliss that should be attained secluded from sensual pleasures and secluded from unprofitable things is the first and second jhānas. If he does not attain that happiness and bliss secluded from sensual pleasures and secluded from unprofitable things, or some other happiness and bliss higher than that,🔽then he should reflect: “What is the cause why I do not attain the happiness and bliss that should be attained secluded from sensual pleasures and secluded from unprofitable things?”🔽

original: jhānānaṃ catunnañca maggānaṃ vasena santataraṃ sukhaṃ nādhigacchati, tassa ime abhijjhādayo
analyzed: jhānānam catunnam ca maggānam vasena santataram sukham na adhigacchati tassa ime abhijjhā ādayaḥ
translated: “Sees clearly” : having seen clearly, having become secluded. This is what is meant: the bliss and pleasure called the first and second jhānas, which are to be attained by seclusion from sense desires and from unwholesome states, if one does not attain that bliss and pleasure by seclusion from sense desires and from unwholesome states, or if one does not attain a still more peaceful bliss and pleasure by way of the two higher jhānas and the four paths, then these covetousness, etc.,

original: cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhantīti. Tattha aratīti adhikusalesu dhammesu ukkaṇṭhitatā.🔽Tandīti ālasiyabhāvo. Evaṃ yo pabbajitvā pabbajitakiccaṃ kātuṃ na sakkoti, tassa🔽ime satta pāpadhammā uppajjitvā cittaṃ pariyādiyantīti dassetvā idāni yassa te dhammā
analyzed: cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti iti tattha arati iti adhikusalesu dhammesu ukkaṇṭhita tā  tandī iti ālasiya bhāvaḥ evam yaḥ pabbajitvā pabbajita kiccam kātum na sakkoti tassa  ime satta pāpa dhammā uppajjitvā cittam pariyādiyanti iti dassetvā idāni yassa te dhammā
translated: stand obstructing his mind. Herein, “discontent” is dissatisfaction with wholesome states.🔽“Dullness” is the state of being lazy. Thus, having gone forth, if one is unable to do the work of one gone forth, then these seven bad states arise and stand obstructing his mind.

original: cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, soyeva samaṇakiccampi kātuṃ na sakkotīti puna vivekaṃ
analyzed: cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti saḥ yā iva samaṇa kiccam pi kātum na sakkoti iti puna vivekam
translated: Having shown this, now, in order to show that he who has these states standing obstructing his mind is unable to do even the work of an ascetic, he said, “He who is overcome by these states,” etc.

original: anuruddhā…pe… aññaṃ vā tato santataranti āha.
analyzed: aññam vā tatas santataranti āha
translated: … or more peaceful than that.’

original: Evaṃ kaṇhapakkhaṃ dassetvā idāni teneva nayena sukkapakkhaṃ dassetuṃ puna vivekantiādimāha. Tassattho vuttanayeneva veditabbo.🔽168. Saṅkhāyāti jānitvā. Ekanti ekaccaṃ. Paṭisevatīti sevitabbayuttakaṃ sevati. Sesapadesupi
analyzed: evam kaṇha pakkham dassetvā idāni tena iva nayena sukka pakkham dassetum puna viveka nti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ  saṅkhāya ati jānitvā ekam ti ekaccam paṭisevati iti sevitabba yuttakam sevati sesa padesu pi
translated: Having thus shown the dark side, he now said ‘Again, a bhikkhu’ may be understood in the same way.🔽‘Having understood’: having known. ‘One’: a certain one. ‘Frequents’: frequents one who is fit to be frequented. The same method of explanation applies in the other passages.

original: eseva nayo. Upapattīsu byākarotīti sappaṭisandhike tāva byākarotu, appaṭisandhike
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ upapattīsu byākaroti iti sa paṭisandhike tāva byākarotu appaṭisandhike
translated: ‘He declares in regard to reappearance’: let him declare in regard to reappearance with rebirth-linking,

original: kathaṃ byākarotīti. Appaṭisandhikassa puna bhave paṭisandhi natthīti vadanto upapattīsu byākaroti nāma.
analyzed: katham byākaroti iti appaṭisandhikassa puna bhave paṭisandhi natthi iti vadantaḥ upapattīsu byākaroti nāma
translated: ‘How does he declare?’ He declares in regard to reappearance by saying that there is no rebirth-linking in a future existence for one without rebirth-linking.

original: Janakuhanatthanti janavimhāpanatthaṃ. Janalapanatthanti mahājanassa upalāpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: jana kuhana ttham ti jana vimhāpana ttham jana lapana ttham ti mahā janassa upalāpana ttham
translated: ‘For the purpose of deceiving people’: for the purpose of deceiving the multitude. ‘For the purpose of deceiving the multitude’: for the purpose of deceiving the great multitude.

original: Na iti maṃ jano jānātūti evaṃ maṃ mahājano jānissati, evaṃ me mahājanassa antare
analyzed: na iti mama janaḥ jānātu uti evam mama mahājanaḥ jānissati evam me mahājanassa antare
translated: ‘Let people not know me thus’: ‘In this way the great multitude will know me thus,’

original: kittisaddo uggacchissatīti imināpi kāraṇena na byākarotīti attho. Uḷāravedāti mahantatuṭṭhino.
analyzed: kitti saddaḥ uggacchissati iti iminā api kāraṇena na byākaroti iti atthaḥ uḷāra vedāti mahanta tuṭṭhinaḥ
translated: “His fame will spread” means: the meaning is, he does not make a declaration for this reason. “With high esteem” means: with great satisfaction.

original: 169. So kho panassa āyasmāti so parinibbuto āyasmā imassa ṭhitassa āyasmato. Evaṃsīlotiādīsu
analyzed: saḥ kho pana assa āyasmā iti saḥ parinibbutaḥ āyasmantaḥ imassa ṭhitassa āyasmataḥ evaṃsīlaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: “That venerable one” means: that venerable one who has attained parinibbāna, for this venerable one who is standing here. As regards “of such virtue” and so on,

original: lokiyalokuttaramissakāva sīlādayo veditabbo. Evaṃdhammoti ettha pana samādhipakkhikā
analyzed: sīla ādayaḥ veditabbaḥ evaṃdhammo ti ettha pana samādhi pakkhikā
translated: it should be understood that virtue and so on are a mixture of mundane and supramundane. As regards “of such qualities,” here

original: dhammā dhammāti adhippetā. Phāsuvihāro hotīti tena bhikkhunā pūritapaṭipattiṃ pūrentassa
analyzed: dhammā dhammā ti adhippetā phāsu vihāraḥ hoti iti tena bhikkhunā pūrita paṭipattim pūrentassa
translated: the qualities that are factors of concentration are intended by the word “qualities.” “He has an easy life” means: when one bhikkhu fulfills the practice that has been fulfilled by another bhikkhu,

original: arahattaphalaṃ sacchikatvā phalasamāpattivihārena phāsuvihāro hoti, arahattaṃ pattumasakkontassa
analyzed: arahatta phalam sacchikatvā phala samāpatti vihārena phāsu vihāraḥ hoti arahattam pattum a sakkontassa
translated: he has an easy life by means of the living of the life of the attainment of fruition after realizing the fruit of arahantship. Even when one who is unable to attain arahantship is fulfilling the practice,

original: paṭipattiṃ pūrayamānassa caratopi phāsuvihāroyeva nāma hoti. Iminā nayena sabbavāresu attho veditabboti.
analyzed: paṭipattim pūrayamānassa carataḥ api phāsu vihāraḥ yā iva nāma hoti iminā nayena sabba vāresu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: he is said to have an easy life. The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya, called The Food of the Wise,

original: Naḷakapānasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: naḷaka pāna sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Naḷakapāna Sutta is finished.

original: 9. Goliyānisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: goliyāni sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Goliyāṇi Sutta

original: 173. Evaṃ me sutanti goliyānisuttaṃ. Tattha padasamācāroti dubbalasamācāro oḷārikācāro,🔽paccayesu sāpekkho mahārakkhitatthero viya. Taṃ kira upaṭṭhākakule nisinnaṃ upaṭṭhāko🔽āha “asukattherassa me, bhante, cīvaraṃ dinna”nti. Sādhu te kataṃ taṃyeva takketvā
analyzed: evam me sutam ti goliyāni suttam tattha pada samācāro ti dubbala samācāro oḷārika ācāro  paccayesu sa apekkhaḥ mahārakkhita theraḥ viya tam kira upaṭṭhāka kule nisinnam upaṭṭhāko  āha asuka ttherassa me bhante cīvaram dinnanti sādhu te katam taṃyeva takketvā
translated: “Thus have I heard” : the Goliya-nisadha Sutta . Herein, by the words “in the way of footing” is meant the way of weakness, the way of grossness.

original: viharantassa cīvaraṃ dentenāti. Tumhākampi, bhante, dassāmīti. Sādhu karissasi taṃyeva
analyzed: viharantassa cīvaram dentena ati tumhākam pi bhante dassāmi iti sādhu karissasi
translated: The Elder Mahārakkhita was dependent on conditions. It seems that when he was sitting in the family that looked after him, the attendant said, “Venerable sir, I have given a robe to so-and-so.” “Good, good, it is well done by you. You will live on, looking after that very one to whom you gave the robe.” “I will give you one too, venerable sir.” “Good, good, it is well done by you. You will live on, looking after that very one to whom you will give it.”

original: takkentassāti āha. Ayampi evarūpo oḷārikācāro ahosi. Sappatissenāti sajeṭṭhakena,🔽na attānaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā viharitabbaṃ. Serivihārenāti sacchandavihārena niraṅkusavihārena.🔽Nānūpakhajjāti na anupakhajja na anupavisitvā. Tattha yo dvīsu mahātheresu ubhato
analyzed: takkentassa ati āha ayam pi evarūpaḥ oḷārika ācāraḥ ahosi sappatissena ati sajeṭṭhakena  na attānam jeṭṭhakam katvā viharitabbam seri vihārena ati sa chanda vihārena niraṅkusa vihārena  na anūpakhajjāti na anupakhajja na anupavisitvā tattha yaḥ dvīsu mahā theresu ubhatas
translated: This one was of such a way of grossness. By “with seniority” is meant with the seniormost.🔽He should not live making himself the seniormost. By “in the way of being led” is meant in the way of being led by desire, in the way of being led by hatred, in the way of being led by delusion, in the way of being led by fear.

original: nisinnesu te anāpucchitvāva cīvarena vā jāṇunā vā ghaṭṭento nisīdati, ayaṃ anupakhajja
analyzed: nisinnesu te an āpucchitvā ava cīvarena vā jāṇunā vā ghaṭṭentaḥ nisīdati ayam an upakhajja
translated: By “not encroaching” is meant not encroaching, not visiting. Herein, one who sits down after pushing aside with his knee or with a robe the two senior elders who are sitting on both sides,

original: nisīdati nāma. Evaṃ akatvā pana attano pattaāsanasantike ṭhatvā nisīdāvusoti vutte🔽nisīditabbaṃ. Sace na vadanti, nisīdāmi, bhanteti āpucchitvā nisīditabbaṃ āpucchitakālato
analyzed: nisīdati nāma evam a katvā pana attanaḥ pattaāsana santike ṭhatvā nisīda avuso ti vutte  nisīditabbam sace na vadanti nisīdāmi bhante iti āpucchitvā nisīditabbam āpucchita kālataḥ
translated: “Sits down” means that he should not sit down without first saying, “Sit down, friend,” and then standing in the place reserved for him.🔽If they do not say so, he should sit down after announcing himself: “I am sitting down, venerable sirs.”

original: paṭṭhāya nisīdāti vuttepi avuttepi nisīdituṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Na paṭibāhissāmīti ettha
analyzed: paṭṭhāya nisīda ati vutte pi a vutte pi nisīditum vaṭṭatiyā iva na paṭibāhissāmi iti ettha
translated: After he has announced himself, it is allowable for him to sit down whether they say so or not.

original: yo attano pattāsanaṃ atikkamitvā navakānaṃ pāpuṇanaṭṭhāne nisīdati, ayaṃ nave bhikkhū🔽āsanena paṭibāhati nāma. Tasmiñhi tathā nisinne navā bhikkhū “amhākaṃ nisīdituṃ na
analyzed: yaḥ attanaḥ pattāsanam atikkamitvā navakānam pāpuṇana ṭhāne nisīdati ayam nave bhikkhū  āsanena paṭibāhati nāma tasmin hi tathā nisinne navāḥ bhikkhū amhākam nisīditum na
translated: “I will not bar” means that if he sits down in a place reserved for the more junior monks, he bars the more junior monks.🔽For if he sits down there, the more junior monks think, “He will not give us a seat,” and they stand about grumbling or go looking for another seat.

original: detī”ti ujjhāyantā tiṭṭhanti vā āsanaṃ vā pariyesantā āhiṇḍanti. Tasmā attano pattāsaneyeva
analyzed: deti iti ujjhāyantā tiṭṭhanti vā āsanam vā pariyesantā āhiṇḍanti tasmai
translated: So he should sit down in the place reserved for himself.

original: nisīditabbaṃ. Evaṃ na paṭibāhati nāma.
analyzed: nisīditabbam evam na paṭibāhati nāma
translated: That is called “not barring.”🔽“The rules concerning proper conduct”: the mere practice of proper conduct.

original: Ābhisamācārikampi dhammanti abhisamācārikaṃ vattapaṭipattimattampi. Nātikālenāti
analyzed: ābhisamācārikam pi dhammanti abhisamācārikam vatta paṭipattimattam pi na ati kālena ati
translated: “Not too long”:

original: na atipāto pavisitabbaṃ, na atidivā paṭikkamitabbaṃ, bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃyeva
analyzed: na atipāto pavisitabbam na atidivā paṭikkamitabbam bhikkhu saṅghena saddhiṃ yeva
translated: He should not enter too early, nor should he return too late, but he should do so🔽together with the Sangha of monks.

original: pavisitabbañca nikkhamitabbañca. Atipāto pavisitvā atidivā nikkhamantassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattādīni
analyzed: pavisitabbam ca nikkhamitabbam ca atipāto pavisitvā atidivā nikkhamantassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇa bodhiyaṅgaṇa vatta ādīni
translated: He should not enter too early and leave too late. He should enter and leave together with the Sangha of monks. If he enters too early and leaves too late, the shrine terrace and the Bodhi tree terrace will be neglected.

original: parihāyanti. Kālasseva mukhaṃ dhovitvā makkaṭakasuttāni chindantena ussāvabindū nipātentena🔽gāmaṃ pavisitvā yāguṃ pariyesitvā yāva bhikkhākālā antogāmeyeva nānappakāraṃ tiracchānakathaṃ
analyzed: parihāyanti kālassa iva mukham dhovitvā makkaṭaka suttāni chindantena ussāva bindū nipātentena  gāmam pavisitvā yāgum pariyesitvā yāva bhikkhā kālāḥ nānappakāram tiracchāna katham
translated: After washing his face early, he should cut the grass and remove the dew.🔽After entering the village, he should look for rice porridge. While waiting for the mealtime, he should sit in the village and talk on all sorts of worldly topics.

original: kathentena nisīditvā bhattakiccaṃ katvā divā nikkhamma bhikkhūnaṃ pādadhovanavelāya
analyzed: kathentena nisīditvā bhatta kiccam katvā divā nikkhamma bhikkhūnam pāda dhovana velāya
translated: After eating his meal, he should leave in the day and return to the monastery in the evening, at the time for washing the feet of the monks.

original: vihāraṃ paccāgantabbaṃ hoti. Na purebhattaṃ pacchābhattaṃ kulesu cārittaṃ āpajjitabbanti
analyzed: vihāram paccāgantabbam hoti na purebhattam pacchābhattam kulesu cārittam āpajjitabbanti
translated: He should not visit families before or after the meal.

original: “yo pana bhikkhu nimantito sabhatto samāno santaṃ bhikkhuṃ anāpucchā purebhattaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ pana bhikkhu nimantito sabhattaḥ samāno santam bhikkhum anāpucchā purebhattam
translated: ‘If a monk who has been invited to a meal, while eating fresh food, visits families beforehand or afterwards without informing an available monk, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.

original: vā pacchābhattaṃ vā kulesu cārittaṃ āpajjeyya, aññatra samayā pācittiya”nti imaṃ
analyzed: vā pacchābhattam vā kulesu cārittam āpajjeyya aññatra samayā pācittiyanti imaṃ
translated: If he should do so, then except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”

original: sikkhāpadaṃ rakkhantena tassa vibhaṅge vuttaṃ purebhattañca pacchābhattañca cārittaṃ
analyzed: sikkhāpadam rakkhantena tassa vibhaṅge vuttam purebhattam ca pacchābhattam ca cārittam
translated: In order to keep this training rule, he should not do any of the following:🔽He should not do any of the following:

original: na āpajjitabbaṃ. Uddhato hoti capaloti uddhaccapakatiko ceva hoti cīvaramaṇḍana-pattamaṇḍana-senāsanamaṇḍanā
analyzed: na āpajjitabbam uddhataḥ hoti capalaḥ iti uddhacca pakatiko ca iva hoti cīvara maṇḍana patta maṇḍana senāsana maṇḍanā
translated: He is restless and puffed up: he is by nature restless and puffed up. He adorns his bedding and seat, he adorns his bowl, he adorns his dwelling,

original: imassa vā pūtikāyassa kelāyanā maṇḍanāti evaṃ vuttena ca taruṇadārakāvacāpalyena samannāgato.🔽Paññavatā bhavitabbanti cīvarakammādīsu itikattabbesu upāyapaññāya samannāgatena🔽bhavitabbaṃ. Abhidhamme abhivinayeti abhidhammapiṭake ceva vinayapiṭake ca pāḷivasena
analyzed: imassa vā pūti kāyassa kelāyanā maṇḍanā ti evam vuttena ca taruṇa dāraka avacāpalyena samannāgataḥ  paññavatā bhavitabbanti cīvara kamma ādīsu itikattabbesu upāya paññāya samannāgatena  bhavitabbam abhidhamme abhivinaye ti abhidhamma piṭake ca iva vinaya piṭake ca pāḷi vasena
translated: he adorns his body, he adorns his speech. He is like a young tender child in his restlessness and his being puffed up.🔽He should be wise: he should be endowed with the skillfulness of what is to be done in regard to robe-making and so on.🔽In the Teaching and the Monastic Law: he should apply himself to the Tipiṭaka by heart and to the commentaries.

original: ceva aṭṭhakathāvasena ca yogo karaṇīyo. Sabbantimena hi paricchedena abhidhamme dukatikamātikāhi
analyzed: ca iva aṭṭhakathā vasena ca yogo karaṇīyo sabba antimena hi paricchedena abhidhamme
translated: In all: he should apply himself to the Tipiṭaka by heart and to the commentaries.

original: saddhiṃ dhammahadayavibhaṅgaṃ vinā na vaṭṭati. Vinaye pana kammākammavinicchayena
analyzed: saddhim dhamma hadaya vibhaṅgam vinā na vaṭṭati vinaye pana kamma akamma vinicchayena
translated: and the Dhamma-body analysis.🔽In the Vinaya, the two Patimokkhas are well analyzed with the analysis of the legal issues.

original: saddhiṃ suvinicchitāni dve pātimokkhāni vinā na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: saddhim su vinicchitāni dve pātimokkhāni vinā na vaṭṭati
translated: Without these, it is not possible.🔽The eight attainments are mentioned up to the “formless” .

original: Āruppāti ettāvatā aṭṭhapi samāpattiyo vuttā honti. Tā pana sabbena sabbaṃ asakkontena
analyzed: āruppā ti ettāvatā aṭṭha api samāpattiyaḥ vuttāḥ honti tāḥ pana sabbena sabbam a sakkontena
translated: But if one is unable to do all of them,🔽one should practice with seven, with six, with five.

original: sattasupi yogo karaṇīyo, chasupi…pe… pañcasupi. Sabbantimena paricchedena ekaṃ kasiṇe
analyzed: satta supi yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ cha supi pe pañca supi sabba antimena paricchedena ekam kasiṇe
translated: One should take one kasiṇa,

analyzed: parikamma kammaṭṭhānam paguṇam katvā ādāya vicaritabbam ettakam vinā na vaṭṭati

original: Uttarimanussadhammeti iminā sabbepi lokuttaradhamme dasseti. Tasmā arahantena hutvā🔽vihātabbaṃ, arahattaṃ anabhisambhuṇantena anāgāmiphale sakadāgāmiphale sotāpattiphale
analyzed: uttari manussa dhamme ti iminā sabbe api lokuttara dhamme dasseti tasmai arahantena hutvā  vihātabbam arahattam an abhisambhuṇantena anāgāmi phale sakadāgāmi phale sa utāpatti phale
translated: Therefore one should live as an arahant,🔽and if one is unable to reach arahantship, one should be established in the fruition of non-return, in the fruition of once-return, or in the fruition of stream-entry.

original: vā patiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Sabbantimena pariyāyena ekaṃ vipassanāmukhaṃ yāva arahattā paguṇaṃ
analyzed: vā patiṭṭhātabbam sabbantimena pariyāyena ekam vipassanā mukham yāva arahattā paguṇam
translated: One should make one of the insight meditation subjects familiar up to the stage of arahantship.

original: katvā ādāya vicaritabbaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānameva. Imaṃ pana desanaṃ āyasmā sāriputto
analyzed: katvā ādāya vicaritabbam sesam sabbattha uttānam eva imam pana desanam āyasmā sāriputto
translated: and having done so, he should carry it along with him. The rest is clear throughout. But the venerable Sāriputta

analyzed: neyya puggalassa vasena ābhisamācārika vattataḥ paṭṭhāya anupubbena arahattam pāpetvā niṭṭhāpesi iti
translated: brought this exposition to a conclusion by gradually establishing the person to be trained in the higher virtue, etc., up to arahatship.🔽The Commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya,

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: the Great Book of the Woods,

analyzed: goliyāni sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 10. Kīṭāgirisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse at Kīṭāgiri

original: 174. Evaṃ me sutanti kīṭāgirisuttaṃ. Tattha kāsīsūti evaṃnāmake janapade. Etha tumhepi,
analyzed: evam me sutam ti kīṭāgiri suttam tattha kāsīsu iti evaṃnāmake janapade tumhe api
translated: “Thus have I heard” . The Discourse at Kīṭāgiri . Herein, in the country named Kāsī : come, bhikkhus,

analyzed: bhuñjatha iti bhagavā rattim vikāla bhojanam divā imāni dve bhojanāni

original: ekappahārena ajahāpetvā ekasmiṃ samaye divā vikālabhojanameva jahāpesi, puna kālaṃ
analyzed: eka pahārena a jahāpetvā ekasmin samaye divā vikāla bhojanam eva jahāpesi puna kālam
translated: at one time made them give up only meals out of the proper time by day, and again at another time

original: atināmetvā rattiṃ vikālabhojanaṃ jahāpento evamāha. Kasmā? Imāni hi dve bhojanāni
analyzed: rattim vikāla bhojanam evam āha kasmai imāni hi dve bhojanāni
translated: and after making them go beyond the night, he had them give up eating at the wrong time, saying this. Why? Because these two kinds of food

analyzed: vattamānāni vaṭṭe āciṇṇāni samāciṇṇāni nadim otiṇṇa odakam viya an upakkhandāni nivātesu
translated: are habitual in the round of rebirths, are well-practised, and are not interrupted like water that has entered a river, and they are increased by eating good food in windless

original: ca gharesu subhojanāni bhuñjitvā vaḍḍhitā sukhumālā kulaputtā dve bhojanāni ekappahārena
analyzed: ca gharesu su bhojanāni bhuñjitvā vaḍḍhitā sukhumālā kula puttā dve bhojanāni eka ppahārena
translated: houses. Young men of good families who give up the two kinds of food all at once

original: pajahantā kilamanti. Tasmā ekappahārena ajahāpetvā bhaddālisutte divā vikālabhojanaṃ
analyzed: pajahantā kilamanti tasmai eka pahārena a jahāpetvā bhaddāli sutte divā vikāla bhojanam
translated: are exhausted. Therefore, after not having them give them up all at once, in the Bhaddekaratta Sutta he had them give up eating at the wrong time by day,

analyzed: jahāpesi idha rattim vikāla bhojanam jahāpento pana na tajjitvā vā niggaṇhitvā vā
translated: and here he had them give up eating at the wrong time by night. But when he had them give it up, he did not do so by frightening them or by restraining them,

original: tesaṃ pahānapaccayā pana appābādhatañca sañjānissathāti evaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ dassetvāva
analyzed: tesam pahāna paccayā pana appa ābādha tañca sañjānissatha ati evam ānisaṃsam dassetvā ava

original: jahāpesi. Kīṭāgirīti tassa nigamassa nāmaṃ.
analyzed: tassa nigamassa nāmam
translated: he had them give it up. Kīṭāgiri is the name of that market town.

original: 175. Assajipunabbasukāti assaji ca punabbasuko ca chasu chabbaggiyesu dve gaṇācariyā.
analyzed: assaji punabbasukā ati assaji ca punabbasukaḥ ca chasu chabbaggiyesu dve gaṇa ācariyā
translated: Assaji and Punabbasuka: two chief disciples among the six groups of six.

original: Paṇḍuko lohitako mettiyo bhummajako assaji punabbasukoti ime cha janā chabbaggiyā
analyzed: paṇḍukaḥ lohitakaḥ mettiyaḥ bhummajakaḥ assaji punabbasukaḥ iti ime cha janāḥ chabbaggiyāḥ
translated: Paṇḍuka, Lohitaka, Mettiya, Bhummajaka, Assaji, and Punabbasuka: these six persons are called the group-of-six.

original: nāma. Tesu paṇḍukalohitakā attano parisaṃ gahetvā sāvatthiyaṃ vasanti, mettiyabhummajakā
analyzed: nāma tesu paṇḍuka lohitakāḥ attano parisam gahetvā sāvatthiyam vasanti mettiya bhummajakā
translated: Of these, the Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka, taking their own retinue, lived in Sāvatthi, the Mettiya and Bhummajaka

analyzed: rājagahe ime dve janā kīṭāgirismiṃ āvāsikāḥ honti āvāsikā ati nibaddha vāsinaḥ taṃnibandhā
translated: lived in Rājagaha, and these two persons were residents in Kīṭāgiri. Residents means those who live permanently, and they are

original: akataṃ senāsanaṃ karonti, jiṇṇaṃ paṭisaṅkharonti, kate issarā honti. Kālikanti anāgate
analyzed: a katam senāsanam karonti jiṇṇam paṭisaṅkharonti kate issarāḥ honti anāgate

analyzed: kāle pattabbam ānisaṃsam

original: 178. Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhaveti idha kiṃ dasseti? Bhikkhave, divasassa tayo vāre bhuñjitvā🔽sukhavedanaṃyeva uppādento na imasmiṃ sāsane kiccakārī nāma hoti, ettakā pana vedanā
analyzed: mayā ca itam bhikkhave iti idha kim dasseti bhikkhave divasassa tayaḥ vāre bhuñjitvā  sukha vedanaṃyā iva uppādentaḥ na imasmin sāsane kiccakārī nāma hoti ettakā pana vedanā
translated: . “Monks, this was said by me”: what does this show here? Monks, by producing only pleasant feeling after eating three times a day,🔽one is not a doer of what should be done in this Dispensation. But how many feelings

analyzed: sevitabbā ettakā na sevitabbā ti etam attham dassetum imam desanam ārabhi evarūpam
translated: should be cultivated, and how many should not be cultivated? In order to show this meaning, this teaching was begun. Such a person

analyzed: sukha vedanam pajahatha ati idam ca geha ssita somanassa vasena vuttam upasampajja viharatha ati  idam ca nekkhamma sita somanassa vasena itas paresu pi dvīsu vāresu gehassita nekkhamma sitānam yeva
translated: And abandon happiness : this is said with reference to the happiness of worldliness. And enter upon and abide in :

analyzed: domanassānam ca upekkhānam ca vasena atthaḥ veditabbo  evam sevitabba asevitabba vedanam dassetvā idāni yesam appamādena kiccam kattabbam

In the next two instances the meaning should be understood in terms of the world-transcendent and world-transcendent-cum-worldly kinds of grief and equanimity respectively.🔽Having thus shown the kinds of feeling to be cultivated and not to be cultivated, the Exalted One now says “Monks, I do not call him a man of wisdom” in order to show who should and should not perform his duties with diligence.

original: yesañca na kattabbaṃ, te dassetuṃ nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbesaṃyevātiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: yesam ca na kattabbam te dassetum na aham bhikkhave sabbesam yeva āti ādim āha tattha
translated: Herein,

original: kataṃ tesaṃ appamādenāti tesaṃ yaṃ appamādena kattabbaṃ, taṃ kataṃ. Anulomikānīti
analyzed: katam tesam appamādena ati tesam yat appamādena kattabbam tat katam anulomikāni iti
translated: he has done what should be done with diligence : he has done what should be done with diligence. Conducive :

original: paṭipattianulomāni kammaṭṭhānasappāyāni, yattha vasantena sakkā honti maggaphalāni
analyzed: paṭipatti anulomāni kammaṭṭhāna sappāyāni yattha vasantena sakkā honti magga phalāni

translated: Bringing the spiritual faculties into alignment : making the spiritual faculties of faith, etc., even.

analyzed: sattime bhikkhave puggalā ati idha kim dasseti yesam appamādena karaṇīyam natthi
translated: 182. What does the text “Seven kinds of persons, bhikkhus” show?🔽Those who have no need to be diligent

analyzed: te dve honti yesam atthi te pañca ati evam sabbe pi ime satta puggalāḥ honti iti imam attham dasseti

analyzed: tattha ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti dvīhi bhāgehi vimuttaḥ arūpa samāpattiyāḥ rūpa kāyataḥ vimuttaḥ

analyzed: maggena nāmakāyato so catunnam arūpa samāpattīnam ekekataḥ vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā

analyzed: puggalaḥ aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā viharati paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā 🔽honti iti evam abhidhamme aṭṭha vimokkha lābhinaḥ vasena āgatā
translated: … touches with his body and abides in the eight deliverances, and his taints are destroyed by seeing with understanding” .

analyzed: paññā vimutto ti paññāya vimutto so sukkha vipassako catūhi jhānehi vuṭṭhāya arahattam
