analyzed: pattā cattāro ca ati imesam vasena pañcavidhaḥ uva hoti pana ittha aṭṭha vimokkha paṭikkhepa vasena iva  āgatā yathā āha na ha iva kho aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā viharati paññāya ca ssa
translated: and he is of four kinds according to whether he has attained arahatship by means of the four jhānas. But in the text he is mentioned only as one who has emerged by means of the eight emancipations.

original: disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo paññāvimutto”ti.🔽Phuṭṭhantaṃ sacchikarotīti kāyasakkhī. Yo jhānaphassaṃ paṭhamaṃ phusati, pacchā nirodhaṃ
analyzed: disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti ayam vuccati puggalo paññā vimutto ti  phuṭṭhantam sacchikaroti iti kāya sakkhī yaḥ jhāna phassam paṭhamam phusati pacchā nirodham
translated: As it is said: “He does not abide having contacted with the body the eight emancipations, and his taints are destroyed by his seeing with wisdom. This is called a person liberated by wisdom” .

original: nibbānaṃ sacchikaroti, so sotāpattiphalaṭṭhaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattamaggaṭṭhā chabbidho🔽hontīti veditabbo. Tenevāha – “idhekacco puggalo aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā viharati,
analyzed: nibbānam sacchikaroti so sotāpatti phala ṭṭham ādim katvā yāva arahatta magga ṭṭhā chabbidhaḥ  honti iti veditabbaḥ tena iva āha idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā viharati
translated: “One who realizes by experiencing” : a body-witness. He who first experiences the jhāna-contact and afterwards realizes Nibbāna, the cessation, is of six kinds according to whether he has attained the fruit of stream-entry, and so on up to the path of arahatship.

original: paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo kāyasakkhī”ti.
analyzed: paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti ayam vuccati puggalo kāya sakkhī ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Here someone abides having contacted with his body the eight emancipations, and his taints are destroyed by his seeing with wisdom. This is called a person a body-witness” .

original: Diṭṭhantaṃ pattoti diṭṭhippatto. Tatridaṃ saṅkhepalakkhaṇaṃ – dukkhā saṅkhārā, sukho
analyzed: diṭṭhantam patto ti diṭṭhi ppatto tatra idam saṅkhepa lakkhaṇam dukkhā saṅkhārā sukho
translated: He has reached the seen, thus he is a “view-attainer” . Herein, the brief characteristic is this: “The formations are suffering,🔽the cessation of formations is bliss” .

original: nirodhoti ñātaṃ hoti diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phusitaṃ paññāyāti diṭṭhippatto.🔽Vitthārato panesopi kāyasakkhi viya chabbidho hoti. Tenevāha – “idhekacco puggalo
analyzed: nirodho ti ñātam hoti diṭṭham viditam sacchikatam phusitam paññāyāti diṭṭhi ppatto  vitthārato pana esaḥ api kāya sakkhi viya chabbidhaḥ hoti tena iva āha idha ekaccaḥ puggalo
translated: The detailed characteristic is this: “The formations are suffering, the cessation of the noble truth of suffering is bliss” , and so he knows, sees, is aware, is conscious, and touches with understanding, thus he is a “view-attainer” .

original: idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti…pe… ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam
translated: But in detail he is of six kinds like the bodily witness. Hence it is said: “Here someone understands as it actually is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: pajānāti, tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā…pe… ayaṃ
analyzed: pajānāti tathāgata ppaveditā ca ssa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhāḥ honti ayaṃ
translated: The Tathāgata’s teachings are clear to him as they are being expounded by another. He has understood the teachings, remembered them, discussed them, investigated them with his mind, and well penetrated them theoretically.

original: vuccati puggalo diṭṭhippatto”ti.🔽Saddhāvimuttoti saddhāya vimutto. Sopi vuttanayeneva chabbidho hoti. Tenevāha – “idhekacco
analyzed: vuccati puggalaḥ diṭṭhi ppatto ti  saddhā vimuttaḥ ti saddhāya vimuttaḥ saḥ api vutta nayena iva chabbidhaḥ hoti tena iva āha idha ekacco
translated: He is called a person who has attained to view” .

original: puggalo idaṃ dukkhanti – yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti…pe… ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti
analyzed: puggalaḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: Liberated in faith: liberated by means of faith . He too is of six kinds in the way already stated. Hence it is said: “Here someone understands as it actually is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā…pe…
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti tathāgata ppaveditā ca assa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: He has no doubt or uncertainty that the Tathāgata is perfectly enlightened, that he teaches the Dhamma, that the Sangha practices the good way.

original: no ca kho yathā diṭṭhippattassa. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo saddhāvimutto”ti. Etesu hi
analyzed: no ca kho yathā diṭṭhi ppattassa ayam vuccati puggalo saddhā vimutto ti etesu hi
translated: But he has not yet attained a stage of perfection. This is called a person liberated by faith.

original: saddhāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggakkhaṇe saddahantassa viya okappentassa viya adhimuccantassa
analyzed: saddhā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga kkhaṇe saddahantassa viya okappentassa viya adhimuccantassa
translated: For in the case of one liberated by faith, the destruction of defilements takes place as though by faith, as though by resolve, as though by appreciation,

original: viya ca kilesakkhayo hoti, diṭṭhippattassa pubbabhāgamaggakkhaṇe kilesacchedakañāṇaṃ🔽adandhaṃ tikhiṇaṃ sūraṃ hutvā vahati. Tasmā yathā nāma nātitikhiṇena asinā kadaliṃ
analyzed: viya ca kilesa kkhayaḥ hoti diṭṭhi ppattassa pubbabhāga magga kkhaṇe kilesa chedaka ñāṇam  adandham tikhiṇam sūram hutvā vahati tasmai yathā nāma na atitikhiṇena asinā kadalim
translated: as though by confirmation. In the case of one attained to vision, the knowledge that destroys defilements

original: chindantassa chinnaṭṭhānaṃ na maṭṭhaṃ hoti, asi na sīghaṃ vahati, saddo suyyati,
analyzed: chindantassa chinna ṭṭhānam na maṭṭham hoti asi na sīgham vahati saddaḥ suyyati
translated: is sharp, keen, strong, hard, and solid. Therefore, just as when one cuts a plantain tree with a very blunt knife, the place cut is not clean, the knife does not move easily, there is a great deal of resistance, and a sound is heard,

original: balavataro vāyāmo kātabbo hoti, evarūpā saddhāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggabhāvanā.
analyzed: balavataraḥ vāyāmaḥ kātabbaḥ hoti evarūpā saddhā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga bhāvanā
translated: so too is the development of the path in the case of one liberated by faith.

original: Yathā pana nisitaasinā kadaliṃ chindantassa chinnaṭṭhānaṃ maṭṭhaṃ hoti, asi sīghaṃ
analyzed: yathā pana nisita asinā kadalim chindantassa chinna ṭhānam maṭṭham hoti asi sīgham
translated: But just as when one cuts a plantain tree with a sharp knife, the place cut is clean, the knife moves easily,

original: vahati, saddo na suyyati, balavavāyāmakiccaṃ na hoti, evarūpā paññāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggabhāvanā veditabbā.
analyzed: vahati saddaḥ na balava vāyāma kiccam na hoti evarūpā paññā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga bhāvanā veditabbā
translated: He is not able to carry out the task of strenuous effort. This is how the development of the path in the prior stage should be understood in the case of one liberated by understanding.

original: Dhammaṃ anussaratīti dhammānusārī. Dhammoti paññā, paññāpubbaṅgamaṃ maggaṃ bhāvetīti
analyzed: dhammaṃ anussarati iti dhamma anusārī dhammo ti paññā paññā pubbaṅgamam maggam bhāveti iti
translated: One who recollects the True Idea is a Dhamma-follower. The True Idea is understanding. The meaning is that he develops the path preceded by understanding.

original: attho. Saddhānusārimhi ca eseva nayo. Ubho panete sotāpattimaggaṭṭhāyeva. Vuttampi
analyzed: attho saddhā anusārimhi ca esa iva nayaḥ ubho pana ete sotāpatti magga ṭṭhāya iva vuttam pi
translated: And the same explanation applies in the case of one a Faith-follower. But both these kinds of persons are only candidates for the first path. For this is said:

original: cetaṃ – “yassa puggalassa sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa paññindriyaṃ
analyzed: yassa puggalassa sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa paññindriyam
translated: “When a person is practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry, if his understanding faculty is outstanding,

original: adhimattaṃ hoti, paññāvāhiṃ paññāpubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo
analyzed: adhimattam hoti paññā vāhim paññā pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti ayam vuccati puggalo
translated: he develops the noble path preceded by understanding and led by understanding. This person is called

original: dhammānusārī”ti. Tathā – “yassa puggalassa sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa
analyzed: dhamma anusārī iti tathā yassa puggalassa sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa
translated: a Dhamma-follower” . And: “When a person is practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry,

original: saddhindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ hoti, saddhāvāhiṃ saddhāpubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti.
analyzed: saddhā indriyam adhimattam hoti saddhā vāhim saddhā pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti
translated: if his faith faculty is outstanding, he develops the noble path preceded by faith and led by faith.

original: Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo saddhānusārī”ti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato panesā ubhatobhāgavimuttādikathā
analyzed: ayam vuccati puggalo saddhā anusārī iti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana isā ubhatobhāga vimutta ādi kathā
translated: This is called a person following faith” . This is the brief treatment here. But the detailed treatment of the kind of person liberated-in-both-ways, etc.,

original: visuddhimagge paññābhāvanādhikāre vuttā. Tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Yā🔽panesā etesaṃ vibhāgadassanatthaṃ idha pāḷi āgatā, tattha yasmā rūpasamāpattiyā vinā
analyzed: visuddhi magge paññā bhāvanā adhikāre vuttā tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbā yā  pana isā etesam vibhāga dassana attham idha āgatā tattha yasmā rūpa samāpattiyā vinā
translated: is given in the Path of Purification in the chapter on the development of understanding, so it should be understood there .

original: arūpasamāpattiyo nāma natthi, tasmā āruppāti vuttepi aṭṭha vimokkhā vuttāva hontīti veditabbā.
analyzed: arūpa samāpattiyaḥ nāma natthi tasmai āruppā ti vutte pi aṭṭha vimokkhāḥ vuttā ava honti iti veditabbā
translated: But as to the text here given in order to show the division of these kinds of persons, it should be understood that although the words “the immaterial” are mentioned, still the eight emancipations are meant.

original: Kāyena phusitvāti sahajātanāmakāyena phusitvā. Paññāya cassa disvāti paññāya ca etassa🔽ariyasaccadhamme disvā. Ekacce āsavāti paṭhamamaggādīhi pahātabbā ekadesaāsavā. Tathāgatappaveditāti
analyzed: kāyena phusitvā ati sahajāta nāmakāyena phusitvā paññāya ca assa disvā ati paññāya ca etassa  ariya sacca dhamme disvā ekacce āsavā ati paṭhama magga ādīhi pahātabbā eka desa āsavā tathāgata ppaveditā ti
translated: “Has touched with his body and realized”: has touched with his body that is associated with the attainment and realized it. “And seen with understanding”: and seen it with understanding.

original: tathāgatena paveditā catusaccadhammā. Paññāya vodiṭṭhā hontīti imasmiṃ ṭhāne sīlaṃ
analyzed: tathāgatena paveditā catu sacca dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhāḥ honti iti imasmim ṭhāne sīlam
translated: “Some defilements”: some defilements that are to be abandoned by the first path, etc. “The states of understanding announced by the Tathāgata”: the four noble truths announced by the Tathāgata. “Are seen with understanding”: at this point virtue is

original: kathitaṃ, imasmiṃ samādhi, imasmiṃ vipassanā, imasmiṃ maggo, imasmiṃ phalanti evaṃ
analyzed: kathitam imasmin samādhi imasmin vipassanā imasmin maggo imasmin phalanti evam
translated: “This is concentration, this is insight, this is the path, this is fruition” .

original: atthena atthe kāraṇena kāraṇe ciṇṇacaritattā maggapaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti. Vocaritāti
analyzed: atthena atthe kāraṇena kāraṇe ciṇṇa carita ttā magga paññāya su diṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: So they are well seen by the path knowledge of the one who has practised in this way in regard to meaning by means of meaning, in regard to phrasing by means of phrasing.🔽“Has frequented” : has frequented.

original: vicaritā. Saddhā niviṭṭhā hotīti okappanasaddhā patiṭṭhitā hoti. Mattaso nijjhānaṃ
analyzed: vicaritā saddhā niviṭṭhā hoti iti okappana saddhā patiṭṭhitā hoti mattasaḥ nijjhānam
translated: “Faith is well placed” : faith consisting in resolve is established.🔽“They are content with just looking” : they are content with just seeing.

original: khamantīti mattāya olokanaṃ khamanti. Saddhāmattanti saddhāyeva, itaraṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ
analyzed: khamanti iti mattāya olokanam khamanti saddhā mattanti saddhāya iva itaram tassa iva vevacanam
translated: “Faith alone” : faith itself, the other is a synonym for it.

original: Iti imesu appamādena karaṇīyesu puggalesu tayo paṭividdhamaggaphalā sekhā. Tesu anulomasenāsanaṃ
analyzed: iti imesu appamādena karaṇīyesu puggalesu tayo paṭividdha magga phalā sekhā tesu anuloma senāsanam
translated: So of these persons who should be made to practise with diligence, three have penetrated the path and fruition and are in training.

original: sevamānā kalyāṇamitte bhajamānā indriyāni samannānayamānā anupubbena arahattaṃ gaṇhanti.
analyzed: sevamānā kalyāṇa mitte bhajamānā indriyāni samannānayamānā anupubbena arahattam gaṇhanti
translated: Of these, one who frequents the right places, associates with good people, and exerts the faculties, eventually reaches Arahantship.🔽So the meaning of the text is as stated.

original: Tasmā tesaṃ yathāṭhitova pāḷiattho. Avasāne pana dve sotāpattimaggasamaṅgino. Tehi
analyzed: tasmā tesam yathā ṭhitaḥ uva avasāne pana dve sotāpatti magga samaṅgino tehi
translated: But at the end there are two who possess the stream-entry path.

original: tassa maggassa anulomasenāsanaṃ sevitaṃ, kalyāṇamittā bhajitā, indriyāni samannānītāni.
analyzed: tassa maggassa anuloma senāsanam sevitam kalyāṇa mittāḥ bhajitāḥ indriyāni samannānītāni
translated: For them the path has been frequented by the right places, etc.,

original: Upari pana tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ atthāya sevamānā bhajamānā samannānayamānā anupubbena🔽arahattaṃ pāpuṇissantīti ayamettha pāḷiattho.
analyzed: upari pana tiṇṇam maggānam atthāya sevamānā bhajamānā samannānayamānā anupubbena  arahattam pāpuṇissanti iti ayam ettha pāḷi atthaḥ
translated: But when they are cultivated, developed, and repeatedly practiced, they will eventually reach Arahantship. This is the meaning of the text.

original: Vitaṇḍavādī pana imameva pāḷiṃ gahetvā – “lokuttaramaggo na ekacittakkhaṇiko, bahucittakkhaṇiko”ti
analyzed: vitaṇḍa vādī pana imam eva pāḷim gahetvā lokuttara maggaḥ na eka citta khaṇikaḥ bahu citta kkhaṇikaḥ ti
translated: But the theorist, taking this very text, says: “The supramundane path is not momentary; it is of many moments.”

original: vadati. So vattabbo – “yadi aññena cittena senāsanaṃ paṭisevati, aññena kalyāṇamitte🔽bhajati, aññena indriyāni samannāneti, aññaṃ maggacittanti sandhāya tvaṃ ‘na ekacittakkhaṇiko🔽maggo, bahucittakkhaṇiko’ti vadasi, evaṃ sante senāsanaṃ sevamāno nīlobhāsaṃ pabbataṃ🔽passati, vanaṃ passati, migapakkhīnaṃ saddaṃ suṇāti, pupphaphalānaṃ gandhaṃ ghāyati,
analyzed: vadati saḥ vattabbaḥ yadi aññena cittena senāsanam paṭisevati aññena kalyāṇa mitte  bhajati aññena indriyāni samannāneti aññam magga cittan ti sandhāya tvam na eka citta kkhaṇikaḥ  maggaḥ bahu cittakkhaṇikaḥ iti vadasi evam sante senāsanam sevamānaḥ nīlobhāsam pabbatam  passati vanam passati miga pakkhīnam saddam suṇāti puppha phalānam gandham ghāyati
translated: He should be asked to explain the meaning of the words “cultivated, developed, and repeatedly practiced.” If he replies that the path is cultivated, developed, and repeatedly practiced by one who resorts to a lodging, associates with good friends, regulates his conduct by the precepts,

original: pānīyaṃ pivanto rasaṃ sāyati, nisīdanto nipajjanto phassaṃ phusati. Evaṃ te pañcaviññāṇasamaṅgīpi
analyzed: pānīyam pivantaḥ rasam sāyati nisīdantaḥ nipajjantaḥ phassam phusati evam te pañca viññāṇa samaṅgīpi
translated: and generates the right states of consciousness, he should be told: “You say that the path is not momentary but of many moments, referring to the fact that one resorts to a lodging with one kind of consciousness, associates with good friends with another kind of consciousness, regulates one’s conduct by the precepts with still another kind of consciousness, and generates the right states of consciousness with yet another kind of consciousness. If that is so, then when one resorts to a lodging, one sees the blue-gleaming mountain, one sees the forest, one hears the sounds of the animals and birds, one smells the scent of the flowers and fruits, one tastes the water one drinks, one touches the bed one lies on, and one cognizes the various objects with the mind. In that case, one who is endowed with the five-sense consciousnesses

original: lokuttaradhammasamaṅgīyeva bhavissati. Sace panetaṃ sampaṭicchasi, satthārā saddhiṃ
analyzed: lokuttara dhamma samaṅgīyā iva bhavissati sace pana etam sampaṭicchasi satthārā saddhim
translated: he will be possessed of supramundane states. But if you accept this, you are in conflict with the Master.

original: paṭivirujjhasi. Satthārā hi pañcaviññāṇakāyā ekantaṃ abyākatāva vuttā, taṃsamaṅgissa
analyzed: paṭivirujjhasi satthārā hi pañca viññāṇa kāyā ekantam abyākatā ava vuttā tad samaṅgissa
translated: For the Master has declared the five kinds of consciousness to be indeterminate only, and he has rejected the profitable and unprofitable in one who is possessed of them.

original: kusalākusalaṃ paṭikkhittaṃ, lokuttaramaggo ca ekantakusalo. Tasmā pajahetaṃ vāda”nti🔽paññapetabbo. Sace paññattiṃ na upagacchati, “gaccha pātova vihāraṃ pavisitvā yāguṃ
analyzed: kusala akusalam paṭikkhittam lokuttara maggo ca ekanta kusalo tasmā  paññapetabbo sace paññattim na upagacchati gaccha pātova vihāram pavisitvā yāgum
translated: And the supramundane path is profitable only. So abandon this view.”

original: pivāhī”ti uyyojetabbo.🔽183. Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādikenevāti ahaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamameva maṇḍūkassa uppatitvā
analyzed: pivāhi iti uyyojetabbo  na aham bhikkhave ādikena iva ati aham bhikkhave paṭhamam eva maṇḍūkassa uppatitvā
translated: If he does not accept the pronouncement, he should be told, “Go and drink rice porridge after entering the monastery tomorrow.”

original: gamanaṃ viya aññārādhanaṃ arahatte patiṭṭhānaṃ na vadāmi. Anupubbasikkhāti karaṇatthe
analyzed: gamanam viya añña ārādhanam arahatte patiṭṭhānam na vadāmi anupubba sikkhā ti karaṇa atthe
translated: “I do not say, bhikkhus, that final knowledge is attained by mere initial virtue”: I do not say that establishment in Arahantship is like a frog leaping from a well.

original: paccattavacanaṃ. Parato padadvayepi eseva nayo. Saddhājātoti okappaniyasaddhāya jātasaddho.
analyzed: paccatta vacanam paratas pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo saddhā jātaḥ ti okappa niya saddhāya jāta saddhaḥ
translated: “Gradual training”: the pronoun “that” refers to the action. The same method of explanation applies to the other two terms.🔽“Faith arisen”: faith arisen through confidence.

original: Upasaṅkamatīti garūnaṃ samīpaṃ gacchati. Payirupāsatīti santike nisīdati. Dhāretīti🔽sādhukaṃ katvā dhāreti. Chando jāyatīti kattukamyatākusalacchando jāyati. Ussahatīti🔽vīriyaṃ karoti. original: khandhānaṃ udayavayaṃ addasa, tasmā. Sabbamaññitānanti sabbesaṃ tiṇṇampi taṇhādiṭṭhimānamaññitānaṃ.

original: Mathitānanti tesaṃyeva vevacanaṃ. Idāni tāni vibhajitvā dassento sabbaahaṃkāra-mamaṃkāra-mānānusayānanti

analyzed: āha ettha hi ahaṃkāraḥ diṭṭhi mamaṃkāro taṇhā māna anusayaḥ māno anupādā vimutto ti

Why? For this one has the view of eternalism,

analyzed: vipassanā mattam a kathetvā samatha vipassanāḥ ācikkhi
translated: did not speak of insight alone but taught him serenity and insight.

original: 198. Sati satiāyataneti sati satikāraṇe. Kiñcettha kāraṇaṃ? Abhiññā vā abhiññāpādakajjhānaṃ vā avasāne pana arahattaṃ vā kāraṇaṃ arahattassa vipassanā vāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sati sati āyatane iti sati sati kāraṇe kiñca ittha kāraṇam abhiññā vā abhiññā pādaka jhānam vā avasāne pana arahattam vā kāraṇam arahattassa vipassanā vā ati veditabbam
translated: In the phrase “in the various objects of thought” , thought is the cause of mindfulness. What is the cause here? It is either the direct-knowledge or the jhāna that is the basis for direct-knowledge, or else the cause is Arahantship. But insight should be understood as the cause of Arahantship.

original: 200. Pariciṇṇo me bhagavāti satta hi sekhā bhagavantaṃ paricaranti nāma, khīṇāsavena
analyzed: pariciṇṇaḥ me bhagavā ati satta hi sekhāḥ bhagavantam paricaranti nāma khīṇāsavena
translated: “I have served the Blessed One” : the seven kinds of disciples in training are said to serve the Blessed One. But the Blessed One is served by the disciple who is free from cankers.

original: bhagavā pariciṇṇo hoti. Iti saṅkhepena arahattaṃ byākaronto thero evamāha. Te pana
analyzed: bhagavā pariciṇṇaḥ hoti iti saṅkhepena arahattam byākaronto theraḥ evam āha te pana
translated: Thus, in brief, the elder said this in order to declare his attainment of Arahantship.

original: bhikkhū tamatthaṃ na jāniṃsu, ajānantāva tassa vacanaṃ sampaṭicchitvā. Bhagavato
analyzed: bhikkhū tam attham na jāniṃsu a jānantā ava tassa vacanam sampaṭicchitvā bhagavataḥ
translated: The monks did not know the meaning of the words, and so they accepted them at his word. They reported the matter to the Exalted One.

original: ārocesuṃ. Devatāti tesaṃ guṇānaṃ lābhī devatā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: ārocesum devatā ati tesam guṇānam lābhī devatā sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: Devatā: deities who have attained those qualities. The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya, the Great Commentary,

original: Mahāvacchasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahāvaccha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 4. Dīghanakhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dīghanakha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Long-Nails Discourse

original: 201. Evaṃ me sutanti dīghanakhasuttaṃ. Tattha sūkarakhatāyanti sūkarakhatāti evaṃnāmake
analyzed: evam me sutanti dīgha nakha suttam tattha sūkarakhatāyanti sūkarakhatāti evaṃnāmake
translated: Thus I heard. This is the Long-Nails Discourse. Herein, in the pig’s cave means in a cave named the pig’s cave.

original: leṇe. Kassapabuddhakāle kira taṃ leṇaṃ ekasmiṃ buddhantare pathaviyā vaḍḍhamānāya🔽antobhūmigataṃ jātaṃ. Athekadivasaṃ eko sūkaro tassa chadanapariyantasamīpe paṃsuṃ
analyzed: leṇe kassapa buddha kāle kira tam leṇam ekasmin buddha antare pathaviyā vaḍḍhamānāya  antar bhūmi gatam jātam atha eka divasam ekaḥ sūkaro tassa chadana pariyanta samīpe paṃsum
translated: In the time of the Buddha Kassapa, it seems, when the earth was expanding,🔽that cave became situated inside the earth. Then one day a pig dug up the earth

original: khaṇi. Deve vuṭṭe paṃsudhoto chadanapariyanto pākaṭo ahosi. Eko vanacarako disvā
analyzed: deve vuṭṭe paṃsudhotaḥ chadana pariyanto pākaṭaḥ ahosi ekaḥ vana carakaḥ disvā
translated: near the edge of the roof of the cave. When the rain fell, the edge of the roof became visible, washed of its soil. A forest-dweller saw it🔽and thought, “This must be a cave used by those who were virtuous in the past. I shall look after it.” He cleared away the soil all round

original: – “pubbe sīlavantehi paribhuttaleṇena bhavitabbaṃ, paṭijaggissāmi na”nti samantato
analyzed: pubbe sīlavantehi paribhutta leṇena bhavitabbam paṭijaggissāmi samantataḥ
translated: and

original: paṃsuṃ apanetvā leṇaṃ sodhetvā kuṭṭaparikkhepaṃ katvā dvāravātapānaṃ yojetvā supariniṭṭhita-sudhākammacittakammarajatapaṭṭasadisāya
analyzed: paṃsum apanetvā leṇam sodhetvā kuṭṭa parikkhepam katvā dvāra vāta pānam yojetvā su pariniṭṭhita sudhā kamma citta kamma rajata paṭṭa sadisāya
translated: He had the rubbish removed, had the cave cleaned, had a wall built round it, had doors and windows made, and had the floor of the cave plastered with lime so well that it looked like a silver plate.

original: vālukāya santhatapariveṇaṃ leṇaṃ katvā mañcapīṭhaṃ paññāpetvā bhagavato vasanatthāya
analyzed: vālukāya santhata pariveṇam leṇam katvā mañca pīṭham paññāpetvā bhagavataḥ vasana tthāya
translated: He had the cave surrounded with a verandah, and he had a bed and chair placed there for the Blessed One to live in.

original: adāsi. Leṇaṃ gambhīraṃ ahosi otaritvā abhiruhitabbaṃ. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Dīghanakhoti tassa paribbājakassa nāmaṃ. Upasaṅkamīti kasmā upasaṅkami? So kira there
analyzed: adāsi leṇam gambhīram ahosi otaritvā abhiruhitabbam tam sandhāya itam vuttam  dīghanakhaḥ iti tassa paribbājakassa nāmam upasaṅkami iti kasmai upasaṅkami saḥ kira there
translated: The cave was deep, and one had to go down into it and then climb up. It was with reference to this that it was said.

original: aḍḍhamāsapabbajite cintesi – “mayhaṃ mātulo aññaṃ pāsaṇḍaṃ gantvā na ciraṃ tiṭṭhati,🔽idāni panassa samaṇassa gotamassa santikaṃ gatassa aḍḍhamāso jāto. Pavattimpissa
analyzed: aḍḍha māsa pabbajite cintesi mayham mātulaḥ aññam pāsaṇḍam gantvā na ciram tiṭṭhati  idāni panassa samaṇassa gotamassa santikam gatassa aḍḍha māsaḥ jātaḥ pavattimpissa
translated: Dīghanakha was the name of that wanderer. He approached: why did he approach? It seems that half a month after the Elders had gone forth, he thought, “My uncle, having gone to another sect, did not last long,🔽but now it is half a month since he went to the recluse Gotama. I hear no news of him.

original: na suṇāmi, ojavantaṃ nu kho sāsanaṃ, jānissāmi na”nti gantukāmo jāto. Tasmā upasaṅkami.
analyzed: na suṇāmi ojavantam nu kho sāsanam jānissāmi nanti gantu kāmaḥ jātaḥ tasmai upasaṅkami
translated: Is his doctrine vigorous or not? I will find out.” He was therefore eager to go, and that is why he approached.

original: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitoti tasmiṃ kira samaye thero bhagavantaṃ bījayamāno ṭhito hoti, paribbājako
analyzed: ekamantam ṭhitaḥ iti tasmin kira samaye theraḥ bhagavantam bījayamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ hoti paribbājako
translated: Standing at one side: it seems that at that time the Elder was standing there, fanning the Blessed One. The wanderer

original: mātule hirottappena ṭhitakova pañhaṃ pucchi. Tena vuttaṃ “ekamantaṃ ṭhito”ti.
analyzed: mātule hirottappena ṭhitakaḥ uva pañham pucchi tena vuttam eka mantam ṭhitaḥ ti
translated: stood there too, asking his question out of respect for his uncle. Hence it was said, “Standing at one side” .

original: Sabbaṃ me nakkhamatīti sabbā me upapattiyo nakkhamanti, paṭisandhiyo nakkhamantīti
analyzed: sabbam me nakkhamati iti sabbāḥ me upapattiyaḥ nakkhamanti paṭisandhiyaḥ nakkhamanti iti
translated: All is acceptable to me: all my rebirths are acceptable to me, all my rebirths are acceptable to me,

original: adhippāyena vadati. Ettāvatānena “ucchedavādohamasmī”ti dīpitaṃ hoti. Bhagavā panassa🔽adhippāyaṃ muñcitvā akkhare tāva dosaṃ dassento yāpi kho tetiādimāha. Tattha esāpi
analyzed: adhippāyena vadati ettāvatā anena uccheda vādaḥ ham asmi iti dīpitam hoti bhagavā pana ssa  adhippāyam muñcitvā akkhare tāva dosam dassentaḥ yā api kho tā iti ādim āha tattha esā api
translated: he says by implication. So far he has indicated that he is an annihilationist. But the Blessed One,

original: te diṭṭhi nakkhamatīti esāpi te paṭhamaṃ ruccitvā khamāpetvā gahitadiṭṭhi nakkhamatīti.
analyzed: te diṭṭhi na khamati iti esā api te paṭhamam ruccitvā khamāpetvā gahita diṭṭhi na khamati iti
translated: having understood his implication, first points out the fault in his words, saying, “But, Vaccha, this view of yours, too, is unacceptable to me.” Herein, this view of yours, too, is unacceptable to me: this view of yours, which you first approved of and then asked to be excused from, is unacceptable to me.

original: Esā ce me, bho gotama, diṭṭhi khameyyāti mayhañhi sabbaṃ nakkhamatīti diṭṭhi, tassa🔽mayhaṃ yā esā sabbaṃ me nakkhamatīti diṭṭhi, esā me khameyya. Yaṃ taṃ “sabbaṃ me
analyzed: esā ce me bho gotama diṭṭhi khameyya ati mayhan hi sabbam na khamati iti diṭṭhi tassa 🔽mayham yā esā sabbam me na khamati iti diṭṭhi esā me khameyya yam tam sabbam me
translated: If this view of mine is acceptable to you, Master Gotama: my view is that all is acceptable to me.🔽Therefore,

original: nakkhamatī”ti vuttaṃ, tampissa tādisameva. Yathā sabbagahaṇena gahitāpi ayaṃ diṭṭhi
analyzed: na khamati iti vuttam tam pissa tādisam eva yathā sabba gahaṇena gahitā api ayam
translated: and he says that it is acceptable, it is just the same.🔽

original: khamati, evamevaṃ tampi khameyya. Evaṃ attano vāde āropitaṃ dosaṃ ñatvā taṃ pariharāmīti🔽saññāya vadati, atthato panassa “esā diṭṭhi na me khamatī”ti āpajjati. Yassa panesā
analyzed: khamati evam evam tam pi khameyya evam vāde āropitam dosam ñatvā tam pariharāmi iti  saññāya vadati atthataḥ pana assa esā diṭṭhi na me khamati iti āpajjati yassa pana esā
translated: and he says, “It is acceptable to me,” then that is acceptable to him too. Just as this view is acceptable to him when it is taken in the sense of all-inclusive annihilation, so too it would be acceptable to him if it were taken in the sense of annihilation of the self. Thinking thus, “I am avoiding the fault that he attributes to my view,”

original: na khamati na ruccati, tassāyaṃ tāya diṭṭhiyā sabbaṃ me na khamatīti diṭṭhi rucitaṃ.
analyzed: na khamati na ruccati tassa ayam tāya diṭṭhiyā sabbam me na khamati iti diṭṭhi rucitam
translated: he says, “It is acceptable to me,” but in fact he is committed to the view, “That view is not acceptable to me.” But if he finds that view unacceptable and disagreeable, then he is committed to the view, “Nothing is acceptable to me.”

original: Tena hi diṭṭhiakkhamena arucitena bhavitabbanti sabbaṃ khamatīti ruccatīti āpajjati.
analyzed: tena hi diṭṭhi akkhamena a rucitena bhavitabbanti sabbam khamati iti ruccati iti āpajjati
translated: Since he finds that view unacceptable, he is committed to the view, “Everything is acceptable to me.”

original: Na panesa taṃ sampaṭicchati, kevalaṃ tassāpi ucchedadiṭṭhiyā ucchedameva gaṇhāti.
analyzed: na pana esa tam sampaṭicchati kevalam tassa api uccheda diṭṭhiyā ucchedam eva gaṇhāti
translated: But he does not accept that either. He takes only the annihilation of the self as the annihilation of the view.

original: Tenāha bhagavā ato kho te, aggivessana,…pe… aññañca diṭṭhiṃ upādiyantīti. Tattha
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā ato kho te aggivessanape aññañca diṭṭhim upādiyanti iti tattha
translated: Therefore the Exalted One said, “From that, Aggivessana, … and you take up another view” . Herein,

original: atoti pajahanakesu nissakkaṃ, ye pajahanti, tehi ye nappajahantīti vucciyanti, teva
analyzed: atas ti pajahanakesu nissakkam ye pajahanti tehi ye na ppajahanti iti te iva
translated: from that = from those who abandon. Those who do not abandon are said to be from those who abandon.

original: bahutarāti attho. Bahū hi bahutarāti ettha hikāro nipātamattaṃ, bahū bahutarāti attho.
analyzed: bahutarā iti atthaḥ bahū hi bahutarā ati ettha hikāraḥ nipāta mattam bahū bahutarā iti atthaḥ
translated: “More numerous” means “more.” For “more numerous” is a mere particle in the sense of “more.”🔽The same method applies to the words “less numerous” and “equal” in the following passages.

original: Parato tanū hi tanutarāti padepi eseva nayo. Ye evamāhaṃsūti ye evaṃ vadanti. Tañceva
analyzed: paratas hi tanutarā ati pade pi eṣā iva nayaḥ ye evam āhaṃsu iti ye evam vadanti tat ca iva
translated: “Those who say thus”: those who speak thus.

original: diṭṭhiṃ nappajahanti, aññañca diṭṭhiṃ upādiyantīti mūladassanaṃ nappajahanti, aparadassanaṃ upādiyanti.🔽Ettha ca sassataṃ gahetvā tampi appahāya ucchedaṃ vā ekaccasassataṃ vā gahetuṃ na🔽sakkā, ucchedampi gahetvā taṃ appahāya sassataṃ vā ekaccasassataṃ vā na sakkā gahetuṃ,
analyzed: diṭṭhim na ppajahanti aññañca diṭṭhim upādiyanti iti mūla dassanam na ppajahanti apara dassanam upādiyanti  ettha ca sassatam gahetvā tam pi appahāya ucchedam vā ekacca sassatam vā gahetum na  sakkā ucchedam pi gahetvā tam appahāya sassatam vā ekacca sassatam vā na sakkā gahetum
translated: “If they do not abandon that view and take up another view”: they do not abandon the view of the root, and they take up another view, a branch.🔽And here, having grasped eternalism, one cannot take up annihilationism or partial-eternalism without abandoning the former view.🔽Having grasped annihilationism, one cannot take up eternalism or partial-eternalism without abandoning the former view.

original: ekaccasassatampi gahetvā taṃ appahāya sassataṃ vā ucchedaṃ vā na sakkā gahetuṃ. Mūlasassataṃ
analyzed: ekacca sassatam pi gahetvā tam appahāya sassatam vā ucchedam vā na sakkā gahetum mūla sassatam
translated: Having grasped partial-eternalism, one cannot take up eternalism or annihilationism without abandoning the former view.

original: pana appahāya aññaṃ sassatameva sakkā gahetuṃ. Kathaṃ? Ekasmiñhi samaye “rūpaṃ sassata”nti
analyzed: pana a pahāya aññam sassatam eva sakkā gahetum katham ekasmin hi samaye rūpam sassatanti
translated: But having abandoned the root-eternalism, one can take up another form of eternalism. How? At one time one may think “form is eternal.”

original: gahetvā aparasmiṃ samaye “na suddharūpameva sassataṃ, vedanāpi sassatā, viññāṇampi🔽sassata”nti gaṇhāti. Ucchedepi ekaccasassatepi eseva nayo. Yathā ca khandhesu, evaṃ🔽āyatanesupi yojetabbaṃ. Idaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tañceva diṭṭhiṃ nappajahanti, aññañca
analyzed: gahetvā aparasmin samaye na suddha rūpam eva sassatam vedanā api sassatā viññāṇam pi  gaṇhāti ucchede pi ekacca sassate pi esa iva nayaḥ yathā ca khandhesu evam  āyatanesu pi yojetabbam idam sandhāya vuttam tat ca iva diṭṭhim na ppajahanti aññam ca
translated: and at another time he takes it that not only material form is eternal but also feeling,🔽perception, mental formations, and consciousness are eternal. The same method applies to the case of partial-eternalism and to the case of annihilationism. And as with the aggregates, so with the bases. It is with reference to this that it is said:🔽“They do not abandon that view, and they take up another view.🔽

original: diṭṭhiṃ upādiyantī”ti.🔽Dutiyavāre atoti appajahanakesu nissakkaṃ, ye nappajahanti, tehi, ye pajahantīti🔽vucciyanti, teva tanutarā appatarāti attho. Tañceva diṭṭhiṃ pajahanti, aññañca diṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhim upādiyanti iti  dutiya vāre atoti appajahanakesu nissakkam ye na pajahanti tehi ye pajahanti iti  te iva tanutarāḥ appatarā ti attho tam ca iva diṭṭhim pajahanti aññam ca diṭṭhim
translated: and at another time he takes it that not only material form but also feeling and consciousness are eternal. The same method applies in the case of annihilationism and in the case of partial-eternalism. And as with the aggregates, so with the bases. It is with reference to this that it is said: “They do not abandon that view and they take up another view” .

original: na upādiyantīti tañca mūladassanaṃ pajahanti, aññañca dassanaṃ na gaṇhanti. Kathaṃ?🔽Ekasmiñhi samaye “rūpaṃ sassata”nti gahetvā aparasmiṃ samaye tattha ādīnavaṃ disvā
analyzed: na upādiyanti iti tat ca mūla dassanam pajahanti aññam ca dassanam na gaṇhanti katham  ekasmin hi samaye rūpam gahetvā aparasmin samaye tattha ādīnavam disvā
translated: In the second section, “from that” refers to the non-abandonment. Those who do not abandon are said to “take up” . They are more subtle, less, i.e., inferior. “They abandon that view and they do not take up another view” : they abandon the view of the root and do not take up another view. How?

original: “oḷārikametaṃ mayhaṃ dassana”nti pajahati “na kevalañca rūpaṃ sassatanti dassanameva
analyzed: oḷārikam etam mayham dassananti pajahati na kevalam ca rūpam dassanam eva
translated: For at one time he takes material form to be eternal, and at another time, seeing the danger in that, he abandons it, thinking: “This view of mine is gross.” He does not take up another view, thinking: “Not only is the view that material form is eternal a gross view,

original: oḷārikaṃ, vedanāpi sassatā…pe… viññāṇampi sassatanti dassanaṃ oḷārikamevā”ti vissajjeti.
analyzed: oḷārikam vedanā api sassata āpe viññāṇam pi sassatanti dassanam oḷārikam eva ati vissajjeti
translated: “The view that material form is eternal is gross, and so is the view that feeling is eternal … that perception is eternal … that formations are eternal … that consciousness is eternal is gross.”

original: Ucchedepi ekaccasassatepi eseva nayo. Yathā ca khandhesu, evaṃ āyatanesupi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ucchede pi ekacca sassate pi esā iva nayaḥ yathā ca khandhesu evam āyatanesu pi yojetabbam
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the case of annihilationism and to the case of partial-eternalism. And the method should be extended also to the case of the bases.

original: Evaṃ tañca mūladassanaṃ pajahanti, aññañca dassanaṃ na gaṇhanti.🔽Santaggivessanāti kasmā ārabhi? Ayaṃ ucchedaladdhiko attano laddhiṃ nigūhati, tassā🔽pana laddhiyā vaṇṇe vuccamāne attano laddhiṃ pātukarissatīti tisso laddhiyo ekato
analyzed: evam tat ca mūla dassanam pajahanti aññam ca dassanam na gaṇhanti  kasmai ārabhi ayam uccheda laddhikaḥ attanaḥ laddhim nigūhati tassā  pana laddhiyāḥ vaṇṇe vuccamāne attanaḥ laddhim pātukarissati iti tissaḥ laddhiyaḥ ekatas
translated: “They abandon the view of a prior self and do not take up another view”:🔽Why did the Blessed One begin his teaching with the question, “What do you think, Aggivessana?”? This Aggivessana was a proponent of annihilationism, and he concealed his view. But when the Blessed One praised his view, he would reveal it.

original: dassetvā vibhajituṃ imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi.🔽Sārāgāya santiketiādīsu rāgavasena vaṭṭe rajjanassa āsannā taṇhādiṭṭhisaṃyojanena
analyzed: dassetvā vibhajitum imam desanam ārabhi  sa arāgāya santikā iti ādīsu rāga vasena vaṭṭe rajjanassa āsannā taṇhā diṭṭhi saṃyojanena
translated: Therefore the Blessed One began this teaching by showing the three views together and then distinguishing them.🔽In the passage beginning, “For the sake of passion for …,” the craving for the round of rebirths by way of passion is near to the fetter of craving and the fetter of views.

original: vaṭṭasaṃyojanassa santike. Abhinandanāyāti taṇhādiṭṭhivaseneva gilitvā pariyādiyanassa
analyzed: vaṭṭa saṃyojanassa santike abhinandanāya ati taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena iva gilitvā pariyādiyanassa
translated: The delighting is by way of craving and views. Having swallowed the round of rebirths, one relishes it.

original: gahaṇassa ca āsannāti attho. Asārāgāya santiketiādīsu vaṭṭe arajjanassa āsannātiādinā
analyzed: gahaṇassa ca āsannā iti atthaḥ asārāgāya santikā iti ādīsu vaṭṭe arajjanassa āsannā iti ādinā
translated: and it is near to the taking of it. In the case of the words “for non-greed, etc., to be” , etc., it is near to the non-greed, etc., of the round.

original: nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: and it is near to the taking up of lust. In the case of the phrases “for non- lust” and so on, the meaning should be understood in the way beginning, “It is near to non-greed” in the case of the wheel of kamma.🔽Herein, the view of eternalism is less blameworthy and slow to fade away,

original: Ettha ca sassatadassanaṃ appasāvajjaṃ dandhavirāgaṃ, ucchedadassanaṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ🔽khippavirāgaṃ. Kathaṃ? Sassatavādī hi idhalokaṃ paralokañca atthīti jānāti, sukatadukkaṭānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca sassata dassanam appa sāvajjam dandha virāgam uccheda dassanam mahā sāvajjam  khippa virāgam katham sassata vādī hi idha lokam para lokam ca atthi iti jānāti su kata dukkaṭānam
translated: and the view of annihilationism is more blameworthy and quick to fade away.

original: phalaṃ atthīti jānāti, kusalaṃ karoti, akusalaṃ karonto bhāyati, vaṭṭaṃ assādeti,🔽abhinandati. Buddhānaṃ vā buddhasāvakānaṃ vā sammukhībhūto sīghaṃ laddhiṃ jahituṃ
analyzed: phalam atthi iti jānāti kusalam karoti akusalam karontaḥ bhāyati vaṭṭam assādeti  abhinandati buddhānam vā buddha sāvakānam vā sammukhībhūtaḥ sīgham laddhim jahitum
translated: How so? The eternalist knows that there is this world and the next world, he knows that there is fruit of good and bad actions, he does what is wholesome, he is afraid of doing what is unwholesome, he delights in the round of rebirths, he is pleased with it.

original: na sakkoti. Tasmā taṃ sassatadassanaṃ appasāvajjaṃ dandhavirāganti vuccati. Ucchedavādī
analyzed: na sakkoti tasmai tam sassata dassanam appasāvajjam dandha virāgam ti vuccati uccheda vādī
translated: And when he comes face to face with Buddhas or their disciples, he is unable to give up his gain quickly. That is why the view of eternalism is called “less blameworthy and slow to fade away.”

original: pana idhalokaparalokaṃ atthīti jānāti, sukatadukkaṭānaṃ phalaṃ atthīti jānāti, kusalaṃ
analyzed: pana idha loka para lokam atthi iti jānāti su kata dukkaṭānam phalam atthi iti jānāti kusalam
translated: But the annihilationist knows that there is this world and the next world, he knows that there is fruit of good and bad actions, he does what is wholesome,🔽he is afraid of doing what is unwholesome,

original: na karoti, akusalaṃ karonto na bhāyati, vaṭṭaṃ na assādeti, nābhinandati, buddhānaṃ
analyzed: na karoti akusalam karontaḥ na bhāyati vaṭṭam na assādeti na abhinandati buddhānam
translated: he does not do what is unwholesome, he does not fear, he does not delight in the round (of births and deaths), he does not rejoice,

original: vā buddhasāvakānaṃ vā sammukhībhāve sīghaṃ dassanaṃ pajahati. Pāramiyo pūretuṃ sakkonto
analyzed: vā buddha sāvakānam vā sammukhībhāve sīgham dassanam pajahati pāramiyaḥ pūretum sakkontaḥ
translated: He does not do what is unwholesome. He does not fear doing what is unwholesome. He does not delight in the round of rebirths. He does not rejoice in it. He abandons the opportunity of seeing the Buddhas and their disciples face to face. He is able to fulfil the pāramīs.

original: buddho hutvā, asakkonto abhinīhāraṃ katvā sāvako hutvā parinibbāyati. Tasmā ucchedadassanaṃ
analyzed: buddhaḥ hutvā a sakkontaḥ abhinīhāram katvā sāvakaḥ hutvā parinibbāyati tasmai uccheda dassanam
translated: Having become a Buddha, or having become a disciple after making the aspiration, he attains final Nibbāna. Therefore the view of annihilation

original: mahāsāvajjaṃ khippavirāganti vuccati.
analyzed: mahā sāvajjam khippa virāgan ti vuccati
translated: is said to be very reprehensible and to lead to quick destruction.

original: 202. So pana paribbājako etamatthaṃ asallakkhetvā – “mayhaṃ dassanaṃ saṃvaṇṇeti pasaṃsati, addhā me sundaraṃ dassana”nti sallakkhetvā ukkaṃseti me bhavantiādimāha.
analyzed: saḥ pana paribbājakaḥ etam attham a saṃlakkhetvā mayham dassanam saṃvaṇṇā iti pasaṃsati addhā me sundaram dassananti sallakkhetvā ukkaṃseti me bhavanti ādim āha
translated: But this wanderer, not understanding the meaning, thought, “He praises and extols my view. Surely my view must be good.” He then boasted, saying, “You are exalted, Master Gotama,” and so on.

original: Idāni yasmā ayaṃ paribbājako kañjiyeneva tittakālābu, ucchedadassaneneva pūrito,
analyzed: idāni yasmai ayam paribbājakaḥ kañjiyena iva tittaka alābu uccheda dassanena iva pūritaḥ
translated: Now this wanderer was filled with bitterness like a bitter gourd and with the view of annihilation.

original: so yathā kañjiyaṃ appahāya na sakkā lābumhi telaphāṇitādīni pakkhipituṃ, pakkhittānipi
analyzed: saḥ yathā kañjiyam appahāya na sakkā lābumhi tela phāṇita ādīni pakkhipitum pakkhittāni pi
translated: Just as, when one does not remove the bitterness, it is impossible to put oil, molasses, etc., into the gourd, and even if one does put them in, they will not stay there,

original: na gaṇhāti, evamevaṃ taṃ laddhiṃ appahāya abhabbo maggaphalānaṃ lābhāya, tasmā laddhiṃ
analyzed: na gaṇhāti evam evam tam laddhim a pahāya abhabbaḥ magga phalānam lābhāya tasmai laddhim
translated: Just as a man who does not give up his hold on a snake cannot obtain a gem, so too, one who does not give up his hold on the view cannot obtain the path and fruit. Therefore, in order to give up the view, the Buddha said: “Here, Aggivessana, a Tathagata arises in the world, an Arahat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, …

original: jahāpanatthaṃ tatraggivessanātiādi āraddhaṃ. Viggahoti kalaho. Evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ
analyzed: jahāpana attham tatraggi vessanā ti ādi āraddham viggahaḥ ti kalahaḥ evam etāsam diṭṭhīnam
translated: a teacher of Devas and men. He makes known this world with its devas, maras and Brahmas, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, its devas and men, having realized it by his own super-knowledge. He teaches the Dhamma which is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life which is utterly perfect and pure.🔽“A disciple goes forth and practices the moralities; he achieves the attainment of concentration, and realizes the destruction of the taints.🔽“A disciple goes forth and practices the moralities; he achieves the attainment of concentration, but does not realize the destruction of the taints.🔽“A disciple goes forth and practices the moralities, but does not achieve the attainment of concentration.🔽“A disciple goes forth, but does not practice the moralities.🔽“A disciple does not go forth, but lives as a layman at home. He supports his mother and father,🔽 Translation: So na sakkoti maggaphalāni pāpuṇituṃ, tasmā laddhiṃ pahātabbaṃ |

original: pahānaṃ hotīti evaṃ viggahādiādīnavaṃ disvā tāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti. So hi paribbājako
analyzed: pahānam hoti iti evam viggaha ādi ādīnavam disvā tāsam diṭṭhīnam pahānam hoti so hi paribbājakaḥ
translated: Viggahoti kalaho | Evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hotīti evaṃ viggahādīnavaṃ disvā tāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti |

original: “kiṃ me iminā viggahādinā”ti taṃ ucchedadassanaṃ pajahati.🔽205. Athassa bhagavā vamitakañjiye lābumhi sappiphāṇitādīni pakkhipanto viya hadaye
analyzed: kim me iminā viggaha ādinā ati tam uccheda dassanam pajahati  athassa bhagavā vamita kañjiye lābumhi sappi phāṇita ādīni pakkhipantaḥ viya hadaye
translated: So hi paribbājako “kiṃ me iminā viggahādī”ti taṃ ucchedadassanaṃ pajahati |

original: amatosadhaṃ pūressāmīti vipassanaṃ ācikkhanto ayaṃ kho pana, aggivessana, kāyotiādimāha.
analyzed: amatosadham pūressāmi iti vipassanam ācikkhantaḥ ayam kho pana aggivessana kāyaḥ ti ādim āha
translated: Atha tassa bhagavā vamitakañjiye lābumhi sappiphāṇitādīni pakkhipanto viya hadaye amatosadhaṃ pūressāmīti vipassanaṃ ācikkhanto ayaṃ kho pana, aggivessana, kāyotiādimāha |

original: Tassattho vammikasutte vutto. Aniccatotiādīnipi heṭṭhā vitthāritāneva. Yo kāyasmiṃ🔽kāyachandoti yā kāyasmiṃ taṇhā. Snehoti taṇhāsnehova. Kāyanvayatāti kāyānugamanabhāvo,🔽kāyaṃ anugacchanakakilesoti attho.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ vammika sutte vuttaḥ aniccato ti ādīni pi heṭṭhā yaḥ kāyasmiṃ 🔽yā kāyasmin taṇhā snehā uti taṇhā snehā uva kāya anvaya tā ati kāya anugamana bhāvaḥ 🔽kāyam anugacchanaka kileso ti attho
translated: Tassattho vammikasutte vutto | Aniccatotiādīnipi heṭṭhā vitthāritāneva | Yo

original: Evaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ dassetvā idāni arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ dassento tisso khotiādimāha.
analyzed: evam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam dassetvā idāni arūpa kammaṭṭhānam dassento tisso kho ti ādim āha
translated: Having thus shown the meditation subject consisting of materiality, he now said “Three kinds of feeling” in order to show the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial.

original: Puna tāsaṃyeva vedanānaṃ asammissabhāvaṃ dassento yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samayetiādimāha.
analyzed: puna tāsaṃyeva vedanānam asammissa bhāvam dassentaḥ yasmin aggivessana samaya iti ādim āha
translated: And again, showing the unmixedness of those same feelings, he said “When, Aggivessana, a bhikkhu is experiencing a pleasant feeling, he understands ‘I am experiencing a pleasant feeling’;

original: Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – yasmiṃ samaye sukhādīsu ekaṃ vedanaṃ vedayati, tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yasmin samaye sukha ādīsu ekam vedanam vedayati tasmin samaye
translated: and the meaning of this in brief is this: at the time when he is experiencing one of the three kinds of feeling,

original: aññā vedanā attano vāraṃ vā okāsaṃ vā olokayamānā nisinnā nāma natthi, atha kho anuppannāva🔽honti bhinnaudakapupphuḷā viya ca antarahitā vā. Sukhāpi khotiādi tāsaṃ vedanānaṃ
analyzed: aññā vedanā attanaḥ vāram vā okāsam vā olokayamānā nisinnā nāma natthi atha kho anuppannā ava  honti bhinna audaka pupphuḷāḥ ca antarahitāḥ vā tāsam
translated: then the other two feelings are not present as though keeping guard over it, but rather they are non-existent, as though dissolved, like bubbles on water.

original: cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Na kenaci saṃvadatīti tassataṃ gahetvā “sassatavādī aha”nti ucchedavādināpi saddhiṃ
analyzed: cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa bhāva dassana attham vuttam  na kenacid saṃvadati iti tassatam gahetvā sassata vādī ahanti uccheda vādinā api saddhim
translated: The words “No pleasant feeling, etc.,” are said in order to show how those feelings are broken up into separate parts.🔽“He does not agree with anyone” means that he does not agree with the eternalists who hold the view of “eternality” , taking it to be “eternality”;

original: na saṃvadati, tameva gahetvā “sassatavādī aha”nti ekaccasassatavādinā saddhiṃ na
analyzed: na saṃvadati tam eva gahetvā sassata vādī ahanti ekacca sassata vādinā saddhim na
translated: nor does he agree with the partial-eternalists who hold the view of “eternality,” taking it to be “eternality.”

original: vivadati. Evaṃ tayopi vādā parivattetvā yojetabbā. Yañca loke vuttanti yaṃ loke kathitaṃ
analyzed: vivadati evam tayo api vādā parivattetvā yojetabbā yat ca loke vuttam ti yam loke kathitam
translated: and so on. In this way the three terms should be construed by turning them round.

original: voharitaṃ, tena voharati aparāmasanto kiñci dhammaṃ parāmāsaggāhena aggaṇhanto. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: voharitam tena voharati a parāmasantaḥ kiñci dhammam parāmāsa ggāhena aggaṇhantaḥ vuttam pi
translated: What is spoken of in the world: what is talked about, discussed, and debated in the world. He uses that without misapprehending, without apprehending anything among those dhammas as a self or the belongings of a self. And this is said:

original: “Yo hoti bhikkhu arahaṃ katāvī,
analyzed: yaḥ hoti bhikkhu araham katāvī
translated: “The bhikkhu who is an arahant, one whose taints are destroyed,

original: Khīṇāsavo antimadehadhārī;🔽Ahaṃ vadāmītipi so vadeyya,
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ antima dehadhārī  aham vadāmi itipi saḥ
translated: Who has reached the true way, the cool state,🔽He might say: ‘I say this,’

original: Mamaṃ vadantītipi so vadeyya;
analyzed: vadanti itipi saḥ
translated: Or he might say: ‘They say this to me.’

original: Loke samaññaṃ kusalo viditvā,
analyzed: loke samaññam kusalaḥ viditvā
translated: Skilled in the conventions of the world,

original: Vohāramattena so vohareyyā”ti. ;
analyzed: vohāra mattena saḥ vohareyyāti
translated: He uses them without misapprehending.”

original: Aparampi vuttaṃ – “imā kho citta lokasamaññā lokaniruttiyo lokavohārā lokapaññattiyo, yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasa”nti.🔽206. Abhiññāpahānamāhāti sassatādīsu tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ sassataṃ abhiññāya jānitvā
analyzed: aparam pi vuttam imā kho citta loka samaññāḥ loka niruttiyaḥ loka vohārāḥ loka paññattiyaḥ yāhi tathāgataḥ voharati a parāmasanti  abhiññā apahānam āha ati sassata ādīsu tesam tesam dhammānam sassatam abhiññāya jānitvā
translated: And this is also said: “These, Cittas, are the conventions, designations, expressions, and conventions in the world by which the Tathāgata uses a designation without misapprehending.”🔽The expression “the abandoning of what is to be directly known” means the abandoning of the eternalist view, etc., in regard to the various dhammas.🔽Having directly known the eternalist view, he says: “The abandoning of the eternalist view.” Having directly known the annihilationist view, he says: “The abandoning of the annihilationist view.”

original: sassatassa pahānamāha, ucchedaṃ, ekaccasassataṃ abhiññāya ekaccasassatassa pahānaṃ
analyzed: sassatassa pahānam āha ucchedam ekacca sassatam abhiññāya ekacca sassatassa pahānam
translated: Having directly known the view of holding to a particular extreme, he says: “The abandoning of the view of holding to a particular extreme.”

original: vadati. Rūpaṃ abhiññāya rūpassa pahānaṃ vadatītiādinā nayenettha attho veditabbo.🔽Paṭisañcikkhatoti paccavekkhantassa. Anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccīti anuppādanirodhena
analyzed: vadati rūpam abhiññāya rūpassa pahānam vadati itiādinā nayena ittha atthaḥ veditabbo  paṭisañcikkhatoti paccavekkhantassa an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimucci iti anuppāda nirodhena
translated: He said: “Having directly known form, he said the abandoning of form.” The meaning should be understood in this way by the method stated here.

original: niruddhehi āsavehi aggahetvāva cittaṃ vimucci. Ettāvatā cesa parassa vaḍḍhitaṃ bhattaṃ
analyzed: niruddhehi āsavehi aggahetvā ava cittam ettāvatā ca isa parassa vaḍḍhitam bhattam
translated: “He reflected”: to one who is reflecting. “His mind was liberated from the taints by non-clinging”: without grasping, his mind was liberated by the cessation of the taints that had arisen.

original: bhuñjitvā khudaṃ vinodento viya parassa āraddhāya dhammadesanāya ñāṇaṃ pesetvā vipassanaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetvā arahattañceva patto, sāvakapāramīñāṇassa ca matthakaṃ, soḷasa ca paññā
analyzed: bhuñjitvā khudam vinodentaḥ viya parassa āraddhāya dhamma desanāya ñāṇam pesetvā vipassanam  vaḍḍhetvā arahattam ca iva patto sāvaka pāramī ñāṇassa ca matthakam soḷasa ca paññā
translated: Up to this point, he was like one who, having eaten another’s food, relieves his hunger. Having sent forth knowledge in the Dhamma-talk begun by another,🔽he developed insight and attained arahatship. He also reached the culmination of the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship and stood having penetrated the sixteen kinds of knowledge.

original: paṭivijjhitvā ṭhito. Dīghanakho pana sotāpattiphalaṃ patvā saraṇesu patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaḥ dīghanakhaḥ pana sotāpatti phalam patvā saraṇesu patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Dīghanakha, however, attained the fruit of stream-entry and was established in the refuges.

original: Bhagavā pana imaṃ desanaṃ sūriye dharamāneyeva niṭṭhāpetvā gijjhakūṭā oruyha veḷuvanaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā pana imam desanam sūriye dharamāneya iva niṭṭhāpetvā gijjhakūṭāḥ oruyha veḷuvanaṃ
translated: The Blessed One, having completed this teaching while the sun was shining, descended from the Vulture Peak and went to the Bamboo Grove.

original: gantvā sāvakasannipātamakāsi, caturaṅgasamannāgato sannipāto ahosi. Tatrimāni aṅgāni
analyzed: gantvā sāvaka sannipātam akāsi catur aṅga samannāgataḥ sannipātaḥ ahosi aṅgāni
translated: He assembled the disciples, and the assembly was endowed with four factors. These are the factors:

original: – māghanakkhattena yutto puṇṇamauposathadivaso, kenaci anāmantitāni hutvā attanoyeva
analyzed: māgha nakkhattena yuttaḥ kenacid an āmantitāni hutvā
translated: The full-moon Uposatha day of the month of Magha was combined with the constellation Magha. Without being invited, they had assembled of their own accord

original: dhammatāya sannipatitāni aḍḍhatelasāni bhikkhusatāni, tesu ekopi puthujjano vā sotāpanna-sakadāgāmi-anāgāmi-sukkhavipassaka-arahantesu
analyzed: dhammatāya sannipatitāni aḍḍhatelasāni bhikkhu satāni tesu ekaḥ api puthujjanaḥ vā sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmi sukkha vipassaka ara hantesu
translated: on the Uposatha day. There were 1,250 bhikkhus, and not one of them was an ordinary man or a stream-enterer or a once-returner or a non-returner or a cankerless saint.

original: vā aññataro natthi, sabbe chaḷabhiññāva, ekopi cettha satthakena kese chinditvā pabbajito
analyzed: vā aññataraḥ na atthi sabbe ekaḥ api ca ittha satthakena kese chinditvā pabbajitaḥ
translated: All were possessed of the six psychic powers. Not one of them had gone forth after having his hair and beard shaved off with a razor.

original: nāma natthi, sabbe ehibhikkhunoyevāti.
analyzed: nāma natthi sabbe ehibhikkhuno yeva ati
translated: All had gone forth by the simple utterance of “Come, bhikkhu!”

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya called “The Food of the Wise”

original: Dīghanakhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dīghanakha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Dīghanakha Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Māgaṇḍiyasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Māgaṇḍiya Sutta

original: 207. Evaṃ me sutanti māgaṇḍiyasuttaṃ. Tattha agyāgāreti aggihomasālayaṃ. Tiṇasanthāraketi
analyzed: evam me sutam ti māgaṇḍiya suttam tattha agya āgārā iti aggi homa sa ālayam tiṇa santhāraka iti
translated: “Thus have I heard.” The Māgaṇḍiya Sutta . Herein, in the fire-house means in the place for the fire sacrifice. In the grass-thatched shed means

original: dve māgaṇḍiyā mātulo ca bhāgineyyo ca. Tesu mātulo pabbajitvā arahattaṃ patto, bhāgineyyopi
analyzed: dve māgaṇḍiyāḥ mātulo ca bhāgineyyo ca tesu mātulaḥ pabbajitvā arahattam pattaḥ bhāgineyyaḥ pi
translated: in the grass-thatched shed in the fire-house. There were two Māgaṇḍiyas, an uncle and a nephew. Of them the uncle had gone forth and attained arahatship, and the nephew🔽had gone forth under the same teacher and attained arahatship.

original: saupanissayo nacirasseva pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇissati. Athassa bhagavā upanissayaṃ🔽disvā ramaṇīyaṃ devagabbhasadisaṃ gandhakuṭiṃ pahāya tattha chārikatiṇakacavarādīhi
analyzed: sa upanissayaḥ nacirassa iva pabbajitvā arahattam pāpuṇissati athassa bhagavā upanissayam  disvā ramaṇīyam deva gabbha sadisam gandhakuṭim pahāya tattha chārika tiṇaka cavara ādīhi
translated: and with the support of that aspiration he will soon go forth and attain arahatship. Then the Blessed One, seeing his support,

original: uklāpe agyāgāre tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññāpetvā parasaṅgahakaraṇatthaṃ katipāhaṃ vasittha.
analyzed: uklāpe agya āgāre tiṇa santhārakam paññāpetvā para saṅgaha karaṇa attham katipāham vasittha
translated: left his delightful gandhakuṭi, which was like a celestial palace, and stayed in the fire-hall for a few days, covered with dust, on a couch of straw, in order to attract the attention of others.🔽This is the reason why it is said that he went there.

original: Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tenupasaṅkamīti na kevalaṃ taṃdivasameva, yasmā pana taṃ
analyzed: tam sandhāya itam vuttam tena upasaṅkamīti na kevalam tam divasam eva yasmai pana tam
translated: “He approached”: not only on that day, but also on other days,

original: agyāgāraṃ gāmūpacāre dārakadārikāhi okiṇṇaṃ avivittaṃ, tasmā bhagavā niccakālampi
analyzed: agyāgāram gāmūpacāre dāraka dārikāhi okiṇṇam a vivittam tasmai bhagavā
translated: because that fire-hall was crowded and noisy with boys and girls who were playing nearby. Therefore the Blessed One,

original: divasabhāgaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe vītināmetvā sāyaṃ vāsatthāya tattha upagacchati.🔽Addasā kho…pe… tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññattanti bhagavā aññesu divasesu tiṇasanthārakaṃ
analyzed: divasa bhāgam tasmin vana saṇḍe vītināmetvā sāyam vāsatthāya tattha upagacchati  addasā khope tiṇa santhārakam paññattanti bhagavā aññesu divasesu tiṇa santhārakam
translated: having spent the day in that forest grove, would go there in the evening to stay.

original: saṅgharitvā saññāṇaṃ katvā gacchati, taṃdivasaṃ pana paññapetvāva agamāsi. Kasmā?
analyzed: saṅgharitvā saññāṇam katvā gacchati tat divasam pana paññapetvā ava agamāsi kasmā
translated: “He saw the Blessed One sitting in the fire-hall, covered with dust, on a couch of straw, having entered upon the cessation of perception and feeling”: on other days the Blessed One would enter upon the cessation of perception and feeling after sweeping up the straw couch and putting it in order, and then he would go away. But on that day he entered upon the cessation of perception and feeling after arranging the straw couch and then left.

original: Tadā hi paccūsasamaye lokaṃ oloketvāva addasa – “ajja māgaṇḍiyo idhāgantvā imaṃ tiṇasanthārakaṃ
analyzed: tadā hi paccūsa samaye lokam oloketvā ava addasa ajja māgaṇḍiyaḥ idha āgantvā imam tiṇa santhārakam
translated: For at that time, as he was surveying the world at dawn, he saw that on that day Māgaṇḍiya would come there, and seeing the grass couch,

original: disvā bhāradvājena saddhiṃ tiṇasanthārakaṃ ārabbha kathāsallāpaṃ karissati, athāhaṃ
analyzed: disvā bhāradvājena saddhim tiṇasanthārakam ārabbha kathā sallāpam karissati atha aham
translated: he would engage in conversation with Bhāradvāja about the grass couch. Then he would say, “I will come and teach the Dhamma.”

original: āgantvā dhammaṃ desessāmi, so dhammaṃ sutvā mama santike pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇissati.
analyzed: āgantvā dhammaṃ desessāmi so dhammam sutvā mama santike pabbajitvā arahattam pāpuṇissati
translated: Hearing the Dhamma, Māgaṇḍiya would go forth in my presence and attain arahatship.

original: Paresaṃ saṅgahakaraṇatthameva hi mayā pāramiyo pūritā”ti tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññapetvāva agamāsi.
analyzed: paresam saṅgaha karaṇa attham eva hi mayā pāramiyaḥ pūritā ati tiṇa santhārakam paññapetvā ava agamāsi
translated: “It is only to gather others to me that I have fulfilled the pāramīs.” Having thus arranged the grass couch, he went away.

original: Samaṇaseyyānurūpaṃ maññeti imaṃ tiṇasanthārakaṃ “samaṇassa anucchavikā seyyā”ti maññāmi.🔽Na ca asaññatasamaṇassa nivutthaṭṭhānametaṃ. Tathāhettha hatthena ākaḍḍhitaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: samaṇa seyyā anurūpam maññeti imam tiṇa santhārakam samaṇassa anucchavikā seyyā ti maññāmi  na ca asaññata samaṇassa nivuttha ṭṭhānam etam tathā ha ittha hatthena ākaḍḍhita ṭṭhānam
translated: I think it is suitable for a recluse: I think this grass couch is a suitable bed for a recluse.🔽But this is not a place for a recluse who is not self-controlled. For there is no sign here of his having dragged in grass with his hands,

original: vā pādena ākaḍḍhitaṭṭhānaṃ vā sīsena pahaṭaṭṭhānaṃ vā na paññāyati, anākulo anākiṇṇo
analyzed: vā pādena ākaḍḍhita ṭṭhānam vā sīsena pahaṭa ṭṭhānam vā na paññāyati an ākulaḥ an ākiṇṇaḥ
translated: or of his having dragged it in with his feet, or of his having struck it with his head. He is undisturbed, unruffled,

original: abhinno chekena cittakārena tūlikāya paricchinditvā paññatto viya. Saññatasamaṇassa🔽vasitaṭṭhānaṃ, kassa bho vasitaṭṭhānanti pucchati. Bhūnahunoti hatavaḍḍhino mariyādakārakassa.
analyzed: abhinno chekena cittakārena tūlikāya paricchinditvā paññattaḥ viya saññata samaṇassa  vasita ṭṭhānam kassa bho vasita ṭṭhānanti pucchati bhūnahuno ti hata vaḍḍhinaḥ mariyāda kārakassa
translated: as if it were marked off by a single line drawn by a single man with a single stroke of the plough. ‘The place where the ascetic is restrained’—🔽‘Whose place is it?’ he asks. ‘The place of the one who has a ploughshare for his horn.’🔽Why does he say this? Because the ploughshare is the means of his livelihood. For this is his livelihood:

original: Kasmā evamāha? Chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhipaññāpanaladdhikattā. Ayañhi tassa laddhi – cakkhu
analyzed: kasmai evam āha chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhi paññāpana laddhi kattā ayam hi tassa laddhi cakkhu
translated: ‘The eye should be extended, enlarged,

original: brūhetabbaṃ vaḍḍhetabbaṃ, adiṭṭhaṃ dakkhitabbaṃ, diṭṭhaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Sotaṃ
analyzed: brūhetabbam vaḍḍhetabbam a diṭṭham dakkhitabbam diṭṭham samatikkamitabbam sotam
translated: the unseen should be seen, the seen should be overpassed. The ear should be extended, enlarged,

original: brūhetabbaṃ vaḍḍhetabbaṃ, asutaṃ sotabbaṃ, sutaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Ghānaṃ brūhetabbaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetabbaṃ, aghāyitaṃ ghāyitabbaṃ, ghāyitaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Jivhā brūhetabbā
analyzed: brūhetabbam vaḍḍhetabbam a sutam sotabbam sutam samatikkamitabbam ghānam brūhetabbam  vaḍḍhetabbam a ghāyitam ghāyitabbam ghāyitam samatikkamitabbam jivhā brūhetabbā
translated: the unheard should be heard, the heard should be overpassed. The nose should be extended, enlarged,🔽the un smelt should be smelt, the smelt should be overpassed. The tongue should be extended, enlarged,

original: vaḍḍhetabbā, assāyitaṃ sāyitabbaṃ, sāyitaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Kāyo brūhetabbo vaḍḍhetabbo,
analyzed: vaḍḍhetabbāḥ assāyitam sāyitabbam sāyitam samatikkamitabbam kāyaḥ brūhetabbaḥ vaḍḍhetabbaḥ
translated: the untasted should be tasted, the tasted should be overpassed. The body should be extended, enlarged,

original: aphuṭṭhaṃ phusitabbaṃ, phuṭṭhaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Mano brūhetabbo vaḍḍhetabbo, aviññātaṃ
analyzed: a phuṭṭham phusitabbam phuṭṭham samatikkamitabbam manaḥ brūhetabbaḥ vaḍḍhetabbaḥ a viññātam
translated: the un touched should be touched, the touched should be overpassed. The mind should be extended, enlarged,🔽the unknown should be known, the known should be overpassed.’

original: vijānitabbaṃ, viññātaṃ samatikkamitabbaṃ. Evaṃ so chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhiṃ paññapeti. Bhagavā pana –
analyzed: vijānitabbam viññātam samatikkamitabbam evam so chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhim paññapeti bhagavā pana
translated: and what is known must be gone beyond. Thus he lays down growth in the six doors. But the Blessed One

original: “Cakkhunā saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu sotena saṃvaro;🔽Ghānena saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu jivhāya saṃvaro.
analyzed: cakkhunā saṃvaraḥ sādhu sādhu sotena saṃvaraḥ  ghānena saṃvaro sādhu sādhu jivhāya saṃvaro
translated: “Restraint by the eye is good, good restraint by the ear;🔽Restraint by the nose is good, good restraint by the tongue;

original: Kāyena saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu vācāya saṃvaro;
analyzed: kāyena saṃvaro sādhu sādhu vācāya saṃvaro
translated: Restraint by the body is good, good restraint by speech;

original: Manasā saṃvaro sādhu, sādhu sabbattha saṃvaro;
analyzed: manasā saṃvaro sādhu sādhu sabbattha saṃvaro
translated: Restraint by the mind is good, good restraint everywhere;

original: Sabbattha saṃvuto bhikkhu, sabbadukkhā pamuccatī”ti. –
analyzed: sabbattha saṃvutaḥ bhikkhu sabba dukkhā pamuccati iti
translated: The bhikkhu restrained everywhere is freed from all suffering” .

original: Chasu dvāresu saṃvaraṃ paññapeti. Tasmā so “vaḍḍhihato samaṇo gotamo mariyādakārako”ti maññamāno “bhūnahuno”ti āha.
analyzed: chasu dvāresu saṃvaram paññapeti tasmai saḥ vaḍḍhihataḥ samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mariyāda kārakā iti maññamānaḥ bhūnahunā iti āha
translated: Thus he lays down restraint in the six doors. So thinking that the recluse Gotama lays down growth, and that he sets a limit, he said “He is a nihilist.”

original: Ariye ñāye dhamme kusaleti parisuddhe kāraṇadhamme anavajje. Iminā kiṃ dasseti? Evarūpassa
analyzed: ariye ñāye dhamme kusala iti parisuddhe kāraṇa dhamme anavajje iminā kim dasseti evarūpassa
translated: In the noble way, in the profitable state: in the pure, blameless state of the reason. What does this show? One who is

original: nāma uggatassa paññātassa yasassino upari vācaṃ bhāsamānena vīmaṃsitvā upadhāretvā
analyzed: nāma uggatassa paññātassa yasassino upari vācam bhāsamānena vīmaṃsitvā upadhāretvā
translated: so exalted, so renowned, so famous, should speak after considering and reflecting on what he says above him.

original: mukhe ārakkhaṃ ṭhapetvā bhāsitabbo hoti. Tasmā mā sahasā abhāsi, mukhe ārakkhaṃ ṭhapehīti🔽dasseti. Evañhi no sutte ocaratīti yasmā amhākaṃ sutte evaṃ āgacchati, na mayaṃ mukhāruḷhicchāmattaṃ
analyzed: mukhe ārakkham ṭhapetvā bhāsitabbaḥ hoti tasmai mā sahasā abhāsi mukhe ārakkham ṭhapehi iti  dasseti evam hi no sutte ocarati iti yasmai amhākam sutte evam āgacchati na mayam mukha āruḷhi chāmattam
translated: He should speak after placing a guard over his mouth. Therefore he says: “Do not speak rashly; place a guard over your mouth.”

original: vadāma, sutte ca nāma āgataṃ vadamānā kassa bhāyeyyāma, tasmā sammukhāpi naṃ vadeyyāmāti
analyzed: vadāma sutte ca nāma āgatam vadamānā kassa bhāyeyyāma tasmai sammukhā api nam vadeyyāma ati
translated: “Thus we are not transgressing the sutta”: because it occurs thus in our sutta. We do not say that we are speaking out of mere desire to talk. And when we are speaking what occurs in the sutta, whom should we fear? Therefore we would speak even to his face.

original: attho. Appossukkoti mama rakkhanatthāya anussukko avāvaṭo hutvāti attho. Vuttova🔽naṃ vadeyyāti mayā vuttova hutvā apucchitova kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā ambajambūādīni
analyzed: atthaḥ appossukkaḥ ti mama rakkhana atthāya anussukkaḥ avāvaṭaḥ hutvā ati atthaḥ vuttaḥ iva  nam vadeyya iti mayā vuttaḥ iva hutvā a pucchitaḥ iva katham samuṭṭhāpetvā amba jambū ādīni
translated: “Without being attentive”: the meaning is: without being attentive to my protection, without being on guard.

original: gahetvā viya apūrayamāno mayā kathitaniyāmena bhavaṃ bhāradvājo vadeyya, vadassūti attho.🔽208. Assosi khoti satthā ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dibbacakkhunā māgaṇḍiyaṃ tattha āgataṃ
analyzed: gahetvā a pūrayamānaḥ mayā kathita niyāmena bhavam bhāradvājaḥ vadeyya vadassu iti attho  assosi kho ti satthā ālokam vaḍḍhetvā dibba cakkhunā māgaṇḍiyam tattha āgatam
translated: “Speak as if spoken to by me”: the venerable Bhāradvāja should speak in the manner I have stated, as if spoken to by me, without my having to be asked, as if he were taking mangoes, rose-apples, etc., without my having to be asked. The meaning is: “Speak.”

original: addasa, dvinnaṃ janānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ dibbasotena saddampi assosi. Paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti
analyzed: addasa dvinnam janānam bhāsamānānam dibba sotena saddam pi assosi paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā ti
translated: “He heard”: the Teacher, having increased his radiance, saw Māgaṇḍiya coming there with his divine eye. And he heard their conversation with his divine ear. Having risen from his seclusion,

original: phalasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhito. Saṃviggoti pītisaṃvegena saṃviggo calito kampito. Tassa
analyzed: phala samāpattiyā vuṭṭhitaḥ saṃviggo ti pīti saṃvegena saṃviggo calito kampito tassa
translated: and had emerged from the attainment of fruition. “Shaken” means that he was shaken, moved, and agitated by the shaking of the rapture.

original: kira etadahosi – “neva māgaṇḍiyena samaṇassa gotamassa ārocitaṃ, na mayā. Amhe muñcitvā
analyzed: kira etat ahosi na iva māgaṇḍiyena samaṇassa gotamassa ārocitam na mayā amhe muñcitvā
translated: It is said that he thought thus: “Neither Māgandiya nor I have informed the recluse Gotama.

original: añño ettha tatiyopi natthi, suto bhavissati amhākaṃ saddo tikhiṇasotena purisenā”ti.
analyzed: aññaḥ ettha tatiyaḥ pi na atthi sutaḥ bhavissati amhākam saddo tikhiṇa sotena purisena ati
translated: Except for us, there is not even a third person here. It must be that the recluse Gotama has heard our conversation through his sharp-pointed human ear.”

original: Athassa abbhantare pīti uppajjitvā navanavutilomakūpasahassāni uddhaggāni akāsi.
analyzed: athassa abbhantare pīti uppajjitvā nava navuti lomakūpa sahassāni uddhaggāni akāsi
translated: Then, as his rapture arose within him, it made the nine hundred and eighty thousand pores of his body stand on end.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto”ti. Atha kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājakoti paribbājakassa
analyzed: tena vuttam saṃviggaḥ lomahaṭṭha jātaḥ ti atha kho māgaṇḍiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ iti paribbājakassa
translated: Hence it is said: “Shaken, his hair standing on end” .

original: pabhinnamukhaṃ viya bījaṃ paripākagataṃ ñāṇaṃ, tasmā sannisīdituṃ asakkonto āhiṇḍamāno
analyzed: pabhinna mukham viya bījam paripāka gatam ñāṇam tasmai sannisīditum a sakkontaḥ āhiṇḍamānaḥ
translated: Then the wanderer Māgandiya: just as a seed with a split seed-coat is ripe, so his knowledge was ripe. Therefore, unable to sit still, he wandered about

original: puna satthu santikaṃ āgantvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Taṃ dassetuṃ “atha kho māgaṇḍiyo”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: puna satthu santikam āgantvā ekamantam nisīdi tam dassetum atha kho māgaṇḍiyaḥ tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: and returned to the Teacher’s presence. To show this, the text says: “Then the wanderer Māgandiya” .

original: 209. Satthā – “evaṃ kira tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, maṃ avacā”ti avatvāva cakkhuṃ kho, māgaṇḍiyāti
analyzed: satthā evam kira tvam māgaṇḍiya mama avaca ati avatvā ava cakkhum kho māgaṇḍiya ati
translated: The Teacher did not say: “Is it true, Māgandiya, that you spoke thus to me?” Instead he said: “Māgandiya, the eye is impermanent” .

original: paribbājakassa dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha vasanaṭṭhānaṭṭhena rūpaṃ cakkhussa ārāmoti
analyzed: paribbājakassa dhamma desanam ārabhi tattha vasana ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena rūpam cakkhussa ārāmo ti
translated: he began to teach the Dhamma to the wanderer. Herein, as a place of living, form is the eye’s pleasure grove,

original: cakkhu rūpārāmaṃ. Rūpe ratanti rūparataṃ. Rūpena cakkhu āmoditaṃ pamoditanti rūpasamuditaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhu rūpa ārāmam rūpe ratanti rūpa ratam rūpena cakkhu āmoditam rūpa samuditam
translated: so the eye is the pleasure grove of form. It is fond of form, it delights in form, it is intent on form.

original: Dantanti nibbisevanaṃ. Guttanti gopitaṃ. Rakkhitanti ṭhapitarakkhaṃ. Saṃvutanti pihitaṃ.
analyzed: dantanti nibbisevanam guttanti gopitam rakkhitanti ṭhapita rakkham saṃvutanti pihitam
translated: It is restrained: it is not indulged. It is guarded: it is protected. It is kept secure: it is kept under surveillance. It is controlled: it is shut.

original: Saṃvarāyāti pidhānatthāya.
analyzed: saṃvarāya ati pidhāna tthāya
translated: It is for the purpose of restraint: it is for the purpose of shutting.

original: 210. Paricāritapubboti abhiramitapubbo. Rūpapariḷāhanti rūpaṃ ārabbha uppajjanapariḷāhaṃ.
analyzed: paricārita pubbaḥ ti abhiramita pubbaḥ rūpa pariḷāham ti rūpam ārabbha uppajjana pariḷāham
translated: It has been frequented: it has been enjoyed. The fever of form: the fever that arises contingent upon form.

original: Imassa pana te, māgaṇḍiya, kimassa vacanīyanti imassa rūpaṃ pariggaṇhitvā arahattappattassa
analyzed: imassa pana te māgaṇḍiya kim assa vacanīyanti imassa rūpam pariggaṇhitvā arahatta ppattassa
translated: What would you say to him, Magandiya? What would you say to one who, having discerned form, has reached Arahantship,

original: khīṇāsavassa tayā kiṃ vacanaṃ vattabbaṃ assa, vuḍḍhihato mariyādakārakoti idaṃ vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa tayā kim vacanam vattabbam assa vuḍḍhi hataḥ mariyāda kārako ti idam vattabbam
translated: who has destroyed the taints? You would have to say this to him: ‘You have reached the limit of what can be attained by development, the culmination of what can be achieved by development’—

original: na vattabbanti pucchati. Na kiñci, bho gotamāti, bho gotama, kiñci vattabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: na vattabbanti pucchati na kiñci bho gotama ati bho gotama kiñci vattabbam natthi
translated: ‘Nothing, Master Gotama’—‘Nothing at all, Master Gotama.’

original: Sesadvāresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sesa dvāre supi e sa iva nayo
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other doors.

original: 211. Idāni yasmā tayā pañcakkhandhe pariggahetvā arahattappattassa khīṇāsavassa kiñci
analyzed: idāni yasmai tayā pañca kkhandhe pariggahetvā arahatta pattassa khīṇāsavassa kiñci
translated: Now, since there is nothing to be said to one who has reached Arahantship and destroyed the cankers after discerning the five aggregates,

original: vattabbaṃ natthi, ahañca pañcakkhandhe pariggahetvā sabbaññutaṃ patto, tasmā ahampi
analyzed: vattabbam natthi aham ca pañca kkhandhe pariggahetvā sabbaññu tam patto tasmai aham pi
translated: and since I have attained omniscience after discerning the five aggregates,

original: te na kiñci vattabboti dassetuṃ ahaṃ kho panātiādimāha. Tassa mayhaṃ māgaṇḍiyāti🔽gihikāle attano sampattiṃ dassento āha. Tattha vassikotiādīsu yattha sukhaṃ hoti
analyzed: te na kiñci vattabbaḥ iti dassetum aham kho pana ati ādim āha tassa mayham māgaṇḍiya iti  gihi kāle attanaḥ sampattim dassentaḥ āha tattha vassikā iti ādīsu yattha sukham hoti
translated: there is nothing to be said to me either. This is how the Exalted One shows that there is nothing to be said to him.🔽He said, “As for me, Magandiya,” showing his own excellence in the time of his lay life.

original: vassakāle vasituṃ, ayaṃ vassiko. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Ayaṃ panettha vacanattho –
analyzed: vassa kāle vasitum ayam vassikaḥ itaresu pi esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana ittha vacana attho
translated: Herein, as regards the words “rainy-season,” etc., a rainy-season retreat is a place where it is pleasant to stay during the rainy season. The same method applies to the others.🔽The meaning of the words is this:

original: vassaṃ vāso vassaṃ, vassaṃ arahatīti vassiko. Itaresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vassam vāsaḥ vassam vassam arahati iti vassikaḥ itaresu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The rainy season is the time of the rains. One who is worthy of the rainy season is a “rainy-season one” . The same method applies to the others.

original: Tattha vassiko pāsādo nātiucco hoti nātinīco, dvāravātapānānipissa nātitanūni nātibahūni,
analyzed: tattha vassikaḥ pāsādaḥ na ati uccaḥ hoti na ati nīcaḥ dvāra vāta pānāni pissa na atitanūni na atibahūni
translated: Herein, a rainy-season pavilion is not too high or too low, and its doors and windows are not too large or too small.

original: bhūmattharaṇapaccattharaṇakhajjabhojjānipettha missakāneva vaṭṭanti. Hemantike thambhāpi
analyzed: bhūmattharaṇa paccattharaṇa khajja bhojjāni pa ittha missakān eva vaṭṭanti hemantike
translated: The floor and the bed with its mattress and counterpane are just right. Only the necessary food, such as pastries, etc., is provided.

original: bhittiyopi nīcā honti, dvāravātapānāni tanukāni sukhumacchiddāni. Uṇhapavesanatthāya
analyzed: bhittiyaḥ pi nīcāḥ honti dvāra vāta pānāni tanukāni sukhuma chiddāni uṇha pavesana tthāya
translated: The walls are low, the doors and windows are thin and have small holes.

original: bhittiniyūhāni nīharīyanti. Bhūmattharaṇapaccattharaṇanivāsanapārupanāni panettha🔽uṇhavīriyāni kambalādīni vaṭṭanti. Khajjabhojjaṃ siniddhaṃ kaṭukasannissitañca. Gimhike🔽thambhāpi bhittiyopi uccā honti. Dvāravātapānāni panettha bahūni vipulajālāni bhavanti.
analyzed: bhitti niyūhāni nīharīyanti bhūmattharaṇa paccattharaṇa nivāsana pārupanāni pana ittha  uṇha vīriyāni kambala ādīni vaṭṭanti khajja bhojjam siniddham kaṭuka sannissitam ca gimhike  thambhā api bhittiyaḥ api uccāḥ honti dvāra vāta pānāni pana ittha bahūni vipula jālāni bhavanti
translated: The floor coverings, bedspreads, bed sheets, and blankets are removed.🔽The food is soft, and has a pungent taste. In the cold season,🔽the pillars and walls are high, and the doors and windows are many and have large nets.

original: Bhūmattharaṇādīni dukūlamayāni vaṭṭanti, khajjabhojjāni madhurarasasītavīriyāni.
analyzed: bhūmattharaṇa ādīni dukūla mayāni vaṭṭanti khajja bhojjāni madhura rasa sīta vīriyāni

translated: In the four directions of the palace there are four lakes. During the day the flocks of birds of various colours, flying out from the eastern lake,
