translated: “Would stand having attained” means would stand having attained divine pleasure and become more distinguished than that.🔽But the correspondence of the similes should be understood as follows:

analyzed: sabbaññu tam paṭividdha kālaḥ tassa nandana vane sampattim anubhavana kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa
translated: is like the time when the Tathāgata, after attaining omniscience, was enjoying the excellence in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpattiratiyā vītivattanakālo, tassa mānusakānaṃ pañcannaṃ
analyzed: catuttha jhānika phala samāpatti ratiyāḥ vītivattana kālo tassa mānusakānam pañcannam
translated: The time when the Realised One was passing beyond the pleasure of the fourth absorption fruit attainment,🔽was like the time when the human beings were not aspiring for the five sense pleasures,

analyzed: kāma guṇānaṃ a patthana kālaḥ viya tathāgatassa catuttha jhānika phala samāpatti ratiyā

translated: later when the disease had subsided he was able to go to the forest, to the mountain, to the rock, and so on, and go where he wished,

original: tasmiṃ pubbe vutte. Amittatopi daheyyāti amitto me ayanti evaṃ amittato ṭhapeyya.

original: Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Iminā cittenāti vaṭṭe anugatacittena. Tassa me upādānapaccayāti

analyzed: eka sandhi dvi saṅkhepo paccaya ākāro kathitaḥ vaṭṭam vibhāvitam

original: Devakatasobbhoti vassodakeneva tinnaṭṭhāne jāto mahāudakarahado. Guhādassanāyāti
analyzed: vassa udakena iva tinna ṭṭhāne jātaḥ mahā udaka rahadaḥ guhā dassanāya āti

analyzed: ettha guhā ti paṃsu guhā sā unname udakamutta ṭṭhāne ahosi ekatas umaṅgam katvā khāṇuke

translated: Herein, the cave was a sand-cave. It was in a place where the water rose in the rainy season, and it was made by digging out the sand and timber on one side and then propping up the remaining part with posts and beams and so on, and then covering the top with timber and thatch.

original: samuddapabbatadassanatthaṃ vāpi gantuṃ vaṭṭatīti.🔽Unnādiniyāti uccaṃ nadamānāya. Evaṃ nadamānāya cassā uddhaṅgamanavasena ucco, disāsu
analyzed: samudda pabbata dassana attham vā api gantum vaṭṭati iti  unnādiniyā ati uccam nadamānāya evam nadamānāya uddhaṅgamana vasena uccaḥ disāsu
translated: The wanderers lived there. It was filled with water in the rainy season, and they lived there in the dry season. It was with reference to this that he said ‘to see the cave.’ For it is allowable to go to see a sea, a mountain, or a cave, after reviewing the purpose of doing so and seeing that there is one.🔽In a loud noise: in a noise that is high. For when it is making such a noise, it is high in the sense of rising upwards, and it is a great noise in the sense of being spread out in all directions.

original: patthaṭavasena mahāsaddoti uccāsaddamahāsaddo, tāya uccāsaddamahāsaddāya. Tesaṃ paribbājakānaṃ
analyzed: patthaṭa vasena mahāsaddo ti uccāsadda mahāsaddo tāya uccāsadda mahāsaddāya tesam paribbājakānam

analyzed: pātova uṭṭhāya kattabbam nāma cetiya vattam vā bodhi vattam vā ācariya upajjhāya vattam
translated: The wanderers had to get up early in the morning to do such duties as attending to the shrines and the Bodhi Tree and to their teachers and preceptors.

original: vā yonisomanasikāro vā natthi. Tena te pātova uṭṭhāya bālātape nisinnā, sāyaṃ vā
analyzed: vā yonisoma nasikāraḥ vā na atthi tena te uṭṭhāya bāla ātape nisinnā sāyam vā
translated: or right reflection. Therefore, when they get up early in the morning and sit in the cool of the day,

analyzed: kathāya phāsu katthāya sannipatitāḥ imassa hattho sobhaṇaḥ imassa pādo ti evam aññamaññassa

original: hatthapādādīni vā ārabbha itthipurisadārakadārikāvaṇṇe vā aññaṃ vā kāmassādabhavassādādivatthuṃ🔽ārabbha kathaṃ paṭṭhapetvā anupubbena rājakathādianekavidhaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathenti.
analyzed: hattha pāda ādīni vā ārabbha itthi purisa dāraka dārikā vaṇṇe vā aññam vā kāma ssāda bhava ssāda ādi vatthum  ārabbha katham paṭṭhapetvā anupubbena rāja kathā ādi anekavidham tiracchāna katham kathenti
translated: or by discussing the beauty of women, men, boys, and girls, or by discussing some other subject that gives rise to sensual pleasure and attachment to becoming.

original: Sā hi aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ tiracchānabhūtā kathāti tiracchānakathā.
analyzed: sā hi aniyyānika ttā sagga mokkha maggānam tiracchāna bhūtā kathā ati tiracchāna kathā
translated: And this is called “animal conversation” because it is not conducive to the attainment of heaven or liberation, and because it is like the conversation of animals.

original: Tattha rājānaṃ ārabbha “mahāsammato mandhātā dhammāsoko evaṃmahānubhāvo”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: tattha rājānam ārabbha mahāsammataḥ mandhātā dhammāsokaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ iti ādinā nayena
translated: Herein, conversation about kings is talk about kings such as this: “King So-and-so is powerful, he is mighty, he is glorious,” and so on.

original: pavattā kathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu.
analyzed: pavattā kathā rāja kathā esa nayo cora kathā ādīsu
translated: The same method applies to conversation about thieves, etc.

original: Tesu “asuko rājā abhirūpo dassanīyo”tiādinā nayena gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā
analyzed: tesu asukaḥ rājā abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ ti ādinā nayena geha sita kathā va tiracchāna kathā
translated: Herein, conversation about kings that is mere idle chatter is animal conversation when it is conducted in such terms as “King So-and-so is handsome, he is good-looking,” and so on.

original: hoti. “Sopi nāma evaṃ mahānubhāvo khayaṃ gato”ti evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve🔽tiṭṭhati. Coresupi “mūladevo evaṃmahānubhāvo, meghamālo evaṃmahānubhāvo”ti tesaṃ🔽kammaṃ paṭicca aho sūrāti gehassitakathāva tiracchānakathā. Yuddhepi bhāratayuddhādīsu
analyzed: hoti saḥ api nāma evam mahā anubhāvaḥ khayam gataḥ ti evam pavattā pana kammaṭṭhāna bhāve  tiṭṭhati coresu pi mūladevaḥ evaṃmahā anubhāvaḥ meghamālaḥ evaṃmahā anubhāvaḥ ti tesam  kammam paṭicca aho sūrāti geha sita kathā va tiracchāna kathā yuddhe pi bhārata yuddha ādīsu
translated: “He too has come to an end, though he was so powerful,” and so on.🔽But when it is used as a meditation subject, it is a meditation subject.🔽And when thieves say, “Mūladeva was so powerful,” and “Megha was so powerful,” and so on, it is animal talk in the sense of talk that is the outcome of the animal’s kamma.

original: “asukena asuko evaṃ mārito evaṃ viddho”ti kāmassādavaseneva kathā tiracchānakathā.
analyzed: asukena asukaḥ evam māritaḥ evam viddhaḥ iti kāmaḥ sāda vasena iva kathā tiracchāna kathā
translated: And when they talk about battles, the battle of the Bārbaras, and so on, in the way beginning, “So-and-so was killed here, and so-and-so was wounded there,” it is animal talk in the sense of talk that is the outcome of the animal’s lust.

original: “Tepi nāma khayaṃ gatā”ti evaṃ pavattā pana sabbattha kathā kammaṭṭhānameva hoti.🔽Apica annādīsu “evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ gandhavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha🔽bhuñjimha pivimha paribhuñjimhā”ti kāmassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ
analyzed: te pi nāma khayam gatā ti evam pavattā pana sabbattha kathā kammaṭṭhānam eva hoti  apica anna ādīsu evam vaṇṇavantam gandhavantam rasavantam phassa sampannam khādimha  bhuñjimha pivimha paribhuñjimha ati kāma ssāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati sātthakam
translated: But when it is used as a meditation subject, it is a meditation subject in all these instances.🔽Besides, it is not proper to talk about food, etc., in terms of the gratification of lust in this way: “We ate such-and-such food, which was so beautiful, so fragrant, so flavoursome, and so pleasant to the touch,”🔽but it is proper to talk about it with reference to its meaning in this way: “In the past there was such-and-such food, which was so beautiful, etc., and so profitable.”

original: pana katvā – “pubbe evaṃ vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ sayanaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ
analyzed: pana katvā pubbe evam vaṇṇa ādi sampannam annam pānam vattham sayanam mālam gandham
translated: And it is not proper to talk about a robe, a dwelling, a bed, a chair, a tooth stick, or anything else in this way:

original: sīlavantānaṃ adamha, cetiye pūjaṃ akarimhā”ti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.🔽Ñātikathādīsupi “amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā”ti vā “pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi yānehi
analyzed: sīlavantānam adamha cetiye pūjam akarimha iti kathetum vaṭṭati  ñāti kathā ādīsu pi amhākam ñātakā sūrā samatthā iti vā pubbe mayam evam vicitrehi yānehi
translated: “We are virtuous; we have made an offering to the shrine.”

original: carimhā”ti vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “tepi no ñātakā🔽khayaṃ gatā”ti vā “pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamhā”ti vā kathetabbā.🔽Gāmakathāpi suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena vā “asukagāmavāsino🔽sūrā samatthā”ti vā evaṃ assādavasena na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā saddhā pasannāti
analyzed: carimha ati vā assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā te pi no ñātakā  khayam gatā ati vā pubbe mayam evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamha ati vā kathetabbā  gāma kathā api suniviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha subhikkha dubbhikkha ādi vasena vā asuka gāma vāsinaḥ  sūrā samatthā ati vā evam assāda vasena na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā saddhā pasannā ati
translated: In the case of talk about relatives, etc., it is not allowable to speak with relish, saying, “Our relatives are powerful and able,” or “Formerly we used to travel about in various kinds of vehicles,” and so on. But it is allowable to speak with reference to a purpose, saying, “Those relatives of ours have come to an end,” or “Formerly we gave such sandals to the Community.”

original: vā khayavayaṃ gatāti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nigamanagarajanapadakathāsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vā khaya vayam gatā ati vā vattum vaṭṭati nigama nagara janapada kathāsu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ
translated: In the case of talk about villages, it is not allowable to speak with relish, saying, “The people of such-and-such a village are powerful and able,” or “They are well-disposed or ill-disposed,” or “They are rich or poor,” and so on. But it is allowable to speak with reference to a purpose, saying, “They are faithful and confident,” or “They have come to an end and perished.” The same method applies in the case of talk about towns, countries, and regions.

original: Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca assādavasena na vaṭṭati, saddhā pasannā khayaṃ
analyzed: itthi kathā api vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīni paṭicca assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khayam
translated: In the case of talk about women, it is not allowable to speak with relish, referring to their beauty, figure, and so on. But it is allowable to speak with reference to a purpose, saying, “They are faithful and confident,” or “They have come to an end and perished.”

original: gatāti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosīti assādavaseneva🔽na vaṭṭati, saddho pasanno ahosi khayaṃ gatoti evameva vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi asukā
analyzed: gatā ati evam eva vaṭṭati sūrakathā api nandimittaḥ nāma yodhaḥ sūraḥ ahosi iti assāda vasena iva  na vaṭṭati saddhaḥ pasannaḥ ahosi khayam gato ti evam eva vaṭṭati visikhākathā api asukā
translated: “Gone” is allowable only in the sense of “he was a hero” or “he was a good man.”🔽“He had faith and confidence” is allowable only in the sense of “he had faith and confidence and reached destruction of the cankers.”

original: visikhā suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthāti assādavaseneva na vaṭṭati, saddhā
analyzed: visikhā su niviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā sūrā samatthā ati assāda vasena iva na vaṭṭati saddhā
translated: “Such and such a street is well laid out, badly laid out, good, bad” is not allowable in the sense of “it is good to enjoy.”

original: pasannā khayaṃ gatā iccevaṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: pasannā khayam gatā icca evam vaṭṭati
translated: “He had faith and confidence and reached destruction of the cankers” is allowable in that sense.

original: Kumbhaṭṭhānakathāti kumbhaṭṭhānaudakatitthakathā vā vuccati kumbhadāsikathā vā. Sāpi
analyzed: kumbha ṭṭhāna kathā ati kumbha ṭṭhāna audaka tittha kathā vā vuccati kumbha dāsi kathā vā sā api
translated: “The water-place for the pots” is either a water-place for pots or a water-place for slave girls.

original: “pāsādikā naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati, saddhā pasannātiādinā
analyzed: pāsādikā naccitum gāyitum chekā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā iti ādinā
translated: “She was graceful, good at dancing and singing” is not allowable in the sense of “good to enjoy.”🔽“She had faith and confidence” is allowable in that sense.

original: nayeneva vaṭṭati. Pubbapetakathāti atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadisova vinicchayo.
analyzed: nayena iva vaṭṭati pubba peta kathā ati atīta ñāti kathā tattha vattamāna ñāti kathā sadisaḥ eva vinicchayaḥ
translated: “Talk about the past” is talk about what has happened. The exposition is like that for “talk about what is happening.”🔽“Miscellaneous talk” is talk about this and that, which is unconnected and pointless.

original: Nānattakathāti purimapacchimakathāvimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā niratthakakathā. Lokakkhāyikāti
analyzed: nānatta kathā ati purima pacchima kathā vimuttā avasesā nānā sabhāvā niratthaka kathā lokakkhāyikā ti
translated: “Stories about the world” is talk about the world’s end.

original: ayaṃ loko kena nimmito, asukena nāma nimmito, kākā setā aṭṭhīnaṃ setattā, bakā rattā
analyzed: ayam loko kena nimmitaḥ asukena nāma nimmitaḥ kākā setāḥ aṭṭhīnam setattāḥ bakāḥ rattāḥ
translated: “By whom was this world created? It was created by so-and-so.” “The crows are white because their bones are white. The herons are blue because their blood is blue.”

original: lohitassa rattattāti evamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā.🔽Samuddakkhāyikā nāma kasmā samuddo sāgaro, sāgaradevena khaṇitattā sāgaro, khato
analyzed: lohitassa evamādikā lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā  samuddakkhāyikāḥ nāma kasmā samuddaḥ sāgaraḥ sāgaradevena khaṇita ttā sāgaraḥ khataḥ
translated: Such talk is called “chatter about the world.”🔽“Stories about the ocean” are such as: “Why is the ocean called sāgara? Because the god Sāgara dug it.” “It is called samudda because the Buddha, raising his hand, pointed to it and said: ‘This is samudda.’“

original: meti hatthamuddāya niveditattā samuddoti evamādikā niratthakā samuddakkhāyikakathā.
analyzed: mā iti hattha muddāya nivedita ttā samuddaḥ ti evamādikā niratthakā samudda khāyika kathā
translated: Such purposeless talk about the ocean is called “stories about the ocean.”

original: Iti bhavo, iti abhavoti yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā.
analyzed: iti bhavaḥ iti abhavaḥ ti yam vā tam vā niratthaka kāraṇam vatvā iti bhava abhava kathā
translated: “Talk about becoming and non-becoming” is talk that occurs by giving some purposeless reason, such as: “It is like this, it is not like that, or it is like that, it is not like this.”

original: Ettha ca bhavoti sassataṃ, abhavoti ucchedaṃ. Bhavoti vaḍḍhi, abhavoti hāni. Bhavoti
analyzed: ettha ca bhavoti sassatam abhavoti ucchedam bhavoti vaḍḍhi abhavoti hāni bhavoti
translated: Here “becoming” is eternalism and “non-becoming” is annihilationism. “Becoming” is increase and “non-becoming” is decrease. “Becoming” is🔽sensual pleasure and “non-becoming” is self-mortification.

original: kāmasukhaṃ, abhavoti attakilamatho. Iti imāya chabbidhāya itibhavābhavakathāya saddhiṃ
analyzed: kāma sukham iti imāya chabbidhāya iti bhava abhava kathāya saddhim
translated: Together with this sixfold talk about becoming and non-becoming,🔽there are thirty-two kinds of “animal talk.”

original: bāttiṃsatiracchānakathā nāma hoti. Evarūpiṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentiyā nisinno hoti.
analyzed: bāttiṃsatiracchānakathā nāma hoti evarūpim tiracchānakatham kathentiyā nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: He sits down when they are talking like this.

original: Tato sandako paribbājako te paribbājake oloketvā – “ime paribbājakā ativiya aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: tatas sandakaḥ paribbājako te paribbājake oloketvā ime paribbājakāḥ ativiya aññamaññam
translated: Then the wanderer Sandaka, looking at those wanderers, thought: “These wanderers have no respect for one another,

original: agāravā appatissā, mayañca samaṇassa gotamassa pātubhāvato paṭṭhāya sūriyuggamane🔽khajjopanakūpamā jātā, lābhasakkāropi no parihīno. Sace pana imaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇo gotamo
analyzed: agāravāḥ appatissāḥ mayam ca samaṇassa gotamassa pātubhāvataḥ paṭṭhāya sūri yuggamane  jātāḥ lābha sakkāraḥ api no parihīnaḥ sace pana imam ṭhānam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ
translated: and since the manifestation of the recluse Gotama, we have become like a dish of curds at sunrise.🔽Our gains and fame have declined. But if the recluse Gotama or one of his disciples or even a lay follower of his should come here,

original: gotamasāvako vā gihiupaṭṭhākopi vāssa āgaccheyya, ativiya lajjanīyaṃ bhavissati.
analyzed: gotama sāvakaḥ vā gihi upaṭṭhākaḥ api vā asse āgaccheyya lajjanīyam bhavissati
translated: it would be a great embarrassment.

original: Parisadoso kho pana parisajeṭṭhakasseva upari ārohatī”ti ito cito ca vilokento theraṃ
analyzed: parisa dosaḥ kho pana parisa jeṭṭhakassa iva upari ārohati iti itas ca itas ca vilokentaḥ theram
translated: The fault of the assembly falls on the head of the chief of the assembly.” Looking here and there, he saw the Elder.

original: addasa. Tena vuttaṃ addasā kho sandako paribbājako…pe… tuṇhī ahesunti.
analyzed: addasa tena vuttam addasā kho sandako paribbājaka ope tuṇhī ahesunti
translated: Therefore it was said: “The wanderer Sandaka saw the venerable Ananda coming in the distance” … “and sat down in silence.”🔽There he instructed him, he taught him, he made him see, he made him penetrate, he made him realize.

original: Tattha saṇṭhapesīti sikkhāpesi, vajjamassā paṭicchādesi. Yathā suṭṭhapitā hoti, tathā
analyzed: tattha saṇṭhapesi iti sikkhāpesi vajjam assā paṭicchādesi yathā su ṭṭhapitā hoti tathā
translated: As he was well instructed, he was established thus.

original: naṃ ṭhapesi. Yathā nāma parisamajjhaṃ pavisanto puriso vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ nivāsanaṃ
analyzed: nam ṭhapesi yathā nāma parisa majjham pavisantaḥ puriso vajja paṭicchādana attham nivāsanaṃ
translated: As a man entering the midst of an assembly, in order to conceal his nakedness,

original: saṇṭhapeti, pārupanaṃ saṇṭhapeti, rajokiṇṇaṭṭhānaṃ puñchati, evamassā vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhapeti pārupanam saṇṭhapeti rajo kiṇṇa ṭṭhānam puñchati evam assā vajja paṭicchādana attham
translated: He spreads it out, he puts on the upper robe, he cleans the place where he has slept, in this way he conceals his offence.

original: “appasaddā bhonto”ti sikkhāpento yathā suṭṭhapitā hoti, tathā naṃ ṭhapesīti attho.
analyzed: appasaddāḥ bhonto ti sikkhāpentaḥ yathā su ṭṭhapitā hoti tathā nam ṭhapesi iti attho
translated: He trains them in the words, “Be quiet, venerable sirs,” and he establishes them in the way in which they have been trained.

original: Appasaddakāmāti appasaddaṃ icchanti, ekakā nisīdanti, ekakā tiṭṭhanti, na gaṇasaṅgaṇikāya
analyzed: appasadda kāmā ati appasaddam icchanti ekakāḥ nisīdanti ekakā tiṭṭhanti na gaṇa saṅgaṇikāya
translated: They desire quiet: they desire quiet, they sit down alone, they stand alone, they do not live in a crowd.

original: yāpenti. Appasaddavinītāti appasaddena niravena buddhena vinītā. Appasaddassa vaṇṇavādinoti
analyzed: yāpenti appasadda vinītā ati appasaddena niravena buddhena vinītāḥ appasaddassa vaṇṇa vādinaḥ
translated: They are trained in quiet: they are trained by the Buddha, who is quiet, who is free from noise, who is free from agitation, who is free from desire. They are speakers of the praise of quiet:

original: yaṃ ṭhānaṃ appasaddaṃ nissaddaṃ. Tassa vaṇṇavādino. Upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyāti idhāgantabbaṃ maññeyya.
analyzed: yam ṭhānam appasaddam nissaddam tassa vaṇṇa vādinaḥ upasaṅkamitabbam maññeyya ati idha āgantabbam maññeyya
translated: they are speakers of the praise of that place which is quiet, which is free from noise. They think that they should approach: they think that they should come here.

original: Kasmā panesa therassa upasaṅkamanaṃ paccāsīsatīti. Attano vuddhiṃ patthayamāno. Paribbājakā
analyzed: kasmā pana esa therassa upasaṅkamanam paccāsīsati iti attanaḥ vuddhim patthayamāno paribbājakā
translated: But why does he turn away from approaching the Elder? He does it desiring his own prosperity. Wanderers, it seems,

original: kira buddhesu vā buddhasāvakesu vā attano santikaṃ āgatesu – “ajja amhākaṃ santikaṃ
analyzed: kira buddhesu vā buddha sāvakesu vā attanaḥ santikam āgatesu ajja amhākam santikam
translated: when Buddhas or disciples of the Buddhas come into their presence, think: “Today we shall get

original: samaṇo gotamo āgato, sāriputto āgato, na kho panete yassa vā tassa vā santikaṃ gacchanti,
analyzed: samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ āgataḥ sāriputto āgataḥ na kho pana ete yassa vā tassa vā santikam gacchanti
translated: “The recluse Gotama has come, Sāriputta has come, but they do not go to anyone,

original: passatha amhākaṃ uttamabhāva”nti attano upaṭṭhākānaṃ santike attānaṃ ukkhipanti ucce
analyzed: passatha amhākam uttama bhāvanti attanaḥ upaṭṭhākānam santike attānam ukkhipanti ucce
translated: they do not come to anyone. Look at our high position!” and they exalt themselves and disparage others in the presence of their followers,

original: ṭhāne ṭhapenti. Bhagavatopi upaṭṭhāke gaṇhituṃ vāyamanti. Te kira bhagavato upaṭṭhāke
analyzed: ṭhāne ṭhapenti bhagavataḥ api upaṭṭhāke gaṇhitum vā āyamanti te kira bhagavataḥ upaṭṭhāke
translated: and they try to win over the Blessed One’s own followers. When they see the Blessed One’s followers,

original: disvā evaṃ vadanti – “tumhākaṃ satthā bhavaṃ gotamopi gotamassa sāvakāpi amhākaṃ🔽santikaṃ āgacchanti, mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ samaggā. Tumhe pana amhe akkhīhi passituṃ na
analyzed: disvā evam vadanti tumhākam satthā bhavam gotamaḥ api gotamassa sāvakā api amhākam  santikam āgacchanti mayam aññamaññam samaggā tumhe pana amhe akkhīhi passitum na
translated: they say: “Your teacher, Master Gotama, and your disciples come to us,

original: icchatha, sāmīcikammaṃ na karotha, kiṃ vo amhehi aparaddha”nti. Appekacce manussā
analyzed: icchatha sāmīci kammam na karotha kim vaḥ amhehi aparaddhanti appa ekacce manussā
translated: but we do not go to them. We are united, but you are not. You do not want to see us face to face, you do not do obeisance to us, you do not pay homage to us. What have we done to you?”

original: – “buddhāpi etesaṃ santikaṃ gacchanti, kiṃ amhāka”nti tato paṭṭhāya te disvā nappamajjanti.
analyzed: buddhāḥ api etesam santikam gacchanti kim amhākam ti tatas paṭṭhāya te disvā na pamajjanti
translated: Some people think: “Even the Buddhas go to them, so why should we not?” and from then on they do not neglect to see them.

original: Tuṇhī ahesunti sandakaṃ parivāretvā nissaddā nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: tuṇhī ahesunti sandakam parivāretvā nissaddāḥ nisīdiṃsu
translated: They were silent: they sat down silently, surrounding Sandaka.

original: 224. Svāgataṃ bhoto ānandassāti suāgamanaṃ bhoto ānandassa. Bhavante hi no āgate
analyzed: svāgatam bhoto ānandassa ati su āgamanam bhoto ānandassa bhavante hi naḥ āgate
translated: “Welcome, revered Ananda,” = “Welcome, revered Ananda, to you.” For when you come,

original: ānando hoti, gate sokoti dīpeti. Cirassaṃ khoti piyasamudācāravacanametaṃ. Thero
analyzed: ānandaḥ hoti gate sokaḥ ti dīpeti cirassam kho ti piya samudācāra vacanam etam theraḥ
translated: there is joy, and when you have gone, there is sorrow, is what is meant. “It is long since,” etc., is a polite way of saying “I am pleased.” But the elder

original: pana kālena kālaṃ paribbājakārāmaṃ cārikatthāya gacchatīti purimagamanaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pana kālena kālam paribbājaka ārāmam cārika atthāya gacchati iti purima gamanam gahetvā
translated: goes to the Wanderers’ Rest House from time to time for the sake of the four kinds of public service . Taking his previous visit as the basis,

original: evamāha. Evañca pana vatvā na mānatthaddho hutvā nisīdi, attano pana āsanā vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: evam āha evam ca pana vatvā na mānatthaddhaḥ hutvā nisīdi attano pana āsanā vuṭṭhāya
translated: he said “It is long since.” And after saying this, he did not sit down as one who is self-important, but he got up from his seat

original: taṃ āsanaṃ papphoṭetvā theraṃ āsanena nimantento nisīdatu bhavaṃ ānando, idamāsanaṃ paññattanti āha.
analyzed: tam āsanam papphoṭetvā theram āsanena nimantentaḥ nisīdatu bhavam ānandaḥ idam āsanam paññattanti āha
translated: and shook out his outer robe, and inviting the elder to sit down by making his own seat known to him, he said “Let the revered Ananda sit down; this seat is prepared.”

original: Antarākathā vippakatāti nisinnānaṃ vo ārambhato paṭṭhāya yāva mamāgamanaṃ etasmiṃ antare kā nāma kathā vippakatā, mamāgamanapaccayā katamā kathā pariyantaṃ na gatāti pucchati.🔽Atha paribbājako “niratthakakathāva esā nissārā vaṭṭasannissitā, na tumhākaṃ purato
analyzed: antarākathā vippakatā ti nisinnānam vaḥ ārambhataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva mama āgamanam etasmin antare kā nāma kathā vippakatā mama āgamana paccayā katamā kathā pariyantam na gatā ati pucchati 🔽atha paribbājakaḥ niratthaka kathāvā esā nissārā vaṭṭa sannissitā na tumhākam puratas
translated: “What was the conversation, friends?” = “What kind of conversation was there, friends, from the time I set out until I came here?” He asks this to find out whether the conversation had ended or not when he came.

original: vattabbataṃ arahatī”ti dīpento tiṭṭhatesā, bhotiādimāha. Nesā bhototi sace bhavaṃ🔽sotukāmo bhavissati, pacchāpesā kathā na dullabhā bhavissati, amhākaṃ panimāya attho
analyzed: vattabba tam arahati iti dīpentaḥ tiṭṭhatā isā bho ti ādim āha na isā bhoto ti sace bhavam  sotu kāmaḥ bhavissati pacchā apesā kathā na dullabhā bhavissati amhākam panimāya attho
translated: “It is worth listening to,” he said, “let it stand aside, good sir.🔽If you, good sir, are desirous of hearing it, this talk will not be hard to get later on. But we have no use for it.

original: natthi. Bhoto pana āgamanaṃ labhitvā aññadeva sukāraṇaṃ kathaṃ sotukāmamhāti dīpeti.
analyzed: natthi bhoto pana āgamanam labhitvā aññat eva su kāraṇam katham sotu kāmamhā ati dīpeti
translated: Having got your coming, good sir, we are desirous of hearing a talk on some other good reason.”

original: Tato dhammadesanaṃ yācanto sādhu vata bhavantaṃ ye vātiādimāha. Tattha ācariyaketi🔽ācariyasamaye. Anassāsikānīti assāsavirahitāni. Sasakkanti ekaṃsatthe nipāto, viññū
analyzed: tatas dhamma desanam yācantaḥ sādhu vata bhavantam ye vā iti ādim āha tattha ācariyaka iti  ācariya samaye anassāsikāni iti assāsa virahitāni ekaṃsa tthe nipātaḥ viññū
translated: Then, asking for a talk on Dhamma, he said, “Excellent, good sir, for those who are … ” . Herein, at the time of the teacher is ācariyake.🔽Not giving comfort is assāsavirahitāni . Sasakka is a nipāta in the sense of “one-sidedly”; the meaning is, a discerning person should not live one-sidedly.

original: puriso ekaṃseneva na vaseyyāti attho. Vasanto ca nārādheyyāti na sampādeyya, na paripūreyyāti
analyzed: purisaḥ ekaṃsena iva na vaseyya ati attho vasanto ca na ārādheyya ati na sampādeyya na paripūreyya ati
translated: And while living he would not succeed is that he would not accomplish, he would not fulfil, is what is meant.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ñāyaṃ dhammaṃ kusalanti kāraṇabhūtaṃ anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ dhammaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam hoti ñāyam dhammam kusalanti kāraṇa bhūtam anavajja ṭṭhena kusalam dhammam
translated: The Dhamma that is reason is kusala in the sense of blameless.

original: 225. Idhāti imasmiṃ loke. Natthi dinnantiādīni sāleyyakasutte vuttāni. Cātumahābhūtikoti
analyzed: idha āti imasmin loke na atthi dinna nti ādīni sāleyyaka sutte vuttāni cātumahābhūtikā ti
translated: Herein is in this world. There is no gift, etc., are stated in the Sāleyyaka Sutta . The four great entities is

original: catumahābhūtamayo. Pathavī pathavīkāyanti ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu bāhirapathavīdhātuṃ.🔽Anupetīti anuyāti. Anupagacchatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ, anugacchatītipi attho, ubhayenāpi
analyzed: catu mahābhūta mayaḥ pathavī pathavīkāyanti ajjhattikā pathavī dhātu bāhira pathavī dhātum  anupeti iti anuyāti anupagacchati iti tassa iva vevacanam anugacchati iti pi atthaḥ ubhayena api
translated: He is made up of the four great primaries. “Earth, earth-body”: the internal earth element, the external earth element.

original: upeti upagacchatīti dasseti. Āpādīsupi eseva nayo. Indriyānīti manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni🔽ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti. Āsandipañcamāti nipannamañcena pañcamā, mañco ceva, cattāro🔽mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti attho. Yāvāḷāhanāti yāva susānā. Padānīti🔽ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā ahosi, evaṃ dussīlotiādinā nayena pavattāni guṇapadāni. Sarīrameva🔽vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ. Kāpotakānīti kapotakavaṇṇāni, pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho.
analyzed: upeti upagacchati iti dasseti āpa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ indriyāni iti indriyāni  ākāsam pakkhandanti āsandi pañcamā ati nipanna mañcena pañcamāḥ mañcaḥ ca iva cattāro  mañca pāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā ca ati atthaḥ yāva āḷāhanā ati yāva susānā padāni iti  ayam evam sīlavā evam dussīlaḥ iti ādinā nayena pavattāni guṇa padāni sarīram eva  vā ettha padāni iti adhippetam kāpotakāni iti kapotaka vaṇṇāni pārāvata pakkha vaṇṇāni iti attho
translated: “Approaches”: goes along with, goes to. “Approaches” is a synonym for “goes to.” The meaning is, “goes along with.” The same method applies in the case of the other three great primaries. “The faculties”: the six faculties with the mind as the sixth.

analyzed: bhassantā ati bhasmantā ayam eva vā yam paheṇaka sakkāra ādi bhedam dinna dānam

original: sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānameva hoti, na tato paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchatīti attho.
analyzed: sabbam tat chārikā avasānam eva hoti na tato param phala dāyakam hutvā gacchati iti attho
translated: All that is only ash-remains, the meaning is, it does not go on to give fruit beyond that.

original: Dattupaññattanti dattūhi bālamanussehi paññattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – bālehi abuddhīhi
analyzed: dattu paññattanti dattūhi bāla manussehi paññattam idam vuttam hoti bālehi abuddhīhi
translated: ‘What is proclaimed by givers’: what is proclaimed by givers, by foolish ordinary people. This is what is said: this giving is proclaimed by the foolish, by the unintelligent,

original: paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ, na paṇḍitehi. Bālā denti, paṇḍitā gaṇhantīti dasseti. Atthikavādanti
analyzed: paññattam idam dānam na paṇḍitehi bālāḥ denti paṇḍitāḥ gaṇhanti iti dassa iti atthika vādanti
translated: not by the wise. It shows that the foolish give, the wise receive. ‘They speak of what is needed’:

original: atthi dinnaṃ dinnaphalanti imaṃ atthikavādaṃyeva vadanti tesaṃ tucchaṃ vacanaṃ musāvilāpo.
analyzed: atthi dinnam dinna phalanti imam atthika vādaṃ yeva vadanti tesam tuccham vacanam musāvilāpaḥ
translated: they speak only of this, namely, that what is given has a fruit of giving. Their words are empty, a lie, a deception.

original: Bāle ca paṇḍite cāti bālā ca paṇḍitā ca.🔽Akatena me ettha katanti mayhaṃ akateneva samaṇakammena ettha etassa samaye kammaṃ
analyzed: bāle ca paṇḍite ca ati bālā ca paṇḍitā ca  a katena me ettha katanti mayham a katena iva samaṇa kammena ettha etassa samaye kammam
translated: ‘Foolish and wise’: the foolish and the wise.

original: kataṃ nāma hoti, avusiteneva brahmacariyena vusitaṃ nāma hoti. Etthāti etasmiṃ samaṇadhamme.
analyzed: katam nāma hoti a vusitena iva brahmacariyena vusitam nāma hoti ettha ati etasmin samaṇa dhamme
translated: ‘By my not doing it here it is done’: by my not doing the recluse’s duties here, by my not doing the duties at this time, it is done, it is done as if it were done. By my not living the life of purity it is done as if it were lived. Here means in this recluse’s duties.

original: Samasamāti ativiya samā, samena vā guṇena samā. Sāmaññaṃ pattāti samānabhāvaṃ pattā.
analyzed: sama samā ati ativiya samā samena vā guṇena samā sāmaññam pattā ati samāna bhāvam pattā
translated: ‘The same’: the same, or even more than the same, by the same quality. ‘They have attained the state of recluses’: they have attained the state of equality.

original: 226. Karatotiādīni apaṇṇakasutte vuttāni. Tathā natthi hetūtiādīni.🔽228. Catutthabrahmacariyavāse akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā, evaṃ karohīti
analyzed: karato tiādīni apaṇṇaka sutte vuttāni tathā natthi hetu iti ādīni  catuttha brahmacariya vāse akaṭāti akatā akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānāḥ evam karohi iti
translated: “From the doing” , etc., are the words of the Apaṇṇaka Sutta . So too, “There is no cause” , etc.🔽“Not made” : not made. “Not fashioned” : not fashioned. The meaning is that they are not made by anyone saying, “Make it like this.”

original: kenaci kārāpitā na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā.🔽Keci animmitabbāti padaṃ vadanti, taṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ, na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ sandissati.
analyzed: kenacid kārāpitāḥ na honti iti atthaḥ a nimmitā ati iddhiyā api na nimmitā a nimmātā ati a nimmāpitā  keci a nimmitabbā ati padam vadanti tam na iva pāḷiyam na aṭṭhakathāyam sandissati
translated: “Uncreated” : not created even by supernormal power. “Not caused to be” : not caused to be.🔽Some read “not to be created” , but that is not found either in the text or in the commentaries.

original: Vañjhāti vañjhapasuvañjhatālādayo viya aphalā, kassaci ajanakāti attho. Etena pathavīkāyādīnaṃ
analyzed: vañjhā ati vañjha pasu vañjha tāla ādayaḥ viya aphalā kassaci ajanakā ati atthaḥ etena pathavī kāya ādīnam
translated: “Barren” : fruitless, like a barren woman, a barren cow, a barren palm, etc.; the meaning is that they do not produce anything. By this he rejects the idea that the earth-element, etc.,

original: rūpādijanakabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Pabbatakūṭā viya ṭhitāti kūṭaṭṭhā. Īsikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitāti
analyzed: rūpa ādi janaka bhāvam paṭikkhipati pabbata kūṭā viya ṭhitā ati kūṭa ṭṭhā īsika ṭṭhāyi ṭhitā ati
translated: produce visible form, etc. “Standing firm like a mountain peak” : standing firm like the peak of a mountain. “Standing firm like a post” :🔽standing firm like a post in a clump of muñja grass.

original: muñje īsikā viya ṭhitā. Tatrāyamadhippāyo – yamidaṃ jāyatīti vuccati, taṃ muñjato🔽īsikā viya vijjamānameva nikkhamatīti. “Esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā”tipi pāṭho, sunikhāto esikatthambho
analyzed: muñje īsikā viya ṭhitā tatra ayam adhippāyaḥ yam idam jāyati iti vuccati tam muñjataḥ 🔽īsikā viya vijjamānam eva nikkhamati iti pāṭhaḥ su nikhātaḥ esika tthambhaḥ
translated: The intention here is this: what is called “produced” comes forth only from what exists, like a post from a clump of muñja grass.

original: niccalo tiṭṭhati, evaṃ ṭhitāti attho. Ubhayenapi tesaṃ vināsābhāvaṃ dīpeti. Na iñjantīti🔽esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇāmentīti pakatiṃ na jahanti. Na
analyzed: niccalaḥ tiṭṭhati evam ṭhitā ati atthaḥ ubhayena api tesam vināsā bhāvam dīpeti na iñjanti iti  viya ṭhita ttāḥ na calanti na vipariṇāmenti iti pakatim na jahanti na
translated: ‘It stands firm’ means it stands still. Both words show that they cannot be destroyed. ‘They do not move’ means

original: aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti aññamaññaṃ na upahananti. Nālanti na samatthā.
analyzed: aññam aññam byābādhenti iti aññam aññam na upahananti na alanti na samatthā
translated: they do not move like a post. ‘They do not change’ means they do not lose their nature. ‘They do not oppress each other’ means they do not harm each other. ‘They do not quarrel’ means they are not able to.

original: Pathavīkāyotiādīsu pathavīyeva pathavīkāyo, pathavīsamūho vā. Tatthāti tesu jīvasattamesu🔽kāyesu. Natthi hantā vāti hantuṃ vā ghātetuṃ vā sotuṃ vā sāvetuṃ vā jānituṃ vā jānāpetuṃ
analyzed: pathavī kāyo ti ādīsu pathavīyā iva pathavī kāyo pathavī samūho vā tattha ati tesu jīva sattamesu  kāyesu natthi hantā vā ati hantum vā ghātetum vā sotum vā sāvetum vā jānitum vā jānāpetum
translated: In the passage beginning ‘The body of earth’ the body of earth is just earth, or a collection of earth. ‘There’ means among those seven bodies of living beings.

original: vā samattho nāma natthīti dīpeti. Sattannaṃtveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu pahaṭaṃ🔽satthaṃ muggarāsiādīnaṃ antarena pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena chiddena
analyzed: vā samatthaḥ nāma natthi iti dīpeti yathā muggara asi ādīsu pahaṭam  sattham mugga rāsi ādīnam antarena pavisati evam sattannam kāyānam antarena chiddena
translated: ‘There is no slayer’ shows that there is no one able to kill or to cause to kill, to hear or to cause to hear, to know or to cause to know. ‘Only in the seven bodies’ means that just as a blow with a weapon enters among a heap of clubs, etc.,

original: vivarena satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha “ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemī”ti kevalaṃ saññāmattameva
analyzed: vivarena sattham pavisati tattha aham imam jīvitā voropemi iti kevalam saññā mattam eva
translated: so a blow with a weapon enters through a hidden opening among the seven bodies. There, ‘I deprive this of life’ is merely a concept.

original: hotīti dasseti. Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ cuddasasatasahassāni
analyzed: hoti iti dasseti yoni pamukha sata sahassāni iti pamukha yonīnam uttama yonīnam cuddasa sata sahassāni
translated: He shows that it is so. “A hundred thousand kinds of wombs and doors”: there are a hundred thousand principal wombs, principal kinds of birth,

original: aññāni ca saṭṭhisatāni aññāni ca chasatāni. Pañca ca kammuno satānīti pañca kammasatāni
analyzed: aññāni ca saṭṭhi satāni aññāni ca cha satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni iti pañca kamma satāni
translated: and another six hundred and another six hundred. “Five hundred kinds of action”: there are five hundred kinds of action,

original: ca, kevalaṃ takkamattakena niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti. Pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammānītiādīsupi
analyzed: ca kevalam takka mattakena niratthakam diṭṭhim dīpeti pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni iti ādīsu pi
translated: he shows a view that is useless, merely a guess. In the case of “five kinds of action and three kinds of action,” etc.,

original: eseva nayo. Keci panāhu pañca kammānīti pañcindriyavasena bhaṇati. Tīṇīti kāyakammādivasenāti.
analyzed: keci pana āhu pañca kammāni iti pañca indriya vasena bhaṇati tīṇi iti kāya kamma ādi vasena ati
translated: the same method applies. But some say this: “He speaks of ‘five kinds of action’ in terms of the five faculties, and of ‘three kinds’ in terms of bodily action, etc.”

original: Kamme ca aḍḍhakamme cāti ettha panassa kāyakammañca vacīkammañca kammanti laddhi,
analyzed: kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca ati ettha panassa kāya kammañca vacī kammañca kammanti laddhi
translated: “Action and half-action”: here his opinion is that bodily action and verbal action are action,

original: manokammaṃ upaḍḍhakammanti. Dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati. Dvaṭṭhantarakappāti
analyzed: mano kammam upaḍḍha kammanti dvaṭṭhi paṭipadā ati dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadā ati vadati dvaṭṭha antara kappā ti
translated: and mental action is half-action. “The sixty-two paths”: he says there are sixty-two paths. “The sixty-two minor eons”:

original: ekasmiṃ kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti, ayaṃ pana aññe dve ajānanto evamāha.
analyzed: ekasmin kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappāḥ nāma honti ayam pana aññe dve a jānantaḥ evam āha
translated: in one eon there are sixty-four minor eons, but not knowing this, he says it is two.

original: Chaḷābhijātiyo apaṇṇakasutte vitthāritā.
analyzed: chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ apaṇṇaka sutte vitthāritā
translated: The six classes of beings are explained in detail in the Apaṇṇaka Sutta .

original: Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi khiḍḍābhūmi vīmaṃsakabhūmi ujugatabhūmi sekkhabhūmi🔽samaṇabhūmi jinabhūmi pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati. Tattha jātadivasato
analyzed: manda bhūmi khiḍḍā bhūmi vīmaṃsaka bhūmi uju gata bhūmi sekkha bhūmi  samaṇa bhūmi jina bhūmi panna bhūmi iti imāḥ aṭṭha purisa bhūmiyo ti vadati tattha jāta divasato
translated: “Eight human stages”: the stage of the dull, the stage of play, the stage of investigation, the stage of uprightness, the stage of the disciple,🔽the stage of the victor, the stage of the perfected being.

original: paṭṭhāya sattadivase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā. Ayaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya satta divase sambādha ṭṭhānataḥ nikkhanta ttā sattāḥ mandāḥ honti momūhāḥ ayam
translated: From the day of his birth, for seven days he is dull and confused because he has come out from a confined place.

original: mandabhūmīti vadati. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti
analyzed: manda bhūmiḥ iti vadati ye pana duggatitaḥ āgatāḥ honti te abhiṇham rodanti ca iva viravanti
translated: This is called the stage of the dull. But those who have come from a bad destination cry and wail frequently.

original: ca. Sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā anussaritvā hasanti. Ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: ca sugatitaḥ āgatā tam anussaritvā anussaritvā hasanti ayam khiḍḍābhūmi nāma mātā pitūnam
translated: Those who have come from a good destination laugh, remembering and recollecting that. This is called the stage of play.

original: hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ vīmaṃsakabhūmi🔽nāma. Padasāva gantuṃ samatthakālo ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippānaṃ sikkhanakālo sekkhabhūmi
analyzed: hattham vā pādam vā mañcam vā pīṭham vā gahetvā bhūmiyam pada nikkhipanam vīmaṃsaka bhūmi  nāma gantum samattha kālo uju gata bhūmi nāma sippānam sikkhana kālo sekkha bhūmi
translated: Taking hold of mother and father’s hand, foot, bed, or chair, and placing the foot on the ground, is called the stage of investigation.🔽The time when one is able to go on foot is called the stage of uprightness. The time of learning crafts is called the stage of the disciple.

original: nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajanakālo samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakālo
analyzed: nāma gharā nikkhamma pabbajana kālo samaṇa bhūmi nāma ācariyam sevitvā jānana kālo
translated: Leaving home and going forth is called the stage of the ascetic. Serving a teacher and learning is called the stage of the victor.

original: jinabhūmi nāma. Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhāti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati.
analyzed: jinabhūmi nāma bhikkhu ca pannakaḥ jinaḥ na kiñci āha ati evam alābhim samaṇam pannabhūmī iti vadati
translated: The “victorious ground” is the ground of a victor, a monk, and a victor, a recluse, does not say anything.

original: Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvasateti ekūnapaññāsa ājīvavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjasatāni.🔽Nāgāvāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsa indriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti
analyzed: ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīva satā iti ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīva vutti satāni paribbājaka satā iti paribbājaka pabbajja satāni  nāga āvāsa satā iti nāga maṇḍala satāni vīse indriya satā iti vīse indriya satāni tiṃse niraya satā iti
translated: “Fifty-nine hundred ways of livelihood”: fifty-nine hundred ways of making a living. “A hundred wanderers”: a hundred kinds of wandering orders.🔽“A hundred snake-infested places”: a hundred snake-rings. “Twenty hundred faculties”: twenty hundred faculties. “Three hundred hells”:

original: tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni. Hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni
analyzed: tiṃsa niraya satāni hattha piṭṭhi pāda piṭṭha ādīni
translated: three hundred hells. “The dust element”: he speaks with reference to the back of the hand, the back of the foot, etc., which are places for the scattering of dust.

original: sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya
analyzed: sandhāya vadati satta sandhāya
translated: “Seven conscious abodes”: he speaks with reference to the ox, the buffalo, the ass, the bird, the dog, the pig, and man.

original: vadati. Asaññīgabbhāti sāliyavagodhumamuggakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: vadati sāli yava godhuma mugga kaṅgu varaka kudrūsake sandhāya vadati
translated: “Seven unconscious abodes”: he speaks with reference to rice, barley, wheat, beans, millet, wild gram, and kidney-beans.

original: Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti nigaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta
analyzed: nigaṇṭhi gabbhā ati nigaṇṭhimhi jāta gabbhā ucchu veḷu naḷa ādayaḥ sandhāya vadati satta
translated: “The womb of the Niganthas”: he speaks with reference to those born in the womb of a Niganthi, such as the ucchu, the veḷunaḷa, etc.

original: devāti bahū devā, so pana sattāti vadati. Mānusāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Satta
analyzed: devā ati bahū devā saḥ pana sattā ati vadati mānusā api anantā saḥ sattā ati vadati satta
translated: ‘Gods’ are many gods, but he says ‘one being’. ‘Humans’ are also infinite, but he says ‘one being’. ‘Beings’

original: pisācāti pisācā mahantā, sattāti vadati.
analyzed: pisācā iti pisācā mahantā sattā iti vadati
translated: ‘Spirits’ are great spirits, but he says ‘one being’.

original: Sarāti mahāsarā. Kaṇṇamuṇḍa-rathakāra-anotatta-sīhapapātakuḷira-mucalinda-kuṇāladahe
analyzed: sarāti mahā sarā
translated: ‘Lakes’ are great lakes. He takes the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, Rathakāra, Anotatta, Sīhapapāta, Kuḷira, Mucalinda, and Kuṇāladahe

original: gahetvā vadati. Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni.
analyzed: gahetvā vadati pavuṭā ati gaṇṭhikā papātā ati mahā papātā papāta satāni iti khuddaka papāta satāni
translated: and says ‘one lake’. ‘Ponds’ are small ponds. ‘Great falls’ are great falls. ‘Hundreds of falls’ are hundreds of small falls.

original: Supināti mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ.
analyzed: supinā ati mahā supinā supina satāni iti khuddaka supina satāni mahākappinaḥ iti mahā kappānam
translated: ‘Dreams’ are great dreams. ‘Hundreds of dreams’ are hundreds of small dreams. ‘Great aeons’ are great aeons.

original: Ettha ekamhā sarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā nīharitvā🔽sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ekamhā sarā vassa sate vassa sate kusaggena ekam udaka bindum nīharitvā nīharitvā  sattakkhattum tamhi sare nirudake kate ekaḥ mahā kappaḥ iti vadati evarūpānam mahā kappānam
translated: Here, after removing one drop of water from a lake with a blade of grass every hundred years,🔽after seven times he says ‘that lake is empty’, and after removing four hundred and eighty-four thousand such great aeons,

original: caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bālā ca paṇḍitā ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa
analyzed: catur āsīti sata sahassāni khepetvā bālā ca paṇḍitā ca dukkha santam karonti iti ayam assa
translated: both the foolish and the wise make an end of suffering. This is his

original: laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira antarā sujjhituṃ na sakkoti, bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: laddhi paṇḍitaḥ api kira antarā sujjhitum na sakkoti bālaḥ api tatas uddham na gacchati
translated: The wise man, it seems, cannot purify himself in the middle, and the fool does not go beyond that.

original: Sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādisena vatena. Tapenāti
analyzed: sīlena ati acelaka sīlena vā aññena vā yena kenacid vatena ati tādisena vatena tapena ati
translated: By virtue: by the virtue of the naked ascetics or by any other kind of virtue. By austerity: by the austerity of the naked ascetics or by any other kind of austerity.

original: tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma yo “ahaṃ paṇḍito”ti antarā visujjhati. Paripakkaṃ
analyzed: tapo kammena a paripakkam paripāca iti nāma yaḥ aham paṇḍitaḥ iti antarā visujjhati paripakkam
translated: He brings to maturity what is unmatured: the one who thinks “I am wise” and in the middle becomes purified.

original: phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo “ahaṃ bālo”ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: phussa phussa byantim karoti nāma yaḥ aham bālaḥ ti vutta parimāṇam kālam atikkamitvā
translated: He makes what is matured to be felt immediately: the one who thinks “I am a fool” and goes beyond the stated measure.

original: yāti. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti. Doṇamiteti
analyzed: yā ati ha ivam natthi iti evam natthi tat hi ubhayam pi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti doṇa mitā iti
translated: There is no such thing: he shows that there is no such thing as that, for neither of them can do that.🔽Measured by a bushel: as if measured by a bushel. Pleasure and pain: pleasure and pain.

original: doṇena mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena🔽katapariyanto. Natthi hāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni. Na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa
analyzed: doṇena mitam viya sukha dukkha iti sukha dukkham pariyantaka tā iti vutta parimāṇena kālena  kata pariyantaḥ na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhane iti na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhanāni na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa
translated: Measured by a limit: measured by the stated measure of time.🔽There is no increase or decrease: there is no increase or decrease. The wise man’s does not decrease in saṃsāra, and the fool’s does not increase, is the meaning.

original: hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā, hāpanavaḍḍhanānamevetaṃ
analyzed: hāyati na bālassa vaḍḍhati iti attho ukkaṃsa avakaṃsa iti ukkaṃsa avakaṃsāḥ hāpana vaḍḍhanānam eva etam
translated: By the addition or subtraction of a fraction: by the addition or subtraction of a fraction. The addition or subtraction

original: vevacanaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento seyyathāpi nāmātiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti
analyzed: vevacanam idāni tam attham upamāya sādhentaḥ seyyathā api nāma ati ādim āha tattha sutta guḷa iti
translated: and a synonym. Now, in order to establish that meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as, friend, a man might throw down” , etc. Herein, a ball of thread is

original: veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷaṃ. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā
analyzed: veṭhetvā kata sutta guḷam nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti iti pabbate vā rukkha gge vā ṭhatvā
translated: a ball of thread made by twisting together . As it is being unwound it goes,

original: khittaṃ suttapamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānaṃ gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattha tiṭṭhati na gacchati.
analyzed: khittam sutta pamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānam gacchati sutte khīṇe tattha tiṭṭhati na gacchati
translated: but when the thread is finished it stands there and does not go.

original: Evamevaṃ vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
analyzed: evam evam vutta kālataḥ uddham na gacchati iti dasseti
translated: He shows that it does not go beyond the time stated.

original: 229. Kimidanti kimidaṃ tava aññāṇaṃ, kiṃ sabbaññu nāma tvanti evaṃ puṭṭho samāno niyativāde pakkhipanto suññaṃ me agārantiādimāha.
analyzed: kim idam ti kim idam tava aññāṇam kim sabbaññu nāma tvanti evam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ niyati vāde pakkhipantaḥ suññam me agāra nti ādim āha
translated: What is this? What is your ignorance? Are you not omniscient? ” When asked thus, he, including himself in the doctrine of fatalism, said, “My house is empty” , etc.

original: 230. Anussaviko hotīti anussavanissito hoti. Anussavasaccoti savanaṃ saccato gahetvā ṭhito. Piṭakasampadāyāti vaggapaṇṇāsakāya piṭakaganthasampattiyā.
analyzed: anussavikaḥ hoti iti anussava nissitaḥ hoti anussava sacco ti savanam saccataḥ gahetvā ṭhitaḥ piṭaka sampadāya ati vagga paṇṇāsakāya piṭaka gantha sampattiyā
translated: He is a traditionalist, he is one who is dependent on tradition. He is one who holds that what is heard is true, he is one who stands by what is heard as true. By the fulfilment of the Piṭaka is by the fulfilment of the Piṭaka-collection, by the fulfilment of the Piṭaka-text.

original: 232. Mandoti mandapañño. Momūhoti atimūḷho. Vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjatīti vācāya vikkhepaṃ
analyzed: mandaḥ iti manda paññaḥ momūhaḥ ti ati mūḷhaḥ vācā vikkhepam āpajjati iti vācāya vikkhepam
translated: He is dull, he is of dull understanding. He is confused, he is very confused. He falls into verbal proliferation, he falls into verbal proliferation.

original: āpajjati. Kīdisaṃ? Amarāvikkhepaṃ, apariyantavikkhepanti attho. Atha vā amarā nāma
analyzed: āpajjati kīdisam amarā vikkhepam apariyanta vikkhepam ti attho atha vā amarā nāma
translated: What kind? The distraction of the endless round of rebirths, the meaning is, the distraction of the endless round of rebirths. Or else, the endless round of rebirths is called “the endless round of rebirths” and “the endless round of rebirths” is the distraction.

original: macchajāti. Sā ummujjananimmujjanādivasena udake sandhāvamānā gahetuṃ na sakkāti
analyzed: macchajāti sā ummujjana nimmujjana ādi vasena udake sandhāvamānā gahetum na
translated: What kind? The ‘wandering beyond the grave’: the meaning is, the wandering without limit. Or alternatively, the ‘wandering beyond the grave’ is a kind of fish. It is not possible to catch it because it keeps darting up and down in the water.

original: evameva ayampi vādo ito cito ca sandhāvati, gāhaṃ na upagacchatīti amarāvikkhepoti
analyzed: evam eva ayam pi vādaḥ itas citas ca sandhāvati gāham na upagacchati iti amarā vikkhepaḥ ti
translated: So too, this view keeps darting hither and thither and does not come to the fore;

original: vuccati. Taṃ amarāvikkhepaṃ.🔽Evantipi me notiādīsu idaṃ kusalanti puṭṭho “evantipi me no”ti vadati, tato kiṃ akusalanti
analyzed: vuccati tam amarā vikkhepam  me no ti ādīsu idam kusalanti puṭṭhaḥ me no ti vadati tato kim akusalanti
translated: hence it is called the ‘wandering beyond the grave.’

original: vutte “tathātipi me no”ti vadati, kiṃ ubhayato aññathāti vutte “aññathātipi me no”ti🔽vadati, tato tividhenāpi na hotīti te laddhīti vutte “notipi me no”ti vadati, tato
analyzed: vutte tathā atipi me no ti vadati kim ubhayatas aññathā ati vutte aññathā atipi me no ti  vadati tatas tividhena api na hoti iti te laddhi iti vutte me no ti vadati tatas
translated: ‘Thus’ : when asked, ‘Is it profitable?’ he says, ‘Thus it is not for me.’ Then, when asked, ‘Is it unprofitable?’ he says, ‘Thus it is not for me.’ When asked, ‘Is it otherwise than both?’ he says, ‘Otherwise it is not for me.’🔽Then, when asked, ‘Is it not that you have no settled view at all?’ he says, ‘It is not for me.’

original: kiṃ no noti te laddhīti vutte “no notipi me no”ti vikkhepamāpajjati, ekasmimpi pakkhe
analyzed: kim no noti te laddhi iti vutte no no ti pi me noti vikkhepam āpajjati ekasmim pi pakkhe
translated: Then, when asked, ‘Is it not that you have no settled view at all?’ he says, ‘It is not for me.’ He falls into the ‘wandering beyond the grave.’ He has no settled view even about one of the three alternatives.

original: na tiṭṭhati. Nibbijja pakkamatīti attanopi esa satthā avassayo bhavituṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: na tiṭṭhati nibbijja pakkamati iti attanaḥ api esa satthā avassayaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti
translated: He does not stand firm. He goes away disappointed: he is disappointed, thinking, “If he cannot be a support to himself,

original: mayhaṃ kiṃ sakkhissatīti nibbinditvā pakkamati. Purimesupi anassāsikesu eseva nayo.🔽234. Sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjitunti yathā pubbe gihibhūto sannidhiṃ katvā vatthukāme
analyzed: mayham kim sakkhissati iti nibbinditvā pakkamati purimesu pi anassāsikesu esa eva nayaḥ  sannidhi kārakam kāme paribhuñjitum ti yathā pubbe gihi bhūtaḥ sannidhim katvā vatthu kāme
translated: what can he do for me?” The same method applies in the case of the other three kinds of non-returners who do not make an effort.🔽He does not enjoy sensual pleasures by hoarding: just as formerly, as a layman, he enjoyed sensual pleasures by hoarding such things as

original: paribhuñjati, evaṃ tilataṇḍulasappinavanītādīni sannidhiṃ katvā idāni paribhuñjituṃ
analyzed: paribhuñjati evam tila taṇḍula sappi navanīta ādīni sannidhim katvā idāni paribhuñjitum
translated: sesame seed, rice, and buffaloes, so now he is unable to enjoy sensual pleasures by hoarding such things as sesame seed, rice, ghee, and molasses.

original: abhabboti attho. Nanu ca khīṇāsavassa vasanaṭṭhāne tilataṇḍulādayo paññāyantīti.
analyzed: abhabbaḥ ti attho nanu ca khīṇāsavassa vasana ṭṭhāne tila taṇḍula ādayo paññāyanti iti
translated: But surely sesame seed, rice, etc., are found in the places where the cankers have been destroyed?

original: No na paññāyanti, na panesa te attano atthāya ṭhapeti, aphāsukapabbajitādīnaṃ atthāya
analyzed: no na paññāyanti na pana esa te attanaḥ atthāya ṭhapeti a phāsuka pabbajita ādīnam atthāya
translated: They are found, but he does not set them aside for his own use. He sets them aside for the use of those who have gone forth into homelessness and are uncomfortable,

original: ṭhapeti. Anāgāmissa kathanti. Tassāpi pañca kāmaguṇā sabbasova pahīnā, dhammena pana
analyzed: ṭhapeti anāgāmissa kathanti tassa api pañca kāmaguṇā sabbaso va pahīnā dhammena pana
translated: and so on. As to the non-returner who is a once-returner: for him the five cords of sense desire are all abandoned. But he uses what he has received according to Dhamma,

original: laddhaṃ vicāretvā paribhuñjati.
analyzed: laddham paribhuñjati
translated: examining whether it is allowable or not.

original: 236. Puttamatāya puttāti so kira imaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā ājīvakā matā nāmāti saññī hutvā🔽evamāha. Ayañhettha attho – ājīvakā matā nāma, tesaṃ mātā puttamatā hoti, iti ājīvakā
analyzed: putta matāya putta ati so kira imam dhammam sutvā ājīvakāḥ matāḥ nāma ati saññī hutvā  evam āha ayam ha ittha attho ājīvakāḥ matāḥ nāma tesam mātā putta matā hoti iti ājīvakā
translated: ‘Sons of their mothers’: it seems that on hearing this Dhamma he thought that the Ājīvaka ascetics were dead,

original: puttamatāya puttā nāma honti. Samaṇe gotameti samaṇe gotame brahmacariyavāso atthi,🔽aññattha natthīti dīpeti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: puttamatāya puttāḥ nāma honti samaṇe gotama iti samaṇe gotame brahmacariya vāsaḥ atthi  aññattha natthi iti dīpeti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: and so he said, ‘They are sons of their mothers.’ The meaning here is this: the Ājīvaka ascetics are dead, their mother is their motherhood,🔽so the Ājīvaka ascetics are sons of their mothers. ‘The life of purity’: there is the life of purity in the recluse Gotama,

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya🔽Sandakasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽7. Mahāsakuludāyisuttavaṇṇanā🔽237. Evaṃ me sutanti mahāsakuludāyisuttaṃ. Tattha moranivāpeti tasmiṃ ṭhāne morānaṃ🔽abhayaṃ ghosetvā bhojanaṃ adaṃsu. Tasmā taṃ ṭhānaṃ moranivāpoti saṅkhaṃ gataṃ. Annabhāroti🔽ekassa paribbājakassa nāmaṃ. Tathā varadharoti. Aññe cāti na kevalaṃ ime tayo, aññepi
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya 🔽sandaka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽       🔽evam me sutanti mahā sakuludāyi suttam tattha mora nivāpa iti tasmim ṭhāne 🔽abhayam ghosetvā bhojanam tasmai tam ṭhānam saṅkham gatam anna bhārā iti 🔽ekassa paribbājakassa nāmam tathā varadharo ti aññe ca ati na kevalam ime tayo aññe pi
translated: but not elsewhere, is what he implies. The rest is clear throughout.

original: abhiññātā bahū paribbājakā. Appasaddassa vaṇṇavādīti idha appasaddavinītoti avatvāva
analyzed: abhiññātāḥ bahū paribbājakāḥ appasaddassa vaṇṇa vādī iti idha appasadda vinītaḥ iti avatvā ava
translated: “He is a speaker of what is praised as peaceful”: here, without saying “he is one who has trained in what is praised as peaceful,”

analyzed: idam vuttam kasmā na hi bhagavā aññena vinītaḥ ti
translated: this is said. Why? Because the Blessed One is not trained by another.

original: 238. Purimānīti hiyyodivasaṃ upādāya purimāni nāma honti, tato paraṃ purimatarāni.
analyzed: purimāni iti hiyyodivasam upādāya purimāni nāma honti tatas param purimatarāni
translated: “The former”: those that are prior are called “the former” in reference to yesterday and the day before. Those that are prior to that are “the still former.”

original: Kutūhalasālāyanti kutūhalasālā nāma paccekasālā natthi, yattha pana nānātitthiyā
analyzed: kutūhalasālāyanti kutūhalasālāḥ nāma paccekasālā natthi yattha pana nānā titthiyā
translated: “The hall of the assembly of wanderers”: there is no separate hall called “the hall of the assembly of wanderers.” But where various sectarians

analyzed: samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ nānāvidham katham sā bahūnam ayam kim vadati ayam
translated: monks and brahmans carry on various discussions, that is called “the hall of the assembly of wanderers” because it is a place for the arising of the curiosity of many, thinking “What is this one saying?

original: kiṃ vadatī”ti kutūhaluppattiṭṭhānato “kutūhalasālā”ti vuccati. “Kotūhalasālā”tipi
analyzed: kim vadati iti kutūhala uppatti ṭṭhānato kutūhala sālā ati vuccati kotūhala sālā atipi
translated: What is this one saying?” The reading “kotūhalasālā” is also found.

original: pāṭho. Lābhāti ye evarūpe samaṇabrāhmaṇe daṭṭhuṃ pañhaṃ pucchituṃ dhammakathaṃ vā🔽nesaṃ sotuṃ labhanti, tesaṃ aṅgamagadhānaṃ ime lābhāti attho.
analyzed: ye evarūpe samaṇa brāhmaṇe daṭṭhum pañham pucchitum dhamma katham vā  na esam sotum labhanti tesam aṅga magadhānam ime attho
translated: “Gain”: the meaning is that the people of Aṅga and Magadha gain the opportunity to see such monks and brahmans, to ask them questions, and to listen to their discourses.

original: Saṅghinotiādīsu pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto saṅgho etesaṃ atthīti saṅghino. Sveva gaṇo
analyzed: saṅghino ti ādīsu pabbajita samūha saṅkhātaḥ saṅgho etesam atthi iti saṅghino su eva gaṇaḥ
translated: “Belonging to the Community”: they have the Community, which is a collection of those who have gone forth, so they belong to the Community.

original: etesaṃ atthīti gaṇino. Ācārasikkhāpanavasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyāti gaṇācariyā.🔽Ñātāti paññātā pākaṭā. Yathābhuccaguṇehi ceva ayathābhūtaguṇehi ca samuggato yaso
analyzed: etesam atthi iti gaṇinaḥ ācāra sikkhāpana vasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyā ati gaṇa ācariyā  ñātā ati paññātā pākaṭā yathābhucca guṇehi ca iva a yathābhūta guṇehi ca samuggataḥ yaso
translated: They are called “having a following” because they have a following. They are called “teachers of a following” because they are teachers of that following by teaching it the training in the life of purity.🔽They are called “famous” because they are well known and renowned.🔽They are called “glorious” because they have glory.

original: etesaṃ atthīti yasassino. Pūraṇādīnañhi “appiccho santuṭṭho, appicchatāya vatthampi
analyzed: etesam atthi iti yasassinaḥ pūraṇa ādīnam hi appicchaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ appiccha tāya
translated: For the glory of Pūraṇa Kassapa, etc., has arisen through such qualities as “He is a man of few wants” and “He is content” and “Because of his fewness of wants he does not even wear a waist band” ,

original: na nivāsetī”tiādinā nayena yaso samuggato, tathāgatassa “itipi so bhagavā”tiādīhi
analyzed: na nivāseti itiādinā nayena samuggataḥ tathāgatassa so bhagavā atiādīhi
translated: while the glory of the Tathāgata has arisen through such qualities as “He is the Tathāgata, accomplished and fully enlightened” ,🔽through his real qualities.

original: yathābhūtaguṇehi. Titthakarāti laddhikarā. Sādhusammatāti ime sādhū sundarā sappurisāti
analyzed: yathā bhūta guṇehi titthakarā ati laddhi karā sādhu sammatā ati ime sādhū sundarā sappurisā ati
translated: They are called “founders of sects” because they are founders of doctrines.

original: evaṃ sammatā. Bahujanassāti assutavato ceva andhabālaputhujjanassa vibhāvino ca paṇḍitajanassa.🔽Tattha titthiyā bālajanassa evaṃ sammatā, tathāgato paṇḍitajanassa. Iminā nayena
analyzed: evam sammatā bahu janassa ati a sutavataḥ ca iva andha bāla puthujjanassa vibhāvino ca paṇḍita janassa  tattha titthiyāḥ bāla janassa evam sammatā tathāgataḥ paṇḍita janassa iminā nayena
translated: They are called “honoured by the many” because they are honoured by the many, both by the ignorant, the witless, the average person, and by the wise, the clever, the discerning.🔽Herein, the sectarians are honoured by the ignorant, the Tathāgata by the wise.

original: pūraṇo kassapo saṅghītiādīsu attho veditabbo. Bhagavā pana yasmā aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇāni
analyzed: pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ saṅghī iti ādīsu atthaḥ veditabbo bhagavā pana yasmai aṭṭhatiṃsa ārammaṇāni
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in the case of the words “Pūraṇa Kassapa is a saint” , etc.

original: vibhajanto bahūni nibbānaotaraṇatitthāni akāsi, tasmā “titthakaro”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vibhajantaḥ bahūni nibbāna otaraṇa titthāni akāsi tasmā titthakaro ti vattum vaṭṭati
translated: He made many a ford leading to Nibbāna. Therefore it is proper to say that he was a founder of a sect.

original: Kasmā panete sabbepi tattha osaṭāti? Upaṭṭhākarakkhaṇatthañceva lābhasakkāratthañca.
analyzed: kasmā pana ete sabbe pi tattha osaṭā ti upaṭṭhāka rakkhaṇa attham ca iva lābha sakkāra ttham ca
translated: Why did all these come to be called “sectarians”? For the sake of protection and support and for the sake of gain and honour.

analyzed: tesam hi evam hoti amhākam upaṭṭhākā samaṇam gotamam saraṇam gaccheyyum te ca  rakkhissāma samaṇassa ca gotamassa upaṭṭhāke sakkāram karonte disvā amhākam pi upaṭṭhākā
translated: For they thought thus: “Our supporters might go over to the recluse Gotama and

original: amhākaṃ sakkāraṃ karissantī”ti. Tasmā yattha yattha bhagavā osarati, tattha tattha sabbe osaranti.
analyzed: amhākam sakkāram karissanti iti tasmai yattha yattha bhagavā osarati tattha tattha sabbe osaranti
translated: we should then lose them. But if we go over to the recluse Gotama, our supporters will follow us and go over to us.” Therefore wherever the Exalted One went, all these went too.

original: 239. Vādaṃ āropetvāti vāde dosaṃ āropetvā. Apakkantāti, apagatā, keci disaṃ pakkantā,
analyzed: vādam āropetvā ati vāde dosam āropetvā apakkantā ati apagatā keci disam pakkantā
translated: Having raised a point of controversy: having raised a fault in the doctrine. They have gone away: they have departed. Some have gone to other lands,

original: keci gihibhāvaṃ pattā, keci imaṃ sāsanaṃ āgatā. Sahitaṃ meti mayhaṃ vacanaṃ sahitaṃ
analyzed: gihi bhāvam pattā keci imam sāsanam āgatā sahitam mā iti vacanam sahitam
translated: some have become householders, and some have come into this Dispensation. My words are coherent: my words are coherent,

original: siliṭṭhaṃ, atthayuttaṃ kāraṇayuttanti attho. Asahitaṃ teti tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ asahitaṃ.
analyzed: siliṭṭham attha yuttam kāraṇa yuttam ti attho asahitam te iti tuyham vacanam asahitam
translated: connected, related, and meaningful. They are not incoherent, unconnected, unrelated, and meaningless, as are your words.

original: Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti yaṃ tuyhaṃ dīgharattāciṇṇavasena suppaguṇaṃ, taṃ mayhaṃ🔽ekavacaneneva viparāvattaṃ viparivattitvā ṭhitaṃ, na kiñci jātanti attho. Āropito
analyzed: adhiciṇṇam te viparāvattanti yam tuyham dīgha ratta āciṇṇa vasena su ppaguṇam tam mayham  ekavacanena iva viparāvattam viparivattitvā ṭhitam na kiñci jātanti atthaḥ āropito
translated: “What you have long practised has turned away from you”: what you have long practised and is well-practised for you,

original: te vādoti mayā tava vāde doso āropito. Cara vādappamokkhāyāti dosamocanatthaṃ cara
analyzed: te vādaḥ iti mayā tava vāde dosaḥ āropito cara vāda ppamokkhāya ati dosa mocana attham cara
translated: that has turned away from you, has turned away and stands by me, the meaning is, nothing has been lost. “Your doctrine has been overthrown”: I have overthrown your doctrine. “Go and free your doctrine”: go and wander about for the purpose of freeing your doctrine,

original: vicara, tattha tattha gantvā sikkhāti attho. Nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti atha sayaṃ
analyzed: vicara tattha tattha gantvā sikkha ati attho nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosi iti atha sayam
translated: go here and there and train, is the meaning. “Or if you can, free yourself”: if you can,

original: pahosi, idāneva nibbeṭhehi. Dhammakkosenāti sabhāvakkosena.
analyzed: pahosi idānā iva nibbeṭhehi dhamma kkosena ati sabhā vakkosena
translated: free yourself right now. “With a doctrine-covering”: with a covering of doctrine.

original: 240. Taṃ no sossāmāti taṃ amhākaṃ desitaṃ dhammaṃ suṇissāma. Khuddamadhunti khuddakamakkhikāhi🔽kataṃ daṇḍakamadhuṃ. Anelakanti niddosaṃ apagatamacchikaṇḍakaṃ. Pīḷeyyāti dadeyya.
analyzed: tam naḥ sossāma ati tam amhākam desitam dhammam suṇissāma khudda madhunti khuddaka makkhikāhi  katam daṇḍaka madhum niddosam apagatam acchikaṇḍakam pīḷeyya ati dadeyya
translated: “We will listen to that”: we will listen to the doctrine taught by you. “Honey made by bees”: honey made by small bees.🔽“Without poison”: without poison, without the husk of fish-bones. “Give”: give.

original: Paccāsīsamānarūpoti pūretvā nu kho no bhojanaṃ dassatīti bhājanahattho paccāsīsamāno
analyzed: paccāsīsamāna rūpaḥ ti pūretvā nu kho naḥ bhojanam dassati iti bhājana hatthaḥ paccāsīsamānaḥ
translated: “As if we were to be filled”: with the thought “Will he give us food after filling us up?” with a bowl in his hand he would be filled up.

original: paccupaṭṭhito assa. Sampayojetvāti appamattakaṃ vivādaṃ katvā.
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhitaḥ assa sampayojetvā ati appamattakam vivādam katvā
translated: He would be ready to go. Having made an agreement: having made a small agreement.🔽With another who is inferior: with one who is inferior and weak.

original: 241. Itarītarenāti lāmakalāmakena. Pavivittoti idaṃ paribbājako kāyavivekamattaṃ sandhāya vadati, bhagavā pana tīhi vivekehi vivittova.
analyzed: itarītarena ati lāmaka lāmakena pavivittaḥ ti idam paribbājako kāya viveka mattam sandhāya vadati bhagavā pana tīhi vivekehi vivittaḥ uva
translated: Secluded: the wanderer spoke of seclusion of the body only, but the Blessed One is secluded by the three kinds of seclusion.

original: 242. Kosakāhārāpīti dānapatīnaṃ ghare aggabhikkhāṭhapanatthaṃ khuddakasarāvā honti,
analyzed: kosaka āhārā api iti dānapatīnam ghare agga bhikkhā ṭhapana attham khuddaka sarāvāḥ honti
translated: With a store of alms rice: there are small pots for the purpose of setting aside the chief alms food in the houses of the donors,

original: dānapatino aggabhattaṃ vā tattha ṭhapetvā bhuñjanti, pabbajite sampatte taṃ bhattaṃ🔽tassa denti. Taṃ sarāvakaṃ kosakoti vuccati. Tasmā ye ca ekeneva bhattakosakena yāpenti,🔽te kosakāhārāti. Beluvāhārāti beluvamattabhattāhārā. Samatittikanti oṭṭhavaṭṭiyā
analyzed: dānapatino agga bhattam vā tattha ṭhapetvā bhuñjanti pabbajite sampatte tam bhattam  tassa denti tam sarāvakam kosako ti vuccati tasmā ye ca ekena iva bhatta kosakena yāpenti  te kosaka āhārā ati beluva āhārā ati beluva mattabhatta āhārā oṭṭha vaṭṭiyā
translated: and the donors either set aside the chief alms food there or, when the alms food is distributed, they give it to him. That pot is called a store. Therefore those who live on a single store of alms food

analyzed: heṭṭhima lekhā samam iminā dhammena ati iminā appāhāra tā dhammena ettha pana sabba ākārena eva
translated: are called “store-food eaters.” With a store of fruit: with a store of a measure of fruit. With a store of edible leaves: with a store of a measure of edible leaves. With a store of rice powder: with a store of a measure of rice powder. With a store of cotton: with a store of a measure of cotton. With a store of hemp: with a store of a measure of hemp.
