With a store of sand: with a store of a measure of sand. With a store of pebbles: with a store of a measure of pebbles. With a store of earth: with a store of a measure of earth. With a store of

original: bhagavā anappāhāroti na vattabbo. Padhānabhūmiyaṃ chabbassāni appāhārova ahosi, verañjāyaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā anappāhāro ti na vattabbo padhāna bhūmiyam cha bassāni appāhāraḥ va ahosi verañjāyam
translated: The Blessed One should not be spoken of as one who eats little. For six years he was one who ate little on the plane of striving.

original: tayo māse patthodaneneva yāpesi pālileyyakavanasaṇḍe tayo māse bhisamuḷāleheva yāpesi.
analyzed: tayaḥ māse patthodanena iva yāpesi pālileyyaka vana saṇḍe tayaḥ māse bhisa muḷālehā iva yāpesi
translated: The Blessed One should not be called one who eats little. For six years he ate little on the plane of preparation. For three months at Verañjā he lived on a harvest-feast of rice gruel. For three months in the Pālileyyaka jungle thicket he lived on a harvest-feast of tubers.

original: Idha pana etamatthaṃ dasseti – “ahaṃ ekasmiṃ kāle appāhāro ahosiṃ, mayhaṃ pana sāvakā🔽dhutaṅgasamādānato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ na bhindantī”ti. Tasmā yadi te iminā
analyzed: idha pana etam attham dasseti aham ekasmin kāle appāhāraḥ ahosim mayham pana sāvakā  dhutaṅga samādānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam dhutaṅgam na bhindanti iti tasmai yadi te iminā
translated: But here the meaning is to be regarded in this way: “At one time I ate little, but my disciples🔽do not break their ascetic practice for as long as they live from the time they undertake it.

original: dhammena sakkareyyuṃ, mayā hi te visesatarā. Añño ceva pana dhammo atthi, yena maṃ
analyzed: dhammena sakkareyyum mayā hi te visesatarāḥ añño ca iva pana dhammo atthi yena mama
translated: So if they should honour me for this quality, they should honour those who surpass me in this respect. But there is another quality for which they honour me.”

original: te sakkarontīti dasseti. Iminā nayena sabbavāresu yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: te sakkaronti iti dassā iti iminā nayena sabba vāresu yojanā veditabbā
translated: This is how the construction should be understood in all the cases.

original: Paṃsukūlikāti samādinnapaṃsukūlikaṅgā. Lūkhacīvaradharāti satthasuttalūkhāni cīvarāni
analyzed: paṃsukūlikā ati samādinna paṃsukūlikaṅgā lūkha cīvara dharā ati sattha sutta lūkhāni cīvarāni
translated: “Rags-robe” means one who has taken up the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice. “Worn-out clothes-wearer” means one who wears clothes that are worn out by being coarse and thin. “Rag-heap” means pieces of cloth devoid of ends,

original: dhārayamānā. Nantakānīti antavirahitāni vatthakhaṇḍāni, yadi hi nesaṃ anto bhaveyya,
analyzed: dhārayamānāḥ nantakāni iti anta virahitāni vattha khaṇḍāni yadi hi na isam antaḥ bhaveyya
translated: for if they had ends, they would not be suitable for a monk.

original: pilotikāti saṅkhaṃ gaccheyyuṃ. Uccinitvāti phāletvā dubbalaṭṭhānaṃ pahāya thiraṭṭhānameva🔽gahetvā. Alābulomasānīti alābulomasadisasuttāni sukhumānīti dīpeti. Ettāvatā ca satthā🔽cīvarasantosena asantuṭṭhoti na vattabbo. Atimuttakasusānato hissa puṇṇadāsiyā pārupitvā🔽pātitasāṇapaṃsukūlaṃ gahaṇadivase udakapariyantaṃ katvā mahāpathavī akampi. Idha
analyzed: pilotikā ati saṅkham gaccheyyuṃ uccinitvā iti phāletvā dubbala ṭṭhānam pahāya thira ṭṭhānam eva  gahetvā alābu lomasāni iti alābu loma sadisa suttāni sukhumāni iti dīpeti ettāvatā ca satthā  cīvara santosena asantuṭṭhaḥ ti na vattabbo atimuttaka susānataḥ hissa puṇṇa dāsiyā  pātita sāṇa paṃsu kūlam gahaṇa divase udaka pariyantam katvā mahā pathavī akampi
translated: would be called a rag-robe. Having torn it: having torn it to pieces, having removed the weak places,🔽and having taken the strong places. With a needle of alābu-fibre: with fine threads like alābu-fibre, is what is shown. And at this point the Teacher🔽cannot be said to be dissatisfied with the robe of cast-off cloth. For on the day he took the cast-off cloth that had been worn by Puṇṇā the slave-girl and thrown on the charnel ground,🔽the great earth shook as far as the ocean, having been made wet all round. Here🔽

original: pana etamatthaṃ dasseti – “ahaṃ ekasmiṃyeva kāle paṃsukūlaṃ gaṇhiṃ, mayhaṃ pana sāvakā🔽dhutaṅgasamādānato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ na bhindantī”ti.🔽Piṇḍapātikāti atirekalābhaṃ paṭikkhipitvā samādinnapiṇḍapātikaṅgā. Sapadānacārinoti
analyzed: pana etam attham dasseti aham ekasmiṃ yeva kāle paṃsukūlam mayham pana sāvakā  dhutaṅga samādānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam dhutaṅgam na bhindanti iti  piṇḍapātikā ati atireka lābham paṭikkhipitvā samādinna piṇḍapātikaṅgā sa padāna cārino ti
translated: would be considered as rags. Having picked out: having torn out. Having avoided the weak places, he took only the strong places. With a needle made of grass: with threads like the grass called alābu, he shows that they were fine. And up to this point the Master should not be spoken of as dissatisfied with the robe of rags. For on the day when he took the rag-robes that had been worn by Puṇṇā the basket-weaver and thrown away in a cemetery that was not yet overgrown, the great earth shook to its ocean boundaries. But here he shows this meaning: “I took the rag-robes on one occasion only, but my disciples do not break their ascetic practice for as long as they live, starting with the undertaking of the ascetic practice.”

original: loluppacāraṃ paṭikkhipitvā samādinnasapadānacārā. Uñchāsake vate ratāti uñchācariyasaṅkhāte
analyzed: loluppa cāram paṭikkhipitvā samādinna sa padāna cārā uñchāsake vate ratāti uñchā cariya saṅkhāte
translated: Rags-robe wearer: one who has taken the ascetic practice of the refuse-rag-wearer by rejecting the extra gain. Alms-food eater: one who has taken the ascetic practice of the alms-food eater by rejecting the practice of accepting invitations to meals. House-to-house: one who has taken the ascetic practice of the house-to-house by rejecting the practice of going to a place where many offerings are laid out.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ pakativate ratā, uccanīcagharadvāraṭṭhāyino hutvā kabaramissakaṃ bhattaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhūnam pakativate ratāḥ ucca nīca ghara dvāra ṭṭhāyinaḥ hutvā kabara missakam bhattam
translated: They were fond of the regular alms round. They stood at the doors of the houses, high and low, and collected the alms mixed with various kinds of food.

original: saṃharitvā paribhuñjantīti attho. Antaragharanti brahmāyusutte ummārato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: saṃharitvā paribhuñjanti iti attho brahmāyusutte ummārataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: The meaning is that they ate it. In the Brahmayu sutta the word “house” is used in the sense of a village, starting with a village of brahmins.🔽Here it is used in the sense of a town, starting with the town of Indapatta.

original: antaragharaṃ, idha indakhīlato paṭṭhāya adhippetaṃ. Ettāvatā ca satthā piṇḍapātasantosena
analyzed: antara gharam idha indakhīlato paṭṭhāya adhippetam ettāvatā ca satthā piṇḍapāta santosena
translated: So far the Master cannot be said to be satisfied with the alms round,

original: asantuṭṭhoti na vattabbo, appāhāratāya vuttaniyāmeneva pana sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ.🔽Idha pana etamatthaṃ dasseti – “ahaṃ ekasmiṃyeva kāle nimantanaṃ na sādayiṃ, mayhaṃ
analyzed: asantuṭṭhaḥ ti na vattabbaḥ appāhāra tāya vutta niyāmena iva pana sabbam vitthāretabbam  idha pana etam attham dasseti aham ekasmiṃ yā iva kāle nimantanam na mayham
translated: but all this should be explained in detail in the same way as the explanation of his satisfaction with little food.

original: pana sāvakā dhutaṅgasamādānato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ na bhindantī”ti.🔽Rukkhamūlikāti channaṃ paṭikkhipitvā samādinnarukkhamūlikaṅgā. Abbhokāsikāti channañca
analyzed: pana sāvakāḥ dhutaṅga samādānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam dhutaṅgam na bhindanti iti  rukkhamūlikā ati channam paṭikkhipitvā samādinna rukkhamūlika aṅgā abbhokāsikā ati channam ca
translated: But here the Master shows the meaning in this way: “I did not accept an invitation at one time, but my disciples, having undertaken the ascetic practices, did not break them as long as they lived.”

original: rukkhamūlañca paṭikkhipitvā samādinnaabbhokāsikaṅgā. Aṭṭhamāseti hemantagimhike māse.
analyzed: rukkha mūlañca paṭikkhipitvā samādinna abbhokāsika aṅgā aṭṭha māse iti hemanta gimhike māse
translated: The “tree-root-dweller” is one who has taken up the tree-root-dweller’s practice after rejecting the six shelters. The “open-air-dweller” is one who has taken up the open-air-dweller’s practice after rejecting the six shelters and the tree root. “Eight months” means the cold and hot seasons.

original: Antovasse pana cīvarānuggahatthaṃ channaṃ pavisanti. Ettāvatā ca satthā senāsanasantosena
analyzed: antovasse pana cīvara anuggaha attham channam pavisanti ettāvatā ca satthā senāsana santosena
translated: But they enter the rains in the woods for the sake of the robe-material.

original: asantuṭṭhoti na vattabbo, senāsanasantoso panassa chabbassikamahāpadhānena ca pālileyyakavanasaṇḍena
analyzed: a santuṭṭhaḥ ti na vattabbo senāsana santoso panassa chabbassika mahāpadhānena ca pālileyyaka vana saṇḍena
translated: And the Master should not be said to be dissatisfied with the kind of resting-place he has, for his satisfaction with the kind of resting-place he has should be demonstrated by the Great Six-Monthly-Alms-Residence and by the Pālileyyaka Wood.

original: ca dīpetabbo. Idha pana etamatthaṃ dasseti – “ahaṃ ekasmiṃyeva kāle channaṃ na pāvisiṃ,
analyzed: ca dīpetabbaḥ idha pana etam attham dasseti aham ekasmiṃ yeva kāle channam na pāvisim
translated: Here, however, he shows this meaning: ‘I did not enter the woods for six months at one time,

original: mayhaṃ pana sāvakā dhutaṅgasamādānato paṭṭhāya yāvajīvaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ na bhindantī”ti.
analyzed: mayham pana sāvakāḥ dhutaṅga samādānataḥ paṭṭhāya yāvajīvam dhutaṅgam na bhindanti iti
translated: but my disciples, after undertaking the ascetic practices, do not break the ascetic practices as long as they live’.

original: Āraññikāti gāmantasenāsanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā samādinnaāraññikaṅgā. Saṅghamajjhe osarantīti
analyzed: āraññikā ati gāmanta senāsanam paṭikkhipitvā samādinna āraññika aṅgā saṅgha majjhe osaranti iti
translated: ‘Forest-dwellers’: those who have undertaken the ascetic practice of forest-dwelling, rejecting a dwelling in a place within a village. ‘Come down into the midst of the Community’

original: abaddhasīmāya kathitaṃ, baddhasīmāyaṃ pana vasantā attano vasanaṭṭhāneyeva uposathaṃ
analyzed: abaddha sīmāya kathitam baddha sīmā ayam pana vasantā attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhāneyā iva uposatham
translated: is said of an unfenced dwelling-place. But those who live in a fenced dwelling-place do the Uposatha observance in their own living quarters.

analyzed: karonti ettāvatā ca satthā no pavivittaḥ ti na vattabbo icchāmaham bhikkhave aḍḍha māsam
translated: And the Master should not be said to be unsociable, for ‘I want, bhikkhus, to live for half a month

original: paṭisalliyitu”nti evañhissa paviveko paññāyati. Idha pana etamatthaṃ dasseti “ahaṃ🔽ekasmiṃyeva tathārūpe kāle paṭisalliyiṃ, mayhaṃ pana sāvakā dhutaṅgasamādānato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: paṭisalliyitum ti evam hissa pavivekaḥ paññāyati idha pana etam attham dasseti aham  ekasmiṃ yeva tathārūpe kāle paṭisalliyim mayham pana sāvakāḥ dhutaṅga samādānataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “I have retired to the seclusion of the forest,” and so his seclusion is known. But here he shows the meaning in this way: “I retired to seclusion at such a time, but my disciples do not break their ascetic practices from the time they undertake them until the end of their lives.”

original: yāvajīvaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ na bhindantī”ti. Mamaṃ sāvakāti maṃ sāvakā.
analyzed: yāvajīvam dhutaṅgam na bhindanti iti sāvakā ati mā sāvakā
translated: My disciples: my disciples.

original: 244. Sanidānanti sappaccayaṃ. Kiṃ pana appaccayaṃ nibbānaṃ na desetīti. No na deseti,
analyzed: sa nidānam ti sa paccayam kim pana appaccayam nibbānam na deseti iti no na deseti
translated: With a source: with a condition. But is it not the case that Nibbāna is taught without a source? No, it is not.🔽But it is taught after a teaching with a cause has been given, not without a cause.

original: sahetukaṃ pana taṃ desanaṃ katvā deseti, no ahetukanti. Sappāṭihāriyanti purimassevetaṃ
analyzed: sa hetukam pana tam desanam katvā deseti no ahetukanti sappāṭihāriyam ti purimassa iva etat
translated: With a demonstration: this is a synonym for the previous phrase. The meaning is: with a reason.

original: vevacanaṃ, sakāraṇanti attho. Taṃ vatāti ettha vatāti nipātamattaṃ.🔽245. Anāgataṃ vādapathanti ajja ṭhapetvā sve vā punadivase vā aḍḍhamāse vā māse vā
analyzed: vevacanam sa kāraṇam ti tam vata ati ettha vata iti nipāta mattam  anāgatam ajja sve vā punadivase vā aḍḍha māse vā māse vā
translated: That is what he said: here, “that is what he said” is merely a particle.🔽A path of talk for the future: a path of talk for the coming of that question again tomorrow or the next day or in a fortnight or a month or a year, after today has been set aside.

original: saṃvacchare vā tassa tassa pañhassa upari āgamanavādapathaṃ. Na dakkhatīti yathā
analyzed: saṃvacchare vā tassa tassa pañhassa upari āgamana vāda patham na dakkhati iti yathā
translated: He will not see: as

analyzed: saccakaḥ nigaṇṭhaḥ attanaḥ niggahaṇa attham āgata kāraṇam visesetvā vadantaḥ na addasa
translated: Saccaka, the Nigantha, when he was trying to justify his own Niganthas, did not see,

original: evaṃ na dakkhatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati. Sahadhammenāti sakāraṇena. Antarantarā kathaṃ
analyzed: evam na dakkhati iti na itam ṭhānam vijjati sahadhammena ati sa kāraṇena antar antarā katham
translated: and he will not see. He will not find an opportunity to do so. ‘With a reason’: with a cause. ‘In the middle of the discussion’:

analyzed: mama kathāvāram pacchinditvā antarantare katham paveseyyunti attho  na kho pana aham udāyī iti udāyi aham ambaṭṭha soṇa daṇḍa kūṭa danta saccaka nigaṇṭha ādīhi  saddhim mahāvāde vattamāne api  aho vata me eka sāvakaḥ api upamam vā kāraṇam vā āharitvā
translated: ‘They would interrupt my discourse and put in a word edgewise.’🔽‘But, Udayin, I do not recall ever having said:’ Udayin, even when I was engaged in a great discussion with Ambattha, Sonadanda, KuddhaJatila, Saccaka the Nigantha, and others,

original: dadeyyā”ti evaṃ sāvakesu anusāsaniṃ na paccāsīsāmi. Mamayevāti evarūpesu ṭhānesu
analyzed: dadeyya ati evam sāvakesu anusāsanim na evarūpesu ṭhānesu
translated: I did not recall ever having said to my disciples: ‘Oh, if only a disciple would give me a simile or a reason🔽and so help me to teach the Dhamma!’

original: sāvakā mamayeva anusāsaniṃ ovādaṃ paccāsīsanti.
analyzed: sāvakāḥ mamayā iva anusāsanim ovādam
translated: But my disciples recall my instructions.

original: 246. Tesāhaṃ cittaṃ ārādhemīti tesaṃ ahaṃ tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ gaṇhāmi
analyzed: tesam aham cittam ārādhemi iti tesam aham tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam gaṇhāmi
translated: ‘I win them over with that view’: I win over their minds by answering their questions.

original: sampādemi paripūremi, aññaṃ puṭṭho aññaṃ na byākaromi, ambaṃ puṭṭho labujaṃ viya
analyzed: sampādemi paripūremi aññam puṭṭhaḥ aññam na byākaromi ambam puṭṭhaḥ labujam viya
translated: I do not answer one thing when asked another, like one asked about a mango answering about a breadfruit,🔽or one asked about a breadfruit answering about a mango.

original: labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ viya. Ettha ca “adhisīle sambhāventī”ti vuttaṭṭhāne buddhasīlaṃ
analyzed: labujam vā puṭṭhaḥ ambam viya ettha ca adhi sīle sambhāventi iti vutta ṭṭhāne buddha sīlam
translated: And here, in the place where it is said, “I honour the higher virtue,” the virtue of the Buddha

original: nāma kathitaṃ, “abhikkante ñāṇadassane sambhāventī”ti vuttaṭṭhāne sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: nāma kathitam abhikkante ñāṇa dassane sambhāventi iti vutta ṭṭhāne sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: is meant. In the place where it is said, “I honour the higher knowledge and insight,” the knowledge of omniscience is meant.

original: “adhipaññāya sambhāventī”ti vuttaṭṭhāne ṭhānuppattikapaññā, “yena dukkhenā”ti vuttaṭṭhāne
analyzed: adhipaññāya sambhāventi iti vutta ṭṭhāne ṭhānuppattika paññā yena dukkhena ati vutta ṭṭhāne
translated: In the place where it is said, “I honour the higher wisdom,” the wisdom of the four noble truths is meant.

original: saccabyākaraṇapaññā. Tattha sabbaññutaññāṇañca saccabyākaraṇapaññañca ṭhapetvā avasesā
analyzed: sacca byākaraṇa paññā tattha sabbaññuta ññāṇañca sacca byākaraṇa paññañca ṭhapetvā avasesā
translated: Herein, except for the knowledge of omniscience and the wisdom of the four noble truths,

original: paññā adhipaññaṃ bhajati.
analyzed: paññāḥ adhipaññam bhajati
translated: the rest of the wisdoms are included in the higher wisdom.

original: 247. Idāni tesaṃ tesaṃ visesādhigamānaṃ paṭipadaṃ ācikkhanto puna caparaṃ udāyītiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tesam tesam visesa adhigamānam paṭipadam ācikkhantaḥ puna ca param udāyi iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to point out the practice for the attainment of each of these special knowledges, he said, “Again, Udāyī, when I was a young man,” etc.

original: Tattha abhiññāvosānapāramippattāti abhiññāvosānasaṅkhātañceva abhiññāpāramīsaṅkhātañca arahattaṃ pattā.
analyzed: tattha abhiññā vosāna pārami pattā ti abhiññā vosāna saṅkhātam ca iva abhiññāpāramī saṅkhātam ca arahattam pattā
translated: Herein, they had attained to the consummation of direct knowledge and to the perfection of direct knowledge means they had attained to arahatship, which is called the consummation of direct knowledge and the perfection of direct knowledge.

original: Sammappadhāneti upāyapadhāne. Chandaṃ janetīti kattukamyatākusalacchandaṃ janeti.🔽Vāyamatīti vāyāmaṃ karoti. Vīriyaṃ ārabhatīti vīriyaṃ pavatteti. Cittaṃ paggaṇhātīti
analyzed: sammappadhāne iti upāya padhāne chandam janeti iti kattu kamya tā kusala chandam janeti  vāyamati iti vāyāmam karoti vīriyam ārabhati iti vīriyam pavatteti cittam paggaṇhāti iti
translated: Right endeavour is the endeavour of means. He generates zeal: he generates unwholesome zeal for doing.

original: cittaṃ ukkhipati. Padahatīti upāyapadhānaṃ karoti. Bhāvanāya pāripūriyāti vaḍḍhiyā
analyzed: cittam ukkhipati padahati iti upāya padhānam karoti bhāvanāya pāripūriyā ati vaḍḍhiyā
translated: He strives: he makes effort. He exerts his mind: he exerts his mind. He makes an endeavour: he makes the endeavour of means. For the fulfilment of development: for the increase,🔽for the fulfilment,

original: paripūraṇatthaṃ. Apicettha – “yā ṭhiti, so asammoso…pe… yaṃ vepullaṃ, sā bhāvanāpāripūrī”ti
analyzed: paripūraṇa attham apica ittha yā ṭhiti so yam vepullam sā bhāvanā pāripūrī iti
translated: And here the former is the meaning of the latter thus: “The state of being still is non-collapse … down to … the state of abundance is fulfilment of development.”

original: evaṃ purimaṃ purimassa pacchimaṃ pacchimassa atthotipi veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam purimam purimassa pacchimam pacchimassa veditabbam
translated: This is how it should be understood.

original: Imehi pana sammappadhānehi kiṃ kathitaṃ? Kassapasaṃyuttapariyāyena sāvakassa pubbabhāgapaṭipadā kathitā. Vuttañhetaṃ tattha –🔽“Cattārome, āvuso, sammappadhānā. Katame cattāro? Idhāvuso, bhikkhu, anuppannā me
analyzed: imehi pana sammappadhānehi kim kathitam kassapasaṃyutta pariyāyena sāvakassa pubbabhāga paṭipadā kathitā vuttam ha etam tattha  cattāro me āvuso sammappadhānā katame cattāro idha āvuso bhikkhu anuppannā me
translated: But what is said by these right endeavours? The disciple’s progress in the earlier stage is said by the Kassapa-samyutta method. For this is said there:

original: pāpakā akusalā dhammā uppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappaṃ karoti. Uppannā
analyzed: pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappam karoti uppannā
translated: “Friend, there are these four right endeavours. What four? Here a bhikkhu … generates zeal, makes an effort, stirs up energy, exerts his mind and strives to prevent the arising of unarisen evil unwholesome states … to abandon arisen evil unwholesome states … to arouse unarisen wholesome states … to maintain arisen wholesome states …

original: me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīyamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappaṃ karoti. Anuppannā🔽me kusalā dhammā anuppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappaṃ karoti. Uppannā me
analyzed: me pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ a pahīyamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappam karoti anuppannā  me kusalāḥ dhammāḥ an uppajjamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappam karoti uppannāḥ me
translated: “If unarisen unprofitable things were not to arise in me, that would lead to my welfare,” he strives,🔽“If unarisen profitable things were not to arise in me, that would lead to my harm,” he strives,

original: kusalā dhammā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyunti ātappaṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammāḥ nirujjhamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyun ti ātappam karoti iti
translated: “If arisen profitable things were to cease in me, that would lead to my harm,” he strives.🔽Herein, unprofitable things should be understood as greed, etc.,

original: Ettha ca pāpakā akusalāti lobhādayo veditabbā. Anuppannā kusalā dhammāti samathavipassanā
analyzed: ettha ca pāpakāḥ akusalā ati lobha ādayaḥ veditabbāḥ anuppannā kusalā dhammā ati samatha vipassanā
translated: Unarisen profitable things are serenity, insight,

original: ceva maggo ca, uppannā kusalā nāma samathavipassanāva. Maggo pana sakiṃ uppajjitvā
analyzed: ca iva maggo ca uppannā kusalā nāma samatha vipassanā ava maggaḥ pana sakim uppajjitvā
translated: and the path. Arisen profitable things are serenity and insight.🔽But the path, having arisen, does not cease in such a way that it would lead to harm.

original: nirujjhamāno anatthāya saṃvattanako nāma natthi. So hi phalassa paccayaṃ datvāva
analyzed: nirujjhamānaḥ anatthāya saṃvattanakaḥ nāma natthi saḥ hi phalassa paccayam datvā ava
translated: For it ceases only after giving its support to the fruit.

original: nirujjhati. Purimasmimpi vā samathavipassanāva gahetabbāti vuttaṃ, taṃ pana na yuttaṃ.🔽Tattha “uppannā samathavipassanā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvattantī”ti atthassa āvibhāvatthamidaṃ
analyzed: nirujjhati purimasmim pi vā samatha vipassanā ava gahetabbā ti vuttam tam pana na yuttam 🔽tattha uppannā samatha vipassanā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvattanti iti atthassa āvi bhāva attham idam
translated: Or it can be taken that the first is said with reference to serenity and insight. But that is not right.🔽For the meaning of the first clause is not clear if it is taken to mean that arisen serenity and insight cease in such a way that they lead to harm.

original: vatthu – eko kira khīṇāsavatthero “mahācetiyañca mahābodhiñca vandissāmī”ti samāpattilābhinā
analyzed: vatthu ekaḥ kira khīṇāsava theraḥ mahā cetiyañca mahābodhiñca vandissāmi iti samāpatti lābhinā
translated: The story is this. It seems that a certain elder who had attained the jhānas and was free from the cankers, thinking, “I will worship the Great Relic Shrine and the Great Bodhi Tree,”

original: bhaṇḍagāhakasāmaṇerena saddhiṃ janapadato mahāvihāraṃ āgantvā vihārapariveṇaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: bhaṇḍa gāhaka sāmaṇerena saddhim janapadataḥ mahā vihāram āgantvā vihāra pariveṇam pāvisi
translated: The story is this. It seems that a certain elder who had attained the higher powers, having obtained the attainment of the jhāna called “beautiful” (subha), was going to the Great Monastery from the provinces with a novice attendant who was a thief. He entered the monastery and the surrounding park.

original: Sāyanhasamaye mahābhikkhusaṅghe cetiyaṃ vandamāne cetiyaṃ vandanatthāya na nikkhami.
analyzed: sāyanha samaye mahā bhikkhu saṅghe cetiyam vandamāne cetiyam vandana atthāya na nikkhami
translated: In the evening when the great body of bhikkhus was worshipping the shrine, he did not go to worship the shrine.

original: Kasmā? Khīṇāsavānañhi tīsu ratanesu mahantaṃ gāravaṃ hoti. Tasmā bhikkhusaṅghe vanditvā
analyzed: kasmā khīṇāsavānam hi tīsu ratanesu mahantam gāravam hoti tasmā bhikkhu saṅghe vanditvā
translated: Why was that? Because the venerable one was one whose cankers were destroyed and he had great respect for the Three Jewels. So when the bhikkhus had worshipped the shrine

original: paṭikkamante manussānaṃ sāyamāsabhuttavelāyaṃ sāmaṇerampi ajānāpetvā “cetiyaṃ vandissāmī”ti
analyzed: paṭikkamante manussānam sāya māsa bhutta velāyam sāmaṇeram pi a jānāpetvā cetiyam vandissāmi iti
translated: and were returning, it was the time for people to eat their evening meal. Without telling the novice, he went out alone to worship the shrine.

original: ekakova nikkhami. Sāmaṇero – “kiṃ nu kho thero avelāya ekakova gacchati, jānissāmī”ti
analyzed: ekakaḥ iva nikkhami sāmaṇero  kim nu kho theraḥ avelāya ekakaḥ iva gacchati jānissāmi iti
translated: The novice thought, “Why does the elder go out alone at this time? I will find out.”

original: upajjhāyassa padānupadiko nikkhami. Thero anāvajjanena tassa āgamanaṃ ajānanto dakkhiṇadvārena
analyzed: upajjhāyassa padānupadikaḥ nikkhami theraḥ an āvajjanena tassa āgamanam a jānantaḥ dakkhiṇa dvārena
translated: So he followed in his footsteps. The elder, not knowing that the novice had come, went up to the shrine terrace by the southern gate.

original: cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ āruhi. Sāmaṇeropi anupadaṃyeva āruḷho.
analyzed: āruhi āruḍhaḥ
translated: The novice also went up.

original: Mahāthero mahācetiyaṃ ulloketvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā sabbaṃ cetaso samannāharitvā
analyzed: mahā theraḥ mahā cetiyam ulloketvā buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā
translated: The Elder looked at the Great Shrine, and taking up the meditation subject of the thirty-two aspects of the body, he concentrated his whole mind on it.

original: haṭṭhapahaṭṭho cetiyaṃ vandati. Sāmaṇero therassa vandanākāraṃ disvā “upajjhāyo me
analyzed: haṭṭha pahaṭṭhaḥ cetiyam vandati sāmaṇeraḥ therassa vandanā ākāram disvā upajjhāyaḥ me
translated: He was delighted and worshipped the Shrine. The novice saw the Elder’s manner of worshipping and thought, “My preceptor

original: ativiya pasannacitto vandati, kiṃ nu kho pupphāni labhitvā pūjaṃ kareyyā”ti cintesi.
analyzed: ativiya pasanna cittaḥ vandati kim nu kho pupphāni labhitvā pūjam kareyya ati cintesi
translated: worships with exceeding great confidence. What if he has got flowers and is going to make an offering?”

original: Thero vanditvā uṭṭhāya sirasi añjaliṃ ṭhapetvā mahācetiyaṃ ulloketvā ṭhito. Sāmaṇero
analyzed: theraḥ vanditvā uṭṭhāya sirasi añjalim ṭhapetvā mahā cetiyam ulloketvā ṭhitaḥ sāmaṇeraḥ
translated: The Elder worshipped and stood up. He placed his hands together in reverential salutation above his head and stood looking at the Great Shrine. The novice

original: ukkāsitvā attano āgatabhāvaṃ jānāpesi. Thero parivattetvā olokento “kadā āgatosī”ti🔽pucchi. Tumhākaṃ cetiyaṃ vandanakāle, bhante. Ativiya pasannā cetiyaṃ vandittha kiṃ🔽nu kho pupphāni labhitvā pūjeyyāthāti? Āma sāmaṇera imasmiṃ cetiye viya aññatra ettakaṃ
analyzed: ukkāsitvā attanaḥ āgata bhāvam jānāpesi theraḥ parivattetvā olokento kadā āgataḥ asi iti  pucchi tumhākam cetiyam vandana kāle bhante pasannā cetiyam vandittha kim  nu kho pupphāni labhitvā pūjeyyātha ati āma sāmaṇera imasmin cetiye viya aññatra ettakam
translated: cleared his throat and made his presence known. The Elder turned round and asked, “When did you come?”🔽“At the time you were worshipping the Shrine, venerable sir.” “You were worshipping the Shrine with exceeding great confidence. What if you have got flowers and are going to make an offering?”🔽“Yes, novice, there is no other such store of relics as there is in this Shrine. If one could get flowers and make an offering to such a peerless Great Shrine as this,

original: dhātūnaṃ nidhānaṃ nāma natthi, evarūpaṃ asadisaṃ mahāthūpaṃ pupphāni labhitvā ko
analyzed: dhātūnam nidhānam nāma natthi evarūpam asadisam mahā thūpam pupphāni labhitvā ko
translated: what more would there be for one to do?”

original: na pūjeyyāti. Tena hi, bhante, adhivāsetha, āharissāmīti tāvadeva jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā
analyzed: na pūjeyya iti tena hi bhante adhivāsetha āharissāmi iti tāvat eva jhānam samāpajjitvā
translated: “I will not worship.” “Well then, Sir, please wait; I will bring them.” He entered into jhāna and,

original: iddhiyā himavantaṃ gantvā vaṇṇagandhasampannapupphāni parissāvanaṃ pūretvā mahāthere🔽dakkhiṇamukhato pacchimaṃ mukhaṃ asampatteyeva āgantvā pupphaparissāvanaṃ hatthe
analyzed: iddhiyā himavantam gantvā vaṇṇa gandha sampanna pupphāni parissāvanam pūretvā mahā there  dakkhiṇa mukhataḥ pacchimam mukham āgantvā puppha parissāvanam hatthe
translated: by means of his psychic power, went to the Himalayas. He filled his bowl with flowers of various colors and fragrances and returned to the Elder.

original: ṭhapetvā “pūjetha, bhante,”ti āha. Thero “atimandāni no sāmaṇera pupphānī”ti āha.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā pūjetha bhante iti āha theraḥ ati mandāni no sāmaṇera pupphāni iti āha
translated: He placed the bowl of flowers in the Elder’s hand and said, “Worship with these, Sir.” The Elder said, “These flowers are too weak, novice.”

original: Gacchatha, bhante, bhagavato guṇe āvajjitvā pūjethāti.🔽Thero pacchimamukhanissitena sopāṇena āruyha kucchivedikābhūmiyaṃ pupphapūjaṃ kātuṃ🔽āraddho. Vedikābhūmiyaṃ paripuṇṇāni pupphāni patitvā dutiyabhūmiyaṃ jaṇṇupamāṇena
analyzed: gacchatha bhante bhagavataḥ guṇe āvajjitvā pūjetha iti  theraḥ pacchima mukha nissitena sopāṇena āruyha kucchi vedikā bhūmiyam puppha pūjam kātum  āraddhaḥ vedikā bhūmiyam paripuṇṇāni pupphāni patitvā dutiya bhūmiyam jaṇṇu pamāṇena
translated: “Go, Sir, and worship the Buddha, recollecting his special qualities.”🔽The Elder climbed the stairs leading to the back of the shrine and began to worship the flowers on the ground of the inner verandah.🔽The flowers filled the ground of the inner verandah to a height of a man’s height and overflowed onto the ground of the outer verandah.

original: odhinā pūrayiṃsu. Tato otaritvā pādapiṭṭhikapantiṃ pūjesi. Sāpi paripūri. Paripuṇṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: odhinā pūrayiṃsu tatas otaritvā pāda piṭṭhika pantim pūjesi sā api paripūri paripuṇṇa bhāvam
translated: From there he descended and worshipped the ground of the back verandah. That too was filled. The flowers overflowed onto the ground of the back stairs.

original: ñatvā heṭṭhimatale vikiranto agamāsi. Sabbaṃ cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ paripūri. Tasmiṃ paripuṇṇe
analyzed: ñatvā heṭṭhima tale vikirantaḥ agamāsi sabbam cetiya ṅgaṇam paripūri tasmim paripuṇṇe
translated: and as he did so, the flowers filled the whole courtyard.🔽When it was full, the Elder said, “The flowers are not exhausted, novice.”

original: “sāmaṇera pupphāni na khīyantī”ti āha. Parissāvanaṃ, bhante, adhomukhaṃ karothāti.
analyzed: sāmaṇera pupphāni na khīyanti iti āha parissāvanam bhante adhomukham karotha ati
translated: “Reverend Sir, turn the sprinkler upside down.”

original: Adhomukhaṃ katvā cālesi, tadā pupphāni khīṇāni. Parissāvanaṃ sāmaṇerassa datvā saddhiṃ
analyzed: adhomukham katvā cālesi tadā pupphāni khīṇāni parissāvanam sāmaṇerassa da tvā saddhim
translated: When he did so, the flowers were exhausted. The Elder gave the sprinkler to the novice and,

original: hatthipākārena cetiyaṃ tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā pariveṇaṃ
analyzed: hatthi pākārena cetiyam tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā pariveṇam
translated: after walking round the shrine three times, keeping it to the right, and worshipping in the four places, went to the monastery.

original: gacchanto cintesi – “yāva mahiddhiko vatāyaṃ sāmaṇero, sakkhissati nu kho imaṃ iddhānubhāvaṃ
analyzed: gacchantaḥ cintesi yāva mahiddhikaḥ vata ayam sāmaṇeraḥ sakkhissati nu kho imam iddha anubhāvam
translated: As he went, he thought, “How great is the power of this novice! But will he be able to preserve this power?”

original: rakkhitu”nti. Tato “na sakkhissatī”ti disvā sāmaṇeramāha – “sāmaṇera tvaṃ idāni mahiddhiko,🔽evarūpaṃ pana iddhiṃ nāsetvā pacchimakāle kāṇapesakāriyā hatthena madditakañjiyaṃ
analyzed: rakkhitunti tatas na sakkhissati iti disvā sāmaṇeram āha sāmaṇera tvam idāni mahiddhikaḥ  evarūpam pana iddhim nāsetvā pacchima kāle kāṇapesakāriyā hatthena madditakañjiyam
translated: Then he saw that he would not be able to do so, and he said to the novice, “Novice, you are now possessed of great power.🔽But you will destroy this power of yours and in the future drink rice-gruel through the corner of a garment, like a blind beggar.”

original: pivissasī”ti. Daharakabhāvassa nāmesa dosoyaṃ, so upajjhāyassa kathāyaṃ saṃvijjitvā
analyzed: pivissasi iti daharaka bhāvassa nāma isa dosaḥ ayam saḥ upajjhāyassa kathā ayam saṃvijjitvā
translated: This was a fault of his youthfulness. He took this advice to heart and

original: – “kammaṭṭhānaṃ me, bhante, ācikkhathā”ti na yāci, amhākaṃ upajjhāyo kiṃ vadatīti🔽taṃ pana asuṇanto viya agamāsi.🔽Thero mahācetiyañca mahābodhiñca vanditvā sāmaṇeraṃ pattacīvaraṃ gāhāpetvā anupubbena
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam me bhante ācikkhatha ati na yāci amhākam upajjhāyo kim vadati iti  tam pana a suṇantaḥ viya agamāsi  theraḥ mahācetiyam ca mahābodhim ca vanditvā sāmaṇeram patta cīvaram gāhāpetvā anupubbena
translated: “Venerable sir, please teach me a meditation subject” he did not ask, but he went away as though he had not heard what was said.🔽The elder paid homage at the Great Shrine and the Great Bodhi Tree, and taking the novice with him, he went away.

original: kuṭeḷitissamahāvihāraṃ agamāsi. Sāmaṇero upajjhāyassa padānupadiko hutvā bhikkhācāraṃ
analyzed: kuṭeḷitissa mahāvihāram agamāsi sāmaṇeraḥ upajjhāyassa padānupadikaḥ hutvā bhikkhācāram

analyzed: karonti tasmā tumhe maññā iva ārammaṇam karitvā appamattāḥ hotha bhante iti tat jetvā  ovādam adāsi te tassa kathentassa iva saṃvegam āpajjitvā vipassamānā tiṃsa janā tattha eva
translated: to birth and old age. Therefore, venerable sirs, be heedful, taking me as your example.”🔽After rebuking them and instructing them,

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsūti. Evampi uppannā samathavipassanā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvattantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu iti evam pi uppannā samatha vipassanā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvattanti iti veditabbā
translated: they became dispassionate and reached Arahantship right there. So it should be understood that when serenity and insight have arisen in this way, they lead to the cessation of suffering.

original: Anuppannānaṃ pāpakānanti cettha “anuppanno vā kāmāsavo na uppajjatī”tiādīsu vuttanayena
analyzed: anuppannānam pāpakānam ti ca ittha anuppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ na uppajjati iti ādīsu vutta nayena
translated: As regards the words, “of unarisen evil things,” the method of explanation is that given in the Description of the Aggregates.

original: attho veditabbo. Uppannānaṃ pāpakānanti ettha pana catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ vattamānuppannaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ uppannānam pāpakānam ti ettha pana catubbidham uppannam vattamānuppannam
translated: The meaning should be understood. As to “ arisen evil states “ : here there are four kinds of arising, that is to say, arising as present,

original: bhutvāvigatuppannaṃ, okāsakatuppannaṃ, bhūmiladdhuppannanti. Tattha ye kilesā vijjamānā🔽uppādādisamaṅgino, idaṃ vattamānuppannaṃ nāma. Kamme pana javite ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavitvā🔽niruddhavipāko bhutvā vigataṃ nāma. Kammaṃ uppajjitvā niruddhaṃ bhavitvā vigataṃ🔽nāma. Tadubhayampi bhutvāvigatuppannanti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Kusalākusalaṃ kammaṃ aññassa🔽kammassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā attano vipākassa okāsaṃ karoti, evaṃ kate okāse vipāko🔽uppajjamāno okāsakaraṇato paṭṭhāya uppannoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Idaṃ okāsakatuppannaṃ
analyzed: okāsa kata uppannam bhūmi laddha uppannam tattha ye kilesāḥ vijjamānā  uppāda ādi samaṅginaḥ idam vattamānuppannam nāma kamme pana javite ārammaṇa rasam anubhavitvā  niruddha vipākaḥ bhutvā vigatam nāma kammam uppajjitvā niruddham bhavitvā vigatam  nāma tat ubhayam pi bhutvā a vigata uppanna nti saṅkham gacchati kusala akusalam kammam aññassa  kammassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā attanaḥ vipākassa okāsam karoti evam kate okāse vipākaḥ  uppajjamānaḥ okāsa karaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya uppannaḥ ti saṅkham gacchati idam okāsa kata uppannam
translated: arising as past after having been present, arising as an opportunity, and arising as a plane. Herein, any defilements that are present

original: nāma. Pañcakkhandhā pana vipassanāya bhūmi nāma. Te atītādibhedā honti. Tesu anusayitakilesā
analyzed: nāma pañca kkhandhā pana vipassanāya bhūmi nāma te atīta ādi bhedāḥ honti tesu
translated: and have the characteristics of arising, etc., are called arising as present. But when a profitable or unprofitable kamma is active, then the result that has ceased after giving its fruit is called “ arisen after having been present “ . And kamma that has arisen and ceased is called “ arisen after having been present “ . Both these are called “ arisen as past after having been present “ . When profitable or unprofitable kamma prevents the result of other kamma and makes an opportunity for its own result, then when the result arises it is called “ arisen “ from the time of the making of the opportunity. This is called “ arising as an opportunity “ . But the five aggregates are called “ the plane “ of insight. They are past, etc., and the latent defilements in them are called “ arisen as a plane “ .

original: pana atītā vā anāgatā vā paccuppannā vāti na vattabbā. Atītakhandhesu anusayitāpi🔽hi appahīnāva honti, anāgatakhandhesu, paccuppannakhandhesu anusayitāpi appahīnāva
analyzed: pana atītā vā anāgatā vā paccuppannā vā ti na vattabbā atīta khandhesu  hi appahīnā ava honti anāgata khandhesu paccuppanna khandhesu anusayitā api appahīnā ava
translated: but it cannot be said of them that they are past, future, or present. For defilements that have lain dormant in past aggregates are not yet abandoned,

original: honti. Idaṃ bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ nāma. Tenāhu porāṇā – “tāsu tāsu bhūmīsu asamugghātitakilesā
analyzed: honti idam bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma tena āhu porāṇā tāsu tāsu bhūmīsu a samugghātita kilesā
translated: and those that have lain dormant in future and present aggregates are not yet abandoned either. This is called “arisen by acquisition of plane.” Hence the Ancients said:

original: bhūmiladdhuppannāti saṅkhaṃ gacchantī”ti.🔽Aparampi catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ samudācāruppannaṃ, ārammaṇādhigahituppannaṃ, avikkhambhituppannaṃ🔽asamugghātituppannanti. Tattha sampati vattamānaṃyeva samudācāruppannaṃ nāma. Sakiṃ
analyzed: bhūmi laddha uppannā ati saṅkham gacchanti iti  aparam pi catubbidham uppannam samudācāra uppannam ārammaṇa adhigahita uppannam a vikkhambhita uppannam  tattha sampati vattamānam yeva samudācāruppannam nāma
translated: “The defilements that have not been eradicated in the various planes go by the name ‘arisen by acquisition of plane.’ ”

original: cakkhūni ummīletvā ārammaṇe nimitte gahite anussaritānussaritakkhaṇe kilesā nuppajjissantīti
analyzed: cakkhūni ummīletvā ārammaṇe nimitte gahite anussarita anussarita khaṇe kilesāḥ nuppajjissanti iti
translated: There is another fourfold arising: arising as appearance, arising as object-conquest, arising as non-suppression, and arising as non-eradication. Herein, what is arising as appearance? Whatever at the moment of its presence is called “arisen” is called “arising as appearance.” For it cannot be said that defilements will not arise in the moment of reviewing the sign of the object after opening the eyes once,

original: na vattabbā. Kasmā? Ārammaṇassa adhigahitattā. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā khīrarukkhassa kuṭhāriyā
analyzed: na vattabbā kasmai ārammaṇassa adhigahita ttā yathā kim yathā khīra rukkhassa kuṭhāriyā
translated: because the object has been conquered. How so? Just as when a tree exudes milk when cut into,

original: āhatāhataṭṭhāne khīraṃ na nikkhamissatīti na vattabbaṃ, evaṃ. Idaṃ ārammaṇādhigahituppannaṃ
analyzed: āhata āhata ṭṭhāne khīram na nikkhamissati iti na vattabbam evam idam ārammaṇa adhigahita uppannam
translated: It should not be said that milk will not come from the place struck. So too, this is called arisen by apprehending an object.

original: nāma. Samāpattiyā avikkhambhitā kilesā pana imasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne nuppajjissantīti na
analyzed: nāma samāpattiyāḥ avikkhambhitāḥ kilesāḥ pana imasmin nāma ṭhāne nuppajjissanti iti na
translated: But it should not be said that defilements unabandoned by the attainment will not arise in such and such a place.🔽Why? Because they are unabandoned. How?

original: vattabbā. Kasmā? Avikkhambhitattā. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā sace khīrarukkhe kuṭhāriyā āhaneyyuṃ,
analyzed: vattabbā kasmai a vikkhambhita ttā yathā kim yathā sace khīra rukkhe kuṭhāriyāḥ āhaneyyuṃ
translated: Just as if they were to strike a milk-tree with an axe,

original: imasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne khīraṃ na nikkhameyyāti na vattabbaṃ, evaṃ. Idaṃ avikkhambhituppannaṃ🔽nāma. Maggena asamugghātitakilesā pana bhavagge nibbattassāpi uppajjantīti purimanayeneva
analyzed: imasmin nāma ṭhāne khīram na nikkhameyya ati na vattabbam evam idam a vikkhambhi tuppannam  nāma maggena asamugghātita kilesā pana bhavagge nibbattassa api uppajjanti iti purima nayena eva
translated: it should not be said that milk will not come from such and such a place. So too, this is called arisen unabandoned.

original: vitthāretabbaṃ. Idaṃ asamugghātituppannaṃ nāma.🔽Imesu uppannesu vattamānuppannaṃ bhutvāvigatuppannaṃ okāsakatuppannaṃ samudācāruppannanti
analyzed: vitthāretabbam idam asamugghātituppannam nāma  imesu uppannesu vattamāna uppannam bhutvā vigata uppannam okāsa kata uppannam samudācāra uppannam iti
translated: But it should be elaborated in the way already stated that defilements un-rooted by the path arise even in one reborn in the existence due to kamma. This is called arisen unrooted.

original: catubbidhaṃ uppannaṃ na maggavajjhaṃ, bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ ārammaṇādhigahituppannaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham uppannam na magga vajjham bhūmi laddha uppannam ārammaṇa adhigahita uppannam
translated: Among these kinds of arising, the four kinds called “arisen in the present,” “arisen in what is reached by condition,” “arisen in the proximate,” and “arisen as occurrence” are not abandoned by the path. Arisen by acquisition of plane and arisen by apprehending an object are not abandoned by the path.

original: avikkhambhituppannaṃ asamugghātituppannanti catubbidhaṃ maggavajjhaṃ. Maggo hi uppajjamāno
analyzed: avikkhambhi tuppannam asamugghāti tuppannam ti catubbidham magga vajjham maggaḥ hi uppajjamānaḥ
translated: For the path, when it arises,🔽abandons these defilements.

original: ete kilese pajahati. So ye kilese pajahati, te atītā vā anāgatā vā paccuppannā vāti
analyzed: ete kilese pajahati saḥ ye kilese pajahati te atītāḥ vā anāgatāḥ vā paccuppannāḥ vā ati
translated: But it cannot be said that it abandons defilements that are past, future, or present.

original: na vattabbā. Vuttampi cetaṃ –🔽“Hañci atīte kilese pajahati, tena hi khīṇaṃ khepeti, niruddhaṃ nirodheti, vigataṃ
analyzed: na vattabbā vuttam pi ca itam  hañci atīte kilese pajahati tena hi khīṇam khepeti niruddham nirodheti vigatam
translated: And this is said:

original: vigameti atthaṅgataṃ atthaṅgameti. Atītaṃ yaṃ natthi, taṃ pajahati. Hañci anāgate
analyzed: vigameti atthaṅgatam atthaṅgameti atītam yam na atthi tam pajahati hañci anāgate
translated: “If he abandons past defilements, then he would purify what is already purified, he would cause cessation what is already ceased, he would cause fading away what is already faded away, he would cause cessation without remainder of what has attained cessation without remainder.🔽And what is past does not exist.

original: kilese pajahati, tena hi ajātaṃ pajahati, anibbattaṃ, anuppannaṃ, apātubhūtaṃ pajahati.
analyzed: kilese pajahati tena hi a jātam pajahati anibbattam anuppannam a pātubhūtam pajahati
translated: If he abandons future defilements, then he would abandon what has not been born, what has not been generated, what has not been produced, what has not been manifested.

original: Anāgataṃ yaṃ natthi, taṃ pajahati, hañci paccuppanne kilese pajahati, tena hi ratto
analyzed: anāgatam yam natthi tam pajahati hañci paccuppanne kilese pajahati tena hi rattaḥ
translated: And what is future does not exist.

original: rāgaṃ pajahati, duṭṭho dosaṃ, mūḷho mohaṃ, vinibaddho mānaṃ, parāmaṭṭho diṭṭhiṃ,
analyzed: rāgam pajahati duṭṭhaḥ dosam mūḷhaḥ moham vinibaddhaḥ mānam parāmaṭṭhaḥ diṭṭhim
translated: If he abandons present defilements, then he would be abandoning lust for what is lustful, hatred for what is hateful, delusion for what is deluding, bondage for what is bound, grasping for what is grasped,

original: vikkhepagato uddhaccaṃ, aniṭṭhaṅgato vicikicchaṃ, thāmagato anusayaṃ pajahati. Kaṇhasukkadhammā
analyzed: vikkhepa gataḥ uddhaccam aniṭṭhaṅgataḥ vicikiccham thāma gataḥ anusayam pajahati kaṇha sukka dhammā
translated: He abandons the distraction that has gone into distraction, the uncertainty that has gone into uncertainty, the underlying tendency that has gone into an underlying tendency.🔽The dark and bright states🔽are yoked evenly. There is development of the path that is defiled…

original: yuganaddhā samameva vattanti. Saṃkilesikā maggabhāvanā hoti…pe… tena hi natthi maggabhāvanā,
analyzed: yuga naddhā samam eva vattanti saṃkilesikā magga bhāvanā hoti pe tena hi natthi magga bhāvanā
translated: Therefore there is no development of the path,

original: natthi phalasacchikiriyā, natthi kilesappahānaṃ, natthi dhammābhisamayoti. Atthi
analyzed: natthi phala sacchikiriyā natthi kilesa ppahānam natthi dhamma abhisamayaḥ ti atthi
translated: no realization of the fruit, no abandoning of defilements, no penetration of states.🔽There is development of the path…

original: maggabhāvanā…pe… atthi dhammābhisamayoti. Yathā kathaṃ viya, seyyathāpi taruṇo rukkho
analyzed: magga bhāvanāpe atthi dhamma abhisamayaḥ ti yathā katham viya seyyathā api taruṇaḥ rukkho
translated: There is penetration of states. In what way? Just as a young tree🔽that has not yet produced flowers or fruits…

original: ajātaphalo…pe… apātubhūtāyeva na pātubhavantī”ti.
analyzed: a jāta phala upe a pātubhūtāya iva na pātubhavanti iti
translated: are not manifest, though they are present.”

original: Iti pāḷiyaṃ ajātaphalarukkho āgato, jātaphalarukkhena pana dīpetabbaṃ. Yathā hi saphalo
analyzed: iti pāḷiyam ajāta phala rukkhaḥ āgataḥ jāta phala rukkhena pana dīpetabbam yathā hi sa phalaḥ
translated: So in the texts a young tree that has not yet produced flowers or fruits is given as an example, but it should be illustrated by a tree that has produced fruits.🔽For just as a young mango tree that has fruits

original: taruṇambarukkho, tassa phalāni manussā paribhuñjeyyuṃ, sesāni pātetvā pacchiyo pūreyyuṃ.
analyzed: taruṇambarukkho tassa phalāni manussā paribhuñjeyyum sesāni pātetvā pacchiyaḥ pūreyyum
translated: and people eat its fruits, and the remaining fruits fall and ripen and fill the ground,

original: Athañño puriso taṃ pharasunā chindeyya, tenassa neva atītāni phalāni nāsitāni honti,
analyzed: athaññaḥ puriso tam pharasunā chindeyya tenassa na iva atītāni phalāni na asitāni honti
translated: then another man cuts it down with an axe, then its past fruits are not destroyed,

original: na anāgatapaccuppannāni nāsitāni. Atītāni hi manussehi paribhuttāni, anāgatāni anibbattāni,
analyzed: na anāgata paccuppannāni na asitāni atītāni hi manussehi paribhuttāni anāgatāni a nibbattāni
translated: not those of the future and the present. For those of the past have been consumed by people, and those of the future have not yet come into existence,

original: na sakkā nāsetuṃ. Yasmiṃ pana samaye so chinno, tadā phalāniyeva natthīti paccuppannānipi🔽anāsitāni. Sace pana rukkho acchinno, athassa pathavīrasañca āporasañca āgamma yāni🔽phalāni nibbatteyyuṃ, tāni nāsitāni honti. Tāni hi ajātāneva na jāyanti, anibbattāneva
analyzed: na sakkā na āsetum yasmin pana samaye saḥ chinno tadā natthi iti paccuppannāni pi  an āsitāni sace pana rukkhaḥ a chinnaḥ athassa pathavī rasañca āpo rasañca āgamma yāni  phalāni nibbatteyyum tāni na asitāni honti tāni hi a jātāna iva na jāyanti a nibbattāna iva
translated: so they cannot be consumed. But at the time when it is cut down, there are no fruits then, so those of the present🔽are not consumed. But if the tree is not cut down, then the fruits that would come into existence through the sap in the roots and the sap in the earth

original: na nibbattanti, apātubhūtāneva na pātubhavanti, evameva maggo nāpi atītādibhede kilese🔽pajahati, nāpi na pajahati. Yesañhi kilesānaṃ maggena khandhesu apariññātesu uppatti
analyzed: na nibbattanti apātubhūtāna eva na pātubhavanti evam eva maggaḥ nā api atīta ādi bhede kilese  pajahati na api na pajahati yesam hi kilesānam maggena khandhesu apariññātesu uppatti
translated: are consumed. For these fruits, though unborn, are not born, though unarisen, do not arise, though unmanifested, do not become manifest. So too, the path does not abandon defilements classed as past, etc.,

original: siyā, maggena uppajjitvā khandhānaṃ pariññātattā te kilesā ajātāva na jāyanti, anibbattāva
analyzed: siyā maggena uppajjitvā khandhānam pariññāta ttā te kilesāḥ a jātā ava na jāyanti a nibbattā ava
translated: nor does it not abandon them. For the defilements whose arising in the aggregates is not terminated by the path would arise if the aggregates were not terminated by the path. But those defilements, though unborn, are not born, though unarisen, do not arise, though unmanifested, do not become manifest.

original: na nibbattanti, apātubhūtāva na pātubhavanti, taruṇaputtāya itthiyā puna avijāyanatthaṃ,
analyzed: na nibbattanti a pātubhūtāḥ ava na pātubhavanti taruṇa puttāya itthiyā puna a vijāyana attham
translated: They do not arise, and those that have not already arisen do not come to arise.

original: byādhitānaṃ rogavūpasamanatthaṃ pītabhesajjehi cāpi ayamattho vibhāvetabbo. Evaṃ
analyzed: byādhitānam roga vūpasamana attham pīta bhesajjehi ca api ayam atthaḥ vibhāvetabbaḥ evam
translated: This meaning should be illustrated also by the medicine taken for the purpose of preventing a woman who has given birth to a child from giving birth again, and for the purpose of allaying the sickness of those who are sick.

original: maggo ye kilese pajahati, te atītā vā anāgatā vā paccuppannā vāti na vattabbā, na🔽ca maggo kilese na pajahati. Ye pana maggo kilese pajahati, te sandhāya “uppannānaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ ye kilese pajahati te atītāḥ vā anāgatāḥ vā paccuppannāḥ vā ti na vattabbāḥ na  ca maggo kilese na pajahati ye pana maggo kilese pajahati te sandhāya uppannānam
translated: Thus it should not be said that the defilements that are abandoned by the path are past, future, or present,

original: pāpakāna”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pāpakānam tiādi vuttam
translated: nor that the path abandons the defilements. But the words “of arisen evil states” are said with reference to those defilements that are abandoned by the path.

original: Na kevalañca maggo kileseyeva pajahati, kilesānaṃ pana appahīnattā ye ca uppajjeyyuṃ
analyzed: na kevalam ca maggaḥ pajahati kilesānam pana appahīna ttā ye ca uppajjeyyum
translated: And the path does not abandon only defilements. It also abandons the aggregates that would arise if there were no path, since the defilements are not abandoned.

original: upādinnakakkhandhā, tepi pajahatiyeva. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “sotāpattimaggañāṇena abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa
analyzed: upādinnaka khandhā te pi pajahatiyā iva vuttam pi ca itam sotāpatti magga ñāṇena abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇassa
translated: For this is said: “By the knowledge of the path of stream-entry, with the cessation of the consciousness that is determined by formations,

original: nirodhena satta bhave ṭhapetvā anamatagge saṃsāre ye uppajjeyyuṃ nāmañca rūpañca,
analyzed: nirodhena satta bhave ṭhapetvā anamatagge saṃsāre ye uppajjeyyum nāmañca rūpañca
translated: the name-and-form that would arise in the future in the beginningless round of rebirths, leaving aside the seven existences,

original: etthete nirujjhantī”ti vitthāro. Iti maggo upādinnaanupādinnato vuṭṭhāti. Bhavavasena🔽pana sotāpattimaggo apāyabhavato vuṭṭhāti, sakadāgāmimaggo sugatibhavekadesato, anāgāmimaggo
analyzed: ettha ete nirujjhanti iti vitthāraḥ iti maggaḥ upādinna anupādinnataḥ vuṭṭhāti bhava vasena  pana sotāpatti maggaḥ apāya bhavataḥ vuṭṭhāti sakadāgāmi maggo sugati bhava eka desataḥ anāgāmi maggo
translated: and here they cease” . So the path emerges from the clung-to and the unclung-to.

original: sugatikāmabhavato, arahattamaggo rūpārūpabhavato vuṭṭhāti. Sabbabhavehi vuṭṭhātiyevātipi vadanti.🔽Atha maggakkhaṇe kathaṃ anuppannānaṃ uppādāya bhāvanā hoti, kathaṃ vā uppannānaṃ
analyzed: sugati kāma bhavataḥ arahatta maggaḥ rūpa arūpa bhavataḥ vuṭṭhāti sabba bhavehi vadanti  atha magga kkhaṇe katham anuppannānam uppādāya bhāvanā hoti katham vā uppannānam
translated: But as regards becoming, the stream-entry path emerges from the kinds of becoming that lead to an unhappy destiny, the once-return path from the kinds of becoming that lead to a happy destiny in part, the non-return path from the kinds of becoming that lead to a happy destiny in the sensual-desire realm, and the Arahant path from the kinds of becoming that lead to a happy destiny in the form and formless realms. They say that it emerges from all kinds of becoming.🔽Now, how is there development of the path in the way beginning, “For the arising of unarisen enlightenment factor … ” , or how is there maintenance of it in being in the way beginning, “For the continuance … of arisen enlightenment factor … ” ?

original: ṭhitiyāti. Maggappavattiyāyeva. Maggo hi pavattamāno pubbe anuppannapubbattā anuppanno🔽nāma vuccati. Anāgatapubbañhi ṭhānaṃ āgantvā ananubhūtapubbaṃ vā ārammaṇaṃ anubhavitvā
analyzed: ṭhitiyā ti magga ppavattiyāya iva maggaḥ hi pavattamānaḥ pubbe anuppanna pubbattā anuppannaḥ  nāma vuccati anāgata pubbam hi ṭhānam āgantvā ananubhūta pubbam vā ārammaṇam anubhavitvā
translated: It is by the occurrence of the path itself. For the path is called “unrisen” because it has not occurred previously,🔽because it has not come into the place where it has not been before, or because it has not experienced the object that it has not experienced before.

original: vattāro bhavanti “anāgataṭṭhānaṃ āgatamhā, ananubhūtaṃ ārammaṇaṃ anubhavāmā”ti. Yā
analyzed: vattāraḥ bhavanti anāgata ṭṭhānam ananubhūtam ārammaṇam anubhavāma ati yā
translated: For it is said, “The occurrences have come to the place they have not come to before, or have experienced the object they have not experienced before” .

original: cassa pavatti, ayameva ṭhiti nāmāti ṭhitiyā bhāvetītipi vattuṃ vaṭṭati.

original: purimesu sabbesu atthi. Rūpī rūpāni passatīti ettha ajjhattakesādīsu nīlakasiṇādivasena🔽uppāditaṃ rūpajjhānaṃ rūpaṃ, tadassa atthīti rūpī. Bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti bahiddhāpi🔽nīlakasiṇādīni rūpāni jhānacakkhunā passati. Iminā ajjhatta bahiddhāvatthukesu kasiṇesu
analyzed: purimesu sabbesu atthi rūpī rūpāni passati iti ettha ajjhatta kesa ādīsu nīla kasiṇa ādi vasena  uppāditam rūpa jjhānam rūpam tat assa atthi iti rūpī bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti bahiddhā api  nīla kasiṇa ādīni rūpāni jhāna cakkhunā passati iminā ajjhatta bahiddhā vatthukesu kasiṇesu
translated: In the first three all are present. In the case of “one who is material sees material things”: the materiality in the materiality jhāna arisen by making the blue kasiṇa the object, etc., is materiality; he has that, thus he is a material being. He sees material things externally: he sees blue kasiṇa, etc., externally with the jhāna eye. By this means he sees kasiṇas as objects both internally and externally.

original: uppāditajjhānassa puggalassa cattāripi rūpāvacarajjhānāni dassitāni.🔽Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññīti ajjhattaṃ na rūpasaññī, attano kesādīsu anuppāditarūpāvacarajjhānoti
analyzed: uppādita jhānassa puggalassa cattāri pi rūpāvacara jhānāni dassitāni  ajjhattam a rūpa saññī iti ajjhattam na rūpa saññī attano kesa ādīsu an uppādita rūpāvacara jhāno ti
translated: In the first three all are present. In the case of “One who is material sees material things”: the fine-material-sphere jhāna arisen in the kasiṇas beginning with that of the earth as blue, etc., is the materiality; he has that, thus he is “material” . He sees material things externally: he sees with the jhāna eye material things externally as well, that is, the kasiṇas beginning with that of the blue. By this he shows the four fine-material-sphere jhānas of a person who has aroused jhāna in the kasiṇas that are internal and external objects.

original: attho. Iminā bahiddhā parikammaṃ katvā bahiddhāva uppāditajjhānassa rūpāvacarajjhānāni🔽dassitāni. Subhanteva adhimutto hotīti iminā suvisuddhesu nīlādīsu vaṇṇakasiṇesu
analyzed: attho iminā bahiddhā parikammam katvā bahiddhā vā uppādita jhānassa rūpāvacara jhānāni  dassitāni adhimuttaḥ hoti iti iminā su visuddhesu nīla ādīsu vaṇṇa kasiṇesu
translated: In the case of “One who is formless internally has no kasiṇa sign as object”: he has no kasiṇa sign internally, that is, he has not aroused fine-material-sphere jhāna in the head hairs, etc., that are internal objects. By this he shows the fine-material-sphere jhānas of one who has aroused jhāna externally only, after doing the preliminary work externally.

original: jhānāni dassitāni. Tattha kiñcāpi antoappanāyaṃ subhanti ābhogo natthi, yo pana suvisuddhaṃ
analyzed: jhānāni dassitāni tattha kiñcā api anto appanā ayam subhanti ābhogo natthi yaḥ pana su visuddham
translated: In the case of “One who is resolved upon the beautiful”: he shows the jhānas in the colour kasiṇas that are quite purified, such as the blue one, etc. Herein, although there is no resolution upon the beautiful in the first absorption, still it is mentioned here because it is mentioned in the description of the fourth absorption.

original: subhakasiṇaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā viharati, so yasmā subhanti adhimutto hotīti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: subha kasiṇam ārammaṇam katvā viharati saḥ yasmai subha nti adhimutto hoti iti
translated: He dwells with the sign of beauty as his object, and therefore he comes to be called one who has resolved upon the sign of beauty.

original: āpajjati, tasmā evaṃ desanā katā. Paṭisambhidāmagge pana “kathaṃ subhanteva adhimutto
analyzed: āpajjati tasmai evam desanā katā paṭisambhidā magge pana katham subhantā iva adhimuttaḥ
translated: That is why the teaching is given in this way. But in the Paṭisambhidā it is said: “How does he become one who has resolved upon the sign of beauty?

original: hotīti vimokkho. Idha bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati…pe…🔽mettāya bhāvitattā sattā appaṭikūlā honti. Karuṇāsahagatena, muditāsahagatena, upekkhāsahagatena
analyzed: hoti iti vimokkhaḥ idha bhikkhu mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati  mettāya bhāvita ttā sattāḥ a paṭikūlāḥ honti karuṇā sahagatena muditā sahagatena upekkhā sahagatena
translated: Liberation: here a bhikkhu abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with loving-kindness, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth;🔽so above, below, around, and everywhere, and to all as to himself, he abides pervading the all-encompassing world with a mind imbued with loving-kindness, abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility and without ill will.🔽Because loving-kindness is developed in this way, beings are not repulsive. He abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with compassion … with a mind imbued with appreciative joy … with a mind imbued with equanimity, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth;

original: cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati…pe… upekkhāya bhāvitattā sattā appaṭikūlā honti.
analyzed: cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati pe upekkhāya bhāvita ttā sattāḥ a paṭikūlāḥ honti
translated: so above, below, around, and everywhere, and to all as to himself, he abides pervading the all-encompassing world with a mind imbued with equanimity, abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility and without ill will.🔽Because equanimity is developed in this way, beings are not repulsive.

original: Evaṃ subhanteva adhimutto hotīti vimokkho”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: evam adhimutto hoti iti vimokkhaḥ ti vuttam
translated: Thus he becomes one who has resolved upon the sign of beauty” .

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānantiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttameva. Ayaṃ🔽aṭṭhamo vimokkhoti ayaṃ catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ sabbaso vissaṭṭhattā vimuttattā aṭṭhamo
analyzed: sabbasas rūpa saññānaṃ ti ādīsu yam vattabbam tat sabbam visuddhi magge vuttam eva ayam  aṭṭhamaḥ vimokkho ti ayam catunnam khandhānam sabbasas vissaṭṭha ttā vimutta ttā aṭṭhamaḥ
translated: As to the passages beginning “Quite secluded from sense desires” , all that should be understood as already explained in the Description of the Meditations .

original: uttamo vimokkho nāma.
analyzed: uttamaḥ vimokkhaḥ nāma
translated: This is the eighth liberation: this is called the eighth and highest liberation because of the complete seclusion and liberation from the four aggregates.

original: 249. Abhibhāyatanakathāyaṃ abhibhāyatanānīti abhibhavanakāraṇāni. Kiṃ abhibhavanti?
analyzed: abhibhāyatana kathā ayam abhibhāyatanāni iti abhibhavana kāraṇāni kim abhibhavanti
translated: In the description of the bases of mastery, the bases of mastery are the causes of mastery. What do they master?

original: Paccanīkadhammepi ārammaṇānipi. Tāni hi paṭipakkhabhāvena paccanīkadhamme abhibhavanti,
analyzed: paccanīka dhamme api ārammaṇāni pi tāni hi paṭipakkha bhāvena paccanīka dhamme abhibhavanti
translated: They master opposing states and objects. For they master opposing states by being their opposites,🔽and they master objects by the superiority of the knowledge of the person.

original: puggalassa ñāṇuttaritāya ārammaṇāni. Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññītiādīsu pana ajjhattarūpe
analyzed: puggalassa ñāṇa uttaritāya ārammaṇāni ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti ādīsu pana ajjhatta rūpe
translated: But in the case of the phrases “perceiving forms internally” , etc.,🔽he is called “perceiving forms internally” because he has made the preliminary work his own by means of internal forms.

original: parikammavasena ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī nāma hoti. Ajjhattañca nīlaparikammaṃ karonto🔽kese vā pitte vā akkhitārakāya vā karoti, pītaparikammaṃ karonto mede vā chaviyā
analyzed: parikamma vasena ajjhattam rūpa saññī nāma hoti ajjhattam ca nīla parikammam karonto  kese vā pitte vā akkhi tārakāya vā karoti pīta parikammam karontaḥ mede vā chaviyā
translated: When he is making the preliminary work with blue externally,🔽he does it in the hair of the head, in the hair of the body, in the nails, or in the blue part of the eyes. When he is making the preliminary work with yellow,

original: vā hatthatalapādatalesu vā akkhīnaṃ pītaṭṭhāne vā karoti, lohitaparikammaṃ karonto
analyzed: vā hattha tala pāda talesu vā akkhīnam pīta ṭṭhāne vā karoti lohita parikammam karonto
translated: he does it in the bile, in the skin, in the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet, or in the yellow part of the eyes. When he is making the preliminary work with red,

analyzed: maṃse vā lohite vā jivhāya vā akkhīnam ratta ṭṭhāne vā karoti odāta parikammam karonto

analyzed: aṭṭhimhi vā dante vā nakhe vā akkhīnam seta ṭṭhāne vā karoti tam pana su nīlam su pītakam
translated: he does it in the bones, in the teeth, in the nails, or in the white part of the eyes. But that is only when they are very pure.

original: sulohitakaṃ suodātaṃ na hoti, asuvisuddhameva hoti.🔽Eko bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti yassetaṃ parikammaṃ ajjhattaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, nimittaṃ🔽pana bahiddhā, so evaṃ ajjhattaṃ parikammassa bahiddhā ca appanāya vasena – “ajjhattaṃ

translated: and it is not very red or very white, but only very clear.

analyzed: rūpa saññī ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti vuccati parittāni iti avaḍḍhitāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti
translated: One who has aroused the preliminary-work in himself but whose sign is external is called “one who has perception of form internally and sees forms externally” in the way already described under the first jhāna in the first triad.

translated: Limited: not extended. Fair and ugly: whether fair or ugly, this is said to be the measure of the extent of the kasiṇa .

analyzed: visada ñāṇaḥ kim ettha parittake ārammaṇe samāpajjitabbam atthi na ayam mama bhāraḥ ti
translated: He masters them: just as a man with a good stomach can eat a given amount of food after collecting it from various places, thinking, “There is nothing here that is not good for me,” so too this person with his clear knowledge collects the various forms with his mind and masters them.

original: tāni rūpāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati, saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetīti
analyzed: tāni rūpāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati saha nimitta uppādena iva itthā appanam pāpeti iti
translated: The meaning is that he reaches absorption with the mere production of the sign.

original: attho. Jānāmi passāmīti iminā panassa ābhogo kathito, so ca kho samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa,
analyzed: atthaḥ jānāmi passāmi iti iminā pana assa ābhogaḥ kathito so ca kho samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa

analyzed: appamāṇāni iti vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni mahantāni iti atthaḥ ettha pana yathā  mahagghasaḥ purisaḥ ekam bhatta vaḍḍhitakam labhitvā aññā api hotu aññā api hotu kim esā
translated: He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.🔽He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.🔽He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.🔽He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.

original: mayhaṃ karissatī”ti taṃ na mahantato passati, evameva ñāṇuttaro puggalo visadañāṇo
analyzed: mayham karissati iti tam na mahantataḥ passati evam eva ñāṇa uttaraḥ puggalo visada ñāṇo
translated: He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.🔽He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.🔽He is “thus” confident, that is, he is confident “thus” in the confidence of one who has emerged from the jhāna.

original: “kimettha samāpajjitabbaṃ, nayidaṃ appamāṇaṃ, na mayhaṃ cittekaggatākaraṇe bhāro
analyzed: kim ettha samāpajjitabbam na yidam appamāṇam na mayham citta ekagga tā karaṇe bhāraḥ
translated: He is “thus” confident

original: atthī”ti tāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati, saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetīti attho.
analyzed: atthi iti tāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam pāpeti iti attho
translated: he enters upon them after surmounting the earth kasiṇa by means of these four jhānas. The meaning is that he brings them to the actual presence of absorption by the mere arising of the jhāna factors.

original: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññīti alābhitāya vā anatthikatāya vā ajjhattarūpe parikammasaññāvirahito.
analyzed: ajjhattam arūpa saññī iti alābhi tāya vā anatthikatāya vā ajjhatta rūpe parikamma saññā virahitaḥ
translated: With non-perception of forms internally: either because he has not obtained the formless states or because he has no need for them.

original: Eko bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti yassa parikammampi nimittampi bahiddhāva uppannaṃ,🔽so evaṃ bahiddhā parikammassa ceva appanāya ca vasena – “ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko
analyzed: ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti yassa parikammam pi nimittam pi bahiddhā vā uppannam  so evam bahiddhā parikammassa ca iva appanāya ca vasena ajjhattam arūpa saññī ekaḥ
translated: One sees forms externally: one whose preliminary work and jhāna kasiṇa are only externally arisen.

original: bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti vuccati. Sesamettha catutthābhibhāyatane vuttanayameva.
analyzed: bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti vuccati sesam ettha catuttha abhibhāyatane vutta nayam eva
translated: So it is in virtue of the external preliminary work and jhāna that it is said: “With non-perception of forms internally, one sees forms externally” .
