original: Imesu pana catūsu parittaṃ vitakkacaritavasena āgataṃ, appamāṇaṃ mohacaritavasena,
analyzed: imesu pana catūsu parittam vitakka carita vasena āgatam appamāṇam moha carita vasena
translated: the measureless one is that of the type whose temperament is dominated by delusion,🔽the beautiful one is that of the type whose temperament is dominated by hate,

original: suvaṇṇaṃ dosacaritavasena, dubbaṇṇaṃ rāgacaritavasena. Etesañhi etāni sappāyāni.
analyzed: su vaṇṇam dosa carita vasena dubbaṇṇam rāga carita vasena etesam hi etāni sappāyāni
translated: and the ugly one is that of the type whose temperament is dominated by greed. For these are suitable for them.

original: Sā ca nesaṃ sappāyatā vitthārato visuddhimaggecariyaniddese vuttā.
analyzed: sā ca nesam sappāya tā vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge cariya niddese vuttā
translated: And the suitability of these for them is given in detail in the Description of the Path in the Visuddhimagga .

original: Pañcamaabhibhāyatanādīsu nīlānīti sabbasaṅgāhikavasena vuttaṃ. Nīlavaṇṇānīti vaṇṇavasena.
translated: In the case of the five bases of mastery, etc., ‘blue’ is said as a comprehensive term. ‘Blue in colour’ is said as a colour term.

original: Nīlanidassanānīti nidassanavasena. Apaññāyamānavivarāni asambhinnavaṇṇāni ekanīlāneva
analyzed: nīla nidassanāni iti nidassana vasena a paññāyamāna vivarāni asambhinna vaṇṇāni eka nīlāni eva
translated: ‘Blue in appearance’ is said as an appearance term. They are not classifiable as to gaps, they are not classifiable as to variegation, they are only blue,

original: hutvā dissantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Nīlanibhāsānīti idaṃ pana obhāsavasena vuttaṃ, nīlobhāsāni🔽nīlapabhāyuttānīti attho. Etena nesaṃ suvisuddhataṃ dasseti. Visuddhavaṇṇavaseneva
analyzed: hutvā dissanti iti vuttam hoti nīla nibhāsāni iti idam pana obhāsa vasena vuttam nīla ubhāsāni  nīla pabhā yuttāni iti attho etena nesam su visuddha tam dasseti visuddha vaṇṇa vasena iva
translated: and they appear as if burnt. ‘Blue in lustre’ is said as a lustre term. They have a blue lustre,

original: hi imāni cattāri abhibhāyatanāni vuttāni. Umāpupphanti etañhi pupphaṃ siniddhaṃ muduṃ
analyzed: hi imāni cattāri abhibhāyatanāni vuttāni umāpupphanti etat hi puppham siniddham mudum
translated: is the meaning. This shows that they are very pure. For these four bases of mastery are stated as a very pure colour.🔽‘Like the umā flower’ . For this flower is glossy, soft,

original: dissamānampi nīlameva hoti. Girikaṇṇikapupphādīni pana dissamānāni setadhātukāni
analyzed: dissamānam pi nīlam eva hoti girikaṇṇika puppha ādīni pana dissamānāni seta dhātukāni
translated: and though it is seen, it is only blue. But the girikaṇṇika flower, etc., though seen, are of the white element,

original: honti. Tasmā idameva gahitaṃ, na tāni. Bārāṇaseyyakanti bārāṇasiyaṃ bhavaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: honti tasmai idam eva gahitam na tāni bārāṇaseyyakanti bārāṇasiyam bhavam tattha
translated: and so only this is included, not those. ‘Of Benares’ : of Benares. There, it seems, the cotton is soft,

original: kira kappāsopi mudu, suttakantikāyopi tantavāyāpi chekā, udakampi suci siniddhaṃ,
analyzed: kira kappāsaḥ api mudu tantavāyā api chekāḥ udakampi suci
translated: the weavers are skilled, and the water is pure and glossy,

original: tasmā vatthaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ hoti, dvīsu passesu maṭṭhaṃ mudu siniddhaṃ khāyati.
analyzed: tasmai vattham ubhatobhāga vimaṭṭham hoti dvīsu passesu maṭṭham mudu siniddham khāyati
translated: So the cloth is called “washed on both sides” because it is washed on the two sides, and it is “soft, delicate, and lovely to the touch.”

original: Pītānītiādīsu imināva nayena attho veditabbo. “Nīlakasiṇaṃ uggaṇhanto nīlasmiṃ nimittaṃ🔽gaṇhāti pupphasmiṃ vā vatthasmiṃ vā vaṇṇadhātuyā vā”tiādikaṃ panettha kasiṇakaraṇañceva
analyzed: pītāni iti ādīsu iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nīla kasiṇam uggaṇhantaḥ nīlasmin nimittam  gaṇhāti pupphasmim vā vatthasmim vā vaṇṇa dhātuyā vāti ādikam pana ittha kasiṇa karaṇam ca iva
translated: The meaning of the rest should be understood in the same way. “One who is learning the blue kasiṇa apprehends the sign in blue,

original: parikammañca appanāvidhānañca sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vitthārato vuttameva.🔽Abhiññāvosānapāramippattāti ito pubbesu satipaṭṭhānādīsu te dhamme bhāvetvā arahattappattāva🔽abhiññāvosānapāramippattā nāma honti, imesu pana aṭṭhasu abhibhāyatanesu ciṇṇavasībhāvāyeva
analyzed: parikammañca appanā vidhānañca sabbam visuddhi magge vitthārataḥ vuttam eva  abhiññā vosāna pārami pattā ti itas pubbesu sati paṭṭhāna ādīsu te dhamme bhāvetvā arahatta ppattā va  abhiññā vosāna pārami pattāḥ nāma honti imesu pana aṭṭhasu abhibhāyatanesu ciṇṇavasībhāvāya iva
translated: in a flower, in a cloth, or in a colour element” . The making of the kasiṇa, the preliminary work, the directions for absorption, etc., are all given in detail in the Visuddhimagga .🔽They have reached the culmination of direct knowledge and penetration: they have reached the culmination of direct knowledge and penetration by developing the earlier meditations beginning with the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: abhiññāvosānapāramippattā nāma.
analyzed: abhiññāvosānapāramippattā nāma
translated: But they are called “those who have reached the culmination of direct knowledge and penetration” only when they have reached mastery of the eight spheres of mastery.🔽In this kasiṇa meditation the kasiṇas are called “totalities” in the sense of being the whole of something.

original: 250. Kasiṇakathāyaṃ sakalaṭṭhena kasiṇāni, tadārammaṇānaṃ dhammānaṃ khettaṭṭhena
analyzed: sakala aṭṭhena kasiṇāni tad ārammaṇānam dhammānam khetta ṭṭhena
translated: The things that have the kasiṇas as their object are called “fields” in the sense of being fields for the exercise of direct knowledge.

original: adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena vā āyatanāni. Uddhanti upari gaganatalābhimukhaṃ. Adhoti heṭṭhā🔽bhūmitalābhimukhaṃ. Tiriyanti khettamaṇḍalamiva samantā paricchinditvā. Ekacco hi
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna aṭṭhena vā āyatanāni uddhanti upari gagana tala abhimukham adhas ti heṭṭhā  bhūmi tala abhimukham tiriyanti khetta maṇḍalam iva samantā paricchinditvā ekaccaḥ hi
translated: Or else the sense bases are the objective fields in the sense of being the bases for the objective fields. “Upwards” means directed upwards towards the sky. “Downwards” means directed downwards towards the earth. “Horizontally” means all around, like the area of a field. For some

original: uddhameva kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍheti, ekacco adho, ekacco samantato. Tena tena kāraṇena evaṃ🔽pasāreti ālokamiva rūpadassanakāmo. Tena vuttaṃ – “pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṃadhotiriya”nti.
analyzed: uddham eva kasiṇam vaḍḍheti ekaccaḥ adhas ekaccaḥ samantataḥ tena tena kāraṇena evam  pasāreti ālokam iva rūpa dassana kāmo tena vuttam pathavī kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti uddhaṃ adhas tiriyanti
translated: Or alternatively, the bases are the “bases” in the sense of standing as foundations for the arising of the jhāna factors. He extends : he extends it upwards, facing the upper sky. Downwards : he extends it downwards, facing the lower earth. Across : he extends it across, as though he were encompassing all round with earth. For some extend the kasiṇa only upwards, some only downwards, and some only across. For that reason it is said: “One perceives earth as earth above, below, across” .

original: Advayanti disāanudisāsu advayaṃ. Idaṃ pana ekassa aññabhāvānupagamanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Yathā hi udakaṃ paviṭṭhassa sabbadisāsu udakameva hoti anaññaṃ, evamevaṃ pathavīkasiṇaṃ
analyzed: advayanti disā anudisāsu advayam idam pana ekassa añña bhāva an upagamana attham vuttam  yathā hi udakam paviṭṭhassa sabba disāsu udakam eva hoti anaññam evam evam pathavī kasiṇam
translated: Without making the twofold distinction of here and there : without making the twofold distinction of “here” and “there” in the directions. But this is said in order to show that it is not to be extended in the way that the earth is divided into here and there.

original: pathavīkasiṇameva hoti, natthi tassa añño kasiṇasambhedoti. Esa nayo sabbattha. Appamāṇanti
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇam eva hoti natthi tassa aññaḥ kasiṇa sambhedo ti esa nayo sabbattha appamāṇam ti
translated: For just as when a man enters the water, the water is all round him and there is none that is not water, so too, this earth kasiṇa is all round him and there is none that is not earth. There is no division of the kasiṇa into different parts. This is the meaning. The same method of explanation applies in each instance.

original: idaṃ tassa tassa pharaṇaappamāṇavasena vuttaṃ. Tañhi cetasā pharanto sakalameva pharati,
analyzed: idam tassa tassa pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena vuttam tat hi cetasā pharantaḥ sakalam eva pharati
translated: Immeasurable : this is said in order to show that it is to be extended to an immeasurable extent. For when he extends it with his mind, he extends it entirely.

original: ayamassa ādi, idaṃ majjhanti pamāṇaṃ gaṇhātīti. Viññāṇakasiṇanti cettha kasiṇugghāṭimākāse
analyzed: ayam assa ādi idam majjhanti pamāṇam gaṇhāti iti viññāṇa kasiṇanti ca ittha kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse
translated: ‘The sign of consciousness’ here is the consciousness occurring in the space defined by the kasiṇa that has been removed.

original: pavattaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Tattha kasiṇavasena kasiṇugghāṭimākāse, kasiṇugghāṭimākāsavasena🔽tattha pavattaviññāṇe uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Kammaṭṭhānabhāvanānayena
analyzed: pavattam viññāṇam tattha kasiṇa vasena kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsa vasena  tattha pavatta viññāṇe veditabbā ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā nayena
translated: The extent of the space defined by the kasiṇa that has been removed should be understood as the extent of the consciousness occurring there.

original: panetāni pathavīkasiṇādīni vitthārato visuddhimagge vuttāneva. Idhāpi ciṇṇavasibhāveneva
analyzed: pana itāni pathavī kasiṇa ādīni vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge vuttānā idha api ciṇṇa vasi bhāvena iva
translated: This is the brief treatment here. But these earth kasiṇas, etc., should be understood in detail according to the method of development given in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa, etc., in the Path of Purification.

original: abhiññāvosānapāramippattā hontīti veditabbā. Tathā ito anantaresu catūsu jhānesu.🔽Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ mahāassapurasutte vuttameva.
analyzed: abhiññā vosāna pārami pattāḥ honti iti veditabbā tathā itas anantaresu catūsu jhānesu  yam pana ittha vattabbam tam mahāassapura sutte vuttam eva
translated: And they should be understood to have reached the culmination of their development when the meditator has acquired mastery in the following five ways: 1. By day and by night, 2. In the several postures, 3. In the various situations of the people, 4. In the four objects, and 5. In the fourfold delimitation.🔽And the explanation of them is given in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa, etc.

original: 252. Vipassanāñāṇe pana rūpītiādīnamattho vuttoyeva. Ettha sitamettha paṭibaddhanti
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇe pana rūpī iti ādīnam atthaḥ ettha sitam ettha paṭibaddhanti
translated: But the meaning of ‘material,’ etc., in the knowledge of insight has already been given .

original: ettha cātumahābhūtike kāye nissitañca paṭibaddhañca. Subhoti sundaro. Jātimāti suparisuddhaākarasamuṭṭhito.
analyzed: ettha cātumahābhūtike kāye nissitañca paṭibaddhañca subho ti sundaraḥ jātimā ati su parisuddha ākara samuṭṭhito
translated: ‘Herein is beauty, herein is foulness’ means herein is what is dependent and bound up with the four primary elements. ‘Beauty’ is what is lovely. ‘Foulness’ is what is ugly. ‘Herein is the desirable, herein the undesirable’ means herein is what is agreeable and what is disagreeable. ‘Herein is the surpassing, herein the unsurpassed’ means herein is what is inferior and what is excellent.

original: Suparikammakatoti suṭṭhu kataparikammo apanītapāsāṇasakkharo. Acchoti tanucchavi.
analyzed: su parikamma katoti suṭṭhu kata parikammaḥ apanīta pāsāṇa sakkharo acchaḥ ti tanu chavi
translated: Well-worked: well-worked down, with stones and gravel removed. Clear: suitable for it.🔽Well-purified: well-purified, complete in all its aspects.

original: Vippasannoti suṭṭhu vippasanno. Sabbākārasampannoti dhovana vedhanādīhi sabbehi ākārehi
analyzed: vippasanno ti suṭṭhu vippasanno sabba ākāra sampanno ti dhovana vedhana ādīhi sabbehi ākārehi
translated: Complete in all its aspects: complete in all the aspects of washing, sewing, etc.

original: sampanno. Nīlantiādīhi vaṇṇasampattiṃ dasseti. Tādisañhi āvutaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sampannaḥ nīla nti ādīhi vaṇṇa sampattim dasseti tādisam hi āvutam pākaṭam hoti
translated: Blue: etc. shows the perfection of its colour. For when it is dyed, it shows up clearly.

original: Evameva khoti ettha evaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ – maṇi viya hi karajakāyo. Āvutasuttaṃ
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha evam upamā saṃsandanam veditabbam maṇi viya hi karaja kāyaḥ āvuta suttam
translated: Just so too: here the correlation of the simile should be understood in this way. For just as the gem is like the physical body,🔽and the thread wound round it is like insight knowledge,

original: viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Cakkhumā puriso viya vipassanālābhī bhikkhu. Hatthe karitvā
analyzed: viya vipassanā ñāṇam cakkhumā puriso viya vipassanā lābhī bhikkhu hatthe karitvā
translated: and the man with good eyesight is like the bhikkhu who has attained insight,

original: paccavekkhato “ayaṃ kho maṇī”ti maṇino āvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ abhinīharitvā🔽nisinnassa bhikkhuno cātumahābhūtikakāyassa āvibhūtakālo. “Tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvuta”nti
analyzed: paccavekkhataḥ ayam kho maṇi iti maṇinaḥ āvibhūta kālaḥ viya vipassanā ñāṇam abhinīharitvā  nisinnassa bhikkhuno cātumahābhūtika kāyassa āvibhūta kālaḥ tatra idam suttam āvutanti
translated: and the time when the gem becomes evident to him as he examines it in his hand is like the time when the bhikkhu, after he has directed insight knowledge to the object,

original: suttassa āvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tadārammaṇānaṃ
analyzed: suttassa āvibhūta kālaḥ viya vipassanā ñāṇam abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tad ārammaṇānaṃ
translated: and the time when the thread becomes evident to him is like the time when the bhikkhu, after he has directed insight knowledge to the object,🔽and the time when the thread becomes evident to him is like the time when the bhikkhu, after he has directed insight knowledge to the object,

original: phassapañcamakānaṃ vā sabbacittacetasikānaṃ vā vipassanāñāṇasseva vā āvibhūtakāloti.
analyzed: phassa pañcamakānam vā sabba citta cetasikānam vā vipassanā ñāṇassa iva vā āvibhūta kālaḥ ti
translated: Or it is the time of the manifestation of the knowledge of insight itself.

original: Kiṃ panetaṃ ñāṇassa āvibhūtaṃ, puggalassāti. Ñāṇassa, tassa pana āvibhāvattā puggalassa🔽āvibhūtāva honti. Idañca vipassanāñāṇaṃ maggassa anantaraṃ, evaṃ santepi yasmā abhiññāvāre
analyzed: kim pana etam ñāṇassa āvibhūtam puggalassa ati ñāṇassa tassa pana āvibhāva ttā puggalassa  āvibhūtā ava honti idam ca vipassanā ñāṇam maggassa anantaram evam sante pi yasmai abhiññāvāre
translated: But is it the knowledge that is manifested or the person? It is the knowledge, but because of the manifestation of that knowledge,🔽the person is manifested too. And this knowledge of insight is next to the path. But even though that is so, since there is no interval between it and the direct-knowledge,

original: āraddhe etassa antarāvāro natthi, tasmā idheva dassitaṃ. Yasmā ca aniccādivasena🔽akatasammasanassa dibbāya sotadhātuyā bheravasaddaṃ suṇanto pubbenivāsānussatiyā
analyzed: āraddhe etassa antarāvāraḥ natthi tasmai idha iva dassitam yasmai ca anicca ādi vasena  a kata sammasanassa dibbāya sotadhātuyā bherava saddam suṇantaḥ pubbenivāsa anussatiyā
translated: it is shown here in the “development” section. And since fear arises in one who has not already discerned mentality-materiality as impermanent, etc.,

original: bherave khandhe anussarato dibbena cakkhunā bheravarūpaṃ passato bhayasantāso uppajjati,🔽na aniccādivasena katasammasanassa, tasmā abhiññāpattassa bhayavinodakahetusampādanatthampi
analyzed: bherave khandhe anussarataḥ dibbena cakkhunā bherava rūpam passataḥ bhaya santāsaḥ uppajjati  na anicca ādi vasena kata sammasanassa tasmai abhiññā pattassa bhaya vinodaka hetu sampādana attham pi
translated: when he hears the loud sounds of the drum with the divine ear element, or when he recollects the aggregates that existed in the past with the knowledge of recollection of past lives, or when he sees materiality with the divine eye,

original: idaṃ idheva dassitaṃ. Idhāpi arahattavaseneva abhiññāvosānapāramippattatā veditabbā.
analyzed: idam idhā iva dassitam idha api arahatta vasena iva abhiññā vosāna pārami patta tā veditabbā
translated: but does not arise in one who has already discerned it, this knowledge of insight is shown here in order to remove fear. And here too the “perfection of direct knowledge” should be understood as the reaching of the goal of arahatship.

original: 253. Manomayiddhiyaṃ ciṇṇavasitāya. Tattha manomayanti manena nibbattaṃ. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅginti
analyzed: tattha manaḥ mayanti manena nibbattam sabbaṅga paccaṅginti
translated: In the psychic-power triad he has mastery in the production of the mind-made body. Herein, mind-made means produced by the mind.🔽Complete in all its parts means complete in all the major and minor parts.

original: sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi ca samannāgataṃ. Ahīnindriyanti saṇṭhānavasena avikalindriyaṃ.🔽Iddhimatā nimmitarūpañhi sace iddhimā odāto, tampi odātaṃ. Sace aviddhakaṇṇo, tampi
analyzed: sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi ca samannāgatam ahīna indriyam ti saṇṭhāna vasena avikalindriyam  iddhimatā sace iddhimā odātaḥ tampi odātam sace a viddha kaṇṇaḥ tampi
translated: With faculties unimpaired means with faculties not impaired in shape.🔽For the kind of materiality that is created by one who possesses supernormal power is like him in all respects. If the possessor of supernormal power is fair, then that is fair too. If he has no pierced ears, then that has no pierced ears too.

original: aviddhakaṇṇanti evaṃ sabbākārehi tena sadisameva hoti. Muñjamhā īsikantiādi upamattayampi
analyzed: evam sabba ākārehi tena sadisam eva hoti muñjamhā īsikanti ādi
translated: The simile of the reed and the arrow is stated

original: taṃ sadisabhāvadassanatthameva vuttaṃ. Muñjasadisā eva hi tassa anto īsikā hoti.
analyzed: tat sadisa bhāva dassana attham eva vuttam muñja sadisā eva hi tassa antar īsikā hoti
translated: only to show that it is like that. For the reed is like the man, and the arrow is like the mind-made body.

original: Kosasadisoyeva asi, vaṭṭāya kosiyā vaṭṭaṃ asimeva pakkhipanti, patthaṭāya patthaṭaṃ.
analyzed: kosa sadisaḥ yā iva asi vaṭṭāya kosiyāḥ vaṭṭam asim eva pakkhipanti patthaṭāya patthaṭam
translated: The sheath is like the supernormal power. The arrow is like the arrow in that it is made of reed. It is like the arrow in that it is made of reed. They put the arrow in a round quiver and the sheath in a case.

original: Karaṇḍāti idampi ahikañcukassa nāmaṃ, na vilīvakaraṇḍakassa. Ahikañcuko hi ahinā
analyzed: karaṇḍā ti idam pi ahi kañcukassa nāmam na vilīva karaṇḍakassa ahi kañcukaḥ hi ahinā
translated: The word “sheath” is the name for a snake’s slough, not for a sheath for a sword. For a snake’s slough is like a snake.

original: sadisova hoti. Tattha kiñcāpi “puriso ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyyā”ti hatthena uddharamāno
analyzed: sadisaḥ uva hoti tattha kiñca api purisaḥ ahim karaṇḍā uddhareyya ati hatthena uddharamāno
translated: Herein, although it is the man who is pulling out the snake with his hand, saying, “Take the snake out of the sheath,”

original: viya dassito, atha kho cittenevassa uddharaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ayañhi ahi nāma sajātiyaṃ
analyzed: viya dassitaḥ atha kho cittena iva assa uddharaṇam veditabbam ayam hi ahi nāma sajātiyam
translated: and the casting off is to be understood as done by the mind. For this snake, it seems, is standing on its own kind,

original: ṭhito, kaṭṭhantaraṃ vā rukkhantaraṃ vā nissāya, tacato sarīranikkaḍḍhanapayogasaṅkhātena
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ kaṭṭhantaram vā rukkhantaram vā nissāya tacataḥ sarīra nikkaḍḍhana payoga saṅkhātena
translated: and it is as though it were gnawing its own body with the effort called the exertion of casting off the skin,

original: thāmena, sarīraṃ khādamānaṃ viya purāṇatacaṃ jigucchantoti imehi catūhi kāraṇehi🔽sayameva kañcukaṃ jahāti, na sakkā tato aññena uddharituṃ. Tasmā cittena uddharaṇaṃ
analyzed: thāmena sarīram khādamānam viya purāṇatacam jigucchantaḥ iti imehi catūhi kāraṇehi  sayam eva kañcukam jahāti na sakkā tatas aññena uddharitum tasmā cittena uddharaṇam
translated: and it is disgusted with the old skin. For these four reasons🔽it casts off the slough by itself; it cannot be drawn out from it by anyone else. So it should be understood that this is said with reference to the casting off by the mind.

original: sandhāya idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Iti muñjādisadisaṃ imassa bhikkhuno sarīraṃ, īsikādisadisaṃ🔽nimmitarūpanti idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ. Nimmānavidhānaṃ panettha parato ca iddhividhādipañcaabhiññākathā
analyzed: sandhāya idam vuttan ti veditabbam iti muñja ādi sadisam imassa bhikkhuno sarīram īsikā ādi sadisam  nimmita rūpan ti idam ettha opamma saṃsandanam nimmāna vidhānam pana ittha paratas ca iddhividha ādi pañca abhiññā kathā
translated: So the bhikkhu’s body is like the muñja grass, etc.,🔽and the created materiality is like the inner skin, etc. This is the correspondence of the similes here.🔽But the directions for the creation and the explanation of the five kinds of direct-knowledge beginning with the supernormal powers are given in detail in the Path of Purification,

original: sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritāti tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Upamāmattameva hi idha adhikaṃ.
analyzed: sabba ākārena visuddhi magge vitthāritā ti tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbā upamā mattam eva hi idha adhikam
translated: so they should be understood there. Only the similes are added here.

original: Tattha chekakumbhakārādayo viya iddhividhañāṇalābhī bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo. Suparikammakatamattikādayo
analyzed: tattha cheka kumbhakāra ādayaḥ viya iddhividha ñāṇa lābhī bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo su parikamma kata mattika ādayo
translated: Herein, the bhikkhu who has obtained the knowledge of supernormal power should be regarded as the potter,

original: viya iddhividhañāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Icchiticchitabhājanavikatiādikaraṇaṃ viya tassa
analyzed: viya iddhividha ñāṇam daṭṭhabbam icchiti chita bhājana vikati ādi karaṇam viya tassa
translated: the knowledge of supernormal power as the well-prepared clay,

original: bhikkhuno vikubbanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Idhāpi ciṇṇavasitāvaseneva abhiññāvosānapāramippattatā
analyzed: bhikkhuno vikubbanam daṭṭhabbam idha api ciṇṇa vasitā vasena iva abhiññā vosāna pārami ppatta tā
translated: and the transformation of the bhikkhu as the making of the various kinds of pots according to the potter’s wish.🔽And here too it should be understood that the perfection of the development of the knowledge of supernormal power is reached when mastery of it has been achieved in all its aspects.

original: veditabbā. Tathā ito parāsu catūsu abhiññāsu.
analyzed: veditabbā tathā ito parāsu catūsu abhiññāsu
translated: And so too with the next four kinds of direct-knowledge.🔽Herein, in the Simile of the Heavenly Ear Element, a conch-blower is a saṅkhadhamaka.

original: 255. Tattha dibbasotadhātuupamāyaṃ saṅkhadhamoti saṅkhadhamako. Appakasirenevāti🔽niddukkheneva. Viññāpeyyāti jānāpeyya. Tattha evaṃ cātuddisā viññāpente saṅkhadhamake
analyzed: tattha dibba sota dhātu upamā ayam saṅkhadhamo ti saṅkhadhamakaḥ appa kasirena iva ati  niddukkhena iva viññāpeyya ati jānāpeyya tattha evam cātuddisā viññāpente saṅkha dhamake
translated: With little trouble: with little difficulty.🔽He would make it known: he would make it understood.

original: “saṅkhasaddo aya”nti vavatthāpentānaṃ sattānaṃ tassa saṅkhasaddassa āvibhūtakālo
analyzed: saṅkha saddaḥ ayanti vavatthāpentānam sattānam tassa saṅkha saddassa āvibhūta kālaḥ
translated: And here the time when the sound of the conch becomes evident to those who are intent on discerning it thus, “This is the sound of the conch,”

original: viya yogino dūrasantikabhedānaṃ dibbānañceva mānusakānañca saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya yoginaḥ dūra santika bhedānam dibbānam ca iva mānusakānam ca saddānam āvibhūta kālaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: should be regarded as the time when the divine and human sounds, whether far or near, become evident to the meditator.

original: 256. Cetopariyañāṇa-upamāyaṃ daharoti taruṇo. Yuvāti yobbanena samannāgato. Maṇḍanakajātikoti🔽yuvāpi samāno na alasiyo kiliṭṭhavatthasarīro, atha kho maṇḍanakapakatiko, divasassa
analyzed: cetas upari yañāṇa aupamāyam taruṇaḥ yuvā ati yobbanena samannāgataḥ maṇḍanaka jātikā iti  yuvā api samānaḥ na alasiyaḥ kiliṭṭha vattha sarīraḥ atha kho maṇḍanaka pakatikaḥ divasassa
translated: In the Simile of the Mind-made Body, “young” means tender, and “youthful” means possessing youth. “One who is fond of adornment”

original: dve tayo vāre nhāyitvā suddhavattha-paridahana-alaṅkārakaraṇasīloti attho. Sakaṇikanti🔽kāḷatilakavaṅka-mukhadūsipīḷakādīnaṃ aññatarena sadosaṃ. Tattha yathā tassa mukhanimittaṃ🔽paccavekkhato mukhadoso pākaṭo hoti, evaṃ cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa
analyzed: dve tayaḥ vāre nhāyitvā suddhavattha paridahana alaṅkāra karaṇa sīlaḥ ti attho sa kaṇikanti  kāḷa tilaka vaṅka mukha dūsi pīḷaka ādīnam aññatarena sa dosam tattha yathā tassa mukha nimittam  paccavekkhataḥ mukha doso pākaṭaḥ hoti evam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharitvā nisinnassa
translated: means that even though he is young, he is not lazy, nor is his clothing and body soiled, but rather he is by nature fond of adornment, and the meaning is that he is in the habit of bathing two or three times a day

original: bhikkhuno paresaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ cittaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ. Pubbenivāsaupamādīsu
analyzed: bhikkhuno paresam soḷasavidham cittam pākaṭam hoti iti veditabbam pubbenivāsa upama ādīsu
translated: and of wearing clean clothes and ornaments. “With a pimple” means with some such blemish as a black mole, a white mole, a freckle, a discolouration, or a pimple. Herein, just as when he looks at the reflection of his face in a looking-glass, etc., the blemish on his face becomes evident to him, so too, when a bhikkhu sits and directs his mind to the knowledge of the minds of others, the sixteen kinds of other people’s consciousness become evident to him.

original: yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ mahāassapure vuttameva.
analyzed: yat vattabbam tat sabbam mahāassapure vuttam eva
translated: As to what should be said in the case of the Simile of the Former Dwelling, etc., all that has been said already in the Mahā Assapura Sutta .

original: 259. Ayaṃ kho udāyi pañcamo dhammoti ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadāvasena ekaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: ayam kho udāyi pañcamaḥ dhammo ti ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadā vasena ekam dhammaṃ
translated: “This is the fifth idea, Udayin,” etc. Twenty-one kinds of ideas are given in the text, but they are all one in the sense of the way of practice.

original: katvā pañcamo dhammoti vutto. Yathā hi aṭṭhakanāgarasutte ekādasa pabbāni pucchāvasena
analyzed: katvā pañcamaḥ dhammaḥ ti vuttaḥ yathā hi aṭṭhakanāgarasutte ekādasa pabbāni pucchā vasena
translated: For just as in the Aṭṭhakanāgarasutta the eleven questions are made into one idea,

original: ekadhammo kato, evamidha ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadāvasena eko dhammo katoti veditabbāni.🔽Imesu ca pana ekūnavīsatiyā pabbesu paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhasu koṭṭhāsesu vipassanāñāṇe ca
analyzed: eka dhammo kato evam idha ekūnavīsati pabbāni paṭipadā vasena ekaḥ dhammo kato ti veditabbāni  imesu ca pana ekūnavīsatiyā pabbesu paṭipāṭiyā aṭṭhasu koṭṭhāsesu vipassanā ñāṇe ca
translated: so here the nineteen questions are made into one idea by the way of the path.

original: āsavakkhayañāṇe ca arahattavasena abhiññāvosānapāramippattatā veditabbā, sesesu ciṇṇavasibhāvavasena.
analyzed: āsava kkhaya ñāṇe ca arahatta vasena abhiññā vosāna pārami ppatta tā veditabbā sesesu ciṇṇa vasi bhāva vasena
translated: And in these nineteen questions the eight sections in order are to be understood as having reached the perfection of the culmination of direct- knowledge in the case of insight knowledge and knowledge of the destruction of the taints in the case of the path knowledge, and in the rest as having reached the state of mastery.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya called “The Clearing-up of the tangle”

original: Mahāsakuludāyisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahāsakuludāyi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 8. Samaṇamuṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samaṇamuṇḍika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the Ascetic Muṇḍiya

original: 260. Evaṃ me sutanti samaṇamuṇḍikasuttaṃ. Tattha uggāhamānoti tassa paribbājakassa
analyzed: evam me sutam ti samaṇa muṇḍika suttam tattha uggāhamāno ti tassa paribbājakassa
translated: Thus I heard. This is the Sutta on the Ascetic Muṇḍiya . Herein, Uggāhamā is the name of that wanderer.

original: nāmaṃ. Sumanoti pakatināmaṃ. Kiñci kiñci pana uggahituṃ uggāhetuṃ samatthatāya uggāhamānoti
analyzed: nāmam sumanoti pakati nāmam kiñci kiñci pana uggahitum uggāhetum samattha tāya uggāhamāno ti
translated: Sumano is his personal name. But because he was able to take up and grasp anything at all, he is called Uggāhamā .

original: naṃ sañjānanti. Samayaṃ pavadanti etthāti samayappavādakaṃ. Tasmiṃ kira ṭhāne caṅkītārukkhapokkharasātippabhutayo
analyzed: nam sañjānanti samayam pavadanti ettha ati samaya ppavādakam tasmin kira ṭhāne caṅkītā rukkha pokkharasāti pabhutayaḥ
translated: they are called “those who proclaim a particular time.” In that place, it seems, there were a walking-path, a tree, a rock, a lotus-pond, a mountain, a cave, and a forest.

original: brāhmaṇā nigaṇṭhācelakaparibbājakādayo ca pabbajitā sannipatitvā attano attano samayaṃ🔽pavadanti kathenti dīpenti, tasmā so ārāmo samayappavādakoti vuccati. Sveva tindukācīrasaṅkhātāya
analyzed: brāhmaṇāḥ nigaṇṭha ācelaka paribbājaka ādayo ca pabbajitā sannipatitvā attanaḥ attanaḥ samayam  pavadanti kathenti dīpenti tasmā saḥ ārāmo samaya ppavādako ti vuccati su eva tindukā cīra saṅkhātāya
translated: They proclaim their own doctrines there, thus it is a place for proclaiming doctrines. In that place, it seems, brahmins, naked ascetics, and wanderers of various kinds, having assembled under the trees and in the ponds,

original: timbarūsakarukkhapantiyā parikkhittattā tindukācīraṃ. Yasmā panettha paṭhamaṃ ekā
analyzed: timba rūsaka rukkha pantiyā tinduka ācīram yasmā pana ittha paṭhamam ekā
translated: proclaim their own doctrines, discuss them, and explain them. Therefore that monastery is called a place for proclaiming doctrines. It is called Tinduka-acira because it is surrounded by a hedge of tinduka and acīra trees.

original: sālā ahosi, pacchā mahāpuññaṃ poṭṭhapādaparibbājakaṃ nissāya bahū sālā katā, tasmā
analyzed: sālā ahosi pacchā mahāpuññam poṭṭhapāda paribbājakam nissāya bahū sālā katā tasmai
translated: But because there was first a single hall and later many halls were built through the great merit of the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda,

original: tameva ekaṃ sālaṃ upādāya laddhanāmavasena ekasālakoti vuccati. Mallikāya pana pasenadirañño
analyzed: tam eva ekam sālam upādāya laddha nāma vasena ekasālako ti vuccati mallikāya pana
translated: it is called Ekasālā, after the name of that single hall. It was a pleasure garden of Queen Mallikā, the wife of King Pasenadi of Kosala.

original: deviyā uyyānabhūto so pupphaphalasañchanno ārāmoti katvā mallikāya ārāmoti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: deviyāḥ uyyāna bhūto saḥ puppha phala sañchanno ārāmo iti katvā mallikāya ārāmo iti saṅkham
translated: That monastery, which was full of flowers and fruits, was called Mallikā’s monastery.

original: gato. Tasmiṃ samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme. Paṭivasatīti
analyzed: gataḥ tasmin samaya ppavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāye ārāme paṭivasati iti
translated: At that time he was living in the Mallika’s Mango Grove, in the single-hall building with the silk-cotton tree door.

original: vāsaphāsutāya vasati. Divā divassāti divasassa divā nāma majjhanhātikkamo, tasmiṃ
analyzed: vāsa phāsutāya vasati divā divassā ati divasassa divā nāma majjhanhā atikkamaḥ tasmin
translated: “He was living” means he was living in the dwelling place.🔽“In the day-time” means after midday.

original: divasassapi divābhūte atikkantamatte majjhanhike nikkhamīti attho. Paṭisallīnoti🔽tato tato rūpādigocarato cittaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā līno, jhānaratisevanavasena ekībhāvaṃ
analyzed: divasassa api divābhūte atikkanta matte majjhanhike nikkhamīti attho paṭisallīnaḥ ti  tatas tatas rūpa ādi gocarato cittam paṭisaṃharitvā līnaḥ jhāna rati sevana vasena ekībhāvam
translated: “After the day had passed” means after midday had passed.🔽“He went out” means he went out from there.🔽“He was secluded” means he was secluded by withdrawing his mind from the objects of the senses such as visible forms, etc.

original: gato. Manobhāvanīyānanti manavaḍḍhanakānaṃ, ye āvajjato manasikaroto cittaṃ vinīvaraṇaṃ
analyzed: gataḥ manaḥ bhāvanīya ananti ye āvajjataḥ cittam
translated: “He was absorbed” means he had attained absorption by cultivating the jhānas.🔽“Worthy of being esteemed” means worthy of being honoured.

original: hoti unnamati vaḍḍhati. Yāvatāti yattakā. Ayaṃ tesaṃ aññataroti ayaṃ tesaṃ abbhantaro
analyzed: hoti unnamati vaḍḍhati yāvatā ati yattakā ayam tesam aññataro ti ayam tesam abbhantaro
translated: “As much as” means as many as.🔽“One of them” means one of them.

original: eko sāvako. Appeva nāmāti tassa upasaṅkamanaṃ patthayamāno āha. Patthanākāraṇaṃ pana
analyzed: ekaḥ sāvakaḥ appā iva nāma ati tassa upasaṅkamanam patthayamānaḥ āha patthanā kāraṇam pana
translated: “Perhaps” means he said this hoping for his approach. But the reason for the hope

original: sandakasutte vuttameva.
analyzed: sandaka sutte vuttam eva
translated: is stated in the Sandaka Sutta.

original: 261. Etadavocāti dandapañño ayaṃ gahapati, dhammakathāya naṃ saṅgaṇhitvā attano sāvakaṃ
analyzed: etat avoca ati danda paññaḥ ayam gahapati dhamma kathāya nam saṅgaṇhitvā attano sāvakam
translated: “He said this” means this householder Dandapañña, after gathering him with a talk on the Dhamma,

original: karissāmīti maññamāno etaṃ “catūhi kho”tiādivacanaṃ avoca. Tattha paññpemīti dassemi
analyzed: karissāmi iti maññamānaḥ etam catūhi kho ti ādi vacanam avoca tattha paññpemi iti dassemi
translated: Thinking, “I will do so,” he spoke the words beginning, “By four things, etc.” Herein, I will give is I will bestow.🔽I will set up is I will establish.🔽Possessed of good is possessed of what is complete.

original: ṭhapemi. Sampannakusalanti paripuṇṇakusalaṃ. Paramakusalanti uttamakusalaṃ. Ayojjhanti
analyzed: ṭhapemi sampanna kusalanti paripuṇṇa kusalam parama kusalanti uttama kusalam
translated: Supreme good is the best good.

original: vādayuddhena yujjhitvā cāletuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ acalaṃ nikkampaṃ thiraṃ. Na karotīti
analyzed: vāda yuddhena yujjhitvā cāletum a sakkuṇeyyam acalam nikkampam thiram na karoti iti
translated: Unwavering is unshakable, unmoving, firm, incapable of being moved by the dispute of argument.

original: akaraṇamattameva vadati, ettha pana saṃvarappahānaṃ vā paṭisevanappahānaṃ vā na vadati.
analyzed: akaraṇam attam eva vadati ettha pana saṃvara pahānam vā paṭisevana ppahānam vā na vadati
translated: Does not do is merely does not do. Herein, he does not say “restraint” or “abandonment by use.”

original: Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sesa pade supi e sa iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the other passages.

original: Neva abhinandīti titthiyā nāma jānitvāpi ajānitvāpi yaṃ vā taṃ vā vadantīti maññamāno
analyzed: na iva abhinandi iti titthiyā nāma jānitvā api a jānitvā api yam vā tam vā vadanti iti maññamāno
translated: Neither welcomes is he does not welcome, thinking, “The sectarians say this or that, whether they know or do not know.”

original: nābhinandi. Na paṭikkosīti sāsanassa anulomaṃ viya pasannākāraṃ viya vadatīti maññamāno na paṭisedheti.
analyzed: na abhinandi na paṭikkosi iti sāsanassa anulomam viya pasanna ākāram viya vadati iti maññamānaḥ na paṭisedheti
translated: Nor does he oppose is he does not oppose, thinking, “He speaks in conformity with the Dispensation, as if he were pleased.”

original: 262. Yathā uggāhamānassāti yathā tassa vacanaṃ, evaṃ sante uttānaseyyako kumāro ayojjhasamaṇo
analyzed: yathā uggāhamānassa ati yathā tassa vacanam evam sante uttānaseyyakaḥ kumāraḥ ayojjha samaṇaḥ
translated: As if he were to take it up is as if the youth Uttara were to take it up.

original: thirasamaṇo bhavissati, mayaṃ pana evaṃ na vadāmāti dīpeti. Kāyotipi na hotīti sakakāyo🔽parakāyotipi visesañāṇaṃ na hoti. Aññatra phanditamattāti paccattharaṇe valisamphassena
analyzed: thirasamaṇaḥ bhavissati mayam pana evam na vadāma ati dīpeti na hoti iti saka kāyaḥ  visesa ñāṇam na hoti aññatra phandita mattā ati paccattharaṇe vali samphassena
translated: “He will be a firm ascetic” . “There is no ‘I’”: there is no “my body”

original: vā maṅguladaṭṭhena vā kāyaphandanamattaṃ nāma hoti. Taṃ ṭhapetvā aññaṃ kāyena karaṇakammaṃ
analyzed: vā maṅgula daṭṭhena vā kāya phandana mattam nāma hoti tam ṭhapetvā aññam kāyena karaṇa kammaṃ
translated: or “another’s body” as a distinction. “There is no more than mere shaking”: there is only shaking of the body, either by contact with the bedspread or by the movement of the limbs. Apart from that there is no bodily action.

original: nāma natthi. Tampi ca kilesasahagatacitteneva hoti. Vācātipi na hotīti micchāvācā
analyzed: nāma natthi tat pi ca kilesa sahagata cittena iva hoti vācā ati pi na hoti iti micchāvācā
translated: And that is only with a consciousness accompanied by defilements. “There is no ‘speech’”: there is no wrong speech

original: sammāvācātipi nānattaṃ na hoti. Roditamattāti jighacchāpipāsāparetassa pana roditamattaṃ🔽hoti. Tampi kilesasahagatacitteneva. Saṅkappoti micchāsaṅkappo sammāsaṅkappotipi
analyzed: sammā vācā atipi nānattam na hoti rodita matta ati jighacchā pipāsā paretassa pana rodita mattam  hoti tam pi kilesa sahagata cittena iva saṅkappoti micchāsaṅkappo sammāsaṅkappo tipi
translated: or right speech as a distinction. “There is only mere weeping”: there is only weeping due to hunger, thirst, and exhaustion.🔽And that is only with a consciousness accompanied by defilements. “There is no ‘thinking’”: there is no wrong thinking or right thinking

original: nānattaṃ na hoti. Vikūjitamattāti vikūjitamattaṃ rodanahasitamattaṃ hoti. Daharakumārakānañhi
analyzed: nānattam na hoti vikūjita matta ati vikūjita mattam rodana hasita mattam hoti dahara kumāraka añchi
translated: as a distinction. “There is only mere noise”: there is only the noise of weeping and laughing. For young children

original: cittaṃ atītārammaṇaṃ pavattati, nirayato āgatā nirayadukkhaṃ saritvā rodanti, devalokato
analyzed: cittam atīta ārammaṇam pavattati nirayataḥ āgatāḥ niraya dukkham saritvā rodanti deva lokato
translated: the mind proceeds with a past object, having remembered the suffering of hell from which they have come, they weep; from the deva-world,

original: āgatā hasanti, tampi kilesasahagatacitteneva hoti. Ājīvoti micchājīvo sammājīvotipi
analyzed: āgatāḥ hasanti tam pi kilesa sahagata cittena iva hoti ājīvo ti micchājīvo sammājīvo tipi
translated: The mind occurs with past objects. Those who have come from hell remember the suffering of hell and weep; those who have come from the deva world laugh. That too is with a mind accompanied by defilements. “Wrong livelihood” and “right livelihood”

original: nānattaṃ na hoti. Aññatra mātuthaññāti thaññacoradārakā nāma honti, mātari khīraṃ🔽pāyantiyā apivitvā aññavihitakāle piṭṭhipassena āgantvā thaññaṃ pivanti. Ettakaṃ
analyzed: nānattam na hoti aññatra mātu thaññāti thañña cora dārakāḥ nāma honti mātari khīram  pāyantiyāḥ a pivitvā añña vihita kāle piṭṭhi passena āgantvā thaññam pivanti ettakam
translated: are not different. “Except for the mother’s milk” : there are children who suckle at the mother’s breast and also at the milk that comes from her armpits.

original: muñcitvā añño micchājīvo natthi. Ayampi kilesasahagatacitteneva hotīti dasseti.
analyzed: muñcitvā aññaḥ micchājīvaḥ natthi ayam pi kilesa sahagata cittena iva hoti iti dasseti
translated: After the mother has drunk milk, they come from behind and suck the milk from her back. Apart from this there is no wrong livelihood. This shows that it is with a mind accompanied by defilements.

original: 263. Evaṃ paribbājakavādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā idāni sayaṃ sekkhabhūmiyaṃ mātikaṃ ṭhapento
analyzed: evam paribbājaka vādam paṭikkhipitvā idāni sayam sekkha bhūmiyam mātikam ṭhapento
translated: Having thus refuted the doctrine of the wanderers, the Exalted One now sets forth the mātikā in the stage of the disciple:

original: catūhi kho ahantiādimāha. Tattha samadhigayha tiṭṭhatīti visesetvā tiṭṭhati. Na kāyena🔽pāpa kammantiādīsu na kevalaṃ akaraṇamattameva, bhagavā pana ettha saṃvarappahānapaṭisaṅkhā
analyzed: catūhi kho aham ti ādim āha tattha samadhigayha tiṭṭhati iti visesetvā tiṭṭhati na kāyena 🔽na kevalam akaraṇa mattam eva bhagavā pana ettha saṃvara ppahāna paṭisaṅkhā
translated: “With four things, monks, a monk dwells restrained by restraint of the Pātimokkha, etc. Herein, “he dwells having attained” means he dwells having attained to distinction.

original: paññapeti. Taṃ sandhāyevamāha. Na ceva sampannakusalantiādi pana khīṇāsavaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Idāni asekkhabhūmiyaṃ mātikaṃ ṭhapento dasahi kho ahantiādimāha. Tattha tīṇi padāni
analyzed: paññapeti tam sandhāya ivam āha na ca iva sampanna kusala nti ādi pana khīṇāsavam sandhāya vuttam  idāni asekkha bhūmiyam mātikam ṭhapentaḥ dasahi kho aham ti ādim āha tattha tīṇi padāni
translated: and he said this with reference to him. But “he has not fulfilled the profitable” and so on was said with reference to one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽Now, as to the line “With ten ideas a man is called a worldling,” he said this in order to set out the schedule in the plane of those still learning. Herein, two first tetrads are set out with three terms each,

original: nissāya dve paṭhamacatukkā ṭhapitā, ekaṃ padaṃ nissāya dve pacchimacatukkā. Ayaṃ
analyzed: nissāya dve paṭhama catukkā ṭhapitāḥ ekam padam nissāya dve pacchima catukkā ayaṃ
translated: and two last tetrads with one term each. This is

original: sekkhabhūmiyaṃ mātikā.🔽264. Idāni taṃ vibhajanto katame ca thapati akusalasīlātiādimāha. Tattha sarāganti🔽aṭṭhavidhaṃ lobhasahagatacittaṃ. Sadosanti paṭighasampayuttacittadvayaṃ. Samohanti🔽vicikicchuddhaccasahagatacittadvayampi vaṭṭati, sabbākusalacittānipi. Moho sabbākusale
analyzed: sekkha bhūmiyam mātikā  idāni tam vibhajanto katame ca thapati akusala sīla ati ādim āha tattha  aṭṭhavidham lobha sahagata cittam paṭigha sampayutta citta dvayam samohanti  vicikicchu ddhacca sahagata citta dvayam pi vaṭṭati sabba akusala cittāni pi moho sabba akusale
translated: the schedule in the plane of those still learning.

original: uppajjatīti hi vuttaṃ. Itosamuṭṭhānāti ito sarāgādicittato samuṭṭhānaṃ uppatti etesanti itosamuṭṭhānā.
analyzed: uppajjati iti hi vuttam itosamuṭṭhānā ati itas sa rāga ādi cittataḥ samuṭṭhānam uppatti etesan ti itosamuṭṭhānā
translated: Now, as to the line “What are the unprofitable things, Thera? ” he said this in order to comment on it. Herein, “With greed” is the eight kinds of consciousness accompanied by greed. “With hate” is the two kinds of consciousness accompanied by hate. “With delusion” is the two kinds of consciousness accompanied by uncertainty and by agitation, and also all unprofitable consciousnesses. For it is said that “Delusion arises in all unprofitable “ . “Originating here” : they originate here, thus they originate here ;

original: Kuhinti kataraṃ ṭhānaṃ pāpuṇitvā aparisesā nirujjhanti. Ettheteti sotāpattiphale
analyzed: kuhin ti kataram ṭhānam pāpuṇitvā aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti ettha ite iti sotāpatti phale
translated: What is the state that, when reached, unwholesome virtue ceases without remainder? It is the fruit of stream-entry.

original: bhummaṃ. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlañhi sotāpattiphale paripuṇṇaṃ hoti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ patvā
analyzed: bhummam pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam hi sotāpatti phale paripuṇṇam hoti tam ṭhānam patvā
translated: For virtue consisting in the restraint of the Patimokkha is fulfilled in the fruit of stream-entry.

original: akusalasīlaṃ asesaṃ nirujjhati. Akusalasīlanti ca dussīlassetaṃ adhivacananti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: akusala sīlam asesam nirujjhati akusala sīlam ti ca dussīlassa etam adhivacanam ti veditabbam
translated: When that state is reached, unwholesome virtue ceases without remainder. And by “unwholesome virtue” should be understood what is called “the virtue of the bad person” .

original: Akusalānaṃ sīlānaṃ nirodhāya paṭipannoti ettha yāva sotāpattimaggā nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti, phalapatte pana te nirodhitā nāma honti.
analyzed: akusalānam sīlānam nirodhāya paṭipanno ti ettha yāva sotāpatti maggāḥ nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti phala patte pana te nirodhitāḥ nāma honti
translated: As to “he is practising for the cessation of unwholesome states”: he is practising for the cessation of unwholesome states as far as the path of stream-entry. But when the fruit has been reached, they have ceased.

original: 265. Vītarāgantiādīhi aṭṭhavidhaṃ kāmāvacarakusalacittameva vuttaṃ. Etena hi kusalasīlaṃ samuṭṭhāti.🔽Sīlavā hotīti sīlasampanno hoti guṇasampanno ca. No ca sīlamayoti alamettāvatā, natthi
analyzed: vīta rāganti ādīhi aṭṭhavidham kāmāvacara kusala cittam eva vuttam etena hi kusala sīlam samuṭṭhāti  sīlavā hoti iti sīla sampanno hoti guṇa sampanno ca no ca sīla mayaḥ ti alam ettāvatā natthi
translated: By the words “free from lust” and so on, eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable consciousness are referred to. For wholesome virtue originates from that.

original: ito kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti evaṃ sīlamayo na hoti. Yatthassa teti arahattaphale
analyzed: itas kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti evam sīla mayaḥ na hoti arahatta phale
translated: “He is virtuous” : he is endowed with virtue, endowed with good qualities. “But he is not a virtuous person” : it is not enough to be merely that; he is not a virtuous person in the sense of one who has done what is to be done. “In which he would be a virtuous person” : in the fruit of arahantship.

original: bhummaṃ. Arahattaphalañhi patvā akusalasīlaṃ asesaṃ nirujjhati.🔽Nirodhāya paṭipannoti ettha yāva arahattamaggā nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti, phalapatte pana te nirodhitā nāma honti.
analyzed: bhummam arahatta phalam hi patvā akusala sīlam asesam nirujjhati  nirodhāya paṭipanno ti ettha yāva arahatta maggāḥ nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti phala patte pana te nirodhitāḥ nāma honti
translated: for when the fruit of arahantship has been reached, unprofitable virtue has ceased without remainder.🔽“He is practising for the cessation of bodily-form”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.

original: 266. Kāmasaññādīsu kāmasaññā aṭṭhalobhasahagatacittasahajātā, itarā dve domanassasahagatacittadvayena sahajātā.
analyzed: kāma saññā ādīsu kāma saññā aṭṭha lobha sahagata citta sahajātā itarā dve domanassa sahagata citta dvayena sahajātā
translated: “He is practising for the cessation of feeling … for the cessation of perception … for the cessation of formations … for the cessation of consciousness”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.

original: Paṭhamaṃ jhānanti anāgāmiphalapaṭhamajjhānaṃ. Ettheteti anāgāmiphale bhummaṃ. Anāgāmiphalañhi patvā akusalasaṅkappā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: paṭhamam jhānanti anāgāmi phala paṭhamajjhānam ettha ite iti anāgāmi phale bhummam anāgāmi phalam hi patvā akusala saṅkappāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: “He is practising for the cessation of the eye … for the cessation of forms … for the cessation of eye-consciousness … for the cessation of contact … for the cessation of feeling”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.🔽“He is practising for the cessation of the ear … for the cessation of the nose … for the cessation of the tongue … for the cessation of the body … for the cessation of the mind … for the cessation of mental phenomena … for the cessation of mind-consciousness … for the cessation of contact … for the cessation of feeling”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.🔽“He is practising for the cessation of the ear … for the cessation of the nose … for the cessation of the tongue … for the cessation of the body … for the cessation of the mind … for the cessation of mental phenomena … for the cessation of mind-consciousness … for the cessation of contact … for the cessation of feeling”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.

original: Nirodhāya paṭipannoti ettha yāva anāgāmimaggā nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti, phalapatte
analyzed: nirodhāya paṭipannaḥ ti ettha yāva anāgāmi maggā nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti phala patte
translated: “He is practising for the cessation of the eye … for the cessation of forms … for the cessation of eye-consciousness … for the cessation of contact … for the cessation of feeling”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.

original: pana te nirodhitā nāma honti. Nekkhammasaññādayo hi tissopi aṭṭhakāmāvacarakusalasahajātasaññāva.🔽267. Ettheteti arahattaphale bhummaṃ. Dutiyajjhānikaṃ arahattaphalañhi pāpuṇitvā
analyzed: pana te nirodhitāḥ nāma honti nekkhamma saññā ādayaḥ hi tissaḥ pi aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala sahajāta saññā va 🔽ettha ite iti arahatta phale bhummam dutiya jhānikam arahatta phalam hi pāpuṇitvā
translated: “He is practising for the cessation of the ear … for the cessation of the nose … for the cessation of the tongue … for the cessation of the body … for the cessation of the mind … for the cessation of mental phenomena … for the cessation of mind-consciousness … for the cessation of contact … for the cessation of feeling”: he is practising for the cessation of the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which is the meaning here.

original: kusalasaṅkappā aparisesā nirujjhanti. Nirodhāya paṭipannoti ettha yāva arahattamaggā
analyzed: kusala saṅkappāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti nirodhāya paṭipannaḥ ti ettha yāva arahatta maggā
translated: and unwholesome intentions cease without remainder. “Who is practising for the cessation of intentions? “ : as far as the path of arahantship

original: nirodhāya paṭipanno nāma hoti, phalapatte pana te nirodhitā nāma honti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: nirodhāya paṭipannaḥ nāma hoti phala patte pana te nirodhitāḥ nāma honti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: he is called “practising for the cessation of intentions,” but when he has reached the fruition they are called “ceased.” The rest is all plain.🔽Commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya🔽Commentary on the Samaṇamaṇḍikā Sutta is finished.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya🔽Samaṇamuṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Cūḷasakuludāyisuttavaṇṇanā

analyzed: evam me sutam ti cūḷasakuludāyi suttam tattha yadā pana bhante bhagavā ti idam paribbājakaḥ dhamma katham sotu kāmaḥ bhagavataḥ dhamma desanāya sa ālaya bhāvam dassentaḥ āha

analyzed: etena hi kāraṇena kathāya samuṭṭhitāya sukham dhammam desetunti dīpeti tassa mayham  bhantā iti saḥ kira tam disvā sace bhagavā idha abhavissāḥ ayam etassa bhāsitassa
translated: For this reason he shows that he can teach the Dhamma happily when the talk has been started.

original: atthoti dīpasahassaṃ viya ujjalāpetvā ajja me pākaṭaṃ akarissā”ti dasabalaṃyeva anussari.
analyzed: attho ti dīpa sahassam viya ujjalāpetvā ajja me pākaṭam akarissāti dasabalaṃya iva anussari
translated: Tassa mayham, bhante: when he saw that, he thought: “If the Blessed One had been here, he would have illuminated the meaning of this statement as if lighting a thousand lamps. Today he has made it clear to me.” Thus he recalled the One of Ten Powers.

original: Tasmā tassa mayhaṃ, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha aho nūnāti anussaraṇatthe nipātadvayaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā tassa mayham bhante ti ādim āha tattha aho nūna iti anussaraṇa atthe nipāta dvayam
translated: Therefore he said: “Tassa mayham, bhante.” Herein, aho nuna is a pair of particles in the sense of recollection.

original: Tena tassa bhagavantaṃ anussarantassa etadahosi “aho nūna bhagavā aho nūna sugato”ti.
analyzed: tena tassa bhagavantam anussarantassa etat ahosi aho nūna bhagavā aho nūna sugataḥ iti
translated: So, as he recalled the Blessed One, this occurred to him: “Oh, if only the Blessed One were here! Oh, if only the Sugata were here!”

original: Yo imesanti yo imesaṃ dhammānaṃ. Sukusaloti suṭṭhu kusalo nipuṇo cheko. So bhagavā
analyzed: yaḥ imesanti yaḥ imesam dhammānam su kusalaḥ ti suṭṭhu kusalaḥ nipuṇaḥ chekaḥ saḥ bhagavā
translated: Yo imesan ti yo imesa dhammanan. Sukusalo ti suṭṭhu kusalo nipuno cheko. So bhagavā

analyzed: aho nūna katheyya so sugataḥ aho nūna katheyya tassa hi bhagavato pubbenivāsa ñāṇassa

analyzed: anekāni kappa koṭi sahassāni eka aṅgaṇāni pākaṭāni iti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ
translated: anekāni kappakoṭisahassāni ekaṅgaṇāni pākaṭānī ti, ayamettha adhippāyo.

original: Tassa vāhaṃ pubbantaṃ ārabbhāti yo hi lābhī hoti, so “pubbe tvaṃ khattiyo ahosi,
analyzed: tassa vā aham pubbantam ārabbha ati yaḥ hi lābhī hoti saḥ pubbe tvam khattiyaḥ ahosi
translated: “Or I might please his mind by answering a question of his that is in his mind” : for when one who has attained is told “Formerly you were a warrior,

original: brāhmaṇo ahosī”ti vutte jānanto sakkaccaṃ sussūsati. Alābhī pana – “evaṃ bhavissati🔽evaṃ bhavissatī”ti sīsakampamettameva dasseti. Tasmā evamāha – “tassa vāhaṃ pubbantaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ ahosi iti vutte jānantaḥ sakkaccam sussūsati alābhī pana evam bhavissati  evam bhavissati iti sīsa kampam ettam eva dasseti tasmai evam āha tassa vā aham pubbantam
translated: a brahmin,” he understands and listens attentively. But one who has not attained just shakes his head, saying “So it is, so it is.”

original: ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheyya”nti.
analyzed: ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam ārādheyyanti
translated: That is why he said “Or I might please his mind by answering a question of his that is in his mind.”

original: So vā maṃ aparantanti dibbacakkhulābhino hi anāgataṃsañāṇaṃ ijjhati, tasmā evamāha. Itaraṃ pubbe vuttanayameva.
analyzed: saḥ vā mam dibba cakkhu lābhinaḥ hi anāgataṃsa ñāṇam ijjhati tasmai evam āha itaram pubbe vutta nayam eva
translated: “Or he might ask me a question” : for one who has obtained the divine eye has knowledge of the future, and that is why he said this. The other case is as already stated.

original: Dhammaṃ te desessāmīti ayaṃ kira atīte desiyamānepi na bujjhissati, anāgate desiyamānepi
analyzed: dhammam te desessāmi iti ayam kira atīte desiyamāne api na bujjhissati anāgate desiyamāne api
translated: “I will teach you a Dhamma that is well proclaimed” : it seems that he would not understand if it were taught in the past or future.

original: na bujjhissati. Athassa bhagavā saṇhasukhumaṃ paccayākāraṃ desetukāmo evamāha. Kiṃ
analyzed: na bujjhissati atha assa bhagavā saṇha su khumam paccaya ākāram desetu kāmaḥ evam āha kim
translated: So the Blessed One, wishing to teach him the subtle and recondite dependent origination, said “I will teach you a Dhamma that is well proclaimed.”

original: pana taṃ bujjhissatīti? Etaṃ pageva na bujjhissati, anāgate panassa vāsanāya paccayo
analyzed: pana tam bujjhissati iti etam pagā iva na bujjhissati anāgate panassa vāsanāya paccayo
translated: But how could he understand that? He would not understand even that, but by the influence of the future, a condition for understanding would be created in him.

original: bhavissatīti disvā bhagavā evamāha.
analyzed: bhavissati iti disvā bhagavā evam āha
translated: Having seen that it would be so, the Blessed One said thus.

analyzed: nagaram gatāḥ dārakāḥ ekam piṇḍapātika ttheram disvā āhaṃsu bhante amhākam mātā

analyzed: vīthiyam gabbha malam paccāsīsamānam disvā tam attham kathesi katham mama tvam passasi iti
translated: and saw her dropping the placenta on the road. She told him what had happened. When he asked, “How do you see me? ”

original: vutte mūlakhaṇḍaṃ dassesi, sā acchinditvā gaṇhi. Evaṃ paṃsupisācakā ekaṃ mūlaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: vutte mūla khaṇḍam dassesi sā a chinditvā gaṇhi evam paṃsu pisācakāḥ ekam mūlam gahetvā

analyzed: a dissamāna kāyāḥ honti tam sandhāya isa paṃsu pisācakam pi na passāmi iti āha na pakkhāyati iti
translated: disappear. That is what is referred to by the words “I do not see even the earth-demons.”

original: na dissati na upaṭṭhāti.🔽272. Dīghāpi kho te esāti udāyi esā tava vācā dīghāpi bhaveyya, evaṃ vadantassa vassasatampi
analyzed: na dissati na upaṭṭhāti  dīghā api kho te esā ati udāyi esā tava vācā dīghā api bhaveyya evam vadantassa vassa satam pi
translated: “Does not appear” means is not seen, is not evident.🔽“Long indeed, Udayin, would be the talk” : the meaning is that even if you were to speak for a hundred or a thousand years, it would not be illuminating.

original: vassasahassampi pavatteyya, na ca atthaṃ dīpeyyāti adhippāyo. Appāṭihīrakatanti aniyyānikaṃ
analyzed: vassa sahassam pi pavatteyya na ca attham dīpeyya ati adhippāyaḥ appāṭihīraka tat ti aniyyānikam
translated: “No argument” : it would be unbeneficial,

original: amūlakaṃ niratthakaṃ sampajjatīti attho.🔽Idāni taṃ vaṇṇaṃ dassento seyyathāpi, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha paṇḍukambale nikkhittoti
analyzed: amūlakam niratthakam sampajjati iti attho  idāni tam vaṇṇam dassento seyyathā api bhante ti ādim āha tattha paṇḍu kambale nikkhittaḥ ti
translated: unfounded, and pointless.🔽Now, in order to show that, he said, “Suppose, venerable sir, a man were to draw a picture with a stick on the surface of the earth” . There, “placed on a white cloth” means

original: visabhāgavaṇṇe rattakambale ṭhapito. Evaṃvaṇṇo attā hotīti idaṃ so subhakiṇhadevaloke
analyzed: visa bhāga vaṇṇe ratta kambale ṭhapitaḥ evaṃvaṇṇaḥ attā hoti iti idam saḥ subha kiṇha deva loke
translated: placed on a cloth of a different color. “Such is the appearance of the self” : this refers to the Subhakinna divine world.

original: nibbattakkhandhe sandhāya – “amhākaṃ matakāle attā subhakiṇhadevaloke khandhā viya jotetī”ti vadati.
analyzed: nibbatta kkhandhe sandhāya amhākam mata kāle attā subha kiṇha deva loke khandhāḥ viya jotā iti iti vadati
translated: He says this because he thinks that at the time of his death his self, which is the light, shines forth in the Subhakiṇha realm of the gods, just as the aggregates do.

original: 273. Ayaṃ imesaṃ ubhinnanti so kira yasmā maṇissa bahi ābhā na niccharati, khajjopanakassa
analyzed: ayam imesam saḥ kira yasmā maṇissa bahi ābhā na niccharati khajjopanakassa
translated: This is the difference between them: the light of the gem does not shine out,

original: aṅguladvaṅgulacaturaṅgulamattaṃ niccharati, mahākhajjopanakassa pana khaḷamaṇḍalamattampi
analyzed: aṅgula dvaṅgula catur aṅgula mattam niccharati mahā khajjopanakassa pana khaḷa maṇḍala mattam pi
translated: but that of the small lamp shines out a distance of one or two or four fingerbreadths, and that of the large lamp shines out a distance of a hand’s breadth.

original: niccharatiyeva, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: tasmai evam āha
translated: That is why he says “This is the difference between them.”

original: Viddheti ubbiddhe, meghavigamena dūrībhūteti attho. Vigatavalāhaketi apagatameghe.🔽Deveti ākāse. Osadhitārakāti sukkatārakā. Sā hi yasmā tassā udayato paṭṭhāya tena🔽saññāṇena osadhāni gaṇhantipi pivantipi, tasmā “osadhitārakā”ti vuccati. Abhido aḍḍharattasamayanti
analyzed: viddha iti ubbiddhe megha vigamena dūrībhūtā iti atthaḥ vigata valāhake iti apagata meghe  deva iti ākāse osadhi tārakā ati sukka tārakā sā hi yasmā tassā udayataḥ paṭṭhāya tena  saññāṇena osadhāni gaṇhanti pi pivanti pi tasmai osadhitārakā ati vuccati
translated: “When the clouds have gone” : when the clouds have disappeared, when they have gone far away, is the meaning. “When the sky is cloudless” : when the sky is free from clouds.

original: abhinne aḍḍharattasamaye. Iminā gaganamajjhe ṭhitacandaṃ dasseti. Abhido majjhanhikepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: abhinne aḍḍha ratta samaye iminā gagana majjhe ṭhita candam dasseti abhidaḥ majjhanhike pi esā iva nayo
translated: “In the sky” : in the air. “The stars” : the dry stars. For from the time of their rising, people gather herbs and drink medicines by their light. That is why they are called “the stars” . “At midnight” : at the time of midnight. By this he shows the moon in the middle of the sky. The same method applies to “at noon.”

original: Ato khoti ye anubhonti, tehi bahutarā, bahū ceva bahutarā cāti attho. Ābhā nānubhontīti obhāsaṃ na vaḷañjanti, attano sarīrobhāseneva ālokaṃ pharitvā viharanti.
analyzed: atas kho ti ye anubhonti tehi bahutarāḥ bahū ca iva bahutarā ca ati attho ābhā na anubhonti iti obhāsam na vaḷañjanti attano sarīra ubhāsena iva ālokam pharitvā viharanti
translated: Therefore, “more numerous are those who do not experience it” means that there are more who do not experience it than who do. “They do not experience light” means that they do not experience radiance; they live with their own bodily radiance spreading out as light.

original: 274. Idāni yasmā so “ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ pucchissāmī”ti nisinno, pucchāmūḷho pana🔽jāto, tasmā naṃ bhagavā taṃ pucchaṃ sarāpento kiṃ pana, udāyi, atthi ekantasukho🔽lokotiādimāha. Tattha ākāravatīti kāraṇavatī. Aññataraṃ vā pana tapoguṇanti acelakapāḷiṃ
analyzed: idāni so ekanta sukham lokam pucchissāmi iti nisinno pucchā mūḷho pana  jātaḥ tasmai nam bhagavā tam puccham sarāpento kim pana udāyi atthi ekanta sukho  loka uti ādim āha tattha ākāravatī iti kāraṇavatī aññataram vā pana acelakapāḷim
translated: Now, since he was sitting down thinking, “I will ask about a world of only pleasure,” but when he came to ask, he became confused,

original: sandhāyāha, surāpānaviratīti attho.
analyzed: sandhāya āha surā pāna virati iti attho
translated: the Blessed One reminded him of his question, saying, “What do you think, Udayin, is there a world of only pleasure?” Herein, “a way that is good” is a way that is a reason . Or alternatively, “any one of the special qualities of ascetics” is said referring to the naked ascetic’s practice of going about with arms upraised ; the meaning is, “abstinence from drinking strong drink.”

original: 275. Katamā pana sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassāti kasmā pucchati?🔽Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “mayaṃ sattānaṃ ekantasukhaṃ vadāma, paṭipadaṃ pana kālena sukhaṃ
analyzed: katamā pana sā bhante ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa ati kasmai pucchati  evam kirassa ahosi mayam sattānam ekanta sukham vadāma paṭipadam pana kālena sukham
translated: But why does he ask, “What is that way, venerable sir, that is good, that leads to a world of only pleasure? ”

original: kālena dukkhaṃ vadāma. Ekantasukhassa kho pana attano paṭipadāyapi ekantasukhāya
analyzed: kālena dukkham vadāma ekanta sukhassa kho pana attanaḥ ekanta sukhāya
translated: He thought thus, “We say that there is a world of only pleasure, but we say that the way to it is sometimes pleasant and sometimes painful. But if there is a world of only pleasure, its way too should be of only pleasure.

original: bhavitabbaṃ. Amhākaṃ kathā aniyyānikā, satthu kathāva niyyānikā”ti. Idāni satthāraṃyeva
analyzed: bhavitabbam amhākam kathā aniyyānikā satthu kathā ava niyyānikā ti idāni satthāram yeva
translated: “Our talk is not conducive to Nibbāna, but the Teacher’s talk is conducive to Nibbāna.” Now he thought, “I will ask the Teacher and find out.”

original: pucchitvā jānissāmīti tasmā pucchati.
analyzed: pucchitvā jānissāmi iti tasmai pucchati
translated: That is why he asked the question.🔽“We are in doubt about this matter”: they were in doubt about this matter.

original: Ettha mayaṃ anassāmāti etasmiṃ kāraṇe mayaṃ anassāma. Kasmā pana evamāhaṃsu? Te kira
analyzed: ettha mayam anassāma ati etasmin kāraṇe mayam anassāma kasmai pana evam āhaṃsu te kira
translated: But why did they say this? They knew that formerly,

original: pubbe pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā tatiyajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā
analyzed: pubbe pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya kasiṇa parikammam katvā tatiya jhānam nibbattetvā
translated: after establishing themselves in the five factors, they had performed the preliminary work on the kasiṇa and had attained the third jhāna,

original: aparihīnajjhānā kālaṃ katvā subhakiṇhesu nibbattantīti jānanti, gacchante gacchante
analyzed: a parihīna jjhānā kālam katvā subha kiṇhesu nibbattanti iti jānanti gacchante gacchante
translated: and that without losing that jhāna they had passed away and had been reborn in the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world.

original: pana kāle kasiṇaparikammampi na jāniṃsu, tatiyajjhānampi nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.🔽Pañca pubbabhāgadhamme pana “ākāravatī paṭipadā”ti uggahetvā tatiyajjhānaṃ “ekantasukho
analyzed: pana kāle kasiṇa parikammam pi na jāniṃsu tatiya jhānam pi nibbattetum na asakkhiṃsu  pañca pubbabhāga dhamme pana ākāravatī paṭipadā ati uggahetvā tatiya jhānam ekanta sukho
translated: But as time went on they forgot even the preliminary work on the kasiṇa, let alone the third jhāna.🔽But they remembered the five factors of preliminary work as “the way that has aspects,” and they remembered the third jhāna as “the world of absolute bliss.” That is why they said this.

original: loko”ti uggaṇhiṃsu. Tasmā evamāhaṃsu. Uttaritaranti ito pañcahi dhammehi uttaritaraṃ
analyzed: uggaṇhiṃsu tasmai evam āhaṃsu uttaritaranti itas pañcahi dhammehi uttaritaraṃ
translated: “Superior”: superior to the five factors.

original: paṭipadaṃ vā tatiyajjhānato uttaritaraṃ ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ vā na jānāmāti vuttaṃ
analyzed: paṭipadam vā tatiya jhānataḥ uttaritaram ekanta sukham lokam vā na jānāma iti vuttam
translated: or a way that is more peaceful than the third jhāna, or a world of complete bliss beyond the third jhāna, we do not know.”

original: hoti. Appasadde katvāti ekappahāreneva mahāsaddaṃ kātuṃ āraddhe nissadde katvā.
analyzed: hoti appasadde katvā ati eka pahārena iva mahā saddam kātum āraddhe nissadde katvā
translated: “In a place free from noise”: in a place where they have not begun to make a great noise.

original: 276. Sacchikiriyāhetūti ettha dve sacchikiriyā paṭilābhasacchikiriyā ca paccakkhasacchikiriyā🔽ca. Tattha tatiyajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā aparihīnajjhāno kālaṃ katvā subhakiṇhaloke tesaṃ🔽devānaṃ samānāyuvaṇṇo hutvā nibbattati, ayaṃ paṭilābhasacchikiriyā nāma. Catutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: sacchikiriyā hetū ti ettha dve sacchikiriyā paṭilābha sacchikiriyā ca paccakkha sacchikiriyā  ca tattha tatiya jhānam nibbattetvā a parihīna jjhāno kālam katvā subha kiṇha loke tesam  devānam samāna āyu vaṇṇaḥ hutvā nibbattati ayam paṭilābhasacchikiriyā nāma catuttha jhānam
translated: “For the sake of realization”: there are two kinds of realization, namely, realization by obtaining and realization by experiencing.🔽Herein, a bhikkhu who has produced the third jhāna and who has not lost it when he dies is reborn in the Brahmā-world of the Subhakiṇha Devas, and he is of the same appearance as those devas and has the same radiance, the same psychic power, the same diet, and the same measure of life. This is called realization by obtaining.

original: nibbattetvā iddhivikubbanena subhakiṇhalokaṃ gantvā tehi devehi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhati🔽sallapati sākacchaṃ āpajjati, ayaṃ paccakkhasacchikiriyā nāma. Tāsaṃ dvinnampi tatiyajjhānaṃ
analyzed: nibbattetvā iddhi vikubbanena subhakiṇha lokam gantvā tehi devehi saddhim santiṭṭhati  sallapati sākaccham āpajjati ayam paccakkha sacchikiriyā nāma tāsam dvinnam pi tatiya jhānam
translated: Having produced the fourth jhāna, he goes to the Subhakiṇha world by his own psychic power, and he associates with those devas, talks with them and enters into conversation with them. This is called realization by experiencing.

original: ākāravatī paṭipadā nāma. Tañhi anuppādetvā neva sakkā subhakiṇhaloke nibbattituṃ,
analyzed: ākāravatī paṭipadā nāma tat hi an uppādetvā na iva sakkā subhakiṇha loke nibbattitum
translated: The third jhāna is called “the way that possesses the characteristic of realization” in the case of both these kinds of realization. For without developing the third jhāna it is impossible to be reborn in the Subhakiṇha world or to go there by psychic power.

original: na catutthajjhānaṃ uppādetuṃ. Iti duvidhampetaṃ sacchikiriyaṃ sandhāya – “etassa
analyzed: na catuttha jhānam uppādetum iti duvidham petam sacchikiriyam sandhāya etassa
translated: nor to arouse the fourth jhāna. So this is twofold in the case of realization.

original: nūna, bhante, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāhetū”ti āha.🔽277. Udañcanikoti udakavārako. Antarāyamakāsīti yathā pabbajjaṃ na labhati, evaṃ🔽upaddutamakāsi yathā taṃ upanissayavipannaṃ. Ayaṃ kira kassapabuddhakāle pabbajitvā
analyzed: nūna bhante ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hetu uti āha  udañcanikaḥ iti udaka vārakaḥ antarāyam akāsi iti yathā pabbajjam na labhati evam  upaddutam akāsi yathā tam upanissaya vipannam ayam kira kassapa buddha kāle pabbajitvā
translated: not to arouse the fourth jhāna. So it was with reference to the two kinds of realization that he said, “Surely, venerable sir, it is for the sake of realizing a world of utter bliss” .

original: samaṇadhammamakāsi. Athassa eko sahāyako bhikkhu sāsane anabhirato, “āvuso, vibbhamissāmī”ti
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam akāsi athassa ekaḥ sahāyakaḥ bhikkhu sāsane an abhirataḥ āvuso vibbhamissāmi iti
translated: “A water-bearing cloud”: a cloud that rains. “It was an obstacle”: it was a hindrance to his obtaining the going forth, for it was a misfortune to the condition for it. For it seems that in the time of Kassapa Buddha this man went forth and did his duties as a monk. Then a friend of his, a bhikkhu who was dissatisfied with the dispensation, announced, “I am going to disrobe, friend.”

original: ārocesi. So tassa pattacīvare lobhaṃ uppādetvā gihibhāvāya vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi. Itaro tassa🔽pattacīvaraṃ datvā vibbhami. Tenassa kammunā idāni bhagavato sammukhā pabbajjāya
analyzed: ārocesi saḥ tassa patta cīvare lobham uppādetvā gihi bhāvāya vaṇṇam abhāsi itaraḥ tassa  patta cīvaram da tvā vibbhami tena assa kammunā idāni bhagavato sammukhā pabbajjāya
translated: The other aroused greed for his robe and bowl and praised the life of a householder for him. The latter gave him his robe and bowl and disrobed.

original: antarāyo jāto. Bhagavatā panassa purimasuttaṃ atirekabhāṇavāramattaṃ, idaṃ bhāṇavāramattanti
analyzed: antarāyaḥ jātaḥ bhagavatā pana assa purima suttam atireka bhāṇa vāra mattam idam bhāṇa vāra mattam ti
translated: As a result of that kamma he was now an obstacle to the Blessed One’s going forth. But the Blessed One preached the first sutta to him, which was a mere introduction, and this sutta, which is the main part.

original: ettakāya tantiyā dhammo kathito, ekadesanāyapi maggaphalapaṭivedho na jāto, anāgate
analyzed: ettakāya tantiyā dhammo kathito eka desanāya api magga phala paṭivedho na jātaḥ anāgate
translated: The Dhamma was taught with just this much thread, but even with this much teaching, the penetration of the path and fruition did not occur. The Blessed One taught the Dhamma thinking, “In the future

original: panassa paccayo bhavissatīti bhagavā dhammaṃ deseti. Anāgate paccayabhāvañcassa disvā
analyzed: pana assa paccayaḥ bhavissati iti bhagavā dhammam deseti anāgate paccaya bhāvam ca assa disvā
translated: he will be a condition.” Seeing that he would be a condition in the future,

original: bhagavā dharamāno ekaṃ bhikkhumpi mettāvihārimhi etadagge na ṭhapesi. Passati hi
analyzed: bhagavā dharamānaḥ ekam bhikkhum pi mettāvihārimhi etad agge na ṭhapesi passati hi
translated: the Blessed One, while holding him, did not place even one bhikkhu in the foremost position among those who dwell in loving-kindness. The Blessed One saw that

original: bhagavā – “anāgate ayaṃ mama sāsane pabbajitvā mettāvihārīnaṃ aggo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: bhagavā anāgate ayam mama sāsane pabbajitvā mettā vihārīnam aggaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: in the future he would go forth in my Dispensation and become foremost among those who dwell in loving-kindness.

original: So bhagavati parinibbute dhammāsokarājakāle pāṭaliputte nibbattitvā pabbajitvā arahattappatto
analyzed: saḥ bhagavati parinibbute dhammāsoka rāja kāle pāṭaliputte nibbattitvā pabbajitvā arahatta ppattaḥ
translated: After the Blessed One’s Parinibbāna, he was reborn in Pāṭaliputta during the time of King Dhammāsoka. Having gone forth, he attained arahatship

original: assaguttatthero nāma hutvā mettāvihārīnaṃ aggo ahosi. Therassa mettānubhāvena tiracchānagatāpi
analyzed: assagutta theraḥ nāma hutvā aggaḥ ahosi therassa mettā anubhāvena tiracchāna gatā api
translated: and became known as the Elder Assagutta. He was foremost among those who dwell in loving-kindness. By the Elder’s power of loving-kindness, even the animals

original: mettacittaṃ paṭilabhiṃsu, thero sakalajambudīpe bhikkhusaṅghassa ovādācariyo hutvā
analyzed: metta cittam paṭilabhiṃsu thero sakala jambudīpe bhikkhu saṅghassa ovāda ācariyaḥ hutvā
translated: obtained loving-kindness. The Elder became the instructor in the training of the entire Sangha of bhikkhus in the Rose-Apple Island.

original: vattanisenāsane āvasi, tiṃsayojanamattā aṭavī ekaṃ padhānagharaṃ ahosi. Thero ākāse
analyzed: vatta nisenāsane āvasi tiṃsa yojana mattā aṭavī ekam padhāna gharam ahosi theraḥ ākāse
translated: He dwelt in the Vattaniya Monastery, and a forest extending thirty leagues became his meditation subject. The Elder

original: cammakhaṇḍaṃ pattharitvā tattha nisinno kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathesi. Gacchante gacchante
analyzed: camma khaṇḍam pattharitvā tattha nisinno kammaṭṭhānam kathesi gacchante gacchante
translated: and he sat down on it and gave a talk on meditation subjects. As time went on,

original: kāle bhikkhācārampi agantvā vihāre nisinno kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathesi, manussā vihārameva
analyzed: kāle bhikkhācāram pi a gantvā vihāre nisinno kammaṭṭhānam kathesi manussāḥ vihāram eva
translated: he did not even go on his alms round but gave his talk on meditation subjects while sitting in the monastery. People went to the monastery

original: gantvā dānamadaṃsu. Dhammāsokarājā therassa guṇaṃ sutvā daṭṭhukāmo tikkhattuṃ pahiṇi.
analyzed: gantvā dhammāsoka rājā therassa guṇam sutvā daṭṭhu kāmo tikkhattum pahiṇi

We shall have much demerit🔽if we do not go back and get the roots.” If the vessel is of little value and the cost of the roots is great, the righteous merchant thinks: “We shall have merit

original: pacchindanto andhe jiṇṇe mātāpitaro posetīti āha.🔽289. Ko nu khoti kuhiṃ nu kho. Kumbhiyāti ukkhalito. Pariyogāti sūpabhājanato. Paribhuñjāti
analyzed: pacchindantaḥ andhe jiṇṇe mātā pitaraḥ poseti iti āha  kaḥ nu kho iti kuhim nu kho kumbhiyā ati ukkhalito sūpa bhājanataḥ paribhuñjāti
translated: if we go back and get the roots.” Like the householders who properly take care of what they have bought, they go back and get the roots. But why does he, who has such qualities, not go forth? He says: “I look after my blind and aged parents, not transgressing the king’s words.”

original: bhuñja. Kasmā panete evaṃ vadanti? Ghaṭikāro kira bhattaṃ pacitvā sūpaṃ sampādetvā

translated: . Ko nu kho means: where? Kumbhiyä means: from the pot. Pariyogä means: from the soup-dish. Paribhuñjä means: eat. Why do they speak thus? The potter, it seems, after cooking the rice and preparing the soup,

analyzed: āsanam paññapetvā ādhārakam upaṭṭhapetvā udakam paccupaṭṭhapetvā mātā pitūnam saññam

analyzed: da tvā araññam gacchati tasmai evam vadanti abhivissatthaḥ ti ativissatthaḥ pīti sukham  na vijahati iti na nirantaram vijahati atha kho ratti bhāge vā divasa bhāge vā gāme  vā araññe vā yasmin yasmin khaṇe sa devake nāma loke agga puggalaḥ mayham geham pavisitvā
translated: ‘With full confidence’: with complete confidence.🔽‘Does not abandon the happiness and gladness’

analyzed: buddhānam sikkhāpada velā nāma natthi yathā hi raññaḥ uyyāne puppha phalāni honti
translated: There is no such thing as a time when the Buddhas are not training themselves. Just as in a king’s garden there are flowers and fruits,

analyzed: haratha bhante haratha bhadra mukha ati amhākam puttaḥ kuhim gataḥ asi iti vutte

analyzed: dasabalassa santikam ti vadati kuhim nu kho gacchati satthu vasana ṭṭhānassa

translated: Thinking that their son had committed an offence, they were pleased that he was being taken, and so they said: “Take him.”

analyzed: ākāsacchadanam na deva utivassi iti kevalam na ativassi yathā pana ittha pakatiyā ca nibba kosassa  udakapāta ṭṭhāna abbhantare ekam pi udaka bindu evam ghana chadana geha abbhantare
translated: and the roof was covered with a canopy of sky. ‘The god did not rain’: he did not rain at all. But just as in the place where the rain-water collected in the hollow of the tree-trunk

analyzed: ābādham ābādham akaṃsu aparabhāge tasmin

translated: And that was not by the power of the Buddha, but by the excellence of their own qualities. For

analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ kattha na labheyya amhākam nāma dvinnam andhakānam nivesanam uttiṇam
translated: – “Where would the Fully Enlightened One not be honoured? The dwelling of us two blind people was cleared of grass,

analyzed: kāresi iti na tad paccayā domanassam udapādi sa devake loke agga puggalaḥ amhākam nivesanā

translated: Because he had acquired the habit of being satisfied with little. He thought, “The king has never seen me before. How much will he send?”

original: pesesī”ti. Tato cintesi – “satthā bārāṇasiṃ gato, addhā so rañño vassāvāsaṃ yāciyamāno

analyzed: mayham paṭiññāta bhāvam ārocetvā mama guṇa katham kathesi guṇa kathāya laddha lābhaḥ

original: Ghaṭikārasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.

translated: The Commentary on the Ghaṭīkāra Sutta in the Majjhima Nikāya is finished.

analyzed: raṭṭhapāla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Raṭṭhapāla Sutta

original: 293. Evaṃ me sutanti raṭṭhapālasuttaṃ. Tattha thullakoṭṭhikanti thullakoṭṭhaṃ paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāraṃ.

translated: Thus I heard. The Raṭṭhapāla Sutta . Herein, Thullakoṭṭhika means a granary with a high bin.

analyzed: saḥ kira janapadaḥ nicca sassaḥ sadā bīja bhaṇḍam nikkhamati khala bhaṇḍam pavisati tena
translated: It seems that this country was always prosperous, for seed-corn was always going out of it and harvested corn coming in.

original: tasmiṃ nigame koṭṭhā niccapūrāva honti. Tasmā so thullakoṭṭhikanteva saṅkhaṃ gato.
analyzed: tasmin nigame koṭṭhāḥ niccapūrā ava honti tasmā saḥ thulla koṭṭhi kantā iva saṅkham gataḥ
translated: So the bins in the town were always full. That is why it became known as Thullakoṭṭhika .
