analyzed: raṭṭha pālo ti kasmai raṭṭha pālaḥ bhinnam raṭṭham sandhāretum pāletum samatthaḥ ti  raṭṭhapālo kadā panassa etam nāmam uppannanti padumuttara sammāsambuddha kāle itas  hi pubbe sata sahassa kappa matthake vassa sata sahassa āyukesu manussesu padumuttaraḥ nāma
translated: Why was he called Ratthapala? Because he was able to protect and preserve a broken country, he was called Ratthapala. But when did he get this name? At the time of the Supremely Enlightened Padumuttara. For a hundred thousand cycles of time before this, when men lived to be a hundred thousand years old, there was a Buddha called Padumuttara.

original: satthā uppajjitvā bhikkhusatasahassaparivāro lokahitāya cārikaṃ cari, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: satthā uppajjitvā bhikkhu sata sahassa parivāraḥ loka hitāya cārikam cari yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: Why was he called Ratthapala? Because he was able to protect and preserve a broken country, he was called Ratthapala. But when did he get this name? At the time of the Supremely Enlightened Padumuttara. For a hundred thousand cycles of time before this, men lived for a hundred thousand years, and at that time a Teacher named Padumuttara arose in the world. Surrounded by a retinue of a hundred thousand monks, he went about doing good in the world. And it was with reference to him that the following was said:

original: “Nagaraṃ haṃsavatī nāma, ānando nāma khattiyo;
analyzed: nagaram haṃsavatī nāma ānandaḥ nāma khattiyaḥ
translated: “The city was named Haṃsavati, and the king was named Ānanda;

analyzed: sujātā nāma janikā padumuttarassa satthunoti  padumuttare pana anuppanne eva haṃsavatiyā dve kuṭumbikā saddhā pasannā kapaṇaddhika yācaka ādīnam
translated: The mother who gave birth to Padumuttara was named Sujata.”

original: dānaṃ paṭṭhapayiṃsu. Tadā pabbatavāsino pañcasatā tāpasā haṃsavatiṃ anuppattā. Te
analyzed: dānam paṭṭhapayiṃsu tadā pabbata vāsino pañca satā tāpasāḥ haṃsavatim anuppattā te
translated: But even before Padumuttara arose in the world, two householders of Haṃsavati, filled with faith and confidence, gave alms to the poor, the helpless, and the beggars. At that time five hundred ascetics of the mountains came to Haṃsavati.

original: dvepi janā tāpasagaṇaṃ majjhe bhinditvā upaṭṭhahiṃsu. Tāpasā kiñcikālaṃ vasitvā pabbatapādameva
analyzed: dve api janā tāpasa gaṇam majjhe bhinditvā upaṭṭhahiṃsu tāpasā kiñcikālam vasitvā pabbata pādam eva

original: gatā. Dve saṅghattherā ohīyiṃsu. Tadā tesaṃ te yāvajīvaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ akaṃsu. Tāpasesu

analyzed: kuṭumbikesu ekaḥ sakka bhavanam patthanam katvā sakkaḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ ekaḥ nāga bhavane
translated: One of the laymen made his wish for Sakka’s palace, and he was reborn as Sakka. The other made his wish for the nāga palace,

analyzed: pālitanāga rājā nāma tam sakkaḥ attanaḥ upaṭṭhānam āgatam disvā nāga yoniyam abhiramasi iti
translated: and he was reborn as the nāga king Pāḷita. When Sakka saw him coming to attend on him, he asked him, “Do you enjoy being in the nāga realm?”

analyzed: pucchi saḥ na abhiramāmi iti āha tena hi padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ dānam da tvā imasmin
translated: He replied, “No, I don’t.” “Well then, make an offering to the Buddha Padumuttara and make your wish right here.🔽We’ll both live happily.” The nāga king invited the Buddha, together with a retinue of a hundred thousand monks,

original: ṭhāne patthanaṃ karohi, ubho sukhaṃ vasissāmāti. Nāgarājā satthāraṃ nimantetvā bhikkhusatasahassaparivārassa
analyzed: ṭhāne patthanam karohi ubho sukham vasissāma iti nāga rājā satthāram nimantetvā bhikkhu sata sahassa parivārassa

original: bhagavato sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ dadamāno padumuttarassa dasabalassa puttaṃ uparevataṃ🔽nāma sāmaṇeraṃ disvā sattame divase buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa dibbavatthāni datvā
analyzed: bhagavato sattāham mahā dānam dadamāno padumuttarassa dasabalassa puttam uparevatam  nāma sāmaṇeram disvā sattame divase buddha ppamukhassa saṅghassa dibba vatthāni datvā
translated: and for seven days he gave a great festival in honour of the Buddha, and on the seventh day, after giving divine garments to the Congregation of Monks presided over by the Buddha,

From the time of his birth

analyzed: tacchitabba yutta ṭṭhānāni sammajjitabba yuttāni ṭhānāni sammajjāpentaḥ vālukā okiraṇa puppha vikiraṇa puṇṇa ghaṭa ṭṭhapana kadali kkhandha ṭhapana ādīni  ca karontaḥ iti atthaḥ yena rājā korabyaḥ tena upasaṅkamīti amhākam rājā sadā imassa kula puttassa  vaṇṇam kathesi passitu kāmo etam āgata bhāvam pana assa na jānāti mahā kho pana ayam
translated: he had the places that should be cut over-run with grass cut, and the places that should be swept swept, and he had sand sprinkled, flowers scattered, full water-pots set out, plantain trees planted, and so on.🔽The meaning is that he was doing all this. “He approached King Koravya”: our king always speaks in praise of this young man, and he wants to see him. But he does not know that he has come. This is a large party. I will go and inform the king.

analyzed: paṇṇākāraḥ gantvā raññaḥ ārocessāmi iti cintetvā yena rājā korabyo tena upasaṅkami

original: Kittayamāno ahosīti so kira rājā theraṃ anussaritvā balamajjhepi nāṭakamajjhepi –
analyzed: kittayamānaḥ ahosi iti saḥ kira rājā theram anussaritvā bala majjhe pi nāṭaka majjhe pi

analyzed: dukkaram katam kula puttena tāva mahantam sampattim pahāya pabbajitvā puna nivattitvā

analyzed: orodha mahāmatta balakāya ādīsu yassa yam anucchavikam tassa tam dāpetvā ati atthaḥ ussaṭāya

analyzed: gahetvā upasaṅkamīti attho idha bhavam raṭṭhapālaḥ hatthatthare nisīdatu uti hatthattharo  tanukaḥ bahala puppha ādi guṇam katvā atthataḥ abhilakkhitaḥ hoti tādise an āpucchitvā nisīditum
translated: he approached. The meaning is: “Here, sir, let Ratthapala sit down on the footstool.”🔽The footstool is described in terms of its width and the many qualities such as flowers, etc., that it possesses.

original: na yuttanti maññamāno evamāha.
analyzed: na yuttam ti maññamānaḥ evam āha
translated: Thinking that it is not proper to sit down without asking permission, he said this.

original: 304. Pārijuññānīti pārijuññabhāvā parikkhayā. Jiṇṇoti jarājiṇṇo. Vuḍḍhoti vayovuḍḍho.🔽Mahallakoti jātimahallako. Addhagatoti addhānaṃ atikkanto. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ🔽anuppatto. Pabbajatīti dhuravihāraṃ gantvā bhikkhū vanditvā, – “bhante, mayā daharakāle🔽bahuṃ kusalaṃ kataṃ, idāni mahallakomhi, mahallakassa cesā pabbajjā nāma, cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ🔽sammajjitvā appaharitaṃ katvā jīvissāmi, pabbājetha maṃ, bhante,”ti kāruññaṃ uppādento🔽yācati, therā anukampāya pabbājenti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Dutiyavārepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pārijuññāni iti pārijuñña bhāvā parikkhayā jiṇṇo ti jarā jiṇṇaḥ vuḍḍhaḥ ti vayas vuḍḍhaḥ  mahallako ti jāti mahallakaḥ addha gataḥ ti addhānam atikkantaḥ vayaḥ anuppatto ti pacchima vayam  an uppattaḥ pabbajati iti dhura vihāram gantvā bhikkhū vanditvā bhante mayā dahara kāle  bahum kusalam katam idāni mahallako mhi mahallakassa ca isā pabbajjā nāma cetiyaṅgaṇam  sammajjitvā appaharitam katvā jīvissāmi pabbājetha mama bhante ti kāruññam uppādento  yācati therāḥ anukampāya pabbājenti tam sandhāya itam vuttam dutiya vāre pi esā iva nayo
translated: “He has gone forth” : he has gone forth by the destruction of the defilements. “He is old” : he is old by age. “He is aged” : he is aged by his years.🔽“He is venerable” : he is venerable by birth. “He has reached the last stage of life” : he has reached the last stage of life.🔽“He has gone forth” : having gone to the monastery, having saluted the bhikkhus, he says, “Venerable sirs, in my youth I did much merit, but now I am old and aged. This going forth is for the young. I will live by sweeping the shrine terrace and making it free from grass. Venerable sirs, have compassion on me and let me go forth.” He asks with compassion.🔽The elders, out of compassion, let him go forth. This is what is meant. The same method applies to the second case.

original: Appābādhoti arogo. Appātaṅkoti niddukkho. Samavepākiniyāti samavipācaniyā. Gahaṇiyāti🔽kammajatejodhātuyā. Tattha yassa bhuttabhutto āhāro jīrati, yassa vā pana puṭabhattaṃ
analyzed: appa ābādho ti arogaḥ appa ātaṅko ti niddukkho sama vepākiniyā ati sama vipācaniyā gahaṇiyā ati 🔽kamma ja tejaḥ dhātuyā tattha yassa bhutta bhuttaḥ āhāraḥ jīrati yassa vā pana puṭa bhattam
translated: ‘He goes forth’ means that after going to the monastery and worshipping the monks he says, ‘Venerable sirs, much merit was made by me in my youth, but now I am old and this going forth is for the old, I will live by sweeping the shrine terrace and making it free from grass, please give me the going forth, venerable sirs,’ and he asks with compassion, and the elders, out of compassion, give him the going forth. This is what is meant. In the second verse the meaning is the same. ‘With little illness’ means healthy. ‘With little affliction’ means without suffering. ‘With a digestion that is easy to tend’ means with a digestion that is easy to ripen. ‘With a body that is easy to carry’ means with a body that is easy to carry by the fire element that is the product of kamma. Herein, the food that is eaten is digested in one, and the food that is eaten is not digested in another.

original: viya tatheva tiṭṭhati, ubhopete na samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgatā. Yassa pana
analyzed: tathā iva tiṭṭhati ubho upete na samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgatā yassa pana
translated: and it remains just as it was. Both are endowed with a non-congregating grasping. But in the case of one who

original: bhuttakāle bhattacchando uppajjateva, ayaṃ samavepākiniyā samannāgato. Nātisītāya
analyzed: bhutta kāle bhatta chandaḥ uppajjateva ayam samavepākiniyā samannāgataḥ na ati sītāya
translated: and it remains just so. Both are endowed with the kind of digestion that does not overreact. But one who gets a craving for food even when he has finished eating is endowed with the kind of digestion that overreacts.

original: naccuṇhāyāti teneva kāraṇena nātisītāya naccuṇhāya. Anupubbenāti rājāno vā harantītiādinā
analyzed: na cuṇhāya ati tena iva kāraṇena na ati sītāya na cuṇhāya anupubbena ati rājānaḥ vā haranti itiādinā
translated: Not too cold, not too hot: for that reason it is not too cold, not too hot. In due course: in due order, beginning thus: “Kings may take it, thieves may take it” .

original: anukkamena. Dutiyavāre rājabhayacorabhayachātakabhayādinā anukkamena.🔽305. Dhammuddesā uddiṭṭhāti dhammaniddesā uddiṭṭhā. Upaniyyatīti jarāmaraṇasantikaṃ🔽gacchati, āyukkhayena vā tattha niyyati. Addhuvoti dhuvaṭṭhānavirahito. Atāṇoti tāyituṃ🔽samatthena virahito. Anabhissaroti asaraṇo abhisaritvā abhigantvā assāsetuṃ samatthena
analyzed: anukkamena dutiya vāre rāja bhaya cora bhaya chātaka bhaya ādinā anukkamena  dhamma uddesāḥ uddiṭṭhāti dhamma niddesāḥ uddiṭṭhāḥ upaniyyati iti jarā maraṇa santikam  gacchati āyu khayena vā tattha niyyati addhuvo ti dhuva ṭṭhāna virahitaḥ  samatthena virahitaḥ an abhissaroti a saraṇaḥ abhisaritvā abhigantvā assāsetum samatthena
translated: In the second case, in due order beginning with fear of kings, fear of thieves, fear of water, and so on.

original: virahito. Assakoti nissako sakabhaṇḍavirahito. Sabbaṃ pahāya gamanīyanti sakabhaṇḍanti
analyzed: virahitaḥ assako ti nissako saka bhaṇḍa virahitaḥ sabbam pahāya gamanīyanti saka bhaṇḍam ti
translated: The headings of the True Idea have been recited: the headings of the True Idea’s demonstration have been recited. It is carried off: it goes near to ageing and death; or it is carried off by the exhaustion of life. Impermanent: devoid of permanence. No protection: devoid of what is able to protect. No shelter: devoid of what is able to shelter by going to it and going up to it. No refuge: devoid of what is able to give refuge. Empty: devoid of one’s own people and one’s own chattels. It must be gone from, leaving everything: one’s own people and one’s own chattels.

original: sallakkhitaṃ sabbaṃ pahāya lokena gantabbaṃ. Taṇhādāsoti taṇhāya dāso.🔽306. Hatthisminti hatthisippe. Katāvīti katakaraṇīyo, sikkhitasikkho paguṇasippoti🔽attho. Esa nayo sabbattha. Ūrubalīti ūrubalasampanno. Yassa hi phalakañca āvudhañca🔽gahetvā parasenaṃ pavisitvā abhinnaṃ bhindato bhinnaṃ sandhārayato parahatthagataṃ🔽rajjaṃ āharituṃ ūrubalaṃ atthi, ayaṃ ūrubalī nāma. Bāhubalīti bāhubalasampanno. Sesaṃ
analyzed: sallakkhitam sabbam pahāya lokena gantabbam taṇhā dāso ti taṇhāya dāso  hatthismin ti hatthi sippe katāvī iti kata karaṇīyo sikkhita sikkho paguṇa sippo ti  attho esa nayaḥ sabbattha ūru balī iti ūru bala sampannaḥ yassa hi phalakam ca āvudhañca  gahetvā para senam pavisitvā abhinnam bhindataḥ bhinnam sandhārayataḥ para hattha gatam  rajjam āharitum ūru balam atthi ayam ūrubalī nāma bāhu balī iti bāhu bala sampanno sesam
translated: and he should go with the world abandoning all that is seen. A slave to craving: a slave to craving.

original: purimasadisameva. Alamattoti samatthaattabhāvo.
analyzed: purima sadisam eva alam atto ti samattha atta bhāvaḥ
translated: In elephants: in the art of handling elephants. He has done his task: he has done what had to be done; he is trained and skilled in the art, is the meaning. The same explanation applies in each case. A man of thigh-power: a man possessing thigh-power. For when a man takes a shield and a weapon and enters the army and is able to break up an unbroken division of the enemy, to hold an unbroken division, and to bring back a conquered realm from under the enemy’s hand, then he is called a man of thigh-power. A man of arm-power: a man possessing arm-power. The rest is as before. A man of sufficient power: a man of sufficient ability.

original: Pariyodhāya vattissantīti uppannaṃ uppaddavaṃ odhāya avattharitvā vattissantīti sallakkhetvā gahitā.
analyzed: pariyodhāya vattissanti iti uppannam uppaddavam odhāya avattharitvā vattissanti iti sallakkhetvā gahitā
translated: They will carry on their business by the light of the lamp: they will carry on their business by the light of the lamp after they have taken it and put it down.

original: Saṃvijjati kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, imasmiṃ rājakule pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇanti idaṃ so rājā upari dhammuddesassa kāraṇaṃ āharanto āha.
analyzed: saṃvijjati kho bho raṭṭhapālaḥ imasmim rājakule pahūtam hirañña suvaṇṇam ti idam saḥ rājā upari dhammuddesassa kāraṇam āharantaḥ āha

translated: “I see in the world no one so blind as he who has eyes but does not see, who has ears but does not hear, who has a mouth but does not speak.”🔽“I see in the world no one so blind as he who has eyes but does not see, who has ears but does not hear, who has a mouth but does not speak.”🔽“I see in the world no one so blind as he who has eyes but does not see, who has ears but does not hear, who has a mouth but does not speak.”

original: Phusanti phassanti maraṇaphassaṃ phusanti. Tatheva phuṭṭhoti yathā bālo, dhīropi🔽tatheva maraṇaphassena phuṭṭho, aphuṭṭho nāma natthi, ayaṃ pana viseso. Bālo ca bālyā
analyzed: phusanti phassanti maraṇa phassam phusanti tathā iva yathā bālaḥ dhīraḥ api  tathā iva maraṇa phassena phuṭṭhaḥ aphuṭṭhaḥ nāma natthi ayam pana visesaḥ bālaḥ ca bālyā
translated: They are touched by the touch of death. The wise man too is touched in the same way.🔽But the difference is that the fool,

original: vadhitova setīti bālo bālabhāvena maraṇaphassaṃ āgamma vadhitova seti abhihatova
analyzed: vadhitaḥ iva seti iti bālaḥ bāla bhāvena maraṇa phassam āgamma vadhitaḥ iva seti abhihataḥ iva
translated: “Having died, lies down as one who has been slain” — the fool, because of his foolishness, having been touched by the touch of death, lies down as one who has been slain, as one who has been struck down.

original: sayati. Akataṃ vata me kalyāṇantiādivippaṭisāravasena calati vedhati vipphandati.
analyzed: sayati a katam vata me kalyāṇanti ādi vippaṭisāra vasena calati vedhati vipphandati
translated: He lies down trembling, agitated, and convulsed, through remorse, thinking, “I have not done what is good.”

original: Dhīro ca na vedhatīti dhīro sugatinimittaṃ passanto na vedhati na calati.
analyzed: dhīro ca na vedhati iti dhīro sugati nimittam passantaḥ na vedhati na calati
translated: But the wise man does not tremble.

analyzed: yāya vosānam idha adhigacchati iti yāya paññāya imasmin loke sabba kicca vosānam arahattam
translated: By which he attains the end here — by which wisdom he attains the end of all his duties here in this world, namely, arahatship —🔽that is better than wealth.

original: adhigacchati, sāva dhanato uttamatarā. Abyositattāti apariyositattā, arahattapattiyā,
analyzed: adhigacchati sā ava dhanataḥ uttamatarā a byosita ttā ati a pariyosita ttā arahatta pattiyā

original: abhāvenāti attho. Bhavābhavesūti hīnappaṇītesu bhavesu.
analyzed: abhāvena ati atthaḥ bhava abhavesu iti hīna paṇītesu bhavesu
translated: “In existence after existence” means in the inferior and superior existences.

original: Upeti gabbhañca parañca lokanti tesu pāpaṃ karontesu yo koci satto paramparāya saṃsāraṃ

analyzed: āpajjitvā gabbhañca parañca lokam upeti tassa appapaññaḥ ti tassa tādisassa appapaññassa
translated: When they are doing evil, whatever being goes to the womb and to the world beyond by way of the round of rebirths🔽is a fool.

original: añño appapañño abhisaddahanto.
analyzed: aññaḥ appapaññaḥ abhisaddahantaḥ
translated: Another fool believes him.🔽He is destroyed by his own deeds.

analyzed: sa kammunā haññati iti attanā kata kamma vasena tāleti itiādīhi kamma kāraṇāhi haññati pecca paramhi loke iti itas gantvā paramhi apāya loke
translated: Because of the deeds he has done, he is destroyed by the means of destruction described in the passage beginning, “He is beaten with whips” .🔽In the world beyond, in the next world,

analyzed: virūpa rūpena ati vividha rūpena nānā sabhāvena ati attho kāma guṇesu ti diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikesu

analyzed: sabba kāma guṇesu ādīnavam disvā antamasaḥ kalala matta bhāvam upādāya taruṇā

analyzed: vuḍḍhā ati vassa sata atikkantā apaṇṇakam sāmaññam eva seyyo ti aviruddham advajjha gāmim

original: ekantaniyyānikaṃ sāmaññameva “seyyo, uttaritarañca paṇītatarañcā”ti upadhāretvā pabbajitosmi🔽mahārājāti. Tasmā yaṃ tvaṃ vadasi – “kiṃ disvā vā sutvā vā”ti, idaṃ disvā ca sutvā
analyzed: ekanta niyyānikam sāmaññam eva seyyo uttaritaram ca paṇītataram ca ati upadhāretvā pabbajitaḥ smi  mahā rāja ati tasmai yam tvam vadasi kim disvā vā sutvā vā ati idam disvā ca sutvā
translated: and that the going forth is the only way out of the world, and that the life of a monk is better and more excellent, and so I went forth.🔽Great King, therefore remember that I went forth on seeing and hearing this.”

analyzed: ca pabbajitaḥ asmi iti mama dhārehi iti desanam niṭṭhāpesi iti  papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: Thus he concluded his teaching.🔽The commentary on the Ratthapala Sutta of the Majjhima Nikaya,

analyzed: raṭṭhapāla sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

analyzed: evam me sutan ti maghadeva suttam tattha maghadeva ambavane ti pubbe maghadevaḥ  nāma rājā tam ambavanam ropesi tesu rukkhesu palujjamānesu aparabhāge aññe api rājāno
translated: The Maghadeva Sutta

analyzed: tam pana paṭhama vohāra vasena saṅkham gatam sitam

original: pātvākāsīti sāyanhasamaye vihāracārikaṃ caramāno ramaṇīyaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ disvā – “vasitapubbaṃ
analyzed: sāyanha samaye vihāra cārikam caramānaḥ ramaṇīyam bhūmi bhāgam disvā vasita pubbam

analyzed: nu kho me imasmin okāse iti āvajjantaḥ pubbe aham maghadevaḥ nāma rājā hutvā imaṃ
translated: “Is this the place?” He saw that it was, and he thought, “Formerly, when I was King Maghadeva, I had this mango grove planted.

analyzed: ambavanam etthā iva pabbajitvā cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahma loke nibbattim
translated: After going forth right here, I developed the four divine abodes and was reborn in the Brahma-world.

analyzed: tam kho pana itam kāraṇam bhikkhu saṅghassa apākaṭam pākaṭam karissāmi iti aggagga dante

analyzed: dhammaḥ assa atthi iti dhammikaḥ dhammena rājā jātaḥ ati dhammarājā dhamme ṭhitaḥ iti dasa kusala kammapatha dhamme  ṭhitaḥ dhammam carati iti samam carati tatra brāhmaṇa gahapatikesu iti yaḥ api saḥ pubba rājūhi
translated: He has Dhamma, thus he is righteous; he was born a king by Dhamma, thus he is a righteous king; he is established in Dhamma, thus he is established in the Dhamma of the ten wholesome courses of action;

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ dinnaparihāro, taṃ ahāpetvā pakatiniyāmeneva adāsi, tathā gahapatikānaṃ.
analyzed: dinna parihāraḥ tam ahāpetvā pakati niyāmena iva adāsi tathā gahapatikānam

original: Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Pakkhassāti iminā pāṭihārikapakkhopi saṅgahito. Aṭṭhamīuposathassa
analyzed: tam sandhāya itam vuttam pakkhassa ti iminā pāṭihārika pakkhaḥ api saṅgahitaḥ aṭṭhamī uposathassa

analyzed: hi paccuggamana anuggamana vasena sattamiyam ca navamiyam ca cātuddasa pannarasānam paccuggamana anuggamana vasena

analyzed: terasiyam ca pāṭipade ca ati ime divasā pāṭihārika pakkhā ati veditabbā tesu pi uposatham upavasi
translated: These days should be understood as the “days of the fortnight of the miracle.” On these days too he should observe the Uposatha.

analyzed: maccu rājassa santike ṭhitaḥ viya hoti tasmā palitāni maccudevassa dūta ati vuccanti  devāḥ deva dūtāḥ yathā hi alaṅkata paṭiyattāya devatāya ākāse ṭhatvā asuka divase

original: hoti. Tasmā palitāni devasadisā dūtāti vuccanti. Visuddhidevānaṃ dūtātipi devadūtā.
analyzed: hoti tasmā palitāni deva sadisā dūtā ati vuccanti deva dūtā
translated: “Messenger of the gods of purity”:

analyzed: jiṇṇam ca disvā dukhitam ca byādhitam  matam ca disvā gatam āyu saṅkhayam
translated: “On seeing the old, the sick, and the dead,

analyzed: tasmai aham pabbajitaḥ amhi rājā ati
translated: And so, O King, I went forth.”

translated: These grey hairs have appeared on my head,🔽The messengers of the gods have come;

analyzed: pātubhūtā deva dūtā pabbajjā samayaḥ mama ati  purisa yuga iti vaṃsa sambhave purise kesa massum ohāretvā ati tāpasapabbajjam pabbajantā api
translated: The time has come for me to go forth.🔽In the prime of life: in the prime of youth.🔽Having shaved off his hair and beard: for those who go forth as ascetics first shave off their hair and beard;

translated: But after going forth, instead of seeking his livelihood by the wrong means of getting a living, he made his living by the alms he received from the royal house and developed the divine abidings.

original: Tasmā so mettāsahagatenātiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā so mettā sahagatena atiādi vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said: “He developed loving-kindness together with … ”

original: Kumārakīḷitaṃ kīḷīti aṅkena aṅkaṃ parihariyamāno kīḷi. Mālākalāpaṃ viya hi naṃ ukkhipitvāva
analyzed: kumāra kīḷitam kīḍīti aṅkena aṅkam parihariyamānaḥ mālā kalāpam viya hi naṃ ukkhipitvā ava
translated: He played the child’s game: he played the game of passing from lap to lap.

original: vicariṃsu. Rañño maghadevassa putto…pe… pabbajīti imassa pabbajitadivase pañca maṅgalāni🔽ahesuṃ. Maghadevarañño matakabhattaṃ, tassa rañño pabbajitamaṅgalaṃ, tassa puttassa
analyzed: vicariṃsu raññaḥ maghadevassa putta upe pabbajī ti imassa pabbajita divase pañca maṅgalāni  ahesum maghadeva raññaḥ mataka bhattam tassa raññaḥ pabbajita maṅgalam tassa puttassa
translated: and the king’s son, Maghadeva, went forth into homelessness. On the day of his going forth there were five auspicious signs:

original: chattussāpanamaṅgalaṃ, tassa puttassa uparajjamaṅgalaṃ, tassa puttassa nāmakaraṇamaṅgalanti
analyzed: chattussāpana maṅgalam tassa puttassa uparajja maṅgalam tassa puttassa nāmakaraṇa maṅgalanti
translated: the funeral feast of King Maghadeva, the auspicious going forth of his son, the auspicious coronation of his grandson, the auspicious naming of his great-grandson, and the auspicious gift of the four requisites to the great-grandson.

original: ekasmiṃyeva samaye pañca maṅgalāni ahesuṃ, sakalajambudīpatale unnaṅgalamahosi.
analyzed: ekasmin yā iva samaye pañca maṅgalāni ahesum sakala jambudīpa tale
translated: On the very same day there were five auspicious signs, and there was great rejoicing throughout the whole of India.

original: 311. Puttapaputtakāti puttā ca puttaputtā cāti evaṃ pavattā tassa paramparā. Pacchimako🔽ahosīti pabbajjāpacchimako ahosi. Bodhisatto kira brahmaloke nibbatto – “pavattati🔽nu kho taṃ mayā manussaloke nihataṃ kalyāṇavatta”nti āvajjanto addasa – “ettakaṃ
analyzed: puttapaputtakā ti puttā ca puttaputtā ca ati evam pavattā tassa paramparā pacchimako  ahosi iti pabbajjā pacchimakaḥ ahosi bodhisatto kira brahma loke nibbattaḥ pavattati  nu kho tam mayā manussa loke nihatam kalyāṇa vattanti āvajjantaḥ addasa ettakam
translated: The line of descendants, beginning with the son and grandson, continued in this way. The last of them🔽was the last of the line to go forth. The Bodhisatta, it is said, was reborn in the Brahma-world, and he considered thus: “Has that good conduct which I practised in the world of men been continued?” He saw that it had continued for a long time, but that now it was not being continued. He did not wish to allow his line to be broken,

original: addhānaṃ pavattati, idāni na pavattissatī”ti. Na kho panāhaṃ mayhaṃ paveṇiyā ucchijjituṃ
analyzed: addhānam pavattati idāni na pavattissati iti na kho pana aham mayham paveṇiyā ucchijjitum
translated: and so he was reborn in the world of men.

original: dassāmīti attano vaṃse jātaraññoyeva aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā🔽attano vaṃsassa nemiṃ ghaṭento viya nibbatto, tenevassa nimīti nāmaṃ ahosi. Iti so
analyzed: dassāmi iti attanaḥ vaṃse jāta raññoya iva aggamahesiyā kucchismim paṭisandhim gahetvā  attanaḥ vaṃsassa nemim ghaṭentaḥ viya nibbattaḥ tena iva assa nimī iti nāmam ahosi iti so
translated: “I will give,” he took rebirth in the womb of the chief queen of his own family.

original: pabbajitarājūnaṃ sabbapacchimako hutvā pabbajitoti pabbajjāpacchimako ahosi. Guṇehi
analyzed: pabbajita rājūnam sabba pacchimakaḥ hutvā pabbajitaḥ iti pabbajjā pacchimakaḥ ahosi guṇehi
translated: He was born as if he were the wheel-gem of his own family. Therefore he was called Nimi. Thus he was the last of the kings who went forth. He was the last to go forth. But he was superior in virtues

original: pana atirekataro. Tassa hi sabbarājūhi atirekatarā dve guṇā ahesuṃ. Catūsu dvāresu
analyzed: pana atirekataro tassa hi sabba rājūhi atirekatarāḥ dve guṇāḥ ahesum catūsu dvāresu
translated: to all the other kings. For he had two virtues superior to those of all the other kings. At the four city gates

original: satasahassaṃ satasahassaṃ vissajjetvā devasikaṃ dānaṃ adāsi, anuposathikassa ca dassanaṃ🔽nivāresi. Anuposathikesu hi rājānaṃ passissāmāti gatesu dovāriko pucchati “tumhe
analyzed: sata sahassam sata sahassam vissajjetvā devasikam dānam adāsi anuposathikassa ca dassanam  nivāresi anuposathikesu hi rājānam passissāma ati gatesu dovāriko pucchati tumhe
translated: he gave alms daily, spending a hundred thousand pieces at each gate. And he refused to see anyone on the fast-day.🔽For when people came to see the king, the doorkeeper asked them,

original: uposathikā no vā”ti. Ye anuposathikā honti, te nivāreti “anuposathikānaṃ rājā dassanaṃ
analyzed: uposathikāḥ no vāti ye an uposathikāḥ honti te nivāreti an uposathikānam rājā dassanam
translated: “Are you fasting or not?” He turned away those who were not fasting, saying, “The king will not see you unless you are fasting.”

original: na detī”ti. “Mayaṃ janapadavāsino kāle bhojanaṃ kuhiṃ labhissāmā”tipi tattha vacanokāso
analyzed: na deti iti mayam janapada vāsino kāle bhojanam tattha vacana ukāsaḥ
translated: “But where shall we get food, being as we are dwellers in the provinces?”

original: natthi. Catūsu hi dvāresu rājaṅgaṇe ca anekāni bhattacāṭisahassāni paṭiyattāneva
analyzed: natthi catūsu hi dvāresu rājaṅgaṇe ca anekāni bhatta cāṭi sahassāni
translated: There was none. For at the four gates and in the royal compound there were many thousands of kitchens prepared.

original: honti. Tasmā mahājano icchiticchitaṭṭhāne massuṃ kāretvā nhāyitvā vatthāni parivattetvā
analyzed: honti tasmai mahā janaḥ icchiticchita ṭṭhāne massum kāretvā nhāyitvā vatthāni parivattetvā
translated: Therefore the multitude had their hair shaved at the place of their choice, bathed, changed their clothes,

original: yathārucitaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya rañño gehadvāraṃ gacchati.
analyzed: yathārucitam bhojanam bhuñjitvā uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya raññaḥ geha dvāram gacchati
translated: ate as much food as they liked, undertook the Uposatha precepts, and went to the king’s door.

original: Dovārikena “uposathikā tumhe”ti pucchitapucchitā “āma āmā”ti vadanti. Tena hi āgacchathāti
analyzed: dovārikena uposathikā tumhe iti pucchita pucchitāḥ āma āma iti vadanti tena hi āgacchatha ati
translated: The doorkeeper asked them, “Are you Uposathikas?” and they replied, “Yes, yes.” He said, “Then come in,”

original: pavesetvā rañño dasseti. Iti imehi dvīhi guṇehi atirekataro ahosi.
analyzed: pavesetvā raññaḥ dasseti iti imehi dvīhi guṇehi atirekataraḥ ahosi
translated: and he admitted them and showed them to the king. Thus he was superior to the other two by these two qualities.

original: 312. Devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānanti tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbattadevānaṃ. Te kira devā videharaṭṭhe
analyzed: devānam tāvatiṃsānam ti tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbatta devānam te kira devāḥ videha raṭṭhe
translated: The Thirty-Three Gods: the gods who were reborn in the Thirty-Threefold World. They were, it seems, the inhabitants of the city of Mithila in the Videha country.

original: mithilanagaravāsino rañño ovāde ṭhatvā pañca sīlāni rakkhitvā uposathakammaṃ katvā
analyzed: mithila nagara vāsinaḥ rañño ovāde ṭhatvā pañca sīlāni rakkhitvā uposatha kammam katvā
translated: They had followed the king’s advice, observed the five precepts, performed the Uposatha observance,

original: tattha nibbattā rañño guṇakathaṃ kathenti. Te sandhāya vuttaṃ “devānaṃ tāvatiṃsāna”nti.
analyzed: tattha nibbattāḥ raññaḥ guṇa katham kathenti te sandhāya vuttam devānam tāvatiṃsānam ti
translated: and were reborn there. They were the ones referred to when it was said above, “the Thirty-Three Gods.”

original: Nisinno hotīti pāsādavarassa uparigato dānañca sīlañca upaparikkhamāno nisinno hoti.
analyzed: nisinnaḥ hoti iti pāsāda varassa upari gataḥ dānañca sīlañca upaparikkhamānaḥ nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: He was seated: he was seated on the top of the palace, considering charity and virtue.

original: Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “dānaṃ nu kho mahantaṃ udāhu sīlaṃ, yadi dānaṃ mahantaṃ, ajjhottharitvā🔽dānameva dassāmi. Atha sīlaṃ, sīlameva pūrissāmī”ti. Tassa “idaṃ mahantaṃ idaṃ mahanta”nti
analyzed: evam kirassa ahosi dānam nu kho mahantam udāhu sīlam yadi dānam mahantam ajjhottharitvā  dānam eva dassāmi atha sīlam sīlam eva pūrissāmi iti tassa idam mahantam idam mahantam ti
translated: For he thought thus: “Is charity greater or is virtue greater? If charity is greater, I will give charity and then🔽become a monk. If virtue is greater, I will become a monk and then practice virtue.” While he was thus unable to decide which was greater, Sakka appeared before him.

original: nicchituṃ asakkontasseva sakko gantvā purato pāturahosi. Tena vuttaṃ atha kho, ānanda,…pe…
analyzed: nicchitum a sakkontassa iva sakkaḥ gantvā puratas pāturahosi tena vuttam atha kho ānandape
translated: Therefore it is said: “Then Sakka, ruler of the gods, …

original: sammukhe pāturahosīti. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “rañño kaṅkhā uppannā, tassa kaṅkhacchedanatthaṃ🔽pañhañca kathessāmi, idhāgamanatthāya paṭiññañca gaṇhissāmī”ti. Tasmā gantvā sammukhe
analyzed: sammukhe pātuḥ ahosi iti evam kirassa ahosi rañño kaṅkhā uppannā tassa kaṅkha chedana attham  pañham ca kathessāmi idha āgamana tthāya paṭiññañca gaṇhissāmi iti tasmai gantvā sammukhe
translated: appeared in the presence of King Koravya.” For he thought thus: “Doubt has arisen in the king’s mind. I will🔽ask him a question to remove his doubt🔽and get him to promise to come here. ” Therefore he appeared before him. When the king saw the previously unseen form, he was frightened and his hair stood on end. Then Sakka said to him:

original: pāturahosi. Rājā adiṭṭhapubbaṃ rūpaṃ disvā bhīto ahosi lomahaṭṭhajāto. Atha naṃ sakko
analyzed: pātuḥ ahosi rājā a diṭṭha pubbam rūpam disvā bhītaḥ ahosi loma haṭṭha jātaḥ atha nam sakko
translated: “Do not be afraid, great king!”

original: – “mā bhāyi, mahārāja, vissattho pañhaṃ puccha, kaṅkhaṃ te paṭivinodessāmī”ti āha.
analyzed: mā bhāyi mahā rāja vissatthaḥ pañham puccha kaṅkham te paṭivinodessāmi iti āha
translated: “Do not be afraid, great king. Be confident. Ask your question. I will remove your doubts.”

original: Rājā –
analyzed: rājā
translated: The king asked:

original: “Pucchāmi taṃ mahārāja, sabbabhūtānamissara;
analyzed: pucchāmi tam mahā rāja sabba bhūta anamissara
translated: “I ask you, great king, lord of all beings,

original: Dānaṃ vā brahmacariyaṃ vā, katamaṃ su mahapphala”nti. –
analyzed: dānam vā brahmacariyam vā katamat su mahapphalanti
translated: Which is more fruitful, giving or celibacy?”

original: Pañhaṃ pucchi. Sakko – “dānaṃ nāma kiṃ, sīlameva guṇavisiṭṭhatāya mahantaṃ. Ahañhi🔽pubbe, mahārāja, dasavassasahassāni dasannaṃ jaṭilasahassānaṃ dānaṃ datvā pettivisayato
analyzed: pañham pucchi sakkaḥ                    pubbe mahā rāja dasa vassa sahassāni dasannam jaṭila sahassānam dānam da tvā petti visayataḥ
translated: He asked his question. Sakka said: “What is giving? Morality is the most important thing because of its excellence.

original: na mutto, sīlavantā pana mayhaṃ dānaṃ bhuñjitvā brahmaloke nibbattā”ti vatvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: na muttaḥ sīlavantā pana mayham dānam bhuñjitvā brahma loke nibbattā ati vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: Formerly, great king, for ten thousand years I gave gifts to ten thousand ascetics, but I was not released from the realm of ghosts. But those who were moral ate my gifts and were reborn in the Brahma-world.” Then he spoke these verses:

original: “Hīnena brahmacariyena, khattiye upapajjati;
analyzed: hīnena brahmacariyena khattiye upapajjati
translated: “By a lowly holy life, one is reborn a noble;

original: Majjhimena ca devattaṃ, uttamena visujjhati.
analyzed: majjhimena ca devattam uttamena visujjhati
translated: By a middling one, a god; by the highest, one is purified.

original: Na hete sulabhā kāyā, yācayogena kenaci;
analyzed: na ha ite sulabhā kāyāḥ yāca yogena kenacid
translated: These bodies are not easily obtained by anyone through begging;

original: Ye kāye upapajjanti, anāgārā tapassino”ti. ;
analyzed: ye kāye upapajjanti anāgārā tapassino ti
translated: Those who are reborn in bodies are homeless ascetics.”

original: Evaṃ rañño kaṅkhaṃ vinodetvā devalokagamanāya paṭiññāgahaṇatthaṃ lābhā te mahārājātiādimāha.
analyzed: evam rañño kaṅkham vinodetvā deva loka gamanāya paṭiññā gahaṇa attham lābhā te mahā rājā ati ādim āha
translated: Having thus removed the king’s doubt, he said, “You have gained, great king,” in order to receive the king’s promise to go to the deva world.

original: Tattha avikampamānoti abhāyamāno. Adhivāsesīti ahaṃ mahājanaṃ kusalaṃ samādapemi,
analyzed: tattha a vikampamānaḥ ti abhāyamānaḥ adhivāsesi iti aham mahājanam kusalam samādapemi
translated: Herein, without trembling means without fear. He consented means he consented, thinking, “I am exhorting the great multitude to what is wholesome,

original: puññavantānaṃ pana vasanaṭṭhānaṃ disvā āgatena manussapathe sukhaṃ kathetuṃ hotīti adhivāsesi.
analyzed: puññavantānam pana vasana ṭṭhānam disvā āgatena manussa pathe sukham kathetum hoti iti adhivāsesi
translated: but when they see the abode of those who have merit, they will come and it will be easy to talk to them on the human path.”

original: 313. Evaṃ bhaddantavāti evaṃ hotu bhaddakaṃ tava vacananti vatvā. Yojetvāti ekasmiṃyeva🔽yuge sahassaassājānīye yojetvā. Tesaṃ pana pāṭiyekkaṃ yojanakiccaṃ natthi, manaṃ
analyzed: evam bhaddantavā ati evam hotu bhaddakam tava vacananti vatvā yojetvā ati ekasmiṃyā iva  yuge sahassaassājānīye yojetvā tesam pana pāṭiyekkam yojana kiccam natthi
translated: So be it, good sir means “So be it, let it be as you say.” He yoked means he yoked them to a single yoke.🔽But they have no separate function of yoking; they are yoked as soon as they are aware of the thought.

original: āgamma yuttāyeva honti. So pana dibbaratho diyaḍḍhayojanasatiko hoti, naddhito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: āgamma yuttāya iva honti so pana dibba rathaḥ diyaḍḍha yojana satikaḥ hoti naddhitaḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: But that divine chariot is two and a half leagues long. From the pole

original: rathasīsaṃ paññāsayojanāni, akkhabandho paṇṇāsayojanāni, akkhabandhato paṭṭhāya pacchābhāgo
analyzed: ratha sīsam paññāsa yojanāni akkhabandho paṇṇāsa yojanāni akkhabandhataḥ paṭṭhāya pacchābhāgaḥ
translated: the chariot-pole is fifty leagues long, and from the axle-joint the rear part is fifty leagues long.

original: paṇṇāsayojanāni, sabbo sattavaṇṇaratanamayo. Devaloko nāma uddhaṃ, manussaloko adho,
analyzed: paṇṇāsa yojanāni sabbaḥ satta vaṇṇa ratana mayaḥ devalokaḥ nāma uddham manussa lokaḥ adhas
translated: and fifty leagues in height, and all of it is made of the seven precious substances. The world of the gods is above, the world of men is below,

original: tasmā heṭṭhāmukhaṃ rathaṃ pesesīti na sallakkhetabbaṃ. Yathā pana pakatimaggaṃ peseti,
analyzed: tasmā heṭṭhā mukham ratham pesesi iti na sallakkhetabbam yathā pana pakati maggam peseti
translated: so it should not be supposed that he sent the chariot facing downwards. But just as he sent it along the normal path,

original: evameva manussānaṃ sāyamāsabhatte niṭṭhite candena saddhiṃ yuganaddhaṃ katvā pesesi,
analyzed: evam eva manussānam sāya māsa bhatte niṭṭhite candena saddhim yuga naddham katvā pesesi
translated: so too he sent it along with the moon as a companion to the men when their evening meal was finished,🔽and they were like twin moons risen in the sky. When the people saw them, they said, “Twin moons have risen.”

original: yamakacandā uṭṭhitā viya ahesuṃ. Mahājano disvā “yamakacandā uggatā”ti āha. Āgacchante
analyzed: yamaka candāḥ uṭṭhitāḥ viya ahesum mahā janaḥ disvā yamaka candā uggatā iti āha āgacchante
translated: As they came,

original: āgacchante na yamakacandā, ekaṃ vimānaṃ, na vimānaṃ, eko rathoti. Rathopi āgacchanto
analyzed: āgacchante na yamakacandāḥ ekam vimānam na vimānam ekaḥ āgacchantaḥ
translated: they were not twin moons, nor a palace, nor a chariot. The chariot came

original: āgacchanto pakatirathappamāṇova, assāpi pakatiassappamāṇāva ahesuṃ. Evaṃ rathaṃ āharitvā🔽rañño pāsādaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pācīnasīhapañjaraṭṭhāne rathaṃ nivattetvā āgatamaggābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ pakati ratha ppamāṇā uva assā api pakati assa ppamāṇā ava ahesuṃ evam ratham āharitvā  raññaḥ pāsādam padakkhiṇam katvā pācīna sīha pañjara ṭṭhāne ratham nivattetvā āgata magga abhimukham
translated: and came, and it was the normal size of a chariot, and the horses were the normal size of horses. So after bringing the chariot,🔽he turned it round to the right of the king’s palace and stopped it facing the way it had come in the eastern lion seat.

original: katvā sīhapañjare ṭhatvāva ārohanasajjaṃ ṭhapesi.
analyzed: katvā sīhapañjare ārohana sajjam ṭhapesi
translated: and he had it made ready for the king to mount while he himself stood in the lion seat.

original: Abhiruha mahārājāti rājā – “dibbayānaṃ me laddha”nti na tāvadeva abhiruhi, nāgarānaṃ
analyzed: abhiruha mahā rāja ati rājā dibba yānam me na tāvat eva abhiruhi nāga rānam
translated: “Ascend, great king,” the king, thinking, “I have obtained a divine vehicle,” did not ascend it at once, but gave advice to the nāgas:

original: pana ovādaṃ adāsi “passatha tātā, yaṃ me sakkena devaraññā dibbaratho pesito, so
analyzed: pana ovādam adāsi passatha tātā yam me sakkena deva raññā dibba rathaḥ pesitaḥ so
translated: “Look, dear friends, at the divine chariot sent to me by Sakka, king of the gods.

original: ca kho na jātigottaṃ vā kulappadesaṃ vā paṭicca pesito, mayhaṃ pana sīlācāraguṇe
analyzed: ca kho na jāti gottam vā kula ppadesam vā paṭicca pesitaḥ mayham pana sīla ācāra guṇe
translated: And that was not sent because of my birth, family, clan, or country, but it was sent because of my virtue, conduct, and good qualities.

original: pasīditvā pesito. Sace tumhepi sīlaṃ rakkhissatha, tumhākampi pesessati, evaṃ rakkhituṃ
analyzed: pasīditvā pesitaḥ sace tumhe api sīlam rakkhissatha tumhākam pi pesessati evam rakkhitum
translated: If you also keep the precepts, he will send to you also. It is not proper to keep the precepts in such a way.

original: yuttaṃ nāmetaṃ sīlaṃ. Nāhaṃ devalokaṃ gantvā cirāyissāmi, appamattā hothā”ti mahājanaṃ🔽ovaditvā pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā rathaṃ abhiruhi. Tato mātali saṅgāhako “ahampi
analyzed: yuttam nāma etam sīlam na aham deva lokam gantvā cirāyissāmi appamattāḥ hotha ati mahājanam  ovaditvā pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhāpetvā ratham abhiruhi tatas mātali saṅgāhakaḥ aham pi
translated: I will not stay long after going to the world of the gods. Be heedful.”

original: mahārājassa mamānucchavikaṃ karissāmī”ti ākāsamhi dve magge dassetvā apica mahārājātiādimāha.
analyzed: mahā rājassa mama ānucchavikam karissāmi iti ākāsamhi dve magge dassetvā apica mahā rāja ati ādim āha
translated: After advising the great multitude in this way and establishing them in the five precepts, he ascended the chariot. Then the charioteer Mātali, thinking, “I will do what is fitting for the great king,” showed two paths in the sky and said this beginning with “But, great king.”

original: Tattha katamenāti, mahārāja, imesu maggesu eko nirayaṃ gacchati, eko devalokaṃ, tesu
analyzed: tattha katamena ati mahā rāja imesu maggesu ekaḥ nirayam gacchati ekaḥ deva lokam tesu
translated: Here, “Which?” means, “Great king, of these two paths, one goes to hell, the other to the world of the gods. Which will you take?”

original: taṃ katamena nemi. Yenāti yena maggena gantvā yattha pāpakammantā pāpakānaṃ kammānaṃ
analyzed: tam katamena nemi yena ati yena maggena gantvā yattha pāpa kammantā pāpakānam kammānam

original: vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvediyanti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ sakkā hoti passitunti attho. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Jātakepi –
analyzed: vipākam paṭisaṃvediyanti tam ṭhānam sakkā hoti passitunti attho dutiya pade pi esā eva nayaḥ jātake pi
translated: By which way, charioteer? By which way, charioteer, going, where can one see the place where evil deeds are done and the result of evil deeds is experienced? analyzed: kena tam nemi maggena rāja seṭṭha disampati

original: Gāthāya ayamevattho. Tenevāha –

analyzed: deva lokam pi iti paṭhamam katamena nemi iti paṭhamam niraya maggena nehi iti tatas mātali

translated: “Mātali showed the king the river Duggaṃvetaraṇi,

analyzed: kuthitam khāra saṃyuttam tattam

analyzed: āmāyadāsī ahu brāhmaṇassa

analyzed: sā patta kāle atithim viditvā

original: Sā vimānasmi modatī”ti. –

original: Jātake vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: jātake vutta nayena iva veditabbā

original: Evaṃ gacchato pana tassa rathanemi vaṭṭiyā cittakūṭadvārakoṭṭhakassa ummāre pahatamatteva

original: paccuggamanamakāsi, taṃ devatānaṃ ādaraṃ disvā sakko cittaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkonto
analyzed: paccuggamanam akāsi tam devatānam ādaram disvā sakko cittam sandhāretum a sakkonto
translated: and was about to go out to meet them. Sakka, seeing the honour paid to the deities, was unable to restrain his thoughts,

original: – “abhirama, mahārāja, devesu devānubhāvenā”ti āha. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “ayaṃ rājā
analyzed: abhirama mahā rāja devesu deva anubhāvena ati āha evam ayam rājā
translated: and said, “Be pleased, great king, with the deities and their power.” Thus he thought: “This king

original: ajja āgantvā ekadivaseneva devagaṇaṃ attano abhimukhamakāsi. Sace ekaṃ dve divase🔽vasissati, na maṃ devā olokessantī”ti. So usūyamāno, “mahārāja, tuyhaṃ imasmiṃ devaloke
analyzed: ajja āgantvā eka divasena iva deva gaṇam abhimukham akāsi sace ekam dve divase  vasissati na mamam devāḥ olokessanti iti saḥ usūyamānaḥ mahā rāja tuyham imasmin deva loke
translated: has come today and in one day has turned the multitude of deities to face him. If he stays

analyzed: vasitum puññam natthi aññesam puññena vasāhi iti iminā adhippāyena evam āha bodhisatto
translated: one or two days more, the deities will not look at me.” Being jealous, he said with this intention, “Great king, you have no merit to live in this heavenly world; live by the merit of others.” The Bodhisatta,

analyzed: na asakkhi jarasakkaḥ manam sandhāretum param nissāya laddham kho pana yācitvā laddha bhaṇḍakam
translated: thinking, “Jarasakka was unable to restrain his thoughts; what is obtained by depending on another is like goods obtained by begging,”

analyzed: yathā yācitakam yānam yathā yācitakam dhanam
translated: “As a vehicle obtained by begging, as wealth obtained by begging,

analyzed: tam yam paratas dāna paccayā
translated: So is this prosperity of yours, which is due to the gift of another;

analyzed: na ca aham etam icchāmi yam paratas dāna paccayā ati
translated: I do not desire that, which is dependent on giving to others.”

original: Sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ. Bodhisatto pana manussattabhāvena kativāre devalokaṃ gatoti. Cattāro
analyzed: sabbam vattabbam bodhisatto pana manussatta bhāvena kati vāre deva lokam gataḥ iti cattāro
translated: All this should be told. But how many times did the Bodhisatta go to the world of the gods in the form of a human being? Four times.

original: – mandhāturājakāle sādhinarājakāle guttilavīṇāvādakakāle nimimahārājakāleti. So mandhātukāle
analyzed: mandhātu rāja kāle sādhina rāja kāle guttila vīṇā vādaka kāle nimi mahārāja kāla iti saḥ mandhātu kāle
translated: In the time of King Mandhatu, in the time of King Sādhin, in the time of the lute-player Guti, and in the time of King Nimi. He lived in the world of the gods for an incalculable time in the time of Mandhatu.

original: devaloke asaṅkhyeyyaṃ kālaṃ vasi, tasmiñhi vasamāneyeva chattiṃsa sakkā caviṃsu.🔽Sādhinarājakāle sattāhaṃ vasi, manussagaṇanāya satta vassasatāni honti. Guttilavīṇāvādakakāle
analyzed: deva loke asaṅkhyeyyam kālam vasi tasmin hi chattiṃsa sakkā  satta aham manussa gaṇanāya satta vassa satāni honti guttila vīṇā vādaka kāle
translated: For while he was living there, thirty-six generations of Sakkas passed away.🔽In the time of King Sādhin he lived for seven days, which in human reckoning are seven hundred years. In the time of the lute-player Guti

original: ca nimirājakāle ca muhuttamattaṃ vasi, manussagaṇanāya satta divasāni honti.
analyzed: ca nimi rāja kāle ca muhutta mattam manussa gaṇanāya satta divasāni honti
translated: and in the time of King Nimi he lived for only a short time, which in human reckoning are seven days.

original: 314. Tattheva mithilaṃ paṭinesīti paṭinetvā pakatisirigabbheyeva patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: tattha iva mithilam paṭinesi iti paṭinetvā pakatisirigabbheya iva patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: He brought Mithila back to its former place, and placed it in the same place as the palace of the former glory.

original: 315. Kaḷārajanakoti tassa nāmaṃ. Kaḷāradantatāya pana kaḷārajanakoti vutto. Na so agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajīti ettakamattameva na akāsi, sesaṃ sabbaṃ pākatikameva ahosi.🔽316. Samucchedo hotīti ettha kalyāṇavattaṃ ko samucchindati, kena samucchinnaṃ, ko
analyzed: kaḷārajanako ti tassa nāmam kaḷāra danta tāya pana kaḷārajanakaḥ iti vutto na saḥ agārasma anagāriyam pabbajī iti ettaka mattam eva na akāsi sesam sabbam pākatikam eva ahosi  samucchedaḥ hoti iti ettha samucchindati kena samucchinnam
translated: Kaḷārajanaka was his name. But he was called Kaḷārajanaka because he had black teeth. He did not do only this much, namely, not go forth from home into homelessness; the rest was all normal.

original: pavatteti, kena pavattitaṃ nāma hotīti ayaṃ vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha sīlavā bhikkhu
analyzed: pavattā iti kena pavattitam nāma hoti iti ayam vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha sīlavā bhikkhu
translated: As regards the words “is cut off” , the distinction here should be understood as follows: Who cuts off the good conduct? By whom is it cut off? Who sets it going? By whom is it set going?

original: “na sakkā mayā arahattaṃ laddhu”nti vīriyaṃ akaronto samucchindati. Dussīlena samucchinnaṃ
analyzed: na sakkā mayā arahattam laddhunti vīriyam a karontaḥ samucchindati dussīlena samucchinnam
translated: Herein, a virtuous bhikkhu who does not make effort, thinking “I cannot attain Arahantship,” cuts it off.🔽That is called “cut off by one of evil wishes.”🔽Seven kinds of trainers set it going.🔽That is called “set going by one whose taints are destroyed.”

original: nāma hoti. Satta sekhā pavattenti. Khīṇāsavena pavattitaṃ nāma hoti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: nāma hoti satta sekhā pavattenti khīṇāsavena pavattitam nāma hoti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati  papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Maghadevasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: maghadeva sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Maghadeva Sutta in the Majjhima Nikāya is finished.

original: 4. Madhurasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Madhura Sutta

original: 317. Evaṃ me sutanti madhurasuttaṃ. Tattha mahākaccānoti gihikāle ujjenikarañño purohitaputto🔽abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko suvaṇṇavaṇṇo ca. Madhurāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare. Gundāvaneti🔽kaṇhakagundāvane. Avantiputtoti avantiraṭṭhe rañño dhītāya putto. Vuddho ceva arahā🔽cāti daharaṃ arahantampi na tathā sambhāventi yathā mahallakaṃ, thero pana vuddho
analyzed: evam me sutam ti madhura suttam tattha mahākaccāno ti gihi kāle ujjenikarañño purohita putto  abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ pāsādiko suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo ca madhurāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare gundāvanā iti  kaṇhakagundāvane avantiputto ti avanti raṭṭhe raññaḥ dhītāya putto vuddhaḥ ca iva arahā  ca ati daharam arahantam pi na tathā sambhāventi yathā mahallakam theraḥ pana vuddhaḥ
translated: The Madhura Sutta with the words “Thus have I heard.” Herein, Mahā Kaccāna was the son of the brāhman who was the royal chaplain of Ujjenī .🔽He was handsome, good-looking, and fair-skinned, the colour of gold. In Madhurā : in a town of that name. In the Gundā Grove :🔽in the Black-wood Gundā Grove. The son of Avanti : the son of the king’s daughter of the Avanti country. He was both aged and an arahant.🔽They do not honour a young arahant as much as they do an old one. But the elder was both aged and an arahant.

original: ceva ahosi arahā ca. Brāhmaṇā, bho kaccānāti so kira rājā brāhmaṇaladdhiko, tasmā🔽evamāha. Brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇotiādīsu jātigottādīnaṃ paññāpanaṭṭhāne brāhmaṇāva🔽seṭṭhāti dasseti. Hīno añño vaṇṇoti itare tayo vaṇṇā hīnā lāmakāti vadati. Sukkoti🔽paṇḍaro. Kaṇhoti kāḷako. Sujjhantīti jātigottādipaññāpanaṭṭhānesu sujjhanti. Brahmuno
analyzed: ca iva ahosi arahā ca brāhmaṇāḥ bho saḥ kira rājā tasmai 🔽evam āha brāhmaṇa uva seṭṭhaḥ vaṇṇo ti ādīsu jāti gotta ādīnam paññāpana ṭṭhāne brāhmaṇa ava 🔽seṭṭhā ati dasseti hīnaḥ aññaḥ vaṇṇo ti itare tayaḥ vaṇṇāḥ hīnāḥ lāmakā ti vadati sukko ti 🔽paṇḍaro kaṇho ti kāḷako sujjhanti iti jāti gotta ādi paññāpana ṭṭhānesu sujjhanti brahmuno
translated: “Thus have I heard” : the Madhura Sutta. There, Mahā Kaccāna was the son of the royal priest of Ujjeni, who was handsome, good-looking, and fair-skinned. In Madhurā, in the Black Rock Garden. The son of Avanti was the son of the king’s daughter of the Avanti country. He was old and an arahant. They do not respect a young arahant as much as an old one. But the elder was both old and an arahant. The brahmins, sirs, Kaccāna, : it seems that the king was devoted to the brahmins, and so he said thus. In the passages beginning with “Only the brahmin is the best of men,” he shows that in the matter of the determination of caste, family, etc., only the brahmin is the best. “The other castes are low and vile” : he says that the other three castes are low and vile. “The white is the best of colors” : white. “The black is the lowliest” : black. “The brahmins alone are purified” : in the matter of the determination of caste, family, etc., the brahmins alone are purified.

original: puttāti mahābrahmuno puttā. Orasā mukhato jātāti ure vasitvā mukhato nikkhantā, ure🔽katvā saṃvaddhitāti vā orasā. Brahmajāti brahmato nibbattā. Brahmanimmitāti brahmunā
analyzed: puttā ati mahābrahmuno puttāḥ orasāḥ mukhataḥ jātāḥ ati ure vasitvā mukhataḥ nikkhantāḥ ure  katvā saṃvaddhitā ati vai orasā brahma jāti brahmataḥ nibbattā brahma nimmitā ati brahmunā
translated: ‘Sons’: sons of the Great Brahma. ‘Born of the mind, mouth-born, heirs of the mouth’: they were born from the mind, from the mouth, from the breast.

original: nimmitā. Brahmadāyādāti brahmuno dāyādā. Ghosoyeva kho esoti vohāramattamevetaṃ.
analyzed: nimmitāḥ brahma dāyādā ati brahmunaḥ dāyādāḥ kho esā iti vohāra mattam eva etam
translated: ‘Brahma-born’: born from Brahma. ‘Created by Brahma’: created by Brahma. ‘Heirs of Brahma’: heirs of Brahma. ‘This is merely a figure of speech’: this is merely a conventional expression.

original: 318. Ijjheyyāti samijjheyya, yattakāni dhanādīni pattheyya, tattakehissa manoratho
analyzed: ijjheyya ati samijjheyya yattakāni dhana ādīni pattheyya tattakehi issa manorathaḥ
translated: ‘Would succeed’: would be successful. Whatever wealth, etc., he might wish for, his wish would be fulfilled, is the meaning.

original: pūreyyāti attho. Khattiyopissāssāti khattiyopi assa issariyasampattassa pubbuṭṭhāyī
analyzed: pūreyya ati attho khattiya upissa assa ati khattiyaḥ upi assa issariya sampattassa pubbuṭṭhāyī
translated: ‘He would be a lord over the nobles’: he would be a lord over the nobles, a leader in the attainment of lordship.

original: assa. Nesaṃ ettha kiñcīti na etesaṃ ettha kiñci.🔽322. Āsanena vā nimanteyyāmāti nisinnāsanaṃ papphoṭetvā idha nisīdāti vadeyyāma.
analyzed: assa nesam ettha kiñci iti na etesam ettha kiñci  āsanena vā nimanteyyāma ati nisinnāsanam papphoṭetvā idha nisīda iti vadeyyāma
translated: ‘There is nothing here for them’: there is nothing here for them.🔽‘We would invite him to a seat’: we would invite him to a seat by patting a seat, saying, “Sit here.”

original: Abhinimanteyyāmapi nanti abhiharitvā taṃ nimanteyyāma. Tattha duvidho abhihāro vācāya
analyzed: abhinimanteyyām api nanti abhiharitvā tam nimanteyyāma duvidhaḥ abhihāraḥ vācāya
translated: ‘We would invite him to a meal’: we would invite him by bringing it to him. Here there are two kinds of invitation: by speech,

original: ceva kāyena ca. “Tumhākaṃ icchiticchitakkhaṇe mamaṃ cīvarādīhi vadeyyātha yenattho”ti🔽vadanto hi vācāya abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Cīvarādivekallaṃ sallakkhetvā “idaṃ🔽gaṇhathā”ti tāni dento pana kāyena abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Tadubhayampi sandhāya
analyzed: ca iva kāyena ca tumhākam icchiticchita kkhaṇe cīvara ādīhi vadeyyātha yena atthi ti  vadantaḥ hi vācāya abhiharitvā nimantā iti nāma cīvara ādi vekallam sallakkhetvā idam  gaṇhatha ati tāni kāyena abhiharitvā nimantā iti nāma tat ubhayam pi sandhāya
translated: and with the body.🔽For when he says, “You can tell me whenever you want any requisites,” he invites by speech. But when he sees that they are short of requisites and gives them, saying, “Take this,” he invites by body.🔽Both these are included in the words “we will not invite.”

original: “abhinimanteyyāmapi na”nti āha. Rakkhāvaraṇaguttinti rakkhāsaṅkhātañceva āvaraṇasaṅkhātañca🔽guttiṃ. Yā panesā āvudhahatthe purise ṭhapentena rakkhā, sā dhammikā nāma saṃvihitā

translated: and he should know that. ‘How wonderful is the Enlightened One! How wonderful is the Dhamma! analyzed: atha nam yadā mahallaka kāle mātā pitaraḥ tāta kucchi gatam eva tam saraṇam 🔽gaṇhāpayimha ati sārenti saḥ ca sallakkhetvā aham saraṇam gataḥ upāsako iti satim uppādeti 🔽tadā saraṇam gahitam nāma hoti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati 🔽papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: and he should know that. ‘How wonderful is the Enlightened One! How wonderful is the Dhamma! So he said this, praising the Dhamma. ‘Yatra hi nāma’ is an expression of wonder. ‘With child’ means pregnant. ‘This being in my womb, venerable sir’—but how does it come to be that refuge is taken in this way? It does not. There is no such thing as taking refuge without consciousness. But protection is still accorded to him. Then when he is grown up his parents remind him, ‘Dear, we had you taken refuge when you were in the womb,’ and he recollects it and arouses memory, ‘I have taken refuge, I am a lay follower.’ Then it is called ‘taken refuge.’ The rest is clear in all ways. The commentary on the Majjhimanikāya called Papañcasūdanī is finished.

translated: He became a pupil of the Teacher, and he set himself to the study of the Scriptures. Therefore we cannot say of him that he is a man of little wisdom. He is not a man of bad conduct, for his conduct is perfect. Therefore we cannot say of him that he is a man of bad conduct. He is not a man of low birth, for he is of high birth. Therefore we cannot say of him that he is a man of low birth. What shall we do?” Then they said to one of their number, “Let us get the better of him by sowing dissension between him and his teacher.” So they divided themselves into three parties. The first party went to the teacher, saluted him, and stood respectfully on one side. “What is it, dear?” “In this house a certain report is being circulated.” “What is it, dear?” “They say that the student Ahiṃsakāyana thinks that you are a man of bad conduct.”
