analyzed: ārocāpesi tatas te sāṇiyā parikkhipitvā therassa bahi sāṇiyam pīṭhakam paññāpesuṃ
translated: Then they surrounded the woman with a curtain and they had a seat prepared outside the curtain for the Elder.

original: Thero tattha nisīditvā – “yato ahaṃ bhagini sabbaññubuddhassa ariyāya jātiyā jāto”ti
analyzed: theraḥ tattha nisīditvā yatas aham bhagini sabbaññu buddhassa ariyāya jātiyā jātaḥ ti
translated: The Elder sat down there and made a declaration of truth thus: “Since I was born, sister, by the Noble Birth of the Enlightened One,”

original: saccakiriyaṃ akāsi, saha saccavacaneneva dhamakaraṇato muttaudakaṃ viya dārako nikkhami.🔽Mātāputtānaṃ sotthi ahosi. Imañca pana parittaṃ na kiñci parissayaṃ na maddati, mahāparittaṃ
analyzed: sacca kiriyam akāsi saha sacca vacanena iva dhama karaṇataḥ mutta udakam viya dārakaḥ nikkhami  mātā puttānam sotthi ahosi imam ca pana parittam na kiñci parissayam na maddati mahā parittam
translated: and with the words of truth the child came out like water from a pierced bladder.🔽There was safety for mother and child. And this safeguard does not overcome any misfortune,🔽it is called a great safeguard.

original: nāmetanti vuttaṃ. Therena nisīditvā saccakiriyakataṭṭhāne pīṭhakaṃ akaṃsu. Gabbhamūḷhaṃ
analyzed: nāma etat nti vuttam therena nisīditvā sacca kiriya kata ṭṭhāne pīṭhakam akaṃsu gabbha mūḷham
translated: They made a seat at the place where the Elder sat down and made a declaration of truth. The child was born with its head downwards,

original: tiracchānagatitthimpi ānetvā tattha nisajjāpenti, tāvadeva sukhena gabbhavuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tiracchānaga titthim pi ānetvā tattha tāvat eva sukhena gabbha vuṭṭhānam
translated: and they brought animals and birds and made them sit there. Immediately they were delivered easily.

original: hoti. Yā dubbalā hoti na sakkā ānetuṃ, tassā pīṭhakadhovanaudakaṃ netvā sīse siñcanti,
analyzed: hoti yā dubbalā hoti na sakkā ānetum tassāḥ pīṭhaka dhovana odakam netvā sīse siñcanti
translated: If a woman was too weak to be brought there, they brought water for washing the bed and sprinkled it on her head.

original: taṅkhaṇaṃyeva gabbhavuṭṭhānaṃ hoti, aññampi rogaṃ vūpasameti. Yāva kappā tiṭṭhanakapāṭihāriyaṃ kiretaṃ.
analyzed: taṅkhaṇam yeva gabbha vuṭṭhānam hoti aññam pi rogam vūpasameti yāva kappā tiṭṭhanaka pāṭihāriyam kiretaṃ
translated: Immediately she was delivered. It also cured other diseases. It is said that this miracle lasted as long as the aeon.

original: Kiṃ pana bhagavā theraṃ vejjakammaṃ kārāpesīti? Na kārāpesi. Therañhi disvā manussā
analyzed: kim pana bhagavā theram vejja kammam kārāpesi iti na kārāpesi theram hi disvā manussā
translated: But did the Blessed One make the Elder perform a medical treatment? He did not. For when people saw the Elder,

original: bhītā palāyanti. Thero bhikkhāhārena kilamati, samaṇadhammaṃ kātuṃ na sakkoti. Tassa
analyzed: bhītā palāyanti theraḥ bhikkhāhārena kilamati samaṇa dhammam kātum na sakkoti tassa
translated: they were frightened and ran away. The Elder was exhausted by his alms round and was unable to do his ascetic duties.

original: anuggahena saccakiriyaṃ kāresi. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “idāni kira aṅgulimālatthero
analyzed: anuggahena sacca kiriyam kāresi evam kirassa ahosi idāni kira aṅgulimāla tthero
translated: So he performed a miracle of truth for his benefit. It seems that he thought, “Now, it seems, the Elder Aṅgulimāla

original: mettacittaṃ paṭilabhitvā saccakiriyāya manussānaṃ sotthibhāvaṃ karotīti manussā theraṃ
analyzed: metta cittam paṭilabhitvā sacca kiriyāya manussānam sotthi bhāvam karoti iti manussā theram
translated: has attained loving-kindness and is bringing welfare to people by a miracle of truth.” People saw the Elder

original: upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññissanti, tato bhikkhāhārena akilamanto samaṇadhammaṃ kātuṃ sakkhissatī”ti
analyzed: upasaṅkamitabbam maññissanti tatas bhikkhāhārena a kilamantaḥ samaṇa dhammam kātum sakkhissati iti
translated: “They will come to him, and then, not being tired with begging for alms, he will be able to practice the ascetic practices.”

original: anuggahena saccakiriyaṃ kāresi. Na hi saccakiriyā vejjakammaṃ hoti. Therassāpi ca
analyzed: anuggahena saccakiriyam kāresi na hi saccakiriyā vejja kammam hoti therassa api ca
translated: He performed the miracle of truth by way of assistance. For the performance of a miracle of truth is not a medical treatment.

original: “samaṇadhammaṃ karissāmī”ti mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhāne nisinnassa
analyzed: samaṇa dhammam karissāmi iti mūlakammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa
translated: The elder thought, “I will practice the ascetic practices.” He took up a meditation subject based on the roots, and while sitting in the first and last watches of the night,

original: cittaṃ kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ na gacchati, aṭaviyaṃ ṭhatvā manussānaṃ ghātitaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: cittam kammaṭṭhāna abhimukham na gacchati aṭaviyam ṭhatvā manussānam ghātita ṭṭhānam eva
translated: his mind did not enter into concentration. Only the killing of human beings in the forest was clear to him.

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti. “Duggatomhi, khuddakaputtomhi, jīvitaṃ me dehi sāmīti maraṇabhītānaṃ🔽vacanākāro ca hatthapādavikāro ca āpāthaṃ āgacchati, so vippaṭisārī hutvā tatova
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti duggataḥ asmi khuddaka puttaḥ asmi jīvitam me dehi sāmi iti maraṇa bhītānam  vacana ākāro ca hattha pāda vikāro ca āpātham āgacchati saḥ vippaṭisārī hutvā tatas va
translated: The words and the gestures of those who were afraid of death and said, “I am lost, I am a small man, give me my life, master,”🔽came to his ears. He became remorseful and left the place.

original: uṭṭhāya gacchati, athassa bhagavā taṃ jātiṃ abbohārikaṃ katvāvāyaṃ vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: uṭṭhāya gacchati atha assa bhagavā tam jātim abbohārikam katvā avāyam vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: Then the Blessed One, having made that birth non-existent,🔽developed insight and attained nibbāna.

original: arahattaṃ gaṇhissatīti ariyāya jātiyā saccakiriyaṃ kāresi. Eko vūpakaṭṭhotiādi vatthasutte vitthāritaṃ.
analyzed: arahattam gaṇhissati iti ariyāya jātiyā saccakiriyam kāresi ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ tiādi vattha sutte vitthāritam
translated: “He will attain Arahantship” he performed the Truth-Utterance in the Noble Lineage. “Alone, secluded, aloof” and so on is given in detail in the Thread of the Cloth.

original: 352. Aññenapi leḍḍu khittoti kākasunakhasūkarādīnaṃ paṭikkamāpanatthāya samantā sarakkhepamatte
analyzed: aññena api leḍḍu khittaḥ iti kāka sunakha sūkara ādīnam paṭikkamāpana tthāya samantā sara khepa matte
translated: “Thrown by another” : in order to ward off crows, dogs, pigs, etc., a stone is thrown all around in the place where the alms food is to be put.

original: ṭhāne yena kenaci disābhāgena khitto āgantvā therasseva kāye patati. Kittake ṭhāne🔽evaṃ hoti? Gaṇṭhikaṃ paṭimuñcitvā piṇḍāya caritvā paṭinivattetvā yāva gaṇṭhikapaṭimukkaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhāne yena kenacid disā bhāgena khittaḥ āgantvā therassa iva kāye patati kittake ṭhāne  evam hoti gaṇṭhikam paṭimuñcitvā piṇḍāya caritvā paṭinivattetvā yāva gaṇṭhika paṭimukka ṭṭhānam
translated: It comes and falls on the Elder’s body from whatever direction it happens to have been thrown.🔽How far does it extend? It extends as far as the place where the Elder, having put on his waistband, gone for alms, and returned, sits down to take off his waistband.

original: āgacchati, tāva hoti. Bhinnena sīsenāti mahācammaṃ chinditvā yāva aṭṭhimariyādā bhinnena.
analyzed: āgacchati tāva hoti bhinnena sīsena ati mahā cammam chinditvā yāva aṭṭhi mariyādā bhinnena
translated: “With a split head” : having split the hide, as far as the bone.

original: Brāhmaṇāti khīṇāsavabhāvaṃ sandhāya āha. Yassa kho tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, kammassa vipākenāti
analyzed: brāhmaṇa iti khīṇāsava bhāvam sandhāya āha yassa kho tvam brāhmaṇa kammassa vipākena ati
translated: “Brahmin” : he said this referring to his being one whose cankers are destroyed. “Brahmin, for the ripening of what action”

original: idaṃ sabhāgadiṭṭhadhammavedanīyakammaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Kammañhi kariyamānameva tayo
analyzed: idam sabhāga diṭṭha dhamma vedanīya kammam sandhāya vuttam kamman hi kariyamānam eva tayo
translated: he said this referring to the action that has a like-fruit and is due to be experienced here and now. For when an action is being done, it has three fruits:

original: koṭṭhāse pūreti. Sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhamajavanacetanā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyakammaṃ🔽nāma hoti. Taṃ imasmiṃyeva attabhāve vipākaṃ deti. Tathā asakkontaṃ ahosikammaṃ,
analyzed: koṭṭhāse pūreti sattasu cittesu kusalā vā akusalā vā paṭhama javana cetanā diṭṭhadhamma vedanīya kammaṃ  nāma hoti tam imasmin yeva atta bhāve vipākam deti tathā a sakkontam a hosi kammam
translated: In the seven consciousnesses, whether profitable or unprofitable, the volition of the first impulsion is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽It gives its ripening in this very existence. If it cannot do so, then it is kamma to be experienced in some future existence.

original: nāhosi kammavipāko, na bhavissati kammavipāko, natthi kammavipākoti imassa tikassa
analyzed: na ahosi kamma vipākaḥ na bhavissati kamma vipāko natthi kamma vipāko imassa tikassa
translated: And that is called kamma that is not to be experienced, according to the three-fold method stated thus: “There was no kamma, there was no ripening of kamma, there will be no kamma, there will be no ripening of kamma, there is no kamma, there is no ripening of kamma” .

original: vasena ahosikammaṃ nāma hoti. Atthasādhikā sattamajavanacetanā upapajjavedanīyakammaṃ
analyzed: vasena ahosikammam nāma hoti attha sādhikā sattama javana cetanā upapajja vedanīya kammaṃ
translated: The seventh impulsion volition is kamma to be experienced after rebirth.

original: nāma. Taṃ anantare attabhāve vipākaṃ deti. Tathā asakkontaṃ vuttanayeneva taṃ ahosikammaṃ
analyzed: nāma tam anantare atta bhāve vipākam deti tathā a sakkontam vutta nayena iva tam ahosi kammam
translated: It gives its ripening in the next existence. If it cannot do so, then it is kamma that is not to be experienced, according to the method stated.

original: nāma hoti. Ubhinnamantare pañcajavanacetanā aparāpariyavedanīyakammaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: nāma hoti ubhinnam antare pañca javana cetanāḥ apara apariya vedanīya kammam nāma hoti
translated: The five impulsion volitions in between are kamma to be experienced in some subsequent existence.

original: Taṃ anāgate yadā okāsaṃ labhati, tadā vipākaṃ deti. Sati saṃsārappavattiyā ahosikammaṃ
analyzed: tam anāgate yadā okāsam labhati tadā vipākam deti sati saṃsāra ppavattiyā ahosi kammam
translated: It gives its ripening when it finds an opportunity in the future. But if there is no more becoming, then it is not kamma that is not to be experienced.

original: nāma na hoti. Therassa pana upapajjavedanīyañca aparāpariyavedanīyañcāti imāni dve
analyzed: nāma na hoti therassa pana upapajja vedanīyan ca apara apariya vedanīyan ca ati imāni dve
translated: But the elder’s kamma was of two kinds, namely, kamma to be experienced after rebirth and kamma to be experienced in some subsequent existence.

original: kammāni kammakkhayakarena arahattamaggena samugghāṭitāni, diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ atthi.
analyzed: kammāni kamma khaya karena arahatta maggena samugghāṭitāni diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyam atthi
translated: and the kamma and its result are both destroyed by the Arahant path.🔽But the kamma that is to be experienced here and now gives its result even to one who has reached Arahantship.

original: Taṃ arahattappattassāpi vipākaṃ detiyeva. Taṃ sandhāya bhagavā “yassa kho tva”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: tam arahatta pattassa api vipākam tam sandhāya bhagavā yassa kho tvanti ādim āha
translated: With reference to this the Blessed One said: “Whatsoever, brahmin, is the result of kamma ….”

original: Tasmā yassa khoti ettha yādisassa kho tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, kammassa vipākenāti evaṃ attho veditabbo.🔽Abbhā muttoti desanāsīsamattametaṃ, abbhā mahikā dhūmo rajo rāhūti imehi pana upakkilesehi
analyzed: tasmā yassa kho ti ettha yādisassa kho tvam brāhmaṇa kammassa vipākena ati evam atthaḥ veditabbo  abbhā mutto ti abbhā mahikā dhūmaḥ rajaḥ rāhu iti imehi pana upakkilesehi
translated: So the meaning here should be understood to be this: “Whatsoever, brahmin, is the result of kamma of yours that is to be experienced here and now.”🔽“Freed from the sky” : this is merely the climax of the teaching. But what is meant here is the moon freed from the obscurations of mist, haze, dust, smoke, and Rāhu.

original: mutto candimā idha adhippeto. Yathā hi evaṃ nirupakkileso candimā lokaṃ pabhāseti,
analyzed: muttaḥ candimā idha adhippetaḥ yathā hi evam nirupakkilesaḥ candimā lokam pabhāseti
translated: For just as the moon, when freed from these obscurations, illuminates the world,

original: evaṃ pamādakilesavimutto appamatto bhikkhu imaṃ attano khandhāyatanadhātulokaṃ pabhāseti,
analyzed: evam pamāda kilesa vimuttaḥ appamattaḥ bhikkhu imam attanaḥ khandha āyatana dhātu lokam pabhāseti
translated: so too the diligent bhikkhu, when freed from the obscuration of negligence, illuminates his own continuity of aggregates, sense bases, and elements,

original: vihatakilesandhakāraṃ karoti.
analyzed: vihata kilesandhakāram karoti
translated: and he dispels the darkness of defilements.

original: Kusalena pidhīyatīti maggakusalena pidhīyati appaṭisandhikaṃ karīyati. Yuñjati buddhasāsaneti
analyzed: kusalena pidhīyati iti magga kusalena pidhīyati appaṭisandhikam yuñjati buddha sāsanā iti
translated: “By the wholesome it is checked”: it is checked by the wholesome of the path; it is made to give no result in rebirth. “He applies himself to the Dispensation of the Buddha”:

original: buddhasāsane kāyena vācāya manasā ca yuttappayutto viharati. Imā tisso therassa udānagāthā nāma.
analyzed: buddha sāsane kāyena vācāya manasā ca yutta ppayuttaḥ viharati imā tissaḥ therassa udānagāthā nāma
translated: he lives devoted to the Buddha’s Dispensation in deed, word, and thought. These are the three verses of the Elder’s spontaneous utterance.

original: Disā hi meti idaṃ kira thero attano parittāṇākāraṃ karonto āha. Tattha disā hi meti
analyzed: disā hi mā iti idam kira theraḥ attano parittāṇa ākāram karontaḥ āha tattha disā hi mā iti
translated: Disā hi me, etc., is what the Elder said, it seems, as he made a protection-device for himself. Herein, disā hi me means

original: mama sapattā. Ye maṃ evaṃ upavadanti – “yathā mayaṃ aṅgulimālena māritānaṃ ñātakānaṃ
analyzed: mama sa pattāḥ ye mam evam upavadanti yathā mayam aṅguli mālena māritānam ñātakānam
translated: my adversaries. Those who revile me thus: “Just as we experience pain through the murder of our relatives

original: vasena dukkhaṃ vediyāma, evaṃ aṅgulimālopi vediyatū”ti, te mayhaṃ disā catusaccadhammakathaṃ
analyzed: vasena dukkham vediyāma evam te mayham disā catu sacca dhamma katham
translated: by Aṅgulimāla, so may Aṅgulimāla experience pain,” let them listen to the four noble truths

original: suṇantūti attho. Yuñjantūti kāyavācāmanehi yuttappayuttā viharantu. Ye dhammamevādapayanti
analyzed: suṇantu iti atthaḥ yuñjantu iti kāya vācā manehi yutta ppayuttāḥ viharantu ye dhammam eva ādapayanti
translated: in the directions, is the meaning. Yuñjantū means let them live devoted to deed, word, and thought. Ye dhammamevādapayanti

original: santoti ye santo sappurisā dhammaṃyeva ādapenti samādapenti gaṇhāpenti, te manujā
analyzed: santo iti ye santo sappurisāḥ dhammaṃyā iva ādapenti samādapenti gaṇhāpenti te manujā
translated: santo means those who are good people, who advise only the Dhamma, who encourage only the Dhamma, who cause to take up only the Dhamma, those people

original: mayhaṃ sapattā bhajantu sevantu payirupāsantūti attho.
analyzed: mayham sapattāḥ bhajantu sevantu payirupāsantu iti atthaḥ
translated: are my adversaries. Let them associate with me, let them serve me, let them attend on me, is the meaning.

original: Avirodhappasaṃsīnanti avirodho vuccati mettā, mettāpasaṃsakānanti attho. Suṇantu
analyzed: avirodha ppasaṃsīnam avirodhaḥ vuccati mettā mettā apasaṃsakānam ti atthaḥ suṇantu
translated: Avirodhappasaṃsīn means let them be associated with non-opposition. Non-opposition is called loving-kindness. Let them be associated with loving-kindness, is the meaning. Suṇantu

original: dhammaṃ kālenāti khaṇe khaṇe khantimettāpaṭisaṅkhāsāraṇīyadhammaṃ suṇantu. Tañca
analyzed: dhammam kālena ati khaṇe khaṇe khanti mettā paṭisaṅkhā sāraṇīya dhammam suṇantu tat ca
translated: Dhammaṃ kālenāti let them listen to the Dhamma of patience, loving-kindness, and sympathetic joy, moment after moment. Tañca

original: anuvidhīyantūti tañca dhammaṃ anukarontu pūrentu.
analyzed: anuvidhīyantu uti tam ca dhammam anukarontu pūrentu
translated: anuvidhīyantūti let them follow that Dhamma, let them fulfill it.

original: Na hi jātu so mamaṃ hiṃseti yo mayhaṃ diso, so maṃ ekaṃseneva na hiṃseyya. Aññaṃ
analyzed: na hi jātu saḥ mamam hiṃseti yaḥ mayham disaḥ saḥ mamam ekaṃsena iva na hiṃseyya aññam
translated: Na hi jātu so mamaṃ hiṃseti yo mayhaṃ diso, so maṃ ekaṃseneva na hiṃseyya. Aññaṃ

original: vā pana kiñci nanti na kevalaṃ maṃ, aññampi pana kañci puggalaṃ mā hiṃsantu mā viheṭhentu.
analyzed: vā pana kiñci nanti na kevalam mam aññam pi pana kañci puggalam mā hiṃsantu mā viheṭhentu
translated: vā pana kiñci nanti not only me, but let them not harm or injure any person.

original: Pappuyya paramaṃ santinti paramaṃ santibhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ pāpuṇitvā. Rakkheyya tasathāvareti
analyzed: pappuyya paramam santinti paramam santi bhūtam nibbānam pāpuṇitvā rakkheyya tasa thāvarā iti
translated: Pappuyya paramaṃ santinti having attained the supreme peace, Nibbāna. Rakkheyya tasathāvareti

original: tasā vuccanti sataṇhā, thāvarā nittaṇhā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yo nibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: tasāḥ vuccanti sa taṇhāḥ thāvarāḥ nittaṇhāḥ idam vuttam hoti yaḥ nibbānam pāpuṇāti
translated: tasā are called those with craving, thāvarā those without craving. This is what is meant: he who attains Nibbāna,

original: so sabbaṃ tasathāvaraṃ rakkhituṃ samattho hoti. Tasmā mayhampi disā nibbānaṃ pāpuṇantu,
analyzed: so sabbam tasa thāvaram rakkhitum samatthaḥ hoti tasmā mayham pi disā nibbānam pāpuṇantu
translated: he is able to protect all those with craving and those without craving. Therefore let my disciples attain Nibbāna,

original: evaṃ maṃ ekaṃseneva na hiṃsissantīti. Imā tisso gāthā attano parittaṃ kātuṃ āha.
analyzed: evam mama ekaṃsena iva na hiṃsissanti iti imāḥ tissaḥ gāthāḥ attanaḥ parittam kātum āha
translated: in this way they will not harm me in any way. These three verses he spoke in order to make his own protection.

original: Idāni attanova paṭipattiṃ dīpento udakañhi nayanti nettikāti āha. Tattha nettikāti
analyzed: idāni attanā iva paṭipattim dīpentaḥ udakam hi nayanti nettikā iti āha tattha nettikā iti
translated: Now, showing his own practice, he said, “They lead water by means of an aqueduct,” etc. Herein, an aqueduct is

original: ye mātikaṃ sodhetvā bandhitabbaṭṭhāne bandhitvā udakaṃ nayanti. Usukārāti usukārakā.🔽Namayantīti telakañjikena makkhetvā kukkuḷe tāpetvā unnatunnataṭṭhāne namentā ujuṃ
analyzed: ye mātikam sodhetvā bandhitabba ṭṭhāne bandhitvā udakam nayanti usukārā ati usukārakā  namayanti iti tela kañjikena makkhetvā kukkuḷe tāpetvā unnata unnata ṭṭhāne namentā ujum
translated: what they make by binding together bamboo or wood or creepers and so on, and then leading it into the water, and they lead the water by means of that. A charcoal-burner is one who burns charcoal.

original: karonti. Tejananti kaṇḍaṃ. Tañhi issāso tejaṃ karoti, parañca tajjeti, tasmā tejananti🔽vuccati. Attānaṃ damayantīti yathā nettikā ujumaggena udakaṃ nayanti, usukārā tejanaṃ,
analyzed: karonti tejananti kaṇḍam tat hi issāsaḥ tejam karoti param ca tajjeti tasmā tejananti  vuccati attānam damayantī iti yathā nettikāḥ uju maggena udakam nayanti usukārā tejanam
translated: They bend it: after smearing it with a mixture of salt and water, they heat it in a charcoal pit and bend it at the uneven places, making it straight. A splinter is a piece of wood. For that is a splinter of fire since it makes fire and it splinters another, thus it is called a splinter .

original: tacchakā ca dāruṃ ujuṃ karonti, evamevaṃ paṇḍitā attānaṃ damenti ujukaṃ karonti nibbisevanaṃ karonti.🔽Tādināti iṭṭhāniṭṭhādīsu nibbikārena – “pañcahākārehi bhagavā tādī, iṭṭhāniṭṭhe tādī,
analyzed: tat śakā ca dārum ujum karonti evam evam paṇḍitāḥ attānam damenti ujukam karonti nibbisevanam karonti 🔽tādinā ati iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādīsu nibbikārena pañcahā ākārehi bhagavā tādī iṭṭha aniṭṭhe tādī
translated: They tame themselves: just as the aqueduct leads the water by a straight course, and the charcoal-burner and the wood-turner make the splinter and the wood straight, so the wise tame themselves, make themselves straight, make themselves free from defilement.

original: vantāvīti tādī, cattāvīti tādī, tiṇṇāvīti tādī, tanniddesāti tādī”ti evaṃ tādilakkhaṇappattena🔽satthārā. Bhavanettīti bhavarajju, taṇhāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tāya hi goṇā viya gīvāya rajjuyā,
analyzed: vantāvī iti tādī cattāvī iti tādī tiṇṇāvī iti tādī tad niddesā ati tādī iti evam tādi lakkhaṇa ppattena  satthārā bhavanettīti bhavarajju nāmam tāya hi goṇā rajjuyā
translated: “He has crossed over doubt, he has gone beyond doubt, he has closed off the path to doubt,” and so on.🔽The Blessed One, who had attained the characteristics of a Tathāgata,

original: sattā hadaye baddhā taṃ taṃ bhavaṃ nīyanti, tasmā bhavanettīti vuccati. Phuṭṭho kammavipākenāti
analyzed: sattā hadaye baddhā tam tam bhavam nīyanti tasmai bhavanettī iti vuccati phuṭṭhaḥ kamma vipākena ati
translated: The “fetter of existence” is a name for craving. For beings are led here and there to various forms of existence as if on a leash by this craving,🔽just as oxen are led here and there by a rope through their noses.🔽“Touched by the ripening of his deeds” means

original: maggacetanāya phuṭṭho. Yasmā hi maggacetanāya kammaṃ paccati vipaccati ḍayhati, parikkhayaṃ
analyzed: magga cetanāya phuṭṭhaḥ yasmā hi magga cetanāya kammam paccati vipaccati ḍayhati parikkhayam
translated: touched by the volition of the path. For the volition of the path cooks the kamma, ripens it, burns it up,🔽and causes it to go to complete destruction.

original: gacchati, tasmā sā kammavipākoti vuttā. Tāya hi phuṭṭhattā esa aṇaṇo nikkileso jāto,
analyzed: gacchati tasmā sā kamma vipākā iti vuttā tāya hi phuṭṭha ttā esa aṇaṇaḥ nikkilesaḥ jātaḥ
translated: Therefore it is called the ripening of kamma. Because he is touched by it, he becomes free from debt, free from stain.

original: na dukkhavedanāya aṇaṇo. Bhuñjāmīti cettha theyyaparibhogo iṇaparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo
analyzed: na dukkha vedanāya aṇaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi iti ca ittha theyya paribhogo iṇa paribhogo dāyajja paribhogo
translated: He is not free from debt through the feeling of pain.

original: sāmiparibhogoti cattāro paribhogā veditabbā. Tattha dussīlassa paribhogo theyyaparibhogo
analyzed: sāmi paribhogaḥ ti cattāro paribhogāḥ veditabbā tattha dussīlassa paribhogo theyya paribhogo
translated: Herein, “I enjoy” should be understood as the four kinds of enjoyment, namely, enjoyment as theft, enjoyment as debt, enjoyment as inheritance,🔽and enjoyment as master.🔽Herein, the enjoyment of one who is unvirtuous is enjoyment as theft;

original: nāma. So hi cattāro paccaye thenetvā bhuñjati. Vuttampi cetaṃ “theyyāya vo, bhikkhave,🔽raṭṭhapiṇḍo bhutto”ti. Sīlavato pana apaccavekkhaṇaparibhogo iṇaparibhogo nāma. Sattannaṃ
analyzed: nāma saḥ hi cattāraḥ paccaye thenetvā bhuñjati vuttam pi ca itam theyyāya vaḥ bhikkhave  raṭṭha piṇḍaḥ bhutto ti sīlavato pana a paccavekkhaṇa paribhogo iṇa paribhogo nāma
translated: For he eats the alms after having stolen the four requisites. And this is said: “The country’s alms food, bhikkhus, is eaten by you as if it were stolen goods” . But the use of requisites by one who is virtuous without reviewing is called “use as a debt.” The use of requisites by one who is virtuous after reviewing is called “use as a gift.”

original: sekkhānaṃ paribhogo dāyajjaparibhogo nāma. Khīṇāsavassa paribhogo sāmiparibhogo nāma.🔽Idha kilesaiṇānaṃ abhāvaṃ sandhāya “aṇaṇo”ti vuttaṃ. “Aniṇo”tipi pāṭho. Sāmiparibhogaṃ
analyzed: sekkhānam paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogaḥ nāma khīṇāsavassa paribhogaḥ sāmi paribhogaḥ nāma  abhāvam sandhāya aṇaṇo ti vuttam sāmi paribhogam
translated: He is called a thief because he eats after having stolen the four requisites. And this is said: “The country’s alms food, monks, is eaten by thieves” . But the use of requisites by one who is virtuous but who does not reflect is called the use of a debtor. The use of requisites by the seven kinds of trainers is called the use of an heir. The use of requisites by one whose cankers are destroyed is called the use of a master.

original: sandhāya “bhuñjāmi bhojana”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya bhuñjāmi bhojanan ti vuttam
translated: Herein, he is called “indebted” with reference to the absence of the debts to the cankers. “Indebted” is also a reading. “I eat the alms food” is said with reference to the use of a master.

original: Kāmaratisanthavanti duvidhesupi kāmesu taṇhāratisanthavaṃ mā anuyuñjatha mā karittha.🔽Nayidaṃ dummantitaṃ mamāti yaṃ mayā sammāsambuddhaṃ disvā pabbajissāmīti mantitaṃ,
analyzed: kāma rati santhavanti duvidhesu pi kāmesu taṇhā rati santhavam mā anuyuñjatha mā karittha  na yidam dummantitam mama ati yam mayā sammāsambuddham disvā pabbajissāmi iti mantitam
translated: “Do not pursue the pleasure of sense desires and the pleasure of rejoicings in social life”: do not pursue the pleasure of sense desires and the pleasure of rejoicing in the two kinds of sense desires.🔽“This wish of mine is not a bad one”: the wish I have made, “Having seen the Perfect Sambuddha, I will go forth,”

original: taṃ mama mantitaṃ na dummantitaṃ. Saṃvibhattesu dhammesūti ahaṃ satthāti evaṃ loke
analyzed: tat mama mantitam na dummantitam saṃvibhattesu dhammesu iti aham satthā ati evam loke
translated: is not a bad wish. “Among the things that should be shared”: having thought, “This is the Teacher,” and “This is the world’s

original: uppannehi ye dhammā saṃvibhattā, tesu dhammesu yaṃ seṭṭhaṃ nibbānaṃ, tadeva ahaṃ
analyzed: uppannehi ye dhammā saṃvibhattā tesu dhammesu yam seṭṭham nibbānam tat eva aham
translated: and the best of those things that have been shared out are Nibbāna, that is to say,

original: upagamaṃ upagato sampatto, tasmā mayhaṃ idaṃ āgamanaṃ svāgataṃ nāma gatanti. Tisso
analyzed: upagamam upagataḥ sampattaḥ tasmā mayham idam āgamanam svāgatam nāma gatanti tissaḥ
translated: The Dhamma that has been shared with me when it arose, the best of those Dhammas is Nibbāna. I have reached that, I have attained it. Therefore this coming of mine is a good coming.

original: vijjāti pubbenivāsadibbacakkhuāsavakkhayapaññā. Kataṃ buddhassa sāsananti yaṃ buddhassa
analyzed: vijjāti pubbenivāsa dibba cakkhu āsava kkhaya paññā katam buddhassa sāsanan ti yam buddhassa
translated: Three knowledges: the knowledge of past lives, the knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings, and the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers.🔽The Buddha’s Dispensation has been done: whatever task there is to be done in the Buddha’s Dispensation, all that has been done by me.

original: sāsane kattabbakiccaṃ atthi, taṃ sabbaṃ mayā kataṃ. Tīhi vijjāhi navahi ca lokuttaradhammehi
analyzed: sāsane kattabba kiccam atthi tat sabbam mayā katam tīhi vijjāhi navahi ca lokuttara dhammehi
translated: With the three knowledges and the nine supramundane states

original: desanaṃ matthakaṃ pāpesīti.
analyzed: desanam matthakam pāpesi iti
translated: he has brought the Teaching to its culmination.🔽The Commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya,

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: the Sūdani of Papañca,

analyzed: aṅgulimāla sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 7. Piyajātikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽353. Evaṃ me sutanti piyajātikasuttaṃ. Tattha neva kammantā paṭibhantīti na sabbena
analyzed: piya jātika sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutam ti piya jātika suttam tattha na iva kammantāḥ paṭibhanti iti na sabbena
translated: The Piyajātika Sutta

original: sabbaṃ paṭibhanti, pakatiniyāmena pana na paṭibhanti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Ettha
analyzed: sabbam paṭibhanti pakati niyāmena pana na paṭibhanti dutiya pade pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha
translated: Thus I heard. This is the Piyajātika Sutta. Herein, they do not all occur: they do not occur in all cases. But they do not occur in the regular order. The same method applies in the second section. Herein:

original: ca na paṭibhātīti na ruccati. Āḷāhananti susānaṃ. Aññathattanti vivaṇṇatāya aññathābhāvo.
analyzed: ca na paṭibhāti iti na ruccati āḷāhanam ti susānam aññathattanti vivaṇṇa tāya aññathābhāvaḥ
translated: and it does not please him, it does not appeal to him. ‘Cemetery’ is a charnel ground. ‘Otherwise’ is the state of being otherwise through discolouration.

original: Indriyāni nāma manoviññeyyā dhammā, patiṭṭhitokāsaṃ pana sandhāya idaṃ vuttaṃ. Piyajātikāti
analyzed: indriyāni nāma manaḥ viññeyyāḥ dhammā patiṭṭhita ukāsam pana sandhāya idam vuttam piya jātikā ti
translated: ‘Faculties’ are mental data cognizable by the mind. But this is said with reference to the place where they are established. ‘Born of what is dear’

original: piyato jāyanti. Piyappabhāvikāti piyato pabhavanti.🔽355. Sace taṃ, mahārājāti tassa atthaṃ asallakkhayamānāpi satthari saddhāya evaṃ🔽vadati. Cara pireti apehi amhākaṃ pare, anajjhattikabhūteti attho. Atha vā cara pireti
analyzed: piyataḥ jāyanti piya pabhāvikā ati piyataḥ pabhavanti  sace tam mahā rāja ati tassa attham a sat lakkhayamānā api satthari saddhāya evam  vadati cara pirā iti apehi amhākam pare an ajjhattika bhūta iti attho atha vā cara pirā iti
translated: are born from what is dear. ‘Originating from what is dear’ originate from what is dear.

original: parato gaccha, mā idha tiṭṭhātipi attho.🔽356. Dvidhā chetvāti asinā dve koṭṭhāse karonto chinditvā. Attānaṃ upphālesīti teneva🔽asinā attano udaraṃ phālesi. Yadi hi tassa sā appiyā bhaveyya, idāni aññaṃ mātugāmaṃ
analyzed: paratas gaccha mā idha tiṭṭha atipi attho  dvidhā chetvā iti asinā dve koṭṭhāse karonto chinditvā attānam upphālesi iti tena iva  asinā attanaḥ udaram phālesi yadi hi tassa sā appiyā bhaveyya idāni aññam mātugāmam
translated: ‘If, great king, you think:’ though not discerning his meaning, she says this out of faith in the Master. ‘Go away, stranger’ means ‘go away from us, stranger’. Or the meaning is: ‘Go away, stranger’ means ‘go away from here, stranger’.

original: gaṇhissāmīti attānaṃ na ghāteyya. Yasmā panassa sā piyā ahosi, tasmā paralokepi tāya
analyzed: gaṇhissāmi iti attānam na ghāteyya yasmā pana assa sā piyā ahosi tasmā para loke pi tāya
translated: ‘Having cut it in two’ means having cut it with a saw, making it into two pieces. ‘He gashed himself’ means he gashed his belly with that very saw. For if she had been unloved by him, he would not have gashed himself thinking ‘Now I will take another woman’. But because she was dear to him, therefore

original: saddhiṃ samaṅgibhāvaṃ patthayamāno evamakāsi.
analyzed: saddhim samaṅgi bhāvam patthayamānaḥ evam akāsi
translated: He did so, wishing to attain the state of being in union with her.

original: 357. Piyā te vajirīti evaṃ kirassā ahosi – “sacāhaṃ, ‘bhūtapubbaṃ, mahārāja, imissāyeva🔽sāvatthiyaṃ aññatarissā itthiyā’tiādikathaṃ katheyyaṃ, ‘ko te evaṃ akāsi, apehi natthi🔽eta’nti maṃ paṭisedheyya, vattamāneneva naṃ saññāpessāmī”ti cintetvā evamāha. Vipariṇāmaññathābhāvāti
analyzed: piyā te vajirī iti evam kirassā ahosi sacā aham bhūta pubbam mahā rāja imissāya eva  sāvatthiyam aññatarissā itthiyā ati ādi katham katheyyam kaḥ te evam akāsi apehi natthi  etat ti mam paṭisedheyya vattamānena iva nam saññāpessāmi iti cintetvā evam āha vipariṇāma aññathābhāvā ti
translated: ‘Was Vajiri dear to you?’ He thought: ‘If I were to say: “Great king, once in this very Sāvatthī …

original: ettha maraṇavasena vipariṇāmo, kenaci saddhiṃ palāyitvā gamanavasena aññathābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: ettha maraṇa vasena vipariṇāmaḥ kenaci saddhim palāyitvā gamana vasena aññathābhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: … who did this to you? Go away, there is no such person here,” he would contradict me. I shall convince him by what is actually happening.’ So he said: ‘Was Vajiri dear to you?’ ‘Change and alteration’ : here ‘change’ should be understood as death, and ‘alteration’ as going away with someone else.

original: Vāsabhāyāti vāsabhā nāma rañño ekā devī, taṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: vāsabhāya iti vāsabhā nāma raññaḥ ekā devī tam sandhāya āha
translated: ‘Vāsabha’s wife’ : Vāsabha was a queen of the king. He said this referring to her.

original: Piyā te ahanti kasmā sabbapacchā āha? Evaṃ kirassā ahosi – “ayaṃ rājā mayhaṃ kupito,
analyzed: piyā te ahanti kasma sabbapacchā āha evam ayam rājā mayham kupito
translated: ‘Was I dear to you?’ Why did he ask this last of all? He thought: ‘This king is angry with me.

original: sacāhaṃ sabbapaṭhamaṃ ‘piyā te aha’nti puccheyyaṃ, ‘na me tvaṃ piyā, cara pire’ti
analyzed: sacā aham sabba paṭhamam piyā te ahanti puccheyyam na me tvam piyā cara pirā iti
translated: If I were to ask: “Was I dear to you?” first of all, he would say: “You were not dear to me. Go away, you are a fool.”

original: vadeyya, evaṃ sante kathā patiṭṭhānaṃ na labhissatī”ti kathāya patiṭṭhānatthaṃ sabbapacchā
analyzed: vadeyya evam sante kathā patiṭṭhānam na labhissati iti kathāya patiṭṭhāna attham sabbapacchā
translated: If he were to say that, then the discussion would not have a basis.” In order to establish a basis for discussion,

original: pucchi. Kāsikosalesu chaḍḍitabhāvena vipariṇāmo, paṭirājūnaṃ hatthagamanavasena aññathābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: pucchi kāsi kosalesu chaḍḍita bhāvena vipariṇāmo paṭirājūnam hattha gamana vasena aññathābhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: If he were to say this, then the discussion would not have a basis. ” So he asked the last question in order to give a basis to the discussion. The “change” should be understood as the change in the elephant’s condition due to his being abandoned in Kāsi and Kosala, and the “alteration” as his coming into the hands of rival kings.

original: Ācamehīti ācamanodakaṃ dehi. Ācamitvā hatthapāde dhovitvā mukhaṃ vikkhāletvā satthāraṃ namassitukāmo evamāha. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: ācamehi iti ācamana udakam dehi ācamitvā hattha pāde dhovitvā mukham vikkhāletvā satthāram namassitu kāmaḥ evam āha sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: “Bring water for washing” means “give me water for washing.” After washing his hands and feet and rinsing his mouth, he said this, wishing to pay homage to the Teacher. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya, called “The Clearing of Confusion,”

analyzed: piya jātika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 8. Bāhitikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽358. Evaṃ me sutanti bāhitikasuttaṃ. Tattha ekapuṇḍarīkaṃ nāganti evaṃnāmakaṃ hatthiṃ.🔽Tassa kira phāsukānaṃ upari tālaphalamattaṃ paṇḍaraṭṭhānaṃ atthi, tenassa ekapuṇḍarīkoti
analyzed: bāhitika sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutam ti bāhitika suttam tattha eka puṇḍarīkam nāgam ti evaṃnāmakam hatthim  tassa kira phāsukānam upari tāla phala mattam paṇḍara ṭṭhānam atthi tena assa eka puṇḍarīkaḥ ti
translated: The Bahitika Sutta🔽Thus have I heard. The Bahitika Sutta. There, the elephant named Ekapuṇḍarīka.🔽It is said that there is a white spot the size of a palm fruit on his forehead, so they named him Ekapuṇḍarīka.

original: nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Sirivaḍḍhaṃ mahāmattanti paccekahatthiṃ abhiruhitvā kathāphāsukatthaṃ
analyzed: nāmam sirivaḍḍham mahā mattanti pacceka hatthim abhiruhitvā kathā phāsu kattham
translated: The minister Sirivaḍḍha, having mounted a single elephant, went to the place where the Blessed One was staying for the sake of conversation and comfort.

analyzed: saddhim gacchantam evaṃnāmakam mahāmattam ettha no ti pucchāya nipāto
translated: and the minister of such and such a name who was going along with him. The word “Venerable Sir” is a vocative in the question.

analyzed: mahāmattaḥ therassa saṅghāṭi patta dhāraṇa ākāram sallakkhetvā evam mahā rājā iti āha
translated: The minister, after observing the Elder’s way of carrying the outer cloak and bowl, said, “Yes, great king.”

analyzed: upārambha uti upārambham dosam āropanā raho kim pucchāmi iti rājā pucchati sundari vatthusmiṃ

analyzed: uppannam idam suttam tam pucchāmi iti pucchati yat hi mayam bhante iti bhante yam
translated: this Thread arose, and he asks about that. “Venerable Sir, that”: venerable sir, that

original: mayaṃ viññūhīti idaṃ padaṃ gahetvā pañhena paripūretuṃ nāsakkhimhā, taṃ kāraṇaṃ āyasmatā
analyzed: mayam viññūhi iti idam padam gahetvā pañhena paripūretum na asakkhimhā tam kāraṇam āyasmatā
translated: we were unable to complete the question by taking the word “wise men”

original: evaṃ vadantena paripūritaṃ.
analyzed: evam vadantena paripūritam
translated: has been completed by the venerable one’s saying it thus.

analyzed: akusalo ti akosalla sambhūto sāvajjo ti sa doso sa byābajjho ti sa dukkho dukkha vipāko ti
translated: “Uninstructed”: arisen from unskilfulness. “Blameworthy”: with hate. “Reprehensible”: with grief. “Resulting in suffering”:

analyzed: khandhāvāram gantvā viṭaṭūbham āmantesi chattam samma ussāpehi iti mayham pitā kim  gataḥ iti pitaram mā puccha sace tvam naḥ ussāpesi tam gaṇhitvā aham ussāpemi iti ussāpemi  sammā iti sampaṭicchi kārāyanaḥ raññaḥ ekam assañca asiñca ekam eva ca paricārikam itthim  ṭhapetvā sace rājā jīvitena atthikaḥ mā āgacchatu uti viṭa ṭūbhassa chattam ussāpetvā
translated: He went to the treasury and said to Vitataka, “Raise the sunshade, my dear.”🔽“Where has my father gone?”🔽“Don’t ask about your father. If you don’t raise the sunshade, I’ll have you arrested and I’ll raise it myself.”🔽“I’ll raise it, my dear,” he replied, and he did so.🔽Kārāyaṇa, having left the king a single horse, a sword, and a single female attendant,🔽said to Vitataka, “Raise the sunshade, my dear. If the king wants to live, let him come.”🔽

original: taṃ gahetvā sāvatthimeva gato.🔽367. Dhammanvayoti paccakkhañāṇasaṅkhātassa dhammassa anunayo anumānaṃ, anubuddhīti🔽attho. Idāni yenassa dhammanvayena “sammāsambuddho bhagavā”tiādi hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: tam gahetvā sāvatthim eva gataḥ  dhamma nvayaḥ ti paccakkha ñāṇa saṅkhātassa dhammassa anunayaḥ anumānam anubuddhi iti  atthaḥ idāni yena assa dhamma anvayena sammāsambuddhaḥ bhagavā atiādi hoti tam dassetuṃ
translated: He went to the treasury and said to Vitaṭūbha, “Raise the sunshade, my dear.” “Where has my father gone?” “Don’t ask about your father. If you don’t raise it, I’ll have you seized and raise it myself.” “I’ll raise it, my dear,” he agreed. Kārāyana, having left the king a single horse, a sword, and a single female attendant, said, “If the king wants to live, let him not come.” He raised the sunshade for Vitaṭūbha, took him, and went to Sāvatthī.

original: idha panāhaṃ, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha āpāṇakoṭikanti pāṇoti jīvitaṃ, taṃ mariyādaṃ
analyzed: idha pana aham bhante ti ādim āha tattha āpāṇakoṭikam ti jīvitam tam mariyādam
translated: The conformity of ideas is the conformity, the inference, of the knowledge called “direct-knowledge” of ideas. The meaning is: the subsequent understanding. Now, in order to show the conformity of ideas by means of which it is that the Blessed One is “fully enlightened” and so on, he said, “But here, venerable sir, I understand it in this way.” Herein, as long as life lasts is as long as life lasts, as long as the life faculty lasts.

original: anto karitvā, maraṇasamayepi carantiyeva, taṃ na vītikkamantīti vuttaṃ hoti. “Apāṇakoṭika”ntipi🔽pāṭho, ājīvitapariyantanti attho. Yathā ekacce jīvitahetu atikkamantā pāṇakoṭikaṃ🔽katvā caranti, na evanti attho. Ayampi kho me, bhanteti buddhasubuddhatāya dhammasvākkhātatāya🔽saṅghasuppaṭipannatāya ca etaṃ evaṃ hoti, evañhi me, bhante, ayaṃ bhagavati dhammanvayo
analyzed: antar karitvā maraṇa samaye pi carantiyā iva tam na vītikkamanti iti vuttam hoti  pāṭhaḥ ājīvita pariyantanti atthaḥ yathā ekacce jīvita hetu atikkamantā pāṇa koṭikam  katvā caranti na evanti atthaḥ ayam pi kho me bhante iti buddha su buddha tāya dhamma su ākkhāta tāya  saṅgha suppaṭipanna tāya ca etam evam hoti evam hi me bhante ayam bhagavati dhamma anvayo
translated: and they do not transgress it even at the cost of their lives. The reading “apāṇakoṭika”🔽means “up to the end of life.” The meaning is: they do not transgress it as some do for the sake of life, having made a “limit of life.”🔽“This, venerable sir, is how I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One: ‘The Tathagata, accomplished and fully enlightened,🔽does not transgress and overstep this Dhamma that is admirable in every way.’“🔽“Good, good, Ananda! It is good that you understand the Dhamma taught by me in this way.🔽

original: hotīti dīpeti. Eseva nayo sabbattha.🔽369. Na viya maññe cakkhuṃ bandhanteti cakkhuṃ abandhante viya. Apāsādikañhi disvā🔽puna olokanakiccaṃ na hoti, tasmā so cakkhuṃ na bandhati nāma. Pāsādikaṃ disvā punappunaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti dīpeti esa eva nayaḥ sabbattha  na viya maññe cakkhum bandhante iti cakkhum a bandhante viya apāsādikam hi disvā  puna olokana kiccam na hoti tasmā so cakkhum na bandhati nāma pāsādikam disvā punappunam
translated: and they do not transgress it even at the cost of their lives. The reading “apāṇakoṭika” is also allowable; the meaning is “up to the limit of life.” The meaning is: just as some transgress it for the sake of life, having made it “up to the cost of life,” so do not do. “This, venerable sir, is how I understand the Dhamma taught by the Exalted One”: he shows that it is so because the Exalted One is well enlightened, the Dhamma is well taught, and the Sangha is practicing well. For this is the way the Dhamma is for me, venerable sir.

original: olokanakiccaṃ hoti, tasmā so cakkhuṃ bandhati nāma. Ime ca apāsādikā, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: olokana kiccam hoti tasmā saḥ cakkhum bandhati nāma ime ca apāsādikā tasmai evam āha
translated: . “As if binding the eyes”: as if not binding the eyes. For when one sees something unappealing, there is no need to look again, and therefore it is said that one does not bind the eyes. But when one sees something appealing, there is a need to look again and again, and therefore it is said that one binds the eyes. But these are unappealing, and therefore he says this.

original: Bandhukarogo noti kularogo. Amhākaṃ kule jātā evarūpā hontīti vadanti. Uḷāranti mahesakkhaṃ.
analyzed: bandhuka rogaḥ no ti kula rogaḥ amhākam kule jātāḥ evarūpāḥ honti iti vadanti
translated: ‘A family disease’ means a disease of the family. They say: ‘Those born in our family become like this.’ ‘A great affliction’ means a serious disease.

original: Pubbenāparanti pubbato aparaṃ visesaṃ. Tattha kasiṇaparikammaṃ katvā samāpattiṃ nibbattento
analyzed: pubbena aparam ti pubbataḥ aparam visesam tattha kasiṇa parikammam katvā samāpattim nibbattento
translated: ‘A family disease’ is a disease of the family. They say: ‘Those born in our family become like this.’ ‘A distinction’: a distinction in the future from what has gone before. Herein, one who has made the kasiṇa the preliminary work and has produced the attainment

original: uḷāraṃ pubbe visesaṃ sañjānāti nāma, samāpattiṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: uḷāram pubbe visesam sañjānāti nāma samāpattim padaṭṭhānam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: ‘perceives a distinction in the future from what has gone before’ in the sense that he has produced the distinction of the path. One who has made the attainment the preliminary work and has extended insight

original: arahattaṃ gaṇhanto uḷāraṃ pubbato aparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānāti nāma.🔽370. Ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetunti ghātetabbayuttakaṃ ghātetuṃ. Jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetunti🔽dhanena vā jāpetabbayuttakaṃ jāpetuṃ jānituṃ adhanaṃ kātuṃ. Pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetunti
analyzed: arahattam gaṇhantaḥ uḷāram pubbatas aparam visesam sañjānāti nāma  ghāteta ayam vā ghātetunti ghātetabba yuttakam ghātetum jāpeta ayam vā jāpetunti  dhanena vā jāpetabba yuttakam jāpetum jānitum adhanam kātum pabbājeta ayam vā pabbājetum ti
translated: ‘perceives a distinction in the future from what has gone before’ in the sense that he has reached Arahantship.

analyzed: raṭṭhataḥ vā pabbājetabba yuttakam pabbājetum
translated: ‘To kill’: to kill one fit to be killed. ‘To make recite’: to make recite, to make known, to make poor, one fit to be made to recite, to be made to recite, to be made known, to be made poor, by means of wealth. ‘To banish’: to banish one fit to be banished from the kingdom.

original: 373. Isidattapurāṇāti isidatto ca purāṇo ca. Tesu eko brahmacārī, eko sadārasantuṭṭho.
analyzed: isidatta purāṇā ati isidatto ca purāṇaḥ ca tesu ekaḥ brahmacārī ekaḥ sa dāra santuṭṭho
translated: ‘Isidatta and Purana’: Isidatta and Purana. Of these, one was a celibate, the other was satisfied with his wife.

original: Mamabhattāti mama santakaṃ bhattaṃ etesanti mamabhattā. Mamayānāti mama santakaṃ
analyzed: mamabhattā ati mama santakam bhattam etesanti mamabhattā mamayānā ati mama santakam
translated: My servants: my servants are they who have my food. My vehicles: my vehicles are they who have my vehicles.

analyzed: yānam etesanti mamayānāḥ jīvikāya dātā ati jīvita vuttim dātā vīmaṃsamānaḥ ti upaparikkhamānaḥ

original: Tadā kira rājā niddaṃ anokkantova okkanto viya hutvā nipajji. Atha te thapatayo “katarasmiṃ🔽disābhāge bhagavā”ti pucchitvā “asukasmiṃ nāmā”ti sutvā mantayiṃsu – “yena sammāsambuddho,
analyzed: tadā kira rājā niddam an ukkantaḥ iva okkantaḥ viya hutvā nipajji atha te thapatayaḥ katarasmin  disā bhāge bhagavā ati pucchitvā asukasmin nāma ati sutvā mantayiṃsu yena sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: It seems that the king was lying down as if he had just gone to bed. Then the overseers asked, “In what direction is the Blessed One?”

original: tena sīse kate rājā pādato hoti. Yena rājā, tena sīse kate satthā pādato hoti, kiṃ
analyzed: tena sīse kate rājā pādatas hoti yena rājā tena sīse kate satthā pādatas hoti kiṃ
translated: When they heard, “In such and such a direction,” they discussed the matter among themselves: “If we put the Fully Enlightened One at the head, the king will be at the foot. If we put the king at the head, the Teacher will be at the foot.

original: karissāmā”ti? Tato nesaṃ etadahosi – “rājā kuppamāno yaṃ amhākaṃ deti, taṃ acchindeyya.
analyzed: karissāma iti tatas na īsam etat ahosi rājā kuppamānaḥ yam amhākam deti tam acchindeyya

original: Na kho pana mayaṃ sakkoma jānamānā satthāraṃ pādato kātu”nti rājānaṃ pādato katvā
analyzed: na kho pana mayam sakkoma jānamānāḥ satthāram pādataḥ kātunti rājānam pādataḥ katvā

translated: and went to bed. The king said this referring to that incident.

original: 374. Pakkāmīti gandhakuṭito nikkhamitvā kārāyanassa ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ gato, taṃ tattha🔽adisvā khandhāvāraṭṭhānaṃ gato, tatthāpi aññaṃ adisvā taṃ itthiṃ pucchi. Sā sabbaṃ🔽pavattiṃ ācikkhi. Rājā – “na idāni mayā ekakena tattha gantabbaṃ, rājagahaṃ gantvā🔽bhāgineyyena saddhiṃ āgantvā mayhaṃ rajjaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti rājagahaṃ gacchanto antarāmagge🔽kaṇājakabhattañceva bhuñji, bahalaudakañca pivi. Tassa sukhumālapakatikassa āhāro
analyzed: pakkāmi iti gandhakuṭitaḥ nikkhamitvā kārāyanassa ṭhita ṭṭhānam gataḥ tam tattha  a disvā khandhāvāra ṭṭhānam gato tattha api aññam a disvā tam itthim pucchi sā sabbaṃ  pavattim ācikkhi rājā na idāni mayā ekakena tattha gantabbam rājagaham gantvā  bhāgineyyena saddhim āgantvā mayham rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti rājagaham gacchantaḥ antarāmagge  kaṇājaka bhattam ca iva bhuñji bahala odakam ca tassa āhāro
translated: He went out from the Fragrant Cell and went to the place where Kārāyaṇa was standing. Not seeing him there, he went to the place where the body-guards were. Not seeing him there either, he asked that woman. She told him all that had happened. The king thought, “Now I cannot go there alone. I will go to Rājagaha, get my nephew to come with me, and then I will take over the kingdom.” As he was going to Rājagaha, on the way he ate a meal of rice and mung beans and drank a lot of water. This food did not agree with him,🔽and he became ill with dysentery.

original: na sammā pariṇāmi. So rājagahaṃ pāpuṇantopi vikāle dvāresu pihitesu pāpuṇi. “Ajja🔽sālāyaṃ sayitvā sve mayhaṃ bhāgineyyaṃ passissāmī”ti bahinagare sālāya nipajji. Tassa🔽rattibhāge uṭṭhānāni pavattiṃsu, katipayavāre bahi nikkhami. Tato paṭṭhāya padasā
analyzed: na sammā saḥ rājagaham vikāle dvāresu pihitesu ajja 🔽sālāyam sayitvā sve mayham bhāgineyyam passissāmi iti bahi nagare sālāya nipajji tassa 🔽ratti bhāge uṭṭhānāni katipaya vāre bahi nikkhami tato paṭṭhāya padasā
translated: He went out of the Perfumed Chamber and went to the place where Kārāyaṇa was standing. Not seeing him there, he went to the place where the body-guards were. Not seeing him there either, he asked the woman. She told him all that had happened. The king thought, “I cannot go there alone now. I will go to Rājagaha, get my nephew to come with me, and then we will take over the kingdom.” As he was going to Rājagaha, on the way he ate a meal of rice and mung-bean curry and drank a lot of water. As he was delicate by nature, the food did not agree with him. He reached Rājagaha, but the gates were closed. “I will sleep in the hall and see my nephew tomorrow.” He lay down in a hall outside the city. During the night he had to get up, and he went outside several times. From then on he had to walk with the help of a stick.

original: gantuṃ asakkonto tassā itthiyā aṅke nipajjitvā balavapaccūse kālamakāsi. Sā tassa🔽matabhāvaṃ ñatvā – “dvīsu rajjesu rajjaṃ kāretvā idāni parassa bahinagare anāthasālāya
analyzed: gantum a sakkonto tassāḥ itthiyāḥ aṅke nipajjitvā balava paccūse kālam akāsi sā tassa  mata bhāvam ñatvā dvīsu rajjesu rajjam kāretvā idāni parassa bahi nagare anāthasālāya
translated: Unable to go on, he lay down in the lap of the woman and died.

original: anāthakālakiriyaṃ katvā nipanno mayhaṃ sāmi kosalarājā”tiādīni vadamānā uccāsaddena
analyzed: anātha kāla kiriyam katvā nipannaḥ mayham sāmi kosala rājā ati ādīni vadamānāḥ uccāsaddena
translated: She, knowing that he was dead, said, “Having ruled over two kingdoms, my husband, the king of Kosala, now lies dead in a poorhouse in a foreign city.”

original: paridevituṃ ārabhi. Manussā sutvā rañño ārocesuṃ. Rājā āgantvā disvā sañjānitvā āgatakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: paridevitum ārabhi manussā sutvā raññaḥ ārocesuṃ rājā āgantvā disvā sañjānitvā āgata kāraṇam
translated: And she began to lament in a loud voice. People heard her and told the king. The king came and recognized the body.

original: ñatvā mahāparihārena sarīrakiccaṃ karitvā “viṭaṭūbhaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti bheriṃ carāpetvā
analyzed: ñatvā mahā parihārena sarīra kiccam karitvā viṭa ṭūbham gaṇhissāmi iti bherim carāpetvā
translated: He learned the reason for his coming and had the funeral rites performed with great pomp. Then he had a proclamation made, “I will take the body of my uncle,”

original: balakāyaṃ sannipātesi. Amaccā pādesu patitvā – “sace, deva, tumhākaṃ mātulo arogo🔽assa, tumhākaṃ gantuṃ yuttaṃ bhaveyya, idāni pana viṭaṭūbhopi tumhe nissāya chattaṃ
analyzed: balakāyam sannipātesi amaccā pādesu patitvā sace deva tumhākam mātulaḥ arogaḥ  assa tumhākam gantum yuttam bhaveyya idāni pana tumhe nissāya chattam
translated: and he assembled his army. The ministers fell at his feet and said, “Your majesty, if your uncle were alive,🔽it would be proper for you to go to him; but now the two kings, relying on you, have raised their parasols. It is fitting that they should do so.”

original: ussāpetuṃ arahatiyevā”ti saññāpetvā nivāresuṃ.
analyzed: ussāpetum a rahatiyā iva ati saññāpetvā nivāresuṃ
translated: And they persuaded him to return.

original: Dhammacetiyānīti dhammassa cittīkāravacanāni. Tīsu hi ratanesu yattha katthaci cittīkāre🔽kate sabbattha katoyeva hoti, tasmā bhagavati cittīkāre kate dhammopi katova hotīti🔽bhagavā “dhammacetiyānī”ti āha. Ādibrahmacariyakānīti maggabrahmacariyassa ādibhūtāni,
analyzed: dhamma cetiyāni iti dhammassa cittīkāra vacanāni tīsu hi ratanesu yattha katthaci cittīkāre  kate sabbattha kataḥ yā iva hoti tasmā bhagavati cittīkāre kate dhammaḥ api kataḥ va hoti iti  bhagavā dhamma cetiyāni iti āha ādi brahmacariyakāni iti magga brahmacariyassa ādi bhūtāni
translated: “Dhamma monuments”: monuments to the Dhamma. For when a monument is erected to any one of the three jewels, it is as if a monument were erected to all three. Therefore, when a monument is erected to the Blessed One, it is as if a monument were erected to the Dhamma as well. Thus the Blessed One said “Dhamma monuments.” “The beginning of the holy life”: the beginning of the holy life of the path.

original: pubbabhāgapaṭipattibhūtānīti attho. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya🔽Dhammacetiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽10. Kaṇṇakatthalasuttavaṇṇanā🔽375. Evaṃ me sutanti kaṇṇakatthalasuttaṃ. Tattha uruññāyanti uruññāti tassa raṭṭhassapi🔽nagarassapi etadeva nāmaṃ, bhagavā uruññānagaraṃ upanissāya viharati. Kaṇṇakatthale🔽migadāyeti tassa nagarassa avidūre kaṇṇakatthalaṃ nāma eko ramaṇīyo bhūmibhāgo atthi,
analyzed: pubba bhāga paṭipatti bhūtāni iti attho sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati 🔽papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya 🔽dhammacetiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽       🔽evam me sutan ti kaṇṇakatthala suttam tattha uruññāyanti uruññā ati tassa raṭṭhassa pi 🔽nagarassa api etat eva nāmam bhagavā uruññā nagaram upanissāya viharati kaṇṇakatthale 🔽migadāya iti tassa nagarassa avidūre kaṇṇakatthalam nāma ekaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ bhūmi bhāgaḥ atthi
translated: “Relics of the Dhamma”: monuments to the Dhamma. For when a monument is made to any one of the Three Jewels, it is made to all three. Therefore when a monument is made to the Blessed One, it is also made to the Dhamma. Thus the Blessed One said “relics of the Dhamma.” “The beginning of the holy life”: the beginning of the holy life of the path. The meaning is: the preliminary practice. The rest is clear.

original: so migānaṃ abhayatthāya dinnattā migadāyoti vuccati, tasmiṃ kaṇṇakatthale migadāye.
analyzed: saḥ migānam abhayatthāya dinnattā migadāyo iti vuccati tasmim kaṇṇakatthale migadāye
translated: because it was given for the protection of the deer, it is called the Deer Park.

original: Kenacideva karaṇīyenāti na aññena, anantarasutte vuttakaraṇīyeneva. Somā ca bhaginī
analyzed: kenacid eva karaṇīyena ati na aññena anantara sutte vutta karaṇīyena iva somā ca bhaginī
translated: On some business: not on any other business, but on the very same business stated in the preceding sutta.🔽Somā the nun and Sakulā the nun: these two nuns were the king’s chief wives.

original: sakulā ca bhaginīti imā dve bhaginiyo rañño pajāpatiyo. Bhattābhihāreti bhattaṃ abhiharaṇaṭṭhāne.
analyzed: sa kulā ca bhaginī iti imāḥ dve bhaginiyaḥ raññaḥ pajāpatiyaḥ bhatta abhihāre iti bhattam abhiharaṇa ṭṭhāne
translated: At the place of the meal: at the place where the meal was brought.

original: Rañño bhuñjanaṭṭhānañhi sabbāpi orodhā kaṭacchuādīni gahetvā rājānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ gacchanti,
analyzed: raññaḥ bhuñjana ṭhānam hi sabbā api orodhā kaṭacchu ādīni gahetvā rājānam upaṭṭhātum gacchanti
translated: For all the palace women go to attend on the king, taking their bowls and so on,

original: tāpi tatheva agamaṃsu.
analyzed: tā api tathā iva agamaṃsu
translated: and they went in the same way.

original: 376. Kiṃ pana, mahārājāti kasmā evamāha? Rañño garahaparimocanatthaṃ. Evañhi parisā🔽cinteyya – “ayaṃ rājā āgacchamānova mātugāmānaṃ sāsanaṃ āroceti, mayaṃ attano dhammatāya
analyzed: kim pana mahā rāja ati kasmai evam āha raññaḥ garaha parimocana attham evam hi parisā  cinteyya ayam rājā āgacchamānaḥ iva mātu gāmānam sāsanam āroceti mayam attanaḥ dhamma tāya
translated: Why is it so, great king? : why is it so, great king? He said this in order to avoid the king’s censure. For the assembly might think:🔽“This king announces the message of the women even before he has come. We think he has come to see the Blessed One on his own initiative,

original: bhagavantaṃ daṭṭhuṃ āgatoti maññāma, ayaṃ pana mātugāmānaṃ sāsanaṃ gahetvā āgato,
analyzed: bhagavantam daṭṭhum āgataḥ iti maññāma ayam pana mātugāmānam sāsanam gahetvā āgataḥ
translated: but he has come taking the message of the women with him.

original: mātugāmadāso maññe, esa pubbepi imināva kāraṇena āgacchatī”ti. Pucchito pana so attano
analyzed: mātugāmadāsaḥ maññe esa pubbe pi iminā ava kāraṇena āgacchati iti pucchitaḥ pana so attano
translated: as if he were a slave to women.” But when asked, he said,

original: āgamanakāraṇaṃ kathessati, evamassa ayaṃ garahā na uppajjissatīti garahamocanatthaṃ evamāha.
analyzed: āgamana kāraṇam kathessati evam assa ayam garahā na uppajjissati iti garaha mocana attham evam āha
translated: He is like a slave to women, and he has come here for the same reason as before.” But when questioned, he will tell the reason for his coming. Thus this reproach will not arise for him. He said this for the purpose of avoiding reproach.

original: 378. Abbhudāhāsīti kathesi. Sakideva sabbaṃ ussati sabbaṃ dakkhitīti yo ekāvajjanena
analyzed: kathesi sakid eva sabbam ussati sabbam dakkhiti iti yaḥ eka āvajjanena
translated: He spoke: he told. There is no one who would see or know all by a single adverting, by a single consciousness.

original: ekacittena atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ sabbaṃ ussati vā dakkhiti vā, so natthīti attho.
analyzed: ekacittena atīta anāgata paccuppannam sabbam ussati vā dakkhiti vā saḥ natthi iti attho
translated: The meaning is that there is no one who would see or know all past, future and present by a single adverting, by a single consciousness.

original: Ekena hi cittena atītaṃ sabbaṃ jānissāmīti āvajjitvāpi atītaṃ sabbaṃ jānituṃ na sakkā,
analyzed: ekena hi cittena atītam sabbam jānissāmi iti āvajjitvā api atītam sabbam jānitum na sakkā
translated: For if he were to advert thus, “I shall know all the past by a single consciousness,” he would not be able to know all the past;

original: ekadesameva jānāti. Anāgatapaccuppannaṃ pana tena cittena sabbeneva sabbaṃ na jānātīti.
analyzed: eka desam eva jānāti anāgata paccuppannam pana tena cittena sabbena iva sabbam na jānāti iti
translated: he would know only a part of it. But he would not know all the future and the present by that consciousness.

original: Esa nayo itaresu. Evaṃ ekacittavasenāyaṃ pañho kathito. Heturūpanti hetusabhāvaṃ
analyzed: esa nayo itaresu evam eka citta vasena ayam pañho kathitaḥ hetu sabhāvam
translated: The same method applies to the other two. This question is answered by a single consciousness.🔽Cause-essence: the nature of a cause, the kind of a cause.🔽With cause: of the kind of a cause.

original: kāraṇajātikaṃ. Saheturūpanti sakāraṇajātikaṃ. Samparāyikāhaṃ, bhanteti samparāyaguṇaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇa jātikam sa hetu rūpanti sa kāraṇa jātikam samparāyikā aham bhanta iti samparāya guṇam
translated: I have, venerable sir, what is called “welfare in the other world”:

original: ahaṃ, bhante, pucchāmi.
analyzed: aham bhante pucchāmi
translated: I ask, Lord.

original: 379. Pañcimānīti imasmiṃ sutte pañca padhāniyaṅgāni lokuttaramissakāni kathitāni.
analyzed: pañcimāni iti imasmin sutte pañca padhāniyaṅgāni lokuttara missakāni kathitāni
translated: In this Thread the five factors of striving are taught mixed with the Supramundane.

original: Kathinaṅgaṇavāsīcūḷasamuddatthero pana “tumhākaṃ, bhante, kiṃ ruccatī”ti vutte “mayhaṃ
analyzed: kathinaṅgaṇa vāsīcūḷasamudda ttheraḥ pana tumhākam bhante kim ruccati iti vutte mayham
translated: But the Elder Cūḷa-Samudda, who lived in the Kathinaṅgaṇavāsī Cave, said: “What do you approve of, venerable sirs? ”🔽“We approve of the Supramundane, venerable sir.”

original: lokuttarānevāti ruccatī”ti āha. Padhānavemattatanti padhānanānattaṃ. Aññādisameva🔽hi puthujjanassa padhānaṃ, aññādisaṃ sotāpannassa, aññādisaṃ sakadāgāmino, aññādisaṃ🔽anāgāmino, aññādisaṃ arahato, aññādisaṃ asītimahāsāvakānaṃ, aññādisaṃ dvinnaṃ aggasāvakānaṃ,
analyzed: lokuttarān eva ati ruccati iti āha padhāna vemattatam ti padhāna nānattam añña ādisam eva  hi puthujjanassa padhānam aññādisam sotāpannassa aññādisam sakadāgāmino aññādisam  anāgāminaḥ aññādisam arahataḥ aññādisam asīti mahāsāvakānam aññādisam dvinnam aggasāvakānam
translated: The diversity of striving is the diversity of the kinds of striving.

original: aññādisaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ, aññādisaṃ sabbaññubuddhānaṃ. Puthujjanassa padhānaṃ sotāpannassa
analyzed: aññādisam paccekabuddhānam aññādisam sabbaññu buddhānam puthujjanassa padhānam sotāpannassa
translated: For the striving of an ordinary man is of one kind, that of a Stream-Enterer of another kind, that of a Once-Returner of another kind, that of a Non-Returner of another kind, that of an Arahant of another kind, that of the eighty Great Disciples of another kind, that of the two Chief Disciples of another kind, that of the Paccekabuddhas of another kind, and that of the Fully Enlightened Ones of another kind.

original: padhānaṃ na pāpuṇāti…pe… paccekabuddhassa padhānaṃ sabbaññubuddhassa padhānaṃ na
analyzed: padhānam na pāpuṇāti pe paccekabuddhassa padhānam sabbaññubuddhassa padhānam na
translated: The striving of an ordinary man does not reach the striving of a Stream-Enterer, … the striving of a Paccekabuddha does not reach the striving of a Fully Enlightened One.

original: pāpuṇāti. Imamatthaṃ sandhāya “padhānavemattataṃ vadāmī”ti āha. Dantakāraṇaṃ gaccheyyunti
analyzed: pāpuṇāti imam attham sandhāya padhāna vemattatam vadāmi iti āha danta kāraṇam gaccheyyun ti
translated: “To go to the place where the tuskers are taken”:

original: yaṃ akūṭakaraṇaṃ, anavacchindanaṃ, dhurassa acchindananti dantesu kāraṇaṃ dissati,
analyzed: yam a kūṭa karaṇam an avacchindanam dhurassa a chindanam ti dantesu kāraṇam dissati
translated: the place where tuskers are taken for the purpose of having their tusks cut is the place where tuskers are taken to have their tusks cut.🔽“To go to the place where the tuskers are taken” means to go to the place where tuskers are taken for the purpose of having their tusks cut.

original: taṃ kāraṇaṃ upagaccheyyunti attho. Dantabhūminti dantehi gantabbabhūmiṃ. Assaddhotiādīsu🔽puthujjanasotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmino cattāropi assaddhā nāma. Puthujjano hi sotāpannassa
analyzed: tam kāraṇam upagaccheyyunti atthaḥ danta bhūminti dantehi gantabba bhūmim assaddhaḥ ti ādīsu  puthujjana sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmino cattāro api assaddhāḥ nāma puthujjanaḥ hi sotāpannassa
translated: “The tusk-cutting place” is the place where tuskers are taken.🔽As to “faithless” and the rest,

original: saddhaṃ appattoti assaddho, sotāpanno sakadāgāmissa, sakadāgāmī anāgāmissa, anāgāmī🔽arahato saddhaṃ appattoti assaddho, ābādho arahatopi uppajjatīti pañcapi bahvābādhā
analyzed: saddham appatto ti assaddhaḥ sotāpanno sakadāgāmissa sakadāgāmī anāgāmissa anāgāmī  arahataḥ saddham appatto ti assaddhaḥ ābādhaḥ arahataḥ api uppajjati iti pañca api bahu ābādhā
translated: all four of the types of person, namely, the worldling, the stream-enterer, the once-returner, and the non-returner, are called “faithless.” For the worldling has not yet attained the faith of the stream-enterer,🔽the stream-enterer that of the once-returner, the once-returner that of the non-returner, and the non-returner that of the Arahant.🔽And since sickness arises even in the Arahant, all five are called “sickly.”

original: nāma honti. Ariyasāvakassa pana saṭho māyāvīti nāmaṃ natthi. Teneva thero – “pañca
analyzed: nāma honti ariya sāvakassa pana saṭhaḥ māyāvī iti nāmaṃ natthi tena iva thero pañca
translated: But the noble disciple has no name for being “deceitful” or “fraudulent.”🔽That is why the elder said: “It seems to me that the five factors of striving are supramundane.”

original: padhāniyaṅgāni lokuttarāni kathitānīti mayhaṃ ruccatī”ti āha. Assakhaḷuṅkasuttante
analyzed: lokuttarāni kathitāni iti mayham ruccati iti āha assakhaḷuṅka suttante
translated: In the Assakhaḷuṅka Sutta ,

original: pana – “tayo ca, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅke tayo ca purisakhaḷuṅke desessāmī”ti ettha
analyzed: pana tayo ca bhikkhave assa khaḷuṅke tayo ca purisa khaḷuṅke desessāmi iti ettha
translated: But in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you three kinds of wild colts and three kinds of men resembling wild colts” ,

original: ariyasāvakassāpi sambodhināmaṃ āgataṃ, tassa vasena lokuttaramissakā kathitāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ariya sāvakassa api sambodhi nāmam āgatam tassa vasena lokuttara missakā kathitā iti vuttam
translated: the noble disciple is called a “fully enlightened one” , and the mixed type is stated with reference to him.

original: Puthujjano pana sotāpattimaggavīriyaṃ asampatto…pe… anāgāmī arahattamaggavīriyaṃ
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ pana sotāpatti magga vīriyam a sampatta upe anāgāmī arahatta magga vīriyam
translated: But the worldling who has not reached the path of stream-entry, and so on, up to the elder who has not reached the path of arahatship,

original: asampattoti kusītopi assaddho viya cattārova honti, tathā duppañño.
analyzed: asampatto ti kusītaḥ api assaddhaḥ viya cattāro va honti tathā duppañño
translated: is “lazy” like the faithless man, and so there are only four types, and likewise only four types of the unwise.

original: Evaṃ panettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ – adantahatthiādayo viya hi maggapadhānarahito
analyzed: evam pana ittha opamma saṃsandanam veditabbam adanta hatthi ādayaḥ viya hi magga padhāna rahitaḥ
translated: The application of the similes should be understood as follows. The person who is devoid of the path is like the untamed elephant, etc.;

original: puggalo. Dantahatthiādayo viya maggapadhānavā. Yathā adantā hatthiādayo kūṭākāraṃ🔽akatvā avicchinditvā dhuraṃ apātetvā dantagamanaṃ vā gantuṃ dantabhūmiṃ vā pattuṃ
analyzed: puggalaḥ danta hatthi ādayaḥ viya magga padhānavā yathā a dantāḥ hatthi ādayaḥ kūṭa ākāram  a katvā a vicchinditvā dhuram a pātetvā danta gamanam vā gantum danta bhūmim vā pattum
translated: the person who possesses the path is like the tamed elephant, etc.🔽Just as the untamed elephant, etc., are unable to go by the way they ought, to reach the place they should reach, without throwing off the goad and breaking the pole,

original: na sakkonti, evamevaṃ maggapadhānarahito maggapadhānavatā pattabbaṃ pāpuṇituṃ nibbattetabbaṃ
analyzed: na sakkonti evam evam magga padhāna rahitaḥ magga padhānavatā pattabbam pāpuṇitum nibbattetabbam
translated: so too the person devoid of the path is unable to reach the place he should reach, namely, Nibbāna,

original: guṇaṃ nibbattetuṃ na sakkoti. Yathā pana dantahatthiādayo kūṭākāraṃ akatvā avicchinditvā
analyzed: guṇam nibbattetum na sakkoti yathā pana danta hatthi ādayaḥ kūṭa ākāram a katvā a vicchinditvā
translated: He cannot produce the special quality.

original: dhuraṃ apātetvā dantagamanaṃ vā gantuṃ dantabhūmiṃ vā pattuṃ sakkonti, evamevaṃ maggapadhānavā
analyzed: dhuram a pātetvā danta gamanam vā gantum danta bhūmim vā pattum sakkonti evam evam magga padhānavā
translated: But just as an elephant with tusks, etc., can go by the tusk-path or reach the tusk-place without breaking the tusk-path or dropping the tusk, so too one who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit can reach the place of the fruit that can be reached by one who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit,

original: maggapadhānavatā pattabbaṃ pāpuṇituṃ nibbattetabbaṃ guṇaṃ nibbattetuṃ sakkoti. Idaṃ
analyzed: magga padhānavatā pattabbam pāpuṇitum nibbattetabbam guṇam nibbattetum sakkoti idam
translated: and he can produce the special quality that can be produced by one who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit.

original: vuttaṃ hoti – “sotāpattimaggapadhānavā sotāpattimaggapadhānavatā pattokāsaṃ pāpuṇituṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti sotāpatti magga padhānavā sotāpatti magga padhānavatā patta ukāsam pāpuṇitum
translated: This is the meaning: “One who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit can reach the place of the fruit that can be reached by one who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit,

original: nibbattetabbaṃ guṇaṃ nibbattetuṃ sakkoti…pe… arahattamaggapadhānavā arahattamaggapadhānavatā
analyzed: nibbattetabbam guṇam nibbattetum sakkotipe arahatta magga padhānavā arahatta magga padhānavatā
translated: and he can produce the special quality that can be produced by one who has the path of the stream-enterer’s fruit. … One who has the path of the Arahant’s fruit can reach the place of the fruit that can be reached by one who has the path of the Arahant’s fruit,

original: pattokāsaṃ pāpuṇituṃ nibbattetabbaṃ guṇaṃ nibbattetuṃ sakkotī”ti.
analyzed: patta ukāsam pāpuṇitum nibbattetabbam guṇam nibbattetum sakkoti iti
translated: and he can produce the special quality that can be produced by one who has the path of the Arahant’s fruit.”🔽“Right endeavours”: right endeavours by means of the path.

original: 380. Sammappadhānāti maggapadhānena sammappadhānā. Na kiñci nānākaraṇaṃ vadāmi yadidaṃ
analyzed: sammappadhānā ti magga padhānena sammappadhānā na kiñci nānākaraṇam vadāmi yat idam
translated: I declare no distinction

original: vimuttiyā vimuttinti yaṃ ekassa phalavimuttiyā itarassa phalavimuttiṃ ārabbha nānākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vimuttiyāḥ vimuttinti yam ekassa phala vimuttiyāḥ itarassa phala vimuttim ārabbha nānākaraṇam
translated: between the deliverances and the deliverances.

original: vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ na kiñci vadāmīti attho. Acciyā vā accinti acciyā vā accimhi.
analyzed: vattabbam siyā tam na kiñci vadāmi iti attho acciyā vā accinti acciyā vā accimhi
translated: It may be said, but I say nothing at all. In the flame or in the flame.

original: Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo, bhummatthe hi etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, mahārājāti,🔽mahārāja, kiṃ tvaṃ? “Santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṃsā…pe… santi devā
analyzed: sesa pada dvaye pi esā iva nayaḥ bhumma tthe hi etam upayoga vacanam kim pana tvam mahā rāja ati  mahā rāja kim tvam santi devā santi devā santi devā
translated: The same method applies in the other two clauses. For this is a locative expression in the sense of ground. But what do you think, great king?

original: paranimmitavasavattino, santi devā tatuttari”nti evaṃ devānaṃ atthibhāvaṃ na jānāsi,
analyzed: paranimmitavasavattinaḥ santi devā evam devānam atthi bhāvam na jānāsi
translated: Great king, what do you think? “There are gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings, there are gods of the heaven of the Thirty-three … there are gods who control what is created by others, there are gods higher than these” . In this way you do not know the existence of the gods,

original: yena evaṃ vadesīti. Tato atthibhāvaṃ jānāmi, manussalokaṃ pana āgacchanti nāgacchantīti🔽idaṃ pucchanto yadi vā te, bhantetiādimāha. Sabyābajjhāti sadukkhā, samucchedappahānena
analyzed: yena evam vadesi iti tatas atthi bhāvam jānāmi manussa lokam pana āgacchanti na āgacchanti iti  idam pucchantaḥ yadi vā te bhante ti ādim āha sa byābajjhā ati sa dukkhā samuccheda ppahānena
translated: by which you say this? Then I know their existence, but I do not know whether they come to the human world or not.

original: appahīnacetasikadukkhā. Āgantāroti upapattivasena āgantāro. Abyābajjhāti samucchinnadukkhā.
analyzed: appahīna cetasika dukkhāḥ āgantāraḥ ti upapatti vasena āgantāraḥ abyābajjhā ati samucchinna dukkhā
translated: Asking this, he said: “If, venerable sir, there are gods … .” With suffering means with pain. With their minds not yet rid of it means with mental pain not yet abandoned by the complete destruction of the underlying tendency to lust.🔽Come means come by rebirth. Without suffering means without pain.

original: Anāgantāroti upapattivasena anāgantāro.
analyzed: anāgantāraḥ ti upapatti vasena anāgantāraḥ
translated: Not come means not come by rebirth.

original: 381. Pahotīti sakkoti. Rājā hi puññavantampi lābhasakkārasampannaṃ yathā na koci🔽upasaṅkamati, evaṃ karonto tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ sakkoti. Taṃ apuññavantampi sakalagāmaṃ🔽piṇḍāya caritvā yāpanamattaṃ alabhantaṃ yathā lābhasakkārasampanno hoti, evaṃ karonto🔽tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ sakkoti. Brahmacariyavantampi itthīhi saddhiṃ sampayojetvā sīlavināsaṃ
analyzed: pahoti iti sakkoti rājā hi puññavantam pi lābha sakkāra sampannam yathā na koci  upasaṅkamati evam karonto tamhā ṭhānā cāvetum sakkoti tam apuññavantam pi sakala gāmam  piṇḍāya caritvā yāpana mattam a labhantam yathā lābha sakkāra sampannaḥ hoti evam karontaḥ  tamhā ṭhānā cāvetum sakkoti brahmacariyavantam pi itthīhi saddhim sampayojetvā sīla vināsam
translated: He can expel means he can expel him from that place. For a king can expel a meritorious man who is honoured with gain and honour so that no one will approach him. He can expel an unmeritorious man so that he will be honoured with gain and honour, by making him go round the whole village for alms and get just enough to live on. He can expel a man who is virtuous so that he will break his virtue, by making him associate with women.

original: pāpento balakkārena vā uppabbājento tamhā ṭhānā cāvetuṃ sakkoti. Abrahmacariyavantampi🔽sampannakāmaguṇaṃ amaccaṃ bandhanāgāraṃ pavesetvā itthīnaṃ mukhampi passituṃ adento🔽tamhā ṭhānā cāveti nāma. Raṭṭhato pana yaṃ icchati, taṃ pabbājeti nāma.🔽Dassanāyapi nappahontīti kāmāvacare tāva abyābajjhe deve sabyābajjhā devā cakkhuviññāṇadassanāyapi
analyzed: pāpentaḥ balakkārena vā uppabbājentaḥ tamhā ṭhānā cāvetum sakkoti a brahmacariyavantam pi 🔽sampanna kāma guṇam amaccam bandhanāgāram pavesetvā itthīnam mukham pi passitum a dentaḥ 🔽tamhā ṭhānā cāvā iti nāma raṭṭhataḥ pana yam icchati tam pabbājeti nāma 🔽dassanāya pi na ppahonti iti kāmāvacare tāva abyābajjhe deve sa byābajjhā devā cakkhu viññāṇa dassanāya pi
translated: He can banish means that he can banish from his own country. For a king can banish from his own country anyone who is meritorious and has gain and honour, so that no one will approach him. He can banish from his own country anyone who is not meritorious and who, after wandering for alms in the whole village, can barely manage to keep body and soul together, so that he will have gain and honour. He can banish from his country anyone who is virtuous, after making him break his virtue by forcing him to have intercourse with women, or after expelling him from the monkhood by force. He can banish from his country anyone who is not celibate, after putting him in prison with all the requisites for sensual pleasures and not allowing him to see the face of a woman. But he can banish from the kingdom anyone he likes.

original: nappahonti. Kasmā? Arahato tattha ṭhānābhāvato. Rūpāvacare pana ekavimānasmiṃyeva🔽tiṭṭhanti ca nisīdanti cāti cakkhuviññāṇadassanāya pahonti, etehi diṭṭhaṃ pana sallakkhitaṃ🔽paṭividdhaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ daṭṭhuṃ sallakkhituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ na sakkontīti ñāṇacakkhunā
analyzed: na pahonti kasmai arahataḥ tattha ṭhāna abhāvato rūpāvacare pana eka vimānasmiṃ yeva  tiṭṭhanti ca nisīdanti ca ati cakkhu viññāṇa dassanāya pahonti etehi diṭṭham pana sallakkhitam  paṭividdham lakkhaṇam daṭṭhum sallakkhitum paṭivijjhitum na sakkonti iti ñāṇa cakkhunā
translated: Why? Because there is no standing place for an Arahant there. But in the fine-material sphere they stand and sit in a single mansion.🔽So they are able to see with eye-consciousness. But they are unable to see with the knowledge-eye the characteristics of what is seen, considered, and penetrated by them.

original: dassanāya nappahonti, uparideve ca cakkhuviññāṇadassanenāpīti.

original: upahato pabbajjampi na labhati. Tathāgatassa pana catasso hatthaṅguliyo pañcapi pādaṅguliyo

analyzed: uddham patiṭṭhita gopphaka ttā ussaṅkhā pādāḥ assa ati ussaṅkha pādaḥ aññesam hi piṭṭhi pāde  gopphakāḥ honti tena tesam pādāḥ āṇi baddhāḥ viya thaddhāḥ honti na yathāsukham parivattanti  gacchantānam pāda talāni na dissanti tathāgatassa pana abhiruhitvā upari gopphakā

original: Eṇijaṅghoti eṇimigasadisajaṅgho maṃsussadena paripuṇṇajaṅgho, na ekato baddhapiṇḍikamaṃso,

translated: He has the calves of an antelope: his calves are full of good flesh, unlike the flesh of a bundle tied on,

analyzed: samantataḥ sama saṇṭhitena maṃsena parikkhittāhi su vaṭṭitāhi sāli gabbha sadisāhi jaṅghāhi

translated: He is endowed with calves like an antelope’s, is the meaning.🔽He has no protruding belly: he has no belly that protrudes,🔽for other people are either bent or dwarfed. In the case of those who are bent, the upper part of the body is incomplete,

original: Usabhavāraṇādīnaṃ viya suvaṇṇapadumakaṇṇikasadise kose ohitaṃ paṭicchannaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ assāti kosohitavatthaguyho. Vatthaguyhanti vatthena gūhitabbaṃ aṅgajātaṃ vuccati.
