analyzed: imehi kho bho saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ ti bho ācariyaḥ imehi dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi  saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ samannāgataḥ devanagare samussita ratana vicittam suvaṇṇa toraṇam viya
translated: “Sir, he is endowed with these thirty-two marks of a Great Man” means, sir, teacher, he, the Blessed One, is endowed with these thirty-two marks of a Great Man,🔽like a golden gateway decorated with various jewels in the city of the gods,

original: yojanasatubbedho sabbapāliphullo pāricchattako viya selantaramhi supupphitasālarukkho
analyzed: yojana satu bedhaḥ sabba pāli phullo pāricchattakaḥ viya selantaramhi su pupphita sāla rukkho
translated: like a coral tree in full bloom in the middle of a rock,

original: viya tārāgaṇapaṭimaṇḍitagaganatalamiva ca attano sirivibhavena lokaṃ ālokaṃ kurumāno
analyzed: tārā gaṇa paṭimaṇḍita gagana talam iva ca siri vibhavena lokam ālokam kurumānaḥ
translated: and as if lighting up the world with his own glory,

original: viya caratīti imatthampi dīpetvā kiriyācāraṃ ācikkhituṃ gacchanto kho panātiādimāha.
analyzed: viya carati iti imattham pi dīpetvā kiriyā ācāram ācikkhitum gacchantaḥ kho pana iti ādim āha
translated: he went on his way. In order to illustrate this meaning and to show the mode of action, the Blessed One said: “As he was going along” .

original: 387. Dakkhiṇenāti buddhānañhi ṭhatvā vā nisīditvā vā nipajjitvā vā gamanaṃ abhinīharantānaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇena ati buddhānam hi ṭhatvā vā nisīditvā vā nipajjitvā vā gamanam abhinīharantānam
translated: . “To the south”: for when Buddhas go, stand, sit, or lie down,

original: dakkhiṇapādova purato hoti. Satatapāṭihāriyaṃ kiretaṃ. Nātidūre pādaṃ uddharatīti
analyzed: dakkhiṇa pādaḥ uva puratas hoti satata pāṭihāriyam na atidūre pādam uddharati iti
translated: their right side is always turned. This is a miracle that is always manifest.

original: taṃ dakkhiṇapādaṃ na atidūre ṭhapessāmīti uddharati. Atidūrañhi abhihariyamāne dakkhiṇapādena
analyzed: tam dakkhiṇa pādam na atidūre ṭhapessāmi iti uddharati atidūram hi abhihariyamāne dakkhiṇa pādena
translated: “He did not lift his foot too far”: he lifted it thinking, “I will place the right foot not too far away.” For if the right foot is lifted too far,

original: vāmapādo ākaḍḍhiyamāno gaccheyya, dakkhiṇapādopi dūraṃ gantuṃ na sakkuṇeyya, āsanneyeva
analyzed: vāma pādaḥ ākaḍḍhiyamānaḥ gaccheyya dakkhiṇa pādaḥ api dūram gantum na sakkuṇeyya
translated: the left foot is dragged along and goes too far, and the right foot is unable to go so far. It would come down too near.

original: patiṭṭhaheyya, evaṃ sati padavicchedo nāma hoti. Dakkhiṇapāde pana pamāṇeneva uddhate
analyzed: patiṭṭhaheyya evam sati pada vicchedaḥ nāma hoti dakkhiṇa pāde pana pamāṇena iva uddhate
translated: In that case there would be a gap between the two feet. But when the right foot is lifted to the right measure,

original: vāmapādopi pamāṇeneva uddhariyati, pamāṇena uddhato patiṭṭhahantopi pamāṇeyeva patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: vāma pādaḥ api pamāṇena iva uddhariyati pamāṇena uddhataḥ patiṭṭhahantaḥ api pamāṇeya iva patiṭṭhāti
translated: the left foot is lifted to the right measure too. And when it comes down, it comes down to the right measure.

original: Evamanena tathāgatassa dakkhiṇapādakiccaṃ vāmapādena niyamitaṃ, vāmapādakiccaṃ dakkhiṇapādena
analyzed: evam anena tathāgatassa dakkhiṇa pāda kiccam vāma pādena niyamitam vāma pāda kiccam dakkhiṇa pādena
translated: So the right foot of the Tathāgata is controlled by the left foot, and the left foot is controlled by the right foot.

original: niyamitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: niyamitan ti veditabbam
translated: This is how it should be understood.

original: Nātisīghanti divā vihārabhattatthāya gacchanto bhikkhu viya na atisīghaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: na ati sīghanti divā vihāra bhatta tthāya gacchantaḥ bhikkhu viya na ati sīgham gacchati
translated: Not too fast: he does not go too fast like a monk going to the day-time lodging or to the meal.

original: Nātisaṇikanti yathā pacchato āgacchanto okāsaṃ na labhati, evaṃ na atisaṇikaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: na ati saṇikam ti yathā pacchatas āgacchantaḥ okāsam na labhati evam na ati saṇikam gacchati
translated: Not too slow: he does not go too slow like one who does not get out of the way of those who are coming behind.

original: Adduvena adduvanti jaṇṇukena jaṇṇukaṃ, na satthiṃ unnāmetīti gambhīre udake gacchanto🔽viya na ūruṃ unnāmeti. Na onāmetīti rukkhasākhāchedanadaṇḍaṅkusapādo viya na pacchato🔽osakkāpeti. Na sannāmetīti obaddhānābaddhaṭṭhānehi pādaṃ koṭṭento viya na thaddhaṃ
analyzed: adduvena adduvanti jaṇṇukena jaṇṇukam na satthim unnāmeti iti gambhīre udake gacchantaḥ  viya naḥ ūrum unnāmeti na onāmeti iti rukkha sākhā chedana daṇḍa ṅkusa pādaḥ viya na pacchatas  na sannāmā iti iti obaddha anābaddha ṭṭhānehi pādam koṭṭentaḥ viya na
translated: With one foot placed on the other: he does not go like one walking in deep water, raising the feet high.🔽Not dragging the feet: he does not go dragging the feet behind like one whose feet are tied with ropes.🔽Not shaking the body: he does not go shaking the body like one who is playing a game with a stick and a ball.

original: karoti. Na vināmetīti yantarūpakaṃ kīḷāpento viya na ito cito ca cāleti. Adharakāyovāti
analyzed: karoti na vināma iti iti adhara kāya uvāti
translated: Not shaking the head: he does not go shaking the head like one who is playing a game with a ball on the end of a string.

original: heṭṭhimakāyova iñjati, uparimakāyo nāvāya ṭhapitasuvaṇṇapaṭimā viya niccalo hoti.
analyzed: heṭṭhima kāyaḥ uva iñjati uparima kāyaḥ nāvāya ṭhapita suvaṇṇa paṭimā viya niccalaḥ hoti
translated: The lower part of his body quivers, but the upper part remains motionless like a golden image set on a pedestal.

original: Dūre ṭhatvā olokento hi buddhānaṃ ṭhitabhāvaṃ vā gamanabhāvaṃ vā na jānāti. Kāyabalenāti
analyzed: dūre hi buddhānam ṭhita bhāvam vā gamana bhāvam vā na jānāti kāya balena ati
translated: For when he looks at the Blessed One from a distance, he does not know whether he is standing or walking.

original: bāhā khipanto sarīrato sedehi muccantehi na kāyabalena gacchati. Sabbakāyenevāti
analyzed: bāhā khipantaḥ sarīrataḥ sedehi muccantehi na kāya balena gacchati sabba kāyena iva ati
translated: By the power of his body: he does not walk by the power of his body, shaking his arms and freeing his body from the dust.

original: gīvaṃ aparivattetvā rāhulovāde vuttanāgāpalokitavaseneva apaloketi.🔽Na uddhantiādīsu nakkhattāni gaṇento viya na uddhaṃ ulloketi, naṭṭhaṃ kākaṇikaṃ vā
analyzed: gīvam a parivattetvā rāhulaḥ vāde vutta nāga apalokita vasena iva apaloketi  na uddhan ti ādīsu nakkhattāni gaṇentaḥ viya na uddham ulloketi naṭṭham kākaṇikam vā
translated: By the whole body: he looks back without turning his neck, as if he were looking back over his shoulder, as described in the Rāhula Sutta .🔽He does not look up, as if counting the stars;🔽he does not look down, as if searching for a lost ring or coin;

original: māsakaṃ vā pariyesanto viya na adho oloketi, na hatthiassādayo passanto viya ito🔽cito ca vipekkhamāno gacchati. Yugamattanti navavidatthimatte cakkhūni ṭhapetvā gacchanto
analyzed: māsakam vā pariyesantaḥ viya na adhas oloketi na hatthi assa ādayo passantaḥ viya itas  citaḥ ca vipekkhamānaḥ gacchati nava vidatthi matte cakkhūni ṭhapetvā gacchantaḥ
translated: he does not look about, as if he were looking for an elephant, horse, etc.🔽He looks only a plough-yoke’s length away, as if he were a well-trained thoroughbred elephant.

original: yugamattaṃ pekkhati nāma, bhagavāpi yuge yutto sudantaājānīyo viya ettakaṃ passanto
analyzed: yuga mattam pekkhati nāma bhagavā api yuge yuttaḥ sudanta ājānīyaḥ viya ettakam passanto
translated: The Blessed One looks only that far,

original: gacchati. Tato cassa uttarīti yugamattato paraṃ na passatīti na vattabbo. Na hi kuṭṭaṃ🔽vā kavāṭaṃ vā gaccho vā latā vā āvarituṃ sakkoti, atha khvassa anāvaraṇañāṇassa anekāni🔽cakkavāḷasahassāni ekaṅgaṇāneva honti. Antaragharanti heṭṭhā mahāsakuludāyisutte🔽indakhīlato paṭṭhāya antaragharaṃ, idha gharaummārato paṭṭhāya veditabbaṃ. Na kāyantiādi
analyzed: gacchati tatas ca ssa uttarī iti yuga mattataḥ param na passati iti na vattabbaḥ na hi kuṭṭam  vā kavāṭam vā gacchaḥ vā latā vā āvaritum sakkoti atha khvassa an āvaraṇa ñāṇassa anekāni  cakkavāḷa sahassāni honti heṭṭhā mahā sakuludāyi sutte  indakhīlataḥ paṭṭhāya antara gharam ghara ommārataḥ paṭṭhāya veditabbam na kāyantiādi
translated: He does not see beyond a yoke’s length, it should not be said. For a wall, a door, a tree, a creeper, cannot obstruct it. On the contrary, the unobstructed knowledge has many thousands of world-spheres as its domain.🔽The interior of a house: in the Mahāsakuludāyi Sutta the interior of a house is from the Indakūṭa pillar downwards. Here it should be understood as from the door-sill onwards. Not with the body: not with the body.

original: pakatiiriyapatheneva pavisatīti dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Daliddamanussānaṃ nīcagharakaṃ🔽pavisantepi hi tathāgate chadanaṃ vā uggacchati, pathavī vā ogacchati, bhagavā pana🔽pakatigamaneneva gacchati. Nātidūreti atidūre parivattantena hi ekaṃ dve padavāre🔽piṭṭhibhāgena gantvā nisīditabbaṃ hoti. Nāccāsanneti accāsanne parivattantena ekaṃ
analyzed: pakati iriya pathena iva pavisati iti dassana attham vuttam dalidda manussānam nīca gharakam 🔽pavisante api hi tathāgate chadanam vai uggacchati pathavī vai ogacchati bhagavā pana 🔽pakati gamanena iva gacchati na atidūra iti atidūre parivattantena hi ekam dve pada vāre 🔽piṭṭhi bhāgena gantvā nisīditabbam hoti na acca āsanne iti acca āsanne parivattantena ekam
translated: He does not see beyond a yoke’s length. But it should not be said that he does not see beyond a yoke’s length. For a wall, a door, a tree, a creeper, or anything else cannot obstruct his knowledge. On the contrary, his unobstructed knowledge extends to many thousands of world-spheres as if they were one single world-sphere. “In a house”: in the Mahāsakuludāyi Sutta the “house” is the world-sphere from the earth to the Brahma-world. Here it should be understood as the house itself. “Not by the body”: this is said in order to show that he enters by the normal human way. For when poor people enter a low-class house, the roof may cave in or the earth may open up. But the Exalted One enters by the normal human way. “Not too far”: if he turns too far away, he has to go back a step or two with his back to the seat. “Not too near”: if he turns too near, he has to go forward a step or two.

original: dve padavāre purato gantvā nisīditabbaṃ hoti. Tasmā yasmiṃ padavāre ṭhitena purato
analyzed: dve padavāre puratas gantvā nisīditabbam hoti tasmai yasmin padavāre ṭhitena puratas
translated: He should sit down in the place where he would stand if he were to stand in the place where he is sitting.

original: vā pacchato vā agantvā nisīditabbaṃ hoti, tattha parivattati.
analyzed: vā pacchatas vā a gantvā nisīditabbam hoti tattha parivattati
translated: That is why it is said that he “reverses” the place where he is standing.

original: Pāṇināti kaṭivātābādhiko viya na āsanaṃ hatthehi gahetvā nisīdati. Pakkhipatīti yo🔽kiñci kammaṃ katvā kīḷanto ṭhitakova patati, yopi orimaṃ aṅgaṃ nissāya nisinno ghaṃsanto
analyzed: pāṇinā ati kaṭi vāta ābādhikaḥ viya na āsanam hatthehi gahetvā nisīdati pakkhipati iti yaḥ  kiñci kammam katvā kīḷanto ṭhitakaḥ uva patati yaḥ api orimam aṅgam nissāya nisinnaḥ ghaṃsanto
translated: With his hand: he does not sit down holding on to the seat with his hands, as if he had a pain in the side.

original: yāva pārimaṅgā gacchati, pārimaṅgaṃ vā nissāya nisinno tatheva yāva orimaṅgā āgacchati,
analyzed: yāva pārimaṅgāḥ gacchati pārimaṅgam vā nissāya nisinnaḥ tathā iva yāva orimaṅgāḥ āgacchati
translated: He “throws” himself down: he falls down as if he were playing, having done some work, and he sits down leaning on one end and moving to the other end, or he sits down leaning on the other end and moving to the first end.🔽In all these cases he throws his body on the seat.

original: sabbo so āsane kāyaṃ pakkhipati nāma. Bhagavā pana evaṃ akatvā āsanassa majjhe olambakaṃ🔽dhārento viya tūlapicuṃ ṭhapento viya saṇikaṃ nisīdati. Hatthakukkuccanti pattamukhavaṭṭiyaṃ
analyzed: sabbaḥ saḥ āsane kāyam pakkhipati nāma bhagavā pana evam a katvā āsanassa majjhe olambakam  dhārentaḥ viya tūla picum ṭhapentaḥ viya saṇikam nisīdati hattha kukkuccanti patta mukha vaṭṭiyam
translated: But the Blessed One does not do this. He sits down gently, as if he were placing a tuft of kapok or cotton wool on the seat.

original: udakabinduṭhapanaṃ makkhikabījaniyā paṇṇacchedanaphālanādi hatthena asaṃyatakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: udaka bindu ṭhapanam makkhika bījaniyā paṇṇa chedana phālana ādi hatthena asaṃyata karaṇam
translated: With his hand: he does not hold the bowl in his hand, nor does he hold the bowl-rest in his hand, nor does he hold the water- strainer in his hand, nor does he hold the water-pot in his hand, nor does he hold the drinking-water vessel in his hand, nor does he hold the refuse bucket in his hand, nor does he hold the spittoon in his hand, nor does he hold the foot-stool in his hand, nor does he hold the leaning-board in his hand, nor does he hold the bed in his hand, nor does he hold the chair in his hand, nor does he hold the mattress in his hand, nor does he hold the pillow in his hand, nor does he hold the mosquito-curtain in his hand, nor does he hold the sunshade in his hand, nor does he hold the sandals in his hand, nor does he hold the robe in his hand.

original: Pādakukkuccanti pādena bhūmighaṃsanādi asaṃyatakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: pāda kukkuccanti pādena bhūmi ghaṃsana ādi asaṃyata karaṇam
translated: “Foot-dragging” is the state of being unrestrained in such actions as kicking up the dust of the ground with the foot.

original: Na chambhatīti na bhāyati. Na kampatīti na osīdati. Na vedhatīti na calati. Na paritassatīti
analyzed: na chambhati iti na bhāyati na kampati iti na osīdati na vedhati iti na calati na paritassati iti
translated: “Does not tremble” : does not fear. “Does not quake” : does not lose his composure. “Does not waver” : does not move. “Does not become anxious” :

original: bhayaparitassanāyapi taṇhāparitassanāyapi na paritassati. Ekacco hi dhammakathādīnaṃ
analyzed: bhaya paritassanāya api taṇhā paritassanāya api na paritassati ekaccaḥ hi dhamma kathā ādīnam
translated: he does not become anxious either through fear or through craving. For one person, when people come to him for the sake of a talk on the Dhamma, etc.,

original: atthāya āgantvā manussesu vanditvā ṭhitesu “sakkhissāmi nu kho tesaṃ cittaṃ gaṇhanto
analyzed: atthāya āgantvā manussesu vanditvā ṭhitesu sakkhissāmi nu kho tesam cittam gaṇhantaḥ
translated: and pay homage to him, he becomes anxious, thinking: “Will I be able to grasp their minds

original: dhammaṃ vā kathetuṃ, pañhaṃ vā pucchito vissajjetuṃ, bhattānumodanaṃ vā kātu”nti🔽bhayaparitassanāya paritassati. Ekacco “manāpā nu kho me yāgu āgacchissati, manāpaṃ
analyzed: dhammam vā kathetum pañham vā pucchitaḥ vissajjetum bhattā anumodanam vā kātum ti  bhaya paritassanāya paritassati ekaccaḥ manāpā nu khalu me yāgu āgacchissati manāpam
translated: and expound the Dhamma, or answer the questions they ask, or offer the blessing?”🔽This is anxiety through fear. Another becomes anxious, thinking: “Will I get a tasty gruel? A tasty

original: antarakhajjaka”nti vā taṇhāparitassanāya paritassati. Tadubhayampi tassa natthīti
analyzed: antara khajjakanti vā taṇhā paritassanāya paritassati tat ubhayam pi tassa natthi iti
translated: mid-day meal?” This is anxiety through craving. Since he has none of this anxiety,

original: na paritassati. Vivekāvaṭṭoti viveke nibbāne āvaṭṭamānaso hutvā. Vivekavattotipi
analyzed: na paritassati viveka avaṭṭaḥ ti viveke nibbāne āvaṭṭa mānasaḥ hutvā viveka vattā tipi
translated: he does not become anxious. “Inclined to seclusion” : inclined to the seclusion of Nibbāna.

original: pāṭho, vivekavattayutto hutvāti attho. Vivekavattaṃ nāma katabhattakiccassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ vivekavatta yuttaḥ hutvā iti atthaḥ vivekavattam nāma kata bhatta kiccassa bhikkhuno
translated: The meaning is that he is endowed with the practice of seclusion. The practice of seclusion is this. After a monk has finished his meal,

original: divāvihāre samathavipassanāvasena mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā nisīdanaṃ.
analyzed: divāvihāre samatha vipassanā vasena mūlakammaṭṭhānam gahetvā pallaṅkam ābhujitvā nisīdanam
translated: he should take up the basic meditation subject by way of serenity and insight during his day-sleep. He should sit cross-legged with his meditation subject.

original: Evaṃ nisinnassa hi iriyāpatho upasanto hoti.
analyzed: evam nisinnassa hi iriyāpathaḥ upasantaḥ hoti
translated: For his posture is then calm.

original: Na pattaṃ unnāmetītiādīsu ekacco pattamukhavaṭṭiyā udakadānaṃ āharanto viya pattaṃ🔽unnāmeti, eko pādapiṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhapento viya onāmeti, eko baddhaṃ katvā gaṇhāti, eko🔽ito cito ca phandāpeti, evaṃ akatvā ubhohi hatthehi gahetvā īsakaṃ nāmetvā udakaṃ
analyzed: na pattam unnāmeti iti ādīsu ekaccaḥ patta mukha vaṭṭiyā udaka dānam āharantaḥ viya pattam  unnāma iti ekaḥ pāda piṭṭhiyam ṭhapentaḥ viya onāma iti ekaḥ baddham katvā gaṇhāti ekaḥ  itas citas ca phandāpā iti evam a katvā ubhohi hatthehi gahetvā īsakam nāmetvā udakaṃ
translated: He should not hold his bowl too high: some people hold their bowls too high as if they were giving a water-pouring ceremony with the bowl.🔽One should not do this. One should not hold it too low, as if one were placing the foot on a stair. One should not hold it tightly, as if one were holding a snake.🔽One should not shake it about, as if one were winnowing. Instead, one should hold it with both hands, raise it a little, and receive the water.

original: paṭiggaṇhātīti attho. Na samparivattakanti parivattetvā paṭhamameva pattapiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: paṭiggaṇhāti iti atthaḥ na samparivattakam ti parivattetvā paṭhamam eva patta piṭṭhim
translated: One should not turn it over and over, washing the back first.

original: na dhovati. Nātidūreti yathā nisinnāsanato dūre patati, na evaṃ chaḍḍeti. Nāccāsanneti
analyzed: na dhovati na atidūra iti yathā nisinna āsanataḥ dūre patati na evam chaḍḍeti na at ca āsannā iti
translated: One should not throw it too far away, so that it falls some distance from the seat where one is sitting. Nor should one throw it too near.

original: pādamūleyeva na chaḍḍeti. Vicchaḍḍayamānoti vikiranto, yathā paṭiggāhako temati, na evaṃ chaḍḍeti.
analyzed: na chaḍḍeti vicchaḍḍayamānā iva na chaḍḍeti vicchaḍḍayamānā iti vikirantaḥ yathā paṭiggāhako naḥ evam chaḍḍeti
translated: he does not throw it away at the foot of the bed.🔽He does not throw it away in such a way that the recipient would be embarrassed.

original: Nātithokanti yathā ekacco pāpiccho appicchataṃ dassento muṭṭhimattameva gaṇhāti,🔽na evaṃ. Atibahunti yāpanamattato atirekaṃ. Byañjanamattāyāti byañjanassa mattā nāma
analyzed: yathā ekaccaḥ pāpicchaḥ appicchatam dassentaḥ muṭṭhimattam eva gaṇhāti  na evam yāpana mattataḥ atirekam byañjana mattāya ati byañjanassa mattā nāma
translated: He does not take too little, as a certain lustful person, pretending to be free from greed, takes only a handful.🔽He does not take too much, more than is needed for sustenance.🔽“Just for the sake of the flavor” means that the flavor is the fourth part of the rice.

original: odanato catuttho bhāgo. Ekacco hi bhatte manāpe bhattaṃ bahuṃ gaṇhāti, byañjane manāpe
analyzed: odanataḥ catutthaḥ bhāgaḥ ekaccaḥ hi bhatte manāpe bhattam bahum gaṇhāti byañjane manāpe
translated: For some people, when the rice is good, they take much rice and a little curry;🔽when the curry is good, they take much curry and a little rice.

original: byañjanaṃ bahuṃ. Satthā pana tathā na gaṇhāti. Na ca byañjanenāti amanāpañhi byañjanaṃ🔽ṭhapetvā bhattameva bhuñjanto, bhattaṃ vā ṭhapetvā byañjanameva khādanto byañjanena
analyzed: byañjanam bahum satthā pana tathā na gaṇhāti na ca byañjanena ati amanāpam hi byañjanam  ṭhapetvā bhattam eva bhuñjantaḥ bhattam vā ṭhapetvā byañjanam eva khādantaḥ byañjanena
translated: But the Teacher does not take in this way.🔽He does not take too much curry, for if he were to eat only rice, leaving aside the curry, or if he were to eat only curry, leaving aside the rice, he would be said to take too much curry.

original: ālopaṃ atināmeti nāma. Satthā ekantarikaṃ byañjanaṃ gaṇhāti, bhattampi byañjanampi
analyzed: ālopam atināma iti nāma satthā ekantarikam byañjanam gaṇhāti bhattam pi byañjanam pi
translated: The Teacher takes the curry in a single mouthful together with the rice.

original: ekatova niṭṭhanti. Dvattikkhattunti tathāgatassa hi puthujivhāya dantānaṃ upanītabhojanaṃ
analyzed: ekatas va niṭṭhanti dvatti khattunti tathāgatassa hi puthu jivhāya dantānam upanīta bhojanam
translated: For a Tathāgata, when food is brought to his mouth with the tongue of an ordinary man,

original: dvattikkhattuṃ dantehi phuṭṭhamattameva saṇhakaraṇīyapiṭṭhavilepanaṃ viya hoti, tasmā
analyzed: dvattikkhattum dantehi phuṭṭha mattam eva saṇha karaṇīya piṭṭha vilepanam viya hoti tasmā
translated: It is like a thick ointment for the back, which is only touched by the teeth twenty-two times.

original: evamāha. Na mukhe avasiṭṭhāti pokkharapatte patitaudakabindu viya vinivattitvā paragalameva
analyzed: evam āha na mukhe avasiṭṭhāti pokkhara patte patita audaka bindu viya vinivattitvā para galam eva
translated: Therefore he said, “It does not remain in the mouth.” It does not remain in the mouth, but falls out of the mouth and goes to another’s stomach, like a drop of water on a lotus leaf.

original: yāti, tasmā avasiṭṭhā na hoti. Rasapaṭisaṃvedīti madhuratittakadukādirasaṃ jānāti.🔽Buddhānañhi antamaso pānīyepi dibbojā pakkhittāva hoti, tena nesaṃ sabbattheva raso
analyzed: yāti tasmai avasiṭṭhā na hoti rasa paṭisaṃvedī iti madhura tittaka duka ādi rasam jānāti  buddhānam hi antamasaḥ pānīye pi dibbojā pakkhittā ava hoti tena nesam sabbattha iva rasaḥ
translated: Therefore he said, “It does not remain in the mouth.” “He experiences the taste” : he knows the taste of sweet, sour, etc.

original: pākaṭo hoti, rasagedho pana natthi.
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ hoti rasa gedhaḥ pana natthi
translated: For the Buddhas have divine food even in their drinking water. Therefore the taste of all their food is clear to them. But they do not have a “taste-obsession.”🔽“Endowed with eight factors” : endowed with the eight factors mentioned in the passage beginning, “Not for amusement” .

original: Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatanti “neva davāyā”ti vuttehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgataṃ. Visuddhimagge🔽panassa vinicchayo āgatoti sabbāsavasutte vuttametaṃ. Hatthesu dhotesūti satthā kiṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatanti na iva davāya ati vuttehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgatam visuddhi magge  pana assa vinicchayaḥ āgataḥ ti sabbāsavasutte vuttam etam hatthesu dhotesu iti satthā kim
translated: But the exposition of this is given in the Visuddhimagga.

original: karoti? Paṭhamaṃ pattassa gahaṇaṭṭhānaṃ dhovati. Tattha pattaṃ gahetvā sukhumajālahatthaṃ
analyzed: karoti paṭhamam pattassa gahaṇa ṭṭhānam dhovati tattha pattam gahetvā sukhuma jālahattham
translated: “When he has washed his hands” : what does the Teacher do? He first washes the place where he will hold the bowl. Then, taking the bowl, he washes his delicate webbed fingers,

original: pesetvā dve vāre sañcāreti. Ettāvatā pokkharapatte patitaudakaṃ viya vinivattitvā🔽gacchati. Na ca anatthikoti yathā ekacco pattaṃ ādhārake ṭhapetvā patte udakaṃ na
analyzed: pesetvā dve vāre sañcāreti ettāvatā pokkhara patte patita odakam viya vinivattitvā  gacchati na ca anatthikaḥ ti yathā ekaccaḥ pattam ādhārake ṭhapetvā patte udakam na
translated: and he pours it out twice. At this stage the water goes out like water falling on a lotus leaf.

original: puñchati, raje patante ajjhupekkhati, na evaṃ karoti. Na ca ativelānurakkhīti yathā
analyzed: puñchati raje patante ajjhupekkhati na evam karoti na ca ativelā anurakkhī iti yathā
translated: And he does not do it without purpose: unlike one who puts the bowl on a stand and does not pour out the water in the bowl, who looks on while the bowl gets dirty, he does not do it in this way.

original: ekacco pamāṇātikkantaṃ ārakkhaṃ ṭhapeti, bhuñjitvā vā patte udakaṃ puñchitvā cīvarabhogantaraṃ
analyzed: ekaccaḥ pamāṇa atikkantam ārakkham ṭhapeti bhuñjitvā vā patte udakam puñchitvā cīvara bhogantaram
translated: And he does not keep it too long: unlike one who keeps the bowl too long, who, after eating, pours out the water in the bowl, puts the bowl in the fold of his upper robe,

original: pavesetvā pattaṃ udarena akkamitvā gaṇhāti, na evaṃ karoti.🔽Na ca anumodanassāti yo hi bhuttamattova dārakesu bhattatthāya rodantesu chātajjhattesu
analyzed: pavesetvā pattam udarena akkamitvā gaṇhāti na evam karoti  na ca anumodanassa ati yaḥ hi bhutta mattaḥ uva dārakesu bhatta atthāya rodantesu chāta jjhattesu
translated: and then takes it, he does not do it in this way.

original: manussesu bhuñjitvā anāgatesveva anumodanaṃ ārabhati, tato sabbakammāni chaḍḍetvā
analyzed: manussesu bhuñjitvā anāgatesu eva anumodanam ārabhati tatas sabba kammāni chaḍḍetvā
translated: And he does not do it before the expression of appreciation: unlike one who, as soon as he has eaten, starts the expression of appreciation before the children who are crying for food, before the people who are standing there with their hands raised,

original: ekacce āgacchanti, ekacce anāgatāva honti, ayaṃ kālaṃ atināmeti. Yopi manussesu āgantvā
analyzed: ekacce āgacchanti ekacce anāgatāḥ ava honti ayam kālam atināma iti yaḥ api manussesu āgantvā
translated: and then, after some of them have given up and gone away and some have not yet come, he goes beyond the proper time, and unlike one who, after coming among the people,

original: anumodanatthāya vanditvā nisinnesu anumodanaṃ akatvāva “kathaṃ tissa, kathaṃ phussa,
analyzed: anumodana tthāya vanditvā nisinnesu anumodanam a katvā ava katham tissa katham phussa
translated: He does not make his thanksgiving but instead starts a conversation with them, saying, “How is Tissa? How is Phussa?

original: kathaṃ sumana, kathaṃ tisse, kathaṃ phusse, kathaṃ sumane, kaccittha arogā, sassaṃ🔽sampanna”ntiādiṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, ayaṃ anumodanassa kālaṃ atināmeti,
analyzed: katham sumana katham tisse katham phusse katham sumane kaccittha arogā sassam  sampanna nti ādim pāṭiyekkam katham samuṭṭhāpeti ayam anumodanassa kālam atināmeti
translated: How is Sumana? How is Tissa’s family? How is Phussa’s family? How is Sumana’s family? Are you all well? Is the harvest good?🔽Is there enough rain? Are cattle and crops thriving? Are you all living peaceably together? Are you all living in concord? Are you all living in concord and unity?” This is called “he outstays his welcome at the thanksgiving.”

original: manussānaṃ pana okāsaṃ ñatvā āyācitakāle karonto nātināmeti nāma, satthā tathā karoti.
analyzed: manussānam pana okāsam ñatvā āyācita kāle karontaḥ na atināma iti nāma satthā tathā karoti
translated: But when he knows the time for people to ask him, he does not outstay his welcome if he makes his thanksgiving then. The Teacher does it in this way.

original: Na taṃ bhattanti kiṃ bhattaṃ nāmetaṃ uttaṇḍulaṃ atikilinnantiādīni vatvā na garahati.🔽Na aññaṃ bhattanti svātanāya vā punadivasāya vā bhattaṃ uppādessāmīti hi anumodanaṃ
analyzed: na tam kim bhattam nāma etam uttaṇḍulam vatvā na garahati  na aññam bhattanti svātanāya vā punadivasāya vā bhattam uppādessāmi iti hi anumodanam
translated: He does not find fault with the meal: he does not find fault with the meal, saying, “This rice is weevily,” “This curry is rancid,” etc.,

original: karonto aññaṃ bhattaṃ paṭikaṅkhati. Yo vā – “yāva mātugāmānaṃ bhattaṃ paccati, tāva
analyzed: karontaḥ aññam bhattam paṭikaṅkhati yaḥ vā yāva mātugāmānam bhattam paccati tāva
translated: He does not expect another meal: when he makes his thanksgiving, expecting a meal tomorrow or the next day, he expects another meal. Or when he thinks, “As long as they are cooking the meal for the women, I shall make my thanksgiving,

original: anumodanaṃ karissāmi, atha me anumodanāvasāne attano pakkabhattatopi thokaṃ dassantī”ti
analyzed: anumodanam karissāmi atha me anumodanā avasāne attanaḥ pakka bhattataḥ pi thokam dassanti iti
translated: and then at the end of my thanksgiving they will give me some of the cooked food,” he expects another meal.

original: anumodanaṃ vaḍḍheti, ayampi paṭikaṅkhati nāma. Satthā na evaṃ karoti. Na ca muccitukāmoti
analyzed: anumodanam vaḍḍheti ayam pi paṭikaṅkhati nāma satthā na evam karoti na ca muccitu kāmo ti
translated: He increases the joy of the assembly. The Teacher does not do this. Nor does he wish to be released.

original: ekacco hi paṭisaṃmuñcitvā gacchati, vegena anubandhitabbo hoti. Satthā pana na evaṃ
analyzed: ekaccaḥ hi paṭisaṃmuñcitvā gacchati vegena anubandhitabbaḥ hoti satthā pana na evam
translated: For some, after being released, go away quickly and have to be followed. But the Teacher does not go like this.

original: gacchati, parisāya majjhe ṭhitova gacchati. Accukkaṭṭhanti yo hi yāva hanukaṭṭhito🔽ukkhipitvā pārupati, tassa accukkaṭṭhaṃ nāma hoti. Yo yāva gopphakā otāretvāva pārupati,
analyzed: gacchati parisāya majjhe ṭhitaḥ uva gacchati accukkaṭṭhanti yaḥ hi yāva hanukaṭṭhitaḥ  ukkhipitvā pārupati tassa accukkaṭṭham nāma hoti yaḥ yāva gopphakā otāretvā ava pārupati
translated: While standing in the middle of the assembly, he goes. Not too high: for some, after lifting up to the jaw,🔽they cover. For them, it is too high. Some, after lowering down to the ankles, cover.

original: tassa accukkaṭṭhaṃ hoti. Yopi ubhato ukkhipitvā udaraṃ vivaritvā yāti, tassapi accukkaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: tassa accukkaṭṭham hoti yaḥ api ubhatas ukkhipitvā udaram vivaritvā yāti tassa api accukkaṭṭham
translated: For them, it is too low. Some, after lifting up on both sides, open the stomach and go. For them, it is

original: hoti. Yo ekaṃsaṃ katvā thanaṃ vivaritvā yāti, tassapi accukkaṭṭhaṃ. Satthā taṃ sabbaṃ na karoti.
analyzed: hoti yaḥ eka aṃsam katvā thanam vivaritvā yāti tassa api accukkaṭṭham satthā tam sabbam na karoti
translated: too low. Some, after making one side, open the place and go. For them, it is too low. The Teacher does not do all that.

original: Allīnanti yathā aññesaṃ sedena tintaṃ allīyati, na evaṃ satthu. Apakaṭṭhanti khalisāṭako
analyzed: yathā aññesam sedena tintam allīyati na evam satthu apakaṭṭhanti khalisāṭako
translated: Not too low: as for others, it is low, being soaked with sweat. Not too high: a dirty robe

original: viya kāyato muccitvāpi na tiṭṭhati. Vātoti verambhavātopi uṭṭhahitvā cāletuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: kāyataḥ muccitvā api na tiṭṭhati vāto ti verambha vātaḥ api uṭṭhahitvā cāletum na sakkoti
translated: and it does not stay away from the body. And the wind cannot stir it, not even the wind of the Verambha storm.🔽Foot-pampering: pampering to the feet by massaging, rubbing, etc.

original: Pādamaṇḍanānuyoganti iṭṭhakāya ghaṃsanādīhi pādasobhānuyogaṃ. Pakkhāletvāti pādeneva
analyzed: pāda maṇḍana anuyogam ti iṭṭhakāya ghaṃsana ādīhi pāda sobha anuyogam pakkhāletvā iti pādena iva
translated: Having washed: having washed one foot with the other.

original: pādaṃ dhovitvā. So neva attabyābādhāyātiādīni na pubbenivāsacetopariyañāṇānaṃ atthitāya
analyzed: pādam dhovitvā saḥ na iva atta byābādhāya ati ādīni na pubbenivāsa cetaḥ pariya ñāṇānaṃ atthitāya
translated: He does not speak about the knowledge of recollecting past lives and the knowledge of the passing away and rebirth of beings because he does not possess them.🔽But he infers from the continuity of their postures and speaks accordingly.

original: vadati, iriyāpathasantataṃ pana disvā anumānena vadati. Dhammanti pariyattidhammaṃ.
analyzed: vadati iriyāpatha santatam pana disvā anumānena vadati dhammanti pariyatti dhammaṃ
translated: Dhamma: the Dhamma of the scriptures.

original: Na ussādetīti kiṃ mahāraṭṭhika, kiṃ mahākuṭumbikātiādīni vatvā gehassitavasena na
analyzed: na ussādeti iti kim mahāraṭṭhika kim mahākuṭumbika ati ādīni vatvā geha sita vasena na
translated: He does not praise: he does not praise by saying, “What a great landowner! What a great householder!”

original: ussādeti. Na apasādetīti “kiṃ, upāsaka, kathaṃ te vihāramaggo ñāto? Kiṃ bhayena nāgacchasi?
analyzed: ussādeti na apasādeti iti kim upāsaka katham te vihāra maggaḥ ñātaḥ kim bhayena na āgacchasi
translated: He does not disparage: he does not disparage by saying, “What, lay follower, how do you know the way to the monastery? Are you not coming because of fear?

original: Na hi bhikkhū kiñci acchinditvā gaṇhanti, mā bhāyī”ti vā “kiṃ tuyhaṃ evaṃ macchariyajīvitaṃ🔽nāmā”ti vā ādīni vatvā gehassitapemena na apasādeti.
analyzed: na hi bhikkhū kiñci a chinditvā gaṇhanti mā bhāyi iti vā kim tuyham evam mad śariya jīvitam 🔽nāma ati vā ādīni vatvā gehassita pemena na apasādeti
translated: The bhikkhus do not take anything by force. Do not be afraid,” or by saying, “What is the use of your living a life of miserliness?”

original: Vissaṭṭhoti siniddho apalibuddho. Viññeyyoti viññāpanīyo pākaṭo, vissaṭṭhattāyeva
analyzed: vissaṭṭhaḥ ti siniddhaḥ apalibuddhaḥ viññeyyaḥ ti viññāpanīyaḥ pākaṭaḥ vissaṭṭha ttāya iva
translated: ‘Distinct’: clear, not confused. ‘To be known’: to be made known, evident. It is ‘to be known’ because it is distinct.

original: cesa viññeyyo hoti. Mañjūti madhuro. Savanīyoti sotasukho, madhurattāyeva cesa savanīyo🔽hoti. Bindūti sampiṇḍito. Avisārīti avisaṭo, binduttāyeva cesa avisārī hoti. Gambhīroti
analyzed: ca isa viññeyyaḥ hoti mañju iti madhuraḥ savanīyaḥ ti sota sukhaḥ madhura ttāya iva ca isa savanīyaḥ  hoti bindu iti sampiṇḍitaḥ avisārī iti a visaṭaḥ ca idam avisārī hoti gambhīraḥ iti
translated: ‘Sweet’: honey-like. ‘To be heard’: pleasant to the ear. It is ‘to be heard’ because it is sweet.🔽‘Distinct’: not confused. It is ‘distinct’ because it is not confused. ‘Deep’:

original: gambhīrasamuṭṭhito. Ninnādīti ninnādavā, gambhīrattāyeva cesa ninnādī hoti. Yathāparisanti
analyzed: gambhīra samuṭṭhitaḥ ninnādī iti ninnādavā gambhīra ttāya iva ca isa ninnādī hoti
translated: arisen from the deep. ‘Resonant’: resounding. It is ‘resonant’ because it is deep. ‘As far as’:

original: cakkavāḷapariyantampi ekābaddhaparisaṃ viññāpeti. Bahiddhāti aṅgulimattampi parisato
analyzed: cakkavāḷa pariyantam pi eka ābaddha parisam viññāpeti bahiddhā ati aṅgulimattam pi parisato
translated: it makes known an unbroken assembly extending to the edge of the world. ‘Not going beyond’: it does not go beyond the assembly even by the width of an eyelash.🔽Therefore, ‘lest this sweet voice be lost for no reason.’ Thus

original: bahiddhā na gacchati. Tasmā? So evarūpo madhurassaro akāraṇā mā nassīti. Iti bhagavato🔽ghoso parisāya matthakeneva carati.
analyzed: bahiddhā na gacchati tasmā saḥ evarūpaḥ madhurassaraḥ akāraṇā mā iti bhagavataḥ  ghosaḥ parisāya matthakena iva carati
translated: the Blessed One’s voice moves right to the top of the assembly.

original: Avalokayamānāti sirasmiṃ añjaliṃ ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ olokentāva paccosakkitvā dassanavijahanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: avalokayamānā ati sirasmim añjalim ṭhapetvā bhagavantam olokentā ava paccosakkitvā dassana vijahana ṭhāne
translated: ‘Looking on’: having placed their hands together in reverential salutation on their heads, they rose up and looked on the Blessed One in the place where they had been dismissed.

original: vanditvā gacchanti. Avijahitattāti yo hi kathaṃ sutvā vuṭṭhito aññaṃ diṭṭhasutādikaṃ🔽kathaṃ kathento gacchati, esa sabhāvena vijahati nāma. Yo pana sutadhammakathāya
analyzed: vanditvā gacchanti a vijahita ttā ati yaḥ hi katham sutvā vuṭṭhitaḥ aññam diṭṭha suta ādikam  katham kathentaḥ gacchati esa sabhāvena vijahati nāma yaḥ pana suta dhamma kathāya
translated: and they go on talking. ‘Without forgetting’ means that one who, having heard a talk, gets up and goes on talking about something else he has seen or heard, etc.,🔽forgets it in the normal way. But one who, after hearing a talk on the Dhamma,🔽

original: vaṇṇaṃ kathentova gacchati, ayaṃ na vijahati nāma, evaṃ avijahantabhāvena pakkamanti.
analyzed: vaṇṇam kathentaḥ iva gacchati ayam na vijahati nāma evam a vijahanta bhāvena pakkamanti
translated: and they go on praising it. ‘Without abandoning it’: he who, having risen from the recitation, goes on talking about something else he has seen or heard, etc., abandons it in the sense of its original nature. But he who goes on praising the recitation of the Dhamma he has heard does not abandon it. So they go on without abandoning it.🔽‘We saw him going’: we saw him going like a golden casket with its lid off.

original: Gacchantanti rajjuyantavasena ratanasattubbedhaṃ suvaṇṇagghikaṃ viya gacchantaṃ.🔽Addasāma ṭhitanti samussitakañcanapabbataṃ viya ṭhitaṃ addasāma. Tato ca bhiyyoti🔽vitthāretvā guṇe kathetuṃ asakkonto avasese guṇe saṃkhipitvā kalāpaṃ viya suttakabaddhaṃ🔽viya ca katvā vissajjento evamāha. Ayamettha adhippāyo – mayā kathitaguṇehi akathitāva
analyzed: rajju yanta vasena suvaṇṇagghikam viya gacchantam  addasāma ṭhitam ti samussita kañcana pabbatam viya ṭhitam addasāma tatas ca bhiyyas ti  vitthāretvā guṇe kathetum asakkontaḥ avasese guṇe saṃkhipitvā kalāpam viya suttaka baddham  ca katvā vissajjentaḥ evam āha ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ mayā kathita guṇehi a kathitā ava
translated: ‘We saw him standing’: we saw him standing like a golden mountain with its peak exposed.🔽‘And more besides’: being unable to tell his special qualities in detail, he sums them up and then, as if he were making up a verse, he says ‘And more besides’. The meaning is this: ‘There are more special qualities of his that I have not told about than those I have told about. For his special qualities are as immeasurable and limitless as the great earth and the great ocean, etc., and they are spread out like the sky.’

original: bahutarā. Mahāpathavimahāsamuddādayo viya hi tassa bhoto anantā appameyyā guṇā ākāsamiva vitthāritāti.
analyzed: bahutarāḥ mahā pathavi mahā samudda ādayaḥ viya hi tassa bhoto anantāḥ appameyyāḥ guṇāḥ ākāsam iva vitthāritā ati
translated: ‘We saw him going’ means we saw him going like a golden casket with its lid off.🔽‘We saw him standing’ means we saw him standing like a golden mountain with its peak exposed.

original: 390. Appaṭisaṃviditoti aviññātaāgamano. Pabbajite upasaṅkamantena hi cīvaraparikammādisamaye
analyzed: appaṭisaṃvidito ti a viññāta āgamano pabbajite upasaṅkamantena hi cīvara parikamma ādi samaye
translated: “Not announced”: not known in advance. For one who goes to see a monk should put on one robe and go to the place where the robes are being made,

original: vā ekaṃ nivāsetvā sarīrabhañjanasamaye vā upasaṅkamitvā tatova paṭinivattitabbaṃ🔽hoti, paṭisanthāramattampi na jāyati. Puretaraṃ pana okāse kārite divāṭṭhānaṃ sammajjitvā
analyzed: vā ekam nivāsetvā sarīra bhañjana samaye vā upasaṅkamitvā tatas va paṭinivattitabbam  hoti paṭisanthāra mattam pi na jāyati puretaram pana okāse kārite divāṭṭhānam sammajjitvā
translated: or to the place where the body is lying, and then return.

original: cīvaraṃ pārupitvā bhikkhu vivitte ṭhāne nisīdati, taṃ āgantvā passantā dassanenapi
analyzed: cīvaram pārupitvā bhikkhu vivitte ṭhāne nisīdati tam āgantvā passantā dassanena pi
translated: But if the place has been prepared beforehand, if the day-quarters have been swept, if the robe has been put on, and if the monk is sitting in a secluded place, then those who come to see him are pleased just by seeing him.

original: pasīdanti, paṭisanthāro jāyati, pañhabyākaraṇaṃ vā dhammakathā vā labbhati. Tasmā🔽paṇḍitā okāsaṃ kārenti. So ca nesaṃ aññataro, tenassa etadahosi. Jiṇṇo vuḍḍhoti attano🔽uggatabhāvaṃ akathetvā kasmā evamāha? Buddhā nāma anuddayasampannā honti, mahallakabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pasīdanti paṭisanthāraḥ jāyati pañha byākaraṇam vā dhamma kathā vā labbhati tasmā  paṇḍitāḥ okāsam kārenti so ca nesam aññataraḥ tena assa etat ahosi jiṇṇaḥ vuḍḍhaḥ ti attano  uggata bhāvam a kathetvā kasmai evam āha buddhāḥ nāma an uddaya sampannāḥ honti mahallaka bhāvam
translated: They are satisfied, and they get answers to their questions and a talk on the Dhamma. That is why the wise prepare the place.🔽But the elder was one of them, and so he thought, “I am old and infirm.” Why did he not say this?

original: ñatvā sīghaṃ okāsaṃ karissatīti evamāha.
analyzed: ñatvā sīgham okāsam karissati iti evam āha
translated: Because the Buddhas are full of loving-kindness. He thought, “They will quickly prepare the place when they know that I am old.”

original: 391. Oramiya okāsamakāsīti vegena uṭṭhāya dvidhā bhijjitvā okāsamakāsi.
analyzed: oramiya okāsamakāsi iti vegena uṭṭhāya dvidhā bhijjitvā okāsamakāsi
translated: ‘He split the space in two and made room for me’: he got up quickly and split the space in two and made room for him.

original: Ye meti ye mayā. Nārīsamānasavhayāti nārīsamānanāmaṃ itthiliṅgaṃ, tena avhātabbāti
analyzed: ye mā iti ye mayā nārī samāna savhayā ati nārī samāna nāmam itthi liṅgam tena a vhātabbā iti
translated: ‘Those who are called by me’: those who are called by me. ‘By the female-natured one’: the female-natured one is the female sex, and he is called by that.

original: nārīsamānasavhayā, itthiliṅgena vattabbāti vohārakusalatāya evaṃ vadati. Pahūtajivhoti
analyzed: nārī samāna savhayā itthi liṅgena vattabbā ati vohāra kusala tāya evam vadati pahūta jivhā iti
translated: ‘By the female-natured one’ means ‘by the female sex’. Because he is skilled in usage, he speaks thus. ‘With a large tongue’:

original: puthulajivho. Ninnāmayetanti nīhara etaṃ.
analyzed: puthula jivhaḥ nīharaḥ etam
translated: with a broad tongue. ‘Take it away’: remove this.

original: 393. Kevalīti sakalaguṇasampanno.
analyzed: kevalī iti sakala guṇa sampannaḥ
translated: ‘The perfected one’: the one endowed with all good qualities.

original: 394. Paccabhāsīti ekappahārena pucchite aṭṭha pañhe byākaronto patiabhāsi. Yo vedīti
analyzed: paccabhāsi iti eka ppahārena pucchite aṭṭha pañhe byākaronto patiabhāsi yaḥ vedi iti
translated: ‘He replied’: he replied by answering the eight questions asked in one statement. ‘He who knows’:

original: yo vidati jānāti, yassa pubbenivāso pākaṭo. Saggāpāyañca passatīti dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ🔽kathitaṃ. Jātikkhayaṃ pattoti arahattaṃ patto. Abhiññā vositoti taṃ arahattaṃ abhijānitvā
analyzed: yaḥ vidati jānāti yassa pubbenivāsaḥ pākaṭaḥ sagga apāyam ca passati iti dibba cakkhu ñāṇam  kathitam jāti kkhayam pattoti arahattam patto abhiññā vositoti tam arahattam abhijānitvā
translated: he who knows, who understands, whose knowledge of his past lives is clear. ‘He sees heaven and the states of deprivation’: the knowledge of the divine eye

original: vosito vosānappatto. Munīti arahattañāṇamoneyyena samannāgato.
analyzed: vositaḥ vosāna ppatto munī iti arahatta ñāṇa moneyyena samannāgato
translated: is referred to. ‘He has reached the destruction of birth’: he has reached Arahantship. ‘He is freed by full-understanding’: he is freed, he has reached the state of being freed, by fully understanding that Arahantship. ‘The sage’: he is endowed with the knowledge of the Arahant’s path.

original: Visuddhanti paṇḍaraṃ. Muttaṃ rāgehīti kilesarāgehi muttaṃ. Pahīnajātimaraṇoti jātikkhayappattattā
analyzed: visuddham ti paṇḍaram muttam rāgehi iti kilesa rāgehi muttam pahīna jāti maraṇaḥ ti jāti khaya ppatta ttā
translated: “Pure” : white. “Freed from passion” : freed from the defilement-passion. “Having abandoned birth and death” : he has abandoned birth because he has reached the destruction of birth.

original: pahīnajātiko, jātipahāneneva pahīnamaraṇo. Brahmacariyassa kevalīti yaṃ brahmacariyassa🔽kevalī sakalabhāvo, tena samannāgato, sakalacatumaggabrahmacariyavāsoti attho. Pāragū
analyzed: pahīna jātikaḥ jāti pahānena iva pahīna maraṇaḥ brahmacariyassa kevalī iti yam brahmacariyassa  kevalī sakala bhāvo tena samannāgato sakala catu magga brahmacariya vāso ti attho pāragū
translated: “Having abandoned death” : he has abandoned death by the mere abandoning of birth. “Having lived the life” : he is endowed with the completeness of the life,

original: sabbadhammānanti sabbesaṃ lokiyalokuttaradhammānaṃ abhiññāya pāraṃ gato, sabbadhamme
analyzed: sabba dhammānam ti sabbesam lokiya lokuttara dhammānam abhiññāya pāram gataḥ sabba dhamme
translated: the complete life of the four paths. The meaning is, he has lived the complete life. “Having gone beyond all the teachings” : he has gone beyond by direct knowledge all the mundane and supramundane teachings. The meaning is, he has stood having directly known all the teachings.

original: abhijānitvā ṭhitoti attho. Pāragūti vā ettāvatā pariññāpāragū pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ,
analyzed: abhijānitvā ṭhito ti attho pāragū ti vai ettāvatā pariññā pāragū pañcannam khandhānam
translated: Or, by this much he has gone beyond by full understanding the five aggregates,

original: pahānapāragū sabbakilesānaṃ, bhāvanāpāragū catunnaṃ maggānaṃ, sacchikiriyāpāragū
analyzed: pahāna pāragū sabba kilesānam bhāvanā pāragū catunnam maggānam sacchikiriyā pāragū
translated: by abandoning the defilements, by developing the four paths,

original: nirodhassa, samāpattipāragū sabbasamāpattīnanti ayamattho vutto. Puna sabbadhammānanti
analyzed: nirodhassa samāpatti pāragū sabba samāpattīnam ti ayam atthaḥ vuttaḥ puna sabba dhammānam ti
translated: by realizing cessation, and by attaining all the attainments. “Having gone beyond all the teachings”

original: iminā abhiññāpāragū vuttoti. Buddho tādī pavuccatīti tādiso chahi ākārehi pāraṃ gato
analyzed: iminā abhiññāpāragū vutto ti buddho tādī pavuccati iti tādiso chahi ākārehi pāram gato
translated: means that he has gone beyond by direct knowledge. “The Enlightened One is said to be such” : he is said to be such because he has gone beyond in these six modes.

original: sabbākārena catunnaṃ saccānaṃ buddhattā buddhoti pavuccatīti.
analyzed: sabba ākārena catunnam saccānam buddha ttā buddho iti pavuccati iti
translated: He is called “awakened” because he has awakened to the four truths in all their aspects.

original: Kiṃ pana ettāvatā sabbe pañhā vissajjitā hontīti? Āma vissajjitā, cittaṃ visuddhaṃ
analyzed: kim pana ettāvatā sabbe pañhāḥ vissajjitāḥ honti iti āma vissajjitā cittam visuddham
translated: But are all the questions answered by this? Yes, they are. The mind is purified,

original: jānāti, muttaṃ rāgehīti iminā tāva bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇoti paṭhamapañho vissajjito
analyzed: jānāti muttam rāgehi iti iminā tāva bāhita pāpattā brāhmaṇo ti paṭhama pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ
translated: and he knows that he is freed from lust. By this he has answered the first question, “He is a brahman because he has expelled evil.

original: hoti. Pāragūti iminā vedehi gatattā vedagūti dutiyapañho vissajjito hoti. Pubbenivāsantiādīhi
analyzed: hoti pāragū ti iminā vedehi gata ttā vedagū ti dutiya pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti pubbenivāsa nti ādīhi
translated: ” He has gone to the other side. By this he has answered the second question, “He is a vedagū because he has gone to the Vedas.

original: imāsaṃ tissannaṃ vijjānaṃ atthitāya tevijjoti tatiyapañho vissajjito hoti. Muttaṃ
analyzed: imāsam tissannam vijjānam atthitāya tevijjaḥ ti tatiya pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti muttam
translated: ” He recollects his manifold past lives. By this he has answered the third question, “He is a tevijja because he possesses these three kinds of knowledge.

original: rāgehi sabbasoti imināva nissaṭattā pāpadhammānaṃ sottiyoti catutthapañho vissajjito
analyzed: rāgehi sabbaso ti iminā ava nissaṭa ttā pāpa dhammānam sottiyā iti catuttha pañhaḥ vissajjito
translated: ” He is freed from lust. By this he has answered the fourth question, “He is a sotāpanna because he has escaped from evil states.

original: hoti. Jātikkhayaṃ pattoti iminā pana arahattasseva vuttattā pañcamapañho vissajjito
analyzed: hoti jāti kkhayam patto ti iminā pana arahattassa iva vutta ttā pañcama pañhaḥ vissajjito
translated: ” He has reached the destruction of birth. By this he has answered the fifth question, “He is an arahant.🔽” He is a recluse. He is perfect in the holy life. By this he has answered the sixth question, “He is a bhikkhu.

original: hoti. Vositoti ca brahmacariyassa kevalīti ca imehi chaṭṭhapañho vissajjito hoti.
analyzed: hoti vosito ti ca brahmacariyassa kevalī iti ca imehi chaṭṭha pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti
translated: and “he is one who has been released” and “he is one who has lived the spiritual life” are answered by the sixth question.

original: Abhiññā vosito munīti iminā sattamapañho vissajjito hoti. Pāragū sabbadhammānaṃ,
analyzed: abhiññā vositaḥ muni iti iminā sattama pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti pāragū sabba dhammānam
translated: “The Sage, gone beyond to direct knowledge” : this answers the seventh question.🔽“The Buddha, gone beyond to all things,

original: buddho tādī pavuccatīti iminā aṭṭhamapañho vissajjito hoti.
analyzed: buddhaḥ tādī pavuccati iti iminā aṭṭhama pañhaḥ vissajjitaḥ hoti
translated: is called the One of Vision” : this answers the eighth question.🔽The “talk on giving” and so on are given in detail in the sutta itself.🔽“I followed” : I practiced.

original: 395. Dānakathantiādīni heṭṭhā sutte vitthāritāneva. Paccapādīti paṭipajji. Dhammassānudhammanti
analyzed: dāna kathaṃ ti ādīni heṭṭhā sutte vitthāritāni eva paccapādi iti paṭipajji dhammassa anudhammanti
translated: “The Dhamma and its underlying tendency” :

original: imasmiṃ sutte dhammo nāma arahattamaggo, anudhammo nāma heṭṭhimā tayo maggā tīṇi🔽ca sāmaññaphalāni, tāni paṭipāṭiyā paṭilabhīti attho. Na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: imasmin sutte dhammaḥ nāma arahatta maggaḥ anudhammaḥ nāma heṭṭhimā tayaḥ maggā tīṇi  ca sāmañña phalāni tāni paṭipāṭiyā paṭilabhi iti atthaḥ na ca mama dhamma adhikaraṇam
translated: in this sutta the Dhamma is the path of arahatship, and the underlying tendency is the three lower paths and the three fruits.🔽The meaning is that he attained them in due succession.

original: vihesesīti mañca dhammakāraṇā na kilamesi, na punappunaṃ kathāpesīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vihesesi iti mañca dhamma kāraṇā na kilamesi na punappunam kathāpesi iti vuttam hoti
translated: “The Dhamma did not obsess me” : he did not trouble himself with the Dhamma, he did not ask again and again.🔽The rest is clear throughout.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānameva. Tattha parinibbāyīti pana padena desanāya arahatteneva kūṭaṃ gahitanti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva tattha parinibbāyi iti pana padena desanāya arahattena iva kūṭam gahitanti
translated: Here, however, the word “parinibbana” shows that the teaching is aimed at arahatship.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikaya, the Great Book of the Middle Length Sayings, is finished.

original: Brahmāyusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: brahmāyu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Brahmayu Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Selasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sela sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sela Sutta

original: 396. Evaṃ me sutanti selasuttaṃ. Tattha aṅguttarāpesūtiādi potaliyasutte vitthāritameva.
analyzed: evam me sutanti sela suttam tattha potaliya sutte vitthāritam eva
translated: “Thus have I heard” is the Sela Sutta. Herein, the words “in the Angutarapeyyala” and so on are given in detail in the Potaliya Sutta.

original: Aḍḍhateḷasehīti aḍḍhena teḷasehi, dvādasahi satehi paññāsāya ca bhikkhūhi saddhinti
analyzed: aḍḍha teḷasehi iti aḍḍhena teḷasehi dvādasahi satehi paññāsāya ca bhikkhūhi saddhinti
translated: With more than twelve hundred bhikkhus: with one and a half times twelve hundred, with one thousand two hundred and fifty bhikkhus.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Te pana sāvakasannipāte sannipatitā bhikkhūyeva sabbe ehibhikkhupabbajjāya
analyzed: vuttam hoti te pana sāvaka sannipāte sannipatitāḥ bhikkhū yeva sabbe ehibhikkhu pabbajjāya
translated: That is what is meant. But all these bhikkhus who had assembled at the time of the disciples’ arrival had gone forth by the going forth in the Buddha’s presence.

original: pabbajitā khīṇāsavā. Keṇiyoti tassa nāmaṃ, jaṭiloti tāpaso. So kira brāhmaṇamahāsālo,
analyzed: pabbajitā khīṇa āsavā keṇiyā iti tassa nāmam jaṭilaḥ ti tāpaso saḥ kira brāhmaṇa mahā sālo
translated: They were all arahats. Keṇiya: this is the name of a matted-hair ascetic. It seems that he was a great brahmin clan.

original: dhanarakkhaṇatthāya pana tāpasapabbajjaṃ samādāya rañño paṇṇākāraṃ datvā bhūmibhāgaṃ
analyzed: dhana rakkhaṇa tthāya pana tāpasa pabbajjam samādāya rañño paṇṇākāram da tvā bhūmi bhāgam
translated: But for the sake of protecting his wealth he had taken up the ascetic life of a matted-hair ascetic. He had received a grant of land from the king in return for a tribute of a basket of grain.

original: gahetvā tattha assamaṃ kāretvā vasati pañcahi sakaṭasatehi vaṇijjaṃ payojetvā kulasahassassa
analyzed: gahetvā tattha assamam kāretvā vasati pañcahi sakaṭa satehi vaṇijjam payojetvā kula sahassassa
translated: He had a hermitage built there and lived there. He employed a thousand families to trade for him with five hundred carts.

original: nissayo hutvā, assamepi cassa eko tālarukkho divase divase ekaṃ sovaṇṇamayaṃ tālaphalaṃ
analyzed: nissayaḥ hutvā assame pi ca ssa ekaḥ tāla rukkho divase divase ekam sovaṇṇa mayam tāla phalam
translated: They say that in his hermitage there was a single palm tree that bore a single golden palm fruit every day.

original: muñcatīti vadanti. So divā kāsāyāni dhāreti, jaṭā ca bandhati, rattiṃ kāmasampattiṃ
analyzed: muñcati iti vadanti saḥ divā kāsāyāni dhārā iti jaṭā ca bandhati rattim kāma sampattim
translated: He wore yellow robes by day, and he bound up his hair and at night he indulged in sensual pleasures.

original: anubhavati. Dhammiyā kathāyāti pānakānisaṃsapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya. Ayañhi
analyzed: anubhavati dhammiyā kathāya ati pānaka anisaṃsa paṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya ayaṃ hi
translated: he experienced. Dhammiyā kathāyāti by means of a talk on Dhamma connected with the advantages of drinking. For this

original: keṇiyo tucchahattho bhagavato dassanāya gantuṃ lajjāyamāno – “vikālabhojanā viratānampi
analyzed: keṇiyaḥ tuccha hatthaḥ bhagavataḥ dassanāya gantum lajjāyamānaḥ vikāla bhojanāḥ viratānam pi
translated: Keṇiya, being ashamed to go to see the Exalted One empty-handed, thought: “Drinking is allowed even for those who have renounced eating at improper times,”

original: pānakaṃ kappatī”ti cintetvā susaṅkhatabadarapānaṃ pañcahi kājasatehi gāhāpetvā agamāsi.🔽Evaṃ gatabhāvo cassa – “atha kho keṇiyassa jaṭilassa etadahosi kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ samaṇassa
analyzed: pānakam kappati iti cintetvā su saṅkhata badara pānam pañcahi kāja satehi gāhāpetvā agamāsi  evam gata bhāvaḥ ca ssa atha kho keṇiyassa jaṭilassa etat ahosi kim nu kho aham samaṇassa
translated: and he had five hundred bunches of grapes brought and went .

original: gotamassa harāpeyya”nti bhesajjakkhandhake pāḷiāruḷhoyeva.
analyzed: gotamassa bhesajja khandhake
translated: The way in which he went is stated in the text of the Bhesajjakkhandhaka thus: “Then this occurred to the coiled-hair ascetic Keṇiya: ‘What can I offer to the ascetic Gotama?’”

original: Dutiyampi kho bhagavāti kasmā punappunaṃ paṭikkhipi? Titthiyānaṃ paṭikkhepapasannatāya,🔽akāraṇametaṃ, natthi buddhānaṃ paccayahetu evarūpaṃ kohaññaṃ. Ayaṃ pana aḍḍhateḷasāni
analyzed: dutiyam pi kho bhagavā ati kasmā punappunam titthiyānam paṭikkhepa pasanna tāya  akāraṇam etam na atthi buddhānam paccaya hetu evarūpam kohaññam ayam pana aḍḍhateḷasāni
translated: Why did the Exalted One refuse again and again? Because of the faith in the refusal of the sectarians,

original: bhikkhusatāni disvā ettakānaṃyeva bhikkhaṃ paṭiyādessati, sveva selo tīhi purisasatehi
analyzed: bhikkhu satāni disvā ettakānam yeva bhikkham paṭiyādessati su eva selaḥ tīhi purisa satehi
translated: this is not a reason, for there is no such kind of stinginess in the Buddhas. But the Exalted One, seeing that there were one thousand two hundred and fifty bhikkhus, thought: “He will prepare almsfood only for this many. Tomorrow the mountain will be crowded with three hundred men.

original: saddhiṃ pabbajissati. Ayuttaṃ kho pana navake aññato pesetvā imeheva saddhiṃ gantuṃ,
analyzed: saddhim pabbajissati ayuttam kho pana navake aññatas pesetvā imehi iva saddhim gantum
translated: and he will go forth with them. It is not proper for the newly arrived to go with them,

original: ime vā aññato pesetvā navakehi saddhiṃ gantuṃ. Athāpi sabbe gahetvā gamissāmi, bhikkhāhāro
analyzed: ime vā aññatas pesetvā navakehi saddhim gantum atha api sabbe gahetvā gamissāmi bhikkhāhāraḥ
translated: or for them to go with the newly arrived. If I take them all, there will not be enough almsfood

original: nappahossati. Tato bhikkhūsu piṇḍāya carantesu manussā ujjhāyissanti – “cirassāpi
analyzed: na pahossati tatas bhikkhūsu piṇḍāya carantesu manussāḥ ujjhāyissanti cirassa api
translated: for them. Then, while the monks are wandering for alms, people will complain, ‘For a long time

original: keṇiyo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ nimantetvā yāpanamattaṃ dātuṃ nāsakkhī”ti, sayampi vippaṭisārī
analyzed: keṇiyaḥ samaṇam gotamam nimantetvā yāpana mattam dātum na asakkhi iti sayam pi vippaṭisārī
translated: we have been inviting the ascetic Gotama, but we have not been able to provide even a meal.🔽’ And he will feel remorse.

original: bhavissati. Paṭikkhepe pana kate “samaṇo gotamo punappunaṃ ‘tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno’ti
analyzed: bhavissati paṭikkhepe pana kate samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ punappunam tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasannaḥ ti
translated: But if I refuse, he will think, ‘The ascetic Gotama keeps on saying, “You are devoted to the brahmins,”

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ nāmaṃ gaṇhātī”ti cintetvā brāhmaṇepi nimantetukāmo bhavissati, tato brāhmaṇe
analyzed: brāhmaṇānam nāmam gaṇhāti iti cintetvā brāhmaṇe api nimantetu kāmaḥ bhavissati tatas brāhmaṇe
translated: and he keeps on mentioning the brahmins by name,’ and he will want to invite the brahmins. He will then invite the brahmins

original: pāṭiyekkaṃ nimantessati, te tena nimantitā bhikkhū hutvā bhuñjissanti. Evamassa saddhā
analyzed: pāṭiyekkam nimantessati te tena nimantitāḥ bhikkhū hutvā bhuñjissanti evam assa saddhā
translated: separately, and they will eat as monks. In this way his faith will be protected.’ And he refused again and again.

original: anurakkhitā bhavissatīti punappunaṃ paṭikkhipi. Kiñcāpi kho, bhoti iminā idaṃ dīpeti,
analyzed: anurakkhitā bhavissati iti punappunam paṭikkhipi kiñca api kho bhoti iminā idam dīpeti
translated: ‘Although, Sir, you say this, it shows that

original: – “bho gotama, kiṃ jātaṃ yadi ahaṃ brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno, adhivāsetu bhavaṃ gotamo,
analyzed: bho gotama kim jātam yadi aham brāhmaṇesu abhippasannaḥ adhivāsetu bhavam gotamaḥ
translated: “‘Sir, what is the matter if I am devoted to the brahmans? Let Master Gotama accept,

original: ahaṃ brāhmaṇānampi dātuṃ sakkomi tumhākampī”ti.
analyzed: aham brāhmaṇānam pi dātum sakkomi tumhākam pi iti
translated: I am able to give to the brahmans and to you too.’

analyzed: tathāgatam ti tathāgatam hetum anujātaḥ tathāgatena hetunā jātaḥ iti attho api ca avajātaḥ  anujātaḥ atijātaḥ ti tayaḥ vuttā tesu avajātaḥ dussīlo so tathāgatassa putto nāma na  hoti atijātaḥ nāma pitarā uttaritaro tādiso pi tathāgatassa putto natthi tathāgatassa
translated: “A son of the Tathāgata” means that he is born with the same cause as the Tathāgata. The meaning is that he is born with the same cause as the Tathāgata. The son born after being found is the son who is superior to his father; such a one also is not the Tathāgata’s son. analyzed: evam nippariyāyena attānam āvikatvā attani kaṅkhā vitaraṇa attham brāhmaṇam aticāriyamānaḥ
translated: Having thus revealed himself in the true sense, in order to remove doubt in himself, he, the brahmin, who is beyond the range of the world,

original: vinayassūti gāthattayamāha. Tattha sallakattoti rāgādisallakantano. Anuttaroti yathā🔽bāhiravejjena vūpasamitarogo imasmiññevattabhāve kuppati, na evaṃ. Mayā vūpasamitassa
analyzed: vinayassu iti gāthattayam āha tattha sallakatto ti rāga ādi sallakantano anuttaraḥ iti yathā  bāhira vejjena vūpasamita rogaḥ imasmin ñevatta bhāve kuppati na evam mayā vūpasamitassa
translated: recited the three verses of the Vinaya. Herein, the physician is the one who has the disease of lust, etc. The unsurpassed one is the one who,🔽unlike the external physician, does not cause the disease to recur in this very existence. For the disease that is cured by me

original: pana rogassa bhavantarepi uppatti natthi, tasmā ahaṃ anuttaroti attho. Brahmabhūtoti
analyzed: pana rogassa bhavantare pi uppatti natthi tasmai aham anuttaraḥ ti atthaḥ brahma bhūtoti
translated: does not arise again even in a future existence. Therefore the meaning is: I am the unsurpassed one. The one who has become Brahma is the one who has become the Brahma-state.

original: seṭṭhabhūto. Atituloti tulaṃ atīto, nirupamoti attho. Mārasenappamaddanoti kāmā te
analyzed: seṭṭha bhūtaḥ atitulaḥ ti tulam atītaḥ nirupamaḥ ti atthaḥ māra sena pamaddano ti kāmā te
translated: is the best. Atitulo means gone beyond the balance, the meaning is: without compare. Mārasenappamaddano means: the destroyer of the army of Māra,

original: paṭhamā senāti evaṃ āgatāya mārasenāya pamaddano. Sabbāmitteti khandhakilesābhisaṅkhāramaccudevaputtamārasaṅkhāte
analyzed: paṭhamā senā ati evam āgatāya māra senāya pamaddano sabba amitta iti khandha kilesa abhisaṅkhāra maccu devaputta māra saṅkhāte
translated: who has come in this way: “Sensual desire is the first army.” Sabbāmitte means: all enemies, known as the aggregates, defilements, death, and the son of the god Māra.

original: sabbapaccatthike. Vasīkatvāti attano vase vattetvā. Akutobhayoti kutoci abhayo.
analyzed: sabba paccatthike vasīkatvā ti attanaḥ vase vattetvā akutobhayaḥ iti kutoci abhayaḥ
translated: Vasīkatvā means: having brought under his own control. Akutobhayo means: fearless from anywhere.

original: Evaṃ vutte selo brāhmaṇo tāvadeva bhagavati sañjātapasādo pabbajjāpekkho hutvā imaṃ🔽bhontoti gāthattayamāha. Tattha kaṇhābhijātikoti caṇḍālādinīcakule jāto. Tato tepi
analyzed: evam vutte selaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ tāvat eva bhagavati sañjāta pasādaḥ pabbajja apekkhaḥ hutvā imaṃ  bhonto ti gāthattayam āha tattha kaṇha abhijātikaḥ ti caṇḍāla ādi nīca kule jātaḥ te pi
translated: When this was said, the brahmin Sela, having immediately gained faith in the Fortunate One, and being desirous of going forth, said this🔽three verse to the Fortunate One, beginning with: “Venerable Sir”. Herein, kaṇhābhijātiko means: born in a low family such as a caṇḍāla and so on. Then those

original: māṇavakā pabbajjāpekkhā hutvā evañce ruccati, bhototi gāthamāhaṃsu. Atha selo tesu
analyzed: māṇavakā pabbajja apekkhā hutvā evañce ruccati bhoto ti gātham āhaṃsu atha selaḥ tesu
translated: young men, being desirous of going forth, said this verse: “If this is agreeable to you, Venerable Sir.” Then Sela,

original: māṇavakesu tuṭṭhacitto te ca dassento pabbajjaṃ yācanto “brāhmaṇā”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: māṇavakesu tuṭṭha citto te ca dassento pabbajjam yācantaḥ brāhmaṇa iti gātham āha
translated: being pleased with those young men, and desiring to go forth, said this verse: “The brahmins” in order to show them.

original: Tato bhagavā yasmā selo atīte padumuttarassa bhagavato sāsane tesaṃyeva tiṇṇaṃ purisasatānaṃ
analyzed: tatas bhagavā yasmā selaḥ atīte padumuttarassa bhagavato sāsane tesam yeva tiṇṇam purisa satānam
translated: Then the Fortunate One, because Sela in the past, in the dispensation of the Fortunate One Padumuttara, was one of those three hundred men,

original: gaṇaseṭṭho hutvā tehi saddhiṃ pariveṇaṃ kāretvā dānādīni puññāni katvā tena kammena
analyzed: gaṇa seṭṭhaḥ hutvā tehi saddhim pariveṇam kāretvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā tena kammena
translated: and becoming the chief of the group, he had a monastery built with them, and after making merit by giving gifts, etc., by that deed,

original: devamanussasampattiṃ anubhavamāno pacchime bhave tesaṃyeva ācariyo hutvā nibbatto,
analyzed: deva manussa sampattim anubhavamāno pacchime bhave tesam yeva ācariyaḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ
translated: and he became their chief. Together with them he had a monastery built, and he performed the meritorious deeds of giving, etc. By that kamma he experienced the happiness of gods and men. In his last existence he was reborn as their teacher.

original: tañca tesaṃ kammaṃ vimuttiparipākāya paripakkaṃ ehibhikkhubhāvassa ca upanissayabhūtaṃ,
analyzed: tat ca tesam kammam vimutti paripākāya paripakkam ehi bhikkhu bhāvassa ca upanissaya bhūtam
translated: And that kamma of theirs was ripe for the attainment of deliverance and was the condition for their becoming monks by the “Come, bhikkhu!” formula.

original: tasmā te sabbeva ehibhikkhupabbajjaṃ pabbājento svākkhātanti gāthamāha. Tattha sandiṭṭhikanti🔽sayameva daṭṭhabbaṃ paccakkhaṃ. Akālikanti maggānantaraphaluppattiyā na kālantaraṃ
analyzed: tasmā te sabbe eva ehi bhikkhu pabbajjam pabbājento su ākkhātanti gātham āha tattha sandiṭṭhikam ti  sayam eva daṭṭhabbam paccakkham akālikam ti magga anantara phala uppattiyāḥ na kāla antaram
translated: Therefore, admitting them all to the monkhood by the “Come, bhikkhu!” formula, he uttered the stanza, “The state of peace is to be seen by the wise here and now;🔽it is not delayed, it is not far away, where it is not in vain to live the holy life.”🔽Herein, to be seen by the wise here and now means to be seen by oneself, to be evident.🔽Not delayed means that the fruit to be attained is not delayed by the lapse of time, since it is attained immediately after the path.

original: pattabbaphalaṃ. Yattha amoghāti yasmiṃ maggabrahmacariye appamattassa sikkhattayapūraṇena
analyzed: pattabba phalam yattha amoghā ati yasmim magga brahmacariye appamattassa sikkhattaya pūraṇena
translated: Where it is not in vain to live the holy life means that for one who trains himself in the three trainings by fulfilling the duties of one gone forth, the going forth is not in vain, since he will reap the fruit of the holy life.

original: sikkhato pabbajjā amoghā hoti, saphalāti attho. Evañca vatvā “etha bhikkhavo”ti bhagavā
analyzed: sikkhataḥ pabbajjā amoghā hoti saphalā ati attho evañca vatvā etha bhikkhavaḥ ti bhagavā
translated: After saying this, the Blessed One said, “Come, bhikkhus!”

original: avoca. Te sabbe pattacīvaradharā hutvā ākāsenāgantvā vassasatikattherā viya suvinītā
analyzed: avoca te sabbe patta cīvara dharāḥ hutvā ākāsena āgantvā vassasatika therāḥ viya su vinītā
translated: All of them, wearing robes and carrying bowls, came through the air like the Elder Assaji, who had been a monk for only seven days, and were well disciplined.

original: bhagavantaṃ abhivādayiṃsu. Evamimaṃ tesaṃ ehibhikkhubhāvaṃ sandhāya “alattha kho selo”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavantam abhivādayiṃsu evam imam tesam ehibhikkhu bhāvam sandhāya alattha kho sela iti ādi vuttam
translated: and they paid homage to the Lord. Thus it was with reference to their becoming monks that it was said: “Sela received the going-forth. ”

original: 400. Imāhīti imāhi keṇiyassa cittānukūlāhi gāthāhi. Tattha aggiparicariyaṃ vinā brāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: imāhi iti imāhi keṇiyassa citta anukūlāhi gāthāhi tattha aggi paricariyam vinā brāhmaṇānaṃ
translated: With these verses: with these verses that were in conformity with Keṇiya’s thoughts. Herein, since the brahmans have no sacrifice without the tending of the sacred fires,

original: yaññābhāvato “aggihuttamukhā yaññā”ti vuttaṃ. Aggihuttaseṭṭhā aggijuhanappadhānāti
analyzed: yaññā abhāvataḥ aggi hutta mukhā yaññā ati vuttam aggi hutta seṭṭhā aggi juhana ppadhānā ti
translated: it is said that the sacrifices have the kindling of the sacred fires as their head . The meaning is that the kindling of the sacred fires is their chief thing.

original: attho. Vede sajjhāyantehi paṭhamaṃ sajjhāyitabbato, sāvittī, “chandaso mukha”nti
analyzed: atthaḥ vede sajjhāyantehi paṭhamam sajjhāyitabbataḥ sā āvittī chandasaḥ mukham ti
translated: The Sāvitti is called the “mouth” because it is what should be recited first by those who recite the Vedas.🔽The king is called the “mouth” because he is the best of men.

original: vutto. Manussānaṃ seṭṭhato rājā “mukha”nti vutto. Nadīnaṃ ādhārato paṭisaraṇato ca🔽sāgaro “mukha”nti vutto. Candayogavasena “ajja kattikā ajja rohiṇī”ti saññāṇato ālokakaraṇato
analyzed: vuttaḥ manussānam seṭṭhataḥ rājā mukhan ti vuttaḥ nadīnam ādhārato paṭisaraṇato ca  sāgaraḥ mukhan ti vutto canda yoga vasena ajja kattikā ajja rohiṇī iti saññāṇataḥ āloka karaṇato
translated: The ocean is called the “mouth” because it is the support and the resort of the rivers.🔽The moon is called the “mouth of the constellations” because it is the sign of the month of Kattika and the month of Rohini, and because it is the illuminator and the light-maker.

original: sommabhāvato ca “nakkhattānaṃ mukhaṃ cando”ti vuttaṃ. Tapantānaṃ aggattā ādicco “tapataṃ
analyzed: somma bhāvato ca nakkhattānam mukham cando ti vuttam tapantānam agga ttā ādicco tapatam
translated: The sun is called the “mouth of those that burn” because it is the chief of those that burn,

original: mukha”nti vutto. Dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ pana aggattā visesena tasmiṃ samaye buddhappamukhaṃ🔽saṅghaṃ sandhāya “puññaṃ ākaṅkhamānānaṃ, saṅgho eva yajataṃ mukha”nti vuttaṃ. Tena
analyzed: mukham ti vuttaḥ dakkhiṇeyyānam pana agga ttā visesena tasmin samaye buddha ppamukham  saṅgham sandhāya puññam ākaṅkhamānānam saṅghaḥ eva yajatam mukham ti vuttam tena
translated: “The mouth” : but because of the foremostness of those worthy of gifts, the Sangha headed by the Buddha is meant in particular at that time.🔽“The Sangha is the mouth for those who wish for merit” :

original: saṅgho puññassa āyamukhanti dasseti.
analyzed: saṅghaḥ puññassa āya mukhanti dasseti
translated: by this it is shown that the Sangha is the source of merit.🔽“The refuge that we have gone to” : he speaks this verse of reply. Its meaning is this:

original: Yaṃ taṃ saraṇanti aññaṃ byākaraṇagāthamāha. Tassattho – pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā
analyzed: yam tam saraṇam ti aññam byākaraṇa gātham āha tassa atthaḥ pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā
translated: The Blessed One, who is endowed with the five eyes,

original: bhagavā yasmā mayaṃ ito aṭṭhame divase taṃ saraṇaṃ āgatamhā, tasmā attanā tava sāsane
analyzed: bhagavā yasmai mayam itas aṭṭhame divase tam saraṇam āgatamhā tasmai attana tava sāsane
translated: since we have gone to that refuge eight days ago,🔽therefore we are tamed by your unsurpassed taming,

original: anuttarena damathena dantāmhā, aho te saraṇassa ānubhāvoti.
analyzed: anuttarena damathena aho te saraṇassa ānubhāvaḥ ti
translated: oh, the power of your refuge!

original: Tato paraṃ bhagavantaṃ dvīhi gāthāhi thometvā tatiyāya vandanaṃ yācanto bhikkhavo tisatā imetiādimāhāti.
analyzed: tato param bhagavantam dvīhi gāthāhi thometvā tatiyāya vandanam yācantaḥ bhikkhavaḥ ti satā imā iti ādim āha ati
translated: After that, having praised the Blessed One with two verses, he said “these three hundred bhikkhus” etc., requesting the Blessed One to pay homage with the third verse.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya called “Papañcasūdanī”

original: Selasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sela sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Selasutta is finished.

original: 3. Assalāyanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: assalāyana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Assalāyanasutta

original: 401. Evaṃ me sutanti assalāyanasuttaṃ. Tattha nānāverajjakānanti aṅgamagadhādīhi🔽nānappakārehi verajjehi āgatānaṃ, tesu vā raṭṭhesu jātasaṃvaḍḍhānantipi attho. Kenacidevāti
analyzed: evam me sutam ti assalāyana suttam tattha aṅga magadha ādīhi  nānā pakārehi verajjehi āgatānam tesu vā raṭṭhesu jāta saṃvaḍḍhānam ti pi atthaḥ kenacid eva ati
translated: “Thus have I heard” : the Assalāyana Sutta . Therein, “from various countries” : from the countries of the Aṅgas, Magadhans, etc.

original: yaññupāsanādinā aniyamitakiccena. Cātuvaṇṇinti catuvaṇṇasādhāraṇaṃ. Mayaṃ pana nhānasuddhiyā🔽bhāvanāsuddhiyāpi brāhmaṇāva sujjhantīti vadāma, ayuttampi samaṇo gotamo karotīti
analyzed: yaññu pāsana ādinā aniyamita kiccena cātuvaṇṇit ti catuvaṇṇa sādhāraṇam mayam pana nhāna suddhiyā  bhāvanā suddhiyā api sujjhanti iti vadāma ayuttam pi samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ karoti iti
translated: The meaning is: “born and grown up in those countries.” “For some reason or other” : for some unspecified reason, such as attending a sacrifice. “Common to all four castes” : shared by all four castes. “But we brahmins are purified by the water that reaches the heart and by the development of wisdom” .

original: maññamānā evaṃ cintayiṃsu. Vuttasiroti vāpitasiro.
analyzed: maññamānāḥ evam cintayiṃsu vutta siro ti vāpita siro
translated: Thinking that the recluse Gotama was doing something improper, they thought thus. “Shaven-headed” : shaved.

original: Dhammavādīti sabhāvavādī. Duppaṭimantiyāti amhādisehi adhammavādīhi dukkhena paṭimantitabbā
analyzed: dhamma vādī iti sabhāva vādī duppaṭimantiyā ti amhādisehi adhamma vādīhi dukkhena paṭimantitabbā
translated: “One who speaks Dhamma” : one who speaks in accordance with reality. “Hard to dispute with” : they are hard to dispute with by those who speak non-Dhamma.

original: honti. Dhammavādino nāma parājayo na sakkā kātunti dasseti. Paribbājakanti pabbajjāvidhānaṃ,
analyzed: honti dhamma vādinaḥ nāma parājayaḥ na sakkā kātunti dasseti paribbājakam ti pabbajjā vidhānam
translated: He shows that it is impossible to defeat those who speak Dhamma. “Wandering forth” : the method of going forth.

original: tayo vede uggahetvā sabbapacchā pabbajantā yehi mantehi pabbajanti, pabbajitā ca
analyzed: tayaḥ vede uggahetvā sabbapacchā pabbajantā yehi mantehi pabbajanti pabbajitā ca
translated: Having learned the three Vedas, they go forth last of all. By whatever mantras they go forth, they go forth.

original: ye mante pariharanti, yaṃ vā ācāraṃ ācaranti, taṃ sabbaṃ bhotā caritaṃ sikkhitaṃ.
analyzed: ye mante pariharanti yam vā ācāram ācaranti tam sabbam bhotā caritam sikkhitam
translated: Whatever mantras they recite, whatever conduct they practice, all that has been practiced and learned by you.

original: Tasmā tuyhaṃ parājayo natthi, jayova bhavissatīti maññantā evamāhaṃsu.
analyzed: tasmā tuyham parājayaḥ na atthi jayaḥ uva bhavissati iti maññantāḥ evam āhaṃsu
translated: Therefore you have no defeat, only victory will be yours.”

original: 402. Dissanti kho panātiādi tesaṃ laddhibhindanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha brāhmaṇiyoti
analyzed: dissanti kho pana atiādi tesam laddhi bhindana attham vuttam tattha brāhmaṇiyā ti
translated: “But, brahmin, we see…” etc. was said in order to break their conceit. Herein, brahmin women are seen

original: brāhmaṇānaṃ puttapaṭilābhatthāya āvāhavivāhavasena kulā ānītā brāhmaṇiyo dissanti.
analyzed: brāhmaṇānam putta paṭilābha tthāya āvāha vivāha vasena kulāḥ ānītāḥ brāhmaṇiyaḥ dissanti
translated: who have been brought to the families of brahmins for the purpose of bearing children, by way of marriage and betrothal.

original: Tā kho panetā aparena samayena utuniyopi honti, sañjātapupphāti attho. Gabbhiniyoti
analyzed: tāḥ kho pana itāḥ aparena samayena utuniyaḥ api honti sañjāta pupphā ati attho gabbhiniyaḥ ti
translated: But at another time, after a while, they become menstruating women, the meaning is, they have their periods. They become pregnant

original: sañjātagabbhā. Vijāyamānāti puttadhītaro janayamānā. Pāyamānāti dārake thaññaṃ pāyantiyo.🔽Yonijāva samānāti brāhmaṇīnaṃ passāvamaggena jātā samānā. Evamāhaṃsūti evaṃ vadanti.
analyzed: sañjāta gabbhā vijāyamānā ati putta dhītaraḥ janayamānā pāyamānā ati dārake thaññam pāyantiyaḥ  samānā ati brāhmaṇīnam passa avamaggena jātā samānā evam āhaṃsu iti evam vadanti
translated: and give birth. They are suckling their children.🔽They are born of the womb, the meaning is, they are born from the womb of a brahmin woman. They say thus:

original: Kathaṃ? Brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo…pe… brahmadāyādāti. Yadi pana nesaṃ saccavacanaṃ
analyzed: katham seṭṭhaḥ vaṇṇa upe brahma dāyā adāti yadi pana sacca vacanam
translated: How do they say? “Only the brahmin race is the highest…they are the heirs of Brahma.” But if their statement is true,

original: siyā, brāhmaṇīnaṃ kucchi mahābrahmuno uro bhaveyya, brāhmaṇīnaṃ passāvamaggo mahābrahmuno
analyzed: siyā brāhmaṇīnam kucchi mahābrahmunaḥ uraḥ bhaveyya brāhmaṇīnam passa avamaggaḥ mahābrahmunaḥ
translated: the womb of the brahmin women could be the chest of Great Brahmā, the brahmin women’s vagina could be Great Brahmā’s🔽

original: mukhaṃ bhaveyya, ettāvatā “mayaṃ mahābrahmuno ure vasitvā mukhato nikkhantā”ti vattuṃ
analyzed: mukham bhaveyya ettāvatā mayam mahābrahmuno ure vasitvā mukhataḥ nikkhantā ati vattum
translated: The brahmin woman’s womb might be the Great Brahmā’s chest, the brahmin woman’s passage of urine and excrement might be the Great Brahmā’s mouth, and to this extent they might say: ‘We have dwelt in the Great Brahmā’s chest and have come forth from his mouth.’🔽But let them not be able to say this.

original: mā labhantūti ayaṃ mukhato jātacchedakavādo vutto.
analyzed: mā labhantu iti ayam mukhataḥ jāta chedaka vādaḥ vutto
translated: This is the view called ‘the annihilationists who are divided by the mouth.’

original: 403. Ayyo hutvā dāso hoti, dāso hutvā ayyo hotīti brāhmaṇo sabhariyo vaṇijjaṃ payojento
analyzed: ayyaḥ hutvā dāsaḥ hoti dāsaḥ hutvā ayyaḥ hoti iti brāhmaṇo sa bhariyaḥ vaṇijjam payojento
translated: ‘Having been a master he becomes a slave, having been a slave he becomes a master’—a brahmin who is a trader,

original: yonakaraṭṭhaṃ vā kambojaraṭṭhaṃ vā gantvā kālaṃ karoti, tassa gehe vayappatte putte
analyzed: yonaka raṭṭham vā kamboja raṭṭham vā gantvā kālam karoti tassa gehe vaya patte putte
translated: having gone to the country of the Yonas or to the country of the Kambojas, dies there. His son,🔽having reached the age of discretion,

original: asati brāhmaṇī dāsena vā kammakarena vā saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappeti. Ekasmiṃ dārake
analyzed: asati brāhmaṇī dāsena vā kammakarena vā saddhim saṃvāsam kappeti ekasmin dārake
translated: lives with the brahmin woman, either with a slave or with a worker. When a child is born to them,

original: jāte so puriso dāsova hoti, tassa jātadārako pana dāyajjasāmiko hoti. Mātito suddho
analyzed: jāte so puriso dāso va hoti tassa jāta dārako pana dāyajja sāmikaḥ hoti mātitaḥ suddho
translated: that man is still a slave, but the child born to him is a master. He is pure on his mother’s side,

original: pitito asuddho so vaṇijjaṃ payojento majjhimapadesaṃ gantvā brāhmaṇadārikaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: pititaḥ asuddhaḥ saḥ vaṇijjam payojentaḥ majjhima padesam gantvā brāhmaṇa dārikam gahetvā
translated: but impure on his father’s side. Having gone to the Middle Country, he takes a brahmin girl.

original: tassā kucchismiṃ puttaṃ paṭilabhati, sopi mātitova suddho hoti pitito asuddho. Evaṃ
analyzed: tassā kucchismim puttam paṭilabhati saḥ api mātitaḥ uva suddhaḥ hoti pititaḥ a suddhaḥ evam
translated: He begets a son in her womb. He is pure on the mother’s side, but impure on the father’s side. Thus

original: brāhmaṇasamayasmiññeva jātisambhedo hotīti dassanatthametaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiṃ balaṃ, ko
analyzed: brāhmaṇa samayasmin ñeva jāti sambhedaḥ hoti iti dassana attham etam vuttam kim balam ko
translated: it is said in order to show that there is a mixture of castes even in the Brahmanical system. What is the strength? What is the
