original: 404. Khattiyova nu khotiādayo suttacchedakavādā nāma honti.🔽408. Idāni cātuvaṇṇisuddhiṃ dassento idha rājātiādimāha. Sāpānadoṇiyāti sunakhānaṃ

translated: For there is a fifth class of people who are a mixture of the first four. In order to show the faults in their doctrine in brief, the Buddha says, “If a noble youth … were to have intercourse with a brahmin girl … ”

original: uppanno khattiyapādasiko nāma, itaro brāhmaṇapādasiko nāma, ete hīnajātimāṇavakā.

original: Evaṃ pañcamassa vaṇṇassa atthitāya cātuvaṇṇisuddhīti etesaṃ vāde dosaṃ dassetvā idāni

original: Thālipāketi paṇṇākārabhatte. Yaññeti yaññabhatte. Pāhuneti āgantukānaṃ katabhatte.

original: Sabbametaṃ pañcasīlamattameva sandhāya vadanti.🔽Kālyāṇavācotiādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā vācā assāti kalyāṇavāco.🔽Kalyāṇaṃ madhuraṃ vākkaraṇaṃ assāti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo. Vākkaraṇanti udāharaṇaghoso.
analyzed: sabbam etam pañca sīla mattam eva sandhāya vadanti  kālyāṇa vācaḥ iti ādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍala pada byañjanā vācā assa ati kalyāṇa vācaḥ  kalyāṇam madhuram vāc karaṇam assa ati kalyāṇa vāc karaṇaḥ udāharaṇa ghosaḥ
translated: All this is said with reference to the five training precepts only.🔽As to “of kindly speech,” etc., he has kindly speech, thus he is of kindly speech.🔽He has kindly, sweet speech-utterance, thus he is of kindly speech-utterance. Speech-utterance is the sound of an utterance.

original: Guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure bhavāti porī. Pure vā bhavattā porī. Nāgarikitthiyā sukhumālattanena
analyzed: guṇa paripuṇṇa bhāvena pure bhavāti porī pure vā bhavattā porī nāgari kitthiyā
translated: He has been for a long time, for a long period, thus he is long-standing. Or alternatively, he is long-standing because he has been for a long time. He is like the long-standing courtesan of Benares, who was well-known for her skill.

original: sadisātipi porī. Tāya poriyā. Vissaṭṭhāyāti apalibuddhāya, sandiṭṭhavilambitādidosarahitāya.
analyzed: porī tāya poriyā vissaṭṭhāya ati apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭha vilambita ādi dosa rahitāya
translated: He is long-standing with that long-standing courtesan, thus he is long-standing with a long-standing courtesan. Unrestrained: unhampered, free from the delay of hesitation, etc.,

original: Anelagalāyāti elagalena virahitāya. Ekaccassa hi kathentassa elaṃ galati, lālā vā
analyzed: anelagalāya ati elagalena virahitāya ekaccassa hi kathentassa elam galati lālā vā
translated: Unclogged: free from the clogging of the throat. For when some people talk, their throat clogs up, their saliva dries up,

original: paggharati, kheḷaphusitāni vā nikkhamanti, tassa vācā elagalā nāma hoti. Tabbiparitāyāti
analyzed: paggharati kheḷa phusitāni vā nikkhamanti tassa vācā elagalā nāma hoti tad biparitāya ati
translated: Or else, if his saliva trickles or his mouth waters, his speech is called “slovenly.”🔽The meaning is: “The opposite of that.”

original: attho. Atthassa viññāpaniyātiādimajjhapariyosānaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā bhāsitatthassa viññāpanasamatthāya.
analyzed: atthaḥ atthassa viññāpaniyā ati ādi majjha pariyosānam pākaṭam katvā bhāsita tthassa viññāpana samatthāya
translated: Capable of making known the meaning: capable of making known the meaning that is being spoken of, making it clear in the middle and at the end.

original: Sesamettha brāhmaṇavaṇṇe uttānameva.
analyzed: sesam ettha brāhmaṇa vaṇṇe uttānam eva
translated: The rest here is just praise of the brahmins.

original: 425. Evaṃ vutteti evaṃ tehi brāhmaṇehi vutte, caṅkī, “ime brāhmaṇā attano vaṇṇe vuccamāne🔽atussanakasatto nāma natthi, vaṇṇamassa bhaṇitvā nivāressāmāti jātiādīhi mama vaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: evam vuttā iti evam tehi brāhmaṇehi vutte caṅkī ime brāhmaṇāḥ attanaḥ vaṇṇe vuccamāne  nāma natthi vaṇṇam assa bhaṇitvā nivāressāma ati jāti ādīhi mama vaṇṇam
translated: When this was said: when this was said by those brahmins, Caṅkī thought: “When their own praise is being spoken of,🔽there is no brahmin who is not pleased. I will stop them by praising myself. They are praising me with my birth, etc.

original: vadanti, na kho pana me yuttaṃ attano vaṇṇe rajjituṃ. Handāhaṃ etesaṃ vādaṃ bhinditvā
analyzed: vadanti na kho pana me yuttam attanaḥ vaṇṇe rajjitum handa aham etesam vādam bhinditvā
translated: It is not proper for me to be pleased with my own praise. Well, I will break their argument

original: samaṇassa gotamassa mahantabhāvaṃ ñāpetvā etesaṃ tattha gamanaṃ karomī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: samaṇassa gotamassa mahanta bhāvam ñāpetvā etesam tattha gamanam karomi iti cintetvā
translated: and make them understand the greatness of the ascetic Gotama, and then I will get them to go to him.” Having thought this,

original: tena hi, bho, mamāpi suṇāthātiādimāha. Tattha yepi “ubhato sujāto”tiādayo attano
analyzed: tena hi bho mama api suṇātha atiādim āha tattha ye pi ubhatas attano
translated: he said: “Then listen, gentlemen, to my reply.” Here, those who say “well-born on both sides” and so on are praising his

original: guṇehi sadisā guṇā, tepi “ko cāhaṃ, ke ca samaṇassa gotamassa jātisampattiādayo guṇā”ti
analyzed: guṇehi sadisāḥ guṇā te api kaḥ ca aham ke ca samaṇassa gotamassa jāti sampatti ādayaḥ
translated: “The qualities are equal to the qualities” means that he thought, “What am I, and what are the qualities of the ascetic Gotama, such as his perfect birth?”🔽and he thought that his own qualities were superior to the other qualities. But the other qualities were proclaimed

original: attano guṇehi uttaritareyeva maññamāno, itare pana ekanteneva bhagavato mahantabhāvadīpanatthaṃ🔽pakāseti. Mayameva arahāmāti evaṃ niyamento cettha idaṃ dīpeti – yadi guṇamahantatāya
analyzed: attanaḥ guṇehi maññamānaḥ itare pana ekantena iva bhagavataḥ mahanta bhāva dīpana attham  pakāseti mayam eva evam ca itthā idam dīpeti yadi guṇa mahantatāya
translated: in order to show the greatness of the Blessed One.

original: upasaṅkamitabbo nāma hoti, yathā sineruṃ upanidhāya sāsapo, mahāsamuddaṃ upanidhāya
analyzed: upasaṅkamitabbaḥ nāma hoti yathā sinerum upanidhāya sāsapaḥ mahā samuddam upanidhāya
translated: “We alone are worthy” means that he was saying this: “If one is worthy to approach because of the greatness of his qualities, then just as a jujube leaf is small in comparison with Sineru,

original: gopadakaṃ, sattasu mahāsaresu udakaṃ upanidhāya ussāvabindu paritto lāmako, evamevaṃ
analyzed: gopadakam sattasu mahā saresu udakam upanidhāya ussāva bindu parittaḥ lāmakaḥ evam evam
translated: or a drop of water is small in comparison with the great ocean, or a drop of water on the tip of a blade of grass is small in comparison with the water in the seven great lakes,

original: samaṇassa gotamassa jātisampattiādayo guṇe upanidhāya amhākaṃ guṇā parittā lāmakā,
analyzed: samaṇassa gotamassa jāti sampatti ādayaḥ guṇe upanidhāya amhākam guṇā parittāḥ lāmakā
translated: in the same way our qualities are small and insignificant in comparison with the qualities of the ascetic Gotama, such as his perfect birth.

original: tasmā mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitunti.
analyzed: tasmai mayam eva arahāma tam bhavantam gotamam dassanāya upasaṅkamitun ti
translated: Therefore we alone are worthy to approach the Master Gotama in order to see him.”

original: Bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhañcāti ettha rājaṅgaṇe ceva uyyāne ca sudhāmaṭṭhā pokkharaṇiyo
analyzed: bhūmi gatañca vehāsaṭṭhañca ati ettha rājaṅgaṇe ca iva uyyāne ca sudhāmaṭṭhā pokkharaṇiyo
translated: “On the ground and in the sky” means that the lotus ponds were in the royal court and in the park.

original: sattaratanapūriṃ katvā bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapitaṃ dhanaṃ bhūmigataṃ nāma, pāsādaniyūhādayo
analyzed: satta ratana pūrim katvā bhūmiyam ṭhapitam dhanam bhūmigatam nāma pāsāda niyūha ādayaḥ
translated: Wealth placed on the ground after filling the seven royal treasures is called “on the ground.” Palaces, etc.,

original: pana pūretvā ṭhapitaṃ vehāsaṭṭhaṃ nāma. Evaṃ tāva kulapariyāyena āgataṃ. Tathāgatassa
analyzed: pana pūretvā ṭhapitam vehāsaṭṭham nāma evam tāva kula pariyāyena āgatam tathāgatassa
translated: The wealth that is placed on the ground after filling up the seven treasures is called “on the ground.” But that which is placed after filling up a palace, etc., is called “in the air.” Thus it is obtained by the method of the clans.

original: pana jātadivaseyeva saṅkho elo uppalo puṇḍarīkoti cattāro nidhayo upagatā. Tesu saṅkho
analyzed: pana jāta divaseya iva saṅkhaḥ elaḥ uppalo puṇḍarīko ti cattāro nidhayaḥ upagatā tesu saṅkhaḥ
translated: But on the very day of the Tathāgata’s birth, four treasures came to him: a conch, a mirror, a great cluster of gems, and a treasure trove.

original: gāvutiko, elo aḍḍhayojaniko, uppalo tigāvutiko puṇḍarīko yojanikoti. Tesupi gahitagahitaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: gāvutikaḥ elaḥ aḍḍha yojanikaḥ uppalo ti gāvutiko puṇḍarīkaḥ yojanikaḥ ti tesu pi gahita gahita ṭṭhānam
translated: Of these, the conch was worth a hundred thousand, the mirror a hundred thousand, the great cluster of gems a hundred thousand, and the treasure trove a hundred thousand.

original: pūratiyeva. Iti bhagavā pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajitoti veditabbo. Daharo
analyzed: pūratiyā iva iti bhagavā pahūtam hirañña suvaṇṇam ohāya pabbajitaḥ iti veditabbaḥ daharaḥ
translated: And wherever they were taken, they were filled again. Thus it should be understood that the Blessed One went forth leaving behind him much gold and silver.

original: vātiādīni heṭṭhā vitthāritāneva.
analyzed: vāti ādīni heṭṭhā
translated: “Young” and the rest have been explained above.

original: Akhuddāvakāsoti ettha bhagavati aparimāṇoyeva dassanāvakāsoti veditabbo. Tatridaṃ
analyzed: ettha bhagavati aparimāṇaḥ yā iva dassana avakāso ti veditabbaḥ tatra idam
translated: “An opportunity to see the Blessed One” should be understood as an opportunity to see the Blessed One, which is immeasurable.

original: vatthuṃ – rājagahe kira aññataro brāhmaṇo “samaṇassa kira gotamassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ
analyzed: vatthum rājagahe kira aññataraḥ brāhmaṇaḥ samaṇassa kira gotamassa pamāṇam gahetum
translated: Here is a story: In Rājagaha, it seems, a certain brahmin thought, “I will take the measure of the recluse Gotama’s

original: na sakkā”ti sutvā bhagavato piṇḍāya pavisanakāle saṭṭhihatthaṃ veḷuṃ gahetvā nagaradvārassa
analyzed: na sakkā ati sutvā bhagavato piṇḍāya pavisana kāle saṭṭhi hattham veḷum gahetvā nagara dvārassa
translated: “I cannot.” When he heard that, he took a bamboo pole sixty cubits long, and stood outside the city gate

original: bahi ṭhatvā sampatte bhagavati veḷuṃ gahetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi, veḷu bhagavato jāṇumattaṃ
analyzed: bahi ṭhatvā sampatte bhagavati veḷum gahetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi veḷu bhagavataḥ jāṇumattam
translated: when the Exalted One entered the city for alms. When the Exalted One came near, he raised the bamboo pole, and it reached only to the Exalted One’s knee.

original: pāpuṇi. Punadivase dve veḷū ghaṭetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi, bhagavā dvinnaṃ veḷūnaṃ upari
analyzed: pāpuṇi puna divase dve veḷū ghaṭetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi bhagavā dvinnam veḷūnam upari
translated: The next day he took two bamboo poles, joined them together, and stood near the Exalted One. The Exalted One appeared to be two bamboo poles high.

original: dviveṇumattameva paññāyamāno, “brāhmaṇa, kiṃ karosī”ti āha? Tumhākaṃ pamāṇaṃ gaṇhāmīti.
analyzed: dvi veṇu mattam eva paññāyamānaḥ brāhmaṇa kim karosi iti āha tumhākam pamāṇam gaṇhāmi iti
translated: “Brahmin, what are you doing?” “I am measuring your height.”

original: “Brāhmaṇa, sacepi tvaṃ sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ pūretvā ṭhitaveḷuṃ ghaṭetvā āgamissasi,
analyzed: brāhmaṇa sace api tvam sakala cakkavāḷa gabbham pūretvā ṭhita veḷum ghaṭetvā āgamissasi
translated: “Brahmin, even if you were to bring bamboo poles filling the entire cosmos and join them together,

original: neva me pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ sakkhissasi. Na hi mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni kappasatasahassañca
analyzed: na iva me pamāṇam gahetum sakkhissasi na hi mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni kappa sata sahassam ca
translated: you would not be able to measure me. For I have fulfilled the perfections for four incalculable ages and a hundred thousand aeons,

original: tathā pāramiyo pūritā, yathā me paro pamāṇaṃ gaṇheyya, atulo brāhmaṇa, tathāgato
analyzed: tathā pāramiyaḥ pūritā yathā me paras pamāṇam gaṇheyya atulaḥ brāhmaṇa tathāgataḥ
translated: so that no one can measure me. The Tathāgata is incomparable, brahmin,

original: appameyyo”ti vatvā dhammapade gāthamāha. Gāthāpariyosāne caturāsītipāṇasahassāni amataṃ piviṃsu.
analyzed: appameyyaḥ ti vatvā dhammapade gātham āha gāthā pariyosāne caturāsīti pāṇa sahassāni amatam piviṃsu
translated: At the conclusion of the verse eighty-four thousand living beings drank the deathless drink.

original: Aparampi vatthu – rāhu kira asurindo cattāri yojanasahassāni aṭṭha ca yojanasatāni
analyzed: aparam pi vatthu rāhu kira asurindo cattāri yojana sahassāni aṭṭha ca yojana satāni
translated: There is another story: Rāhu, it seems, the king of the Asuras, was four thousand and eight hundred leagues high,

original: ucco, bāhantaramassa dvādasayojanasatāni, hatthatalapādatalānaṃ puthulatā tīṇi yojanasatāni,
analyzed: uccas dvādasa yojana satāni hattha tala pāda talānam puthula tā tīṇi yojana satāni
translated: and the distance between his shoulders was twelve hundred leagues. The palms of his hands and the soles of his feet were three hundred leagues in extent,

original: aṅgulipabbāni paṇṇāsayojanāni, bhamukantaraṃ paṇṇāsayojanaṃ, nalāṭaṃ tiyojanasataṃ,
analyzed: aṅguli pabbāni paṇṇāsa yojanāni bhamukantaram paṇṇāsa yojanam nalāṭam ti yojana satam
translated: and the fingers of his hands and the toes of his feet were fifty leagues in length. The distance between his eyes was fifty leagues,

original: sīsaṃ navayojanasataṃ. So – “ahaṃ uccosmi, satthāraṃ onamitvā oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmī”ti
analyzed: sīsam nava yojana satam saḥ aham ucco asmi satthāram onamitvā oloketum na sakkhissāmi iti
translated: and his head was nine hundred leagues in extent. He thought to himself, “I am so tall that I shall not be able to look at the Teacher without bending down.”

original: na gacchati. So ekadivasaṃ bhagavato vaṇṇaṃ sutvā “yathā kathañca olokessāmī”ti āgato.
analyzed: na gacchati saḥ eka divasam bhagavataḥ vaṇṇam sutvā yathā kathañca olokessāmi iti āgataḥ
translated: and he did not go. But one day he heard the praises of the Exalted One and thought to himself, “I will go and see him, whatever happens.”

original: Bhagavā tassa ajjhāsayaṃ viditvā “catūsu iriyāpathesu katarena dassemī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: bhagavā tassa ajjhāsayam viditvā catūsu iriyāpathesu katarena dassemi iti cintetvā
translated: The Exalted One, knowing his thoughts, considered within himself, “In what posture shall I stand when I reveal myself to him?”

original: “ṭhitako nāma nīcopi ucco viya paññāyati, nipannovassa attānaṃ dassessāmī”ti, “ānanda,🔽gandhakuṭipariveṇe mañcakaṃ paññāpehī”ti vatvā tattha sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi. Rāhu āgantvā
analyzed: ṭhitakaḥ nāma nīcaḥ api uccaḥ viya paññāyati attānam dassessāmi iti ānanda  gandha kuṭi pariveṇe mañcakam paññāpehi iti vatvā tattha sīha seyyam kappesi rāhu āgantvā
translated: “Standing, he is as tall as a palm-tree. I will show him to myself lying down.”🔽“Ānanda, prepare a bed between the Gabled Hall and the gateway.” He lay down on his right side in the lion’s posture, placing one foot on the other. Rāhu came and looked at the Exalted One lying down.

original: nipannaṃ bhagavantaṃ gīvaṃ unnāmetvā nabhamajjhe puṇṇacandaṃ viya ulloketi. Kimidaṃ🔽asurindāti ca vutte, bhagavā onamitvā oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmīti na gacchinti. Na🔽mayā asurinda adhomukhena pāramiyo pūritā, uddhaggaṃ me katvā dānaṃ dinnanti. Taṃdivasaṃ
analyzed: nipannam bhagavantam gīvam unnāmetvā nabha majjhe puṇṇa candam viya ulloketi kim idam  asurinda iti ca vutte bhagavā onamitvā oloketum na sakkhissāmi iti na gacchinti na  mayā asurinda adhomukhena pāramiyaḥ pūritāḥ uddhaggam me katvā dānam tat divasam
translated: He looked like the full moon in the middle of the sky. “What is this?”🔽“I will not be able to look down at him. I will not go.”

original: rāhu saraṇaṃ agamāsi. Evaṃ bhagavā akhuddāvakāso dassanāya.🔽Catupārisuddhisīlena sīlavā. Taṃ pana sīlaṃ ariyaṃ uttamaṃ parisuddhaṃ, tenāha ariyasīlīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā akhudda avakāsaḥ dassanāya  catu pārisuddhi sīlena sīlavā tam pana sīlam ariyam uttamam parisuddham tena āha ariya sīlī iti
translated: “Rāhu, I did not perfect the pāramīs with my head down. I gave gifts with my head up.” On that day Rāhu went for refuge. Thus the Exalted One is not a place of disappointment for those who go to see him.🔽He is virtuous by means of the virtue of the fourfold purity. But that virtue is noble and supreme, and thus he is said to be “virtuous in the noble way.”

original: Tadeva anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ, tenāha kusalasīlīti. Kusalena sīlenāti idamassa vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: tat eva anavajja ṭṭhena kusalam tena āha kusala sīlī iti kusalena sīlena ati idam assa vevacanam
translated: That same virtue is skillful in the sense of being blameless, and thus he is said to be “virtuous in the skillful way.” “Virtuous in skillful virtue” is a synonym for this.

original: Bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyoti bhagavato ekekāya dhammadesanāya caturāsītipāṇasahassāni
analyzed: bahūnam bhagavato ekekāya dhamma desanāya catur āsīti pāṇa sahassāni
translated: “Teacher of many, teacher of the multitude” : by each discourse of the Exalted One, eighty-four thousand living beings

original: aparimāṇāpi devamanussā maggaphalāmataṃ pivanti. Tasmā bahūnaṃ ācariyo, sāvakavineyyānaṃ pācariyoti.
analyzed: deva manussāḥ magga phala amatam pivanti tasmai bahūnam ācariyo sāvaka vineyyānam pācariyo ti
translated: and innumerable gods and men drink the nectar of the paths and fruits. Therefore he is the teacher of many, the teacher of the multitude of disciples to be trained.

original: Khīṇakāmarāgoti ettha kāmaṃ bhagavato sabbepi kilesā khīṇā, brāhmaṇo pana te na jānāti,
analyzed: khīṇa kāma rāgaḥ ti ettha kāmam bhagavato sabbe pi kilesā khīṇā brāhmaṇaḥ pana te na jānāti
translated: “One who has destroyed the lusts” : although all the defilements of the Exalted One have been destroyed, the brahmin does not know this.

original: attano jānanaṭṭhāneyeva guṇaṃ katheti. Vigatacāpalloti “pattamaṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā
analyzed: attanaḥ jānana ṭṭhāneyā iva guṇam kathā iti vigata cāpallā iti patta maṇḍanā cīvara maṇḍanā
translated: He speaks of a quality that the brahmin himself knows: “free from fickleness” : “the fickleness of bowls, the fickleness of robes,

original: senāsanamaṇḍanā imassa vā pūtikāyassa…pe… kelanā paṭikelanā”ti evaṃ vuttacāpalyavirahito.
analyzed: senāsana maṇḍanā imassa vā pūti kāyassape kelanā paṭikelanā ti evam vutta cāpalya virahitaḥ
translated: the fickleness of beds and seats, the fickleness of this putrid body, the fickleness of gain, the fickleness of fame, the fickleness of praise, the fickleness of happiness, the fickleness of bad unwholesome states that are unbecoming to a contemplative, shaven-headed, in the saffron robe” .

original: Apāpapurekkhāroti apāpe navalokuttaradhamme purato katvā vicarati. Brahmaññāya pajāyāti
analyzed: apāpa purekkhāro ti apāpe nava lokuttara dhamme puratas katvā vicarati brahmaññāya pajāyāti
translated: “One who has no concern for evil” : he lives with the nine supramundane states of the ariyan disciple placed in the forefront. “One who has been born into the brahmin class” :

original: sāriputtamoggallānamahākassapādibhedāya brāhmaṇapajāya. (Aviruddho hi so) etissāya
analyzed: sāriputta moggallāna mahākassapa ādi bhedāya brāhmaṇa pajāya a viruddhaḥ hi saḥ etissāya
translated: into the brahmin class consisting of Sariputta, Moggallana, Kassapa, and the rest. For he is not opposed to this class.

original: pajāya purekkhāro. Ayañhi pajā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ purato katvā caratīti attho. Apica
analyzed: pajāya purekkhāraḥ ayam hi pajā samaṇam gotamam puratas katvā carati iti atthaḥ apica
translated: He is the leader of this class. The meaning is that this class lives with the recluse Gotama placed in the forefront.

original: apāpapurekkhāroti na pāpupurekkhāro, na pāpaṃ purato katvā carati, pāpaṃ na icchatīti
analyzed: a pāpa purekkhāraḥ ti na pāpupurekkhāraḥ na pāpam puratas katvā carati pāpam naḥ icchati iti
translated: “With no wish for evil”: he has no wish for evil, he does not go about doing evil, he does not wish for evil.

original: attho. Kassa? Brahmaññāya pajāya attanā saddhiṃ paṭiviruddhāyapi brāhmaṇapajāya aviruddho
analyzed: attho kassa brahmaññāya pajāya attanā saddhim paṭiviruddhāya api brāhmaṇa pajāya a viruddhaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he does not wish for evil. For whom? For the brahmin people who are opposed to him, even though they are opposed to him.

original: hitasukhatthikoyevāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vuttam hoti
translated: He is not opposed to them, but he is only concerned with their welfare and happiness.

original: Tiroraṭṭhāti pararaṭṭhato. Tirojanapadāti parajanapadato. Saṃpucchituṃ āgacchantīti
analyzed: tiroraṭṭhā ati para raṭṭhataḥ tirojanapadā ati para janapadataḥ saṃpucchitum āgacchanti iti
translated: “From other countries”: from other kingdoms. “From other lands”: from other countries. “Come to ask”:

original: khattiyapaṇḍitādayo ceva brāhmaṇagandhabbādayo ca pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā pucchissāmāti
analyzed: khattiya paṇḍita ādayo ca iva brāhmaṇa gandhabba ādayo ca pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā pucchissāma ati
translated: having formulated questions, the wise nobles, etc., and the brahmin householders, etc., come thinking, “We will ask.”

original: āgacchanti. Tattha keci pucchāya vā dosaṃ vissajjanasampaṭicchane vā asamatthataṃ
analyzed: āgacchanti tattha keci pucchāya vā dosam vissajjana sampaṭicchane vā a samattha tam
translated: There, some, having discerned a fault in the question or an inability to answer it,

original: sallakkhetvā apucchitvāva tuṇhī nisīdanti, keci pucchanti, kesañci bhagavā pucchāya
analyzed: sallakkhetvā a pucchitvā ava tuṇhī nisīdanti keci pucchanti kesañci bhagavā pucchāya
translated: sit down silently without asking. Some ask. The Blessed One encourages some to ask by saying, “Ask, bhikkhus.”

original: ussāhaṃ janetvā vissajjeti. Evaṃ sabbesampi tesaṃ vimatiyo tīraṃ patvā mahāsamuddassa
analyzed: ussāham janetvā vissajjeti evam sabbesam pi tesam vimatiyaḥ tīram patvā mahā samuddassa
translated: Thus all their doubts are dispelled, and they are like the great ocean, which cannot be measured by, “How many gallons does it contain?”

original: ūmiyo viya bhagavantaṃ patvāva bhijjanti. Sesamettha tathāgatassa vaṇṇe uttānameva.
analyzed: ūmiyaḥ viya bhagavantam patvā ava bhijjanti sesam ettha tathāgatassa vaṇṇe uttānam eva
translated: and they broke up as soon as they reached the Exalted One, like waves on the ocean. The rest of the passage is mere praise of the Tathāgata.🔽They are our guests: the meaning is that they are our visitors, our newcomers, our guests.

original: Atithī no te hontīti te amhākaṃ āgantukā navakā pāhunakā hontīti attho. Pariyāpuṇāmīti
analyzed: atithī no te honti iti te amhākam āgantukāḥ navakā pāhunakāḥ honti iti attho pariyāpuṇāmi iti
translated: I will learn:

original: jānāmi. Aparimāṇavaṇṇoti tathārūpeneva sabbaññunāpi appameyyavaṇṇo, pageva mādisenāti
analyzed: jānāmi aparimāṇa vaṇṇaḥ ti tathārūpena iva sabbaññunā api appameyya vaṇṇo pagā iva mādisena ati
translated: I will know. Of immeasurable glory: his glory is immeasurable even to the Omniscient One himself, who is of such a nature, how much more so to one like me.

original: dasseti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: dassa iti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: This is shown. And this is said:

original: “Buddhopi buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇaṃ,
analyzed: buddhaḥ api buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇam
translated: “Even if the Buddha were to speak the praise of the Buddha

original: Kappampi ce aññamabhāsamāno;🔽Khīyetha kappo ciradīghamantare,
analyzed: kappam pi ce aññam a bhāsamāno  khīyetha cira dīgham antare
translated: For an eon, and then speak it again for another eon,

original: Vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassā”ti.
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa ati
translated: The eon would be used up, but the description of the Tathāgata’s glory would not be used up.”

original: Imaṃ pana guṇakathaṃ sutvā te brāhmaṇā cintayiṃsu “yathā, caṅkī, samaṇassa gotamassa
analyzed: imam pana guṇa katham sutvā te brāhmaṇā cintayiṃsu yathā caṅkī samaṇassa gotamassa
translated: Having heard this discourse on the qualities, the brahmins thought: “As Caṅkī speaks the praise of the recluse Gotama,

original: vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, anomaguṇo so bhavaṃ gotamo, evaṃ tassa guṇe jānamānena kho pana iminā
analyzed: vaṇṇam bhāsati anoma guṇo saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ evam tassa guṇe jānamānena kho pana iminā
translated: the venerable Gotama must be of incomparable qualities. But this one,

original: aticiraṃ adhivāsitaṃ, handa naṃ anuvattāmā”ti anuvattamānā “tena hi, bho”tiādimāhaṃsu.
analyzed: aticiram adhivāsitam handa nam anuvattāmāti anuvattamānā tena hi bhoti ādim āhaṃsu
translated: who knows his qualities, has endured it for too long. Let us follow him.” And following him, they said: “Well then, sirs.”

original: 426. Opātetīti paveseti. Saṃpurekkharontīti puttamattanattamattampi samānaṃ purato katvā vicaranti.🔽427. Mantapadanti mantāyeva mantapadaṃ, vedoti attho. Itihitiha paramparāyāti evaṃ
analyzed: samānam puratas katvā vicaranti  manta padam ti mantāya iva manta padam vedo ti iti hiti ha paramparāya ati evam
translated: ‘He brings in’ means he introduces. ‘They go about with their heads held high’ means they go about with the thought ‘We are the sons of the one who brought in the mantras.’

original: kira evaṃ kirāti paramparabhāvena āgatanti dīpeti. Piṭakasampadāyāti pāvacanasaṅkhātasampattiyā.
analyzed: evam kirāti parampara bhāvena dīpa iti piṭaka sampadā āyāti
translated: ‘Mantrapada’ is the mantra itself, the meaning being ‘Veda.’ ‘Thus, thus, in this way, in this way’ shows that it has come down by a succession of teachers. ‘By the perfection of the Tipitaka’ means by the perfection called the recitation.

original: Sāvittiādīhi chandabandhehi ca vaggabandhehi ca sampādetvā āgatanti dasseti. Tattha🔽cāti tasmiṃ mantapade. Pavattāroti pavattayitāro. Yesanti yesaṃ santakaṃ. Mantapadanti
analyzed: sāvitti ādīhi chanda bandhehi ca vagga bandhehi ca sampādetvā āgata nti dasseti tattha  ca ati tasmin mantapade pavattāraḥ iti pavattayitāraḥ yesanti santakam
translated: He shows that it has come down by the arrangement of the verses beginning with the Sāvitti and by the arrangement of the vaggas. Herein,

original: vedasaṅkhātaṃ mantameva. Gītanti aṭṭhakādīhi dasahi porāṇakabrāhmaṇehi padasampattivasena
analyzed: veda saṅkhātam mantam eva gītam ti aṭṭhaka ādīhi dasahi porāṇaka brāhmaṇehi pada sampatti vasena
translated: ‘there’ means in that mantra-text. ‘The expounders’ means the expounders. ‘Whose’ means whose. ‘Mantrapada’ means the mantra itself called the Veda. ‘Song’ means what has been recited by the ten ancient brahmin seers beginning with Aṭṭhaka by way of the perfection of the words.

original: sajjhāyitaṃ. Pavuttanti aññesaṃ vuttaṃ, vācitanti attho. Samihitanti samupabyūḷhaṃ
analyzed: sajjhāyitam pavuttam ti aññesam vuttam vācitam iti attho samihitam ti samupabyūḷham
translated: ‘What is recited’ means what is recited by others, the meaning being ‘what is chanted.’ ‘Composed’ means well-composed.

original: rāsikataṃ, piṇḍaṃ katvā ṭhapitanti attho. Tadanugāyantīti etarahi brāhmaṇā taṃ tehi🔽pubbe gītaṃ anugāyanti anusajjhāyanti vādenti. Tadanubhāsantīti taṃ anubhāsanti,
analyzed: rāsikatam piṇḍam katvā ṭhapitanti etarahi brāhmaṇā tam tehi  pubbe gītam anugāyanti anusajjhāyanti vādenti tat anubhāsanti iti tam anubhāsanti
translated: the meaning is, they were stored in heaps, in lumps. They sing it after them: at present the brahmins sing it after them, they chant it after them, they speak it after them. They speak after it: they speak after it,

original: idaṃ purimasseva vevacanaṃ. Bhāsitamanubhāsantīti tehi bhāsitaṃ sajjhāyitaṃ anusajjhāyanti.
analyzed: idam purimassa iva vevacanam bhāsitam anubhāsanti iti tehi bhāsitam sajjhāyitam anusajjhāyanti
translated: The meaning is: they are piled up in a heap, made into a lump and set down. They sing after that: at present brahmins sing after that, they recite it, they speak of it. They speak after that: this is a synonym for the former. They speak after what was spoken: they recite what was recited by them.

original: Vācitamanuvācentīti tehi aññesaṃ vācitaṃ anuvācenti. Seyyathidanti te katameti attho.
analyzed: vācitam anuvācenti iti tehi aññesam vācitam anuvācenti te katame iti attho
translated: They recite after what was recited: they recite after what was recited by others. As for example: the meaning is: which of them?

original: Aṭṭhakotiādīni tesaṃ nāmāni, te kira dibbena cakkhunā oloketvā parūpaghātaṃ akatvā🔽kassapasammāsambuddhassa bhagavato pāvacanena saha saṃsandetvā mante ganthesuṃ, aparāpare
analyzed: aṭṭhaka uti ādīni tesam nāmāni te kira dibbena cakkhunā oloketvā para upaghātam a katvā  kassapa sammāsambuddhassa bhagavataḥ pāvacanena saha saṃsandetvā mante ganthesum apara apare
translated: Aṭṭhaka, etc., are their names. They, it seems, after looking with the divine eye, without harming others,

original: pana brāhmaṇā pāṇātipātādīni pakkhipitvā tayo vede bhinditvā buddhavacanena saddhiṃ viruddhe akaṃsu.
analyzed: pana brāhmaṇā pāṇātipāta ādīni pakkhipitvā tayaḥ vede bhinditvā buddha vacanena saddhim viruddhe akaṃsu
translated: after combining it with the word of the Lord, the Perfectly Awakened One Kassapa, they made the mantras into texts. But other brahmins, after inserting killing-breathing-things, etc., divided them into the three Vedas, and made them contradictory with the word of the Buddha.

original: 428. Andhaveṇīti andhapaveṇī. Ekena hi cakkhumatā gahitayaṭṭhiyā koṭiṃ eko andho
analyzed: andha veṇī iti andha paveṇī ekena hi cakkhumatā koṭim ekaḥ andhaḥ
translated: The blind’s stick: the blind’s staff. For one blind man, after taking hold of the end of a stick held by another man who has eyes,

original: gaṇhāti, taṃ andhaṃ añño, taṃ aññoti evaṃ paṇṇāsa saṭṭhi andhā paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā🔽andhaveṇīti vuccati. Paramparāsaṃsattāti aññamaññaṃ laggā, yaṭṭhiggāhakenapi cakkhumatā
analyzed: gaṇhāti tam andham añño tam aññoti evam paṇṇāsa saṭṭhi andhā paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā  andhaveṇī iti vuccati paramparā saṃsattā ati aññam aññam laggā cakkhumatā
translated: If one blind man takes hold of another, and if another takes hold of him, and so on, then fifty or sixty blind men may be linked together in a chain.🔽This is called a “chain of the blind.” “Linked in mutual dependence” means clinging to one another, as though they were holding bamboo staves.

original: virahitāti attho. Eko kira dhutto andhagaṇaṃ disvā “asukasmiṃ nāma gāme khajjabhojjaṃ
analyzed: virahitā ati attho ekaḥ kira dhuttaḥ andha gaṇam disvā asukasmin nāma gāme khajja bhojjam
translated: The meaning is that they are devoid of a man of vision. It is said that a certain robber saw a group of the blind and said, “In such and such a village food and drink are easily obtained.”

original: sulabha”nti ussāhetvā tehi “tattha no sāmi nehi, idaṃ nāma te demā”ti vutte lañjaṃ🔽gahetvā antarāmagge maggā okkamma mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā purimassa hatthena
analyzed: sulabhanti ussāhetvā tehi tattha no sāmi nehi idam nāma te dema iti vutte lañjaṃ  gahetvā antarāmagge maggā okkamma mahantam gaccham anuparigantvā purimassa hatthena
translated: He encouraged them, saying, “Come, let us go there.” When they said, “We will go if you lead us, master,” he took their valuables as a fee,

original: pacchimassa kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā “kiñci kammaṃ atthi, gacchatha tāva tumhe”ti vatvā
analyzed: pacchimassa kaccham gaṇhāpetvā kiñci kammaṃ atthi gacchatha tāva tumhe iti vatvā
translated: and on the way he left the path and went into the jungle. He made the last man in the chain take hold of the first man’s feet, saying, “You have some work to do. Go on ahead.”

original: palāyi. Te divasampi gantvā maggaṃ avindamānā “kahaṃ, bho, cakkhumā kahaṃ maggo”ti
analyzed: palāyi te divasam pi gantvā maggam a vindamānā kaham bho cakkhumā kaham maggo ti
translated: And he ran away. The blind men went on all day, but not finding the path, they cried out, “Where is the man of vision? Where is the path?”

original: paridevitvā maggaṃ avindamānā tattheva mariṃsu. Te sandhāya vuttaṃ “paramparāsaṃsattā”ti.
analyzed: paridevitvā maggam a vindamānā tattha iva mariṃsu te sandhāya vuttam paramparā saṃsattā ati
translated: Not finding the path, they died right there. The Buddha had this in mind when he said, “Linked in mutual dependence.”

original: Purimopīti purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Majjhimopīti majjhe ācariyapācariyesu
analyzed: purimaḥ api iti purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekaḥ api majjhimaḥ api iti majjhe ācariya pācariyesu
translated: “Even one of the first ten Brahmins”: even one of the first ten Brahmins.🔽“Even one of the middle ten Brahmins”: even one of the middle ten Brahmins.

original: ekopi. Pacchimopīti idāni brāhmaṇesu ekopi.
analyzed: ekaḥ api pacchimaḥ api iti idāni brāhmaṇesu ekaḥ api
translated: “Even one of the last ten Brahmins”: even one of the last ten Brahmins.

original: Pañca khoti pāḷiāgatesu dvīsu aññepi evarūpe tayo pakkhipitvā vadati. Dvedhāvipākāti
analyzed: pañca kho ti pāḷi āgatesu dvīsu aññe pi evarūpe tayo pakkhipitvā vadati dvedhā avipākā ati
translated: “Five”: he speaks of five by including three of that sort among the two mentioned in the text.

original: bhūtavipākā vā abhūtavipākā vā. Nālametthāti, bhāradvāja, saccaṃ anurakkhissāmīti🔽paṭipannena viññunā “yaṃ mayā gahitaṃ, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña”nti ettha ekaṃseneva
analyzed: bhūta vipākāḥ vā abhūta vipākāḥ vā na alam ettha ati bhāradvāja saccam anurakkhissāmi iti  paṭipannena viññunā yam mayā gahitam idam eva saccam mogham aññanti ettha ekaṃsena iva
translated: “With a twofold result”: either a true result or a false result.🔽“It is not proper for me to maintain that this is true and the rest is false”:

original: niṭṭhaṃ gantuṃ nālaṃ na yuttanti upari pucchāya maggaṃ vivaritvā ṭhapesi.
analyzed: niṭṭham gantum na alam na yuttam ti upari pucchāya maggam vivaritvā ṭhapesi
translated: one who has set out to maintain that this is true and the rest is false is not fit to come to a definite conclusion by taking one side only and rejecting the other.🔽“Here, Bharadvaja, a bhikkhu”: he speaks of himself.

original: 430. Idha, bhāradvāja, bhikkhūti jīvakasutte viya mahāvacchasutte viya ca attānaññeva sandhāya vadati. Lobhanīyesu dhammesūti lobhadhammesu. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: idha bhāradvāja bhikkhu iti jīvaka sutte viya mahāvaccha sutte viya ca attānam eva sandhāya vadati lobhanīyesu dhammesu iti lobha dhammesu sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo
translated: “In regard to things that breed greed”: in regard to things that are a ground for greed. The same method applies to the other two terms.

original: 432. Saddhaṃ nivesetīti okappaniyasaddhaṃ niveseti. Upasaṅkamatīti upagacchati. Payirupāsatīti
analyzed: saddham niveseti iti okappa niya saddham niveseti upasaṅkamati iti upagacchati payirupāsati iti
translated: He establishes confidence in him: he establishes confidence in him that is inspiring confidence. He approaches: he goes to. He serves:

original: santike nisīdati. Sotanti pasādasotaṃ odahati. Dhammanti desanādhammaṃ suṇāti. Dhāretīti
analyzed: santike nisīdati sotanti pasāda sotam odahati dhammanti desanā dhammam suṇāti dhāreti iti
translated: he sits down near. He listens: he opens the ear-sensitivity. He hears the Dhamma: he hears the Dhamma of the teaching. He bears it in mind:

original: paguṇaṃ katvā dhāreti. Upaparikkhatīti atthato ca kāraṇato ca vīmaṃsati. Nijjhānaṃ🔽khamantīti olokanaṃ khamanti, idha sīlaṃ kathitaṃ, idha samādhīti evaṃ upaṭṭhahantīti🔽attho. Chandoti kattukamyatā chando. Ussahatīti vāyamati. Tuletīti aniccādivasena
analyzed: paguṇam katvā dhāreti upaparikkhati iti atthataḥ ca kāraṇataḥ ca vīmaṃsati nijjhānam  khamanti iti olokanam khamanti sīlam kathitam idha samādhi iti evam upaṭṭhahanti iti  attho chando ti kattu kamyatā chando ussahati iti vāyamati tuleti iti anicca ādi vasena
translated: he bears it in mind after making it a plurality. He investigates: he examines the meaning and the cause. He scrutinizes:

original: tīreti. Padahatīti maggapadhānaṃ padahati. Kāyena ceva paramasaccanti sahajātanāmakāyena🔽ca nibbānaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca kilese nibbijjhitvā tadeva vibhūtaṃ pākaṭaṃ karonto passati.
analyzed: tīreti padahati iti magga padhānam padahati kāyena ca iva sahajāta nāmakāyena 🔽ca nibbānam sacchikaroti paññāya ca kilese nibbijjhitvā tat eva vibhūtam pākaṭam karonto passati
translated: he scrutinizes the meaning and the cause. He is content: he is satisfied. He is not contemptuous of the country: he does not despise the country. He is not contemptuous of the people: he does not despise the people. He is not contemptuous of the Dhamma: he does not despise the Dhamma. He is not contemptuous of the teacher: he does not despise the teacher. He is not contemptuous of the explanation: he does not despise the explanation. He is not contemptuous of the recitation: he does not despise the recitation. He is not contemptuous of the training: he does not despise the training. He is not contemptuous of the minor training rules: he does not despise the minor training rules. He is not contemptuous of the minor training precepts: he does not despise the minor training precepts. He is not contemptuous of the training rules: he does not despise the training rules. He is not contemptuous of the training precepts: he does not despise the training precepts. He is not contemptuous of the training: he does not despise the training. He is not contemptuous of the recitation: he does not despise the recitation. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Pātimokkha: he does not despise the recitation of the Pātimokkha. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Monastic Code: he does not despise the recitation of the Monastic Code. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Monastic Code in its entirety: he does not despise the recitation of the Monastic Code in its entirety. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Monastic Code in sections: he does not despise the recitation of the Monastic Code in sections. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Monastic Code in the middle: he does not despise the recitation of the Monastic Code in the middle. He is not contemptuous of the recitation of the Monastic Code at the end: he does not despise the recitation of the Monastic Code at the end.

original: 433. Saccānubodhoti maggānubodho. Saccānuppattīti phalasacchikiriyā. Tesaṃyevāti
analyzed: sacca anubodhaḥ ti magga anubodhaḥ sacca anuppatti iti phala sacchikiriyā tesam yeva ati
translated: ‘Understanding of the Truths’: understanding of the Path. ‘Realization of the Truths’: realization of the fruition. ‘Of those same’:

original: heṭṭhā vuttānaṃ dvādasannaṃ, evaṃ dīghaṃ maggavādaṃ anulometi, tasmā nāyamattho.
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttānam dvādasannam evam dīgham magga vādam anulomā iti tasmā na ayam attho
translated: of the twelve mentioned above. This is the way of interpreting the text as a long sentence. But that is not the meaning here.

original: Ayaṃ panettha attho – tesaṃyevāti tesaṃ maggasampayuttadhammānaṃ. Padhānanti maggapadhānaṃ.
analyzed: ayam pana ittha atthaḥ tesam yeva ati tesam magga sampayutta dhammānam padhānam ti magga padhānam
translated: The meaning here is this: ‘of those same’ means of those states associated with the path. ‘Pre-eminence’ means pre-eminence of the path.

original: Tañhi phalasacchikiriyasaṅkhātāya saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṃ, magge asati phalābhāvatoti.
analyzed: tat hi phala sacchikiriya saṅkhātāya sacca anuppattiyā bahukāram magge asati phala abhāvato ti
translated: For that is of great service in the realization of the Truths called fruition, since there is no fruition if there is no path.

original: Iminā nayena sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: iminā nayena sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in all the passages. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya in the Papañcasūdanī

original: Caṅkīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: caṅkī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Caṅkī Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Esukārīsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Esakāri Sutta

original: 437. Evaṃ me sutanti esukārīsuttaṃ. Tattha bilaṃ olaggeyyunti koṭṭhāsaṃ laggāpeyyuṃ,
analyzed: evam me sutanti esukārī suttam tattha bilam olaggeyyunti koṭṭhāsam
translated: Thus have I heard. In this sutta, “he would have the grain stored in a granary” means he would have the grain stored in a bin.

original: iminā satthadhammaṃ nāma dasseti. Satthavāho kira mahākantārapaṭipanno antarāmagge
analyzed: iminā sattha dhammam nāma dasseti satthavāhaḥ kira mahā kantāra paṭipannaḥ antarāmagge
translated: By this he shows the duty of a teacher. A caravan leader, it seems, while travelling through a great wilderness,

original: goṇe mate maṃsaṃ gahetvā sabbesaṃ satthikānaṃ “idaṃ khāditvā ettakaṃ mūlaṃ dātabba”nti
analyzed: goṇe mate maṃsam gahetvā sabbesam satthikānam idam khāditvā ettakam mūlam dātabbanti
translated: and having bought the meat of the oxen, he distributed the meat to all the merchants, saying, “Having eaten this, you must pay so much money.”

original: koṭṭhāsaṃ olaggeti, goṇamaṃsaṃ nāma khādantāpi atthi akhādantāpi, mūlaṃ dātuṃ sakkontāpi
analyzed: koṭṭhāsam olaggā iti goṇa maṃsam nāma khādantā api atthi a khādantā api mūlam dātum sakkontā api
translated: There were some who ate the meat of the oxen, and some who did not eat it, and some who were able to pay the money,

original: asakkontāpi. Satthavāho yena mūlena goṇo gahito, tassa nikkhamanatthaṃ sabbesaṃ balakkārena
analyzed: a sakkontā api satthavāhaḥ yena mūlena goṇaḥ gahito tassa nikkhamana attham sabbesam balakkārena
translated: and some who were not able to pay the money. The caravan leader, in order to get the money for the oxen, having distributed the meat by force to all the merchants,

original: koṭṭhāsaṃ datvā mūlaṃ gaṇhāti, ayaṃ satthadhammo. Evamevaṃ brāhmaṇāpi lokassa paṭiññaṃ
analyzed: koṭṭhāsam da tvā mūlam gaṇhāti ayam sattha dhammo evam evam brāhmaṇa api lokassa paṭiññam
translated: took the money. This is the custom of caravans. In the same way, the brahmins, without taking a vow from the world,

original: aggahetvā attanova dhammatāya catasso pāricariyā paññapentīti dassetuṃ evameva khotiādimāha.
analyzed: aggahetvā attanā iva dhamma tāya catasso pāricariyāḥ paññapenti iti dassetum evam eva kho ti ādim āha
translated: themselves, by the nature of things, proclaim the four kinds of service. In order to show this, he said, “In the same way, indeed.”

original: Pāpiyo assāti pāpaṃ assa. Seyyo assāti hitaṃ assa. Atha vā pāpiyoti pāpako lāmako
analyzed: pāpiyaḥ assa ati pāpam assa seyyaḥ assa ati hitam assa atha vā pāpiyaḥ iti pāpakaḥ lāmakaḥ
translated: “Pāpiyo assa” means “bad for him.” “Seyyo assa” means “good for him.” Or, “pāpiyo” means “bad, inferior”

original: attabhāvo assa. Seyyoti seṭṭho uttamo. Seyyaṃsoti seyyo. Uccākulīnatāti uccākulīnattena
analyzed: attabhāvaḥ assa seyyo ti seṭṭhaḥ uttamaḥ seyyaṃso ti seyyaḥ ucca akulīna tā ati ucca akulīna ttena
translated: “attabhāvo assa.” “Seyyo” means “best, excellent.” “Seyyaṃso” means “better.” “Uccākulīnatā” means “high birth.”

original: seyyo. Pāpiyaṃsoti pāpiyo. Uccākulīnatā ca dvīsu kulesu vaḍḍheti khattiyakule brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: ucca akulīna tā ca dvīsu kulesu vaḍḍheti khattiya kule brāhmaṇa kule
translated: Better. Worse: inferior. High birth is found in two families, the noble and the brahmin.

original: ca, uḷāravaṇṇatā tīsu. Vessopi hi uḷāravaṇṇo hoti. Uḷārabhogatā catūsupi. Suddopi
analyzed: ca uḷāra vaṇṇa tā tīsu vessaḥ api hi uḷāra vaṇṇaḥ hoti uḷāra bhoga tā catūsu pi suddaḥ api
translated: Great beauty is found in three families, for even a merchant can be of great beauty. Great wealth is found in all four.

original: hi antamaso caṇḍālopi uḷārabhogo hotiyeva.🔽440. Bhikkhācariyanti koṭidhanenapi hi brāhmaṇena bhikkhā caritabbāva, porāṇakabrāhmaṇā
analyzed: hi caṇḍālaḥ api uḷāra bhogaḥ  bhikkhā cariyanti koṭi dhanena api hi brāhmaṇena bhikkhā caritabbā ava porāṇaka brāhmaṇā
translated: Even a candala can be greatly wealthy.🔽Ascetic practice: even a brahmin with a hundred thousand a year must still go on the alms round. For ancient brahmins with a hundred thousand a year went on the alms round at one time.

original: asītikoṭidhanāpi ekavelaṃ bhikkhaṃ caranti. Kasmā? Duggatakāle carantānaṃ idāni bhikkhaṃ🔽carituṃ āraddhāti garahā na bhavissatīti. Atimaññamānoti yo bhikkhācariyavaṃsaṃ haritvā
analyzed: asīti koṭi dhanā api ekavelam bhikkham caranti kasmā duggata kāle carantānam idāni bhikkham  caritum āraddhā ati garahā na bhavissati iti atimaññamānaḥ ti yaḥ bhikkhā cariya vaṃsam haritvā
translated: Why? So that there would be no criticism of them if they went on the alms round in a time of scarcity.

original: sattajīvakasikammavaṇijjādīhi jīvikaṃ kappeti, ayaṃ atimaññati nāma. Gopo vāti yathā
analyzed: satta jīva kasi kamma vaṇijja ādīhi jīvikam kappeti ayam atimaññati nāma gopaḥ vāti yathā
translated: Overweening: one who, having abandoned the tradition of ascetic practice, makes a living by the seven kinds of brahminical practices, namely, the fire oblations, the tending of cattle, the study of the Vedas, the making of sacrifices, the giving of gifts, the taking of a wife, and the performance of the funeral ceremonies for ancestors, is called “overweening.”

original: gopako attanā rakkhitabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ thenento akiccakārī hoti, evanti attho. Iminā
analyzed: gopakaḥ attanā rakkhitabbam bhaṇḍam thenentaḥ akicca kārī hoti evam ti atthaḥ iminā
translated: As a cowherd: just as a cowherd is a bungler in looking after the goods entrusted to him, so too is this person.

original: nayena sabbavāresu attho veditabbo. Asitabyābhaṅginti tiṇalāyanaasitañceva kājañca.
analyzed: nayena sabba vāresu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ asita byābhaṅgi ti
translated: The meaning should be understood in all instances according to the method stated. “Food and drink”: both the food and drink of grass and hay and the food and drink of grain.

original: Anussaratoti yattha jāto, tasmiṃ porāṇe mātāpettike kulavaṃse anussariyamāneti attho.
analyzed: anussarato ti yattha jātaḥ tasmin porāṇe mātāpettike kula vaṃse anussariyamānā iti attho
translated: “Remembering”: the meaning is that he remembers the ancient family lineage of his mother and father where he was born.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is all clear.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhimanikāya of the Papañcasūdani

original: Esukārīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: esukārī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 7. Dhanañjānisuttavaṇṇanā🔽445. Evaṃ me sutanti dhanañjānisuttaṃ. Tattha dakkhiṇāgirisminti girīti pabbato,
analyzed: dhanañjāni sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutan ti dhanañjāni suttam tattha dakkhiṇāgirismin ti giri iti pabbato
translated: The Dhanañjāni Sutta

original: rājagahaṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitapabbatassa dakkhiṇadisābhāge janapadassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Taṇḍulapālidvārāyāti
analyzed: rājagaham parikkhipitvā ṭhita pabbatassa dakkhiṇa disā bhāge janapadassa etam nāmam taṇḍulapāli dvāra āyāti
translated: Thus I heard. The Dhanañjāni Sutta. There, Dakkhiṇāgiri means “Southern Mountain.” It is the name of a district on the southern side of the mountain that encircles Rājagaha. The threshing floor gate means

original: rājagahassa kira dvattiṃsamahādvārāni catusaṭṭhikhuddakadvārāni, tesu ekaṃ taṇḍulapālidvāraṃ
analyzed: rājagahassa kira dvattiṃsa mahā dvārāni catur aṭṭhi khuddaka dvārāni tesu ekam taṇḍula pāli dvāram
translated: it is said that Rājagaha had thirty-two great gates and sixty-four small gates. Among them, one was called the threshing floor gate.

original: nāma, taṃ sandhāyevamāha. Rājānaṃ nissāyāti “gaccha manusse apīḷetvā sassabhāgaṃ
analyzed: nāma tam sandhāya evam āha rājānam nissāya ati gaccha manusse a pīḍetvā sassa bhāgam
translated: It is in reference to that that it is said thus. “Relying on the king”: “Go and oppress the people and take a share of the rice.”

original: gaṇhāhī”ti raññā pesito gantvā sabbameva sassaṃ gaṇhāti, “mā no, bhante, nāsehī”ti
analyzed: gaṇhāhi iti raññā pesitaḥ gantvā sabbam eva sassam gaṇhāti mā naḥ bhante nāsehi iti
translated: and he went and took all the crops. “Do not cry, Reverend Sir,”

original: ca vutte – “rājakule vuttaṃ mandaṃ, ahaṃ raññā āgamanakāleyeva evaṃ āṇatto, mā kanditthā”ti
analyzed: ca vutte rāja kule vuttam mandam aham raññā āgamana kāleya iva evam āṇattaḥ mā kandittha ati
translated: and he said, “The king’s word is slow. I was ordered by the king at the time of his coming. Do not cry.”

original: evaṃ rājānaṃ nissāya brāhmaṇagahapatike vilumpati. Dhaññaṃ yebhuyyena attano gharaṃ
analyzed: evam rājānam nissāya brāhmaṇa gahapatike vilumpati dhaññam yebhuyyena attanaḥ gharam
translated: Thus he robbed the brahmans and householders by means of the king. Most of the grain he brought to his own house

original: pavesetvā appakaṃ rājakule paveseti. Kiṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ na pīḷaṃ akāsīti ca
analyzed: pavesetvā appakam rājakule paveseti kim brāhmaṇa gahapatikānam na pīḍam akāsi iti ca
translated: and only a little to the king’s house. When asked, “Did you not oppress the brahmans and householders?”

original: vutto – “āma, mahārāja, imasmiṃ vāre khettāni mandasassāni ahesuṃ, tasmā apīḷentassa
analyzed: vuttaḥ mahā rāja imasmin vāre khettāni manda sassāni ahesum tasmai a pīḷentassa
translated: he said, “Yes, great king, but in this case the fields had poor crops, and so I took them without oppressing you.

original: me gaṇhato na bahuṃ jāta”nti evaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatike nissāya rājānaṃ vilumpati.🔽446. Payo pīyatanti taruṇakhīraṃ pivatu. Tāva bhattassāti yāva khīraṃ pivitvā nisīdissatha,
analyzed: me gaṇhataḥ na bahum jātanti evam brāhmaṇa gahapatike nissāya rājānam vilumpati  payaḥ taruṇa khīram pivatu tāva bhattassa ati yāva khīram pivitvā nisīdissatha
translated: I did not get much.” Thus he robbed the king by means of the brahmans and householders.🔽“Let him drink milk” means let him drink fresh milk. “It is time for his meal” means that it will be time for his meal after he has drunk the milk and sat down.

original: tāvadeva bhattassa kālo bhavissati. Idheva hi no pātarāsabhattaṃ āharissantīti dasseti.
analyzed: tāvat eva bhattassa kālaḥ bhavissati idha iva hi naḥ pātarāsa bhattam āharissanti iti dasseti
translated: He shows that they will bring his breakfast right there.

original: Mātāpitarotiādīsu mahallakā mātāpitaro mudukāni attharaṇapāvuraṇāni sukhumāni vatthāni
analyzed: mātā pitaraḥ iti ādīsu mahallakāḥ mātā pitaraḥ mudukāni attharaṇa pāvuraṇāni sukhumāni vatthāni
translated: In the case of the words “mother and father,” etc., old parents should be sought out and looked after with soft bedding and clothing and with delicious food and drink, perfumes and garlands, etc.,

original: madhurabhojanaṃ sugandhagandhamālādīni ca pariyesitvā posetabbā. Puttadhītānaṃ nāmakaraṇamaṅgalādīni
analyzed: madhura bhojanam sugandha gandha mālā ādīni ca pariyesitvā posetabbā putta dhītānam nāmakaraṇa maṅgala ādīni
translated: and the naming ceremony, etc., should be performed for their children and grandchildren.

original: sabbakiccāni karontena puttadāro posetabbo. Evañhi akariyamāne garahā uppajjatīti
analyzed: sabba kiccāni karontena putta dāraḥ posetabbaḥ evam hi a kariyamāne garahā uppajjati iti
translated: Children and wife should be looked after by one who is performing all the duties in this way. For if he does not do so, blame arises.

original: iminā nayena attho veditabbo.🔽447. Adhammacārīti pañca dussīlyakammāni vā dasa dussīlyakammāni vā idha adhammo nāma. Upakaḍḍheyyunti pañcavidhabandhanādikammakaraṇatthaṃ taṃ taṃ nirayaṃ kaḍḍheyyuṃ.🔽448. Dhammacārīti dhammikasivavijjādikammakārī. Paṭikkamantīti osaranti parihāyanti.
analyzed: iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbo  adhamma cārī iti pañca dussīlya kammāni vā dasa dussīlya kammāni vā idha adhammaḥ nāma upakaḍḍheyyunti pañcavidha bandhana ādi kamma karaṇa attham tam tam nirayam kaḍḍheyyuṃ  dhamma cārī iti dhammika siva vijja ādi kamma kārī paṭikkamanti iti osaranti parihāyanti
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance.🔽“One who acts contrary to the Dhamma”: the five kinds of wrong acts or the ten kinds of wrong acts are called “contrary to the Dhamma” here. “They would lead him”: they would lead him to this or that hell for the performance of the five kinds of binding acts, etc.🔽“One who acts in accordance with the Dhamma”: one who performs the duties of a righteous man, such as the science of medicine, etc. “They would lead him”: they would lead him to this or that heaven for the performance of the five kinds of binding acts, etc.

original: Abhikkamantīti abhisaranti vaḍḍhanti. Seyyoti varataraṃ. Hīneti nihīne lāmake. Kālaṅkato
analyzed: abhikkamanti iti abhisaranti vaḍḍhanti varataram hīna iti nihīne lāmake
translated: “Better”: more excellent. “Worse”: inferior, low. “One who has passed away”

original: ca sāriputtāti idaṃ bhagavā “tatrassa gantvā desehī”ti adhippāyena theramāha. Theropi
analyzed: ca sāriputta ati idam bhagavā tatrassa gantvā desehi iti adhippāyena theram āha theraḥ api
translated: and Sāriputta, too” : the Exalted One said this to the Elder with the intention of saying: “Go there and teach him.” The Elder

original: taṃkhaṇaṃyeva gantvā mahābrahmuno dhammaṃ desesi, tato paṭṭhāya cātuppadikaṃ gāthaṃ
analyzed: tad khaṇam yeva gantvā mahābrahmunaḥ dhammaṃ desesi tatas paṭṭhāya cātuppadikam gāthaṃ
translated: went there at that very moment and taught the Dhamma to Mahā-Brahmā. From that time on, even when he was reciting the four-line stanza,

original: kathentopi catusaccavimuttaṃ nāma na kathesīti.
analyzed: kathentaḥ api catu sacca vimuttam nāma na kathesi iti
translated: he did not teach what is called “the four truths for one liberated.”

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya, the Papañcasūdanī, is finished.

original: Dhanañjānisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhanañjāni sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Dhanañjāni Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Vāseṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽454. Evaṃ me sutanti vāseṭṭhasuttaṃ. Tattha icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍeti icchānaṅgalagāmassa
analyzed: vāseṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutam ti vāseṭṭha suttam tattha icchānaṅgala vana saṇḍe iti icchānaṅgala gāmassa
translated: The Vāseṭṭha Sutta

original: avidūre vanasaṇḍe. Caṅkīti ādayo pañcapi janā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa purohitā🔽eva. Aññe ca abhiññātāti aññe ca bahū abhiññātā brāhmaṇā. Te kira chaṭṭhe chaṭṭhe
analyzed: avidūre vana saṇḍe caṅkī iti ādayaḥ pañca api janā raññaḥ pasenadissa kosalassa purohitā  eva aññe ca abhiññātāti aññe ca bahū abhiññātā brāhmaṇā te kira chaṭṭhe chaṭṭhe
translated: Thus I heard. The Vāseṭṭha Sutta. There, in the Icchānaṅgala forest grove: in the forest grove not far from the village of Icchānaṅgala. Caṅkī, etc.: these five men were the royal priests of King Pasenadi of Kosala.

original: māse dvīsu ṭhānesu sannipatanti. Yadā jātiṃ sodhetukāmā honti, tadā pokkharasātissa
analyzed: māse dvīsu ṭhānesu sannipatanti yadā jātim sodhetu kāmāḥ honti tadā pokkharasātissa
translated: Others, too, well-known: there were also many other well-known brahmins. It seems that every sixth month they assembled in two places. When they wanted to purify their birth, they assembled at the place of Pokkharasāti.

original: santike jātisodhanatthaṃ ukkaṭṭhāya sannipatanti. Yadā mante sodhetukāmā honti, tadā
analyzed: santike jāti sodhana attham ukkaṭṭhāya sannipatanti yadā mante sodhetu kāmāḥ honti tadā
translated: and they assemble in the highest place for the purpose of purifying their birth. When they wish to purify the Mantras,

original: icchānaṅgale sannipatanti. Imasmiṃ kāle mantasodhanatthaṃ sannipatiṃsu. Ayamantarā
analyzed: sannipatanti imasmin kāle sannipatiṃsu ayam antarā
translated: they assemble in the place of desire. At this time they assembled for the purpose of purifying the Mantras. This is the intermediate

original: kathāti yaṃ attano sahāyakabhāvānurūpaṃ kathaṃ kathentā anuvicariṃsu, tassā kathāya
analyzed: kathā ati yam sahāyaka bhāva anurūpam katham kathentāḥ anuvicariṃsu tassā kathāya
translated: talk. As to the talk which they had while wandering about in accordance with their friendship, this talk

original: antarā ayamaññā kathā udapādi. Sīlavāti guṇavā. Vattasampannoti ācārasampanno.
analyzed: antarā ayamaññā kathā udapādi sīlavā ati guṇavā vatta sampanno ti ācāra sampanno
translated: arose in the middle of that talk. Virtuous means having virtues. Having good conduct means having good manners.

original: 455. Anuññātapaṭiññātāti sikkhitā tumheti evaṃ ācariyehi anuññātā, āma ācariya sikkhitamhāti
analyzed: anuññāta paṭiññātā ati sikkhitā tumhe ti evam ācariyehi anuññātā āma ācariya sikkhitamha ati
translated: Approved and acknowledged means approved by the teachers thus: “You are trained,” and acknowledged by themselves thus:

original: evaṃ sayañca paṭiññātā. Asmāti bhavāma. Ahaṃ pokkharasātissa, tārukkhassāyaṃ māṇavoti
analyzed: evam sayam ca paṭiññātāḥ bhavāma aham pokkharasātissa tārukkhassa ayam māṇavoti
translated: “Yes, teacher, I am trained.” We are means we exist. I am the pupil of Pokkharasāti, and this young man is the son of Tarukkha.

original: ahaṃ pokkharasātissa jeṭṭhantevāsī aggasisso, ayaṃ tārukkhassāti dīpeti.
analyzed: aham pokkharasātissa jeṭṭha antevāsī agga sissaḥ ayam tārukkhassa ati dīpeti
translated: I am the chief pupil of Pokkharasāti, and this one is the son of Tarukkha, thus he shows.🔽Of the three knowledges means of the three knowledges of the brahmans. What is declared means what is one

original: Tevijjānanti tivedānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ. Yadakkhātanti yaṃ atthato ca byañjanato ca ekaṃ
analyzed: tevijjānanti tivedānam brāhmaṇānam yat akkhātanti yam atthato ca byañjanato ca ekam
translated: in meaning and in letter.

original: padampi akkhātaṃ. Tatra kevalinosmaseti taṃ sakalaṃ jānanato tattha niṭṭhāgatamhāti
analyzed: padam pi akkhātam tatra kevalinā usmasa iti tam sakalam jānanataḥ tattha
translated: and the verse too has been stated. Therein, we are the only ones who know it all: the meaning is that we have reached the end of it.

original: attho. Idāni taṃ kevalibhāvaṃ āvikaronto padakasmātiādimāha. Tattha jappe ācariyasādisāti
analyzed: idāni tam kevali bhāvam āvikarontaḥ tattha jappe
translated: Now, revealing that all-inclusive nature, he said, “In the verse, we are the only ones who know it all,” etc. Herein, in the verse: in the place of exposition.

original: kathanaṭṭhāne mayaṃ ācariyasadisāyeva.🔽Kammunāti dasakusalakammapathakammunā. Ayañhi pubbe sattavidhaṃ kāyavacīkammaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: kathana ṭṭhāne ācariya sadisāya iva  kammunā ati dasa kusala kamma patha kammunā ayam hi pubbe sattavidham kāya vacī kammam sandhāya
translated: We are the only ones who know it all: we are the only ones who know it all.🔽In the act: in the act of the ten profitable courses of action. For this is what is meant by “When one is virtuous” , namely, the seven kinds of bodily and verbal action.

original: “yato kho, bho, sīlavā hotī”ti āha, tividhaṃ manokammaṃ sandhāya “vattasampanno”ti.🔽Tena samannāgato hi ācārasampanno hoti. Cakkhumāti pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumantabhāvena
analyzed: yatas kho bho sīlavā hoti iti āha tividham manaḥ kammam sandhāya vatta sampannaḥ ti  tena samannāgataḥ hi ācāra sampannaḥ hoti cakkhumā ati pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumanta bhāvena
translated: And what is meant by “and has fulfilled his duty” is the three kinds of mental action.🔽For one who possesses that is one who has fulfilled his duty.

original: bhagavantaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: bhagavantam ālapati
translated: In the eye: he addresses the Blessed One as “one who is possessed of eyes” by means of the five eyes.🔽Gone beyond destruction: gone beyond deficiency; the meaning is, complete.

original: Khayātītanti ūnabhāvaṃ atītaṃ, paripuṇṇanti attho. Peccāti upagantvā. Namassantīti namo karonti.
analyzed: khayā atītam ti ūna bhāvam atītam paripuṇṇam ti attho pecca ati upagantvā namassanti iti namaḥ karonti
translated: We pay homage: we do homage.

original: Cakkhuṃ loke samuppannanti avijjandhakāre loke taṃ andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā lokassa diṭṭhadhammikādiatthadassanena cakkhu hutvā samuppannaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhum loke samuppannanti avijja andhakāre loke tam andhakāram vidhamitvā lokassa diṭṭhadhammika ādi attha dassanena cakkhu hutvā samuppannam
translated: “Eye in the world arisen”: in the world of the darkness of ignorance, having dispelled that darkness, arisen as an eye for the world by showing the meaning of the present life, etc.

original: 456. Evaṃ vāseṭṭhena thometvā yācito bhagavā dvepi jane saṅgaṇhanto tesaṃ vo ahaṃ🔽byakkhissantiādimāha. Tattha byakkhissanti byākarissāmi. Anupubbanti tiṭṭhatu tāva
analyzed: evam vāseṭṭhena thometvā yācitaḥ bhagavā dve api jane saṅgaṇhantaḥ tesam vaḥ aham  byakkhissanti ādim āha tattha byakkhissanti byākarissāmi anupubbanti tiṭṭhatu tāva
translated: Having thus been urged by Vasettha, the Blessed One, in order to include both of them, said: “I will explain to you, Vasettha,

original: brāhmaṇacintā, tiṇarukkhakīṭapaṭaṅgato paṭṭhāya anupaṭipāṭiyā ācikkhissāmīti attho.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa cintā tiṇa rukkha kīṭa paṭaṅgataḥ paṭṭhāya anupaṭipāṭiyā ācikkhissāmi iti attho
translated: I will make clear. Anupubba: first, let alone the thought of the brahmins, I will teach in order, beginning with grass, trees, insects, and birds.

original: Jātivibhaṅganti jātivitthāraṃ. Aññamaññā hi jātiyoti tesaṃ tesañhi pāṇānaṃ jātiyo
analyzed: jāti vibhaṅganti jāti vitthāram aññamaññāḥ hi jātiyaḥ ti tesam tesam hi pāṇānam jātiyaḥ
translated: Jati-vibhaṅga: the detailed classification of the kinds of birth. Aññamañña: the kinds of birth of those beings are different from each other.

original: aññamaññā nānappakārāti attho.🔽Tiṇarukkheti anupādinnakajātiṃ katvā pacchā upādinnakajātiṃ kathessāmi, evaṃ tassa
analyzed: aññamaññā nānappakārā ti attho  tiṇa rukkha iti anupādinnaka jātim katvā pacchā upādinnaka jātim kathessāmi evam tassa
translated: The meaning is: they are of different kinds.🔽Grass and trees: having made the kinds of birth of the non-appropriated elements, I will later teach the kinds of birth of the appropriated elements. Thus the classification of its birth will become clear.

original: jātibhedo pākaṭo bhavissatīti imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Mahāsīvatthero pana “kiṃ, bhante,
analyzed: jāti bhedaḥ pākaṭaḥ bhavissati iti imam desanam ārabhi mahāsīva theraḥ pana kim bhante
translated: Thus he began this teaching. But the Elder Maha-Siva said: “What, Bhante,

original: anupādinnakaṃ bījanānatāya nānaṃ, upādinnaṃ kammanānatāyāti? Evaṃ vattuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti
analyzed: an upādinnakam bīja nānatāya nānam upādinnam kamma nānatāya ati evam vattum na vaṭṭati iti
translated: and the unapprehendable is various because of the variety of seeds, and the apprehendable is various because of the variety of kamma? ”

original: pucchito āma na vaṭṭati. Kammañhi yoniyaṃ khipati. Yonisiddhā ime sattā nānāvaṇṇā
analyzed: pucchitaḥ āma na vaṭṭati kamman hi yoniyam khipati yoni siddhāḥ ime sattāḥ nānā vaṇṇāḥ
translated: “No, friend,” he replied. “ For kamma hurls beings into the womb. These beings are of various complexions because of the womb in which they are established. ”

original: hontīti. Tiṇarukkheti ettha antopheggū bahisārā antamaso tālanāḷikerādayopi tiṇāneva,
analyzed: honti iti tiṇa rukkha iti ettha antopheggū bahisārāḥ tāla nāḷikera ādayaḥ pi tiṇān eva
translated: “ Grass and trees” : here the grass is that which has the top inside and the sap outside, and it includes even such things as the palm and coconut trees.

original: antosārā pana bahipheggū sabbe rukkhā nāma. Na cāpi paṭijānareti mayaṃ tiṇā mayaṃ
analyzed: antosārā pana bahipheggū sabbe rukkhāḥ nāma na ca api mayam tiṇāḥ mayam
translated: But all those that have the sap inside and the top outside are called trees.

original: rukkhāti vā, ahaṃ tiṇaṃ, ahaṃ rukkhoti vā evaṃ na jānanti. Liṅgaṃ jātimayanti ajānantānampi
analyzed: rukkhā ati vai aham tiṇam aham rukkhā iti vai evam na jānanti liṅgam jāti mayanti a jānantānam pi
translated: And they do not declare themselves thus: “We are grass, we are trees,” or “I am grass, I am a tree.”

original: ca tesaṃ jātimayameva saṇṭhānaṃ attano mūlabhūtatiṇādisadisameva hoti. Kiṃ kāraṇā?
analyzed: ca tesam jāti mayam eva saṇṭhānam mūla bhūta tiṇa ādi sadisam eva hoti kim kāraṇā
translated: And yet their shape, which is made of the primary elements, is like that of the grass, etc., which is their root. Why is it so?

original: Aññamaññā hi jātiyo. Yasmā aññā tiṇajāti, aññā rukkhajāti. Tiṇesupi aññā tālajāti,
analyzed: aññamaññāḥ hi jātiyaḥ yasmai aññā tiṇa jāti aññā rukkha jāti tiṇesu pi aññā tāla jāti
translated: Because the species are different from each other. The species of grass is one, the species of trees is another. Among the grasses, the species of palm is one,

original: aññā nāḷikerajāti, evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ. Iminā idaṃ dasseti – yaṃ jātivasena nānā
analyzed: aññā nāḷikera jāti evam vitthāretabbam iminā idam dasseti yam jāti vasena nānā
translated: the species of coconut is another. This should be extended. By this he shows that the shape of the grass, etc., is like that of the grass, etc., which is their root, because the species are different from each other.

original: hoti, taṃ attano paṭiññaṃ paresaṃ vā upadesaṃ vināpi aññajātito visesena gayhati.
analyzed: hoti tam attanaḥ paṭiññam paresam vā upadesam vinā api añña jātitaḥ visesena gayhati
translated: and he would know it without his own claim or the instruction of others.

original: Yadi ca jātiyā brāhmaṇo bhaveyya, sopi attano paṭiññaṃ paresaṃ vā upadesaṃ vinā khattiyato
analyzed: yadi ca jātiyā brāhmaṇaḥ bhaveyya saḥ api attanaḥ paṭiññam paresam vā upadesam vinā khattiyato
translated: And if a man were a brahmin by birth, he would know it without his own claim or the instruction of others

original: vessato suddato vā visesena gayheyya, na ca gayhati. Tasmā na jātiyā brāhmaṇoti.
analyzed: vessataḥ suddataḥ vā visesena gayheyya na ca gayhati tasmā na jātiyā brāhmaṇoti
translated: that he was different from a noble, a merchant, or a worker, but he does not know it. That is why he is not a brahmin by birth.

original: Parato pana “yathā etāsu jātīsū”ti gāthāya etamatthaṃ vacībhedeneva āvikarissati.🔽Evaṃ anupādinnakesu jātiṃ dassetvā upādinnakesu dassento tato kīṭetiādimāha. Yāva
analyzed: paratas pana yathā etāsu jātīsu iti gāthāya etam attham vacībhedena iva āvikarissati  evam anupādinnakesu jātim dassetvā upādinnakesu dassentaḥ tatas kīṭa iti ādim āha yāva
translated: But in the verse ‘Among these kinds of birth’ he will reveal this meaning by a different phrasing.

original: kunthakipilliketi kunthakipillikaṃ pariyantaṃ katvāti attho. Ettha ca ye uppatitvā
analyzed: kuntha kipillikā iti kuntha kipillikam pariyantam katvā ati attho ettha ca ye uppatitvā
translated: Having thus shown birth among those not subject to cankers, he said ‘Then insects’ in order to show it among those subject to cankers. The meaning is that he has taken the ant as the limit.

original: gacchanti, te paṭaṅgā nāma. Aññamaññā hi jātiyoti tesampi nīlarattādivaṇṇavasena🔽jātiyo nānappakārāva honti.
analyzed: gacchanti te paṭaṅgāḥ nāma aññamaññāḥ hi tesam pi nīla ratta ādi vaṇṇa vasena  jātiyaḥ nānappakārāḥ ava honti
translated: And here those that fly up and go are called ‘crickets.’ For their kinds are of various sorts according to their colours, blue, red, and so on.

original: Khuddaketi kāḷakādayo. Mahallaketi sasabiḷārādayo.
analyzed: khuddaka iti kāḷaka ādayaḥ mahallaka iti sasa biḷāra ādayaḥ
translated: ‘Small’ are the black ones, etc., and ‘large’ are the rabbit-eating lizards, etc.

original: Pādūdareti udarapāde, udaraṃyeva nesaṃ pādāti vuttaṃ hoti. Dīghapiṭṭhiketi sappānañhi sīsato yāva naṅguṭṭhā piṭṭhiyeva hoti, tena te “dīghapiṭṭhikā”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: pādūdarā iti udara pāde udaram yeva nesam pādā ti vuttam hoti dīgha piṭṭhikā iti sappānam hi sīsataḥ yāva naṅguṭṭhā hoti tena te dīgha piṭṭhikā ati vuccanti
translated: ‘With feet on the belly’ means with feet on the belly; what is meant is that they have feet only on the belly. ‘With long backs’ : snakes have only a back from the head to the tail, and that is why they are called ‘long-backed’.

original: Udaketi odake, udakamhi jāte.
analyzed: udaka iti ā udake udakamhi jāte
translated: ‘In the water’ means in the water, born in the water.

original: Pakkhīti sakuṇe. Te hi pattehi yantīti pattayānā, vehāsaṃ gacchantīti vihaṅgamā.🔽Evaṃ thalajalākāsagocarānaṃ pāṇānaṃ jātibhedaṃ dassetvā idāni yenādhippāyena taṃ🔽dasseti, taṃ āvikaronto yathā etāsūti gāthamāha. Tassattho saṅkhepena vuttova. Vitthārato
analyzed: pakkhī iti sakuṇe te hi pattehi yanti iti pattayānāḥ vehāsam gacchanti iti vihaṅgamāḥ  evam thala jala ākāsa gocarānam pāṇānam jāti bhedam dassetvā idāni yena adhippāyena tam  dassa iti tam āvikarontaḥ yathā etāsu iti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ saṅkhepena vuttaḥ iva vitthārato
translated: ‘Birds’ means birds. They are called ‘pattayānā’ because they go with wings, and ‘vihaṅgamā’ because they go through the air.🔽Having thus shown the different kinds of beings that move on the earth, in the water, and through the air, he now reveals the purpose for which he showed them. He does so in the verse ‘As to these’ . The meaning of the verse is given in brief. But the meaning of the verse should be understood in detail as follows.

original: panettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sayameva dassento na kesehītiādimāha. Tatrāyaṃ yojanā
analyzed: pana ittha yam vattabbam tam sayam eva dassentaḥ na kesehi iti ādim āha tatra ayam yojanā
translated: He says ‘Not by the hair’ , showing what should be said. The application is as follows.

original: – yaṃ vuttaṃ “natthi manussesu liṅgajātimayaṃ puthū”ti, taṃ evaṃ natthīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: yam vuttam natthi manussesu liṅga jāti mayam puthu uti tam evam natthi iti veditabbam
translated: It was said above ‘Among men there is no difference of caste by marks’ . That should be understood in this way.

original: Seyyathidaṃ? Na kesehīti. Na hi – “brāhmaṇānaṃ edisā kesā honti, khattiyānaṃ edisā”ti
analyzed: sā iyyathidam na kesehi iti na hi brāhmaṇānam edisāḥ kesāḥ honti khattiyānam edisā ati
translated: ‘Not by the hair’ : for it is not the case that ‘Brahmaṇas have such hair, Khattiyas have such’ .

original: niyamo atthi yathā hatthiassamigādīnanti iminā nayena sabbaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: niyamaḥ atthi yathā hatthi assa miga ādīnam ti iminā nayena sabbam yojetabbam
translated: “There is a rule, as in the case of elephants, horses, cattle, etc.”

original: Liṅgaṃ jātimayaṃ neva, yathā aññāsu jātisūti idaṃ pana vuttassevatthassa nigamananti
analyzed: liṅgam jāti mayam na iva yathā aññāsu jātisu iti idam pana vuttassa iva atthassa nigamanan ti
translated: “The sign is not of species, as in other species” is the conclusion to the meaning already stated.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tassāyaṃ yojanā – evaṃ yasmā imehi kesādīhi natthi manussesu liṅgaṃ jātimayaṃ
analyzed: veditabbam tassa ayam yojanā evam yasmai imehi kesa ādīhi na atthi manussesu liṅgam jāti mayam
translated: This is how it should be understood. The construction is as follows: “Since there is no sign of species among men by way of head hairs, etc.,

original: puthu, tasmā veditabbametaṃ “brāhmaṇādibhedesu manussesu liṅgaṃ jātimayaṃ neva, yathā aññāsu jātisū”ti.
analyzed: puthu tasmai veditabbam etam brāhmaṇa ādi bhedesu manussesu liṅgam jāti mayam na iva yathā aññāsu jātisu ti
translated: it should be understood that the sign is not of species among men classed as brahmans, nobles, etc., as it is in other species.”

original: 457. Idāni evaṃ jātibhede asatipi “brāhmaṇo khattiyo”ti idaṃ nānattaṃ yathā jātaṃ,
analyzed: evam jāti bhede asati api brāhmaṇaḥ khattiyaḥ ti idam nānattam yathā jātam
translated: Now, although there is no such classification by species, the diversity of “brahmans,” “nobles,” etc., is a diversity of “class” that has come down from beginningless becoming.🔽In order to show that, he uttered the tenth stanza, “The class is not by birth,” etc.

original: taṃ dassetuṃ paccattanti gāthamāha. Tattha vokāranti nānattaṃ. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho🔽– yathā hi tiracchānānaṃ yonisiddhameva kesādisaṇṭhānena nānattaṃ, tathā brāhmaṇādīnaṃ🔽attano attano sarīre taṃ natthi. Evaṃ santepi yadetaṃ “brāhmaṇo khattiyo”ti vokāraṃ,
analyzed: tam dassetum paccattam ti gātham āha tattha vokāram ti nānattam ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ 🔽yathā hi tiracchānānam yoni siddham eva kesa ādi saṇṭhānena nānattam tathā brāhmaṇa ādīnam 🔽attano attano sarīre tam natthi evam sante pi yat etam brāhmaṇaḥ khattiyaḥ iti vokāram
translated: Herein, the class is the diversity. The meaning in brief is this:

original: taṃ vokārañca manussesu samaññāya pavuccati, vohāramatteneva pavuccatīti.
analyzed: tam vokāram ca manussesu samaññāya pavuccati vohāra mattena iva pavuccati iti
translated: and that usage is proclaimed among human beings by common consent, it is proclaimed by mere usage.

original: Ettāvatā bhagavā bhāradvājassa vādaṃ niggaṇhitvā idāni yadi jātiyā brāhmaṇo bhaveyya,
analyzed: ettāvatā bhagavā bhāradvājassa vādam niggaṇhitvā idāni yadi jātiyā brāhmaṇaḥ bhaveyya
translated: Up to this point the Blessed One has refuted Bhāradvāja’s doctrine. Now, if one were a brahmin by birth,

original: ājīvasīlācāravipannopi brāhmaṇo bhaveyya. Yasmā pana porāṇā brāhmaṇā tassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ🔽na icchanti, loke ca aññepi paṇḍitamanussā, tasmā vāseṭṭhassa vādaṃ paggaṇhanto yo
analyzed: ājīva sīla ācāra vipannaḥ api brāhmaṇaḥ bhaveyya yasmai pana porāṇā brāhmaṇā tassa brāhmaṇa bhāvam  na icchanti loke ca aññe pi paṇḍita manussā tasmai vāseṭṭhassa vādam paggaṇhantaḥ yo
translated: then even one who is destitute of the livelihood, virtue, and conduct of a brahmin would be a brahmin. But since the ancient brahmins do not accept him as a brahmin,🔽nor do other wise men in the world, the Blessed One, in order to support Vāseṭṭha’s doctrine, spoke eight verses, beginning with “Whoever among human beings.”

original: hi koci manussesūti aṭṭha gāthā āha. Tattha gorakkhanti khettarakkhaṃ, kasikammanti
analyzed: hi koci manussesu iti aṭṭha gāthāḥ āha tattha go rakkham ti khetta rakkham kasi kamman ti
translated: Herein, “cattle-tending” is the guarding of fields; “agriculture” is said to be

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Goti hi pathaviyā nāmaṃ, tasmā evamāha. Puthusippenāti tantavāyakammādinānāsippena.
analyzed: vuttam hoti go ti hi pathaviyāḥ nāmam tasmai evam āha puthu sippena ati tantavāya kamma ādi nānā sippena
translated: the work of ploughing. For “cattle” is a name for the earth, thus he said thus. “Various crafts” are the various crafts such as weaving.

original: Vohāranti vaṇijjaṃ. Parapessenāti paresaṃ veyyāvaccakammena. Issatthanti āvudhajīvikaṃ,
analyzed: vohāram ti vaṇijjam para pessena ati paresam veyyāvacca kammena issattham āvudha jīvikam
translated: “Trade” is commerce. “Service” is by means of the work of others. “Arms” is the livelihood of weapons,

original: usuñca sattiṃ cāti vuttaṃ hoti. Porohiccenāti purohitakammena.
analyzed: usum ca sattim ca iti vuttam hoti porohiccena ati purohita kammena
translated: it is said to be the spear and the sword. “Priesthood” is by means of the work of a chief priest.

original: Evaṃ brāhmaṇasamayena ca lokavohārena ca ājīvasīlācāravipannassa abrāhmaṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam brāhmaṇa samayena ca loka vohārena ca ājīva sīla ācāra vipannassa a brāhmaṇa bhāvam
translated: Thus, by the Brahmanical tradition and by worldly convention, he shows that one who is devoid of the virtue and conduct of livelihood is not a Brahman.

original: sādhetvā evaṃ sante na jātiyā brāhmaṇo, guṇehi pana brāhmaṇo hoti. Tasmā yattha katthaci
analyzed: evam sante na jātiyā brāhmaṇaḥ guṇehi pana brāhmaṇaḥ hoti tasmai yattha katthaci
translated: When this is so, one is not a Brahman by birth, but one becomes a Brahman by qualities. Therefore, wherever

original: kule jāto yo guṇavā, so brāhmaṇo, ayamettha ñāyoti evametaṃ ñāyaṃ atthato āpādetvā
analyzed: kule jātaḥ yaḥ guṇavā saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ayam ettha ñāyaḥ iti evam etam ñāyam atthataḥ āpādetvā
translated: one is born in a family, he who is virtuous is a Brahman. This is the meaning here. Having thus established this principle,

original: idāni naṃ vacībhedena pakāsento na cāhaṃ brāhmaṇantiādimāha. Tassattho – ahañhi yvāyaṃ
analyzed: idāni nam vacībhedena pakāsentaḥ na ca aham brāhmaṇa nti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ aham hi yvā ayam
translated: now, in order to reveal it by way of verbal differentiation, he says, “I do not say that one is a Brahman” and so on. The meaning is this: I do not say that one is a Brahman

original: catunnaṃ yonīnaṃ yattha katthaci jāto, tatrāpi visesena yo brāhmaṇassa saṃvaṇṇitāya🔽mātari sambhūto, taṃ yonijaṃ mattisambhavaṃ, yā cāyaṃ ubhato sujātotiādinā nayena
analyzed: catunnam yonīnam yattha katthaci jātaḥ tatra api visesena yaḥ brāhmaṇassa saṃvaṇṇitāya  mātari tam yoni jam matti sambhavam yā ca ayam ubhatas su jātā iti ādinā nayena
translated: by birth in any of the four wombs, but rather, by a special quality, one who is born of a mother praised by Brahmans,

original: brāhmaṇehi brāhmaṇassa parisuddhauppattimaggasaṅkhātā yoni vuttā, saṃsuddhagahaṇikoti
analyzed: brāhmaṇehi brāhmaṇassa parisuddha auppatti magga saṅkhātā yoni vuttā saṃsuddha gahaṇikā ti
translated: that womb is called “born of the womb” and “born of the mother.” And this is said to be the womb that is called “pure” by Brahmans in the way beginning with “born of a pure womb on both sides.”

original: iminā ca mātisampatti, tatopi jātasambhūtattā yonijo mattisambhavoti vuccati, taṃ
analyzed: iminā ca tatas pi jāta sambhūta ttā yoni jaḥ matti sambhavaḥ ti vuccati tam
translated: By this, the excellence of the mother is shown. Because of being born and produced from that, it is called “born of the womb” and “born of the mother.” That🔽is the meaning.

original: yonijaṃ mattisambhavaṃ iminā ca yonijamattisambhavamattena na brāhmaṇaṃ brūmi. Kasmā?
analyzed: yoni jam matti sambhavam iminā ca yoni ja matti sambhava mattena na brāhmaṇam brūmi kasmai
translated: I do not say that one is a brahmin by birth or by lineage. Why?

original: Yasmā, bho bhoti, vacanamattena aññehi sakiñcanehi visiṭṭhattā bhovādi nāma so hoti,
analyzed: yasmā bho bho ti vacana mattena aññehi sa kiñcanehi visiṭṭha ttā bhovādi nāma saḥ hoti
translated: Because, good sirs, one is called a “good sir” by reason of the excellence of one’s possessions over others.🔽But if one has possessions and is fettered, then wherever one is born,

original: sace hoti sakiñcano sapalibodho. Yo panāyaṃ yattha katthaci jātopi rāgādikiñcanābhāvena
analyzed: sace hoti sa kiñcanaḥ sa palibodhaḥ yaḥ pana ayam yattha katthaci jātaḥ api rāga ādi kiñcana abhāvena
translated: if one is free from possessions, free from greed, by reason of the absence of greed, etc.,

original: akiñcano, sabbagahaṇapaṭinissaggena anādāno, akiñcanaṃ anādānaṃ, tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
