analyzed: akiñcanaḥ sabba gahaṇa paṭinissaggena anādānaḥ akiñcanam anādānam tam aham brūmi brāhmaṇam
translated: and free from grasping, by reason of the relinquishment of all acquisitions, then I say that one is a brahmin.

original: Kasmā? Yasmā bāhitapāpoti.🔽458. Kiñcabhiyyo sabbasaṃyojanaṃ chetvātiādi sattavīsati gāthā. Tattha sabbasaṃyojananti🔽dasavidhasaṃyojanaṃ. Na paritassatīti taṇhāparitassanāya na paritassati. Saṅgātiganti
analyzed: kasmai yasmai  kiñca bhiyyas sabba saṃyojanam chetvā atiādi sattavīsati gāthā tattha sabba saṃyojanam ti  dasavidha saṃyojanam na paritassati iti taṇhā paritassanāya na paritassati saṅga atiganti
translated: Why? Because he has shaken off the stain.

original: rāgasaṅgādayo atikkantaṃ. Visaṃyuttanti catūhi yonīhi sabbakilesehi vā visaṃyuttaṃ.
analyzed: rāga saṅga ādayaḥ atikkantam visaṃyuttam ti catūhi yonīhi sabba kilesehi vā visaṃyuttam
translated: “And further, he who has cut off all fetters, etc.,” are twenty-seven verses. Herein, all fetters means the ten fetters. He does not tremble means he does not tremble with craving. He has gone beyond attachment means he has gone beyond attachment to lust, etc. He is detached means he is detached from all defilements by the four paths.

original: Naddhinti upanāhaṃ. Varattanti taṇhaṃ. Sandānanti yuttapāsaṃ, diṭṭhipariyuṭṭhānassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Sahanukkamanti anukkamo vuccati pāse pavesanagaṇṭhi, diṭṭhānusayassetaṃ
analyzed: naddhinti upanāham varattanti taṇham sandānam ti yutta pāsam diṭṭhi pariyuṭṭhānassa etam  adhivacanam saha anukkamanti anukkamaḥ vuccati pāse pavesana gaṇṭhi diṭṭha anusayassa etam
translated: “Snare” is the enveloper. “Rope” is craving. “Noose” is the binding noose; this is a term for the perversions of perception.

original: nāmaṃ. Ukkhittapalighanti ettha palighoti avijjā. Buddhanti catusaccabuddhaṃ. Titikkhatīti khamati.
analyzed: nāmam ukkhitta paligham ti ettha palighaḥ ti avijjā buddham ti catu sacca buddham titikkhati iti khamati
translated: “With its string” : the string is said to be the knot that enters the noose; this is a name for the underlying tendency to views. “With its stake drawn out” : here, the stake is ignorance. “The Buddha” : the one who has awakened to the four truths. “Endures” : he forgives.

original: Khantibalanti adhivāsanakhantibalaṃ. Sā pana sakiṃ uppannā balānīkaṃ nāma na hoti, punappunaṃ uppannā pana hoti. Tassā atthitāya balānīkaṃ.
analyzed: khanti balanti adhivāsana khanti balam sā pana sakim uppannā bala anīkam nāma na hoti punappunam uppannā pana hoti tassāḥ atthitāya bala anīkam
translated: “The strength of patience” : the strength of the patience of forgiveness. But this, when it arises once, is not called an army; it is when it arises again and again that it is so. Because of its existence, there is an army.

original: Vatavantanti dhutaṅgavantaṃ. Sīlavantanti guṇavantaṃ. Anussadanti rāgādiussadavirahitaṃ. “Anussuta”ntipi pāṭho, anavassutanti attho. Dantanti nibbisevanaṃ.
analyzed: vatavantanti dhutaṅgavantam sīlavantanti guṇavantam anussadanti rāga ādi ussada virahitam anussutanti pi pāṭhaḥ anavassutanti atthaḥ dantanti nibbisevanam
translated: “Endowed with virtue” : endowed with good qualities. “Free from defilement” : free from the defilements of lust, etc. The reading “anussada” is also correct, meaning “not defiled.” “Self-controlled” : not indulging in sensual pleasures.

original: Na limpatīti na allīyati. Kāmesūti kilesakāmavatthukāmesu.
analyzed: na limpati iti na allīyati kāmesu iti kilesa kāma vatthu kāmesu
translated: “Does not stick” : does not adhere. “In sensual pleasures” : in sensual desires as defilements and as objects.

original: Dukkhassa pajānāti, idheva khayanti ettha arahattaphalaṃ dukkhakkhayoti adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: dukkhassa pajānāti idha iva khayanti ettha arahatta phalam dukkha kkhayo ti adhippetam
translated: “He understands here and now the destruction of suffering”: here the fruit of arahantship is intended by “the destruction of suffering.”

original: Pajānātīti adhigamavasena jānāti. Pannabhāranti ohitabhāraṃ, khandhakilesaabhisaṅkhārakāmaguṇabhāre
analyzed: pajānāti iti adhigama vasena jānāti ohita bhāram khandha kilesa abhisaṅkhāra kāma guṇa bhāre
translated: “He understands”: he knows by way of realization. “His burden cast off”: he has cast off the burden of the aggregates, the defilements, and the formations of the sense-spheres.

original: otāretvā ṭhitaṃ. Visaṃyuttapadaṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: ṭhitam visaṃyutta padam vuttattham eva
translated: “He is detached”: the meaning of the words “detached” is already stated.

original: Gambhīrapaññanti gambhīresu ārammaṇesu pavattapaññaṃ. Medhāvinti pakatipaññāya paññavantaṃ.
analyzed: gambhīra paññanti gambhīresu ārammaṇesu pavatta paññam medhāvin ti pakati paññāya paññavantam
translated: “Deeply wise”: his wisdom penetrates deep into the objects. “Intelligent”: he is endowed with wisdom by way of his natural wisdom.

original: Anāgārehi cūbhayanti anāgārehi ca visaṃsaṭṭhaṃ ubhayañca, dvīhipi cetehi visaṃsaṭṭhamevāti
analyzed: anāgārehi ca visaṃsaṭṭham ubhayam ca visaṃsaṭṭham eva ati
translated: “He is detached from both the lay life and the monastic life”: he is detached from both the lay life and the monastic life. The meaning is that he is detached from both of these.

original: attho. Anokasārinti okaṃ vuccati pañcakāmaguṇālayo, taṃ anallīyamānanti attho. Appicchanti anicchaṃ.
analyzed: attho anokasārin ti okam vuccati pañca kāmaguṇa ālayo tam an al līyamānanti attho appicchanti aniccham
translated: “He wanders solitary as a rhinoceros horn”: the “horn” is said to be the abode of the five strands of sense pleasure; the meaning is that he does not delight in it. “He is content with any kind of alms”: he is content with any kind of alms.

original: Tasesūti sataṇhesu. Thāvaresūti nittaṇhesu.
analyzed: tasesu iti sa taṇhesu thāvaresu iti nittaṇhesu
translated: “Among those who are greedy”: among those who are full of craving. “Among those who are self-controlled”: among those who are free from craving.

original: Attadaṇḍesūti gahitadaṇḍesu. Nibbutanti kilesanibbānena nibbutaṃ. Sādānesūti saupādānesu.
analyzed: atta daṇḍesu iti gahita daṇḍesu nibbutanti kilesa nibbānena nibbutam sa ādānesu iti sa upādānesu
translated: “Among those who carry their own burden”: among those who carry their own burden. “He is one who is at peace”: he is at peace by way of the pacification of defilements. “Among those who are full of grasping”: among those who are full of clinging.

original: Ohitoti patito.
analyzed: ohitaḥ iti patitaḥ
translated: “He has cast off”: he has fallen off.

original: 459. Akakkasanti niddosaṃ. Sadoso hi rukkhopi sakakkasoti vuccati. Viññāpaninti atthaviññāpanikaṃ.🔽Saccanti avisaṃvādikaṃ. Udīrayeti bhaṇati. Yāya nābhisajjeti yāya girāya parassa
analyzed: akakkasanti niddosam sa dosaḥ hi rukkhaḥ api sa kakkasaḥ ti vuccati viññāpanin ti attha viññāpanikam  avisaṃvādikam udīraya iti bhaṇati yāya na abhisajjeti yāya girāya parassa
translated: “Truth” is what is not deceptive. “He utters” is he speaks.

original: sajjanaṃ vā lagganaṃ vā na karoti, tādisaṃ apharusaṃ giraṃ bhāsatīti attho.
analyzed: sajjanam vā lagganam vā na karoti tādisam a pharusam giram bhāsati iti
translated: By which speech he does not cause resentment, by which speech he does not cause another to be annoyed or to be bound, he speaks such a gentle speech. This is the meaning.

original: Dīghanti suttāruḷhabhaṇḍaṃ. Rassanti vippakiṇṇabhaṇḍaṃ. Aṇunti khuddakaṃ. Thūlanti
analyzed: dīghanti sutta āruḷha bhaṇḍam rassanti vippakiṇṇa bhaṇḍam aṇunti khuddakam thūlanti
translated: “Long” is goods loaded on a cart. “Short” is goods scattered about. “Small” is little. “Large” is

original: mahantaṃ. Subhāsubhanti sundarāsundaraṃ. Dīghabhaṇḍañhi appagghampi hoti mahagghampi.
analyzed: mahantam sundara asundaram sundara asundaram
translated: big. “Good and bad” is beautiful and ugly. For long goods may be of little value or of great value.

original: Rassādīsupi eseva nayo. Iti ettāvatā na sabbaṃ pariyādiṇṇaṃ, “subhāsubha”nti iminā
analyzed: rassa ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ iti ettāvatā na sabbam pariyādiṇṇam subha asubham iti iminā
translated: The same method applies to short goods, etc. Thus far he has not taken possession of all of it. But with “good and bad” he

original: pana pariyādiṇṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pana pariyādiṇṇam hoti
translated: has taken possession of it.

original: Nirāsayanti nittaṇhaṃ.
analyzed: nirāsayanti nittaṇham
translated: “No-hope” is without craving.

original: Ālayāti taṇhālayā. Aññāyāti jānitvā. Amatogadhanti amatabbhantaraṃ. Anuppattanti anupaviṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: ālayā ti taṇhā ālayā aññāyā iti jānitvā amatogadham amatabbhantaram anuppattam anupaviṭṭham
translated: “Attachment” is the attachment of craving. “Having known” is having understood. “Surrounded by the deathless” is having the deathless inside. “Arrived at” is reached.

original: Ubho saṅganti ubhayampetaṃ saṅgaṃ. Puññañhi sagge laggāpeti, apuññaṃ apāye, tasmā ubhayampetaṃ saṅganti āha. Upaccagāti atīto.
analyzed: ubho ubhayam petam saṅgam puññam hi sagge lagga apeti apuññam apāye tasmai ubhayam petam saṅgam iti āha upaccagāti atītaḥ
translated: Both are a fetter: both are a fetter in that they fetter one to the world of men and gods. For merit fetters one to the world of men and gods, and demerit fetters one to the worlds of the animals and so on. He has gone beyond: he has gone beyond, passed beyond, surmounted.

original: Anāvilanti āvilakaraṇakilesavirahitaṃ. Nandībhavaparikkhīṇanti parikkhīṇanandiṃ parikkhīṇabhavaṃ.
analyzed: anāvilam ti āvila karaṇa kilesa virahitam nandī bhava parikkhīṇanti parikkhīṇa nandim parikkhīṇa bhavam
translated: Unclouded: free from the defilements that cloud the mind. With craving for becoming destroyed: with craving destroyed, with becoming destroyed.

original: “Yo ima”nti gāthāya avijjāyeva visaṃvādakaṭṭhena palipatho, mahāviduggatāya duggaṃ,🔽saṃsaraṇaṭṭhena saṃsāro, mohanaṭṭhena mohoti vutto. Tiṇṇoti caturoghatiṇṇo. Pāraṅgatoti
analyzed: yaḥ imanti gāthāya avijjāya iva visaṃvāda kaṭṭhena mahā viduggatāya duggam  saṃsaraṇa ṭṭhena saṃsāro mohana ṭṭhena moho ti vutto tiṇṇo ti catur ogha tiṇṇo pāraṅgato ti
translated: In the verse “He who has crossed the flood” , ignorance is called a “thicket” because it deceives, a “difficult place” because it is a great wilderness,🔽a “flood” because it carries one away, and a “delusion” because it deludes. He has crossed the four floods: he has crossed the four floods of sensuality, becoming, ignorance, and views. He has gone beyond: he has gone beyond, passed beyond, surmounted.

original: nibbānaṃ gato. Jhāyīti ārammaṇalakkhaṇūpanijjhānavasena jhāyī. Anejoti nittaṇho.
analyzed: nibbānam gataḥ jhāyī iti ārammaṇa lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna vasena jhāyī anejaḥ iti nittaṇhaḥ
translated: A meditator: a meditator in the sense of one who has attained to the sign of concentration as object. Motionless: free from longing.

original: Anupādāya nibbutoti kiñci gahaṇaṃ aggahetvā sabbakilesanibbānena nibbuto.
analyzed: an upādāya nibbutaḥ ti kiñci gahaṇam aggahetvā sabba kilesa nibbānena nibbutaḥ
translated: Extinguished by nonclinging: extinguished by the extinguishing of all defilements without taking anything as a basis.

original: Kāmeti duvidhepi kāme. Anāgāroti anāgāro hutvā. Paribbajeti paribbajati. Kāmabhavaparikkhīṇanti khīṇakāmaṃ khīṇabhavaṃ.
analyzed: kāma iti duvidhe api kāme anāgāraḥ anāgāraḥ hutvā paribbajeti paribbajati kāma bhava parikkhīṇam ti khīṇa kāmam khīṇa bhavam
translated: In the verse “He who has crossed the flood” , “sensual pleasures” are of two kinds. He wanders homeless: he wanders without taking up any abode. With craving for becoming destroyed: with craving destroyed, with becoming destroyed.

original: Mānusakaṃ yoganti mānusakaṃ pañcakāmaguṇayogaṃ. Dibbaṃ yoganti dibbaṃ pañcakāmaguṇayogaṃ. Sabbayogavisaṃyuttanti sabbakilesayogavisaṃyuttaṃ.
analyzed: mānusakam yogam iti mānusakam pañca kāmaguṇa yogam dibbam yogam iti dibbam pañca kāmaguṇa yogam sabba yoga visaṃyuttanti sabba kilesa yoga visaṃyuttam
translated: “Human yoke” : the yoke of the five cords of sensual pleasure pertaining to human beings. “Divine yoke” : the yoke of the five cords of sensual pleasure pertaining to the gods. “Unfettered from all yokes” : unfettered from all the yokes of defilements.

original: Ratinti pañcakāmaguṇaratiṃ. Aratinti kusalabhāvanāya ukkaṇṭhitaṃ. Vīranti vīriyavantaṃ.
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa ratim kusala bhāvanāya ukkaṇṭhitam vīranti vīriyavantam
translated: “Delight” : delight in the five cords of sensual pleasure. “Disenchantment” : dissatisfaction with the practice of the profitable. “Vigor” : one who is vigorous.

original: Sugatanti sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ gataṃ, sundarāya vā paṭipattiyā gataṃ.
analyzed: sugata nti sundaram ṭhānam gatam sundarāya vā paṭipattiyā gatam
translated: “Well-gone” : gone to a good place, or gone by a good way.

original: Gatinti nibbattiṃ. Pureti atīte. Pacchāti anāgate. Majjheti paccuppanne. Kiñcananti kiñcanakārako kileso.
analyzed: gatim ti nibbattim purā iti atīte pacchā ati anāgate majjhe iti paccuppanne kiñcananti kiñcana kārako kilesaḥ
translated: “State” : rebirth. “Past” : in the past. “Future” : in the future. “Present” : in the present. “Possession” : the defilement that is a possessor.

original: Mahesinti mahante guṇe pariyesanaṭṭhena mahesiṃ. Vijitāvinanti vijitavijayaṃ.
analyzed: mahesim ti mahante guṇe pariyesana ṭṭhena mahesim vijita āvinanti vijita vijayam
translated: “Great seer” : the great seer in the sense of seeking out great qualities. “Conqueror” : the conqueror of what is to be conquered.

original: 460. Evaṃ bhagavā guṇato khīṇāsavaṃyeva brāhmaṇaṃ dassetvā ye jātito brāhmaṇoti abhinivesaṃ
analyzed: evam bhagavā guṇataḥ khīṇāsavaṃyā iva brāhmaṇam dassetvā ye jātitaḥ abhinivesam
translated: Having thus shown the true brahmin to be one whose cankers are destroyed, the Blessed One now said, “Those who claim that a brahmin is so by birth,”

original: karonti, te idaṃ ajānantā, sāva nesaṃ diṭṭhi duddiṭṭhīti dassento samaññā hesāti
analyzed: karonti te idam a jānantā sā ava nesam diṭṭhi duddiṭṭhi iti dassento samaññā ha isā ti
translated: showing that those who insist on the brahmin by birth are ignorant of the true brahmin and that their view is a wrong view.

original: gāthādvayamāha. Tassattho – yadidaṃ brāhmaṇo khattiyo bhāradvājo vāseṭṭhoti nāmagottaṃ
analyzed: gāthā dvayam āha tassa atthaḥ yat idam brāhmaṇaḥ khattiyaḥ bhāradvājaḥ vāseṭṭhaḥ iti nāma gottam
translated: He uttered two stanzas. Their meaning is this. Whatever name-and-surname is made up, created, and established, such as “Brahmin”, “Noble”, “Bhāradvāja”, “Vāseṭṭha”,

original: pakappitaṃ kataṃ abhisaṅkhataṃ, samaññā hesā lokasmiṃ, vohāramattanti attho. Kasmā?🔽Yasmā samuccā samudāgataṃ samaññāya āgataṃ. Etañhi tattha tattha jātakāleyevassa
analyzed: pakappitam katam abhisaṅkhatam samaññā ha isā lokasmim vohāra mattanti attho kasmā  yasmai samuccā samudāgatam samaññāya āgatam etat hi tattha tattha
translated: that is a mere concept in the world, a mere usage, a mere designation. Why?

original: ñātisālohitehi pakappitaṃ kataṃ. No ce naṃ evaṃ pakappeyyuṃ, na koci kiñci disvā
analyzed: ñāti sālohitehi pakappitam katam no ce naṃ evam pakappeyyum na koci kiñci disvā
translated: Because it is created by convention, it has come about by convention. For that name-and-surname is created and made up by relatives and kinsmen at the time of a person’s birth. If they did not make it up in this way, no one seeing a person would know

original: ayaṃ brāhmaṇoti vā bhāradvājoti vā jāneyya. Evaṃ pakappitaṃ petaṃ dīgharattānusayitaṃ,🔽diṭṭhigatamajānataṃ, taṃ pakappitaṃ nāmagottaṃ “nāmagottamattametaṃ, vohāratthaṃ
analyzed: ayam brāhmaṇa iti vā bhāradvāja iti vā jāneyyaḥ evam pakappitam petam dīgha ratta anusayitam  diṭṭhi gatam a jānatam tam pakappitam nāma gottam nāma gottamattam etam vohāra attham
translated: that he was a Brahmin or a Bhāradvāja. That name-and-surname, which is made up in this way, has been long settled in the heart of those who do not know the way of looking at things.

original: pakappita”nti, ajānantānaṃ sattānaṃ hadaye dīgharattaṃ diṭṭhigatamanusayitaṃ. Tassa🔽anusayitattā taṃ nāmagottaṃ ajānantā no pabrunti, “jātiyā hoti brāhmaṇo”ti ajānantāva
analyzed: pakappitam ti a jānantānam sattānam hadaye dīgharattam diṭṭhi gatam anusayitam tassa  tam nāma gottam a jānantā no pabrunti jātiyā hoti brāhmaṇā iti a jānantā ava
translated: “This name-and-surname is a mere name-and-surname, a mere usage, a mere designation made up” — this way of looking at things has long been settled in the hearts of beings who do not know.

original: evaṃ vadantīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: evam vadanti iti vuttam hoti
translated: Because of that settlement, those who do not know that name-and-surname do not proclaim it. “One is a Brahmin by birth” — those who do not know say this.

original: Evaṃ “ye ‘jātito brāhmaṇo’ti abhinivesaṃ karonti, te idaṃ vohāramattaṃ ajānantā,🔽sāva nesaṃ diṭṭhi duddiṭṭhī”ti dassetvā idāni nippariyāyameva jātivādaṃ paṭikkhipanto
analyzed: evam ye jātitaḥ abhinivesam karonti te idam vohāra mattam  sā ava nesam diṭṭhi duddiṭṭhī iti dassetvā idāni nippariyāyam eva jāti vādam paṭikkhipanto
translated: So, having shown that those who insist on the view that a man is a brahmin by birth do so because of their ignorance of this mere usage,

original: kammavādañca patiṭṭhapento na jaccātiādimāha. Tattha “kammunā”ti upaḍḍhagāthāya vitthāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: kamma vādam ca patiṭṭhapentaḥ na jacca ati ādim āha tattha kammunā iti upaḍḍha gāthāya vitthāraṇa attham
translated: and that their view is a wrong view, he now said, “Not by birth is one an outcaste,” etc., in order to refute the theory of birth absolutely and to establish the theory of kamma. Herein, he said “by kamma” in order to elaborate the first half of the verse.

original: kassako kammunātiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kammunāti paccuppannena kasikammādinibbattakacetanākammunā.
analyzed: kassakaḥ kammunā ātiādi vuttam tattha kammunā ti paccuppannena kasi kamma ādi nibbattaka cetanā kammunā
translated: And he said “the ploughman by his kamma” in order to elaborate the second half. Herein, by kamma means by the kamma consisting of the volition that produces the present ploughing, and so on.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādadassāti iminā paccayena evaṃ hotīti evaṃ paṭiccasamuppādadassāvino.🔽Kammavipākakovidāti sammānāvamānārahakule kammavasena uppatti hoti, aññāpi hīnapaṇītatā
analyzed: paṭicca samuppāda dassā ti iminā paccayena evam hoti iti evam paṭicca samuppāda dassāvino  kamma vipāka kovidā ti sammāna avamāna araha kule kamma vasena uppatti hoti aññā api hīna paṇīta tā
translated: By seeing dependent origination: by seeing how this comes to be through that condition.

original: hīnapaṇīte kamme vipaccamāne hotīti. Evaṃ kammavipākakusalā.
analyzed: hīna paṇīte kamme vipaccamāne hoti iti evam kamma vipāka kusalā
translated: Skilled in the ripening of kamma: birth in a family that deserves honour and respect comes about through kamma. And also the inferiority and superiority of the various kinds of birth come about through the ripening of inferior and superior kamma respectively. So he is skilled in the ripening of kamma.

original: Kammunā vattatīti gāthāya pana lokoti vā pajāti vā sattoti vā ekoyevattho, vacanamattabhedo.
analyzed: kammunā vattati iti gāthāya pana vā vā vā vacana matta bhedaḥ
translated: By kamma the world revolves: here the world is a single concept, and the beings or the generation is a single concept, and the living being is a single concept. The difference is merely verbal.

original: Purimapadena cettha “atthi brahmā mahābrahmā seṭṭho sajitā”ti diṭṭhiyā paṭisedho
analyzed: purima padena ca ittha atthi brahmā mahābrahmā seṭṭhaḥ sajitā ati diṭṭhiyā paṭisedho
translated: The first line rejects the view that there is a Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Supreme One, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker, the Embodiment of Virtue, the Ordainer, the Father of the Created World.

original: veditabbo. Kammunā hi tāsu tāsu gatīsu vattati loko, tassa ko sajitāti. Dutiyapadena🔽“evaṃ kammunā nibbattopi ca pavattepi atītapaccuppannabhedena kammunā vattati, sukhadukkhāni
analyzed: veditabbaḥ kammunā hi tāsu tāsu gatīsu vattati loko tassa kaḥ dutiya padena  evam kammunā nibbattaḥ api ca pavatte api atīta paccuppanna bhedena kammunā vattati sukha dukkhāni
translated: For the world goes on revolving in these and those states by kamma. Who is the controller of that?🔽The second line shows that even though he is born by kamma, he goes on revolving by kamma classed as past and present, experiencing pleasure and pain and attaining to states that are inferior and so on.

original: paccanubhonto hīnapaṇītādibhedañca āpajjanto pavattatī”ti dasseti. Tatiyena tamevatthaṃ🔽nigameti “evaṃ sabbathāpi kammanibandhanā sattā kammeneva baddhā hutvā pavattanti,🔽na aññathā”ti. Catutthena tametthaṃ upamāya vibhāveti. Yathā hi rathassa yāyato āṇi🔽nibandhanaṃ hoti, na tāya anibaddho yāti, evaṃ lokassa nibbattato ca pavattato ca
analyzed: paccanubhontaḥ hīna paṇīta ādi bhedañca āpajjantaḥ pavattati iti dasseti tatiyena tam eva attham  nigame ti evam sabbathā api kamma nibandhanā sattā kammena iva baddhā hutvā pavattanti  na aññathā ati catutthena tam ettham upamāya vibhāveti yathā hi rathassa  nibandhanam hoti na tāya a nibaddhaḥ yāti evam lokassa nibbattataḥ ca pavattataḥ ca
translated: The third line confirms that meaning.

original: kammaṃ nibandhanaṃ, na tena anibaddho nibbattati na pavattati.
analyzed: kammam nibandhanam na tena anibaddhaḥ nibbattati na pavattati
translated: The fourth line illustrates that meaning by a simile. For just as the movement of a chariot is dependent on the axle, and it does not move without it being fastened to the axle, so too the rebirth of the world and its going on revolving are dependent on kamma, and it does not happen that it is reborn or goes on revolving without being fastened to kamma.

original: Idāni yasmā evaṃ kammanibandhano loko, tasmā seṭṭhena kammunā seṭṭhabhāvaṃ dassento
analyzed: idāni yasmai evam kamma nibandhanaḥ loko tasmai seṭṭhena kammunā seṭṭha bhāvam dassento
translated: Now, since the world is thus bound by kamma, the Exalted One, in order to show that the best state is attained by the best kamma,

original: tapenāti gāthādvayamāha. Tattha tapenāti dhutaṅgatapena. Brahmacariyenāti methunaviratiyā.🔽Saṃyamenāti sīlena. Damenāti indriyadamena. Etenāti etena seṭṭhena parisuddhena brahmabhūtena
analyzed: tapena iti gāthā dvayam āha tattha tapena ati dhutaṅga tapena brahmacariyena ati methuna viratiyā  saṃyamena ati sīlena damena ati indriya damena etena ati etena seṭṭhena parisuddhena brahma bhūtena
translated: said the two verses beginning with “By austerity.” Herein, by austerity means by the austerity of the ascetic practices. By chastity means by abstinence from sexual intercourse.

original: kammunā brāhmaṇo hoti. Kasmā? Yasmā etaṃ brāhmaṇamuttamaṃ, yasmā etaṃ kammaṃ uttamo🔽brāhmaṇaguṇoti vuttaṃ hoti. “Brahmāna”ntipi pāṭho. Ayaṃ panettha vacanattho – brahmaṃ
analyzed: kammunā brāhmaṇaḥ hoti kasmai yasmai etam brāhmaṇam uttamam yasmai etam kammam uttamaḥ  brāhmaṇa guṇo ti vuttam hoti pāṭhaḥ ayam pana ittha vacana tthaḥ
translated: By self-control means by virtue. By restraint means by restraint of the sense faculties. By this means, by this best, most purified, most sublime kamma, one becomes a brahmin. Why? Because this is the highest brahminhood, because this kamma is the highest brahmin quality.

original: ānetīti brahmānaṃ, brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ āvahatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: āneti iti brahmānam brāhmaṇa bhāvam āvahati iti vuttam hoti
translated: The reading “brahmāna” is also found. But the meaning of the word is this: it brings , thus it is brahma ; it causes to come , thus it is brahma ; it causes to attain the state of a brahmin, is what is meant.

original: Dutiyagāthāya santoti santakileso. Brahmā sakkoti brahmā ca sakko ca, yo evarūpo,
analyzed: dutiya gāthāya santaḥ iti santa kilesaḥ brahmā sakko ti brahmā ca sakko ca yaḥ evarūpaḥ
translated: In the second verse, the word santo means one who has destroyed defilements. Brahma and Sakka are Brahma and Sakka. One who is such,

original: so na kevalaṃ brāhmaṇo, atha kho brahmā ca sakko ca so vijānataṃ paṇḍitānaṃ, evaṃ
analyzed: saḥ na kevalam brāhmaṇaḥ atha khalu brahmā ca sakkaḥ ca saḥ vijānatam paṇḍitānam evam
translated: is not only a brahmin, but also Brahma and Sakka. He is known to the wise,

original: vāseṭṭha, jānāhīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: vāseṭṭha jānāhi iti vuttam hoti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: “You should know, Vasettha” means “You should understand, Vasettha”. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Papañcasūdaniyā majjhimanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyā majjhima nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya, called “The Food of the Wise”,

original: Vāseṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vāseṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 9. Subhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: subha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Subha Sutta

original: 462. Evaṃ me sutanti subhasuttaṃ. Tattha todeyyaputtoti tudigāmavāsino todeyyabrāhmaṇassa
analyzed: evam me sutanti subha suttam tattha todeyya putto ti tudi gāma vāsinaḥ todeyya brāhmaṇassa
translated: Thus I heard. The Subha sutta . Herein, Todeyyaputta is the son of the brahmin Todeyya who lived in the village of Tudu.

original: putto. Ārādhako hotīti sampādako hoti paripūrako. Ñāyaṃ dhammanti kāraṇadhammaṃ.
analyzed: puttaḥ ārādhakaḥ hoti iti sampādakaḥ hoti paripūrakaḥ ñāyam dhamman ti kāraṇa dhammam
translated: He is a fulfiller, a completer. The way, the truth : the cause, the Dhamma.

original: Kusalanti anavajjaṃ.
analyzed: kusalanti anavajjam
translated: Skilful : blameless.

original: 463. Micchāpaṭipattinti aniyyānikaṃ akusalapaṭipadaṃ. Sammāpaṭipattinti niyyānikaṃ kusalapaṭipadaṃ.🔽Mahaṭṭhantiādīsu mahantehi veyyāvaccakarehi vā upakaraṇehi vā bahūhi attho etthāti🔽mahaṭṭhaṃ. Mahantāni nāmaggahaṇamaṅgalādīni kiccāni etthāti mahākiccaṃ. Idaṃ ajja
analyzed: micchā paṭipattinti aniyyānikam akusala paṭipadam sammā paṭipattinti niyyānikam kusala paṭipadam  mahaṭṭha nti ādīsu mahantehi veyyāvacca karehi vā upakaraṇehi vā bahūhi atthaḥ ettha ati  mahaṭṭham mahantāni nāma ggahaṇa maṅgala ādīni kiccāni ettha ati mahā kiccam idam ajja
translated: Wrong practice : unbeneficial, unskilful practice. Right practice : beneficial, skilful practice.🔽In the words great-gain, great-effort, great-work, great-cause, great-gain is so called because of the great gains of requisites or of the great effort in the service of the brahmin.

original: kattabbaṃ, idaṃ sveti evaṃ mahantāni adhikārasaṅkhātāni adhikaraṇāni etthāti mahādhikaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: kattabbam idam sva iti evam mahantāni adhikāra saṅkhātāni adhikaraṇāni ettha ati mahādhikaraṇam
translated: Great-work is so called because of the great works, such as the naming ceremony, the ceremony of taking the first food, etc. Great-cause is so called because of the great causes, called “business,” thus: “This should be done today, this tomorrow.”

original: Bahūnaṃ kamme yuttappayuttatāvasena pīḷāsaṅkhāto mahāsamārambho etthāti mahāsamārambhaṃ.
analyzed: bahūnam kamme yutta ppayutta tā vasena pīḷā saṅkhātaḥ mahā samārambhaḥ ettha ati mahā samārambham
translated: It is a great undertaking in the sense of being a great affliction, since it involves many people in work and in the various tasks connected with it: thus it is “a great undertaking.”

original: Gharāvāsakammaṭṭhānanti gharāvāsakammaṃ. Evaṃ sabbavāresu attho veditabbo. Kasikamme
analyzed: ghara āvāsa kammaṭṭhānan ti ghara āvāsa kammam evam sabba vāresu atthaḥ veditabbo kasi kamme
translated: “Householder’s duties” : the duties of a householder. The meaning should be understood in all instances in the same way.

original: cettha naṅgalakoṭiṃ ādiṃ katvā upakaraṇānaṃ pariyesanavasena mahaṭṭhatā, vaṇijjāya
analyzed: naṅgala koṭim ādim katvā upakaraṇānam pariyesana vasena mahā aṭṭha tā vaṇijjāya
translated: Herein, the “ploughman’s work” is a great undertaking because of the great effort involved in seeking the requisites, beginning with the ploughshare tip.

original: yathāṭhitaṃyeva bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā parivattanavasena appaṭṭhatā veditabbā. Vipajjamānanti🔽avuṭṭhiativuṭṭhiādīhi kasikammaṃ, maṇisuvaṇṇādīsu acchekatādīhi ca vaṇijjakammaṃ
analyzed: yathā ṭhitam yeva bhaṇḍam gahetvā parivattana vasena appaṭṭha tā veditabbā vipajjamāna nti  avuṭṭhi ativuṭṭhi ādīhi kasi kammam maṇi suvaṇṇa ādīsu accheka tā ādīhi ca vaṇijja kammam
translated: The “mercantile work” is not a great undertaking because of the small effort involved in seeking the requisites, since one can make a living by merely taking up what is already there.🔽“Failing” :🔽the ploughman’s work fails to yield much fruit and can even lead to the loss of one’s capital through such causes as the ploughman’s not getting up early in the morning, or through the breaking of the ploughshare tip, etc.

original: appaphalaṃ hoti, mūlacchedampi pāpuṇāti. Vipariyāyena sampajjamānaṃ mahapphalaṃ cūḷantevāsikassa viya.
analyzed: appa phalam hoti mūla chedam pi pāpuṇāti vipariyāyena sampajjamānam mahapphalam cūḷa antevāsikassa viya
translated: The mercantile work fails to yield much fruit and can even lead to the loss of one’s capital through such causes as the merchant’s being cheated by dishonest scales, etc., or through the loss of his goods by fire, etc.🔽“Succeeding” : when the opposite of the above is the case, it yields much fruit.

original: 464. Evameva khoti yathā kasikammaṭṭhānaṃ vipajjamānaṃ appaphalaṃ hoti, evaṃ gharāvāsakammaṭṭhānampi.
analyzed: evam eva kho ti yathā kasi kammaṭṭhānam vipajjamānam appa phalam hoti evam ghara āvāsa kammaṭṭhānam pi
translated: “So too, the householder’s duties” : just as the ploughman’s work fails to yield much fruit when it fails, so too the householder’s duties.

original: Akatakalyāṇo hi kālaṃ katvā niraye nibbattati. Mahādattasenāpati nāma kireko brāhmaṇabhatto
analyzed: a kata kalyāṇaḥ hi kālam katvā niraye nibbattati mahādatta senāpati nāma kira ikaḥ brāhmaṇabhatto
translated: For one who has not done good dies and is reborn in hell. A certain general called Mahādattathat is said to have been a devotee of the brahmins.

original: ahosi, tassa maraṇasamaye nirayo upaṭṭhāsi. So brāhmaṇehi “kiṃ passasī”ti vutto?
analyzed: ahosi tassa maraṇa samaye nirayaḥ upaṭṭhāsi saḥ brāhmaṇehi kim passasi iti vutto
translated: When he was dying, hell appeared to him. When the brahmins asked him, “What do you see?,”

analyzed: āha brahmalokaḥ bho brahmalokaḥ nāma bho upari iti
translated: he said, “A red tent.” “Sir, that is the brahmā world.” “Sir, what is this brahmā world?” “Above.”

original: heṭṭhā upaṭṭhātīti. Kiñcāpi heṭṭhā upaṭṭhāti, tathāpi uparīti kālaṃ katvā niraye🔽nibbatto. “Iminā amhākaṃ yaññe doso dinno”ti sahassaṃ gahetvā nīharituṃ adaṃsu. Sampajjamānaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā upaṭṭhāti iti kiñcā api heṭṭhā upaṭṭhāti tathā api upari iti kālam katvā niraye  nibbattaḥ iminā amhākam yaññe doso dinno ti sahassam gahetvā nīharitum adaṃsu sampajjamānam
translated: “It is appearing below me.” “Though it is appearing below, still it is above.” After he died he was reborn in hell.🔽They took a thousand from him and expelled him, saying, “You have brought misfortune to our sacrifice.” But when it is successful, it is very fruitful.

original: pana mahapphalaṃ hoti. Katakalyāṇo hi kālaṃ katvā sagge nibbattati. Sakalāya guttilavimānakathāya🔽dīpetabbaṃ. Yathā pana taṃ vaṇijjakammaṭṭhānaṃ vipajjamānaṃ appaphalaṃ hoti, evaṃ
analyzed: pana mahapphalam hoti kata kalyāṇaḥ hi kālam katvā sagge nibbattati sakalāya guttila vimāna kathāya  dīpetabbam yathā pana tat vaṇijja kammaṭṭhānam vipajjamānam appa phalam hoti evam
translated: For one who has done good dies and is reborn in heaven. The whole story of the Guttivimāna should be told here.🔽But just as that place of trade is unprofitable when it fails,🔽so too the ascetic practice of going forth is unprofitable for one who is not fulfilled in virtue and who is engaged in wrong livelihood.

original: sīlesu aparipūrakārino anesanāya yuttassa pabbajjākammaṭṭhānampi. Evarūpā hi neva
analyzed: sīlesu a paripūra kārinaḥ anesanāya yuttassa pabbajjā kammaṭṭhānam pi evarūpā hi na iva
translated: For such a one,

analyzed: jhāna ādi sukham na saggamokkham labhati sampajjamānam pana mahapphalam hoti sīlāni
translated: but the happiness of jhāna, etc., is not the bliss of heaven or of liberation. But it is successful and has great fruit.

Brāhmaṇā vadanti – “pabbajito🔽ime pañca dhamme pūretuṃ samattho nāma natthi, gahaṭṭhova pūretī”ti. Samaṇo pana🔽gotamo – “gihissa vā ahaṃ māṇava pabbajitassa vā”ti punappunaṃ vadati, neva pabbajitaṃ
analyzed: hi pūretvā vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ arahattam pi pāpuṇāti  brāhmaṇāḥ bho gotama uti idha kim pucchāmi iti pucchati brāhmaṇāḥ vadanti pabbajitaḥ  ime pañca dhamme pūretum samatthaḥ nāma natthi gaha ṭṭhaḥ uva pūreti iti samaṇaḥ pana  gotamaḥ gihissa vai aham māṇava pabbajitassa vā ati punappunam vadati na iva pabbajitam
translated: but the happiness of jhana, etc., is not the happiness of heaven or of emancipation. But it is successful and has great fruit. For by fulfilling the precepts and developing insight one reaches Arahantship.

original: muñcati, mayhameva pucchaṃ maññe na sallakkhetīti cāgasīsena pañca dhamme pucchāmīti🔽pucchati. Sace te agarūti sace tuyhaṃ yathā brāhmaṇā paññapenti, tathā idha bhāsituṃ
analyzed: muñcati mayham eva puccham maññe na sallakkheti iti ca āgasīsena pañca dhamme pucchāmi iti  pucchati sace te sace tuyham yathā brāhmaṇā paññapenti tathā idha bhāsitum
translated: “What do I ask? ” He asks, “What do I ask here? ” The brahmans say, “No one who has gone forth is able to fulfil these five things; only one who remains a layman can fulfil them. ” But the recluse Gotama again and again says, “Whether a man is a layman or one gone forth, … ” He does not let the one gone forth go, and he does not seem to consider my question. So I ask him the five things by way of generosity.

analyzed: akkhare akkhare dosam eva vadanti ekanta paṇḍitā pana katham sutvā su kathitam pasaṃsanti  dukkathite pāḷi pada attha byañjanesu yam yam virujjhati tam tam ujum katvā denti  bhagavatā ca sadisaḥ ekantapaṇḍitaḥ nāma natthi tena āha na kho me bho gotama garu

analyzed: methuna viratim ajjhenanti manta gahaṇam cāganti āmisa pariccāgam  pāpitaḥ bhavissati iti a jānana bhāvam pāpitaḥ bhavissati etat avoca ati bhagavatā
translated: “The holy life” : abstinence from sexual activity. “The recitation of mantras” : the learning of spells. “Giving” : the giving of material things.

analyzed: andha veṇu upamāya niggahitaḥ tam paccāharitum a sakkontaḥ yathā nāma dubbala su nakhaḥ migam
translated: “He will be condemned” : he will be condemned for his ignorance. “He said this” : having been checked by the Blessed One with the simile of the blind turtle, unable to reply, just as a weak lion cub unable to drag a large carcass

analyzed: evam brāhmaṇa uti ādi vacanam avoca tattha pokkharasātī iti idam tassa nāmam pokkharasāyī iti pi  vuccati tassa kira kāyaḥ seta pokkhara sadisaḥ devanagare ussāpita rajata toraṇam viya  sobhati sīsam panassa kāḷa vaṇṇa ainda nīla mayam viya canda maṇḍale kāḷa megha rāji

translated: pure like a silver tube,

analyzed: hattha pāda talāni ca iva mukham ca ka tala ākhā rasa parikammam viya sobhati ati viya sobhagga ppatto  brāhmaṇassa atta bhāvaḥ arājake ṭhāne rājānam kātum yuttam imam brāhmaṇam evam esa
translated: and the palms of his hands and feet and his face shine like a polished mirror. His brahmin form is extremely

original: sassiriko, iti naṃ pokkharasadisattā “pokkharasātī”ti sañjānanti, pokkhare pana so
analyzed: iti nam pokkhara sadisa ttā pokkhara sātī iti sañjānanti pokkhare pana so
translated: beautiful. He is fit to be a king in a country without a king. Thus he is a lord. They call him Pokkharasāti because he🔽is like a lotus, but he is not a lotus.

original: nibbatto, na mātukucchiyanti iti naṃ pokkhare sayitattā “pokkharasāyī”tipi sañjānanti.🔽Opamaññoti upamaññagotto. Subhagavanikoti ukkaṭṭhāya subhagavanassa issaro. Hassakaṃyevāti
analyzed: nibbattaḥ na mātukucchiyanti iti nam pokkhare sayitattā pokkharasāyī itipi sañjānanti  opamañño ti upamañña gotto subhagavaniko ti ukkaṭṭhāya subhagavanassa issaraḥ
translated: He was born not in a mother’s womb but in a lotus, and so they called him “Lotus-born” because he lay in a lotus.🔽Upamañña was his clan name. Subhagavanika was the name of his village. Hassakaṃyeva means “only to be laughed at.” Nāmakaṃyeva means “only to be despised.” That is empty because it has no meaning.

original: hasitabbakaññeva. Nāmakaṃyevāti lāmakaṃyeva. Tadeva taṃ atthābhāvena rittakaṃ. Rittakattā
analyzed: hasitabbakaññeva nāmakaṃya iva ati lāmakaṃya iva tat eva tam attha abhāvena rittakam rittaka ttā
translated: Because it is empty, it is hollow.

original: ca tucchakaṃ. Idāni naṃ bhagavā sācariyakaṃ niggaṇhituṃ kiṃ pana māṇavātiādimāha.

translated: Now the Blessed One said, “But, student, what is best among these?” in order to refute his teacher’s doctrine.

translated: Herein, what is best among these? What speech is best, most praiseworthy?

original: sammutiyā lokavohārena. Mantāti tulayitvā pariggaṇhitvā. Paṭisaṅkhāyāti jānitvā.🔽Atthasaṃhitanti kāraṇanissitaṃ. Evaṃ santeti lokavohāraṃ amuñcitvā tulayitvā jānitvā
analyzed: sammutiyā lokavohārena mantā ati tulayitvā pariggaṇhitvā paṭisaṅkhāya ati jānitvā  attha saṃhitam ti kāraṇa nissitam evam santā iti lokavohāram a muñcitvā tulayitvā jānitvā
translated: By common consent: by common consent, by general agreement. By reasoning: by weighing, by investigating. By reflection: by knowing.🔽In accordance with what is right: based on a reason. If it is so: if it is so that it is best when it is spoken of after rejecting worldly usage, after weighing, after knowing,

original: kāraṇanissitaṃ katvā kathitāya seyyabhāve sati. Āvutoti āvarito. Nivutoti nivārito.
analyzed: kāraṇa nissitam katvā kathitāya seyya bhāve sati āvuto ti āvaritaḥ nivuto ti nivāritaḥ

analyzed: dhūma chārikā ādīnam abhāvena saḥ assa aggi accimā ca vaṇṇimā ca pabhassaro  ca ati tathūpamā aham māṇava ati tad paṭibhāgam aham idam vuttam hoti yathā iva hi tiṇa kaṭṭhupādānam  paṭicca jalamānaḥ aggi dhūma chārika aṅgārānam atthitāya sa dosaḥ hoti evam evam pañca
translated: “It would be smoky and soiling” means that it would be smoky and soiling because of the presence of smoke, soot, and embers.

original: kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppannā pīti jātijarābyādhimaraṇasokādīnaṃ atthitāya sadosā. Yathā🔽pana pariccattatiṇakaṭṭhupādāno dhūmādīnaṃ abhāvena parisuddho, evamevaṃ lokuttarajjhānadvayasampayuttā
analyzed: kāma guṇe paṭicca uppannā pīti jāti jarā byādhi maraṇa soka ādīnam atthitāya sa dosā yathā  pana dhūma ādīnam abhāvena parisuddhaḥ evam evam lokuttara jhāna dvaya sampayuttā
translated: “So too, student, I say that delight is smoky and soiling” means that just as the fire burning with the supply of grass and sticks is faulty because of the presence of smoke, soot, and embers, so too the delight arisen with the five cords of sense desire is faulty because of the presence of birth, aging, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and despair.

original: pīti jātiādīnaṃ abhāvena parisuddhāti attho.
analyzed: pi iti jāti ādīnam abhāvena parisuddhā iti attho
translated: But just as the fire burning with the supply of grass and sticks is purified when the smoke, etc., are absent, so too the delight associated with the two supramundane jhānas is purified because of the absence of birth, etc. This is the meaning.

translated: Now, as for the five ideas that the brahmans have laid down as the chief things, they are not five

analyzed: dassetum ye te māṇava ti ādim āha tattha anukampā jātikam ti anukampā sabhāvam  kattha bahulam samanupassasi iti idam bhagavā yasmai esaḥ ime pañca dhamme pabbajitaḥ  paripūretum samatthaḥ nāma na atthi gahaṭṭhaḥ paripūreti iti āha tasmai pabbajitaḥ iva
translated: but six, since they do not stand still but go on to sympathy. So in order to show that fault he said ‘ But where do you see a brahmin who is born of Brahma’s mouth … ‘ . Herein, born of sympathy is born of the nature of sympathy.

analyzed: ime pūreti gahaṭṭhaḥ pūretum samatthaḥ nāma natthi iti tena iva mukhena pucchati  na satatam samitam sacca vādi iti ādīsu gahaṭṭhaḥ aññasmin asati
translated: Where do you see that? This is said by the Blessed One because ‘ there is no one gone forth who can fulfil these five ideas, it is only a householder who can fulfil them ‘ . translated: The monk is virtuous for life. The layman cannot keep the scriptures written in a book, even the Jewel Sutta and the Auspicious Sutta.

analyzed: nu kho maggaḥ ayam na nu kho ti kaṅkhā vasena cirāyitattam vitthāyitattam ti yathā  sukhumam attha jātam sahasā pucchitassa kassaci sarīram thaddha bhāvam gaṇhāti evam

analyzed: pamāṇam atikkamitvā odhisaka anodhisaka disā pharaṇa vasena vaḍḍhetvā kata ttā appamāṇa kata nti

original: vuccati. Na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhatīti taṃ kāmāvacarakammaṃ tasmiṃ🔽rūpārūpāvacarakamme na ohīyati na tiṭṭhati. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? analyzed: vuccati na tam tatra avasissati na tam tatra avatiṭṭhati iti tam kāma avacara kammam tasmin  rūpa arūpa avacara kamme na ohīyati na tiṭṭhati kim vuttam hoti kāma avacara kammam tassa  rūpa arūpa avacara kammassa antarā laggitum vā ṭhātum vā rūpa arūpa avacara kammam pharitvā  pariyādiyitvā attanaḥ okāsam gahetvā patiṭṭhātum vā na sakkoti atha kho rūpa arūpa avacara kammam eva
translated: is said. It does not remain there, it does not stand there: that kamma of the sense-sphere does not remain, does not stand, in that kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. What is said? Kamma of the sense-sphere cannot remain, stand, in the middle of that kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres, and having taken the place of that kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres, it cannot stand having spread out and pervaded. But kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres

original: kāmāvacaraṃ mahogho viya parittaudakaṃ pharitvā pariyādiyitvā attano okāsaṃ gahetvā🔽tiṭṭhati, tassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā sayameva brahmasahabyataṃ upanetīti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: kāmāvacaram mahā oghaḥ viya paritta odakam pharitvā attanaḥ okāsam gahetvā  tiṭṭhati tassa vipākam paṭibāhitvā sayam eva brahma sahabyatam upaneti iti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: is said. It does not remain there, it does not stay there: that kamma of the sense sphere does not remain, does not stay, in that kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. What is meant? Kamma of the sense sphere cannot remain or stay in the way of obstructing or hindering kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres, or of displacing it and taking its place, after it has spread out and pervaded that kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. On the contrary, kamma of the fine-material and immaterial spheres remains after it has displaced and taken the place of kamma of the sense sphere, just as a great flood of water displaces and takes the place of a small amount of water. It prevents the result of the kamma of the sense sphere and leads to rebirth in the company of the Brahmās. The rest is clear in all its aspects.🔽The commentary on the Subha Sutta in the Majjhima Nikāya,
